title: ACCT 462 Detecting Fraudulent Financial Reporting
description: Understanding/identifying methods of fraudulent financial reporting, and signals that financial statements were fictitiously prepared; major frameworks for analyzing ethical dilemmas; reforms in corporate reporting environment.

title: COLT 565 Studies in Literatures of Asia
description: Study of major cultural paradigms and their divergent influences in the literatures of China, Japan, Korea, and Southeast Asia.

title: COMM 456 Entertainment, Marketing and Culture
description: Explores blurring of entertainment, marketing and culture in advanced information economies; intersections of culture and media and their social ramifications.

title: COMM 455 Advertising and Society
description: Examination of the role of advertising in contemporary society as an economic force and a cultural form of representation.

title: CHE 205 Numerical Methods in Chemical Engineering
description: Computational tools for solving numerical problems in Chemical Engineering.

title: CHEM 205Lgx Chemical Forensics: The Science, and Its Impact
description: Scientific principles underlying forensic approaches to the investigation of crimes and its societal impact on law, culture and media.

title: CE 464 Geotechnical Engineering
description: Fundamentals of soil mechanics and foundation engineering; soil classification, seepage, stress-strain behavior, shear strength, consolidation, design of retaining structures and foundations, and slope stability.

title: CE 463L Water Chemistry and Analysis
description: Chemistry of water purification technology and water pollution control. Chemical processes in natural and engineering aquatic environments; physical/chemical and biological characterization of water and wastewater.

title: BUAD 495 Practicum in Business Issues (Internship)
description: Combined classroom discussion and structured, supervised field application of business theories and practices within a part-time employment context.

title: ART 434 Sound Art
description: A survey of developments in non-traditional musical instrument making in clay including design, fabrication and composition, culminating in a musical performance.

title: ART 430 Topics in Advanced Ceramics
description: Continued directed examination of aesthetic concepts and investigation into personal ideas as they relate to the development of a creative visual language in ceramics.

title: ART 419 Professional Internship in the Arts
description: An experiential/academic opportunity in a museum, gallery, community cultural center, or related facility. Lectures, seminars, written analysis, and working internship.

title: ART 418 Independent Studies in Studio Arts
description: Independent research of specific topics under the direction of a faculty member. Administrative and faculty approval required.

title: ART 420 Topics in Advanced Painting
description: Directed painting with continued emphasis on personal choices regarding appropriation of conceptual images and arrangement, material processes, scale, number of paintings. Ongoing critical response to painting.

title: BUAD 497 Strategic Management
description: Examination of managerial decision-making, planning, and policy under changing environments; readings, cases, exercises, simulations.

title: ART 410 Topics in Advanced Drawing
description: Continued directed examination of personal approaches in drawing, emphasis on making visual and artistic decisions and developing an appropriate attitude toward visual expression.

title: BISC 102Lgx Humans and Their Environment
description: An examination of the physical and biological laws that influence agriculture, pollution, population dynamics (including humans), climate, biodiversity and ecosystem structure and function.

title: BISC 577a Computational Molecular Biology Laboratory
description: Practical experience in computational molecular biology applications. Mathematical and statistical software packages relevant to genomic analysis. Retrieval and analysis of genomic data from databases.

title: BKN 567 Advanced Topics in Biomechanics
description: Advanced examination of motion-analysis techniques, applications and data interpretation. Magnetic tracking techniques, upper-extremity kinematics, energy/work/impulse concepts, intersegmental dynamics, and EMG muscle modeling are examined.

title: BPMK 510 Capstone I: Biopharmaceutical Management Project
description: Program directed basic research and topics to develop student core skills surrounding research design, execution, planning, presentation and defense, consistent with BP industry standards.

title: BKN 611L Technology in Sport: Physiological Assessments
description: Introduction to the physiological assessment of athlete performance. Focus on understanding, performing and interpreting physiological assessments such as metabolic testing (VO2max), hydration, oxygen saturation, body composition, lactate threshold, heart rate, core body temperature.

title: CLAS 461 Topics in Ancient Iranian Languages and Cultures
description: Studies and readings in one or more pre-modern Iranian languages and their cultural and historical contexts. Specific topics vary; may be repeated for credit.

title: CJ 550 Corrections and Community Supervision
description: Examines evidence-based corrections and community supervision practices including offender rehabilitation, bail, restorative justice and victims' issues.

title: CJ 555 Making a Difference in Criminal Justice
description: Preparing for the critical role of leadership through policy evaluation and policy change initiatives.

title: CJ 545 Criminal Investigations
description: Explores criminal investigative techniques such as search and seizure, use of technology, and multi-jurisdictional and transnational crime investigations.

title: BME 210 Biomedical Computer Simulation Methods
description: Computational methods for simulation of circulatory, respiratory, pharmacokinetic, and neural models. Quadrature, differential equations, systems of linear equations, simulation languages, experimental statistics.

title: CJ 540 Criminal Justice Policy and Program Development
description: In-depth analysis of all major stages of the criminal justice policymaking process.

title: CJ 535 Youthful Offenders
description: Key concepts and evidence-based interventions and responses to promote positive growth and reduced recidivism in the youthful offender population.

title: CJ 530 Organizational Change in Criminal Justice
description: Knowledge, skills, and tools necessary to lead organizational change within the context of criminal justice systems.

title: CJ 525 Ethical Decision-Making in Criminal Justice
description: Examination and analysis of how societal expectations for ethical behavior and regulatory oversight affect leaders and managers in criminal justice.

title: CJ 520 Applied Statistics and Data Analysis in Criminal Justice
description: Fundamentals of statistics and statistical analyses commonly used to interpret crime data for evaluation and performance.

title: CJ 515 Applied Research Methods for Criminal Justice
description: Fundamental research methods and design commonly used to answer questions related to criminal justice.

title: CJ 510 Criminal Justice Leadership
description: Theory and practice of traditional and contemporary approaches to leadership in the context of criminal justice.

title: CJ 505 Analysis of Criminal Justice Systems
description: The criminal justice system's response to crime through a theoretical and interdisciplinary lens.

title: CJ 500 Criminology
description: Key theories and frameworks used to explain crime and inform responses to crime.

title: WRIT 540 Writing for Master's Students
description: Instruction to prepare Master's students for writing in academic and professional contexts.

title: WRIT 501a Theory and Practice in Teaching Expository Writing
description: Pedagogical application of rhetorical and linguistic theory to teaching university-level expository writing. Accompanies supervised teaching. Limited to assistant lecturers and teaching assistants.

title: WRIT 499 Special Topics
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: WRIT 501b Theory and Practice in Teaching Expository Writing
description: Pedagogical application of rhetorical and linguistic theory to teaching university-level expository writing. Accompanies supervised teaching. Limited to assistant lecturers and teaching assistants.

title: WRIT 450 Advanced Research Writing
description: Instruction in writing and research techniques in support of a capstone undergraduate research thesis in the humanities, social sciences, or sciences

title: WRIT 440 Writing in Practical Contexts
description: Advanced training in analytical and argumentative writing for particular purposes, in professional and practical contexts.

title: WRIT 133 College Writing for International Students
description: College writing for International Students, emphasizing the expectations of academic discourse in U.S. higher education while drawing upon a context informed by cross-cultural perspectives.

title: WRIT 340 Advanced Writing
description: Instruction in writing for various audiences on topics related to a student's professional or disciplinary interests, with some emphasis on issues of broad public concern.

title: WRIT 130 Analytical Writing
description: Focuses on analytical and argumentative writing skills requisite to academic and professional writing. Emphasizes logical analysis of texts and other data, effective use of evidence, ethical argumentation, and stylistic and grammatical fluency. Enrollment limited to specified groups of students. Students must achieve a satisfactory score on the verbal portion of the SAT, the USC Writing Examination, or credit for

title: WRIT 121 Introduction to College Writing in a Second Language
description: Intensive instruction and practice in the writing process for non-native speakers of English. Focuses on the formal and conceptual conventions of college writing, with emphasis upon the grammatical, stylistic, and rhetorical techniques required in successful writing. Limited to and required of students who score below specified level on the USC Writing Examination.

title: WRIT 120 Introduction to College Writing
description: Intensive instruction and practice in the writing process. Focuses upon the formal conventions and conceptual expectations of college writing, with emphasis upon the grammatical, stylistic, and rhetorical techniques required in successful writing. Limited to and required of students who score below specified level on the USC Writing Examination.

title: VISS 599 Special Topics
description: Focuses on a comparative investigation of ways in which people in the past used images to make history by recording current events and subsequently use them to create narratives about the past.

title: VISS 501 Introduction to Visual Studies:  Methods and Debates
description: A critical introduction to the field of visual studies focusing on interdisciplinary approaches to images, objects, and visual technologies as well as key texts and interpretive debates.

title: USC 250 The Academic Culture
description: Study the meaning of culture in society, experience the culture of learning on campus, and examine the relationship between the two. Topics will vary.

title: WRIT 095x Writing Tutorial
description: Individualized instruction in writing to support instruction in

title: USC 101 Honors Research Apprenticeship
description: Students work directly with faculty on faculty research projects, gain experience in the process of research and thereby contribute to new scholarship.

title: TRGN 599 Special Topics
description: Selected topics in Translational Genomics.

title: TRGN 590 Directed Research
description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

title: TRGN 543 Biotechnology Entrepreneurship and Commercialization I
description: Global biotechnology industry, idea generation, business plan formulation, intellectual property protection, funding, personnel management including board composition, regulatory body interaction, company exits.

title: TRGN 544 Biotechnology Entrepreneurship and Commercialization II
description: Advanced discussion: global biotechnology industry, idea generation, business plan formulation, intellectual property protection, funding, personnel management including board composition, regulatory body interaction, company exits.

title: TRGN 545 Exploring Chemical and Biological Therapeutic Modalities
description: Turning molecules into drugs and cells into therapeutics. Emphasizing selection, development, and optimization of appropriate modalities to target specific key defects in diseases.

title: TRGN 540 Translational Biotechnology Capstone Preparation
description: Duplicates Credit in former MEDS 540

title: TRGN 542 Biotechnology-based Therapeutics
description: Covers advanced biotechnology principles and applications.

title: TRGN 539 Translational Biotechnology Practicum
description: Experiential training based on a project in a biomedical, biotechnology or pharmaceutical setting.

title: TRGN 541 Translational Biotechnology Capstone Defense
description: Duplicates Credit in former MEDS 541

title: TRGN 538 Seminar in Translational Biotechnology
description: Two semesters of Introductory Biology plus two semesters of Molecular Biology, Genetics, or Cell Bio

title: TRGN 537 Pathway and Target Discovery
description: Two semesters of Introductory Biology plus two semesters of Molecular Biology, Genetics, or Cell Bio

title: TRGN 536 Biotechnology Primer
description: Examination of classical and novel techniques used to explore and manipulate gene function and implications for the use of biotechnology in areas of global need. Recommended preparation: two semesters of introductory biology; two semesters of molecular biology and genetics.

title: TRGN 526 Clinical Bioinformatics in Genomic Testing
description: Covers basic understandings of clinical bioinformatics methodologies and practices, along with the genomic technologies used for clinical diagnostic purposes.

title: TRGN 525 Applications of Genomic Technology in Biomedical Research II
description: Molecular biotechnology, genomics, next-generation sequencing, epigenomics, drug discovery, biomarkers, microarrays, analytical validation, pipelines, molecular analysis, cloning, stem cells.

title: TRGN 524 Applications of Genomic Technology in Biomedical Research I
description: Molecular biotechnology, genomics, next-generation sequencing, epigenomics, drug discovery, biomarkers, microrarrays, commercialization, microarray analysis, expression, proteomics.

title: TRGN 520 Translational Biomedical Informatics Capstone Portfolio
description: Portfolio, translational biomedical informatics, bioinformatics, genomics, application development, web-based application.

title: ARCH 596 Building Science Thesis Preparation
description: Exploration of topics leading to the development of a thesis prospectus. Topics may be in the areas of building structures, seismic design, environmental control, passive and active energy, or other relevant topics.

title: ARCH 590 Directed Research
description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

title: TRGN 516 Translational Genomics, Applied Databases and Datastructures
description: Genomics, bioinformatics resources, NCBI, portals, databases, datastructures, NoSQL, SQL, big data.

title: ARCH 588 Physical Computing: Linking Architectural Computing with the Physical World
description: While no experience working with electronics is required, basic knowledge and willingness to learn programming and physical prototyping is assumed.

title: ARCH 586 City Cine: Visuality, Media and Urban Experience
description: Explores the relationship between urban experience and visual media (from the photographic, to the filmic, to the digital) from circa 1880 to the present.

title: ARCH 585 Visual Storytelling and Entrepreneurship in Media
description: Investigating visual stories as an active tool to critically explore and express design ideas; positions social media and crowdfunding as a foundation for creative action.

title: ARCH 581 Techniques in Digital Fabrication
description: A practical introduction to digital fabrication. Covered topics include 3D surface milling, thermoforming, materials, casting and shop technology as applied to repeatable surfaces in architecture.

title: ARCH 579 Sustainable Building and Environment using LEED Metrics
description: Fundamental knowledge of sustainable building concepts, current environmental design building rating systems, building performance and diagnostics metrics, as well as reference standards related to sustainable design.

title: ARCH 580L Field Studies
description: Off-campus field studies using direct observation, site recordings/documentation, analysis and evaluation supplemented by discussions and readings.

title: ARCH 576 Sustainable Design for Healthy Indoor Environments
description: Course outlines the building design and its performance diagnostic processes required to assure indoor environmental quality and the building occupants' environmental health, productivity, and physiological comfort.

title: ARCH 577L Lighting Design
description: The physics, technical knowledge, professional knowledge, design, and documentation processes used in architectural lighting design, including first principles, manual calculations and computer simulations.

title: ARCH 575b Systems
description: The fundamental scientific principles governing light and sound in the built environment will be examined in the context of human physiological, psychological and biological needs.

title: ARCH 573 Seismic Design
description: Theory, design methodology and practice of how seismicity affects architecture and structural system selection required for robust earthquake performance and seismic sustainability.

title: ARCH 575a Systems
description: Application of the scientific principles governing the thermal environment and human physiology to contemporary issues of environmentally responsive building energy concepts and systems.

title: ARCH 574 Parametric Design
description: An in depth and critical look into the reasons and uses for parametric design and its relationship to contemporary form, fabrication, and construction of the built environment.

title: ARCH 566 Cross Cultural Topics in Landscape Architecture History
description: Comparative analysis and appreciation of landscape architecture as a manifestation of nature, society, and design. Topics and world regions vary from year to year; may be repeated for credit when subject matter is different.

title: ARCH 564 Descriptive and Computational Architectural Geometry
description: Introduction to the history, methods, and cases of descriptive and computational geometry impacting representational, modeling, and historically significant paradigms of architectural design. Introduces a range of geometric first principles, technologies and techniques through contemporary design tools.

title: ARCH 567L Landscape Architecture Vertical Workshop and Debate Series
description: A dynamic and topical supplement that provides critical content in the form of a post-mid review workshop and series of debates led by distinguished guests.

title: ARCH 563 Contemporary Architectural Theory
description: Investigates, compares, and critiques modern and contemporary theories of the designed and built environment by focusing on key figures, movements, and texts.

title: WRIT 150 Writing and Critical Reasoning–Thematic Approaches
description: Academic writing, emphasizing analysis and argumentation, rhetorical judgment, critical reasoning, creative insight, the careful use of evidence, ethical perspectives, logical organization, stylistic and grammatical fluency.

title: ARCH 565 Global History of Landscape Architecture
description: Understanding of the global history of landscape design in relation to social, political, religious, environmental and aesthetic principles; current design theory, projects and their historical references are critically reviewed and analyzed.

title: ARCH 562 Architecture Themes and Case Studies
description: Architectural themes and case studies focusing on the design and development of architecture, from the industrial city to today.

title: ARCH 561 Urbanism Themes and Case Studies
description: Examines urbanism through case studies in theory and design to understand the impacts of globalization, technology, and sustainability on the contemporary city.

title: BME 413 Bioengineering Signals and Systems
description: Introduction to concepts relating to linear signals and systems theory, time and frequency domain analysis, and application of these concepts to problems in Biomedical Engineering.

title: ARCH 560 A History of Architectural Theory: 1400-1914
description: A seminar on architectural history from Alberti to Scott, reviewing primary texts and subsequent criticisms.

title: BME 410 Introduction to Biomaterials and Tissue Engineering
description: Application of principles of physical chemistry, biochemistry, and materials engineering to biomedical problems, e.g., materials selection and design for implants and tissue replacement.

title: BME 406 Introduction to Bioengineering in Medicine
description: Bioengineering concepts and technologies applied to cancer diagnosis, drug discovery, immunotherapeutic development, and mechanistic research.

title: BME 403L Physiological Systems
description: A thorough bioengineering treatment of the physiological properties of various mammalian organ systems: e.g., cardiovascular, respiratory, renal, and musculoskeletal.

title: BME 404 Biomechanics
description: Mechanical properties of biological tissues and fluid transport in physiological systems: blood rheology; bioviscoelastic solids and fluids; gas flow and mixing; prosthesis design.

title: BME 405L Senior Projects: Measurements and Instrumentation
description: Application of instrumentation and measurement techniques to biomedical engineering projects involving measurement, replacement or augmentation of biomedical systems.

title: BME 390 Special Problems
description: Supervised, individual studies. No more than one registration permitted. Enrollment by petition only.

title: ARCH 557 Sustainable Conservation of the Historic Built Environment
description: Analysis of the intersection between "green building" and historic resources with an emphasis on stewardship and sustainability.

title: ARCH 558 Fundamentals of Place-Making
description: Concepts and strategies for urban design and place-making for heritage conservation as revealed by place-making exercises, site visits, and case studies.

title: BME 350 Biomedical Engineering Industrial Project
description: Training in specific skills relevant to biomedical industry. Placement in summer internship following successful completion of the course. Junior standing.

title: ARCH 556 Readings in Heritage Conservation Theory
description: Trans-disciplinary intensive reading and discussion course related to issues in contemporary heritage conservation.

title: BME 302L Medical Electronics
description: Electronic design and measurements for medical applications. Use of integrated circuits, biopotential measurements, static and dynamic calibration of physiological transducers.

title: BME 402 Control and Communication in the Nervous System
description: An introduction to the structural and functional elements common to nervous systems, with emphasis on cellular dynamics, interneuronal communication, sensory and effector systems.

title: ARCH 554 Heritage Conservation Practicum — Advanced Documentation
description: Heritage conservation practicum utilizing in-depth documentation methodology to explore the historic built environment of greater Los Angeles. Topics will vary from year to year; may be repeated for credit when subjectmatter is different.

title: ARCH 553 History of American Architecture and Urbanism
description: History of American architecture and urbanism from prehistory to World War II examined in relation to European influences and indigenous developments.

title: BME 412 Craniofacial and Dental Technology
description: Biomedical engineering and technology applied to oral health professions. Dental biomaterials, CAD-CAM, digital dental technology and tissue engineering applications to craniofacial diseases, disorders, and enhancements.

title: ARCH 552 Introduction to Historic Site Documentation
description: Survey of basic guidelines and standards for documentation in historic preservation, including cultural resource surveys, historic structures reports and Historic American Building Survey and Historic American Engineering Record recordation.

title: ARCH 550 Heritage Conservation Policy and Planning
description: Conservation practice within an economic, political, and cultural context looking at the regulatory environment, public advocacy and policy, real estate development, heritage tourism, environmental sustainability, cultural diversity, and interpretation.

title: ARCH 551 Conservation Methods and Materials
description: Concepts and techniques for building conservation including identification of treatments, recordation and research, material properties and behavior, building forensics, and project implementation.

title: ARCH 549 Fundamentals of Heritage Conservation
description: Concepts and strategies for conservation of significant elements of the built environment: buildings, sites and communities as revealed by readings, site visits, and case studies.

title: ARCH 555 Global Perspectives in Heritage Conservation
description: In-depth analysis of international heritage conservation practice with a focus on a single country, continent, or world region outside the United States. Topics will vary from year to year; may be repeated for credit when subject matter is different.

title: ARCH 548 Media for Landscape Architecture: 3D Design
description: Developing and communicating landscape architecture design intent using visualization tools for three-dimensional studies.

title: ARCH 547 Urban Nature
description: Interactions of cities and nature: introduction to the ecology of cities; major threats to urban biodiversity interacting with human attitudes; review of restoration and conservation projects.

title: ARCH 546 Topics in Landscape Architecture: Issues and Practices
description: A broad range of developing urban landscape conditions and issues, both domestic and global, are given focused attention.

title: ARCH 545 Urban Landscape: Contemporary History and Prospect
description: Explores contemporary landscape architecture propositions and projects in the context of cities. The exploration methodology includes the study of epochal projects and theoretical texts organized by central themes of nature and culture.

title: ARCH 544 Urban Landscape: Process and Place
description: Projects are examined as incremental interventions in the formation and qualities of the evolving urban landscape. Case studies are explored to understand purposes, typologies, catalytic capacities, and strategies for urban landscape design.

title: BME 308 Computer-Aided Design for Bio-Mechanical Systems
description: Concepts of computer-aided design in 2-dimensions and 3-dimensions. Creating advanced parts using extrusions, surfaces, and equation driven sketches. Forming assemblies, and sub-assemblies, for motion analysis

title: ARCH 543 Research Methods
description: Introduction to methods of inquiry and documentation including critical review of published materials, techniques for systematic observation, generating findings from comparative studies of relevant precedents and problems, and legible presentation of outcomes.

title: ARCH 542aL Landscape Architecture Design
description: Project strategies for urban infrastructure repair and intervention, phasing, and design of initial catalytic projects.

title: ARCH 541bL Landscape Architecture Design
description: Projects in urban settings with emphasis on landscape continuities as well as development of integrative schematic proposals and detailed open space design.

title: ARCH 542bL Landscape Architecture Design
description: Projects for the public realm with emphasis on urbanity and connectivity, place and meaning.

title: ARCH 541aL Landscape Architecture Design
description: Projects on urban sites with emphasis on cultural and ecological purpose and on urban place and form; use of traditional and digital media.

title: ASTE 694z Thesis
description: Required for the degree Engineer in Astronautical Engineering. Credit on acceptance of thesis.

title: ASTE 694b Thesis
description: Required for the degree Engineer in Astronautical Engineering. Credit on acceptance of thesis.

title: ASTE 694a Thesis
description: Required for the degree Engineer in Astronautical Engineering. Credit on acceptance of thesis.

title: ASTE 690 Directed Research
description: Laboratory studies of specific problems by candidates for the degree Engineer in Astronautical Engineering.

title: ASTE 599 Special Topics
description: Course content to be selected each semester from current developments in astronautics, space technology, and related fields.

title: ASTE 683 Advanced Spacecraft Navigation
description: Advanced topics in spacecraft navigation: rendezvous, frozen/sun synchronous orbits, stationkeeping. Nonlinear filtering for orbit and attitude determination. Optical navigation. Mission applications.

title: ASTE 594z Master's Thesis
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: ASTE 594b Master's Thesis
description: Grading Option: In-progress & Credit/No Credit

title: ASTE 594a Master's Thesis
description: Grading Option: In-progress & Credit/No Credit

title: ASTE 590 Directed Research
description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the division.

title: ASTE 586 Spacecraft Attitude Dynamics
description: Dynamics of systems of particles and rigid bodies; spacecraft attitude systems; attitude maneuvers (spin, precession, nutation, etc.); attitude stabilization and attitude determination; simulation methods.

title: ASTE 589 Solar System Navigation
description: Free-return trajectories for exploration of the moon, optimization and control of interplanetary trajectories, and mission design using the Interplanetary Superhighway.

title: ASTE 584 Spacecraft Power Systems
description: Introduction to solar arrays, batteries, nuclear power sources, mechanical energy storage. Application theory of operation, practical considerations. Subsystem topologies and performance. Design optimization techniques.

title: ASTE 585 Spacecraft Attitude Control
description: Review of attitude dynamics, gravity gradient stabilization, attitude stabilization with a spin, attitude maneuvers, control using momentum exchange devices, momentum-biased stabilization, reaction thruster control.

title: ASTE 581 Orbital Mechanics II
description: Theory of perturbations of orbits; numerical methods in orbital mechanics; satellite dynamics; averaging methods; resonance; mission analysis.

title: ASTE 580 Orbital Mechanics I
description: Physical principles; two-body and central force motion; trajectory correction maneuvers; position and velocity in conic orbits; Lambert's problem; celestial mechanics; orbital perturbations.

title: ASTE 583 Space Navigation: Principles and Practice
description: Statistical orbit determination: (weighted) least squares, batch and sequential (Kalman) processing, illustrative examples; online ephemeris generation: potentially hazardous asteroids, comets, satellites; launch: vehicles, payloads, staging. Graduate standing in engineering or science.

title: BISC 536 Advanced Seminar in Marine Biogeochemistry
description: Examination of the interplay between ocean biology and the cycling of carbon, nitrogen and other elements on a local, regional and global scale.

title: ASTE 577 Entry and Landing Systems for Planetary Surface Exploration
description: Multi-disciplinary engineering theory, simulation techniques, and unique technologies for landing robotic and human space vehicles on the surface of planets and moons.

title: BISC 534 Advanced Seminar in Population Genetics of Marine Organisms
description: An overview of the theory underlying population and quantitative genetics, with applications to marine systems. Basic evolutionary mechanisms (mutation, migration, drift, selection, nonrandom mating) and modern evidence for their roles in structuring genetic variation within and among marine populations.

title: BISC 535 Seminar in Physiology
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: BISC 533 Advanced Seminar in Remote Sensing and Modeling
description: Modern oceanographic methods for making remote measurements of aquatic and terrestrial ecosystems using satellite imagery and other means. Integrating these data into models that describe ecosystem structure and enable interpretation of ecosystem function.

title: BISC 532 Advanced Seminar in Molecular and Microbial Ecology
description: Microorganisms dominate biological processes in the ocean. These species pose significant problems for estimating species diversity, abundance and activity. Examination of modern molecular biological approaches for analyzing aquatic microbial communities and their ecological roles.

title: BISC 531 Advanced Seminar on the Physiology of Marine Organisms
description: Physiological processes dictate survival potential, growth rates, and many other biological processes that affect the distribution of species in the oceans. Emphasis on the diverse environmental factors that influence physiological adaptations of marine organisms. Examples from a wide variety of marine organisms, from bacterial to animals, will be studied.

title: BME 201 Biomedical Engineering Practice
description: Examination of the technical and practical challenges involved in the development of medical devices, including neural implants, in industry and the clinical setting.

title: BME 101 Introduction to Biomedical Engineering
description: Historical development and survey of major areas comprising biomedical engineering: theoretical neurobiology and systems physiology, biomedical instrumentation, artificial organ and prosthetic devices, biomedical computer applications.

title: BMDD 594z Master's Thesis
description: Registration Restriction: Open only to the Herman Ostrow School of Dentistry

title: BMDD 594b Master's Thesis
description: Registration Restriction: Open only to the Herman Ostrow School of Dentistry

title: BMDD 594a Master's Thesis
description: Registration Restriction: Open only to the Herman Ostrow School of Dentistry

title: BMDD 590 Directed Research
description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

title: BMDD 588a Digital Technology Applied to Dentistry
description: Weekly seminar devoted to critically review, analyze, and discuss digital technologies applied to dentistry.

title: BMDD 588b Digital Technology Applied to Dentistry
description: Weekly seminar devoted to critically review, analyze, and discuss digital technologies applied to dentistry.

title: BPMK 511 Capstone II: Biopharmaceutical Management Project
description: Student directed advanced research and topics to develop student individual skills surrounding research design, execution, planning, presentation and defense, consistent with BP industry standards.

title: ARCH 540 Topics in Media for Landscape Architecture
description: Exploration of emerging techniques for landscape architecture study, presentation and documentation; topics vary from year to year; may be repeated for credit when subject matter is different.

title: ARCH 539L Media for Landscape Architecture
description: Development of methods and skills for the study of landscape architecture design and for project presentation, including natural resource and urban mapping.

title: ARCH 537 Urban Plant Ecology: Environmental Perspectives
description: Principles and concepts of plant ecology for urban planting design; introduction to California native plant species and communities with field trips and case studies.

title: ARCH 538L Urban Plant Ecology: Cultural Perspectives
description: Cultural perspectives of urban planting design and plant species found in Southern California emphasizing aesthetic, functional and ecological designs.

title: ARCH 536 The Landscape Planning Process
description: Methods of assessing urban places regarding natural, social, cultural and political factors; identification of landscape architecture planning and project implementation issues and strategies.

title: ARCH 535 Landscape Construction: Performance Approaches
description: Develop tools and knowledge to expand the performative boundaries of landscape architecture beyond common typologies. Topics range from ecological infrastructure to design with weather patterns. A systematic approach to case studies, landscape technologies, and field trips seeds the knowledge base and respresentational methods necessary to design and build these complex landscape performances.

title: ARCH 534 Landscape Construction: Topographic Design
description: Techniques, strategies, materials, and standards to topographic design and construction in landscape architecture. In-class labs practice basic grading, drainage design, and stormwater management.

title: ARCH 533 Urban Landscape Case Studies
description: Lectures, discussion, and individual research on the physical, formal, and spatial characteristics of historical urban centers.

title: ARCH 532 Elements of the Urban Landscape
description: Study of the basic spatial and infrastructure elements of the city, and how urban places are formed. Typological analysis of buildings, open space, and urban patterns.

title: ARCH 531 The Natural Landscape
description: Lectures, laboratory exercises and field trips introducing basic knowledge of the continually transforming landscape as a base for human settlement.

title: ARCH 530 Landscape Architecture Practice
description: Introduction to the principles and ethics, scope and activities, and types of organization for landscape architecture practice.

title: ASTE 574 Space Launch Vehicle Design
description: Fundamentals, technologies, and design of space launch vehicles. Propulsion, trajectory analysis and optimization, static and dynamic structural loads, stability, control, and safety.

title: ASTE 572 Advanced Spacecraft Propulsion
description: Nuclear, electric, sails, and far-term propulsion systems. Overviews of nozzles, heat transfer, electromagnetics, rarefied gases, and plasma physics. Analysis of electrothermal, electrostatic and electromagnetic thrusters. Graduate standing in engineering or science.

title: ASTE 570 Liquid Rocket Propulsion
description: Liquid-propelled rocket propulsion systems. Capillary devices for gas-free liquid acquisition in zero gravity. Ground and in-orbit operations. Propellant life predictions and spacecraft end-of-life de-orbiting strategies.

title: ASTE 557 Spacecraft Structural Strength and Materials
description: Spacecraft structural strength analysis and design concepts overview; spacecraft material selection; analysis of composite materials; finite element method; spacecraft configuration; structural testing; bolted joint design.

title: ASTE 566 Ground Communications for Satellite Operations
description: Theory, practice, architecture, operations of ground satellite communications with satellites. Practical implementation of satellite communications system and reception and analysis of satellite transmitted signals.

title: ASTE 556 Spacecraft Structural Dynamics
description: Applied analytical methods (vibrations of single and multidegree of freedom systems, finite element modeling, spacecraft applications); requirements definition process; analytical cycles; and design verification.

title: ASTE 555 Space Cryogenic Systems and Applications
description: Theory and practice in cryogenic engineering as applied to space systems, emphasizing sensor cooling techniques; cryostats; cryoradiators; mechanical cryocoolers; introductions to superfluidity and superconductivity.

title: ASTE 554 Spacecraft Sensors
description: Spacecraft sensors from concept and design to building, testing, interfacing, integrating, and operations. Optical and infrared sensors, radiometers, radars, phased arrays, signal processing, noise reduction.

title: ASTE 553 Systems for Remote Sensing from Space
description: The operation, accuracy, resolution, figures of merit, and application of instruments which either produce images of ground scenes or probe the atmosphere as viewed primarily from space.

title: ASTE 552 Spacecraft Thermal Control
description: Spacecraft and orbit thermal environments; design, analysis, testing of spacecraft thermal control system and components; active and passive thermal control, spacecraft and launch vehicle interfaces.

title: ASTE 546 Computational Plasma Dynamics
description: Plasma simulation techniques; particle-in-cell (PIC); PIC with Monte Carlo; computational electromagnetics; computational magnetohyrdodynamics. Parallelization. Applications in engineering and space plasma physics.

title: ASTE 545 Computational Techniques in Rarefied Gas Dynamics
description: Particle-based computational simulation methods for rarefied, high-speed flows. Molecular collision kinetics. Monte Carlo direct simulation and related techniques.

title: ASTE 535 Space Environments and Spacecraft Interactions
description: Space environments and interactions with space systems. Vacuum, neutral and ionized species, plasma, radiation, micrometeoroids. Phenomena important for spacecraft operations.

title: ASTE 529 Safety of Space Systems and Space Missions
description: Engineering methodology and analysis techniques for safety certification and mission assurance of robotic and human space systems and space missions by government and commercial industry.

title: BISC 530 Advanced Seminar in Plankton Biology
description: An overview of phytoplankton and zooplankton taxa, their morphologies and life histories using material collected from the local environment off LA and near the Phillip K. Wrigley Marine Science Center on Catalina Island.

title: BISC 529 Seminar in Marine Biology
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: BISC 520 Recent Advances in Neurobiology
description: Lectures on selected topics in neurobiology. Registration restricted to three semesters.

title: BISC 521 Hearing and Communication Neuroscience
description: A basic grounding in broad aspects of the neuroscience of hearing and vocal communication.

title: BISC 512 Evolutionary Biology
description: Survey of current topics in evolutionary biology; genetics, natural selection, ecology; emphasis on higher order complex questions of lifespan, form, function, and energy use.

title: BISC 515 Evolution and Human Biology
description: Topics in evolution and human biology with emphasis on life span, form, function and energy use in the context of genetics, natural selection and ecology.

title: BISC 511 Integrative Biology
description: Current topics in integrative biology including form, function and energy use throughout the lifespan in the context of genetics, natural selection and ecology.

title: BPMK 506 Biopharmaceutical Product Pricing and Competition
description: Design risk maps, methods and processes for competitive intelligence.  War Games! Pricing tools and revenue models.

title: BISC 505 Genomics and Molecular Genetics
description: Molecular genetics (mutagenesis, repair, recombination, and gene regulation) from quantitative and mechanistic approaches. Simple and complex genome analysis using recombinant DNA, physical, and computational techniques.

title: BPMK 505 Product Health Economics and Valuation
description: Applied microeconomic tools, health technology assessment, cost effectiveness and commercial utility research. Practical understanding data sets and applications of real-world outcomes research and innovative modeling.

title: BPMK 504 Payer Formulary Placement: Value and Access
description: Profile insurance categories, controls and public demands. Aligning formulary and value measures and research. Play to Win! Quantitative assessment of market segmentation and evidence generation.

title: BPMK 503 Biopharmaceutical Advertising and Communication
description: Understand product positioning, timing and market opportunities. Key message development and communication pathways, budgets, quantitative measures for Grab and Growth! Integrated launch and market planning.

title: BPMK 502 Biopharmaceutical Product Development and Marketing
description: Portfolio role of clinical trials, regulatory and government agencies in product development. Winning through strategy! Planning profiles for novel products R&D vs. unmet medical needs.

title: BPMK 501 Healthcare Payers, Insurance and Coverage Policy
description: Review evolution, design, forecasting future healthcare and coverage policies. Actuarial costs impact and controls on insurance premiums. Master and design successful formulary and reimbursement tactics.

title: BPMK 500 Biopharmaceutical Market: Reimbursement Strategy
description: Gain fundamental analytic skills and insights of medical trends directly from global payers, industry and government policy leaders covering healthcare reform, access and future therapies.

title: BKN 794z Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: ARCH 529 Urban Housing: Programs, Precedents, and Recent Case Studies
description: Historical overview of the major domestic and international housing developments and innovations since the early 20th century. Case study format examining a wide range of issues that determine the form of urban housing in various cultures. Major emphasis on the detail analysis of social, technical, and design factors affecting recent housing developments.

title: BISC 522 Nonlinear Dynamical Systems, Vibrations, and Chaos
description: Interacting population dynamics, Cheyne-Stokes respiration, reaction kinetics, biological switches, neuronal models, BZ reaction, phase locking, reaction diffusion, chemotaxis, biological waves, and animal coat patterns.

title: ARCH 528 Urban Housing: Types and Typologies
description: Applications and precedents for the architect interested in designing multi-family housing. Review of the sources of modern housing types, the impact of building codes and technology on the form and construction of housing, and study of housing densities; comparative analysis of multi-family residential patterns. Major emphasis on critical knowledge of historic housing typologies as they are applied to site conditions and groupings, building form, section, organization, and the design of individual dwellings.

title: ARCH 527 Case Studies: The Development of Urban Housing
description: An exploration of the various elements and stages of the housing development process.

title: BISC 519 Recent Advances in Neurobiology and Endocrinology of Aging
description: Theories of the biology of aging and the effects of age on functional integrity of the total organism.

title: ARCH 525 Professional Practice: Pre-Design, Project and Office Administration
description: Design methodology, typology programming, site analysis, budget formulation and pro-forma procedures. Office management, emphasizing professional service and professional ethics as well as project management focusing on the architect's responsibilities during construction.

title: ARCH 526 Professional Practice: Legal and Economic Context, Project Documentation
description: Design methodology, typology programming, site analysis, budget formulation and pro-forma procedures. Office management, emphasizing professional service and professional ethics as well as project management focusing on the architect's responsibilities during construction.

title: ARCH 524 Professional Practicum
description: Registration Restriction: Open to international upper-division undergraduate and graduate architecture students only

title: ARCH 523bL Structural Design and Analysis
description: Investigation and design of building structural systems for gravity, wind and seismic loading. Comprehensive design exploration of framing type, materials, detailing, layout, form and integration.

title: ARCH 521 Health and the Designed Environment: Landscape, Place, and Architecture
description: Case study-oriented course presenting critical relationships between human health and well-being and architectural and landscape architectural design at three scales: buildings, public space, and the urban landscape.

title: ARCH 523aL Structural Design and Analysis
description: Introduction to behavior and analysis of building structures. Structural loading, materials, and element types will be explored to understand the basic building blocks of buildings.

title: ARCH 520 Housing and Community Design for an Aging Population
description: Exploration of the role design plays in enhancing independence and well-being for older people by examining cross-cultural models of housing and community design.

title: ARCH 519 Sustainability in the Environment: Infrastructures, Urban Landscapes, and Buildings
description: Methodologies and exercises on contextual design and environmentally sound technologies (EST's) applications for the sustainability of urban infrastructures, operative landscapes, and building integration in the urban system.

title: ASTE 528 Reliability of Space Systems
description: Reliable space system design and operations for human and robotic space, applications, and commercial space. Reliability of space systems, subsystems, hardware, software and human reliability.

title: ASTE 527 Space Studio Architecting
description: Programmatic/conceptual design synthesis/choice creation methods for complex space missions. Aerospace system engineering/architecture tools to create innovative projects. Evaluated by faculty/industry/NASA experts.

title: ASTE 524 Human Spaceflight
description: Engineering, technologies, and systems for human spaceflight. Life support, space environments, crew accomodations. Mission operations, safety. Astrodynamics, launch and space vehicles, space stations, palnetary bases.

title: ASTE 520 Spacecraft System Design
description: System components; vehicle structure, propulsion systems, flight dynamics, thermal control, power systems, telecommunication. Interfaces and tradeoffs between these components. Testing, system reliability, and integration.

title: ASTE 523 Design of Low Cost Space Missions
description: Reviews all aspects of space mission design for practical approaches to reducing cost. Examines "LightSat" mission experience and potential applicability to large-scale missions. Graduate standing in engineering or science.

title: ASTE 505b Plasma Dynamics
description: Charged particle dynamics. Kinetic fluid theories. Rarefied and collisional plasma flows. Plasma-surface interactions. Waves, instabilities, turbulence. Applications in engineering and space technology.

title: ASTE 501a Physical Gas Dynamics
description: Molecular structure; radiative processes; microscopic description of gas phenomena; translational, rotational, vibrational, and electronic freedom degrees; particle energy distributions; microscopic representation of thermodynamic functions.

title: ASTE 505a Plasma Dynamics
description: Charged particle dynamics. Kinetic fluid theories. Rarefied and collisional plasma flows. Plasma-surface interactions. Waves, instabilities, turbulence. Applications in engineering and space technology.

title: ASTE 501b Physical Gas Dynamics
description: Kinetic concepts in gas physics; thermal non-equilibrium; intermolecular potentials; transport of radiation and particles in high-temperature gas; dissociation and ionization equilibrium; energy relaxation.

title: ASTE 499 Special Topics
description: Course content to be selected each semester from current developments in astronautics, space technology, and related fields.

title: ASTE 491 Team Projects II
description: Participation in ASTE undergraduate student team projects. Intended for students with prior project experience.

title: BISC 504L Laboratory Techniques in Cellular and Molecular Biology
description: Rotation of graduate students through Molecular Biology research laboratories to learn the major technological skills required in the field.

title: BISC 502b Molecular Genetics and Biochemistry
description: Current genetic and biochemical analysis of replication, recombination, mutagenesis, and repair. Fundamentals of transcription and regulation of gene expression. Recent applications of genetic engineering and genome analysis.

title: BISC 502a Molecular Genetics and Biochemistry
description: Current genetic and biochemical analysis of replication, recombination, mutagenesis, and repair. Fundamentals of transcription and regulation of gene expression. Recent applications of genetic engineering and genome analysis.

title: BISC 494x Honors Thesis
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: BISC 499 Special Topics
description: Lecture and discussion in specialized areas of the biological sciences. Students cannot register more than twice for this course.

title: BISC 490x Directed Research
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: BISC 493x Honors Seminar
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: BISC 486 Regenerative Medicine: Principles, Paradigms and Practice
description: Examination of molecular and cellular processes that generate, maintain and repair body systems.  Special emphasis on stem cell biology with clinical applications to regenerative medicine.

title: BKN 794d Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: BKN 794c Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: BISC 483 Geobiology and Astrobiology
description: Relationships between microbiota and the earth environment including the hydrosphere, lithosphere and atmosphere, with consideration of the potential for life on other planets.

title: BKN 794b Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: BKN 794a Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: BISC 485 Advanced Seminar in Bacterial Survival and Evolution
description: Literature-based seminar in current topics in microbial evolution and adaptation.

title: BKN 672 Advanced Independent Study in Biokinesiology
description: Examination of selected mechanisms underlying normal movement and pathological movement.

title: BKN 790 Research
description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

title: BKN 623 Neuroplasticity and Neural Repair
description: Integration of basic research on neuroplasticity and clinical research on central nervous system reorganization after brain injury. Implication for neurorecovery and rehabilitation.

title: BKN 618L Modeling the Motor System: Laboratory
description: Introduction of computer programming and implementation of computational models in a laboratory setting.

title: BKN 621 Electromyography in Research and Practice
description: Physiology and electrophysiology of muscular contraction, how it is collected, quantified and processed. Uses of electromyographic information for research and clinical assessments.

title: BKN 617 Modeling the Motor System: An Introduction
description: Introduction of basic principles and models of the primate motor system. Emphasis on arm control.

title: BKN 630 Resistance Training Techniques for High Performance Athletes
description: Introduction to training methods and techniques as they pertain to high performance athletes with a focus on advanced resistance training programs and periodization schemes.

title: BKN 615 Principles of Skeletal Adaptation
description: Introduction to the integrative physiology of skeletal adaptation to mechanical loading. Emphasis on mechanical and chemical regulation of bone mass.

title: ARCH 518 Advanced Surface Tectonics: Methods in Material and Enclosure
description: Studies in contemporary building systems through analysis, research, and computational methods leading to the design of a prototypical building surface.

title: ARCH 517 Current Topics in Building Science
description: Critical studies in building science ranging from sustainability, lighting, acoustics, materials and methods, structures, energy issues, digital media, and fabrication. Students focus on minimum of two topics.

title: ARCH 515L Seminar: Advanced Environmental Systems
description: A compressed course in design criteria and calculation methods for mechanical and passive solar systems (loads, plant system, duct, and storage sizing) and lighting and acoustics (CIE and IES methods, dBA and NC systems).

title: ARCH 514b Global History of Architecture
description: A historical survey of global architecture, analyzed as a product of social, cultural, religious and political forces. 1500 CE to present.

title: ARCH 513L Seminar: Advanced Structures
description: Issues and problems in the development of structural systems for buildings; design criteria, system choice, design development, optimization, subsystem integration.

title: ARCH 514a Global History of Architecture
description: A historical survey of global architecture, analyzed as a product of social, cultural, religious and political forces. 4500 BCE to 1500 CE.

title: ARCH 511L Building Systems: Materials and Construction
description: Studies of construction system development within the architectural design context; processes and issues of selection, evaluation, optimization, integration, design control, and innovation.

title: ARCH 512 Material + Process: Material Systems
description: Confronts the conventional concepts behind modern building science and material applications, reapplying the processes of fabrication and methods of construction to investigate materiality.

title: ARCH 510 Independent Degree Project Preparation
description: Research and analysis, including written and graphic components, that tests a question/proposition in detail in preparation for Independent Degree Project Document.

title: ASTE 490x Directed Research
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: ASTE 480 Spacecraft Dynamics
description: Two-body motion, rigid-body motion, attitude dynamics and maneuvers, spacecraft stabilization: gravity gradient, reaction wheels, magnetic torques, thruster attitude control.

title: ASTE 470 Spacecraft Propulsion
description: Introduction to rocket engineering. Space missions and thrust requirements. Compressible gas dynamics. Propellant chemistry and thermodynamics. Liquid- and solid-fueled rockets. Nuclear and electric propulsion.

title: ASTE 445 Molecular Gas Dynamics
description: Physical description of kinetic nature of gas flows; distribution function; introduction to the Boltzmann equation; free-molecule flow; surface and molecular reflection properties; Monte Carlo flow calculations.

title: ASTE 421x Space Mission Design
description: Space systems engineering process: requirements definition; trade studies; system integration; technical reviews; cost and schedule development; case studies; ethics. Capstone design experience.

title: ASTE 390 Special Problems
description: Supervised, individual studies. No more than one registration permitted. Enrollment by petition only.

title: BISC 481 Structural Bioinformatics: From Atoms to Cells
description: Introduction to computational and experimental methods for structural bioinformatics. Analysis of macro molecules and their complexes.

title: ASTE 330 Introduction to Spacecraft Systems and the Space Environment
description: Spacecraft systems: attitude determination and control, power, thermal, command and data handling, telecommunication, structures and mechanisms, propulsion. Space environment: atmosphere, gravity gradients, radiation.

title: BISC 480 Developmental Biology
description: Basic mechanisms of animal development are considered at different levels of analysis. Emphasis is on molecular, genetic, and cellular processes underlying vertebrate and invertebrate development. General concepts and evolutionary mechanisms are emphasized.

title: BISC 478 Computational Genome Analysis
description: Introduction to and applications of algorithms and statistics to genome analysis. Analysis of physical and genetic maps, DNA sequencing, sequence comparisons, DNA chips.

title: BISC 474L Ecosystem Function and Earth Systems
description: General principles of ecosystem function, energy flow and materials cycling in marine systems at various scales and the importance of microbial processes in these systems. Taught on Catalina Island.

title: BISC 473L Biological Oceanography
description: Biological, physical, chemical dynamics and analysis of the ocean; primary production of phytoplankton, secondary production by zooplankton, bacterial remineralization; physiology, ecology of fishes, marine mammals.

title: BISC 462 Seminar in Neurobiology
description: Registration Restriction: Open only to juniors, seniors, master and doctoral students

title: BISC 461 Seminar in Molecular and Computational Biology
description: Topical seminar in molecular and computational biology.

title: BISC 469L Marine Biology
description: Oceanography and marine biology, sampling techniques, evolutionary adaptations, morphology, systematics.

title: BISC 460 Seminar in Marine and Environmental Biology
description: Topical seminar in marine and environmental biology.

title: BKN 599 Special Topics
description: Studies of scientific theory in physical therapy.

title: BKN 610L Technology in Sport: Field Assessment of Athlete Performance
description: Introduction of topics related to assessments of athlete performance on the field or in the sports setting. Focus on understanding and applying available technology to athlete field assessments. Overview of the techniques and hardware used to assess athlete performance outside of a laboratory setting.

title: BKN 594z Master's Thesis
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: BKN 600 Sports Science Internship
description: A combination of observation, participation (testing/assessments, training) and analysis and interpretation of data. Supervision and guidance from the internship mentor will vary depending on the setting and credit hours. Allows students a progressively increasing amount of responsibility with respect to athlete/subject and/or data involvement.

title: BKN 594a Master's Thesis
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: BKN 594b Master's Thesis
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: BKN 593 Behavioral Basis of Motor Control and Learning
description: Seminar in movement science dealing with the behavioral basis of motor control and learning from an information processing perspective.

title: BKN 588 Physiology and Biomechanics of Resistance Exercise
description: Science of resistance-exercise prescription, adaptation, and outcome assessment. Topics include periodization, neuromuscular and connectivetissue adaptation, special populations, and biomechanical considerations.

title: BKN 590 Directed Research
description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

title: BKN 587b Physiological Correlates of Therapeutic Exercise
description: Responses of the physically handicapped to exercise, with emphasis on cardiovascular and respiratory adaptations and pathology.

title: BKN 587a Physiological Correlates of Therapeutic Exercise
description: Responses of the physically handicapped to exercise. Emphasis on muscle, energy metabolism, body temperature, environment, endocrine considerations. Strengthening, training, endurance, and evaluation of performance.

title: BKN 585 Systematic Research Writing
description: Development of analytical journal reading skills and proficiency in scientific writing. Lecture and tutorial format.

title: BKN 578 Classic Readings in Biokinesiology
description: A seminar course in which students read and discuss classic scientific papers that have shaped the development of the movement sciences over the past 150 years.

title: BKN 573a Advanced Dissection Anatomy
description: Advanced analysis of systems or structures with dissection. Emphasis on correlations with function.

title: BKN 575 Principles of Musculoskeletal Imaging
description: Basic principles of musculoskeletal imaging as it relates to biomechanics research. Topics include MRI physics, variable imaging parameters and selection of pulse sequences.

title: BKN 573b Advanced Dissection Anatomy
description: Advanced analysis of systems or structures with dissection. Emphasis on correlations with function.

title: ARCH 507 Theories of Computer Technology
description: Fundamental theories and meanings of computation as a technique in architectural design.

title: ARCH 505bL Graduate Architecture Design I
description: A general introduction to architectural principles, intended to develop design and critical thinking skills and proficiency to communicate those ideas effectively.

title: ARCH 505aL Graduate Architecture Design I
description: A general introduction to architectural principles, intended to develop design and critical thinking skills and proficiency to communicate those ideas effectively.

title: ARCH 502zL Architectural Design V
description: The final comprehensive architectural project under the guidance of a faculty adviser to demonstrate architectural knowledge, skills, and professional interests and goals.

title: ARCH 502aL Architectural Design V
description: The final architectural project under the guidance of a faculty adviser to demonstrate architectural knowledge, skills, and professional interests and goals.

title: ARCH 501 Critical Topics in Architecture
description: Seminar supporting the research, development, and writing of Degree Project Paper provides a comprehensive base of information for the final Bachelor of Architecture studio.

title: ARCH 500zL Comprehensive Architectural Design
description: Selected areas of specialization; projects chosen from a variety of studio offerings, all with an emphasis on the comprehensive design of buildings.

title: ARCH 499 Special Topics
description: Selected topics in various specialty areas of architecture.

title: ARCH 490x Directed Research
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: ARCH 500aL Comprehensive Architectural Design
description: Selected areas of specialization; projects chosen from a variety of studio offerings, all with an emphasis on the comprehensive design of buildings.

title: ARCH 481 Furniture Design
description: An investigation into 20th century furniture design and its relationships to architecture, art and design.

title: ARCH 470b Architectural Studies Capstone
description: Registration Restriction: Open only to seniors in Architectural Studies

title: ASTE 291 Team Projects I
description: Participation in ASTE undergraduate student team projects. Intended for lower-division students or those with little prior project experience.

title: ASTE 301b Thermal and Statistical Systems
description: Thermodynamics and statistical mechanics; kinetics of atoms, molecules, and photons; compressible fluid dynamics.

title: ASTE 280 Foundations of Astronautical Engineering
description: Coordinate systems and transformations. Spherical trigonometry. Orientation angles. Spacecraft orbits and orbital maneuvers. Introduction to rocket propulsion, spacecraft attitude dynamics and control, and space environment.

title: ASTE 101L Introduction to Astronautics
description: Gateway to the Astronautical Engineering major. Introduction to space, space exploration and the space business. Elements of orbits, spacecraft systems, rocket propulsion, and communications. Laboratory: introduction to graphics, computation and simulation.

title: ASTE 301a Thermal and Statistical Systems
description: Thermodynamics and statistical mechanics; kinetics of atoms, molecules, and photons; compressible fluid dynamics.

title: ASCJ 420 Annenberg Collaboratory
description: Collaborative, cutting-edge, experimental, experiential, interdisciplinary, results-based classes taught in new ways and places.

title: BISC 457L Methods in Marine Biology and Biological Oceanography
description: Introduction to standard methods used in oceanography and marine biology through a combination of lectures, laboratory exercises and field experiences.

title: BISC 455L Molecular Approaches to Microbial Diversity — Catalina Semester
description: Overview and practical application of genetic and immunological techniques for examining diversity and community structure of natural microbial assemblages in aquatic ecosystems.

title: BISC 447L Island Biogeography and Field Ecology
description: Biogeography, geology, ecology, climate, flora, and fauna of terrestrial and marine environments of Catalina and the Channel Islands including laboratory and field techniques of ecology. Taught on Catalina Island.

title: BISC 450L Principles of Immunology
description: Immune processes, humoral and cellular; immunoglobulins; antibody formation; antigen-antibody interactions; immune dyscrasias; transplantation and tumor immunology; basic hematology and immuno-hematology.

title: BISC 444 Practical Analysis of Biological Data in R
description: Instruction in the open-source statistical program environment R to analyze biological data; manipulation of large datasets and customization of statistical tests using simulations.

title: BISC 456L Conservation Genetics
description: Biological principles underlying conservation including ecology, evolution, genetics and biogeography. Covers both marine and terrestrial environment, with special emphasis on island biology. Catalina semester only.

title: BKN 566 Neurobiology of Locomotion
description: Topics include developmental biology of embryonic motility, central pattern generators, descending neural regulation, sensory modulation, and perception/action influences on the motor control of locomotion.

title: BKN 563 Biomechanics
description: Advanced study of the kinematics of human motion. Emphasis on the inverse dynamics solution to qualify forces and moments of force.

title: BKN 559 Readings in Biokinesiology
description: Independent review and synthesis of papers appearing in the current literature.

title: BKN 557L Functional Neuroanatomy with Lab Dissection
description: Comprehensive survey of regional neuroanatomy covered in lecture and laboratory format with dissection. In-depth consideration is given to neuroanatomical basis of sensory and motor function. Topics include neuroanatomical basis of cellular function, somatosensation, special senses, movement and distributed motor control, and homeostasis regulation.

title: BKN 553 Experimental Methods for the Analysis of Human Movement
description: Introduces students to the techniques and hardware used to record movement, measure movement-related variables, and analyze those variables to address hypotheses.

title: BISC 445L Fundamentals of Vertebrate Biology
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture, Lab Required

title: BKN 552 Physiological Basis of Voluntary Movement
description: Consideration of the neuromuscular and musculoskeletal physiology of voluntary movement.

title: BKN 551 Musculoskeletal and Biomechanical Basis of Movement
description: Introduction to the mechanical properties of the musculoskeletal system. Review of connective tissue and muscle mechanics, arthrology, anatomical design and statics. Laboratory dissections illustrate biomechanical concepts.

title: BKN 550 Neurobehavioral Basis of Movement
description: Introduction to the neurobehavioral and neurobiological basis of movement. Review of information processing, neural basis of perception/action, motor systems, and higher cognitive function and behavior.

title: BISC 794z Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: ARCH 470a Architectural Studies Capstone
description: Introduction to methods of inquiry, research framework, and scholarly writing necessary to develop a comprehensive foundation for the Architectural Studies Capstone (ARCH 470b).

title: ARCH 454 Contemporary Asian Architecture
description: Exploration of various "Asian" architectures, comparisons of areas, identifying current trends and impact of Asia on Southern California and Los Angeles.

title: ARCH 465 The Landscape Imaginary
description: A cross-cultural introduction to ideas about and attitudes toward nature, landscape and the environment.

title: ARCH 447 Ecological Factors in Design
description: Lectures, laboratory exercises and field trips introduce basic knowledge of incorporating ecological factors in urban design and interaction of landscape science with the human environment.

title: ARCH 442m Women's Spaces in History: "Hussies," "Harems" and "Housewives"
description: Methods for studying patterns of spatial differentiation of women throughout history from home to city embodied in gender specific language and gendered spaces.

title: ARCH 444 Great Houses of Los Angeles
description: An introduction to the architectural philosophies of seven influential California architects through readings and site visits to significant case studies.

title: ARCH 440m Literature and the Urban Experience
description: Post-industrial revolution urban environments and dynamic relationships in cities such as Manchester, Paris, St. Petersburg, New York, and Los Angeles, as revealed in novels, architecture, and urban forms.

title: ARCH 432 People, Places and Culture: Architecture of the Public Realm
description: Critical observation of the architecture of public buildings and places and the importance of design in promoting a better contemporary public life.

title: ARCH 439 Landscape Architecture Media Workshop
description: Introductory media workshop for new landscape architecture students in the 3-year graduate program. Topics include: hand drawing, measuring, architectural drawings, computer software tutorials, and field trips.

title: ARCH 430 Design Teaching Methods
description: The teaching of architectural design is introduced through readings, seminar discussions, and the observation of teaching in action. In addition to a one hour per week seminar, each student will participate in a design practicum.

title: ARCH 425L Field Studies in Urbanism
description: (Study abroad programs only.) Field studies using direct observation, site recordings/documentation, analysis and evaluation supplemented by discussions and readings in urbanism.

title: ARCH 426L Field Studies in Tectonics
description: (Study abroad programs only.) Field studies using direct observation, site recordings/documentation, analysis and evaluation supplemented by discussions and readings in tectonics.

title: ARCH 424L Field Studies in Architecture
description: (Study abroad programs only.) Field studies using direct observation, site recordings/documentation, analysis and evaluation supplemented by discussions and readings in architecture.

title: ARCH 423 Light, Color and the Character of Material
description: Color theory, constructed drawings, constructed shadows, descriptive geometry, constructed perspective drawing, and layered wash techniques lead to experimentation with methods representing materiality and construction in design projects.

title: ASCJ 220x Annenberg Experimental
description: Cutting-edge, experimental, experiential, interdisciplinary, results-based classes taught in new ways and places.

title: ASCJ 200 Navigating Media and News in the Digital Age
description: Students will be engaged as discriminating media/news consumers and contributors. Emphasis on critical skills needed to understand, employ, enjoy and help shape our media landscape.

title: ASCJ 210 Contours of Change in Media and Communication
description: Provides an introduction to cultivating a curious, critical, and proactive approach to the challenges of social change. Students will be encouraged to develop an expansive and critical definition and understanding of change as it relates to the role of media and communication in producing and responding to political and cultural transformations that shape our status as citizens and our ideas of citizenship.

title: ASCJ 100 The Changing World of Communication and Journalism
description: Survey of major themes in media and communication; exploring what it means to be a professional in the fields of communication, journalism, and public relations.

title: ARTL 790 Research
description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

title: ASCJ 020x Annenberg Skills
description: Intensive skills boot camps teach the verbal, written, and digital skills needed for "real world" jobs. Not available for degree credit.

title: ARTL 599 Special Topics
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: ARTL 590 Directed Research
description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

title: ARTL 512 Essentials of Orchestra Management
description: Ten day seminar that provides in depth, participative instruction in orchestra management and the practicalities of being a successful leader of an arts organization.

title: ARTL 520 Arts Leadership Intensive
description: Five-day, intensive course that serves as a deep-dive introduction to the field for all Arts Leadership students.

title: ARTL 510 Arts Leadership Practicum
description: Year-long practicum which puts ideas and concepts into practice. Each student will conceptualize, develop, and complete an arts project of his/her own choosing.

title: ARTL 504 Arts and the Community: Current Practice and New Visions
description: Exploration of a range of ideas, ideologies and strategies that have historically been used to connect arts organizations to their communities.

title: ARTL 503 Arts Organizations: Innovation and New Models
description: Designed for current and future arts leaders interested in looking critically at organizational practice and bringing innovative solutions to old problems in a contemporary context.

title: ARTL 501 Executive Leadership in the Arts
description: Investigation into a variety of leadership approaches within an arts organization, with a focus on the development of the student's own leadership capacity.

title: ARTL 500 Arts Leadership and Arts Entrepreneurship
description: Introduction to key issues involved in both managing an arts organization and creating sustainable enterprise. For students in music, arts, public policy, and related fields.

title: ARTL 502 Issues in the Arts and the Contemporary World
description: Examination of major environmental trends including changing demographics, new business models, rapidly developing technology and globalization, and understanding their implications for the arts.
