title: ARTL 499 Special Topics
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: BISC 438 Nutritional Biochemistry
description: Metabolism of carbohydrates, proteins, fats. Biochemical basis of nutrition's impact on metabolic functions, including vitamins, minerals and biologically active non-nutrients; medical aspects of nutrition.

title: BISC 437L Comparative Physiology of Animals
description: Control of the internal environment of animals in relation to their external environment. Thermal regulation, osmoregulation, excretion, and ion balance. Offered on Catalina.

title: BISC 435 Advanced Biochemistry
description: Macro molecular structure and function; enzymology; metabolic regulation.

title: BISC 428 The Biology of Tropical Diseases
description: Biological and biochemical approaches to the prevention and treatment of infectious and chronic tropical diseases. Course is offered off campus and summer only.

title: BISC 426 Principles of Neural Development
description: Basic phenomena and principles of neural development, their relation to functional development of neural circuits, behavior, and disease. General concepts and experimental approaches are emphasized.

title: BISC 425 Advanced Genetics through the Primary Scientific Literature
description: Literature-based seminar in current and classical topics in genetics.

title: BISC 431L Aquatic Microbiology
description: Introduction to the habitat, phylogenetic, physiological and metabolic diversity of microbial life in aquatic environments.

title: BISC 434 Introduction to Genome Science
description: Characterization of the sequence, function and evolution of genomes; study of the molecular basis of phenotypes and the relationship between genomics and synthetic biology.

title: BISC 429 Cancer Immunology
description: In-depth study of the role of the immune system in oncogenesis. Discussion of cellular transformation, immune surveillance, immune-based therapies, and new approaches in cancer treatment.

title: BISC 424 Brain Architecture
description: How the parts of the brain are interconnected to form a complex biological computer, from historical, evolutionary, and developmental perspectives.

title: BISC 423 Epilepsy to Ecstasy: Biological Basis of Neurological Disorders

description: Critical analysis of significant works of literature, philosophy, visual arts, music and/or film; intensive reading and writing to develop knowledge of analytical techniques in the humanities. Limited to freshmen and sophomores.

description: Registration Restriction: Open only to masters students.

description: Comprehensive exploration of particular aspects of the history of art.

title: BISC 419L Environmental Microbiology
description: Qualitative and quantitative appraisal of microbial activities in pure and contaminated environments; microbial community and its development; interspecific relationships; effects of microorganisms on their surroundings.

title: BISC 414 Biology of Cancer
description: Focus on the advances in molecular biology of cancer, from fundamental molecular signaling pathways to DNA repair to stem cell biology, through primary research literature reviews.

title: BISC 411 Advanced Cell Biology
description: The synthesis, transport and assembly of the complex structures that mediate eukaryotic cellular function. Electrical and biochemical mechanisms underlying intercellular communication.

title: BISC 410 Applications of Molecular Biology to Medicine
description: Advances and trends in the understanding, diagnosis and treatment of human diseases.

title: BISC 408 Systems Neuroscience: From Synapses to Perception
description: Sensory systems to illustrate basic concepts regarding the functional organization of the brain, from the microscopic arrangement of neural circuits to global processes such as perception.

title: BISC 407 Cellular and Molecular Neuroscience
description: An examination of individual nerve cell development, target location, and establishment of functional synapses; how dysfunction in these processes contributes to neurological and neuropsychiatric diseases.

title: BISC 406L Biotechnology
description: Techniques in molecular biology and biochemistry applied to prokaryotic and eukaryotic model systems; applications of recombinant DNA and genomic technology.

title: BISC 588L Quantitative Analysis for Biological and Earth Sciences
description: Basics of biometrics, biodiversity, quantitative methods in ecology, environmental impact assessments and other topics in quantitative analysis.

title: BISC 587 Communicating Ocean Science
description: Multi-instructor, interdisciplinary course focused on student awareness and improvement of cognitive processes used in research development, and communication of ocean literacy in the public sector.

title: BISC 405L General Embryology
description: Vertebrate and human development: cellular differentiation; germ cell development and growth; hormonal regulation of reproductive cycles; cleavage through neurulation and subsequent development of primary organs.

title: BISC 585 Scientific Writing and Reviewing
description: Hands-on experience writing and reviewing scientific literature. The review process and participation in writing and reviewing their own proposals.

title: BISC 586 Biological Oceanographic Instrumentation
description: Survey of analytical principles, theory and application behind commonly used methodologies in biological oceanography.

title: BISC 584 Faculty Lecture Series
description: Multi- instructor course designed to introduce students to the breadth and depth of faculty interests within the Marine Environmental Biology section of Biological Sciences and the Natural History Museum.

title: BISC 583 Evolution and Adaptation of Marine Organisms
description: Fundamentals of evolutionary patterns and processes in the marine environment, with emphasis on rates of adaptation to a changing ocean.

title: BISC 582 Advanced Biological Oceanography
description: Aspects of physics and chemistry of the oceans. Qualitative and quantitative considerations of the ecology of pelagic and benthic communities.

title: BISC 581L Current Problems in Marine Sciences
description: In-depth studies on selected problems of current interest in the marine sciences.

title: BISC 577b Computational Molecular Biology Laboratory
description: Practical experience in computational molecular biology applications. Mathematical and statistical software packages relevant to genomic analysis. Retrieval and analysis of genomic data from databases.

title: ART 594b Master's Thesis
description: Registration Restriction: Open only to masters students.

title: ART 594a Master's Thesis
description: Registration Restriction: Open only to masters students.

title: ART 590 Directed Research
description: Research leading to graduate degree. Maximum units which may be applied to degree determined by department.

title: ART 535 Group Critique
description: Presentation and critique which builds students' skills in presenting and contextualizing their artwork for peer review; analytic discussion regarding directions in contemporary art.

title: ART 530 Global Art Seminar: the Globalization of Art and Culture
description: An examination of the emergence of the idea of "globalism" through the lens of art practice and theory.

title: ART 520 Individual Studies
description: Investigation of creative problems through various media. Course may be repeated.

title: ART 499 Special Topics
description: Comprehensive exploration of particular aspects of visual art.

title: ART 515 Visiting Artist and Scholar Seminar
description: Lecture and discussion course in the professional practice of art featuring formal presentations by visiting artists and scholars.

title: ART 494a Senior Thesis
description: Individual research under guidance of faculty member for senior-level BFA students, leading to a substantial paper or other project.

title: ART 494b Senior Thesis
description: Individual research under the guidance of faculty for senior level BFA students, leading to a substantial paper or project.

title: BISC 390 Special Problems
description: Supervised, individual studies. No more than one registration permitted. Enrollment by petition only.

title: BISC 403 Advanced Molecular Biology
description: Molecular mechanisms and control of DNA replication, DNA repair, recombination, gene expression, cell growth, and development in prokaryotic and eukaryotic organisms, from bacteria to humans.

title: BISC 371L Molecular Approaches to the Diversity of Life
description: Patterns of evolutionary change investigating the molecular basis of heredity utilizing DNA data. History, principles and application of molecular systematics, and genetic variation. Taught on Catalina Island.

title: BISC 352 Conservation Biology
description: Principles of conservation science in marine and terrestrial ecosystems with emphasis on protecting biological diversity and balancing the needs of nature with those of humans.

title: BISC 330L Biochemistry
description: Basic biochemical principles; classes of molecules - structure and function; cellular energetics.

title: BISC 576 Practical Statistics and Bioinformatics
description: Practical experience in statistics and bioinformatics methods, software packages applicable to molecular biology, genomics analysis, and structural bioinformatics and their underlying principles.

title: BISC 320L Molecular Biology
description: Structure and synthesis of nucleic acids and proteins; molecular biology of prokaryotes and eukaryotes; principles of genetics and cell biology.

title: BISC 549 Seminar in Integrative and Evolutionary Biology
description: Current topics in integrative and evolutionary biology.

title: ART 525 Making and Curating Art: Pedagogy and Praxis
description: Provides students with a foundation in the history and theory of studio art and curatorial education and develops their teaching skills in these areas.

title: BISC 325 Genetics
description: Transmission genetics and genotype/phenotype; mapping methods; complex traits; genetics of human disease and population genetics.

title: BISC 545 Modeling and Numerical Techniques for Marine Scientists
description: Statistical analyses of data sets, development of modeling frameworks, numerical models of varying complexity, and techniques for analyzing model results.

title: BISC 321 Multidisciplinary Seminar: Science, Technology and Society
description: Builds upon a basic science background to provide students with an awareness of cutting edge scientific research, its technological applications and its societal ramifications.

title: BISC 544 Advanced Reading in Molecular Biology
description: Registration Restriction: Open only to master and doctoral students in Computational Molecular Biology, Molecular Biology, Computational Biology and Bioinformatics majors

title: BISC 542 Seminar in Molecular Biology
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: ART 490x Directed Research
description: Credit Restriction: Not available for graudate credit

title: BISC 538 Metals and Biology in Oceanic Regimes
description: Relationships between metals in reducing regimes and microbes that utilize them for metalloenzymes. Focus on biological availability of micronutrient and processes like chemoautotrophy or biomineralization.

title: BISC 335 Science, Health and the Environment
description: Exploration of environmentally transmitted human diseases; understanding the human/pathogen/environment nexus that leads to disease in human populations; disease transmission reduction.

title: ART 484 Contemporary Issues in Art
description: An advanced studio and discussion course aims to expand a student's relationship to, and understanding of, contemporary artistic dissemination, discourse, and display via a series of rotating topics.

title: ART 485 Studio Capstone
description: A faculty-mentored course supporting advanced conceptual exploration and the development of an ambitious, self-defined series or body of work, culminating in an exhibition.

title: ART 480 International Art Study Tour
description: An immersive experience in the artistic culture of a specific city or region that includes a short (less than two weeks) international trip.

title: BISC 369L Ecology and the Natural History of California
description: Marine, freshwater, and terrestrial communities of California. Life histories, morphology, special evolutionary adaptations. Relationships between organisms and their biological-physical-chemical environment. Offered on Catalina. Emphasis on field biology.

title: ART 460 Post-Material Studio
description: Advanced studio and discussion course that affords the student a conceptual and practical platform from which to discuss and realize a major work or series.

title: ART 470 Topics in Advanced Printmaking
description: Directed examination of specific printmaking media in relation to personal aesthetic goals and expressive concepts.

title: ART 450 Topics in Advanced Photography
description: In-depth exploration of photographic and artistic concepts as they apply to the articulation of personal work.

title: ART 442 Art and Technology
description: An interdisciplinary course between art and engineering that addresses creative thinking in the manipulation of media and the communication of ideas.

title: BISC 572 Systems Physiology and Disease I
description: Mammalian organ systems operation during health, and pathophysiologic analysis of related diseases with focus on muscle, respiratory, cardiovascular and renal systems. Faculty from basic and clinical sciences. Open to graduate students in biomedical science only.

title: BISC 315L Introduction to Ecology
description: Organism-environment interactions; dynamics of populations, communities, and ecosystems; evolutionary forces.

title: BISC 574 Systems Physiology and Disease II
description: Mammalian organ systems operation during health, and pathophysiologic analysis of related diseases with focus on neuroscience, immunology, metabolism, endocrine, reproduction, GI and liver. Faculty from basic and clinical sciences. Open to graduate students in biomedical science only.

title: BISC 312x Molecular Biochemistry

title: BISC 313L Evolution and Population Genetics
description: History of evolutionary thought; molecular basis for evolution; dynamics of genes in populations; speciation and macro evolution; patterns of evolution.

title: BISC 305 Introduction to Statistics for Biologists
description: Statistical methods in biological science and medicine, including populations and samples, random sampling, confidence intervals, paired samples and regression.

title: BISC 307L General Physiology
description: Physiological functions of the circulatory, digestive, endocrine, integumentary, musculoskeletal, nervous, respiratory, and urogenital systems of animals.

title: BISC 300L Introduction to Microbiology
description: Comparative approach to bacteria, Archaea and viruses; their structure, life cycles, geochemical activity, ecology and nutrition. Fundamentals of metabolism and microbial genetics.

title: BISC 230Lgx The Biology of the Brain
description: The structure and function of the mammalian brain including the role of the brain in regulating behavior, both in normal and diseased states; in relation to mind; and in comparison with machine forms of intelligence.

title: BISC 221Lg Advanced General Biology: Cell Biology and Physiology
description: Equivalent to 220L, but taught at a higher level for exceptionally well-prepared students. Admission to the course by departmental approval only.

title: BISC 290 Introduction to Biological Research
description: Experience in basic techniques through supervised research in the research laboratory of a departmental faculty member.

title: BISC 220Lg General Biology: Cell Biology and Physiology
description: In-depth survey of key topics related to advances in our knowledge of cellular biology and physiology; cell composition/metabolism; gene action; organism structure and function.

title: BISC 199 Neuroscience Colloquium
description: Introduction to research activities conducted by Neuroscience faculty at USC.

title: BISC 194 Introduction to Research II
description: A series of lectures and discussions at which faculty of the department introduce their research activities to students entering biology and related majors.

title: BISC 537 Seminar in Cellular and Molecular Biology
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: ART 440 Topics in Advanced Sculpture
description: Individual direction of the study of aesthetic issues in sculpture; investigation of an individual creative vision.

title: BISC 180Lgx Evolution
description: Changes in the physical and biological universe over time; origins of life, dinosaurs, human evolution. Implications of evolutionary mechanisms and mass extinctions for human survival.

title: BISC 193 Introduction to Research I
description: A series of lectures and discussions at which faculty of the department introduce their research activities to students entering biology and related majors.

title: BISC 150Lgx The Nature of Human Health and Disease
description: The human organism; the nature of inherited and acquired diseases; the biological and societal basis for the AIDS epidemic; therapy, drug design and the future.

title: BISC 140g Our Blue Planet in a Changing Climate
description: Introduction to biological oceanography and marine ecosystems. Impact of climate changes on marine ecosystems. Analysis of ocean-related case studies being discussed by mainstream media.

title: BISC 121Lg Advanced General Biology: Organismal Biology and Evolution
description: , but taught at a higher level for exceptionally well-prepared students. Admission to the course by departmental approval only.

title: BISC 120Lg General Biology: Organismal Biology and Evolution
description: In-depth survey of key topics related to advances in our knowledge of the diversity of life and evolution; origin of life; eukaryotes/prokaryotes; ecology.

title: BISC 110g Good Genes, Bad Genes
description: Introduction to the scientific method; basic instruction in molecular biology with emphasis on how biological research advancement has impacted medicine, commerce and society in general.

title: BISC 115Lxg The Biology of Food
description: Exploration of molecular biology, biochemistry, microbiology, nutrition and the history of biology through the study of food, focusing on food's relationship to the biological world.

title: BISC 108L Special Laboratory I
description: for entering freshmen or transfer students with advanced placement or equivalent lecture credit from another institution.

title: BISC 109L Special Laboratory II
description: for entering freshmen or transfer students with advanced placement or equivalent lecture credit from another institution.

title: BISC 104Lgx How the Body Works
description: Structure and function of the human body, including the role of organ systems, tissues, and cells in normal function. Malfunctions relating to disease, substance abuse and lifestyle.

title: ART 390 Special Problems
description: Supervised, individual studies. No more than one registration permitted. Enrollment by petition only.

title: BISC 103Lgx General Biology for the Environment and Life

title: ART 370 Printmaking

title: ART 380 Studio Critique II

title: ART 320 Advanced Painting

title: ART 310 Advanced Drawing

title: ART 240 Sculpture II

title: ART 230 Wheel Throwing

title: ART 210 Drawing II

title: ART 220 Painting II

title: ARCH 605aL Graduate Architecture Design II
description: Basic principles of structural (seismic/wind and gravity), HVAC, building envelope, access/egress, building service systems; and sustainable strategies are critical to the proper execution of performative goals. The integration of building systems will be delineated to demonstrate the tectonic viability a design solution.

title: ARCH 605bL Graduate Architecture Design II
description: Comprehensive project emphasizing the interaction between general principles and local sites, building technologies and total building design.

title: BIOC 590 Directed Research
description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

title: BIOC 581 Toolbox for Biochemistry and Molecular Biology
description: Explores the principles and applications of traditional and state-of-the-art methods in molecular biology and biochemistry with live demonstrations of techniques when feasible.

title: BIOC 575 Predictive and Prognostic Biomarkers in Cancer Treatment
description: Exploration of how appropriate biomarkers can predict response to cancer therapy, tumor recurrence after surgery, rapid detection of tumor response and overall prognosis.

title: BIOC 573 Optimal Research Presentations by PhD Students
description: Students will attend lectures by peers, and after their first year in the PhD program, prepare and present their own research to an audience of faculty and peers.

title: BIOC 557 Biochemistry of Anti-Cancer Agents
description: Explore how the development of various classes of anti-cancer drugs came about: the rationales behind their design, what was discovered about their biochemical mechanisms of action and whether their clinical activities came up to the original expectations. Other aspects such as the origin of the concepts of combination chemotherapy and biochemical modulation will also be addressed.

title: BIOC 543 Human Molecular Genetics
description: Comprehensive course covering basic principles of human genetics, genetic disease, the Human Genome Project, and gene therapy.

title: BIOC 542 Cellular and Molecular Basis of Animal Development
description: Processes of cell type specification, determination, and morphogenesis in metazoans from vertebrates to insects. Genetic, paragenetic and molecular biological approaches to developmental processes.

title: BIOC 536 Molecular Biology of Cellular Communication in the Nervous System
description: Discussion of cellular communications in the nervous system through neurotransmitters and their receptors, neuromodulators; biochemical changes during development and the impact of human genomic research.

title: BIOC 510 Introductory Molecular Biology
description: Principles of molecular biology with applications to the medical sciences. Nucleic acid structure, function, and analysis.

title: BIOC 522 Applications of Physical Methods in Biochemistry
description: Applications of physical analytical methods commonly utilized in research in biochemistry and molecular biology.

title: BIOC 502 Biochemistry Seminar
description: Formal presentations and discussion by students of material from research literature.

title: BAEP 599 Special Topics
description: Registration Restriction: Online registration open to only graduate accounting and business students.

title: BIOC 501 Recent Advances in Biochemistry
description: Lectures on areas of intermediary metabolism and the chemistry of natural products.

title: ARCH 599 Special Topics
description: Selected topics in various specialty areas of architecture.

title: BAEP 598 Special Topics
description: Registration Restriction: Online registration open to only graduate accounting and business students

title: BIOC 571 Biochemistry
description: Physical-chemical basis of life processes: protein structure and enzyme function; synthesis and metabolism of carbohydrates, lipids, amino acids, and nucleotides.

title: BIOC 561 Molecular Biology
description: Biochemistry and molecular biology of replication, transcription, RNA processing, translation, and regulation of gene expression with emphasis on multicellular eukaryotic organisms and comparisons to prokaryotes.

title: BIOC 555 Biochemical and Molecular Bases of Disease
description: Biochemical and molecular abnormalities in disease states.

title: BAEP 597 Consulting Project in Business Entrepreneurship
description: Individual or team project solving real business problems for an existing business entity, domestic and/or international. Proposal, field research, analyses and oral and written presentations.

title: BIOC 549 Protein Chemistry – Structure and Function
description: Chemistry of peptides and proteins; protein structure and folding; molecular basis of protein action.

title: BAEP 595 Internship in Business Entrepreneurship
description: Supervised on-the-job business experience in the student's area of interest. (Curricular Practical Training.) Recommended preparation: completion of required MBA, MAcc, MBT, MKT, MSEI, or MSSE course work.

title: BAEP 596 Research Practicum in Business Entrepreneurship
description: Hands-on practical experience working with a faculty member in the Lloyd Greif Center for Entrepreneurial Studies on an ongoing research project.

title: BIOC 551 Prokaryotic Molecular Genetics
description: Macromolecular processes and their regulation in prokaryotes; DNA replication, transcription, and post-transcriptional events in general and as related to operons, phage biology, and eukaryotic organelles.

title: BAEP 593 Independent Research in Business Entrepreneurship
description: Independent research beyond normal course offerings. Proposal, research and written report/paper required.

title: BAEP 592 Field Research in Business Entrepreneurship
description: Individual or team projects studying the business practices of an entrepreneurial industry, company, government agency, country, etc. Proposal, data collection, analyses, and written report. (Recommended Preparation: completion of required MBA, MAcc, MBT, MKT, MSEI or MSSE course work)

title: BIOC 531 Cell Biology
description: Current perspectives on major research areas in cell biology. Emphasis will be on in-depth examination of cellular structures, regulatory processes, intra-cellular routing and targeting, and cell/environmental interactions.

title: BAEP 591 Social Entrepreneurship
description: Lead and manage with entrepreneurial methodology for charities, non-government organizations, social oriented enterprises and not for profit organizations.

title: BIOC 504 Molecular Biology of Cancer
description: Epidemiology, pathobiology, carcinogenesis, tumor biology and heterogeneity; retroviruses, oncogenes, cell cycle control, genetics of cancer, tumor immunology; treatment strategies.

title: BAEP 590 Directed Research
description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

title: BAEP 575 Entrepreneurship in the Media and Entertainment Industry
description: Introduction to the ever-evolving field of media and entertainment with a focus on entrepreneurial opportunities within the industry.

title: BAEP 571 Social Innovation Design
description: Use innovative problem-solving approaches to design radically affordable solutions to challenges faced by under-resourced communities. Engage in early-stage market and rapid prototyping.

title: BAEP 567 Social Entrepreneurship:  Design, Develop, and Deliver
description: Develop the analytical, conceptual, and practical skills required to design, develop, and deliver a new social business concept and opportunity.

title: BAEP 564 Investing in Impact Ventures
description: Exploring the field of social impact investing, learn how social entrepreneurs attract for-profit investors and how conscious investors are utilizing investments to achieve social impact.

title: BAEP 566 Cases in Feasibility Analysis for Social Ventures
description: Study of analytical techniques used to evaluate business concepts with a specific focus on the development of a new social venture.

title: BAEP 563 Corporate Entrepreneurship
description: How established organizations build successful new businesses through corporate venturing and intrapreneurship. Learn to apply an entrepreneurial mindset and entrepreneurial frameworks within an established organization.

title: BAEP 562 Entrepreneurship in eCommerce
description: Registration Restriction: Online registration open to only graduate and business students

title: BAEP 561 Entrepreneurship in Innovative Industries: Life Sciences
description: The challenges of new venture creation in the biotechnology, medical device, and healthcare areas; experience, evaluate, and analyze profits of current impact in the life sciences.

title: BAEP 560 Acquiring Your Own Business or Opportunity
description: Issues faced by the entrepreneur who wishes to acquire an enterprise; appropriateness of an enterprise, understanding funding sources and valuation methods, developing a plan for due diligence, negotiating and consummating the transaction. The acquisition process, approaches to valuation, and the roles of the various parties in negotiating and consummating an acquisition of an existing business.

title: BAEP 559 Investing in New Ventures
description: Focus on the entrepreneurial skill set applied to new venture opportunities. Taught from the business plan reader's point of view; focus on selecting opportunities, structuring the relationship, adding value and realizing the value of that investment.

title: BAEP 556 Technology Feasibility
description: Learn critical thinking and analytical skills they need to evaluate, value, and manage technology as intellectual property. Understand the technology commercialization process, use data mining and assessment techniques for patent databases, and study the unique business issues facing high technology start-ups.

title: BAEP 557 Technology Commercialization
description: Identification, evaluation and commercialization of new technologies. Emphasis will be placed on the legal, financial and marketing aspects of technology transfer and development.

title: BAEP 558 The Entrepreneurial Advisor: Problem Solving for Early-Stage Companies
description: Experiential course designed to develop skills in framing and solving complex problems in young companies. Apply skills to real ventures participating in course projects.

title: BAEP 553 Cases in New Venture Management
description: Cases and readings expose students to the challenges of developing long-range strategies for entrepreneurial ventures. Case work emphasizes developing new industries, growth through strategic alliances, and issues involved in the long-term strategic positioning of emerging companies.

title: BAEP 555 Founder's Dilemmas: Anticipate and Avoid Startup Pitfalls
description: Delves into founders' early decisions about when and whether to found, co-founders, hires, and investors that tend to get them into trouble down the road.

title: BAEP 554 Venture Initiation
description: Learn to launch and scale a new business through entrepreneurial action and execution.

title: BAEP 551 Introduction to New Ventures
description: Study and development of analytical and conceptual skills in the management of new enterprises and new ventures within large organizations.

title: BAEP 550 Entrepreneurship and Venture Management
description: Registration Restriction: Online registration limited to graduate business and accounting students

title: BAEP 499 Special Topics
description: Current developments in the field of entrepreneurship: topics to be selected each semester.

title: BAEP 549 The Entrepreneurial Journey
description: An introduction to entrepreneurship with a focus on opportunity recognition and the entrepreneurial mindset. Development of knowledge and skills in launching new ventures.

title: BAEP 495 Practicum in Business Issues (Internship)
description: Combined classroom discussion and field application of business theories and practices; part-time internship employment. Project to be jointly defined by student, employer and professor.

title: BAEP 497 Field Project in Entrepreneurship
description: Individual or team projects solving real problems for an enterprise. Situation analyses; research proposal composition; field research techniques; statistical analysis; oral and written presentations.

title: BAEP 552 Cases in Feasibility Analysis
description: Registration Restriction: Online registration open only to graduate business and accounting majors.

title: BAEP 491 Introduction to Social Entrepreneurship
description: Analysis of social enterprise models from micro-finance to job development. Analysis of basic issues regarding the difference between socially responsible companies, for-profit, and non-profit-run enterprises.

title: BAEP 480 Entrepreneurial Family Business
description: Explores the dynamics of family and privately held businesses. Exploring generational and extended family issues, opportunities and obstacles faced in today's environment.

title: BAEP 475 Entertainment Entrepreneurship
description: Explore the current entrepreneurial trends and opportunities in the entertainment industry and uncover the key success factors for entrepreneurs in this industry.

title: BAEP 496 The Digital Startup Launchpad
description: Real-life challenge of imagining, prototyping, testing and iterating, building, pricing, marketing, distributing and selling a digital product or service.

title: BAEP 474 The Entrepreneur's Guide to Intellectual Property
description: The fundamentals of intellectual property -- its value, its basic workings, and its role in entrepreneurship, business in general, science, the arts, and the professions.

title: BAEP 472 The Science of Peak Performance
description: Ingrains expertise and application of the science of peak performance, broadens preparation for personal challenge, and builds business-centered critical thinking and applied analytical skills.

title: BAEP 469 Growth Hacking: Scaling Startups
description: Accelerate the growth of an entrepreneurial business with applied analytics tools and methods.

title: BAEP 465 Digital Playbook for Entrepreneurs: Creating a Tech Startup
description: Learn to use digital tools and technologies, such as social media, mobile, cloud computing, and e-commerce, to start and grow entrepreneurial ventures.

title: BAEP 471 Social Innovation Design Lab
description: Introduction to design thinking as applied to innovation and entrepreneurship. Hands-on projects to create solutions to specific societal problems faced by underprivileged communities.

title: BAEP 470 The Entrepreneurial Mindset — Taking the Leap
description: A deeper insight into the entrepreneurial mind, how it approaches opportunities and challenges and gives leadership to an organization.

title: BAEP 455 Founder's Dilemmas
description: Prepares potential founders, hires, and investors for the decisions they will face both before and during their involvement with new ventures.

title: BAEP 460 Seminar in Entrepreneurship
description: Perspectives into the art and science of entrepreneurship under the guidance of a master instructor. Specific topics vary.

title: BAEP 454 Venture Initiation: Launching and Scaling Your Startup
description: Learn to build a startup from concept to reality. Focus on real-world entrepreneurial action and execution.

title: BAEP 451 The Management of New Enterprises
description: Development of analytical and conceptual skills in entrepreneurship and venture management.

title: BAEP 453 Venture Management
description: Design and application of organization structures and systems in management of new ventures.

title: BAEP 452 Feasibility Analysis
description: Students develop, analyze, and validate entrepreneurial concepts (including marketing, operational, and financial considerations) using customer feedback and risk assessment to conclude worthiness to pursue.

title: BAEP 423 Management of Small Businesses
description: Duplicates Credit in BAEP 310 and BAEP 450 and BAEP 451 and BUAD 301.

title: BAEP 450 Fundamentals of Entrepreneurship
description: Starting and managing one's own business: developing a viable concept, organizing the enterprise, market and financial planning, and controlling the organization.

title: BAEP 310 Launching Disruptive Ventures
description: Fundamentals of entrepreneurship tracing new venture evolution, including recognition of disruptive opportunities, entrepreneurial financial analysis, and understanding the innovator's and investor's mindsets.

title: ASTR 740 Selected Topics in Astrophysics
description: Selected topics in cosmology. Course content includes dark matter, dark energy, gravitational lensing, the cosmic microwave background, inflation, galaxy and galaxy cluster surveys.

title: ASTR 490x Directed Research
description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

title: ASTR 450 Stellar Astrophysics
description: Observation and theory of stellar atmospheres and stellar interiors. Theory of stellar evolution. Physical and astronomical significance of the end states of stellar evolution.

title: ASTR 424 Cosmology
description: Concepts of space-time, general relativity applied to an homogeneous and expanding universe. Universe's content and thermal history. Introduction to current observational tests of cosmology.

title: ASTR 540 Advanced Cosmology
description: Perturbed Einstein's and Boltzman equations, Universe's content, anisotropies: initial conditions, linear evolution, comparison with observations.

title: ASTR 422 Galaxies and Large-Scale Structures in the Universe
description: Galaxies and clusters of galaxies: their content, structure, dynamics, distribution, and motions; the cosmic microwave background: theory and observation; elements of observational cosmology.

title: ASTR 400 The Solar System
description: Earth's motions; planets and their satellites; comets; meteorites; interplanetary matter; elementary celestial mechanics.

title: ASTR 390 Special Problems
description: Supervised, individual studies. No more than one registration permitted. Enrollment by petition only.

title: ASTR 200Lg Life in the Universe
description: Survey of the prospects for life in our solar system and beyond, based on the evolution of life on Earth.

title: ASTR 104L Special Laboratory
description: for transfer students with equivalent lecture credit from another institution. For transfer students only.

title: ASTR 100Lgx The Universe
description: Survey of the universe: planets, satellites, comets, stars, nebulae, galaxies. Practical component includes planetary observations and dark-sky field trip.

description: Grading Option: In-progress & Credit/No Credit

description: Grading Option: In-progress & Credit/No Credit

description: Provides the methodological tools to identify research problems, develop researchable hypotheses, apply appropriate methodologies, conduct research, derive meaningful conclusions from data, write a research proposal.

title: BUAD 494 Marshall Honors Research and Thesis
description: Experience in conducting research and writing a thesis under the supervision of a faculty adviser.

description: Supervised, individual studies. No more than one registration permitted. Enrollment by petition only.

title: BUAD 350 Macroeconomic Analysis for Business Decisions

description: Statistical methods for business analysis; data exploration and description; sampling distributions; estimation; hypothesis testing, simple and multiple regression; model building. Extensive computer applications.

title: BUAD 307 Marketing Fundamentals
description: Develops a managerial viewpoint in planning and evaluating marketing decisions of the firm: products, pricing, channels, promotion, information processing, legal implications, and marketing in contemporary society.

title: BUAD 302T Communication Strategy in Accounting
description: Theory, practices, and techniques essential to communication in accounting. Interpersonal and group communication; oral presentations; writing; use of communication technologies; communication strategies for varied audiences.

title: BUAD 302 Communication Strategy in Business
description: Theory, practices, and techniques of business communication strategy essential to external and organizational communication; group and interpersonal communication; development of skill in oral and written communication.

title: BUAD 304 Organizational Behavior and Leadership
description: The role of leadership in business organizations; concepts and skills for managing oneself and others.

title: BUAD 301 Technology Entrepreneurship
description: Starting and managing a technological business: developing a viable concept, market and financial planning, product development, organizing the venture, protecting intellectual property rights.

title: BUAD 305 Abridged Core Concepts of Accounting Information
description: Uses of accounting information in decision-making; accounting issues concerning income and cash flows, economic resources and capital.

description: : accounting information useful for the analysis of the income statement, balance sheet and cash flow statement.

title: BUAD 286a Accounting Fundamentals, Managerial and Financial Accounting
description: Development and use of accounting information important to executives, managers, and other decision-makers, with a focus on the analysis of business operations and organizational performance.

title: BUAD 285a Accounting Fundamentals, Financial and Managerial Accounting
description: Development and use of accounting information important to investors and professionals with a focus on the analysis of business operations, financial position, and cash flows.

title: BUAD 285b Accounting Fundamentals, Financial and Managerial Accounting
description: : accounting information useful for the analysis of product costing, budgeting and organizational performance.

title: BUAD 281 Introduction to Managerial Accounting
description: An emphasis on how accounting information, combined with a variety of techniques and best practices, supports enhanced management decision making.

title: BUAD 280 Introduction to Financial Accounting
description: Emphasis on understanding financial statements and the impact of business transactions on information presented to management and interested stakeholders.

title: BUAD 252 Choosing and Planning a Future Career in Business
description: Explore and plan for future career choices and options in business. Learn theoretical principles, best practices and strategies, and contemporary workplace issues/trends.

title: BUAD 215x Foundations of Business Finance
description: Principles and practices of modern financial management; use of financial statements; valuation of investment; asset pricing under uncertainty; elements of financial decisions.

title: BUAD 201x Introduction to Business for Non-Majors
description: Introduction to the principles and practices of businesses, sequence of exercises developing the basic skills, and influence of the economy on business and individual decisions.

title: BUAD 206 Transfer International Experience

title: BUAD 206a Transfer International Experience
description: Experiential study of international business. Analysis of the impacts of global and international business on an industry. International travel required.

title: BUAD 206b Transfer International Experience
description: Experiential study of international business. Analysis of the impacts of global and international business on an industry. International travel required.

title: BUAD 204 Global Business from a Local Perspective
description: Concepts, frameworks and cultural insights into global business. Includes readings, group projects and visits with Los Angeles area companies that have an international presence.

title: BUAD 105 The Business Experience
description: Introduction to and overview of key business functions, their relationships, and how various professional disciplines come together to help form a successful enterprise.

title: BUAD 200x Economic Foundations for Business
description: Examines fundamental concepts of both microeconomics and macroeconomics as they pertain to business and financial decisions.

title: BUAD 101 Freshman Leadership Seminar
description: Colloquium of leading researchers, authors, and administrators in the Marshall School of Business and other schools at USC. Industry leaders will also be invited to talk about leadership challenges.

title: BUAD 100x Foundations of Finance and Accounting
description: Accounting information in decision-making from the perspective of users and preparers. Basics of financial asset valuation. Consideration of time-value of money and risk.

title: BUAD 104 Learning About International Commerce
description: Provides insight into the opportunities and challenges faced by business professionals operating in a global environment by focusing on international cultural norms.

title: BUAD 102 Global Leadership Seminar
description: Colloquium of researchers and industry leaders discussing international business and the challenges faced by leaders in a global environment, with a specific focus on China. International travel may require additional fees.

title: BUAD 040 Executive Development
description: Problems and cases in contemporary management and business economics in American society.

description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: BUAD 020x Survey of Business Administration
description: Survey of the important topics in business administration, including marketing, accounting, finance, management information systems, leadership, business communication, and human resource management.

description: Mathematical theories and computation techniques for modeling physiological systems, with emphasis on cardiorespiratory, metabolicendocrine, and neuronal functions.

description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

description: Design of measurement systems and biomedical instrumentation; architecture of electronic instruments used to measure physiological parameters, analysis of major process functions integrated in these instruments.

title: BME 671 Late Visual Processing
description: Interdisciplinary topics in biological and artificial high-level visual processing. Visual cortex; computer vision; neurophysiology; psychophysics; MRI; computational models; orientation selectivity; steropsis; motion; contours; object recognition.

title: BME 670 Early Visual Processing
description: Interdisciplinary topics in biological and artificial low-level visual processing. Retina, lateral geniculate nucleus; computer vision; neurophysiology, retinal prosthesis; molecular biology, phototransduction; edge detection; movement.

description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: BME 620L Applied Electrophysiology
description: The theoretical basis and applied design principles for medical devices and instrumentation that interact with electrically excitable tissues of the body.

title: BME 594a Master's Thesis
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: BME 599 Special Topics
description: Current trends and developments in the field of biomedical engineering.

title: BME 594b Master's Thesis
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: BME 590 Directed Research
description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

title: BME 575L Computational Neuroengineering
description: Introduction to computational modeling in neuroengineering, anchored in examples of brain function. Topics include transduction, synapses, spiking, networks, normalization, learning, Bayesian models, and Kalman filtering.

title: BME 567b Case Studies in Health, Technology and Engineering
description: Learning from cases illustrating paths from health care problems to solutions. Faculty, students and invited guests will provide examples of both successful and unsuccessful innovation attempts.

title: BME 567a Case Studies in Health, Technology and Engineering
description: Learning from cases illustrating paths from health care problems to solutions. Faculty, students and invited guests will provide examples of both successful and unsuccessful innovation attempts.

title: BME 566c Topics in Health, Technology and Engineering
description: Interdisciplinary approach to impart the skills, knowledge and familiarity with stages of collaborative projects related to medical device and methods innovation in health care settings.

title: BME 566d Topics in Health, Technology and Engineering
description: Interdisciplinary approach to impart the skills, knowledge and familiarity with stages of collaborative projects related to medical device and methods innovation in health care settings.

description: Interdisciplinary approach to impart the skills, knowledge and familiarity with stages of collaborative projects related to medical device and methods innovation in health care settings.

title: BME 566a Topics in Health, Technology and Engineering
description: Interdisciplinary approach to impart the skills, knowledge and familiarity with stages of collaborative projects related to medical device and methods innovation in health care settings.

title: BME 559 Nanomedicine and Drug Delivery
description: Drug delivery and nanoengineered materials; cutting-edge nanoparticle-based therapy; imaging and tissue engineering; Nanotoxicology and regulatory landscape.

title: BME 552 Neural Implant Engineering
description: Advanced studies of the basic neuroscience, engineering design requirements and technological issues associated with implantable neural prostheses, with particular emphasis on retinal and cortical function.

title: BME 551 Introduction to Bio-MEMS and Nanotechnology
description: Principles and biomedical applications of micro-electromechanical systems (MEMS) and nanotechnology, including microfluidics, nanowire sensors, nanomotors, quantum dots, biofuel cells and molecular imaging.

title: BME 535 Ultrasonic Imaging
description: All aspects of ultrasonic imaging including ultrasound and tissue interaction, ultrasonic transducers, instrumentation, imaging methods, clinical applications, bioeffects, safety, and recent developments in the field.

title: BME 533 Seminar in Bioengineering
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: BME 536 Ultrasonic Transducers
description: Background and foundation covering the design, fabrication and testing of ultrasonic transducers and arrays. Design approaches, modeling tools will be discussed. Design project assigned.

title: BME 530 Introduction to Systems Biology
description: Computational methods for simulation and analysis of metabolic networks, cellular signaling pathways, and gene regulatory networks. Biochemical kinetics, differential equations, stability analysis, sensitivity analysis.

title: BME 528 Medical Diagnostics, Therapeutics and Informatics Applications
description: Picture archive communication system (PACS) design and implementation; clinical PACS-based imaging informatics; telemedicine/teleradiology; image content indexing, image data mining; grid computing in large-scale imaging informatics; image-assisted diagnosis, surgery and therapy.

title: BME 527 Integration of Medical Imaging Systems
description: Medical imaging quality, compression, data standards, workflow analysis and protocols, broadband networks, image security, fault tolerance, picture archive communication system (PACS), image database and backup.

title: BME 525 Advanced Biomedical Imaging
description: Advanced scientific and engineering principles of biomedical imaging including magnetic resonance, X-ray computed tomography, ultrasound, and single photon and positron emission tomography.

title: BME 523 Measurement and Processing of Biological Signals
description: Acquisition, analysis, and display of biological data using digital computers; laboratory applications of digital signal processing and real time analysis.

title: BME 582 CMOS:Nano Neuromorphic Circuits
description: Design and simulation of CMOS and nano electronic circuits modeling brain cells, including neurons and glial cells; low-power design; simulation laboratory.

title: BME 513 Signal and Systems Analysis

title: BME 511 Physiological Control Systems
description: Application of control theory to physiological systems; static analysis of closed-loop systems; time-domain analysis of linear control identification methods; nonlinear control.

title: BME 510 Cellular Systems Engineering
description: Introduction to the materials, tools, and techniques used to engineer functional biological tissues. Topics include stem cells, biomaterials, microfabrication, regenerative medicine, and Organs on Chips.

title: BME 505bL Laboratory Projects in Biomedical Engineering
description: Integration of biomedical science, engineering principles and state-of-the-art technology for the study of selected physiological systems in the laboratory setting. Laboratory.

title: BME 505aL Laboratory Projects in Biomedical Engineering
description: Integration of biomedical science, engineering principles and state-of-the-art technology for the study of selected physiological systems in the laboratory setting. Laboratory.

title: BME 506 Bioengineering of Disease and Cell Therapeutics
description: Introduction to micro-/nano-technologies, microscopy, single-cell techniques, materials, surface chemistry, pathology, cancer, immunology, cell therapy, and grant writing in biomedical research.

title: BME 504 Neuromuscular Systems
description: Introduces the fundamentals of mathematical, Newtonian, and robotic analysis applicable to multi-muscle biomechanical systems. Combines physiology with numerical simulations to understand and predict motor function.

title: BME 502 Advanced Studies of the Nervous System
description: Advanced topics on the structure and function of the nervous system examined from the viewpoint of computational systems science.

title: BME 501 Advanced Topics in Biomedical Systems
description: Advanced topics in selected biomedical systems: cardiopulmonary, neuromuscular, renal and endocrine.

title: BME 499 Special Topics
description: Current trends and developments in the field of biomedical engineering.

title: BME 490x Directed Research
description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

title: BME 459 Introduction to Nanomedicine and Drug Delivery
description: Introduction to drug delivery and biomedical applications of nanoengineered materials, including nanotechnology-based drug delivery, imaging, and tissue engineering approaches. Nanotoxicology and regulatory landscape is included.

title: BME 453 Engineering Biomedical Innovations
description: Engineering principles in design, modeling, and analysis of biomedical innovations will be presented to develop creative solutions for real-world medical problems or treatment implementation.

title: BME 452 Introduction to Biomimetic Neural Engineering
description: Engineering principles, biology, technological challenges and state-of-the-art developments in the design of implantable biomimetic microelectronic devices that interface with the nervous system.

title: BME 451 Fundamentals of Biomedical Microdevices
description: Introduction to biomedical microdevices with emphasis on microtechnologies and biomedical microelectromechanical systems (bioMEMS). Principles for measurement of small-scale biological phenomena and clinical applications.

title: BME 425 Basics of Biomedical Imaging
description: Engineering, clinical applications and modern physics concepts underlying X-ray imaging, Computed Tomography (CT), nuclear medicine, positron emission tomography, Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI), ultrasound imaging.

title: BME 423 Statistical Methods in Biomedical Engineering
description: Applications of parametric and nonparametric tests, analysis of variance, linear regression, time-series analysis, and autoregressive modeling, with biomedical applications to statistical analysis of biomedical data.

title: BME 416 Development and Regulation of Medical Products
description: An introduction to the process of medical product development with emphasis on the regulations that govern the design, fabrication, and maintenance of medical products.

title: BME 430 Principles and Applications of Systems Biology

description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: CE 560 Simulation of Civil Infrastructure Systems Performance

description: Elements and techniques of strategic planning for construction engineering. Fundamentals of engineering as a service sector enterprise. Assessment of markets (including international issues), competitors, and technology. Aspects of overseas engineering business. Management of technology and the role of R&D. Emphasis on concepts.

title: CE 557 Advanced Building Estimating
description: Processes in compiling a bid for construction of nonresidential building.

title: CE 556 Project Controls — Budgeting and Estimating

title: CE 555 Underwater Structures

title: CE 580 Law and Finance for Engineering Innovation

title: CE 581 Negotiation For Engineering Management

title: CE 554 Risk and Reliability Analysis for Civil Infrastructure Systems

title: CE 550 Computer-Aided Engineering

title: CE 547 Earthquake Engineering: Response of Structures

title: CE 545b Advanced Finite Element Method in Structural and Continuum Mechanics

title: CE 562 Aquatic Chemistry

title: CE 545a Advanced Finite Element Method in Structural and Continuum Mechanics

title: CE 544 Theory of Shell Structures

title: CE 543 Stability of Structures

title: CE 537 Advanced Reinforced Concrete

title: CE 535 Earthquake Engineering: Strong Motion Studies

title: CE 534 Design of Earth Structures

title: CE 536 Structural Design for Dynamic Loads

title: CE 530 Nonlinear Mechanics

title: CE 529b Finite Element Analysis

title: CE 529a Finite Element Analysis

title: CE 528 Seismic Analysis and Design of Reinforced Concrete Bridges

title: CE 522 Groundwater Hydrologic Modeling

title: CE 520b Ocean and Coastal Engineering

title: CE 523 Physiochemical Processes in Environmental Engineering

title: CE 520a Ocean and Coastal Engineering

title: CNTV 393 16mm Filmmaking: Structuring Scenes That Work

title: CNTV 370 3-D Animation for Film and Video

description: Social, cultural, and political history of Egypt from Alexander to Cleopatra; state formation; immigration and cultural interaction between ethnic groups.

title: CHEM 589 Macromolecular Crystallography
description: Advanced techniques and methods in X-ray crystal structure determination of biological macromolecules with emphasis on practical work.

title: CHEM 593x Practicum in Teaching Chemistry
description: Practical principles for effective teaching in the laboratory. Intended for teaching assistants in Chemistry.

title: CLAS 415 Object-Worlds: Histories and Theories of Things
description: Developing strategies for analyzing what material culture of the past can tell us about the individuals and cultures that interacted with it.

title: CHEM 588 Advanced Practical X-ray Structure Determination of Small Molecules
description: Advanced techniques and methods in small molecule X-ray crystal structure determination. Emphasis on practical and laboratory work.

title: CHEM 580 Current Topics in Inorganic Chemistry and Nanoscience
description: Introduction to emerging research areas in inorganic chemistry and nanoscience through a discussion of seminal research articles and presentations of current research topics.

title: CHEM 581 Current Topics in Sustainable Energy Generation and Storage
description: Introduction to emerging research areas in the chemistry of sustainable energy generation and storage through discussion of core research areas and presentations on current research.

title: CLAS 425 Interdisciplinary Studies in Classical Art and Archaeology: Research and Methodology
description: Each year a different topic in Greek and Roman art and archaeology will be examined in depth. Emphasis on interdisciplinary methodological approaches and research techniques.

title: CHEM 577b Medicinal Chemistry and Drug Design
description: Concepts, methods and examples of current approaches to drug design including computer-based molecular modeling techniques.

title: CHEM 577a Medicinal Chemistry and Drug Design
description: Introduction to fundamentals of medicinal chemistry with special attention to the drug discovery process.

title: CLAS 375 Alexander the Great
description: Ancient sources on Alexander's life, personality and conquests. Modern evaluations of his achievements as a prototype for autocracy and empire-building from antiquity to today.

title: CLAS 370 Leaders and Communities: Classical Models
description: Examination of political and moral leadership in classical republican, democratic, and imperial communities; consideration of how these models are useful to contemporary democracies.

title: CLAS 371 From Alexander to Cleopatra: The Mediterranean in an Age of Expansion
description: The history and culture of the Greek kingdoms in Egypt and Asia.

title: CLAS 349gp Ancient Empires
description: History and cultures of the ancient empires of southwest Asia, from Cyrus the Great to the establishment of Islam.

title: CLAS 348g Athens in the Age of Democracy and Empire
description: Democratic Institutions and practices, empire building, and cultural innovations of fifth and fourth century B.C. Athens using historical, rhetorical, dramatic, philosophical, and artistic sources.

title: CHEM 575 Modern Trends in Physical Chemistry
description: Emerging research areas in physical and theoretical chemistry through a thorough discussion of seminal research articles and presentations of current research topics.

title: CHEM 561 Polymer Synthesis
description: Concepts of polymer structure and stereochemistry. Organic chemistry of polymerization reactions with emphasis on condensation, radical, cationic, anionic, and coordination- - metathesis polymerization.

title: CHEM 570 Seminar in Chemical Biology
description: Introduce students to emerging research areas in chemical biology through a thorough discussion of seminal research articles and presentations of current research topics.

title: CLAS 340 Ethics and Politics in Ancient Rome
description: Introduction to ethical and political thought of classical Roman writers. Relationship between theory and practice. Implications for contemporary society.

title: CLAS 339 Ancient Science
description: Cross-cultural investigation of aims, origins, and transmission of various scientific traditions in antiquity. Relationship between science and philosophy, scientific thought and practice.

title: CLAS 337gp Ancient Drama
description: Satisfies Global Perspective in Category H: Traditions and Historical Foundations

title: CLAS 338 Warfare, State, and Society in the Ancient World
description: War, warriors, and their relationship to politics and culture in the ancient world. Mobilization, socioeconomic status of soldiers, discipline, organization, and hierarchy. Memory of war.

title: CHEM 555 Computational Quantum Chemistry: Methods and Applications
description: Introduction to modern computational quantum chemistry. Prediction of molecular structure, molecular spectra and molecular reaction mechanisms using ab initio and semi-empirical methods.

title: CHEM 565L Advanced Practical Nuclear Magnetic Resonance Spectroscopy
description: Application of multidimensional and time resolved NMR spectroscopy to problems in structure determination and thermochemistry.

title: CLAS 336 Rome and its Discontents: Literature and Social Change
description: A study of major literary texts in translation from early imperial Rome and their responses to profound political and social change.

title: CLAS 330 Ancients VS. Moderns
description: The history of the conflicts and compromises between advocates of antiquity and of modernity that continues to shape our own approaches to the past.

title: CLAS 328 Archaeology of Religion in the Greco- Roman World
description: Examination of ancient objects, images and archaeological sites as evidence for religious practice and ideas about the sacred in the GrecoRoman world.

title: CLAS 325 Ancient Epic
description: Representative epics of the Greek and Roman world; development of the character of the hero; later influences.

title: CLAS 324 Late Antique Art and Archaeology
description: Investigation of the transformation between classical antiquity and the middle ages through examination of cities, buildings, images and artifacts of the 3rd–8thcentury Mediterranean.

title: CLAS 333 Cult and City in Ancient Greece
description: Explores the relationship between civic and religious institutions in ancient Greece: city planning, warfare, mystery cults, drama, sacrifice, and women's rituals.

title: CLAS 323 Aegean Archaeology
description: Survey of the Bronze Age Aegean societies of Minoan Crete and Mycenaean Greece; emphasis on archaeological theory and method in a prehistoric context.

title: CLAS 320gmp Diversity and the Classical Western Tradition
description: Political, ethical, and ideological aspects of classical Western attitudes towards human diversity. Relationship between classical tradition and - contemporary discussions of diversity and unity.

title: CLAS 315 Sport and Spectacle in the Ancient World
description: The role of athletic training and competition in ancient society, from the Greek Olympic games to Roman gladiatorial combat and modern recreations.

title: CHEM 550 Special Topics in Chemical Physics
description: Study of selected areas of chemical physics. Critical evaluation of recent advances in the field.

title: CHEM 548 Computer Simulations of Chemical and Biological Systems
description: Key aspects of the rapidly growing field of computer simulation of molecular systems in general and biological molecules in particular.

title: CHEM 544 Introduction to Quantum Chemistry
description: Basic principles of quantum mechanics and their application to chemistry. Electronic structure of atoms and molecules.

title: CHEM 540 Introduction to Statistical Mechanics
description: Study of macroscopic systems from molecular viewpoint using statistical mechanics: ensembles, fluctuations, gases, gas-solid interfaces, crystals, polymers, critical phenomena, non-equilibrium systems.

title: CHEM 546 Mathematics in Physical Chemistry
description: Introduction to mathematical methods in physical chemistry and quantum mechanics: ordinary and partial differential equations, orthogonal polynomials, Fourier series, Fourier transforms, eigenvalue and matrix equations

title: CHEM 545 Theory and Practice of Molecular Electronic Structure
description: Provide working knowledge and hands-on experience in current quantum chemical methods for chemists who would like to employ these techniques in their own research.

title: CHEM 547 Numerical Calculations in Physical Chemistry
description: Introduction to numerical calculations in physical chemistry and quantum mechanics: translational and vibrational wavepackets, tunneling motions, particle in a potential, rotational-vibrational spectra of diatomic molecules.

title: CHEM 538 Mathematical Techniques of Physical Chemistry
description: Fundamentals and techniques of mathematics and physics. Linear algebra, differential equations, mechanics, electricity and magnetism. Applications to physical chemistry/chemical physics.

title: CHEM 539 Surface Chemistry
description: Physical and chemical properties of solid surfaces; thermodynamics and kinetics of gas chemisorption; chemical bonding at surfaces; applications to catalysis and electronic materials.

title: CHEM 536 Molecular Dynamics
description: Potential energy surfaces, reaction dynamics, scattering theories, classical trajectories, statistical theories, molecular energy transfer, photodissociation dynamics, gas- surface interactions, experimental results, beam and laser techniques.

title: CHEM 526 Structure and Mechanism in Organic Chemistry
description: Review of modern structural theory of organic chemistry; and relation to the mechanisms of organic chemical reactions.

title: CHEM 535 Introduction to Molecular Spectroscopy
description: Theory and experimental methods of molecular spectroscopy and applications to chemistry. Rotational, vibrational, electronic and nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopies.

title: CHEM 527 Synthetic Organic Chemistry
description: A survey of representative groups of widely used synthetic organic reactions; emphasis on scope, limitations, and stereochemical consequences.

title: CLAS 322 Roman Art and Archaeology
description: Survey of the art and architecture of ancient Rome and its empire, from the beginnings of the city through Constantine (8th century BCE to 4th century CE).

title: CLAS 321 Greek Art and Archaeology
description: Survey of artistic works and monuments of ancient Greece from the Geometric through the Hellenistic period (c. 1000 - 30 BCE.).

title: CHEM 523 Introduction to Functional Inorganic Materials
description: An introduction to functional inorganic materials emphasizing crystalline materials and how their properties can be understood based on their structure, elemental composition, and electronic structure.

title: CHEM 524 Inorganic Materials Chemistry
description: Studies in the fundamental principles governing inorganic materials. Structure and chemical bonding, preparative methods, and electrical, optical and magnetic properties of inorganic materials and applications.

title: CHEM 521 Basic Principles of Physical Methods in Biochemistry
description: Principles underlying physical analytical methods commonly utilized in research in biochemistry and molecular biology.

title: CHEM 519 Biochemistry and Molecular Biology: An Introduction for Chemists
description: Amino acids and peptides; protein structure and function; enzyme kinetics; structure, analysis and synthesis of nucleic acids; chemical biology of DNA and RNA; biotechnology.

title: CLAS 310 Pagans and Christians

title: CHEM 516 Synthesis, Reactivity, and Mechanism in Inorganic and Organometallic Chemistry
description: A reactivity framework for inorganic and organometallic chemistry. Synthesis, reaction mechanisms and energetics. Homogeneous catalysis.

title: CHEM 510x Alternative Energy Technologies and Options

title: CHEM 515 Structure and Bonding in Inorganic and Organometallic Chemistry
description: An integrated core course of structure and bonding in inorganic, coordination and organometallic chemistry within an oxidation state framework. Symmetry, electronic properties.

title: CHEM 495 Beyond the Classroom - Research in Modern Chemistry

description: Application of thermodynamics to chemical engineering systems.

description: Chemical reactions and scavenging processes important in urban air pollution. Effects of solar irradiation on vehicle exhaust gases, oxides of nitrogen and sulfur.

description: Registration Restriction: Open only to master and doctoral students.

title: CHE 501 Modeling and Analysis of Chemical Engineering Systems
description: Application of mathematics to problems in chemical engineering; mathematical modeling, differential and integral equations, linear systems analysis and stability, asymptotic and numerical methods.

description: Course content to be selected each semester from recent developments in chemical engineering and related fields.

description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: CHE 489 Biochemical Engineering
description: Application of chemical engineering principles to biological and biochemical processes and materials. Design of biochemical reactors and of processes for separation and purification of biological products.

title: CHE 488 Molecular and Cellular Bioengineering
description: Design, synthesis, and analysis of biological molecules; routes to understand and engineer living systems at the molecular and cellular level; systems and synthetic biology.

title: CHE 487 Nanotechnology and Nanoscale Engineering through Chemical Processes
description: Properties and processing of nanomaterials including polymeric, metallic, and ceramic nanoparticles, composites, colloids, and surfactant self-assembly for templated nanomaterial production.

title: CHE 486 Design of Environmentally Benign Process Plants
description: Chemical Process Plants interact with the environment as an integrated system. This course discusses design procedures to minimize unwanted effluents to air, water and solid wastes.

title: CHE 485 Computer-Aided Chemical Process Design
description: Use and optimization of modern computer software for chemical process design.

title: CHE 523 Principles of Electrochemical Engineering
description: Electrochemical techniques; mass, charge, and heat transfer; electrochemical thermodynamics and electrode kinetics; electrochemical reactors; optimization; materials and corrosion; experimental modeling of industrial processes.

title: CHE 480 Chemical Process and Plant Design
description: Applications of unit operations, thermodynamics, kinetics, and economic balance; energy conservation in heat exchanger networks and in sequencing of separational devices. Safety aspects.

title: CHE 531 Enhanced Oil Recovery
description: Survey of current enhanced oil recovery processes, including water-flooding, miscible displacement, and thermal oil recovery.

title: CHE 582 Fluid Flow and Transport Processes in Porous Media
description: Principles of single and multiphase flow through porous media; mechanisms of immiscible and miscible displacement; momentum, heat and mass transport in porous media.

title: CHE 477 Computer Assisted Polymer Engineering and Manufacturing I
description: Estimation of physical, mechanical, chemical and processing properties of thermal plastics. Major molding processes. Mold flow simulation and residual stresses analysis. Case studies.

title: CHE 476 Chemical Engineering Materials
description: Chemical and physical properties of solid materials used by chemical engineers, including polymers, metals, and ceramics. Materials design for industrial applications.

title: CHE 513 Principles of Combustion
description: Thermochemistry, equilibrium, chemical kinetics, flame temperature, flame velocity, flame stability, diffusion flames spray combustion, detonation. Equations of motion including reaction, heat transfer, and diffusion.

title: CHE 475 Physical Properties of Polymers
description: Theoretical methods and semi-empirical correlations for estimating mechanical, thermodynamic, transport, optical, and electrical properties of polymer solutions, melts, networks, glasses, polymer blends and semi-crystalline polymers.

title: CHE 474L Polymer Science and Engineering Laboratory
description: Experimental methods for the preparation, characterization, and properties of synthetic polymers.

title: CHE 472 Polymer Science and Engineering
description: The preparation, characterization, and properties of synthetic polymers. An interdisciplinary approach to polymers as materials.

title: CHE 450 Sustainable Energy
description: A comparison of various forms of sustainable energy from a perspective ranging from molecules and materials to industrial-scale processes, including biomass, geothermal, and solar energy as well as carbon dioxide capture and utilization.

title: CHE 460L Chemical Process Dynamics and Control
description: Simulation, stability, and automatic control of chemical processes. Open and closed loop control schemes and introduction to optimal control theory. Computer implementation and laboratory application.

title: CHE 446 Mass Transfer in Chemical Engineering Processes
description: Molecular and continuum approaches to diffusion and convection in fluids and multicomponent mixtures; simultaneous mass, heat and momentum transfer; steady-state and time-dependent diffusion; Maxwell-Stefan equations.

title: CHE 445 Heat Transfer in Chemical Engineering Processes
description: Phenomenological rate laws, differential and macroscopic equations, and elementary kinetic theory of heat transfer processes with emphases on conduction and convection.

title: CHE 405 Applications of Probability and Statistics for Chemical Engineers
description: Principles of probability and statistics, random variables and random functions. Application to chemical engineering problems, including process design, process safety, heterogeneous materials and processes.

title: CHE 442 Chemical Reactor Analysis
description: Basic concepts of chemical kinetics and chemical reactor design.

title: CHE 444aL Chemical Engineering Laboratory
description: Resolution of chemical engineering problems that require original planning, observations, and data interpretation. Written and oral reports.

title: CHE 443 Viscous Flow
description: Constitutive equations and rate laws, momentum equations and kinetic theory of Newtonian, Non-Newtonian and complex flows. Applications to chemical engineering systems.

title: CHE 390 Special Problems
description: Supervised, individual studies. No more than one registration permitted. Enrollment by petition only.

title: CHE 444bL Chemical Engineering Laboratory
description: Resolution of chemical engineering problems that require original planning, observations, and data interpretation. Written and oral reports.

title: CHE 465L Drilling Technology and Subsurface Methods
description: Theory and practice in drilling technology; mechanical properties of reservoir rocks; well completion; acidizing and fracturing, oil production technology.

title: CHE 464L Petroleum Reservoir Engineering
description: Properties of reservoir fluids, volumetric and material balances for gas and oil reservoirs; reservoir modeling concepts.

title: CHE 350 Introduction to Separation Processes

title: CHE 463L Introduction to Transport Processes in Porous Media
description: Properties of porous rocks; capillarity effect, single-phase and multiphase flow through porous media; diffusion and dispersion, miscible displacement, heat transfer.

title: CHE 462 Economic, Risk and Formation Productivity Analysis
description: Principle of economic evaluation, risk analysis, reserves estimation, decline curves, energy prices, and well transients for flow prediction.

title: COMM 444 Critical Theories of Sport

title: COMM 440 Music as Communication
