title: COMM 449 Perspectives on the Networked Press
description: Critical survey of the forces defining today's networked press, examining the people, technologies, and institutions that produce news in today's online environments.

title: CE 692 Transportation and the Environment
description: Analysis of the benefits and costs of urban transportation; concepts of social costs; benefits and externalities; environmental costs; social justice issues; policy and planning alternatives for sustainable transportation.

title: COMM 433 Home Entertainment
description: History and impact of television and ancillary home entertainment (pay television, cable television, home video, DVD, DVR, video-on-demand, etc.) on media industries and consumer experience.

title: COMM 432 American Media and Entertainment Industries
description: Examines the history, technology, regulations and business practices of American broadcast and entertainment industries.

title: COMM 431 Global Strategy for the Communications Industry
description: Addresses the practical and theoretical aspects of the international economy that are most relevant to management strategy in the communications industry.

title: CE 638 Stochastic Optimization
description: Stochastic linear and integer programming, multi-stage stochastic programming, application, models and algorithms.

title: CE 637 Urban Mass Transit
description: Fundamentals of urban mass transit planning.  Topics include the fiscal context of mass transit planning, fares and farebox recovery, ridership forecasts, land development near transit, and transit operations, scheduling, and network design.

title: COMM 430 Global Entertainment
description: Survey of economic, political, and cultural dimensions of the global entertainment marketplace; focuses on the international production and distribution of media products and services.

title: COMM 427 Topics in Media Economics, Law and Policy
description: Selected current topics in the overlapping areas of media economics, law, and policy.

title: COMM 429 The Internet, Economy, and Society
description: Examines the effects of the Internet on communication industries, the economy, economic policy, and on social, political, and cultural practices.

title: CE 633 Urban Transportation Planning and Management
description: Background applications of established urban travel forecasting procedures; land use; trip-generation, trip-distribution, modal-choice, trip-assignment; evaluation; criticisms.

title: CE 634 Institutional and Policy Issues in Transportation
description: Analysis of policies relating to transportation alternatives; institutional environment and background; federal, state, regional, and local agency responsibilities and interactions.

title: COMM 426 Religion, Media and Hollywood: Faith in TV
description: How religion, ethics and spirituality are embedded, embodied and emplotted in television drama; how secular texts represent "lived religion" to increasingly diverse audiences.

title: COMM 422 Legal Issues and New Media
description: Examines laws and regulatory policies shaping new media, especially the Internet; impact of regulation on development and use of communication technology.

title: COMM 425 Communicating Religion
description: Genres of religious communication, including sermon, prayer, ritual, polemic, and revival. Impact of technological and cultural change on religious advocacy, beliefs, and practices.

title: COMM 421 Legal Communication
description: How lawyers and judges communicate in the courtroom; how legal issues are discussed by lay people; how lawyers and judges are viewed in popular culture.

title: COMM 415m African American Rhetoric and Image
description: Interactive course addresses how people of color use symbols to construct identities and communities and disrupt networks through media, politics, entertainment and technology.

title: COMM 413 Propaganda, Ideology and Public Controversy
description: Seminar examining the relationship between propaganda, ideology, critical thinking and rhetoric; application to contemporary controversies, both domestic and global; role of public argument.

title: COMM 412 Communication and Social Movements
description: Social and political movements as rhetorical phenomena; ideology, organization, and influence of such movements as civil rights, "New Left," feminism, "New Right," environmentalism.

title: COMM 414 Communication and Social Change in China
description: Examines social, political, and cultural implications of media and communication on Chinese society; regulations relevant to Chinese communication; market reforms, telecommunication, Internet and creative industries.

title: COMM 402 Public Communication Campaigns
description: Theory and research in public health communication campaigns; design, implementation, and evaluation; extensive discussion of historical case studies and reasons for success or failure.

title: COMM 405 From the Ground Up: Communicating About Food
description: Explores food communication as a facilitator of human interaction and cultural diplomacy; controversies regarding food production/consumption; and evolution of food entertainment programming.

title: COMM 411 Communication Criticism
description: Methods and functions of criticism in forms of public communication; historical-contextual, textual, and interpretive procedures; diverse theoretical approaches including formalism, dramatism, genre, and ideology.

title: COMM 400 Seminar in Communication
description: Advanced readings in communication theory and research (broadly defined); specialized interest areas of individual faculty on the frontiers of knowledge; seminar topics change each semester.

title: COMM 401 Audience Analysis
description: Examines audience analysis methodologies including focus groups, shadow juries, surveys, test marketing and content analysis; application of statistical sampling procedures, data analysis, interpretation and presentation.

title: COMM 396g Fashion, Media and Culture
description: Fashion as a form of communication and culture; fashion's role in identity, body politics, art, nationhood, celebrity and Hollywood culture, youth cultures and subversive practices.

title: COMM 395m Gender, Media and Communication
description: Issues of gender in communication, including: media representations of femininity and masculinity; and gender's role in communication at the interpersonal, public, and cultural levels.

title: COMM 393 Rhetoric of Rome
description: Registration Restriction: Open only to Communication, Journalism, and Public Relations majors

title: COMM 420 Regional Studies in Public Diplomacy
description: Analyzes the role and effectiveness of public diplomacy in different countries, examining a region's influence on global affairs and the development of diplomatic strategies.

title: COMM 419 Public Diplomacy in Los Angeles
description: Examines how the City of Los Angeles and other local actors use public diplomacy tools to strengthen ties between themselves and foreign audiences.

title: COMM 392 Media and Migration in Times of European Crisis
description: Investigates the implications of the perceptual process of mass media generated immigration discourse in Europe

title: COMM 418 International Exchanges and Public Diplomacy
description: Examines international exchanges, their role in the foreign policy process, and their challenges in a world marked by rapid change and innovation in communication technologies.

title: COMM 417 Global Engagement: Designing Public Diplomacy Strategies
description: Examines issues on the global political agenda and the tools and approaches that the Public Diplomacy practitioner might profitably employ to address them.

title: COMM 388 Ethics in Human Communication
description: Value perspectives on communication in varied settings: interpersonal, organizational, and public. Issues of truth and responsibility in family and social interactions, advertising, and governmental communication.

title: COMM 391 Made in Italy-The Marketing of an Ideal
description: Examines case studies on important Italian companies, ranging from the transportation to the luxury goods industries from both an economical and business point of view.

title: COMM 390 Special Problems
description: Supervised, individual studies. No more than one registration permitted. Enrollment by petition only.

title: COMM 387 Sports and Social Change
description: Application of critical, sociological and rhetorical theories to sports events and sport media; examination of the role of sports in enacting social change.

title: COMM 385 Organizational Communication
description: How communication processes both create organizations and are constrained by them. Theory and research into topics such as culture, technology, power, leadership and decision-making in a variety of organizational contexts.

title: COMM 383m Sports, Communication and Culture
description: Rhetorical and critical approaches to sports and public discourse; application to sports organizations, the news and popular media; representations of gender and race in sports.

title: COMM 384 Interpreting Popular Culture
description: Popular culture as an indicator of cultural values, a producer and reflection of cultural meaning, and a means of communication; theory and case studies.

title: COMM 381 Issues in Contemporary Sport
description: Explores social, political and ethical issues in elite sports and how issues are addressed through popular media; examination includes the relationship between sports and politics.

title: COMM 380 Forensics Laboratory
description: Directed individual research studies of contemporary problems. Supervised laboratory experience.

title: COMM 375 Business and Professional Communication
description: Oral and written communication skills demanded in the workplace including informative and persuasive speeches; interviewing; team communication; and training material preparation.

title: COMM 371 Censorship and the Law: From the Press to Cyberspace
description: The study of current and historical battles over the limits of free expression from press and public parks to television, movies, music and cyberspace.

title: COMM 370 The Rhetoric of Ideas: Ideology and Propaganda
description: Techniques of propaganda in public discourse; communication strategies through which ideas become ideologies; case studies in wartime and corporate propaganda, imperialism, and cultural colonialism.

title: COMM 367 Community Engagement and Service Learning
description: Students engage with a community partner, bridging classroom learning with "real world" experiences by working within the diverse community surrounding USC.

title: COMM 366 Designing Media and Communication Projects for Social Change
description: Students explore the theoretical and practical issues involved in designing effective media and communication projects for social change in international contexts.

title: COMM 364 Comparative Media: United States and the United Kingdom
description: Cross-national approaches to the study of U.S. and U.K. media; focuses on news and entertainment media products; examines content, industries, technologies and audiences.

title: COMM 365 The Rhetoric of London
description: Examination of the modern city as a communicative text with London as the case study.

title: COMM 363 Media Consumption
description: Theoretical approaches to the study of media consumption and audiences; examines international media and consumption practices; explores new media's impact on consumption.

title: COMM 360 The Rhetoric of Los Angeles
description: Representations of Los Angeles communicated in diverse media; the city as a rhetorical text; analysis of cultural identities, art, architecture, and representations in popular culture.

title: COMM 355 Advertising and Communication
description: Advertising as a mode of communication; U.S. advertising history and institutions; economic and policy contexts (domestic and global); critical analysis of advertising texts.

title: COMM 350 Video Games: Content, Industry, and Policy
description: Introduction to the medium; history of video games; video games as aesthetic products, cultural products, economic outputs; policy issues, effects, and sites of community.

title: COMM 345 Social and Economic Implications of Communication Technologies
description: Social and economic impacts of information and communication technologies; social factors that shape technological change; issues include access, privacy, freedom of expression, productivity, democratic control.

title: COMM 340 The Cultures of New Media
description: Cultural implications of computer-mediated communication and related media. Ideological responses to media innovation; debates over artificial intelligence, virtual communities, and virtual reality.

title: COMM 339 Communication Technology and Culture
description: Examination of philosophies and popular representations of technology from the origins of western culture to the present and identifies the complex attitudes toward technology.

title: COMM 382 Sports, Business and Media in Today's Society
description: An inside look at the important stories, topical issues, trends and historical developments related to the growing influence of business and media on college and professional sports; identifying the key components and meeting the influencers in class that help shape the business side of sports, while recognizing the role the media plays in providing daily coverage across multiple platforms.

title: COMM 337 The LGBTQ Revolution and the Media
description: Explores the role of the media in the LGBTQ revolution that transformed the lives of sexual and gender minorities in the United States.

title: COMM 336 Communicating About Sex
description: Communicating with partners, friends, parents and health care professionals about sexual behavior; interpersonal and mediated contexts; understanding of sexual scripts; current theory and research.

title: COMM 372 The Image of the Journalist in Popular Culture
description: The impact of conflicting images of reporters in movies and television on the American public's perception of newsgatherers in the 20th century. A decade-by-decade evaluation.

title: COMM 335 Rhetoric in Contemporary Culture
description: Theories of communication and persuasion in contemporary society; cultural and social contexts of contemporary rhetorical theory; major theorists, concepts and controversies.

title: COMM 369w Public Diplomacy and Global Citizenship
description: Introduces public diplomacy as a central feature of contemporary international relations and challenges students to locate themselves as both its target and practitioners.

title: COMM 330 Rhetoric in Classical Culture
description: Theories of communication and persuasion in ancient Greece and Rome; cultural and social contexts of classical rhetorical theory; major historical figures and concepts.

title: COMM 325 Intercultural Britain: Media, History and Identity
description: Examines urgent social and political issues as they are shaped, represented and expressed by the institutions of media, culture and communication within the United Kingdom.

title: COMM 324mw Intercultural Communication
description: Cultural variables and social psychological processes that influence intercultural interaction; relationship between communication and culture in diverse settings including business, medicine, and education.

title: COMM 323 Public Deliberation
description: Introduction to deliberative democracy in culture and governance; examines historical and contemporary institutions of democratic discourse and emerging communication norms.

title: COMM 322 Argumentation and Advocacy
description: Basic argumentation theory including analysis, research and evidence, case construction, refutation; discursive and visual argument; diverse fields of advocacy including law, politics, organizations, interpersonal relations.

title: COMM 321 Communication and Social Media
description: Social media within the broader social, political, and historical contexts; key themes include labor, Web 2.0, self-branding, celebrity, participation, privacy, online shaming, and activism.

title: COMM 320 Small Group and Team Communication
description: Group process theories relevant to communicative behavior in small group/team settings, including information exchange, decision making, leadership, and meetings; student team projects testing theoretic propositions.

title: COMM 315 Health Communication
description: Behavioral approaches to health communication; communication competencies in health care settings, theories of risky behaviors, and behavioral change programs; special emphasis on AIDS-related issues.

title: COMM 312 The Business and Culture of Celebrity
description: Employs the concept of "celebrity" as an optic through which to view and assess some of the key aspects of the communication revolution.

title: COMM 313 Communication and Mass Media
description: Survey of mass communication research; history, content, effects, theories, and policy implications of various media.

title: COMM 310 Media and Society
description: Interplay between media and society, including family and children's socialization, inter-group relations and community, pornography and violence, gender and race, media ethics, conduct of politics.

title: COMM 311 Rhetoric and the Public Sphere
description: Humanistic approaches to inquiry in communication; qualitative research techniques; core theories of message production and reception in social, political, and mediated contexts.

title: COMM 309 Communication and Technology
description: Cultural, social, political, and economic dynamics of communication technologies, including internet architecture, social media, participatory cultures, privacy, surveillance, networked journalism, big data, algorithms, online activism.

title: COMM 308 Communication and Conflict
description: Nature and functions of communication in human conflict; development of communication skills for managing conflict productively in interpersonal, organizational and intercultural contexts.

title: COMM 307 Sound Clash: Popular Music and American Culture
description: Music as inter-cultural communication and method for exploring race and ethnicity in the constitution of American culture and American self; role of music industry.

title: COMM 306 Innovation, Entertainment, and the Arts
description: Explorations of innovation in the entertainment business. The effects of digital mobile media on TV, movies, music, advertising, social networks and art.

title: COMM 305 Understanding Social Science Research
description: Students learn to be consumers rather than creators of social science research. Examines the challenges and opportunities of communicating research through mass media.

title: COMM 303 Learning from Case Studies in Communication
description: Case study approaches to communication research; reliability, validity, generalizability, and ethics in qualitative social research; cases in communication policy and practices.

title: COMM 304 Interpersonal Communication
description: Analysis of face-to-face interaction; role of communication in the development, maintenance and destruction of relationships; communication processes in managing interpersonal conflict.

title: COMM 302 Persuasion
description: Theories and research in social influence; strategies and tactics of persuasive communications in such settings as politics, public relations, advertising, business.

title: COMM 301Lg Empirical Research in Communication
description: Experimental and survey methods for communication study; basic statistical concepts, procedures, and tests.

title: COMM 300 Entertainment, Communication and Society
description: Theoretical foundation for understanding the construction, consumption, and consequences of entertainment from classical to contemporary times; situates entertainment within the ecology of information and communication.

title: COMM 209 Communication and Media Economics
description: Economic and political economic principles for the analysis of communication and media industries including broadcasting, newspapers, motion pictures, music, video games, advertising and public relations.

title: COMM 206 Communication and Culture
description: Examines cultural institutions, ideologies, artifacts, and productions; role of culture in everyday life; cultural studies as methodology; culture and power.

title: COMM 205x Communication Practicum
description: Students address communication issues in a field setting. They will evaluate communication practices using appropriate methodology. Projects are jointly evaluated by internship supervisor and professor.

title: COMM 204 Public Speaking
description: Principles and practices of effective oral communication; analysis of the speaking-listening process; selection and organization of speech materials; use of new presentation technologies.

title: COMM 203 Communication and Mass Media
description: Survey of mass communication research; history, content, effects, theories and policy implications of various media.

title: COMM 200 Communication and Social Science
description: Social scientific inquiry into human communication; core theories of message production and reception in interpersonal, group and organizational contexts.

title: COLT 620 Seminar in Literature, Culture, and Thought
description: Varying focus on social and political thought, psychoanalysis, and philosophy in relation to literary and cultural analysis.

title: COLT 602 Seminar in Literary Theory
description: Intensive study of a theoretical tradition or critical movement, or of an individual topic or thinker, in literary criticism or theory.

title: COLT 593 Teaching Practicum for Graduate Students
description: Practical principles for the long-term development of effective teaching within College disciplines. Intended for teaching assistants in Dornsife college.

title: COLT 585 Studies in Literature and Gender
description: Emphasis on gender difference and sexual difference as signifying categories for literary works, criticism, or theory.

title: COLT 555 Studies in Literatures of the Americas
description: Comparative study of literary currents in the U.S., Canada, Latin America, and the Caribbean.

title: COLT 575 Studies in Literature and Ethnicity
description: Study of literary expression in different cultural, racial, or religious communities. Possible focus on African, Asian, Hispanic, or Jewish themes across several national traditions.

title: COLT 545 Studies in Literature and the Other Arts
description: Study of intersections between the literary arts and music, opera, film, theatre, photography, dance, or painting.

title: COLT 525 Studies in Literary and Cultural History
description: Literary and cultural currents from classical antiquity through modernity. Varying focus on specific genres, periods, movements, or problematics.

title: COLT 519 Translation in Theory and Practice
description: Workshop in translation; capstone to graduate certificate in Translation Studies.

title: COLT 512 Literary and Cinematic Translingualism and Translation
description: Introduces key debates regarding translingualism and translation in postcolonial, comparative, and cross-cultural literary and cinematic contexts

title: COLT 510 Introduction to Translation Studies
description: Introduction to the graduate certificate in Translation Studies; study of canonical works in translation theory.

title: COLT 511 Translating Race
description: Contemporary notions of racial, cultural, and religious difference across languages and history.

title: COLT 499 Special Topics
description: Intensive study of selected author or authors in the context of a major literary tradition.

title: COLT 495 Senior Honors Thesis
description: Writing of an honors thesis under individual faculty supervision.

title: COLT 487 Critical Image
description: Introduction to critical reflection on the image. Analysis of criticism, fiction, film, and visual artifacts.

title: COLT 490x Directed Research
description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

title: COLT 486 Deconstructive Thought
description: Deconstructive analysis of theories of language, representation, selfhood, the human, art and technology, politics and ethics. Study of works by Derrida and others.

title: COLT 485 The Shoah (Holocaust) in Literature and the Arts
description: A critical analysis, in their historical contexts, of representative literary, dramatic, musical and artistic works created by or about the victims of the Shoah (Holocaust).

title: COLT 478 Family in Theory and Literature
description: Representations of the family in literary works and films across different cultures and historical periods. Readings in anthropology, philosophy, psychoanalysis, and feminist and gender theory.

title: COLT 480 Dada and Surrealism
description: A comparative study of Dada and Surrealism in literature in relation to painting, sculpture, photography and cinema.

title: COLT 476 Narrative and the Law
description: Study of the relationship between law and narrative through Western literature, including the realist novel, medieval morality plays and Greek drama.

title: COLT 475 Politics and the Novel
description: Examination of the modern realist novel with special focus on the representation of social change (revolution, class conflict, sexual politics).

title: COLT 474 Desire, Literature, Technology
description: Relations between technology, desire, power and literature through contemporary philosophers, theorists and literary critics. Examines literature and philosophy in relation to global technological planning.

title: COLT 472 Los Angeles Crime Fiction
description: The noir tradition in books and films set in Los Angeles. Emphasis on generic conventions, representations of the city, and discourses of class, gender, race.

title: COLT 471 Literature, Theory, History
description: Examines the relation between historical and theoretical approaches to literary works.

title: COLT 470 Literature and Media in Latin America
description: Study of the relations between Latin American literature and different mass-media genres.

title: COLT 462 Soundtracks of Our Lives
description: The reciprocal, ideological relations between modes of listening, sounds, music; and literature, film, culture. Examines a range of issues in auditory culture across a broad historical span.

title: COLT 454 Aesthetic Philosophy and Theory
description: Introduction to philosophical and critical writings on the nature of art and aesthetic experience. Special attention to technology's impact on art.

title: COLT 452 Representation and Cognition in Photography
description: Analysis of documentary photo- - representation in its historical context through study of the work of selected 20th century documentary photographers and of pertinent critical writings.

title: COLT 451 Opera and Cultural Theory
description: Study of the words and plots of operas from the viewpoint of gender, postcolonial, and psychoanalytical theory. Special attention to contemporary stagings and film versions.

title: COLT 448 Multilingual Encounters
description: Exploration of multilingual encounters in literary works, films, and theoretical texts. Topics may include immigrant languages, dialects, jargons, imaginary or hybrid languages, theories of translation.

title: COLT 447 Traveling Genres: Politics/Poetics of Modern Arabic Prose
description: Introduction to nineteenth-century Arabic travel-writing and investigation of its role in the reconfiguration of the Arabic tradition at the interface of aesthetics and politics.

title: COLT 435 Poetry and Poetics of the Everyday
description: Relations between poetry of the dominant tradition in various languages and vernacular forms of poetry, such as riddles, nursery rhymes, ballads, and poems in dialect or slang.

title: COLT 437 Arabic Autobiography: Writing and Interpreting the Self
description: Exploration of twentieth-century Arabic autobiographical writings and interrogation of the complex ways by which such works unsettle fundamental assumptions of literary history and modernity.

title: COLT 445 Europe and the Writing of Others
description: Analysis of European texts — literary, musical, philosophical, visual — that focus on other cultures, as well as of non-European texts dealing with Europe or - European cultural forms.

title: COLT 426 Utopias
description: Examination of selected utopias in their historical context as "no places" whose projections of alternate cultures always comment on their own.

title: COLT 420 The Fantastic
description: Representative works from the "fantastic" and related currents within the European, U.S., and Spanish American traditions; reading of texts by authors such as Borges, Cortazar, Kafka, and Poe. Discussion of relevant theoretical concepts and critical works.

title: COLT 391 Literary Criticism from Plato to Postmodernism
description: Survey of major texts in the literary criticism of the West from the Greeks to postmodern theories.

title: COLT 385 Literature and Justice
description: Examination of literary and autobiographical texts that raise questions of justice in multicultural societies; links to theories of justice in historical, political, or philosophical contexts.

title: COLT 390 Special Problems
description: Supervised, individual studies. No more than one registration permitted. Enrollment by petition only.

title: COLT 381 Psychoanalysis and the Arts
description: Introduction to psychoanalytic literature on the arts, including classic texts by Freud, Jones, Lacan, Derrida, and others. Readings of theoretical and fictional works.

title: COLT 382gw Zen and Taoism in Asian Literature
description: Studies of the presence and influence of Zen Buddhism and Taoism in Asian literature, with a focus on China and Japan.

title: COLT 460 Love, Self and Gender in Japanese Literature
description: Examines conceptions of love, self, gender, and sexuality in Japanese literature and culture of the modern and pre-modern periods with comparisons to European and Chinese literature.

title: COLT 379 Nationalism and Postcolonialism in Southeast Asian Cinema
description: Cinema from Cambodia, Indonesia, Laos, Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore, Thailand, and Vietnam in local and global cultural contexts.

title: COLT 377 Literature, Theory, Gender
description: Literary representations and theories of gender difference. - Examines questions of gendered voice in writing and the cultural construction of gender in various periods and cultures.

title: COLT 453 Bildungsroman in Modern East Asia
description: Comparative study of core narratives of youth and its destiny in modern literature from China, Japan, Korea, and Taiwan. Readings include scholarship on European literature.

title: COLT 375 Latin American Cultural and Literary Theory
description: Survey of cultural critique focused on Latin America as a cultural region and on Latin Americanism as a transnational academic practice.

title: COLT 374gm Women Writers in Europe and America
description: Introduction to works of major women writers from the Middle Ages to the 20th century in their literary, social, and cultural contexts.

title: COLT 449g Dante
description: Analysis of the Divina Commedia and other works. Conducted in English. (Duplicates credit in former ITAL 450)

title: COLT 373 Literature and Film
description: Examines literature and film as distinct modes of representation, narration, and structuring of time, language, memory, and visuality.

title: COLT 365 Literature and Popular Culture
description: Study of mass-reproduced verbal and visual art forms, such as graphic novels, comics, animation, popular music, video, graffiti, advertising.

title: COLT 357 The Avant-Garde
description: Study of the relationship between literary modes and other arts since 1900, focusing on particular avant-garde movements.

title: COLT 354 Revolutions in Theater
description: Comparative study of groundbreaking contributions to modern theories of theater and performance in the context of other 20th century revolutions — aesthetic, cultural, and social.

title: COLT 351 Modern and Contemporary Drama
description: Comparative study of major modern dramatic trends, subgenres, and techniques, through representative works from Strindberg to the Theatre of the Grotesque and the Absurd.

title: COLT 348 Modernist Fiction
description: Study of the Modernist aesthetic in narrative texts by Gide, Joyce, Kafka, Woolf and others; possible focus on related trends in other literary traditions.

title: COLT 346 Fictions of the First Person
description: Study of prose fiction in the first person as a model of fiction in general and as a reflection of the fictional structure of selfhood.

title: COLT 345 Realist Fiction
description: Study of the ways literature presents the "real" (social and/or individual) through readings of selected novels and short stories in the realist and naturalist traditions.

title: COLT 335 Decadence and Modernity
description: Study of the notion of "decadence" and its impact on modern and contemporary literary/cultural production, with a comparatist focus on different linguistic traditions.

title: COLT 324 Women in Medieval and Renaissance Europe
description: Study of literary, social and cultural lives of women during the European Middle Ages and Renaissance. Reading and analysis of texts written by and about women.

title: COLT 312 Heroes, Myths and Legends in Literature and the Arts
description: Study of transformations of characters and themes from myth, legend or fairytale (Oedipus, Antigone, Faust, Don Juan, Cinderella, Comic and Tragic Twins, Hero and Monster).

title: COLT 311 Epic
description: Formation and development of epic poetry from Near Eastern and Greco-Roman antiquity through the Renaissance to the present. Emphasis on relation to political and cultural change.

title: COLT 303 Globalization: Culture, Change, Resistance
description: Cultural dimensions of issues in globalization: migration, diaspora, terrorism, communications, climate change, collectives, production and technology, money and exchange.

title: COLT 302 Introduction to Literary Theory
description: Introduction to general forms of reflection on literary discourse.

title: COLT 264gp Asian Aesthetic and Literary Traditions
description: A comparative study of the Asian aesthetic heritage of poetry, painting, music, and drama; of literary themes, trends, and myths.

title: COLT 251g Modern Literature and Thought of the West Since 1800
description: Survey of literary and other cultural texts from the 19th to the 21st centuries, with emphasis on the individual and social change.

title: COLT 250g Cultures of Latin America
description: Comparative study of Latin American cultures, especially vis-a-vis those of Europe and the U.S. Materials drawn from literature, but also film, opera, history, cultural theory.

title: CNTV 794c Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: In-progress & Credit/No Credit

title: COLT 102g On Location: The Place of Literature in Global Cultures
description: Comparative study of works from a broad range of cultural traditions that originate from, and provide insight into, vital global locations outside the Western sphere.

title: COLT 101gp Masterpieces and Masterminds: Literature and Thought
description: A broad introduction to the great works of Western culture from antiquity to 1800.

title: CNTV 794z Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: In-progress & Credit/No Credit

title: CNTV 794d Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: In-progress & Credit/No Credit

title: CNTV 794b Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: In-progress & Credit/No Credit

title: CNTV 594z Master's Thesis
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: CNTV 594b Master's Thesis
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: CNTV 599 Special Topics
description: Detailed investigation of new or emerging aspects of cinematic arts; special subjects offered by visiting faculty; experimental subjects.

title: CNTV 794a Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: In-progress & Credit/No Credit

title: CNTV 595 Professional Practicum
description: Film, media, archival and interactive industry experience in areas of interest to the individual student, and development of a personal brand. Requires departmental approval.

title: CNTV 594a Master's Thesis
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: CNTV 590 Directed Research
description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

title: CNTV 589 Graduate Film Seminar
description: Detailed investigations and discussion of various aspects of film.

title: CNTV 530 Cinematic Ethics
description: An introductory course in the ethical questions professionals encounter in the field of cinematic arts. Case studies and guest lectures.

title: CNTV 525 Entertainment Marketing in Today's Digital Environment
description: Entertainment industry marketing disciplines, covering motion pictures, television, music, theme parks, home entertainment, and video games. Current principles and business practices.

title: CNTV 524 Digital Technologies and the Entertainment Industry
description: The impact of digital technologies on the film, television, and music industries from content creation to distribution.

title: CNTV 523 Feature Film Financing and the Studio System
description: An overview of the motion picture studio system and how to finance feature films. Principles, business practices, and future trends.

title: CNTV 522 The Television Industry: Networks, Cable and the Internet
description: The current state of the television industry and future business paradigms.

title: CNTV 521 The World of the Producer
description: A comprehensive overview of the role of the producer in creating television programming, feature films, and new media content.

title: COLT 255gw Southeast Asian Literature and Film
description: Comparative approach and general introduction to literature and cinema from the four major nations of maritime Southeast Asia (Indonesia, the Philippines, Singapore, and Malaysia).

title: CNTV 499 Special Topics
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: CNTV 501 Cinematic Arts Seminar
description: Introduction to an industry and art form in the midst of transformation, with guest speakers and cinematic arts faculty who will address new research and technologies.

title: CNTV 495 Internship in Cinematic Arts
description: On-the-job film, television, and interactive industry experience in the areas of interest of the individual student. Requires departmental approval.

title: CNTV 490x Directed Research
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: CNTV 467 The Future of Digital Media and the Entertainment Industry
description: Examines how digital media will affect the future of the television, motion picture, game, music, and interactive industries.

title: CNTV 463 Television: Integrating Creative and Business Objectives
description: An investigation of the creative and business sides of television and how they connect, including changes caused by fractionalization and digital technology.

title: CNTV 458 Producing and Marketing Feature Length Films
description: The principles and business practices of producing and marketing feature length films in the motion picture industry.

title: CNTV 441 Business and Cinematic Arts Entertainment Practicum
description: Application of business and cinematic arts concepts to entertainment industry networking and career-building experiences. Peer collaboration/competition, and identifying organizational compatibility.

title: CNTV 440 The Business of the Entertainment Industry: Motion Pictures, Television, Animation, Video Games, and Interactive Entertainment
description: An in-depth analysis of the history, evolution, and current state of the motion picture, television, animation, video game, and interactive entertainment industries.

title: CNTV 457 The Entertainment Entrepreneur: Getting Your First Project Made
description: The practical aspects of entrepreneurial producing in the entertainment industry. Identifying and understanding the pitfalls and benefits of creating one's own projects.

title: CNTV 474 Digital DNA: Media Redefined
description: A practical, hands-on learning experience in creating media content and turning that content into a myriad of viable businesses.

title: CNTV 427 The Art and Commerce of Independent Film

title: CNTV 420 Independent Feature Filmmaking

title: CNTV 419 Inside the Business of Film and Television

title: CNTV 413 Digital Editing

title: ACCT 430 Accounting Ethics

title: ACCT 410x Foundations of Accounting

title: ACCT 416 Financial Reporting and Analysis
description: Examination of the role of financial statement analysis in the prediction of a firm's future financial performance.

title: ACCT 390 Special Problems

title: ACCT 385x Introduction to Risk Management and Insurance
description: Understand the underlying economics, structure, and business models of an organization (often an insurance carrier) willing to accept risk for diverse situations: property, life, healthcare.

title: ACCT 415x Intermediate Financial Accounting for Non-Accounting Majors

title: ACCT 380x Introduction to Enterprise Risk Management
description: Understand the concept of risk, risk assessment and management frameworks; learn to identify, analyze, manage and mitigate and communicate this risk to stakeholders.

title: ACCT 377 Valuation for Financial Statement Purposes
description: Explores Accounting Standards Codification (ASC) 820 "Fair Value Measurements and Disclosures" and reviews the historical background of US GAAP fair value guidance.

title: ACCT 373 Introduction to Auditing and Assurance Services
description: Exploration of the requisite skills and knowledge needed to offer services in assurance, attestation or auditing engagements.

title: ACCT 372 Internal Reporting Issues
description: Understanding of decision-making, problem solving, and research skills as a supplement to managerial accounting knowledge for accounting professionals.

title: ACCT 371 Introduction to Accounting Systems
description: Understanding of technology and controls needed to capture data used by professionals in financial and managerial accounting, auditing and taxation.

title: ACCT 374 Introduction to Tax Issues
description: Basic tax principles, introduction to U.S. federal, state and local tax systems, income and expense definitions, property transactions, and fundamentals of individual taxation.

title: ACAD 590 Directed Research
description: Research leading to graduate degree. Maximum units which may be applied to degree determined by department.

title: ACCT 370 External Financial Reporting Issues
description: Understanding of decision-making, problem solving, and research skills as a supplement to financial accounting knowledge for accounting professionals.

title: ACAD 599 Special Topics
description: Comprehensive exploration of particular aspects of art, technology and the business of innovation.

title: ACAD 499 Special Topics
description: Comprehensive exploration of particular aspects of art, technology and the business of innovation.

title: ACCT 442 The Ethics of Financial and Political Accountability
description: Examination of how kingdoms, empires and great companies have risen and fallen due to good or poor financial and political accountability.

title: ACAD 491 Individual Instruction
description: Weekly, individual instruction with an Academy professor for deep exploration and study within an Academy core discipline.

title: ACAD 490 Directed Research
description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

title: ACAD 475b The Garage Experience
description: Academy capstone experience, innovative projects leading to operational prototypes and viable enterprises, mentored by faculty and industry experts.

title: ACAD 475a The Garage Experience
description: Academy capstone experience, innovative projects leading to operational prototypes and viable enterprises, mentored by faculty and industry experts.

title: ACAD 445 Product Design III
description: An understanding of bringing a product to market through the process of determining consumer pain points, competitive analysis, marketability, feasibility, and the supporting business model.

title: ACAD 419 Professional Internship
description: An experiential/academic opportunity in an arts, technology and business related facility. Written analysis, evaluation, and working internship.

title: ACAD 407 Multimedia for Designers and Entrepreneurs III
description: Designing persuasive multimedia experiences; new and experimental media types; intermediate production methods; advanced techniques for creative software.

title: ACAD 480 Information Technology Internship

title: ACAD 476 Technologies for Interactive Marketing

title: ACAD 467 Strategic Management of Innovation
description: How firms in different industries manage strategic innovation for competitive advantage. Analysis of industry dynamics. Crafting and implementing innovation strategy.

title: ACAD 377 Discerning and Making II: Creation and Implementation
description: Students create and implement – from conception through prototype – new ventures, products, services, and processes; building upon the innovations of designers, engineers, and entrepreneurs.

title: ACAD 449 Data Mining: Descriptive and Predictive
description: Examine and compare practical methods in data mining - data preparation, classification, clustering. Knowledge discovery process is to find patterns and regularities from large datasets.

title: ACAD 425 Web Application Security

title: ACAD 442 Mobile App Project
description: Capstone course for Mobile App Development minor. Work in project teams to develop new mobile app from start to finish. Meet with client, create app design, develop, test, and demonstrate app to client.

title: ACAD 435 Professional C++

title: ACAD 376 Discerning and Making I: Concept and Feasibility

title: ACAD 385x Marketing of Creative Disruption and Innovation

title: ACAD 360 Design Consulting: Problem Solving for Organizations

title: ACAD 356 Audio and Media Integration

title: ACAD 404 Modern Technologies of Web Development

title: ACAD 405 Professional Applications and Frameworks in Web Development
description: Provide students with the necessary skills to build structured, maintainable, scalable, and testable web applications using frameworks, tools, and techniques common in the industry.

title: ACAD 354 Synthesis and Sound Design

title: ACAD 352 Digital Audio Recording and Processing

title: ACAD 345 Product Design II

title: ACAD 350 International Experience

title: ACAD 365 Managing Data in C++

title: ACAD 324g The Practice of Design: Ideation to Innovation

title: ACAD 351 Technologies and Practices for Analytics

title: ACAD 307 Multimedia for Designers and Entrepreneurs II

title: ACAD 344 Advanced Topics in Mobile App Development

title: ACAD 341 App Development for Phones and Tablets

title: ACAD 342 Mobile Application Development

title: ACAD 332a Typography

title: ACAD 332b Typography
description: Duplicates Credit in former FADN 332b

title: ACAD 343 Mobile Development for Content and Media
description: Creating media-focused mobile applications. Topics include recording/playback, audio synthesis, stream mixing, and positional audio.

title: ACAD 331x Influence and Collaboration

title: ACAD 323g Design Theory
description: A comprehensive study of visual communication focusing on graphic design from 1900 to the present. An introduction to design thinking, language and principles including political and cultural implications.

title: ACAD 330 3D Design: Objects and Space
description: to produce finished models and prototypes of package, product and environmentally-based designs in actual and virtual space.

title: ACAD 325 Justice Innovation Startup Lab

title: ACAD 312 Materials Behavior and Processing

title: ACAD 302 The Hacker Imagination: from Ancient Greece to Cupertino

title: ACAD 301 Understanding Play

title: ACAD 277 Dev III: Advanced Topics

title: ACAD 280 Designing for Experiences

title: ACAD 276 Dev II

title: ACAD 275 Dev I

title: ACAD 240 Materials: Denim to Nanotubes
description: Covers the fundamentals of materials science and introduce students to the principles of designing with specific materials in mind.

title: ACAD 245 Product Design I
description: A wide investigation of techniques specific to dimensional design as they apply to package, product and spatial design, in analog and digital environments.

title: ACAD 207 Multimedia for Designers and Entrepreneurs I
description: Basics of industry-standard hardware and software specific to creating effective and compelling multimedia experiences.

title: ACAD 202 Modeling Physical Systems

title: ACAD 300x Database Web Development

title: ACAD 303 Web Design
description: A workshop-based course that focuses on software applications in design and web design.

title: ACAD 200 Advanced Sound and Audio

title: ACAD 189 Digital Toolbox: Modeling Products II

title: ACAD 181g Disruptive Innovation

title: ACAD 251 Applied Statistics for Analytics

title: ACAD 250 Database Systems for Analytics

title: ACAD 180 Digital Toolbox: Sound and Audio

title: ACAD 177 Digital Toolbox for Design

title: ACAD 176 Rapid Visualization

title: SCOR 490x Directed Research
description: Registration Restriction: Open only to juniors and seniors

title: PPDE 665 Economic Impact Analysis: Methods and Applications

description: Directed research for the MS thesis or PhD dissertation.

title: PSCI 756b Seminar in Pharmaceutical Sciences
description: Review of current pharmaceutical and related research topics.

title: PSCI 790 Research
description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

title: PSCI 756a Seminar in Pharmaceutical Sciences
description: Review of current pharmaceutical and related research topics.

title: PSCI 665 Drug Transport and Delivery

title: PSCI 599 Special Topics
description: Topics in advanced pharmaceutical sciences.

title: PSCI 596 Internship for Curricular Practical Training

Students are individually supervised by faculty. May not be taken until the student has completed at least one semester of enrollment in the graduate program with a cumulative 3.0 GPA.

title: PSCI 594z Master's Thesis
description: completion of all required course work for the MS degree.

title: PSCI 594b Master's Thesis
description: completion of all required course work for the MS degree.

title: PSCI 594a Master's Thesis
description: completion of all required course work for the MS degree.

title: PSCI 590 Directed Research
description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

title: PSCI 556 Principal Research Approaches and Scientific Writing
description: Familiarizes new graduate students with basic approaches used in biomedical research, with a focus on approaches in pharmaceutical, pharmacological and translational sciences. Provides an understanding of what to expect in the coming years as a graduate student doing biomedical research and in scientific writing.

title: PSCI 557 Introduction to Tools and Techniques for Chemical Biology

title: PSCI 515 Drugs: Genetics and Pharmacogenetics

title: PSCI 513 Drugs: Biologics and Specialty Pharmaceuticals

title: PSCI 512 Drugs: Metabolism and Transporters
description: Drug metabolism and transport, mechanism of CYP P450 enzymes, chemistry of metabolic pathways, prediction of metabolism, mechanism of drug uptake and efflux, drug-drug interactions.

title: PSCI 502 Principles of Therapeutic Mechanisms
description: Principles of mechanisms of actions of common drug classes, medicinal chemistry, pharmacology, drug interactions with protein targets, biologics, drug targeting and nanotechnology.

title: PSCI 511 Drugs: Solubility, Dissolution and Absorption

title: PSCI 633 Free Radical Chemistry, Biology, and Medicine

title: PSCI 501 Drugs: Principles of ADME and Bioavailability

title: PR 599 Special Topics
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: PR 598 Graduate Honors Seminar: Improvisational Leadership

title: PR 597 Financial and Investor Communications

title: PR 594z Master's Thesis
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: PR 594b Master's Thesis
description: Grading Option: In Progress to Credit/No Credit

title: PR 594a Master's Thesis
description: Grading Option: In Progress/Credit/No Credit

title: PR 590 Directed Research
description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

title: PR 568 Crisis Management in Strategic Public Relations

title: PR 536 Digital, Social and Mass Media Public Relations Strategies

title: PR 537 Public Relations and Branding

title: PR 534 Case Studies in Public Relations

title: PR 532 International Public Relations

title: PR 510 Legal, Ethical and Social Foundations of Strategic Public Relations

title: PR 527 Multimedia Content Creation for Strategic Public Relations

title: PR 508 Introduction to Strategic Public Relations

title: PR 504 Strategic Public Relations Research, Evaluation and Insights

title: PR 501 Advocacy Communications

title: PR 499 Special Topics
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: PR 498 Public Relations Honors Seminar
description: Leadership workshop inspires students to be braver and more creative; encourages them to discover their leadership potential/explore new challenges inside and outside of classroom.

title: PR 492 Personal Branding
description: Learn to build, promote and manage a personal brand through critical analysis, case study, interactive interpretation and creative problem solving.

title: PR 491 Transmedia, New Media and Strategic Public Relations

title: PR 540 International Journalism Seminar I

title: PR 490 Directed Research
description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

title: PR 487 Multimedia PR Content: Introduction to Audio/Video Tools

title: PR 488 Multimedia PR Content: Visual Communication of Information

title: PR 486 Multimedia PR Content: Introduction to Digital Design Tools

title: PR 485 Multimedia PR Content: Digital/Social Media Lab
