title: PR 481 Careers and Strategies in Health Communication
description: Understanding of the dynamic, changing world of U.S. healthcare; knowledge of healthcare audiences and how to reach them; creating effective strategic communications initiatives.

title: PR 478 Social Media Analytics: Data and Content Creation for Real-time Public Relations
description: Application of monitoring tools to become social media analysts and real-time content creators; interpretation of large data sets drawn from the social web; understanding of how to present data visually for optimal impact.

title: PR 477 Strategic Netnography for Digital Communication Insights
description: Provides deep understanding and hands-on experience in the strategic application of netnography, or digital anthropology, to contemporary public relations and communication fields.

title: PR 473 Emerging Media Strategies for Communication and Public Relations
description: In-depth, hands-on study of emerging tradigital, social and owned media channels; Emphasis on the evaluation of such media as effective tools for audience engagement.

title: PR 463 Strategic Public Relations Research, Analysis and Insights
description: Identification of key strategic insights that drive successful communication campaigns, based on research techniques including surveys, content evaluation and social media monitoring.

title: PR 458 Public Relations in Politics and Political Campaigns
description: Application of public relations principles to the context of political campaigns; emphasis on message development and delivery; relationship between candidate, news media, and electorate.

title: PR 457 The Role of Celebrity in Public Relations
description: Understanding of the history and application of celebrity in public relations, focusing on the entertainment industry and the notoriety attached to politics and the media.

title: PR 456 Public Relations for Diverse Audiences
description: Researching, planning, executing and evaluating communications campaigns aimed at audiences segmented by culture, lifestyle and other factors.

title: PR 455 Public Relations for Non-Profit Organizations
description: Introduction to the specialized field of public relations for non-profit and non-governmental organizations; emphasis on case studies, strategic and critical thinking, and campaign development.

title: PR 454 Sports Public Relations
description: Introduction to the field of sports information and promotion, including lectures, media assignments, role-playing, and presentations by sports professionals.

title: PR 453 Public Relations Strategies for Working with Athletes
description: Sports Public Relations isn't only getting press for a team or player; it's managing communications among influencers. Complements overview course giving students advanced look at practitioners' role with professional athletes.

title: PR 452 Public Relations in Entertainment
description: Public relations in the design, promotion, and presentation of popular entertainment, including films, broadcasting, music, expositions, amusement parks, resorts and arenas.

title: PR 451 Promotional Public Relations
description: Principles and practices of public relations as a basic component in the promotion and marketing of goods and services; regulatory considerations; consumerism.

title: PR 444 Lifestyle Public Relations: Food, Fashion and Fun!
description: An extensive overview of the Lifestyle Public Relations category with special emphasis on social media, non-traditional influencers and audience segmentation.

title: PR 450 Advanced Strategic Public Relations
description: In-depth study of methods for planning, managing and evaluating strategic communication campaigns; critical analysis of contemporary cases; development of campaigns for real world clients.

title: PR 429 Business and Economic Foundations of Public Relations
description: Relationship between public relations/strategic communication and other organizational disciplines; understanding business goals and objectives; economic literacy; financial/investor relations; how PR/communication agencies are built and managed.

title: PR 482 Comparative Media in Europe
description: Examines print, broadcast and public relations media and their interactive roles in multi-national and supra-national settings at sites in both Western and Eastern Europe.

title: PR 428 Social, Legal and Ethical Foundations of Public Relations
description: Covers the complex intersection of legal standards and regulations, ethical practices and decision making, and social responsibilities for public relations/strategic communication practitioners.

title: PR 410 London Calling: Public Relations in the UK Hub
description: Examines how politics affects and influences public relations campaigns in the UK and Europe.

title: PR 390 Special Problems
description: Supervised, individual studies. No more than one registration permitted. Enrollment by petition only.

title: PR 352 Public Relations Media and Content for Non-Majors
description: Learn advanced public relations writing and editing, basic design skills and sophisticated video planning, shooting, editing and production skills.

title: PR 351a Strategic Public Relations Media and Content
description: Introduction to media relations, social media and influencer engagement; intensive writing and creating multimedia content for traditional, emerging and social media.

title: PR 351b Strategic Public Relations Media and Content
description: Advanced course in writing, digital content and multimedia creation; production of communications collateral for social and owned media channels targeting an array of audiences.

title: PR 343 Advertising Design and Production
description: Production of advertising materials; emphasis on the creation and design of advertising elements.

title: PR 342 Advertising Media and Analysis
description: Selling, planning, buying for the media; advertising's relationship to society and business; media choice.

title: PR 340 Introduction to Advertising
description: History and development of advertising; basic advertising campaigns showing relationships of marketing, creative, print and electronic media.

title: PR 341 Advertising Copywriting
description: Writing and editing for advertising and commercial copy for all media.

title: PR 250 Strategic Public Relations: An Introduction
description: Strategies and practices in the growing field of public relations/strategic communication, including landmark cases; special emphasis on historical roots, evolution, current and future practice.

title: PR 209 Effective Writing for Strategic Public Relations
description: Focus on the unique writing requirements of social, online, broadcast, print and other media in public relations/strategic communication; emphasis on judgment, context and audience understanding.

title: PPDE 683 Social Finance and Development
description: Critical analysis on the innovations, merits and challenges of wealth creation and poverty reduction based on the microfinance model.

title: PPDE 682 Capstone in Nonprofit Leadership and Management
description: Mission-mandated accountable and ethical practice, individually and organizationally; applications of core competencies; practical inquiry, analysis, systems; comparative frameworks; strategic leadership and management of public value production.

title: PSYC 545 Neuropsychology
description: Brain mechanisms underlying perceptual and cognitive functioning: brain damage, loss of function, and clinical assessment.

title: PSYC 540 Cognitive Neuroscience
description: An examination of the major components of cognition (e.g., perception, memory, intelligence) in terms of the neural coding characteristic of the relevant brain areas.

title: PSYC 544 Psychophysiology
description: Recent research on relations between basic psychological states (e.g., cognition, learning, emotion) and physiological response processes (e.g., autonomic responses, covert muscle activity).

title: PSYC 538 Origins of Human Nature
description: Exploration of the evolutionary and developmental origins of human nature. Topics include navigation, object and number cognition, culture, sexual behavior, cooperation, language, and morality.

title: PSYC 539 Behavioral Approaches to Skill Acquisition
description: Examines contemporary research on behavioral procedures for teaching complex skills to individuals of a variety ages and populations, including language, social, cognitive, vocational, and independent living skills.

title: PSYC 536 Behavioral Interventions
description: Examines empirically supported behavioral interventions across a range of socially relevant behavioral excesses, skill deficits, disorders, and age ranges. Focuses on least-intrusive, person-centered approaches.

title: PSYC 537 Development and Supervision of Intervention Systems
description: Analyzes evidence-based approaches to designing behavior change systems at the individual, family, group, and organizational levels. Examines family and systems variables that affect the likelihood of initial and continued success of interventions.

title: PSYC 535 Research Methods in Behavior Analysis
description: Survey of methods for measuring behavior. Examines theoretical background for single subject research methods, practical application of research methods to treatment evaluation, and analyzes strengths and limitations of single subject research methods.

title: PSYC 534 Social and Emotional Development in Children
description: Theories of social and emotional development, including sociocultural perspectives. Analysis of research on temperament, social relationships, individuation and moral development from birth to adolescence.

title: PSYC 533 Cognitive Development in Children
description: Review of theories of cognitive development. Analysis of research on brain functioning, perception, memory, language, reasoning and academic skills from birth to adolescence.

title: PSYC 532 Ethics for Behavior Analysts
description: Provides training in legal and ethical issues as they pertain to the professional practice of behavior analysis. Reviews the Guidelines for Responsible Conduct for Behavior Analysts, as well as the American Psychological Association's Ethical Principles of Psychologists and Code of Conduct.

title: PSYC 531 Behavioral Assessment
description: Studies theory and application of behavioral methods for skill assessment, functional assessment of destructive behavior, and learner motivation. Discusses relative strengths and limitations of direct versus indirect methods.

title: PSYC 530 Concepts and Principles of Behavior Analysis
description: Provides intensive training in behavioral principles and laws of learning and motivation. Focuses on broad application of principles, from basic research with nonhumans, to application across human clinical populations.

title: PSYC 524 Research Design in Developmental Psychology
description: Review and practice in the analysis and design of experimental and quasiexperimental paradigms for research on ontogenetic age changes and generational differences in behavior.

title: PSYC 521 Cross Cultural Psychology in Applied Settings
description: Examination of major theoretical frameworks mapping worldwide cultures and values with a focus on applying that knowledge in organizations.

title: PSYC 520 Fundamentals of Psychological Measurement
description: Factor analysis; latent variable; scaling; test construction; classical true score reliability model; generalizability theory; validity; decision theoretic approaches to selection; item analysis; item response theory.

title: PSYC 517 Group Dynamics and Leadership
description: Theory and research on effective teams and characteristics of strong leaders. Negotiation, morale-building, managing expectancies, utilization of cultural diversity as a strength.

title: PSYC 515 Clinical Assessment
description: Study of clinical assessment: test construction, measurement and prediction of behavior, major cognitive and personality assessment instruments. (One of three clinical psychology core courses:

title: PSYC 513 Attitudes and Social Influence
description: Current theories of attitudes and behavior, measurement, attitudes as predictors of behaviors, effects on changing attitudes and behavior.

title: PSYC 514 Psychopathology
description: Study of psychopathology: in-depth survey of theory and research concerning psychological disorders; introduction of diagnosis. (One of three clinical psychology core courses: PSYC 514,

title: PSYC 512 Seminar in Social Psychology
description: Problems and theories of the person in the social context. Person perception, interpersonal relations, attitude dynamics, social systems.

title: PSYC 508 Historical Foundations of Psychology
description: History of psychology: clinical, cognitive, developmental, experimental, quantitative, and social; epistemology and philosophy of science as applied to psychology.

title: PSYC 506 Learning and Cognition
description: Survey of learning theory and research, including conditioning and information-processing approaches with human and animal subjects.

title: PSYC 505 Research Methods in Applied Social Psychology
description: Various research techniques that are useful in a variety of different real world settings, such as business, governmental agencies and charities.

title: PSYC 504 Research Design
description: Intensive review of research methods in the behavioral sciences. Problem analysis, formulation of research propositions, and procedures for research inference.

title: PSYC 503L Regression and the General Linear Model
description: Multiple regression as a tool in experimental and non-experimental data; analysis of variance and covariance as regression on coded variables. Computer applications Laboratory exercises.

title: PSYC 502 Classic and Modern Statistical Methods II
description: Classic and modern ANOVA, ANCOVA methods, multiple comparison procedures, basic multivariate methods, robust regression methods and basic methods for analyzing categorical data.

title: PSYC 501L Classic and Modern Statistical Methods I
description: An introduction to classic statistical techniques as well as modern robust methods for dealing violations of standard assumptions.

title: PSYC 500L An Overview of Quantitative Methods in Psychology
description: Team taught introduction to analysis of variance, regression analysis, multivariate measurement, and significance testing. Computer laboratory linked to class material using SAS, SPSS, and R.

title: PSYC 499 Special Topics
description: Selected topics in the various specialty areas within psychology. Topic will vary from semester to semester.

title: PSYC 490x Directed Research
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: PSYC 480x Senior Honors Seminar
description: Advanced study of empirical approaches in psychology. Progress presentations and evaluations of Senior Honors Thesis research. In-depth exploration of issues in science.

title: PSYC 469 Schizophrenia Research
description: Current research on possible causes of schizophrenia. Topics: history, diagnosis, genetics, neural development, obstetrics, psychosocial factors, brain imaging, psychopharmacology, premorbid signs and aging.

title: PSYC 464 Psychology of Marriage and the Family
description: Theories and research on family relationships across the life span, including research methods, cultural and developmental perspectives, communication, conflict, attachment, individual psychopathology and family violence.

title: PSYC 462m Culture and Mental Health
description: The influence of culture, ethnicity, race and gender on human behavior. Mental health issues relevant to ethnic minorities in the U.S.

title: PSYC 459 Industrial/Organizational Psychology
description: I/O Psychologists develop and apply scientifically supported solutions to the workplace. "Industrial" deals with human resource functions, and "Organizational" with psychological aspects of the organization.

title: PSYC 456 Conservation Psychology
description: Examination of theories, research, interventions regarding psychology of environmental sustainability including cognition, emotion, behavior, attitudes, persuasion, values, social identity, consumerism, and science of happiness.

title: PSYC 454 Social Cognition
description: Theory and research on cognitive processes in social behavior, to include social inference, cognition and emotion, the Self, social categorization, person memory, and attribution processes.

title: PSYC 450 Neural Network Models of Social and Cognitive Processes
description: Introduction to using neural network or connectionist models to simulate cognitive, social, emotional and motivational processes; basic concepts and tools in computational neuroscience.

title: PSYC 453 Intergroup Relations
description: Examination of the nature of relations between human groups and the psychological mechanisms relating to intergroup conflict, war, genocide, stereotyping, prejudice, and discrimination.

title: PSYC 440 Introduction to Cognitive Neuroscience
description: Introduction to the major components of cognition (perception, memory, intelligence) in terms of the neural coding characteristic of the relevant brain areas.

title: PSYC 451 Formation and Change of Attitudes
description: Effects of socialization, personal influence, propaganda and social structure on private attitudes and public opinion.

title: PSYC 438 Behavioral Genetics
description: Inheritance and evolution of behavioral characteristics in man and other species.

title: PSYC 437 Adolescent Development
description: The adolescent years from both an applied and a research-oriented perspective. Topics include physical, cognitive, and moral development; socialization; and sexual and sex-role development.

title: PSYC 433 Children's Learning and Cognitive Development
description: Principles of cognitive development, learning, and motivation applied to the development of literacy; includes tutoring a child two hours per week.

title: PSYC 434 Intelligence, Problem Solving and Creativity
description: Psychometric and experimental approaches to the study of intelligence, problem solving, reasoning and creativity, including analysis of mental test construction and validity.

title: PSYC 428 Advanced Psychobiology Seminar
description: Topics in psychobiology, including brain mechanisms that provide for perception, motivation, and memory. Student led mini-lectures and discussion in seminar format.

title: PSYC 430 Social Development of Infants, Children and Adolescents
description: An analysis of selected topics and issues in child social development.

title: PSYC 424 Neuropsychology
description: Effects of brain damage on human behavior and abilities, particularly language, memory, and emotion.

title: PSYC 425 Functional Imaging of the Human Brain
description: Introduction to the physical and physiological bases of Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI), and principles of functional MRI, safety, design and analysis of experiments, and operation.

title: PSYC 426 Motivated Behaviors and Addiction
description: Social, environmental, and physiological influences on behaviors associated with aggression, eating, reproduction, and sleep. Will focus on behavioral disorders such as addiction.

title: PSYC 422 Human Judgment and Decision Making
description: Descriptive and normative models of decision making; topics include probability judgments, inference, correlation, emotion, mental accounting, decision analysis, lens model, equity, social dilemmas, time, risk.

title: PSYC 421L Data Analysis for Psychological Research
description: Multivariate analysis emphasizing model estimation and testing; topics vary, e.g., multiple regression, logistic regression, factor analysis, multilevel linear modeling, structural equation modeling, multiway frequency analysis.

title: PSYC 420 Animal Behavior
description: Exploration of human nature through studies of nonhuman animals, including topics of navigation, culture, object representation, social cognition, music, and morality.

title: PSYC 415L Psychological Measurement
description: Classical and modern approaches to psychological measurement; scaling; test construction; true score reliability model; generalizability theory; validity; decision theoretic selection; item analysis; item response theory.

title: PSYC 418 Experimental Exploration into the Origins of Cognition
description: Exploration of the origins of cognition via the basics of experimental design, 3D computer modeling, data analysis, and scientific presentation.

title: PSYC 412 Current Topics In Social Psychology
description: Extensive examination of select current research in social psychology, based on original research papers. Specific topics change by semester.

title: PSYC 390 Special Problems
description: Supervised, individual studies. No more than one registration permitted. Enrollment by petition only.

title: PSYC 404L Psychophysiology of Emotion
description: Introduction to the scientific study of emotional behavior. Emphasizes research into relations between physiological and psychological variables underlying emotional experience.

title: PSYC 391 Directed Field Experience in Psychology
description: Individual field experience and independent study supervised by an on-site professional and USC faculty sponsor.

title: PSYC 367g Stress, Health, and the Mind-Body Connection
description: Introduction to psychological, biological, and behavioral processes affecting physical health, including stress, coping with disease, health behaviors, and socioeconomic and cultural influences on health.

title: PSYC 372 Human Sexuality
description: Psychological and physiological base of sexuality; gender identity, childbearing, birth control, venereal diseases; dysfunctions and treatments.

title: PSYC 365 Introduction to Forensic Psychology
description: Survey of current topics, technologies and techniques. Students acquire a basic understanding of how forensic psychologists contribute their unique expertise to the American legal system.

title: PSYC 380 Junior Honors Seminar
description: Advanced study of scientific inquiry in psychology with in-depth analysis of current research by faculty in the Psychology Department. Preparation for senior honors thesis research.

title: PSYC 363 Criminal Behavior
description: Genetic, biological, psychological, and sociological characteristics of those who evidence criminal behavior; theoretical formulations to be reviewed and appraised.

title: PSYC 361 Introduction to Clinical Psychology
description: Introduction to the scientist-practitioner model of clinical psychology, including research methods, psychological assessment and diagnosis, psychotherapeutic interventions, and treatment of special populations.

title: PSYC 423 User Experience
description: Introduction to the field of user experience (UX), with a specific focus on theoretical foundations, research methodology and principles of design.

title: PSYC 360 Abnormal Psychology
description: The commonly diagnosed behavior pathologies; biological, social, cultural, and developmental antecedents of abnormal behavior; principles of learning, perception, and motivation, as they relate to psychopathology.

title: PSYC 353g Close Relationships
description: Scientific perspective of close relationships: intimate relationships, friendships and others, evolutionary and biological bases of attraction and love, historical, social , cultural influences.

title: PSYC 339Lg Origins of the Mind
description: Exploration of ancient philosophical questions concerning the origins of human knowledge through empirical studies of infants, animals, and adults from diverse cultures.

title: PSYC 355 Social Psychology
description: Theoretical and experimental analysis of human behavior. Social processes involved in attitudes, conformity, compliance, interpersonal perception, liking, affiliation, aggression, altruism, and group dynamics.

title: PSYC 337L Adult Development and Aging
description: Genetic, physical, and social influences during adult years on perception, learning and memory, intelligence, personality, social roles, and normal and deviant behavioral patterns.

title: PSYC 407 Atypical Language
description: Analysis of atypical language and language pathologies throughout the lifespan and their relevance to current linguistic and cognitive science theory.

title: PSYC 336L Developmental Psychology
description: Child and adolescent behavior and associated theories; exploration of the continuity between child and adult behavior.

title: PSYC 326 Behavioral Neuroscience
description: Neural bases of behavior. Concentration on sensory and motor processes and the interaction of neural, chemical, and hormonal systems.

title: PSYC 405 Child Language Acquisition
description: Universal characteristics of child language; stages of acquisition of phonology, syntax, semantics; processes and dimensions of development; psychological mechanisms; communicative styles.

title: PSYC 406 Psycholinguistics
description: Experimental and theoretical aspects of how spoken and written language is produced and understood, learned during childhood, and affected by brain damage.

title: PSYC 320 Principles of Psychobiology
description: The integrative study of bio-behavioral systems. Evolutionary, developmental, ecological, social, ethological, and physiological factors mediating representative behavioral and psychological phenomenon are examined in detail.

title: PSYC 305 Learning and Memory
description: Principles involved in classical and operant conditioning. Concentration on basic causes of behavior; consideration of the relevance of simple behavioral laws to complicated human behavior.

title: PSYC 316L Non-Experimental Research Methods
description: Non-experimental research methods in psychology. Observational, survey and data analysis exercises.

title: PSYC 314L Research Methods
description: Experimental research methods in psychology; nature and concepts of scientific method.

title: PSYC 304L Sensation and Perception
description: Receptor processes and stimulus organization; traditional topics in the perception of objects, space, time.

title: PSYC 301L Cognitive Processes
description: Experimental and theoretical aspects of human memory, perception, thinking, and language.

title: PSYC 290x Supervised Research in Psychology
description: Supervised Research with department faculty.

title: PSYC 240gx Scientific Inquiry and Reasoning in Health Care
description: Critical analysis and reasoning skills required to solve scientific problems in human behavior, including presentation of data, logic of research design, statistics, and research ethics.

title: PSYC 274Lg Statistics
description: Introduction to the use of statistics in psychology: basic ideas in measurement; frequency distributions; descriptive statistics; concepts and procedures in statistical inference.

title: PSYC 201Lg The Science of Happiness
description: Evaluates scientific research on human happiness. Integrates research from psychology, economics, and neuroscience in the evaluation of personal and public policy choices.

title: PSYC 165Lg Drugs, Behavior and Society
description: An integrative systems perspective of drugs; including their historical, economic, and cultural importance, psychopharmacology, addiction, relationship to crime, and therapeutic use in treating psychological disorders.

title: PSYC 100Lg Introduction to Psychology
description: Introduction to psychological science, including historical and contemporary approaches. Behavior examined from biological, cognitive, social, developmental, and personality perspectives. Disorders and treatments.

title: PSCI 794z Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: PSCI 794c Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: PSCI 794d Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: PSCI 794b Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: PSCI 794a Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: PPDE 661 Methods for Equity Analysis
description: Techniques to measure inequality and segregation. Policy evaluation using techniques for casual inference.

title: PPDE 660 Environmental Policy Design and Analysis
description: Analytical foundation for design of institutions and policies; environmental policy; welfare economics and market failure; policy evaluation; economic policy instruments; climate change policy issues; other policy issues.

title: PPDE 649 International Development NGOs: Theory, Policy and Management Issues
description: Critical issues involved in International Development NGO management; theoretical work and analytical framework to understand organizational features; NGO management, issues and challenges.

title: PPDE 648 Performance Management
description: Concept and practice of performance management; examination of performance measurement; analysis and reporting practices for organizational accountability and improvements; performance design, indicators, utilization of information.

title: PPDE 647 Civic Engagement in Governance
description: Roles of citizens, civic associations, nonprofit organizations, government and business in democratic governance; civil society as the interface among these entities; techniques, purposes and contexts of civic engagement.

title: PPDE 646 Grant Writing Practicum
description: Grant making process and proposal development; philanthropic foundations; strategies for funding; budgeting, logic models, and evaluation; peer review.

title: PSYC 275Lg Language and Mind
description: Language within cognitive science: speech physiology and acoustics, language acquisition, reading, language disorders, perception and mental representation of words, linguistic diversity and computer analysis of speech.

title: PPDE 645 Financial Management of Nonprofit Organizations
description: Accounting and financial management principles and practices in nonprofit organizations: budgeting financial analysis, internal controls, financial policies, grant making and financial reporting.

title: PPDE 636 Urban Spatial Ethnography and Critical Cartography
description: Theories and methods of how to develop original data about, analyze, and produce visualizations of urban space; conventional conceptualization and representations of cities and urban spatial data.

title: PPDE 635 Housing and Land Use in Rapidly Urbanizing Regions
description: Interdisciplinary approach to conceptualize urban land and property rights; property rights strategies; design and policy interventions; the struggle for rights to space in the city.

title: PPDE 644 Land Use and Transportation Planning
description: Key theories of land use — transportation interactions; understanding of land markets and derived-demand approach; use of evidence for information; travel data collection methods; application of land use.

title: PPDE 634 Methodology, Methods and Tools for Urban Sustainability
description: Methodology, assessment and planning methods for urban sustainability and land use planning; how the choice and use of theory and methods impact the planning process; systems and spatial analysis.

title: PPDE 633 Communicating City Design: Positions and Representations
description: Communicating the processes, products, and concepts of city design; merging theoretical and skill-based exercises for effective communication; verbal and graphic communication; physical components of urban landscape and dimensional attributes.

title: PPDE 632 Sustainable Cities
description: Exploration of environmental problems linked to urbanization, drawing on historical analysis, social theory, scientific research, and city planning/design practice. Alternative policy options for urban sustainability.

title: PPDE 631 Public Space: Theory, Policy, and Design
description: Examination of contemporary issues and practices in the design, production, and uses of public space in a comparative perspective; implications for future design and public policy.

title: PPDE 630 Community Health Planning
description: The role of planning in sustaining community health; examines relationship between health and environment; historical development, conceptualization and practice of community health planning.

title: PPDE 629 Transitional Care and Hospital Readmission Prevention
description: Alternatives within the healthcare delivery system beyond the acute hospital; how social, medical and financial determinants provide alternatives to acute care and impact a patient's disposition; Hospital Readmission Penalty Program; effect of the Affordable Care Act of 2010 on patient care.

title: PPDE 610 Population Health Management
description: Principles and concepts of population health management; application of key principles that drive health and well being of populations; development and evaluation of strategies in management of disease and prevention of illness.

title: PPDE 589 Public Policy and Administration in the European Union, Germany, and the United States
description: Governance issues from a comparative perspective with a special focus on the US, Germany and the European Union.

title: PPDE 628 Introduction to Lean Health Care
description: Performance improvement methods and principles in health care; how Lean, Six-Sigma, and Human Centered Design (HCD) methodologies are applied to health care organizations to improve quality and efficiency.

title: PPDE 580 Social Innovation
description: Strategies and processes of social innovation in the context of economics, institutional, and innovation theory. How social innovation materializes across all sectors, including the government, nonprofit, and for-profit spheres. Critical thinking and practical application development to solve social problems.

title: PPD 794z Doctoral Dissertation
description: Duplicates Credit in former PLUS 794abcdz and PUAD 794abcdz.

title: PPD 794d Doctoral Dissertation
description: Duplicates Credit in former PLUS 794abcdz and PUAD 794abcdz.

title: PPD 794c Doctoral Dissertation
description: Duplicates Credit in former PLUS 794abcdz and PUAD 794abcdz.

title: RED 551 The Approval Process
description: Approval process for real estate development including land use entitlement, site selection, zoning, environmental review, community and government relations, infrastructure financing, ethical issues, negotiation skills.

title: PPD 794b Doctoral Dissertation
description: Duplicates Credit in former PLUS 794abcdz and PUAD 794abcdz.

title: PPD 794a Doctoral Dissertation
description: Duplicates Credit in former PLUS 794abcdz and PUAD 794abcdz.

title: RED 547 Project Management and Construction
description: Managing the building phase of development. Architectural and engineering aspects of construction management for the real estate developer.

title: PPD 790 Research
description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

title: PPD 713 Advanced Planning Theory
description: Positive and normative attitudes of public plans, policies, programs, organizational and institutional settings; policy analysis; modeling of social choices; evaluation; applied welfare analysis; performance assessment.

title: PPD 715 Political Economy and Institutional Analysis
description: Institutional dimension of political economy; analytic approaches in institutional analysis and their relevance for understanding the interactions between political and economic factors in public-sector issues.

title: PPD 714 Advanced Urban Development
description: Urbanization, urban economics, land use, the politics of growth, governance, regulation, and the state, immigration, and place promotion.

title: PPD 712 Seminar in Public Policy
description: Critical analysis of the policy field; theoretical foundations; integration of quantitative, organizational, and political considerations; policy research.

title: PPD 711 Theoretical Foundation of Public Management
description: Theories of the role, structure, and growth of the public sector; political economy of public bureaucracies; the voluntary nonprofit sector.

title: PPD 710a Research Seminar
description: Research fields and design; literature reviews; critical reading and critiquing; project development.

title: PPD 709 Applications in the Advanced Quantitative Methods
description: Statistical and econometric modeling in real estate finance, urban economics, public policy, and planning research. Building, estimating and adjusting models for real-world.

title: PPD 710b Research Seminar
description: Research fields and design; literature reviews; critical reading and critiquing; project development.

title: PPD 795 Law of the Political Process
description: Examines the state and federal laws regulating the political process and related Constitutional issues.

title: PPD 708 Qualitative Methods
description: Reflective and critical approach that questions data collection techniques, positions relative to those being studied, and explanatory methods.

title: PPD 797 Public Policy in Law: Analysis and Advocacy
description: Focuses on contemporary policy problems, identifies relevant legal issues and utilizes multidisciplinary techniques found in law, political science, economics and history to formulate positions.

title: PPD 706 Paradigms of Research and the Design of Inquiry
description: Philosophy of social science; applied social research; research design; sampling and validity; overview of qualitative and quantitative methods.

title: PPD 707 Survey Research Methods
description: Collection and use of survey data: basic orientation, mechanics of using SAS, and interpretation of survey tabulations.

title: RED 546 Applications of Real Estate Finance to Problems of Development
description: Advanced topics in finance applied to cases and problems of real estate development; emphasis on structuring, finance and evaluation of various types of development projects.

title: RED 544 Real Estate Capital Markets
description: Explore structure, instruments and institutions of real estate capital markets. Consider linkages between real estate and capital markets. Assess role of Real Estate Investment Trusts.

title: RED 545 Advanced Real Estate and Financial Modeling
description: Quantitative problem solving using computerized modeling. Complex debt financing, including lender participation, subordination, joint venture structuring, systematic treatment of real estate portfolios.

title: RED 541 Finance Fundamentals for Real Estate Development
description: Introduction to the general principles of finance with application to real estate development, including capital markets, financial institutions, valuation and risk management.

title: RED 542 Finance of Real Estate Development
description: Theory and methods of real estate finance and investment. Real estate investment analysis, real estate entities, taxation; introduction to securization of real estate equities, debt.

title: RED 510 Real Estate Practice and Principles
description: Fundamental principles of real estate analysis; economics; capital markets; development decision-making; relationships between real estate markets and federal, state and local government policies; property value.

title: RED 512 Real Estate Project Analysis
description: Fundamental economic theories; analytical techniques; practical applications for market analysis of various forms of real estate.

title: RED 511 Foundations of Real Estate Analysis
description: Principles of real estate analysis; capital markets; importance of uncertainty and metrics of risk; investments; valuation techniques; use of debt and equity, leases, taxes.

title: RED 500 Real Estate Development and the Economy
description: Linkages between national and regional economies and the performance of the real estate sector. Anticipating development trends. Public policy applications.

title: RED 509 Market Analysis for Real Estate
description: Explores macro and micro aspects of residential, retail, office, and industrial markets and examines methodologies for analyzing such markets for real estate development/investment purposes.

title: RED 499 Special Topics
description: Selected topics in real estate development.

title: RED 490x Directed Research
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: RED 437 Advanced Finance and Investment for Real Estate Development
description: Advanced real estate principles. Underwriting property valuation and deal structure including risk and return. Debt and equity markets; difference between development and existing assets.

title: RED 435 Analyzing Real Estate Markets
description: Macro and micro-analysis of urban property markets; demographics; location choice; regulation

title: RED 425 Designing Livable Communities
description: Theories and concepts of livable communities and good city form; case studies of historical and current best practices; field visits; collaborative design project.

title: RED 417 History of Planning and Development
description: Historical evolution of planning and development. How changing modes of planning and development have shaped the built landscape throughout the century.

title: RED 398 Shaping Cities Through Real Estate
description: Cities and urban form created through various real estate product types. Case studies and site visits.

title: RED 375 Real Estate Development Analysis
description: Real estate development feasibility and analysis; underwriting local fundamentals including neighborhood and city change, real estate capital flows

title: PPD 698 Strategic Management and Change
description: Theory and applied skills in management of social sector organizations with applications in international settings. Strategic management and planning; communication strategies, marketing and promotion; leadership skills; organizational development and change.

title: PPD 697 Cultural Proficiency in Health Management and Policy
description: Provides an understanding of what social factors contribute to racial/ethnic, socioeconomic, and gender disparities in health and the culturally proficient provision of health care.

title: RED 362 Real Estate Development Fundamentals
description: Real estate overview; evolution of cities and neighborhoods; product types; introduction to valuation.

title: PPD 695 Clinical Issues for Managers
description: Introduces key information and concepts for managers of clinical services. Examines problems and issues facing health care managers and clinician relations.

title: PPD 696 Health Care Venture Development
description: Focuses on developing the resourcefulness, know-how and decision support skills needed to identify, assess and develop new health ventures. Includes business planning, financing, strategy, entrepreneurship.

title: PPD 693 Communicating Public Policy
description: Exploring the complex relationships that exist among policies, policymakers, and the media; analyzing the role of journalists and policy analysts in the public policy process.

title: PPD 694 Coastal Policy and Planning
description: Coastal management issues in the context of public and private users competing for land resources, the costs and benefits of seaports, compare coastal development models.

title: PPD 690 Alternative Dispute Resolution
description: Theory and methods of conflict analysis, negotiation, facilitation and mediation in the public sector.

title: PPD 689 The Nonprofit Sector and Philanthropy
description: Nonprofit organizations and their relation to government and business; the role of philanthropy, social enterprise and public support; and implications for policy, strategy and management.

title: PPD 688 Business and Public Policy
description: The business-government relationship; effects of selected public policies (antitrust, economic, and social regulation, industrial policies, legal policy) on firm and industry behavior.

title: PPD 687 Strategic Management in the Nonprofit Sector
description: Strategic management of nonprofit organizations, social entrepreneurship, and management practice.

title: RED 351 Land Use Regulation
description: Land use planning and zoning; community and government relations; environmental regulation.

title: QBIO 499 Special Topics
description: Registration Restriction: Open only to QBIO majors. Other majors require permission from the instructor

title: QBIO 494x Quantitative Biology Honors Thesis
description: Experience in conducting research and writing a thesis under supervision of a faculty adviser.

title: QBIO 490x Directed Research
description: Individual research and readings. Project approval by QBIO committee or faculty adviser required.

title: QBIO 493 Quantitative Biology Honors Seminar
description: Student-led discussions of recent research in quantitative biology and presentation of their own research.

title: QBIO 105 Introduction to Quantitative Biology Seminar
description: Introduction to quantitative biology including a definition of its role within the Biological Sciences and relationship with Chemistry, Computer Science, Engineering, Mathematics, Medicine and Physics.

title: PUBD 599 Special Topics
description: Special topics in the area of public diplomacy.

title: PUBD 596 Practicum in Public Diplomacy Research
description: Development and production of original research-based project in the area of public diplomacy.

title: PUBD 590 Directed Research
description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the school.

title: PUBD 526 Public Diplomacy Evaluation
description: Critical examination of challenges and benefits of measuring public diplomacy's impact; terminology and mechanics of evaluation, the measurement community, and varying approaches for evaluation.

title: PUBD 522 Hard Power, Soft Power and Smart Power
description: Institutional and cultural perspectives on instruments of state power: military, intelligence, trade, and traditional diplomacy; strategic analyses for determining proper use; desirability of combining resources.

title: PUBD 524 The Public Diplomacy of Trade
description: Public diplomacy's role in shaping ideas about trade and development and in creating trade agreements, and the use of trade agreements as public diplomacy.

title: PUBD 520 Regional Studies in Public Diplomacy
description: In-depth examination of historical, political, economic, cultural factors that influence public diplomacy efforts within specific geographic regions.

title: PUBD 519 News Media and the Foreign Policy Process
description: Analysis of news media's role in contemporary diplomacy; historical context; consideration of the professional practices of journalists and those who devise and implement foreign policy.

title: PUBD 518 International Exchanges and Public Diplomacy
description: Examination of educational and cultural exchanges; variety and experience of participants, flagship exchange programs, economic and social implications of the programs, and measurement of outcomes.

title: PPD 686 U.S. Immigration Policy
description: Overall understanding of contemporary U.S. immigration policy.

title: PPD 685 Human Resources Management in Public and Non-Profit Sectors
description: Merit principles, position classification, recruitment and selection, compensation, organizational development, labor relations; challenges and strategies for managing a diverse workforce.

title: PPD 684 Leadership Development in the Public and Nonprofit Sectors
description: An overview of leadership concepts, frameworks and skills; application of leadership in complex or inter-sectoral settings.

title: PPD 683 Homeland Security and Public Policy
description: Definition and history of terrorism, counterterrorism, domestic policy and public sector management; intelligence/information sharing and analysis; emergency preparedness planning, response and recovery.

title: PPD 681 Public Organization and Management Theory
description: Nature and management of public organizations; examination of organizational characteristics, forms, and processes, including the relationship with the broader environment.

title: PPD 682 Justice Administration: A Management Perspective
description: Justice administration as an interactive system: law, etiology of crime, police, the judiciary and corrections. Interface of offenders with community and political force fields.

title: PPD 680 Development of Effective Groups and Organizations
description: Theories and techniques of assessing and improving interpersonal relationships and group dynamics in an organizational context; action research-based approaches to implementing organizational change.

title: PPD 679 Financial Administration in Developing Countries
description: Public sector finance; tax policy and administration; budgeting and auditing; debt management; public enterprise and development banks; planning; techniques; project assessment.

title: PPD 678 Processes of Change in Developing Societies
description: Nature of traditional and transitional societies; theories and practice of developmental change; role of bureaucracy in development; institution building; public enterprise; technology assessment and transfer.

title: PPD 677 International Development Administration
description: Development of theories; role of international institutions in resource exchanges; foreign investment and trade policies; national planning and allocation systems; development and modernization strategies and implementation.

title: PPD 676 Comparative Public Administration
description: Methodologies, theories and models of comparison; administrative systems; role and functions of the public sector; administrative cultures.

title: PPD 674 Science, Technology, and Government
description: Impact of science/technology on governmental policy, processes, institutions; critical policy areas in science/technology; machinery for formulating science policy; governmental impact on science/technology.

title: PPD 675 Nonprofit Management and Leadership
description: Issues in nonprofit management and leadership including: the role of boards; strategic planning; marketing and fund-raising; financial management; and volunteer and human resource management.

title: PPD 672 Presidency, Congress, and the Bureaucracy
description: Relationships in national government among political executive, legislative, and administrative units; reviews institutions, formal processes, and political dynamics.

title: PPD 673 Strategic Planning in the Public Sector
description: Analysis/field application of action research models for strategic planning in public agencies; design of effective public systems; citizens/administrators' roles in strategic decision-making.

title: PPD 671 Decision-Making in Regulatory Agencies
description: Risk assessment, management, and communication concepts and practices; comparisons of regulatory decision making in regulatory agencies; emerging benefit assessment, cost-effectiveness, and communication issues.

title: PPD 669 Federal Management Systems
description: Principal institutions and processes in federal government for overhead leadership and control; examines Office of Management and Budget, Office of Personnel Management, Merit Systems Protection Board, General Services Administration, and General Accounting Office.

title: PPD 670 Management of Intergovernmental Programs
description: Analysis of relationships among governmental units in delivery of governmental programs; historical development of intergovernmental relations; present status and future implications.

title: PPD 668 Entrepreneurship in the Public Sector
description: Providing public services through the private and nonprofit sectors; public-private partnerships; political and organizational skills required for public entrepreneurship.

title: PPD 667 Public Ethics
description: Following an introduction to the study of ethics, relationships among administrative, political and policy ethics are examined, emphasizing the ethics of the administrative role.

title: PPD 665 Contemporary Issues in Philanthropy
description: Motivations and strategies of philanthropists; philanthropic foundations and emerging institutions for philanthropy; issues of philanthropic stewardship, public policy and public accountability.

title: PPD 666 Administrative Research and Analysis
description: Theory and methods for study of administrative effectiveness: problem solving, performance measurement, administrative and organizational research, quality improvement, and change implementation.

title: PUBD 515 Transnational Diplomacy and Global Security
description: Examination of the historical and theoretical basis of diplomatic relationships between states, international organizations, and transnational nonstate actors in developing global peace and security policies.

title: PUBD 516 International Broadcasting
description: History, context and practice of global international broadcasting strategies; technological and financial parameters that shape future international broadcasting strategies; use of radio, television, and Internet.

title: PUBD 514 Corporate Diplomacy
description: Provides basic public diplomacy and public relations tools for global organizations and their foreign publics.

title: PUBD 512 Cultural Diplomacy
description: Provides overview of formal cultural diplomacy and concentrates on ways in which non-governmental entities communicate across international boundaries and the effects of those interchanges.

title: PUBD 508 The Rhetoric of War and Peace
description: Special exercise in "Think Tank" procedure that explores rhetorics of war and peace from a 21st century perspective.

title: PUBD 510 Technologies and Public Diplomacy
description: Explores relationship between diplomacy and technological change. Emphasis on question of how new media may force us to rethink traditional frameworks of public diplomacy.

title: PUBD 509 Advocacy in Public Diplomacy: Argumentation and Debate
description: Skills and theory based approach to the criticism and development of public diplomacy campaigns. Emphasizes the instruction of advocacy skills to assess the utility of specific campaigns.

title: PUBD 504 Global Issues and Public Diplomacy
description: Focuses on critical global issues/challenges that require some form of intervention from the international community. Taught with active leading strategies: case studies and "problem-based learning."

title: PUBD 502 Historical and Comparative Approaches to Public Diplomacy
description: Examines historical and comparative approaches to public diplomacy. Explores public diplomacy operations in public and private settings, by individuals and institutions. Reviews traditional, critical, war, and peace perspectives.

title: PUAD 791b Public Administration Research Seminar
description: Presentation and discussion of research histories and current research projects of members of the faculty and distinguished guest scholars.

title: PUBD 500 Introduction to the Advanced Study of Public Diplomacy
description: Introduction to the advanced academic study of public diplomacy from multidisciplinary perspectives: including media and communication, international relations and history.

title: PUAD 697 Seminar in Public Management
description: Public management research and theory; differences between private and public organizations: contextual influences on public management; contemporary empirical studies; bibliographic research.

title: PUAD 791a Public Administration Research Seminar
description: Presentation and discussion of research histories and current research projects of members of the faculty and distinguished guest scholars.

title: PUAD 692 Multivariate Statistical Analysis
description: Multivariate analysis of qualitative and quantitative variables including multiple linear regression, multiple contingency table analysis, log-linear and logit models, and path analysis.

title: PUAD 695 Seminar in Administrative Theory
description: Assessment of current normative and descriptive theories of public administration; variety of conceptual systems; operationalism; levels of organizational analysis.

title: PTE 505 Inverse Modeling for Dynamic Data Integration
description: Introduction to fundamentals of deterministic and stochastic inverse modeling, integration of dynamic data into predictive reservoir models, reservoir parameterization, derivation of adjoint models.

title: PUAD 675 Institutional Context of the Public Sector
description: Theories of the role, structure and growth of the public sector; public choice processes; political economy of public bureaucracies; the voluntary nonprofit sector.

title: PTE 504 Geophysics for Petroleum Engineers
description: Geosciences concepts and technologies with applications in petroleum engineering: 2D-3D-4D seismic, borehole geophysics, passive seismic, controlled source electromagnetics, geophysical and geological modeling and inversion.

title: PUAD 685 Seminar on Organizational Behavior in Public Systems
description: Organizing processes; decision-making; communication; leadership; behavioral models; political and social behavior in organizations.

title: PPD 664 Contract Management
description: Contract management techniques in the public and private sectors; micro and macro management; compliance and negotiation; conflicts of interest and ethical issues.

title: PTE 503 Technology of Unconventional Oil and Gas Resources Development
description: Geology of unconventional resources, exploration, development, laboratory testing, drilling, formation evaluation, design and monitoring of hydraulic fracturing, forecasting, technology of oil sand and environmental issues.

title: PPD 663 Intergovernmental Management: Federal Perspective
description: Role of national government in intergovernmental process; impact of federal legislative, executive, and judicial actions on state and local government; intergovernmental policy-making process.

title: PPD 661 Intergovernmental Management: Local Perspective
description: Role of city, special district, and metropolitan governments in intergovernmental relations; intergovernmental impacts on local policy process and service delivery; management problems and alternatives.

title: PPD 662 Intergovernmental Management: State Perspective
description: Role of state government in intergovernmental relations, emphasis on California experience; financial aspects of intergovernmental system.

title: PPD 658 Advocacy in Public Administration
description: Perspectives on advocacy in the policy process; practice of advocacy; accessing the policy process; simulation of the advocacy process; ethical considerations.

title: PPD 660 Local Agency Debt and Cash Administration
description: Overview of methods of debt and cash administration including official statement analysis; mechanics of different types of issues; and cash management principles.

title: PPD 659 National Security Administration and the Domestic and International Environment
description: Interplay of domestic and international environments; resultant constraints upon national security program administration; administrative and organizational implications for future scenarios.

title: PPD 656 Political Management: Theory and Applied Techniques
description: Political management theories; strategy formation; research and data collection approaches; computer applications; electronic databases; issue management; problem-solving techniques; ethical considerations.

title: PPD 657 Political Leadership in Public Organizations
description: Concepts and skills for public executives and senior managers; understanding the dynamics of governmental institutions and policy processes; organizational and personal assessment skills.

title: PPD 654 Information Technology Management in the Public Sector
description: Application of computer and information technology in government; e-government; information technology architecture; systems project management.

title: PPD 655 Administrative Law and Public Management
description: Administrative perspectives on legal principles of agency rule-making and adjudication; distinctions between the two; informal administrative actions; decision-making; judicial review; public control of administrative decisions.

title: PPD 653 Training in the Public Sector
description: Emergence of public service training; learning theories; program development process — assessing needs, design, delivery, and evaluation; role of media; individual, group, organization development; managing training.

title: PPD 651 Seminar in the Administration of Local Government
description: Intensive consideration of the functions of the municipal executive and his environment. Research preparation and discussion of cases.

title: PPD 652 Financial Administration in Local Government
description: Revenue sources, fees and charges, benefit assessments; financing economic development and redevelopment, issuing and managing debt, current asset management, and state-local relations.

title: PPD 650 Organization Development in Public Administration
description: Overview of concepts and methodologies of organization development; diagnosing organizational needs; developing change strategies; selecting appropriate interventions.

title: PPD 648 Concepts and Practices of Public Budgeting
description: Budget planning, budget formulation, tools for budget analysis and budget implementation.

title: PPD 649 Concepts and Practices in Public Personnel Administration
description: Concepts of man and of work; workforce; government personnel systems, including merit concepts, classification, and compensation; collective bargaining; organizational justice; training and development.

title: PPD 646 Fieldwork
description: Supervised study of management activities in governmental agencies.

title: PPD 647 Finance of the Public Sector
description: Sources of government revenue, intergovernmental financial relations, budgeting, public goods theory. Theoretical and applied skills in analysis of equity and efficiency issues.

title: PUAD 617 Seminar on Behavioral Aspects of Training and Development
description: Theoretical concepts governing the administration of socio-technical systems, organization development, action training and research, and other development and change processes utilized in public service.

title: PUAD 613 Seminar in Financial Policy
description: Historical development and trends in public revenues and expenditures. Political, economic, and administrative significance of decisions in the field of financial management.

description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: PTE 794d Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: PTE 794c Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit
