title: PTE 790 Research
description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

title: PTE 690 Directed Research
description: Laboratory study of specific problems for candidates for the degree engineer in petroleum engineering.

title: PTE 599 Special Topics
description: Course content will be selected each semester to reflect current trends and developments in the field of petroleum engineering.

title: PTE 594z Master's Thesis
description: For the master's degree. Credit on acceptance of thesis.

title: PTE 594b Master's Thesis
description: For the master's degree. Credit on acceptance of thesis.

title: PTE 594a Master's Thesis
description: For the master's degree. Credit on acceptance of thesis.

title: PTE 594 Formation Damage in Petroleum Reservoirs
description: Overview of background and techniques required for understanding, assessing, and mitigating formation damage in petroleum and subsurface reservoirs.

title: PTE 591 Petroleum Geochemistry
description: Application of chemical principles to the study of the origin, migration, accumulation, and alteration of petroleum.

title: PTE 590 Directed Research
description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

title: PTE 592 Computational Geomechanics
description: Physical, mathematical and simulation aspects of coupled fluid flow and geomechanics in petroleum reservoirs.

title: PTE 589 Advanced Oilfield Operations with Remote Immersive Visualization and Control
description: Immersive subsurface and surface environments, web based monitoring and feedback, visualizing risk, unattended operation. Limited to students with graduate standing.

title: PTE 587 Smart Completions, Oilfield Sensors and Sensor Technology
description: Intelligent Wellbore completion, technology of subsurface and surface sensors, deployment and data acquisition, telemonitoring and feedback, reliability of sensors, data transmission, systems networks.

title: PTE 588 Smart Oilfield Data Mining
description: Methods for oilfield data mining, data preparation mining images, prediction and knowledge discovery, subset selection, pattern recognition. Limited to students with graduate standing.

title: PTE 500 Computational Reservoir Modeling
description: Introduction to mathematical and computational methods in characterizing, modeling, and describing the subsurface flow and transport phenomena.

title: PTE 499 Special Topics
description: Course content to be selected each semester from recent developments in petroleum engineering and related fields.

title: PTE 502 Advanced Reservoir Characterization
description: Sources of data for reservoir characterization; cross-disciplinary integration; geologic models; sequence stratigraphic, lithologic, well test and geophysical models; 4-D seismic; compartmentalized and fractured reservoirs; error and risk analysis.

title: PTE 490x Directed Research
description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

title: PTE 466 Petroleum Geology
description: Introductory topics of physical and historical geology will be focused on the components that relate to the formation of oil and gas accumulations.

title: PTE 412x Petroleum Reservoir Engineering
description: Properties of reservoir fluids, volumetric and material balances for gas and oil reservoirs; reservoir modeling concepts.

title: PTE 390 Special Problems
description: Supervised, individual studies. No more than one registration permitted. Enrollment by petition only.

title: PTE 202x Energy and Society
description: Study of the impact of the development, production, and global distribution of energy on societal, political, and economic behavior. Not available for major credit to engineering majors.

title: PT 665 Advanced Clinical Experience
description: A 16-week clerkship consisting of a minimum of 36 hours per week in a full-time setting. Emphasis on care of orthopedic, neurologic, pediatric or complicated medical conditions.

title: PTE 411 Introduction to Transport Processes in Porous Media
description: Properties of porous rocks; capillarity effect, single-phase and multiphase fluid flow through porous media; diffusion and dispersion, miscible displacement heat transfer. Lecture, 3 hours. Not available for credit to Petroleum Engineering majors.

title: PT 660 Advanced Clinical Experience with Academic Integration
description: A 16-week clerkship consisting of a minimum of 24 hours per week in a part-time setting. Emphasis on the care of orthopedic, neurologic, pediatric or complicated medical conditions.

title: PT 650 Differential Diagnosis in Physical Therapy
description: Consideration of principle of differential diagnosis with emphasis on mastering this skill.

title: PT 630 Integrated Patient Management Clinical Skills
description: Advanced evaluation and management of patients with movement dysfunction spanning all diagnoses seen by physical therapists.

title: PPD 645 Professional Development
description: Selected topics in the practical application of administrative concepts.

title: PT 632 Integrated Patient Management Seminar
description: Integration of physical therapy management of complicated patients with concurrent musculoskeletal, cardiopulmonary and/or neurologic disorders.

title: PT 621L Clinical Management of the Patient with Musculoskeletal Dysfunction
description: Physical therapy theory and methods of evaluation and treatment of orthopedic dysfunction.

title: PTE 586 Intelligent and Collaborative Oilfield Systems Characterization and Management
description: Review of soft computing methods such as neural networks, fuzzy logic, problematic reasoning in reservoir characterization, dynamic reservoir modeling, oilfield data integration and analysis of uncertainty in prediction. Limited to students with graduate standing.

title: PTE 581 Environmental Technology in the Petroleum Industry
description: This course examines engineering and scientific principles necessary for understanding, assessing, and remediating environmental problems in the petroleum industry including drilling, production, transportation and refining operations. Graduate standing.

title: PTE 578 Advanced Production Engineering
description: Principles of onshore and offshore oil well & gas well production; design of artificial lift systems and surface operations; field problems of enhanced oil recovery operations.

title: PTE 572 Geostatistics
description: Use of geostatistical methods for exploration and development of mineral and petroleum resources, application of semivariogram, kriging, cokriging, nonlinear and parametric estimation and conditional stimulation. Graduate standing.

title: PTE 574 Optimization Methods for Subsurface Energy Resources Development
description: Optimization algorithms for oilfield development, including well control optimization, well placement, open-loop and closed-loop model predictive control, and robust optimization.

title: PTE 555 Well Completion, Stimulation, and Damage Control
description: This course reviews current practices related to well completion methods, wellbore stimulation, and damage control. Formation damage prevention and stimulation methods are emphasized.

title: PTE 542 Carbonate Rocks
description: Classification; porosity development; source rocks; wettability; capillary pressure curves; compressibility; surface areas; relative permeabilities; various petrophysical properties; formation evaluation; overpressures; thin section analysis.

title: PTE 545 Corrosion Control in Petroleum Production
description: Types of corrosion encountered in petroleum production; methods for practical control including use of inhibitors, coatings, and cathodic protection.

title: PTE 519 Integrated Physical and Cyber Security for Oil and Gas Operations
description: Infrastructure Security, Resilience and Management of Digital Oil Fields, Process Control Networks in exploration and production, refining and chemical plants, Asset Integrity principles, case histories.

title: PTE 517 Testing of Wells and Aquifers
description: Principles of well testing; down hole device; Aquifer tests; slug tests; DST; pressure transient modeling in homogeneous and heterogeneous systems; parameter estimation; computer aided techniques.

title: PTE 515 Natural Gas Engineering
description: Characterization, development and prediction of natural gas reservoirs, including natural gas surface production equipment and systems, forecasting natural gas well and reservoir performance and current LNG developments

title: PTE 512 Gas Injection Processes — Analytical Solutions and Analysis
description: Gas injection and enhanced oil/gas recovery; conservation equations; flow and phase behavior; displacement efficiency; dispersion; method of characteristics; development of multicontact miscibility in multicomponent systems.

title: PTE 508 Numerical Simulation of Subsurface Flow and Transport Processes
description: Formulation and solution of the equations describing the underground flow of fluids through porous media. Includes mass (contaminant) transport in single and multiphase flow.

title: PTE 511 Advanced Phase Behavior of Petroleum Reservoir Fluids
description: From classical thermodynamics to engineering application; equations of state based calculations; PVT experiments; reservoir fluid characterization; PT-flash calculations and stability analysis; compositional grading; transport properties.

title: PTE 507 Engineering and Economic Evaluation of Subsurface Reservoirs
description: Studies, data and methods for estimating size of underground fluid deposits for predicting physical and economic behavior of designed flow schemes, and for quantifying uncertainty.

title: PT 606 Clinical Imaging
description: Elements of reading roentgenographs, CAT and MRI scans for the physical therapist. Lecture, demonstration, practical experience.

title: PTE 514 Drilling Engineering
description: Graduate level course on drilling engineering with an emphasis on field design and applications. Topics covered include well planning; rock mechanics; rotary drilling processes; drilling rig components; drill string and bottom hole assemblies; well hydraulics and drilling muds; casing design and cementing; directional drilling; offshore drilling and drilling economics.

title: PT 600z Clinical Clerkship
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: PT 600d Clinical Clerkship
description: Practical experience in eight week physical therapy psychomotor skills, decision making and professional behaviors.

title: PT 600c Clinical Experience
description: Practical experience in two-week physical therapy psychomotor skills, decision making and professional behaviors.

title: PT 600b Clinical Experience
description: Practical experience in six-week physical therapy manual skills, decision making, and professional behaviors.

title: PT 600a Clinical Experience
description: Practical experience in two- or six-week physical therapy manual skills, decision making and professional behaviors.

title: PT 599 Special Topics
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: PT 582 Mechanics of Human Gait
description: Introduction to both normal and pathological gait. Emphasis on the basic components of abnormal ambulation including temporal-spatial factors, joint motion, kinetics, kinematics, and muscle activity.

title: PT 583L Clinical Electrophysiology
description: Use of electrical currents to evaluate and treat musculoskeletal, neurological and wound disorders. Theory and practice.

title: PT 571L Clinical Management of Cardiopulmonary Dysfunction
description: Physical therapy evaluation and intervention in the care of patients with circulatory, cardiac, or pulmonary dysfunction. Lecture, case presentations, laboratory.

title: PT 581L Clinical Management of the Patient with Neurological Dysfunction
description: Physical therapy theory and methods for intervention in neurological dysfunction.

title: PT 566 Disorders of the Musculoskeletal System
description: Regional description of pathology and pathophysiological mechanisms of disorders of bone, connective tissue, and joints. Lecture, demonstration.

title: PT 574 Clinical Biomechanics
description: Introduction to the principles of biomechanics (statics, dynamics) as they apply to physical therapy practice. Emphasis on tissue mechanics, joint function and gait.

title: PT 569 Fundamentals of Neuroscience
description: Detailed analysis of neurophysiologic mechanisms underlying normal and abnormal motor and sensory function.

title: PT 561e Evidence for Physical Therapist Practice
description: Analysis of the integration of physical therapist practice into the national health care system; administration, budgeting and reimbursement for physical therapist services.

title: PT 561d Evidence for Physical Therapist Practice
description: Advanced integration of patient values as influenced by culture, ethnicity, lifestyles, gender, and age into patient-centered clinical decision making.

title: PT 561c Evidence for Physical Therapist Practice
description: Advanced critical analysis and application of research of evidence.

title: PT 561b Evidence for Physical Therapist Practice
description: Introduction to acquiring, appraising and integrating research evidence.

title: PT 561a Evidence for Physical Therapist Practice
description: Introduction to a patient-centered Evidence Based Practice model with emphasis on professional communication skills, ethics, professional guidelines, laws and regulations.

title: PT 554L Analytical Anatomy
description: Detailed kinesiologic analysis of axial, spine, head, neck, face and bulbar muscles.

title: PT 551L Therapeutic Application of Physical Agents
description: Physiologic responses to the application of thermal, mechanical, electromagnetic and hydrodynamic therapeutic procedures. Evaluation procedures and intervention planning.

title: PTE 506 Geothermal Reservoirs
description: Geothermal reservoirs, heat and mass flow in fracture network, enhanced geothermal systems (EGS), exploration methods, exploitation of hydrothermal and EGS fields, stimulation, forecasting, power generation.

title: PT 549L Clinical Exercise Physiology
description: Adaptation of the human body to exercise and the use of exercise to modify human function.

title: PT 546 Neuropathology
description: Pathology in the central and peripheral nervous systems that alter motor and sensory performance. Emphasis on loss of motion, excessive and involuntary movement disorders.

title: PT 539 Clinical Pharmacology
description: Effects of commonly used drugs in patients with physical disability; side effects that alter physical performance or responses to exercise.

title: PT 534L Neuroanatomy
description: Organized approach to structures in the brain, spinal cord and peripheral nervous systems that subserve motor, sensory, and integrative functions, memory, cognitive and special senses.

title: PT 530a Therapeutic Exercise
description: Theoretical and practical principles for evaluation of exercise need and prescription of exercise programs. Emphasis on approaches for patients with musculoskeletal deficits.

title: PT 530b Therapeutic Exercise
description: Examination of needs analysis and prescription of exercise programs for special patient populations and assessment of current community trends in exercise and wellness.

title: PT 536 Pathology of Cardiopulmonary Disease and General Medical Conditions
description: Pathology and pathophysiological mechanisms in disease of the cardiac, pulmonary and circulatory systems; examination of diabetes, burns, and other disabling medical disorders.

title: PT 529 Life Span Motor Control
description: Introduction to sensorimotor systems, overview of current perspectives in motor control from fetus through late adulthood, and clinical tests of motor proficiency.

title: PT 521L Basics of Patient Management
description: Development of basic decision-making skills, professional behaviors and impairment assessment in patients with musculoskeletal neurologic and/or cardiopulmonary dysfunction.

title: PT 516 Principles of Disease
description: Principles and mechanisms of genetics, immunology, infection, wound healing, and oncology.

title: PT 514L Musculoskeletal Anatomy
description: Musculoskeletal anatomy, innervation, blood supply, and function: intensive study of the head, neck, trunk, and limbs. Lecture, dissection laboratory.

title: PT 509 Cellular and Systems Physiology
description: Selected subjects in cellular and systems physiology. Emphasis on molecular and cellular aspects of neuromuscular function; also renal and endocrine physiology.

description: Didactic practicum combining theory and research on psychological intervention with clinical practice in assessment and treatment, focused on particular client groups or disorders.

title: PSYC 691b Internship in Clinical Psychology
description: Supervised clinical work in an approved mental health setting.

title: PSYC 691a Internship in Clinical Psychology
description: Supervised clinical work in an approved mental health setting.

description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: PSYC 626 Computational Social Sciences
description: Discussion of advances in computational social sciences, including automated text and network analysis.

title: PSYC 625 Advanced Big Data Methods
description: Machine learning techniques, including Bayesian and Neural Networks, for analyzing different types of human-generated data.

title: PSYC 622 Decision Analysis and Behavioral Decision Theory
description: Normative and descriptive theories and research on human decision-making, with special emphasis on applications to real social decision problems.

title: PSYC 621 Seminar in Quantitative Psychology
description: Selected topics in mathematical psychology.

title: PSYC 616 Research Techniques for Non-Experimental Social Science
description: Quasiexperimental designs; causal inference from correlational research, techniques for evaluating measures of attitude, personality, and social motives: observational methods; content analysis; sampling and survey techniques.

title: PSYC 619 Psychological Intervention
description: Study of clinical psychological treatment: research and theory about major psychological approaches to intervention. (One of three clinical psychology core courses:

title: PSYC 612 Seminar in Advanced Social Psychology
description: An intensive consideration of selected concepts, theories, and research problems in social psychology.

title: PSYC 599 Special Topics
description: Selected topics in the various speciality areas within psychology at the graduate level. Topic will vary from semester to semester.

title: PSYC 597b Capstone Project in Behavior Analysis
description: Supervision for completing independent project, consisting of practical treatment evaluation, program development, or literature review.

title: PSYC 597a Capstone Project in Behavior Analysis
description: Supervision for completing independent project, consisting of practical treatment evaluation, program development, or literature review.

title: PSYC 597 Internship for Curricular Practical Training
description: Part-time or full-time, practical work experience in the student's field of study. The internship must be located at an off-campus facility. Students are individually supervised by faculty. May not be taken until the student has completed at least two semesters of enrollment in the graduate program.

title: PSYC 602 Self-concept and Motivation
description: Graduate-level depth-and-breadth course using a social psychological perspective on self-concept.

title: PSYC 596 Advanced Behavioral Theory
description: Examines advanced topics in behavioral theory and philosophy, including a comprehensive behavioral approach to language and cognition. Discusses the nature of productive relations between behavior analysis and other psychological theories.

title: PSYC 595 Practicum in Clinical Psychology
description: Supervised experience in interviewing skills and assessment, including psychological test administration and the preparation of reports.

title: PSYC 594b Master's Thesis
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: PSYC 592 Applied Psychology Treatise
description: Requires a research paper of substantial length and high quality that integrates the Internship experience with concepts and principles of human behavior.

title: PSYC 591 Applied Psychology Internship
description: Internship in a non-university setting, such as business, governmental agency, or NGO.

title: PSYC 590 Directed Research
description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

title: PSYC 587 Practicum in Applied Behavior Analysis
description: Provides supervised practical experience in implementing behavior analytic assessment and treatment services. Meets supervision requirements for the Board Certified Behavior Analyst exam. Students meet with course instructor to present and discuss cases for two hours per week every semester, including one summer session. Practicum hours in the field vary from 18-20 hours per week during the academic year to 30 hours per week during the summer.

title: PSYC 578 Workshop in Quantitative Methods
description: Practical, hands-on experience in the application of selected quantitative methods to empirical data. Includes training in use of relevant computer software.

title: PSYC 577 Analysis of Covariance Structures
description: Multivariate analysis of non-experimental data, including structural equation modeling, path analysis, and confirmatory factor analysis. Computer applications using variety of optimization routines and purpose-written software.

title: PSYC 575L Multivariate Analysis of Behavioral Data
description: Multivariate statistical models and contemporary computer methods in multiple regression, multivariate analysis of variance, factor analysis, canonical correlation, repeated measures analysis, and structural equation modeling.

title: PSYC 566 The Psychology of Employee Selection and Assessment
description: Develop an understanding of recruitment and selection practices, processes, and approaches into the strategic role that recruitment and selection plays in organizational success.

title: PSYC 565x Organizational Psychology
description: Examination of the psychological factors that impact employee motivation, job satisfaction, teamwork, leadership, and organizational development.

title: PSYC 556 Psychology of Interactive Media
description: Examination of the diverse methods of communicating with a target audience with a special emphasis on the newest computer-based tools for providing information and influence.

title: PSYC 555 Introduction to Functional Magnetic Resonance Imaging
description: The physical and physiological bases of MRI and fMRI. Design and analysis of fMRI experiments. Operation of a magnetic resonance imaging system.

title: PSYC 552 Principles of Consumer Psychology
description: Examination of the attitudes and decisions of consumers, and how to effectively reach consumers by using persuasion and proper positioning in the marketplace.

title: RPRO 510 Implant Dentistry
description: Principles and use of implants in dentistry: includes history, biological basis, types, diagnosis and treatment planning, surgical and restorative procedures, and limitations.

title: RPRO 503b Preclinical Removable Prosthodontics and Implants

title: RPRO 503a Preclinical Removable Prosthodontics and Implants
description: Introduction to disciplines of removable complete and partial dentures and implants, including classification and progress of edentulism, support sources and principles, design, fabrication and evaluation.

description: Complete denture treatment: phases, clinical procedures, philosophy, concept, rationale, and need.

title: RPRO 501 Preclinical Removable Complete Prosthodontics

description: Fundamental concepts of restoring an individual tooth with a cast restoration; principles of cavity preparation; casting fabrication and cementation.

description: Biology and function of the gnathostomatic system. Role of the hygienist in diagnosis and treatment of occlusal dysfunctions.

description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

title: REL 654 Readings in Chinese Religious Texts
description: Study of Chinese religious texts primarily in literary Chinese. Covers multiple genres of texts from Buddhist sutras to Daoist texts.

title: REL 655 Readings in Japanese Religious Texts
description: Study of Japanese Buddhist texts in classical or modern Japanese and/or kambun. Covers multiple genres from sutras to vernacular text.

title: REL 652 Readings in Buddhist Texts
description: Study of varied Asian Buddhist texts in translation and in original languages. Exploration of the major secondary literature on Buddhist texts.

title: REL 653 Readings in Indic Religious Texts
description: Study of varied Hindu, Buddhist, and Jain texts, primarily in Sanskrit. The class covers multiple genres from Puranas to Tantra.

title: REL 651 Readings in Christian Texts
description: Survey of the different genres of texts in the history of Christian spirituality from ancient Christianity to the present.

title: REL 650 Readings in Islamic Texts
description: Study of Islamic religious texts in multiple genres, primarily in Arabic, though other languages may be offered.

title: REL 645 Advanced Graduate Seminar in Asia Pacific Religions
description: Application of comparative and transhistorical methods for understanding the most prominent themes in Asian Pacific Religions.

title: REL 625 Advanced Graduate Seminar in Global Islam
description: Exploration of themes and traditions of Islam as they appear globally in a variety of specific country contexts

title: REL 635 Advanced Graduate Seminar in Comparative Christianities
description: Comparative and transhistorical methods for understanding the most prominent developments in premodern or modern globalized Christianity.

title: REL 593 Practicum in Teaching the Liberal Arts
description: Practical principles for the long-term development of effective teaching within liberal arts disciplines.

title: REL 599 Special Topics
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: REL 592 Professionalization Proseminar in Religious Studies
description: Offers students a structured environment in which to consider issues in professional development and to discuss their dissertation proposals.

title: REL 590 Directed Research
description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

title: REL 545 Colloquium in Asia Pacific Religions
description: Research methods, tools and current scholarship in the study of Asian Pacific Religions.

title: REL 535 Colloquium in Comparative Christianities
description: Research methods in the comparative study of Christian religions; recent scholarship in Christian studies.

title: REL 525 Colloquium in Global Islam
description: Introduces major issues that have defined Islamic Studies in premodern and modern periods. Generally taken in the first year.

title: REL 502 Themes in the Study of Religion
description: Thematic approaches to the study of religion and religions transcending particular traditions, time periods and geographic regions. Course topic varies by semester according to faculty.

title: REL 500 Methods and Theories in the Study of Religion
description: Introduction to the major topics, trends, and theoretical approaches in the study of religion.

title: REL 499 Special Topics in Religion
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: REL 495 Field Methods and Theories in Archaeology
description: Archaeological field study emphasizing current paradigms of data collection and evaluation; social scientific study of material culture and its relationship to religious expression.

title: REL 493 Art and Archaeology of Religion
description: The history of religion through its material expression: art, architecture and artifact. Exploration of different themes and time periods.

title: REL 491x Undergraduate Honors Research
description: Individual research for honors in the major leading to a substantial project.

title: REL 494 Lab Methods and Theories in Archaeology
description: Archaeological research design, data recovery, artifact analysis, interpretation and analogy, publication and ethics.

title: REL 490x Directed Research
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: REL 481 History of Religion in America
description: Intellectual, institutional, and social history of religion in America from colonial times to the present.

title: REL 483 Religion and Popular Culture in the United States
description: Critical analysis of the relationship between religion, mass media, and popular cultural forms in the U.S.

title: REL 479 Seminar in Christian Thought
description: Studies a theme, period, or problem from the history of Christian thought within its intellectual and social context.

title: REL 475 Religion, Material Culture and the Senses
description: A comparative study of the role of material culture and the senses in religions based on a number of case studies and problem sets.

title: REL 474 Advanced New Testament Studies
description: Consideration of specific topics in New Testament studies. Particular topics determined each semester.

title: REL 471 Jesus
description: A study of major interpretations of the figure of Jesus, with focus on the interaction between religious traditions and culture.

title: REL 473 Advanced Hebrew Bible Studies
description: Consideration of specific topics in Old Testament studies; particular topics determined each semester.

title: REL 469 Black Religion in America
description: Historical, sociological, and theological analysis of the nature and role of black religion in the American setting.

title: REL 462 Religion and Violence
description: Religious and moral perspectives on war, pacifism, violent and nonviolent protest, and religion-based terrorism and militia.

title: REL 468 Sociology of Religion
description: The role of religion in modern society from the standpoint of sociological theory and research.

title: REL 460 Senior Seminar: Medical Ethics
description: Analysis of ethical problems related to new developments in medical science.

title: REL 455 Philosophy of Religion: Bases of Belief and Disbelief
description: Rational and empirical foundations for religious faith and for skepticism.

title: REL 442 Religion and Science
description: Explores whether religion and science offer competing or complementary models for understanding the world and the human place within it.

title: REL 441 Origins of Modern Theology
description: 19th century liberal, rationalist, and historical theology.

title: REL 435 Religious Thought After the Enlightenment
description: Changes in religious thought between the late 18th and early 20th centuries in the wake of the emergence of modernity in the West.

title: REL 440 Christian Thought in the 20th Century
description: Examination of dynamic new directions taken by Christian understandings of self, God, and salvation in response to the novel conditions of modern culture, politics and philosophy.

title: REL 482 Jesus in American History and Culture
description: The place of Jesus Christ in diverse American cultures from colonial times to the present: Jesus as cultural icon, secular inspiration, Christian Son of God.

title: REL 414 History of Islamic Law
description: Examines legal methods and religious sources used in Islamic law. Emphasis is placed on the way cultural developments affect legal thought and the administration of justice.

title: REL 417 Seminar in South Asian Religions
description: Exploration of particular themes and/or traditions in South Asian religions.

title: REL 415 Seminar in Buddhism
description: Seminar on selected aspects of the Buddhist tradition.

title: REL 390 Special Problems
description: Supervised, individual studies. No more than one registration permitted. Enrollment by petition only.

title: REL 394 Archaeology of Egypt and the Near East
description: Study of archaeology and excavated artifacts from Egypt and the Near East.

title: REL 402 Cultural Heritage, Religion, and Politics in the Middle East
description: In-depth exploration of archaeology and heritage issues in the Middle East and their implications for politics and practice in modern Islam, Judaism and Christianity.

title: REL 401 Seminar in Religious Studies
description: Survey of methods and selected issues in the field of religious studies; required of all majors during their junior or senior year.

title: REL 371 Religion and the Supernatural
description: Methods of religious studies, history, anthropology, and psychology used to analyze religious beliefs in and responses to the supernatural.

title: REL 370 Religion and Visuality
description: Examination of the deep connections between visuality and religions, including visions, controversies over religious images, and other connections between religion and visual art.

title: REL 366 Religion and Social Change
description: Empirical and theoretical analysis of social change and its effect on religious institutions as well as the impact of religious movements on society.

title: REL 376g Religion and Human Rights
description: Close examination and discussion of a variety of religious views regarding human rights. Forges useful frameworks for interpreting the complexity of competing ideas.

title: REL 448m Islam in France
description: Historical and theoretical analyses of the complex history of Western perceptions of Islam, focusing on France. Taught in French.

title: REL 365 Global Ethics
description: Provide an overview of debates concerning moral, cultural ethics in a globalizing world. Encourage critical reflection on global justice, ethical systems, role of religion.

title: REL 361 Law and Religion
description: Explores the intersection between law and religion including ways in which religious traditions conceive of, create, order, and contest law.

title: REL 431 The Taoist Tradition
description: Close reading of primary text(s) of early Chinese Taoist thinkers (in translation), along with analysis of relevant secondary scholarship.

title: REL 364 Religion and Ethics
description: Traces the development of how religious ideas have informed ethics, or accounts of the good life, including notions of justice, righteousness, virtue, duty, charity and happiness.

title: REL 359g Culture in Diaspora: The Jews of Spain
description: Course traces the Jewish diaspora from Spain and Portugal with particular attention to how Sephardic Jews maintained ties of culture, commerce, language, and identity.

title: REL 360 Ethical Issues in the New Medical Revolution
description: Multimedia-oriented analysis of issues; definition of life and death; research on human subjects, health care delivery, euthanasia, abortion, genetic counseling, behavior control.

title: REL 342g Buddhist Modernism
description: Examines various topics in the process of rapid modernization and globalization in Buddhism including environmentalism, gender, nationalism, social activism, and war and peace.

title: REL 341 Technology, Culture, and Ethics
description: Examination of value questions arising from the impact of technology on individuals, social institutions, and culture.

title: REL 340 Introduction to Indian Philosophy
description: An introduction to Indian philosophy, including major schools of thought in Hindu, Buddhist, and Jain philosophies. No previous knowledge of Indian religions or philosophy required.

title: REL 339 Studies in the History of Christianity
description: In-depth exploration of one of the pivotal moments in the history of Christianity and Western society.

title: REL 338 Mysticism and Religious Desire
description: How human appetites for sex, food, community or immortality are articulated as mystical desires in different religions, either within institutional structures or working against them.

title: REL 336w Re-Viewing Religion in Asian America
description: Interdisciplinary analysis of the religions traditions, institutions, and experiences of Asians and Pacific Islanders in the U.S.

title: REL 335 Gender, Religion, and Sexuality
description: The construction of gender and sexuality in Western religious traditions; its continued impact on contemporary intellectual, cultural, and social life.

title: REL 334 Religion and Colonial Encounter
description: Survey of religious responses to colonial encounter in the Americas. Emphasis given to study of religious innovations of Amerindians, Africans, and Europeans.

title: REL 333 Religion in the Borderlands
description: Survey of religious history of U.S./Mexico borderlands. Emphasis is given to definitions of place and transformations in culture and forms of belief.

title: REL 332 Religions of Japan
description: The development of religious thought and practice in the Japanese islands, with Buddhism and Shinto being the most prominent.

title: REL 330 Introduction to the Religions of India
description: History, teaching, and practice of Hinduism, Buddhism, and other religious traditions of India.

title: REL 331 Religions of East Asia
description: History, teaching, and practice of the religions of China, Tibet, and Japan.

title: REL 329 Themes in the Religions of China
description: A study of selected themes in the history of Chinese religions and culture. Compares cases and materials from several historical periods and religious traditions.

title: REL 327g Heretics, Martyrs, and Miracles
description: Examines Christianity in the second century including theology, ethics and identity.

title: REL 326gp Historical Jesus
description: Examination of the question of how ancient and modern Christians and scholars have reconstructed the life of Jesus of Nazareth, founding figure of Christianity.

title: REL 324g Sex and the Bible: Gender, Sexuality, and Scripture
description: Role the Bible has played in debates about sex, gender, and sexuality in Western history.

title: REL 325gp Religious Experience in the Greco-Roman World
description: Varieties of religious experience as reflected in the literature, art, and cultic practices of the Hellenistic world.

title: REL 344 Islamic Law and American Society
description: Examination of the nature and substance of Islamic law (Shari'a) and how it relates to American democracy, society and secularism.

title: REL 319 Religious and Ethical Issues in Death and Dying
description: Analysis of religious and ethical approaches to death and dying, including refusal of treatment for competent and incompetent patients, voluntary and involuntary euthanasia, and resuscitation.

title: REL 317g The Bible in Its Ancient Context
description: A close consideration of ancient Near Eastern myths — especially those from Mesopotamia and Canaan — with special attention to their influence on the Bible.

title: REL 337 Islam in Black America: From Slavery to Hip Hop
description: Exploration of the rise of Islam in Black America, and the relationship of Black American Muslims to more recent Muslim immigrants using historical and sociopolitical frameworks.

title: REL 316 Women and the Islamic Tradition
description: Overview of social and legal status of women in Islamic society, past and present. Examination of social roles established both for and by Muslim women.

title: REL 315 Thought and Life of Islam
description: History, thought, institutions, and religious practices of Islam.

title: REL 314 Introduction to Shiism
description: Examination of the major branches of Shiism, the second largest articulation of Islam, both historically and in the world today.

title: REL 312 Biblical Wisdom Literature
description: Survey of and inquiry into the biblical wisdom literature; emphasis on the Book of Job.

title: REL 311g The Bible in Western Literature
description: Comparative analysis of biblical works and how they were employed by various writers in major works of Western literature.

title: REL 304 Ethics and Global Heritage
description: Archaeology and global heritage debates, laws, ethical conundrums, and stakeholder perspectives reveal goals and guiding values of society's exploration of the past.

title: REL 301 Introduction to the Study of Religion
description: Survey of academic approaches to the study of religion. When possible this course will be taken during the first year of the major or minor.

title: REL 302 Religions of Ancient Egypt and the Near East
description: Religious experience and values of ancient Egypt and Near East through material culture, literature, art, and cultic practices; and their legacies in contemporary society.

title: REL 147g Religion, Media and Popular Culture
description: Exploration of the manner in which the media frame discussions and understandings of ethical issues, moral dilemmas, spirituality and religious imagination.

title: REL 141g Global Religions in Los Angeles
description: Congregational and individual expressions of religion in Los Angeles.

title: REL 138g Japanese Religions and Culture
description: Major religious traditions of Japan (such as Buddhism, Shinto, Christianity, Confucianism) and their broader social and cultural contexts.

title: REL 137g Introduction to Islam
description: Introduction to Islam, emphasizing its historical and cultural development since the seventh century C.E., and the basic teachings of Islam.

title: REL 136g Sense and Sensuality in Indian Religions and Culture
description: Exploration of the senses and the technologies of pleasure in India, relating this material to some fascinating examples of Hindu, Jain, and Buddhist literature.

title: REL 134g Introduction to Buddhism
description: Focus primarily on works of Buddhist literature written in a variety of genres. Introduction of basic teachings that link Buddhist traditions across time and space.

title: REL 135g Chinese Religions and Culture
description: Historical and thematic survey of Chinese religious history from earliest times to the present.

title: REL 132g Origins of Western Religions
description: Examination of Judaism, Christianity, and Islam in their origins and their development in relation to Western civilization.

title: REL 125gp Introduction to Christianity
description: Survey of the changing beliefs and practices of the Christian religion from obscure origins to globalized present, with special attention to the varieties of Christian literature.

title: REL 121g The World of the New Testament
description: Historical investigation of New Testament characters, events, ethics and theology in relation to its social, intellectual, and religious contexts in the Jewish and GrecoRoman world.

title: REL 115g Jerusalem, City of Three Faiths
description: History of Jerusalem as a window onto the nature of the three Abrahamic faiths.

title: REL 310 Anti-Semitism, Racism and Other Hatreds
description: History and contexts of anti-Semitism, racism and other discourses about difference examined through religious, national and cultural forms in Europe and in the U.S.

title: REL 114g The Mediterranean: A Religious History
description: Explores multiple religious traditions of the Mediterranean as networks that emerge within and among the landscapes, cultures, and politics of this highly interconnected geographic space.

title: REL 112g Religions of Ancient Egypt and the Near East
description: Religions, cultures, and values of ancient Egypt and Near East (Iran, Iraq, Israel, Syria, Lebanon, Arabia, Turkey) and their legacies in contemporary society.

title: REL 111g The World of the Hebrew Bible
description: The Hebrew Bible in the cultural setting of the Ancient Near East; the formation of theological and ethical concepts which have shaped Western culture.

title: RED 599 Special Topics
description: Current issues, trends, and developments in real estate development.

title: RED 598 Real Estate Product Development
description: An evaluation of various real estate development types. Case studies and site visits.

title: REL 305L Virtual and Digital Culture, Heritage and Archaeology
description: In-depth exploration of design, techniques and evaluation of immersive, virtual and augmented reality and digital visualizations of cultural heritage, archaeology, historical sites and artifacts.

title: RED 585 Comparative International Development Workshop
description: Comparative study tour focused on understanding international real estate development practices and markets, site visits and meeting with principals.

title: RED 590 Directed Research
description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

title: RED 583 International Development Opportunities
description: A survey of various markets prominent in the global real estate community. Protocols for analyzing international development opportunities and cultural, political, and socioeconomic considerations.

title: RED 575L Community Design and Site Planning
description: Physical implementation of development projects. Students will develop concept plan, preliminary design and marketing plan for selected domestic and/or international development sites.

title: RED 574 Building Typologies
description: The exploration of categories of building types, including retail, industrial, residential, office and institutional, using key examples or case studies from each.

title: RED 573 Design History and Criticism
description: The concepts, language and metaphors of design-related disciplines are examined in relation to design and construction values and choices in real estate development.

title: RED 572 Advanced Appraisal Approaches and Applications
description: Highest and best use. Advanced income capitalization. Advanced cost and sales comparison approaches. Advanced applications.

title: RED 571 Introduction to Appraisal Principles, Procedures, and Standards
description: Valuation concepts. Theory and problem solving. Cost, sales comparison, and income approaches.

title: RED 563 Introduction to the Asset Management of Real Estate
description: Overview of institutional asset management: creating and implementing investment and portfolio strategies through the development, acquisition, underwriting, and operational stages of the investment, asset disposition.

title: RED 562 Legal Issues in Real Estate Development
description: Ownership and transfer of real estate; formation and enforcement of contracts; business associations; environmental regulation; taxation of property transfers; acquiring, financing, leasing of commercial property.

title: RED 564 Issues in Asset Management of Real Estate
description: Advanced issues in institutional asset management. How value is created during investment process with focus on tactical, operational, and strategic goals of asset and owner.

title: SAE 599 Special Topics
description: Course content will be selected each semester to reflect current trends and developments in the field of systems architecting and engineering.

title: SAE 594z Master's Thesis
description: Grading Option: In-progress & Credit/No Credit

title: SCOR 403 Introduction to Scoring Movies and Television
description: Practical composition course covering the unique art, craft, and technology involved in writing and integrating music for animated and live-action visual media.

title: SAE 594a Master's Thesis
description: Grading Option: In-progress & Credit/No Credit

title: SAE 594b Master's Thesis
description: Grading Option: In-progress & Credit/No Credit

title: SAE 590 Directed Research
description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

title: SAE 574 Net-Centric Systems Architecting and Engineering
description: In-depth examination of the technical design approaches, tools, and processes to enable the benefits of net-centric operations in a networked systems-of-systems.

title: SAE 560 Economic Considerations for Systems Engineering
description: Impact of economic factors for systems architects and engineers, tools for understanding these factors, fundamental quantitative analysis of cash flow, life-cost estimating for systems and software engineering.

title: SAE 549 Systems Architecting
description: Introduction to systems architecture in aerospace, electrical, computer, and manufacturing systems emphasizing the conceptual and acceptance phases and using heuristics.

title: SAE 547 Model-Based Systems Architecting and Engineering
description: Approaches for modeling systems using software such as SySML; modeling system, requirements, structure, behavior, and parametrics; mapping to hardware description language and behavioral code generation.

title: SAE 550 Systems Architecting and the Political Process
description: Analysis of risks inherent in managing hightech/ high-cost government-funded engineering programs; tools and techniques for coping with the impacts of politically-driven budgets on the engineering design process.

title: SAE 548 Systems/System-of-Systems Integration and Communication
description: Essentials of systems and system-of-systems integration from the perspectives of business, programs, and technology. Process, legacy, and systems-of-systems integration. Verification and validation methods. Case studies.

title: SAE 543 Case Studies in Systems Engineering and Management
description: Real-world case studies in DoD, NASA, and commercial arenas, employing new methodologies to cover the fundamental positive and negative development learning principles of systems engineering.

title: SAE 546 Engineered Resilient Systems and System-of-Systems
description: Formal methods for the design and analysis of resilient systems and system-of-systems (SoS); Disruption risks as a function of system scale and complexity, management, and architectures.

title: SAE 541 Systems Engineering Theory and Practice
description: Integration of engineering problem solving methodologies based on systems concepts. Application to complex, large scale technical systems and problems faced by engineering managers. Case studies.

title: SAE 542 Advanced Topics in Systems Engineering
description: Probability theory in systems engineering: test design and performance, reliability and maintainability, quantitative decision models. Constraint theory to manage and de-conflict complex requirements. Complexity theory.

title: SAE 515 Sustainable Infrastructure Systems
description: Explores broad issues and mitigation measures involved in the analysis and design of complex, uncertain, interacting infrastructure systems needing to be resilient and sustainable.

title: SAE 496 Systems Engineering Through Motorsports
description: Applied systems architecting, engineering and management to motorsports from design to validation and verification; venues include drag racing, grand prix Formula SAE racing, DARPA Challenges.

title: RXRS 490x Directed Research
description: Individual research, reading, writing and project development.

title: SAE 499 Special Topics
description: Course content to be selected each semester from recent developments in Systems Architecting and Engineering and related fields.

title: RXRS 418 Plant Medicines in Modern Medicine
description: Plant medicines; how discovered; activity; pharmacology, toxicity and human benefit; emphasis on the US, Europe and China.

title: RXRS 420 Organ Physiology, Drug Delivery, and Drug Action
description: Principles of cellular and organ physiology. Interplay between the physiology of these organ systems, drug delivery, and drug action.

title: RXRS 417 Food Safety: The Good, The Bad and The Deadly
description: Critical thinking, science translation, effective communications, personal health, and public policy development are at the interface of food safety, nutrition intervention and health controversies.

title: RXRS 416 Medical Products: From Idea to Market
description: Progress of medical product development through intellectual property, animal and clinical trials  and commercialization. Emphasis on safety, quality systems and efficacy.

title: SAE 551 Lean Operations
description: Study of lean principles and practices as applied to various industries.

title: RXRS 413w Globalization of the Biomedical Industry
description: Globalization; pharmaceuticals, biologics, medical devices, and combination products in advanced, emerging, and developing markets; regional and national regulations, global and regional harmonization efforts, ethical considerations.

title: RXRS 412 Twenty-First Century Medical Issues and the Law
description: Difficult issues in the law are examined regarding medical and healthcare controversies such as euthanasia, abortion, embryonic stem cells, human experimentation, and the death penalty.

title: RXRS 411 Innovations in Medical Product Development
description: Developing new medical technologies; political, regulatory, financing and reimbursement issues that may be associated; case studies looking at the newest medical technologies.

title: RXRS 410 Cancer Biology and Pharmacotherapy
description: Cancer and the complex molecular basis leading to tumor oncogenesis, invasion and metastasis; current therapeutic strategies and strategies on the horizon.

title: RXRS 408 Immunology and Immunotherapeutics
description: Principles of human immunological responses to maintain wellness and perturbation in disease. Focus on discovery, development and use of pharmacological therapeutic strategies targeting immune mechanisms.

title: RXRS 409 Neuroimmunology: Focus on Disease and Therapy
description: Newly evolving science focusing on the role of neuroimmune communication in the pathophysiology of the central nervous system (CNS) disorders. Neuroinflammation as a target for novel therapeutic approaches.

title: RXRS 407 The Discovery, Development and Marketing of Medicines
description: Principles, concepts, challenges and short comings of modern day drug discovery and development of medicines. Inter-relationships with regulatory, ethical and societal sectors presented.

title: RXRS 406 Clinical Pharmacology and Medication Management
description: Comprehensive Medication Management Applications in Pharmacotherapy; evidence-based, pharmacist driven medication selection; improved and/or optimized medication therapy; patient compliance; better and safer health outcomes.

title: RXRS 405 Pharmacology and Sociology of Drug Abuse
description: Social, psychological, economical, biological reasons associated with drug use/abuse; prevention strategies; pharmacology and pharmacotherapy successes/ challenges; current trends; case studies; roles of health care professionals.

title: RXRS 404 Neuroimmunity in Health and Disease
description: Social, psychological, economical, biological reasons associated with drug use/abuse; prevention strategies; Pharmacology and Pharmacotherapy successes/ challenges; current trends; case studies; roles of health care professionals.

title: RXRS 402 Human Pharmacology: Challenge of Therapeutics in Society
description: Principles of human pharmacology/toxicology related to prescription, over the counter medications; nutraceuticals; drug-drug interactions; polypharmacy; hot topics related to recently approved drugs.

title: RXRS 304 Mysterious Deaths: Toxicology, Poisons, Literature, History
description: Poisons in classical literature helped shape, modify or change history. Presented in the context of pharmacological/toxicological principles of drug action.

title: RXRS 403 Neuropharmacology in Health and Disease
description: Neuropharmacological treatments of brain disorders including neurodegenerative disorders, injury, and disease; influence of environment and experiences on neuroplasticity and brain development; drug discovery.

title: RXRS 302 Pharmacology and Drug Development
description: Introduction to drug development. Drug/Receptor interactions, pharmacodynamics, pharmacokinetics, toxicology, therapeutic interventions, biotransformation, pharmacogenomics, FDA, regulatory requirements and challenges, intellectual property, global challenges of drug development.

title: RXRS 209 Mysterious Deaths: Poisons in Literature and History
description: Poisons as described in classical literature that shaped, modified or changed the course of history presented in the context of pharmacological/toxicological principles of drug action.

title: RXRS 201p The History and Geography of Drugs
description: Global perspectives; discovery and use of drugs (legal/illegal); poisons. How they helped shape, modify or change history as described in classical literature through present day.

title: RSCI 794z Doctoral Dissertation
description: Dissertation research required for completion of doctoral degree in regulatory science.

title: RSCI 800 Studies for the Qualifying Exam
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: RSCI 794d Doctoral Dissertation
description: Dissertation research required for completion of doctoral degree in regulatory science.

title: RSCI 794c Doctoral Dissertation
description: Dissertation research required for completion of doctoral degree in regulatory science.

title: RSCI 794b Doctoral Dissertation
description: Dissertation research required for completion of doctoral degree in regulatory science.

title: RSCI 794a Doctoral Dissertation
description: Dissertation research required for completion of doctoral degree in regulatory science.

title: RSCI 608 Regulatory Strategy in Europe and the Americas
description: Regulatory strategy in EU, Canada, Mexico and South America; culture, health-care practices, reimbursement, product registration, quality systems, trade restrictions, import/export requirements. Travel may be required.

title: RSCI 790 Directed Research
description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied towards the degree to be determined by the department.

title: RSCI 606 Regulation of Emerging Technologies and Biological Products
description: Policies, testing and regulatory requirements affecting commercialization of biologics and novel medical technologies. Focus on biologics, blood and tissue products, radiopharmaceuticals and nanotechnology.

title: RSCI 605 Managing Organizations and Human Resources
description: Theory and practice of personnel management, organizational structure and industrial relations in small, growing enterprises and large global companies typical of pharmaceutical and medical device sectors.

title: RSCI 607 Theory, Methods and Practice of Medical Products Research
description: Statistical and research design methods, data analysis, survey and interview techniques laying the foundation for the dissertation.

title: RSCI 603 Managing Complex Projects
description: Theory and methods to manage complex projects in medical products sectors; timelines, intellectual property, security, contracts, budgets, review activities, reports, electronic tools, cross-cultural communication.

title: RSCI 601 Biomedical Commerce
description: Introduction to business principles appropriate to medical products, including: supply and demand, product entry-exit strategies, financing, reimbursement, marketing and pricing in global marketplace.

title: RSCI 604 Regulatory Strategy in Asia
description: Regulatory policy, standards and practices in different Asian markets: product licensing, import/export management, materials sourcing, quality systems compliance, reimbursement, prescribing practices. Travel may be required.

title: RSCI 590 Directed Research
description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

title: RSCI 596 Internship for Curricular Practical Training in Regulatory Science
description: undergraduate or professional degree in pharmacy, medicine or independent health sciences, engineering or equivalent mix of post-secondary training and industry experience; enrollment in MS (Regulatory Science).

title: RSCI 541 Drug Development, Reimbursement, and Marketing
description: Survey of drug development strategies; health economics and outcomes researches and reimbursements; emphasis on coverage determination process and FDA and CMS parallel review process.

title: RSCI 540 Analysis of Food and Dietary Supplement Regulations
description: Changes and interpretation of regulations affecting food supply and dietary supplements impacting global markets. Product development, health-claim positioning, advertising, media messaging, consumer choices, personal health outcomes.

title: RSCI 535 Methods Development and Validation
description: Foundation in the process of developing and validating analytical methodology for purposes of pharmaceutical, biological and medical device development.

title: RSCI 533 Safety Evaluation during Drug Development
description: Safety pharmacology/toxicology requirements mandated by FDA and other regulatory agencies to move a new chemical entity from discovery stage to market approval.

title: RSCI 534 Drug Development in CNS Disorders
description: Successes and challenges related to central nervous system therapeutics. Major brain disorders, current and future therapeutic targets and clinical trial designs.

title: RSCI 532 Early Stage Drug Development
description: undergraduate degree in pharmacy, medical or independent health sciences, engineering or equivalent mix of post-secondary training and industry experience; enrollment in MS, Regulatory Science, Certificate in Preclinical Drug Development and MS, Management of Drug Development.

title: RSCI 531 Industrial Approaches to Drug Discovery
description: undergraduate degree in pharmacy, medical or independent health sciences, engineering or equivalent mix of post-secondary training and industry experience; enrollment in MS, Regulatory Science, Certificate in Preclinical Drug Development and MS, Management of Drug Development.

title: RSCI 529 Application of Risk Management Tools and Techniques
description: Use of risk management tools in the medical products arena: functional analysis, fault-tree analysis, failure modes and effects analysis, HACCP and six sigma methods.

title: RSCI 525 Introduction to Drug and Food Toxicology
description: Factors affecting toxic responses to foods and drugs: dose-response relationships, absorption, distribution, biotransformation, elimination of toxicants; target organ toxicity, teratogenesis, mutagenesis, carcinogenesis, food allergies, risk assessment.

title: RSCI 527 Medical Product Safety
description: Management of medical product safety by manufacturers/suppliers including: safe manufacturing, labeling, packaging; pharmacovigilance, field observations, complaint handling; record-keeping, safety issues documentation; crisis management/recalls.

title: RSCI 521 Seminars in Regulatory Science
description: undergraduate degree in pharmacy, medical or independent health sciences, engineering or equivalent mix of post secondary training and industry experience; enrollment in MS, Regulatory Science program.

title: RSCI 523 Advanced Concepts in Risk Management for Medical Products
description: undergraduate or professional degree in pharmacy, medicine or independent health sciences, engineering or equivalent mix of post-secondary training and industry experience; enrollment in M.S. (Regulatory Science), Certificate in Patient and Product Safety, or permission of instructor.

title: RSCI 520 Introduction to Risk Management for Health Care Products
description: Historical development, formal language and theoretical approaches to risk management in health care and medical product environment; policies, regulations, standards; liability prevention and loss control.

title: RSCI 509 Quality Assurance, Medical Devices and Combination Products
description: Design of systems according to FDA and international regulations and guidelines to ensure the quality and safety of medical devices and combination products.

title: RSCI 508 Quality Assurance for Drugs and Biologics
description: Design and implementation of a quality system to assure quality and safety of pharmaceuticals and biologics, according to relevant FDA and international regulations and guidance documents.

title: RSCI 507 Quality Systems and Statistical Process Control
description: Fundamentals and applications of Statistical Process Control (SPC) in development and monitoring of manufacturing processes; includes SPC in root cause analysis and CAPA.

title: RSCI 506 Auditing Principles
description: Audit requirements mandated by the FDA and other international regulatory agencies including internal, external, regulatory agency, third party, GMP, GLP, ISO 13485/QSR and supplier audits.

title: RPRO 605 Prosthodontic Seminar: Removable Partial Prosthodontics
description: Provides fourth year dental students with an advanced didactic foundation for treating the partially edentulous patient with a removable partial.

title: RSCI 504 Good Laboratory Practices (GLP)
description: Introduction to Good Laboratory Practices (GLP), including the design, implementation and monitoring of non-clinical GLP studies, and GLP studies in an academic environment.

title: RPRO 604c Advanced Removable Prosthodontics
description: Critical review and evaluation of the removable prosthodontic literature; guided experience in the laboratory and clinical phases of removable prosthodontic therapy.

title: RPRO 604b Advanced Removable Prosthodontics
description: Critical review and evaluation of the removable prosthodontic literature; guided experience in the laboratory and clinical phases of removable prosthodontic therapy.

title: RPRO 604a Advanced Removable Prosthodontics
description: Critical review and evaluation of the removable prosthodontic literature; guided experience in the laboratory and clinical phases of removable prosthodontic therapy.

title: RPRO 603 The Edentulous Patient — Conventional or Implant Prosthesis
description: Effective management of the edentulous patient who is unable to adapt to a prosthesis; includes a review of implant dentistry with a hands-on session.

title: RPRO 602 Advanced Removable Prosthodontics
description: Critical review and evaluation of the removable prosthodontic literature; guided experience in the laboratory and clinical phases of removable prosthodontic therapy.

title: RPRO 571f Clinic: Removable Partial Prosthodontics
description: Clinical experience in diagnosis, treatment planning, and laboratory procedures necessary for the treatment of the partially edentulous patient. Includes seminars related to clinical treatment.

description: Clinical experience in diagnosis, treatment planning, and laboratory procedures necessary for the treatment of the partially edentulous patient. Includes seminars related to clinical treatment.

description: Clinical experience in diagnosis, treatment planning, and laboratory procedures necessary for the treatment of the partially edentulous patient. Includes seminars related to clinical treatment.
