description: Clinical experience in diagnosis, treatment planning, and laboratory procedures necessary for the treatment of the partially edentulous patient. Includes seminars related to clinical treatment.

title: RPRO 571b Clinic: Removable Partial Prosthodontics
description: Clinical experience in diagnosis, treatment planning, and laboratory procedures necessary for the treatment of the partially edentulous patient. Includes seminars related to clinical treatment.

title: RPRO 571a Clinic: Removable Partial Prosthodontics
description: Clinical experience in diagnosis, treatment planning, and laboratory procedures necessary for the treatment of the partially edentulous patient. Includes seminars related to clinical treatment.

title: RPRO 562a Clinic: Removable Complete Prosthodontics II
description: Diagnosis, treatment planning, and care of edentulous patients. Complex cases involving temporomandibular joint dysfunction, surgical and congenital defects; seminars on clinical treatment.

title: RPRO 562b Clinic: Removable Complete Prosthodontics II
description: Diagnosis, treatment planning, and care of edentulous patients. Complex cases involving temporomandibular joint dysfunction, surgical and congenital defects; seminars on clinical treatment.

title: RPRO 561d Clinic: Removable Complete Prosthodontics I
description: Diagnosis, treatment planning, and care of edentulous patients. Complex cases involving temporo-mandibular joint dysfunction, surgical and congenital defects; seminars on clinical treatment.

title: RPRO 561c Clinic: Removable Complete Prosthodontics I
description: Diagnosis, treatment planning, and care of edentulous patients. Complex cases involving temporo-mandibular joint dysfunction, surgical and congenital defects; seminars on clinical treatment.

title: RPRO 561b Clinic: Removable Complete Prosthodontics I
description: Diagnosis, treatment planning, and care of edentulous patients. Complex cases involving temporo-mandibular joint dysfunction, surgical and congenital defects; seminars on clinical treatment.

title: RPRO 561a Clinic: Removable Complete Prosthodontics I
description: Diagnosis, treatment planning, and care of edentulous patients. Complex cases involving temporo-mandibular joint dysfunction, surgical and congenital defects; seminars on clinical treatment.

title: RPRO 550 Removable Complete Prosthodontics Clinic I
description: Clinical demonstration with supervised clinic experience in construction, repair, and evaluation of the removable complete denture.

title: RPRO 532 Preclinical Removable Partial Prosthodontics Laboratory II
description: Laboratory experience in fabrication of removable partial dentures.

title: RPRO 523b Preclinical Removable Prosthodontics and Implants Laboratory
description: Laboratory experience in the fabrication of removable complete and partial dentures and implants.

title: RPRO 523a Preclinical Removable Prosthodontics and Implants Laboratory
description: Laboratory experience in the fabrication of removable complete and partial dentures and implants.

title: RPRO 521 Preclinical Removable Complete Prosthodontics Laboratory
description: Fundamental theory for the fabrication of removable complete dentures.

title: SOCI 667 Seminar in Social Deviance
description: Deviance and social rules in groups and communities; contemporary social policies involving ethnic, cultural, and social factors.

title: SOCI 656 Social Demography
description: Theoretical perspectives of population, historical and contemporary accounts of population trends and statistics, and the latest research on the causes and consequences of demographic processes.

title: SOCI 655 Seminar in Race Relations
description: Current racial problems in the United States and other countries; critiques of literature on race relations.

title: SOCI 657 Sociology of Culture
description: Cultural theories and forms of cultural analysis appropriate for sociological research; critical examination of theory and research on how culture relates to social structure, social inequality, politics, institutions, and everyday interaction.

title: SOCI 653 Seminar in Science and Technology Studies
description: Introduction to key concepts and theories in the interdisciplinary field of Science and Technology Studies.

title: SOCI 651 Seminar in Social Stratification
description: Critique of research literature and research methods in the area of social class and social stratification; major theories and theoretical implications of current research.

title: SOCI 649 Migration Policies
description: Analysis of migration and population redistribution; policies affecting such migration and redistribution.

title: SOCI 648 Fertility Control Policies
description: Fertility control policies, and their consequences, including family planning and other pronatalist and antinatalist programs.

title: SOCI 647 Political Sociology: Politics, Symbols and Everyday Life
description: Political power, conflict and apathy; public symbols, debate and discourse; nationalism; relations between politics, provision of social services and economics in comparative and historical perspective.

title: SOCI 645 Seminar in World Population Problems
description: Demographic characteristics of the major regions of the world; social, economic, and political implications of population trends and methods of demographic analysis.

title: SOCI 646 Economic Sociology
description: Classical/neoclassical economic models of human action, sociological alternatives, the history of the large corporation, sociological models of production/labor/financial markets... and the role of economic institutions in the larger society.

title: SOCI 644 Population Trends: Public and Private Policies
description: World and national population trends; causes and implications for economic, health, and social policies.

title: SOCI 643 Sociology of Labor
description: Viewing labor and labor movements from a macro/meso/micro perspective. Examination in the formation of labor markets, global economy, organization of work, conditions of work, movements.

title: SOCI 642 Sex and Gender in Society
description: The social organization of gender in the contexts of work, families, intimacy, sexuality, reproduction, violence. Variations by race, ethnicity, social class. Processes of social change.

title: SOCI 640 Sociology of Gender and Sexuality
description: Approaches to gender and sexuality within sociology and social theory, highlighting contemporary empirical research on sexualities.

title: SOCI 625 Demographic Methods
description: Procedures and techniques for the collection, evaluation, and analysis of demographic data; census and vital registration systems; basic measures of demographic components, and the construction of life tables and population projections.

title: SOCI 622L Advanced Methods – Quantitative Research
description: Advanced research methodology in survey technique, evaluation research, instrument construction, and demographic analysis.

title: SOCI 621L Quantitative Methods and Statistics II
description: Casual modeling and the inter-relationships among social phenomena: covers the basic elements of casual inference and generalizability, linear regressions analysis, and categorical data analysis.

title: SOCI 620 Advanced Methods – Qualitative Research
description: Seminar and practicum in conducting and interpreting original qualitative research.

title: SOCI 594b Master's Thesis
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: SOCI 599 Special Topics
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: SOCI 594z Master's Thesis
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: SOCI 594a Master's Thesis
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: SOCI 590 Directed Research
description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

title: SOCI 593 Practicum in Teaching the Liberal Arts
description: Practical principles for the long-term development of effective teaching within college disciplines. Intended for teaching assistants in Dornsife College.

title: SOCI 521 Quantitative Methods and Statistics
description: Introduction to the logic and methods of quantitative analysis in sociology; covers the basic elements of designing and research, summarizing and exploring patterns in data, and making generalizations about populations based on characteristics of samples.

title: SOCI 520 Qualitative Research Methods
description: Seminar in epistemologies, ethics, and techniques of qualitative research. Critical reading and practice in social observation, interviewing, fieldwork, and research design. Preparation of IRB proposal.

title: SOCI 525 Sociology Proseminar: Approaches to Sociological Research
description: Graduate students begin their customized literature reviews and develop a paper that will frame the research they pursue in the empirical paper requirement.

title: SOCI 511 Sociological Theory II
description: Developments in sociological theory from World War II to the present.

title: SOCI 510 Sociological Theory I
description: Developments in sociological theory from the discipline's 19th century origins to World War II.

title: SOCI 500 Sociology Professional Seminar
description: Introduces students to the theoretical questions and methodological approaches that comprise the discipline of sociology. Experts in each subfield share their latest research with students.

title: SOCI 499 Special Topics
description: An interdisciplinary examination of selected emerging issues.

title: SOCI 490x Directed Research
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: SOCI 495 Sociology Honors Seminar II
description: Seminar in workshop form to accompany completion of Senior Honors Thesis under faculty guidance. Acceptance into Honors Program.

title: SOCI 494 Sociology Honors Seminar I
description: Advanced seminar involving extensive reading, research and discussions. Selected subjects; offered in fall only and restricted to honors students. Acceptance into the Honors Program.

title: SOCI 475 Medical Sociology
description: Social and cultural factors in causation of disease, health care utilization and health care delivery.

title: SOCI 472 Health, Disease, Language and Culture: Guatemala
description: Studies health, illness, disease, culture, language and social-economic burdens that affect Guatemala.  Students will be immersed into day-to-day life, studying from practitioners in the field.

title: SOCI 480 The Sociology of Risk and Disaster
description: Is there such a thing as a "natural" disaster? Examination of both natural and technological disasters, and exploration of the centrality of risk in industrialized societies.

title: SOCI 470 Social Change in Low-Income Countries
description: Theories and case studies on social, economic, political, and cultural development and change in the Third World: Latin America, Asia, or Africa.

title: SOCI 460 Key Issues in Contemporary International Migration
description: Overview of contemporary patterns of international migration and its implications for receiving and sending countries, with a special emphasis on immigration to the United States.

title: SOCI 465 Visual Sociology of the City and Its Residents
description: Students examine images of urban America and use the camera to produce visual representation in their analysis of social relations.

title: SOCI 464 Sociology of Gender and Work
description: Examination of gender inequality in the U.S. labor market; work-family conflict; employer remedies; comparative social policy.

title: SOCI 445 Political and Social Theory
description: Classical and contemporary theories of power, inequality, sociability, symbols and language in market, state, political, and civic organizations.

title: SOCI 450 Non-Governmental Organizations/Non-profits Field Practicum
description: Internship in a Non-Governmental Organization (NGO). Students will conduct sociological research on issues surrounding NGOs and the work they do.

title: SOCI 430m Work and the Workplace
description: Contrasting views of work in contemporary societies; technological change in the workplace; opportunity, inequality, conflict, and alienation in different occupations.

title: SOCI 435m Women in Society
description: Women today in the labor force, in politics, and in the family. Past and contemporary attempts to expand the position of women in society.

title: SOCI 432m Racial and Ethnic Relations in a Global Society
description: Examines race/ethnic relations with U.S. and selected countries from a global perspective, causes/social effects of globalization on people's lives, U.S. attitudes, and political policies.

title: SOCI 431 Cities
description: Organization of urban society, including such topics as segregation, urban decay, local politics, residential change, and community conflict.

title: SOCI 410 The Sociology of Popular Culture
description: From the entertainment capital of the world, course surveys sociological research on artistic producers and critical theories of the connections between popular culture and society.

title: SOCI 429 Immigration, Work and Labor
description: Examination of the experiences of racial minorities in the labor market, niche concentration, the effects of globalization on labor migration, entrepreneurship, discrimination, and minorities in white-collar occupations.

title: SOCI 408 Volunteers, Non-Governmental Organizations, and Everyday Politics
description: Theory, practice, and history of civic life. Examines communication, personal obligation, collective imagination, and political representation, in grassroots, state-sponsored, and non-governmental organization-sponsored civic associations around the world.

title: SOCI 390 Special Problems
description: Supervised, individual studies. No more than one registration permitted. Enrollment by petition only.

title: SOCI 402 Human Trafficking
description: Interrogates the social construction of the legal category "human trafficking," examining the ideological foundations, the social contentions, and political issues surrounding the issue.

title: SOCI 425 Social Movements: Power, Resistance, and Political Dynamics
description: When do groups mobilize to defend or resist power? Explores collective mobilization including student protest, minority rights and labor movements, the alt-right, and revolutions.

title: SOCI 376m Contemporary Issues in Asian American Communities
description: Survey of current social and political issues facing Asian American communities with emphasis on Los Angeles region; design and implementation of community-based research projects.

title: SOCI 369 The Family in a Changing Society
description: Changing family patterns; personality development; family unity, predicting success in marriage; the family in transition; crises such as economic changes, death, divorce; family reorganization.

title: SOCI 362 Global and Transnational Sociology
description: Examines key issues in global and transnational sociology. Globalization is the empirical phenomenon where social, economic, and political interconnectedness across countries impacts the world.

title: SOCI 356m Mexican Immigrants in Sociological Perspective
description: Effects of class, global inequality, legal status, gender, racial/ethnic, and language differences in distinguishing Mexican immigrant populations from the U.S.-born population; differentiation among Mexican immigrants.

title: SOCI 360m Social Inequality: Class, Status, and Power
description: Inequalities in wealth, prestige, and power in the United States; the American class structure and the extent of upward mobility in that structure.

title: SOCI 355m Immigrants in the United States
description: Social construction of historical and contemporary immigration to the United States, including causes of migration, immigration policies, and the socioeconomic integration of immigrants.

title: SOCI 353 Public Policy and Criminal Justice
description: Nature and trends in crime, policing, courts, and correctional agencies in relation to past, current, and prospective changes in society.

title: SOCI 351 Public Policy and Juvenile Justice
description: Past and current theories of youth crime; gangs and other forms of youth deviance; the changing response of the police, courts, and public to these behaviors.

title: SOCI 345 Social Institutions
description: Cultural and interactional aspects of social institutions as complex social systems; religious, political, industrial, and familial institutions.

title: SOCI 350 Social Exclusion, Social Power, and Deviance
description: Current theories of origin, distribution, and control of deviant behavior; examination of processes involved in the career deviance of drug addicts, alcoholics, sexual deviants, gamblers, and mentally disordered.

title: SOCI 342m Race Relations
description: Past and present relations between the White majority and the "conquered minorities" (Blacks, Chicanos, American Indians), as well as Asian immigrants; conflict vs. assimilation perspectives.

title: SOCI 340 Organizations: Bureaucracy and Alternatives to Bureaucracy
description: Importance of organizations in social life; techniques for using and changing organizations; examination of strategies for building and sustaining nonbureaucratic organizations.

title: SOCI 335 Society and Population
description: World population trends and their consequences: determinants of fertility, mortality, and migration; development of elementary models of population change.

title: SOCI 314Lg Analyzing Social Statistics
description: Sociological measurement, univariate description, elementary correlation, introduction to statistical inference.

title: SOCI 379gm Mixing and Matching: Intermarriage in 21st Century
description: An investigation into interethnic, interracial, and inter-religious marriage in the 21st century.

title: SOCI 325 Applied Social Research Methods
description: Use quantitative or qualitative analysis skills to study major social issues using large existing survey data sets or qualitative methods. Become conversant in describing data to a variety of audiences.

title: SOCI 382 Judaism as an American Religion
description: The development of American expressions of Judaism as part of the American religious context, from the perspective of the social scientific study of religion.

title: SOCI 313L Sociological Research Methods
description: Logic of theory construction, research design, elementary data collection and analysis.

title: SOCI 275 Sociology of Everyday Life
description: The social philosophy of understanding everyday life; describing and analyzing forms of interaction, emotions, knowledge, and the social self.

title: SOCI 305m Sociology of Childhood
description: Social construction of childhoods; children's social relations and cultures; issues of childcare, poverty, violence, and children's rights; effects of children on adults.

title: SOCI 270g Sociological Theory
description: Historical and contemporary approaches to sociological theory; analysis of conceptual frameworks applied to the study of society and social interaction.

title: SOCI 255g Sociology of Globalization
description: This course examines globalization through social and economic processes and its consequences for social conflict, economic development, human rights, social movements, and national identity.

title: SOCI 357m Latino Politics
description: Focuses on the political experience of Latinos in the U.S. Comparative analysis of their political experiences and perspectives, their histories of identity formation, and their political organizations.

title: SOCI 250gmw Grassroots Participation in Global Perspective
description: Theory and history behind the ideal of "the local, grassroots volunteer": a direct link between theory and research using Los Angeles as a case study.

title: SOCI 242g Sociology, Demography, and Health
description: Sociological and demographic concepts focusing on the causes of disease, health and wellness. Empirical analysis of population composition and its connection to health.

title: SOCI 225gw Sociology of Health and the Body
description: Investigation of health as a social category and the varied ways that social and cultural factors shape bodies and health.

title: SOCI 220gm Questions of Intimacy
description: Analysis of conditions of intimacy and intimate personal relationships as lenses for understanding social inequalities of race, social class, gender, sexuality, and nation.

title: SOCI 215g Sociology of Wall Street
description: Examines Wall Street as a: market for allocating investment; arbiter of prices; place to work; and a powerful force directing the activities of corporations everywhere.

title: SOCI 200gm Introduction to Sociology
description: Basic concepts of sociology with special reference to group life, social institutions, and social processes.

title: SOCI 210g Science, Technology, and Social Conflict
description: Science and technology change society and how we understand ourselves. In turn, social struggles influence science. We will explore the interplay between these forces.

title: SOCI 169gm Changing Family Forms
description: The peculiarity of the "modern" Western family system in historical and cross cultural perspective; focus on the "postmodern" family crisis in the United States.

title: SOCI 155gm Immigrant America
description: Examination of the immigrant experience in the United States. Comparative analysis of social context of migration, formation of immigrant communities, and social integration of immigrants.

title: SOCI 150gm Social Problems
description: Analysis of factors in current American social problems: crime, delinquency, prostitution, family disorganization, race relations, mental illness.

title: SOCI 142gm Diversity and Racial Conflict
description: Introduction to the causes and effects of contemporary race relations in a diverse U.S. society. Exploration of racial conflict at the personal and institutional levels.

title: SOCI 100gm Los Angeles and the American Dream
description: Los Angeles as a metaphor for the American Dream, exploring the city's history and potential futures, including economic opportunity, social justice, spatial organization, and environmental sustainability.

title: SLL 794d Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: SLL 794z Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: SLL 794c Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: SLL 794b Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: SPAN 413m Social and Geographic Varieties of Spanish
description: Historical, social, and cultural elements represented in the dialectal diversity of the Spanish language; fieldwork in bilingual communities in the United States. Majors prepare assignments in Spanish, non-majors in English. Conducted in Spanish and English.

title: SPAN 412 Spanish Rhetoric and Style
description: Close grammatical and rhetorical analysis of a variety of text types (general, literary, technical, journalistic) as the basis for practice in advanced written and oral expression as well as translation.

title: SPAN 391 Introduction to Contemporary Spanish Literature (USC Madrid Center)
description: Readings in contemporary Spanish literature. Includes lectures by recognized Spanish writers and scholars.

title: SPAN 405 History of the Spanish and Portuguese Languages
description: Development of sounds, forms, words, meanings and structures from their origins to modern Spanish and Portuguese.

title: SPAN 390 Special Problems
description: Supervised, individual studies. No more than one registration permitted. Enrollment by petition only.

title: SPAN 385 The Culture of Food in Hispanic Los Angeles
description: Experiential learning and project-based course designed to familiarize students with the food culture of Hispanic Los Angeles. Students create Spanish language blogs about their experiences.

title: SPAN 383 Mexican Noir
description: Comparative study of the noir form in Mexico through readings in literature and cinema, with attention on questions of modernity, technology, politics and gender. Taught in Spanish.

title: SPAN 380g Literature of Mexico
description: Principal writers and their works from Colonial times to the present. Non-majors may write assignments in English.

title: SPAN 381 Narco-World
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: SPAN 382 The Aesthetics of Violence in Latin America
description: An exploration of representations of violence and violent representations in Latin American narrative, poetry, music, and film.

title: SPAN 373 Modern and Postmodern Spanish Fiction
description: An exploration of the literary and filmic narratives of contemporary Spain focusing on the major historical and cultural movements of the 20th century.

title: SPAN 352 The Transatlantic Golden Age: New Worlds Real and Imagined
description: Selected readings from 1500 to 1700 exploring Renaissance and baroque visions of the classical and new worlds.

title: SPAN 372 Modern and Contemporary Latin American Fiction
description: Study of major trends in Latin American fiction from the 1930s to the present with a focus on narrative experimentation.

title: SPAN 341 Advanced Conversation and Culture
description: Conversation based on study of Spanish art and architecture. Field trips.

title: SPAN 350 Cultural Cross-Currents of the Iberian Middle Ages
description: Selected readings from 1040 to 1499 examining the rich cultural diversity of the Iberian Middle Ages in the symbiosis of Christian, Moslem and Jewish traditions.

title: SPAN 321 Sounds, Images, Objects
description: Introduction to the study of Iberian and Latin American cultural forms through readings on the visual arts, cinema, architecture, and music. Conducted in Spanish.

title: SPAN 320 Politics, Thought, Society
description: Introduction to the study of Iberian and Latin American cultural patterns through readings on such topics as history, gender, ethnicity, and politics. Conducted in Spanish.

title: SPAN 318x Creative Writing in Spanish
description: An introduction to the art and craft of creative writing in Spanish with a focus on narrative fiction; writing workshop, literary readings.

title: SLL 794a Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: SLL 790 Research
description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

title: SPAN 315 Advanced Grammar and Translation
description: Contrastive study of Spanish and English structures designed to explore the similarities and differences between the two languages and to familiarize students with translation techniques. Emphasis on a variety of text types with the aim of increasing linguistic and cultural appreciation of the Spanish language.

title: SLL 670 Seminar in Eastern European Cinema
description: Topics in Eastern European cinema selected for intensive study. May be repeated with varying content.

title: SLL 665 Seminar in Russian Culture and the Arts
description: Subject varies from year to year. A trend or major figure will be studied in its cultural and artistic contexts. May be repeated, with departmental permission, if content of the seminar is different.

title: SLL 660 Seminar on a Single Author or Work
description: Theme varies from year to year. An author or major work will be selected for intensive study; research paper required. May be repeated, with departmental permission, if content of the seminar is different.

title: SLL 650 Seminar in Russian Literature
description: Detailed study of single literary period, movement or genre; two or more selected authors; specific school of literary criticism. May be repeated, with departmental permission, if content of the seminar is different.

title: SLL 599 Special Topics
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: SLL 590 Directed Research
description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

title: SPAN 316x Spanish for the Professions
description: The language and culture of a particular area of study or profession, such as medicine and healthcare, political and social sciences, business and the law. Limited to 4 units for major or minor credit.

title: SLL 585 20th Century Russian Literary Criticism
description: Relationship between practical and theoretical literary criticism: Formalism and Structuralism, Sociological school, and Bakhtin; theoretical approaches applied to specific literary texts.

title: SLL 584 Russian Fiction and the West
description: A survey of major Russian fiction in the context of Western European literary movements from the late 18th through late 19th centuries. The course presumes the students' basic acquaintance with the major monuments.

title: SLL 575 Socialist Realism
description: The course examines the origins, doctrine, and ideology of socialist realism, the predominant, and officially prescribed, aesthetic of Soviet literature.

title: SLL 557 Soviet Literature II (1953–present)
description: De-Stalinization of Soviet culture, the reappropriation of Russia's literary past, and new directions in contemporary literature.

title: SLL 555 Soviet Literature I (1917–1953)
description: The course surveys the major writers and literary schools of Soviet literature in the crucial period from the Revolution to the death of Stalin.

title: SLL 550 Russian Modernism
description: "Russian Modernism" subsumes theoretical ideas, practical achievements, and stylistic movements which contributed to Russia's cultural renaissance between ca. 1890 and ca. 1925.

title: SLL 546 The Russian Novel
description: Genre of the novel as exemplified in the works of one or more Russian authors. Readings from Gogol, Turgenev, Tolstoy, Dostoevsky, and others.

title: SLL 548 History of Russian Literary Criticism
description: History and principles of literary criticism in Russia with attention to major periods and movements from the early 19th century through the Formalists.

title: SLL 545 19th Century Russian Poetry
description: Analysis of major works of 19th century Russian poetry in the context of developing aesthetic principles and cultural history.

title: SLL 544 Russian Short Story
description: Pushkin, Gogol, Dostoevsky, Turgenev, Tolstoy, Chekhov.

title: SLL 532 18th Century Russian Literature
description: Major works and genres of the 18th century. The development of a "modern" literary tradition, focusing on problems of Russia's indigenization of Western literary movements (classicism and sentimentalism).

title: SLL 542 Symbolism
description: Russian symbolist literature; cultural and philosophical background of this late 19th and early 20th century movement.

title: SPAN 311 Advanced Spanish Through Contemporary Issues: Oral Emphasis
description: (Summer sessions abroad.) Advanced Spanish with emphasis on grammar and oral communication.

title: SPAN 310 Structure of Spanish
description: A systematic study of the structure of Spanish. Topics include fundamental aspects of the sound system; word classes; sentences and their meaning; linguistic change and variation; standard and colloquial usage.

title: SPAN 308 The Art of Poetry
description: A survey of Spanish and Latin American poetry from the Middle Ages to the present, acquainting students with various critical and theoretical approaches to verse. Conducted in Spanish.

title: SPAN 306 Performance from Street to Stage
description: A survey of Spanish and Latin American plays from the Middle Ages to the present, acquainting students with various critical and theoretical approaches to drama. Conducted in Spanish.

title: SPAN 304 The Art of Fiction
description: A survey of Spanish and Latin American fiction from the Middle Ages to the present, acquainting students with various critical and theoretical approaches to narrative. Conducted in Spanish.

title: SPAN 290gp Introduction to Latin American and Iberian Studies
description: Introduction to the cultural history of Spain, Portugal and Latin America with a focus on literature and visual works from the early-modern period to the twenty-first century.

title: SPAN 270 Spanish for Native Speakers
description: For speakers with an advanced level of oral proficiency, but no previous formal study of Spanish. Focus on grammar, spelling and punctuation, reading, and writing.

title: SPAN 280x Conversational Spanish
description: Discussions of short films, cultural and literary texts and other activities designed to improve conversational skills.

title: SPAN 261 Advanced Spanish: Society and the Media
description: Analysis of cultural issues in the Spanish-speaking world. Discussions, presentations, writing assignments, and grammar instruction designed to improve students' proficiency in Spanish.

title: SPAN 302 Screen Cultures: From Film to the Internet
description: A survey of Spanish and Latin American cinema from the silent film era to the present, acquainting students with various critical and theoretical approaches to cinema studies. Conducted in Spanish.

title: SPAN 250x Spanish for Business Communication
description: Four-skills language and culture course for intermediate-high Spanish students interested in Business/Communications. Prepares students to communicate in the Spanish-speaking commercial market in a linguistically sensitive manner.

title: SPAN 260 Advanced Spanish: Arts and Sciences
description: Development of students' oral and writing skills using literary and scientific materials; grammar review.

title: SPAN 245 Spanish Through Social Issues in Costa Rica
description: (Costa Rica Summer Program only). Intensive review of Spanish grammar with emphasis on four skills. Audiovisual materials, guest speakers, and readings related to the history and culture of Costa Rica.

title: SPAN 240 Spanish IV
description: Intensive review of Spanish grammar with emphasis on four skills. Audiovisual materials and readings related to Hispanic culture and civilization.

title: SPAN 233x Business Spanish: Case Studies
description: Four-skills language and culture course.  Students read/analyze Spanish-language case studies and present their own case studies orally and in writing in Spanish.

title: SPAN 232x Business Spanish:  Business Culture
description: Four-skills language and culture course.  Students engage in research about the culture of business practices in Spain/Latin America; write/present company profiles, including NGOs, in Spanish.

title: SPAN 220 Spanish III
description: ; intensive work in listening comprehension, oral communication, reading and writing, with emphasis on free expression; readings related to Hispanic culture and civilization.

title: SPAN 231x Business Spanish: Job Search
description: Four-skills language and culture course.  Students create culturally appropriate professional dossiers, execute job searches in Spain/Latin America; engage in face-to-face and phone interviews in Spanish.

title: SPAN 120 Spanish I
description: For students with limited proficiency in Spanish. Practice in listening comprehension, oral communication, elementary reading and writing.

title: SPAN 301 Introduction to Literature and Film
description: Introduction to critical reading and interpretation of poetry, narrative fiction, drama, and film from Spain and Latin America.

title: SPAN 020x Spanish for Reading Knowledge
description: Preparation for the ETS standardized examination, with readings related to the student's major area. Offered upon sufficient demand.

title: SPAN 150 Spanish II
description: ; increased emphasis on listening comprehension, oral communication, reading, and writing.

title: SOWK 794z Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: SLL 516 Structure of Modern Russian: Morphology
description: Essential issues in current linguistic description of the syntax and morphology of modern Russian. Considers word order, negation, verbal aspect.

title: SLL 530 Early Russian Literature and Culture (11th–17th Centuries)
description: Major monuments of medieval Russian literature examined in their cultural, literary, and theological context, with special emphasis on issues of genre. Focus on problems of Russian cultural identity and Russia's complex relationship to Byzantine and Western traditions.

title: SLL 514 Structure of Modern Russian: Phonology
description: Articulatory phonetics, phonemics, morphophonemics, and intonational patterns of modern Russia.

title: SLL 512 History of the Russian Language
description: Phonetic, morphological, syntactical changes from common Slavic to the present. Russian literary language; influence of 19th century Russian authors and old church Slavic on contemporary Russian.

title: SLL 501 Proseminar in Russian Literature
description: Introduction to graduate study of Russian literature: research methods, bibliography, transliteration, development of critical writing skills.

title: SLL 500 Topics in Advanced Russian
description: Study of Russian required for graduate work and professional activities.

title: SLL 510 Old Church Slavonic
description: Study of the earliest recorded Slavic language; linguistic interpretation of original texts; knowledge of a Slavic language or general linguistics will be helpful.

title: SLL 490x Directed Research
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: SLL 499 Special Topics
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: SLL 465 Seminar in Russian Studies
description: Readings and discussion in Russian of current topics in Russian culture, politics and society. Content varies each time offered.

title: SLL 397 Literature and Film in Eastern European Historical Experience
description: Exploration of key moments in the recent historical experience of Eastern Europe through close readings of literature and film. Taught in English.

title: SLL 378 Modern Russian Art
description: Changing concepts of aesthetic value as expressed in the development of 19th and 20th century Russian art (painting and architecture).

title: SLL 370 Advanced Russian for Native Speakers
description: For students with basic oral proficiency in Russian who need to develop native fluency in an array of genres and situations. Emphasis on advanced grammar, reading (literary and scholarly texts), written expression (scholarly, administrative, and business genres), spelling, and punctuation.

title: SLL 390 Special Problems
description: Supervised, individual studies. No more than one registration permitted. Enrollment by petition only.

title: SLL 348g The Novels of Vladimir Nabokov
description: Survey of Vladimir Nabokov's novels written in Europe and America from the 1920s–1960s. Primary focus on the structure of the novels and their themes of art and emigration. Readings in English.

title: SLL 345g Literature and Philosophy: Dostoevsky
description: Dostoevsky's novels as psychological and philosophical analyses of modern alienated man. Readings in Dostoevsky and selections from Gide, Kafka, Camus, and Sartre. Conducted in English.

title: SLL 346 Russian Drama and the Western Tradition
description: Representative plays from the 18th century to the present. Development of the Russian theater in the European context. Conducted in English.

title: SLL 344g Tolstoy: Writer and Moralist
description: Tolstoy's major works in the context of his ethical views. Readings and lectures in English.

title: SLL 330gp Russian Thought and Civilization
description: Russian cultural identity from its beginnings until today. The Eastern Orthodox tradition, its traumatic confrontation with Western culture, and their continuous interaction.

title: SLL 321 Russian Culture
description: Survey of Russian civilization from the beginnings to the Soviet period focusing on major cultural and artistic trends.

title: SLL 340 Intercultural Communication in Russian
description: Advanced language training focusing on specific issues of communication with Russians. Analysis and translation of literary texts. Advanced syntax. Conducted in Russian.

title: SOWK 794d Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: SLL 310 Advanced Russian in Popular Culture
SOWK 794c Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: SOWK 794b Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: SOWK 790 Research
description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

title: SOWK 794a Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: SOWK 785 Guided Research Internship
description: Research practicum designed to provide students with handson practical experience with an ongoing faculty research project.

title: SOWK 781 Guided Teaching Experience
description: Mentorship with a member of the teaching faculty; discussions of curriculum design; observation; preparation and delivery of selected course sessions.

title: SOWK 770 Introduction to Qualitative and Mixed Research Methods
description: Overview of the use of qualitative and mixed methods in social, clinical and health services research.

title: SOWK 764 Advanced Multivariate Statistics
description: Introduction to single equation statistical modeling using limited dependent variables (categorical and ordered categorical). Methods are drawn from statistics and econometrics.

title: SOWK 763 Social Work Research Methods II: Issues in Research for Social Work Practice
description: Research methods to provide students with advanced methodological knowledge in two areas related to social work practice: psychotherapy outcome research and program research.

title: SOWK 760L Introduction to Social Work Statistics
description: Foundation course covering univariate and bivariate descriptive and inferential statistics. Required lab covering basic computer skills and utilization of statistical software.

title: SOWK 765 Writing Successful Dissertation Research Grants
description: Prepares doctoral students to write and submit applications to obtain extramural funding to support their dissertation research. Students will learn about opportunities and eligibility requirements for federal and foundation supported dissertation research grants, how grants are reviewed and scored once submitted, and how to write successful proposals. Recommended preparation: Completion of a qualitative or mixed methods course is preferred.

title: SOWK 762 Social Work Research Methods I
description: Models of research, the nature of inquiry, and the research process including problem formulation, measurement, designs, sampling and data sources.

title: SOWK 761L Multiple Regression for Social Work Research
description: Multivariate statistical methods including descriptive and inferential statistics, parametric and non-parametric tests of hypotheses; correlation, analysis of variance, multiple regression, and factor analysis; utilization of computer programs for statistical analysis.

title: SOWK 744 Theories for Practice with Large Systems
description: Examination of the development and utility of theories, models and approaches to social work community and administrative practice.

title: SOWK 743 Theories for Practice with Small Systems
description: Early practice theories and their historical roots are examined. Implications for evolving current practice theories with individuals, families, and groups are discussed.

title: SOWK 733 Policy Analysis and Advocacy in a Comparative Social Policy Context
description: Examination of the evolution of American and other welfare states in selected nations. Analysis of global welfare institutions. Engaging in policy analysis in a comparative context.

title: SOWK 723 Design Laboratory for Social Innovation II
description: The Design Laboratory provides a space for DSW students to test theoretical frameworks and models for their Grand Challenge Capstone Project.

title: SOWK 721 Data Driven Decision Making in Social Services
description: Practical introduction to using quantitative administrative data to identify trends, track performance, evaluate programs, and drive decision making.

title: SLL 303 Contemporary Russian Literature
description: Developments in Russian Literature from the 1960s to the present. Literature of moral resistance directed against official cultural models. In English.

title: SOWK 722 Implementing Your Capstone and Re-envisioning Your Career
description: Culminates in the completion of a fully implementable Grand Challenge capstone project and a plan that re-envisions career pathways conducive to launching the project.

title: SLL 302g Modern Russian Literature
description: Survey of the major developments in Russian literature during the 20th century, from modernism to the post-Soviet era. Readings in English.

title: SOWK 724 Residency II
description: Campus-based residency in the final semester of the DSW program bringing students together to present their Capstone Projects to different professional audiences.

title: SLL 300 The Russian Novel
description: The rise of the novel as the dominant form in Russian literature of the 19th century. Major works by Gogol, Turgenev, Dostoevsky, Tolstoy, and others. In English.

title: SLL 301 Russian Literary Avant-Garde
description: Russian modernism and the avant-garde: development of modern sensibility in literature and the arts from 1880 to 1930. Readings in Chekhov, Sologub, Bely, Mayakovsky, and others. Conducted in English.

title: SLL 299 Chess — Advanced Thinking Techniques
description: Development of advanced understanding of the game of chess. Critical analysis of games and of the problem-solving techniques applicable in various game situations.

title: SLL 270a Russian for Native Speakers
description: For native Russian speakers who cannot read or write Russian. Emphasis on essentials of grammar, vocabulary, and orthography, and the reading and writing of simple texts in Russian.

title: SLL 270b Russian for Native Speakers
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: SLL 260x The Trans-Siberian Experience
description: Introduction to Russian language and culture by means of a study-tour on the Trans-Siberian Railway.

title: SLL 255 Business Russian
description: Language and culture course for intermediate Russian level students interested in business. Prepares students to communicate in Russian-speaking business settings in a linguistically sensitive manner.

title: SLL 252 Readings in Polish Literature II
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: SLL 222 Readings in Polish Literature I
SLL 250 Intermediate Russian II
description: . Development of proficiency in conversation skills, reading, and writing.

title: SLL 220 Intermediate Russian I
description: Development of thematic conversational skills with emphasis on extended dialogue. Review of basic morphology with special attention to verbs of motion. Reading of authentic material is emphasized.

title: SLL 210 Masterpieces of the Russian Short Story
description: Critical reading of selected masterpieces of the Russian short story; works by Gogol, Turgenev, Dostoevsky, Tolstoy, Babel, Pasternak, Solzhenitsyn, and others. In English.

title: SLL 199 Chess and Critical Thinking
description: Analysis of significant chess games, reflecting societal attitudes toward science, competition, art, gender, psychology, politics, and technology.

title: SLL 150 Beginning Russian II
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: SLL 152 Elementary Polish II
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: SOWK 714 Leaders as Maestros: Designing Change in the Grand Challenges
description: The Leader/Maestro Concept enlarges the student from a virtuoso perspective -- individual performance -- to include an organizational performance in creating and measuring change.

title: SOWK 720 Communication and Influence for Social Good
description: Explores how communication and new information technology influence decision-makers and the general public to address the Grand Challenges in the interest of the public good.

title: SOWK 713 The Application of Implementation Science
description: Introduction to doctoral level research and evaluation, introducing concepts of effectively using literature, formulating a problem for research, and effectively identifying a research or evaluative approach.

title: SOWK 711 Design Laboratory for Social Innovation I
description: Integrates design thinking with innovation dynamics as a practice methodology for social innovation with application towards the development of an innovation corresponding to capstone project.

title: SOWK 707 Financial Management for Social Change
description: Effective financial management in human service organizations emphasizing designing fiscal approaches that maximize revenue, improve decision making, and support disruptive social change.

title: SOWK 712 Residency I
description: Five-day campus based residency in the third semester of the DSW program designed to bring students together for a series of presentations and workshops by 'thought leaders' of the Grand Challenges of Social Work.

title: SOWK 706 Leading and Managing Large Complex Systems
description: Examining large scale national, state and local social intervention programs as well as implications for fiscal and outcome accountability.

title: SOWK 710 Preparatory Scholarship for Capstone
description: Design and develop an innovative, feasible, logical, and defensible Grand Challenge Capstone Project; consider contextual issues, and enhance innovation and communication skills

title: SOWK 705 Leading Public Discourse
description: Leading public discourse for the purposes of increasing civic engagement and public participation, building broad based public support and enabling competencies.

title: SOWK 704 Strategic Innovations for the Grand Challenges
description: Grand Challenge initiatives and interventions from diverse perspectives are explored.  Multidisciplinary strategies of innovation are analyzed to effect broad-based opportunities and barriers to change.

title: SOWK 702 Theories of Human Behavior in the Contexts of Social Environments
description: A focus on human behavior in interaction with the social environment; major paradigms including general systems theory, ego psychology, and role theories are examined.

title: SOWK 703 Explanatory Theories for Larger Social Systems
description: Theories of organizational and community behavior are examined in relation to their influence on the development of social services.

title: SOWK 698b Integrative Learning for Advanced Social Work Practice
description: Advanced integrative learning builds on 698a by incorporating field experiences, case/best practices consultations, and dialogical inquiry on micro, mezzo, and macro practice levels.

title: SOWK 699b Advanced Applied Learning in Field Education
description: Advanced supervised field education where students practice social work skills and apply evidence-based interventions, including some that are specific to their academic department.

title: SOWK 697 Research Project II
description: Credit on acceptance of professional research project.

title: SOWK 698a Integrative Learning for Advanced Social Work Practice
description: Advanced integrative learning that incorporates field experiences, evidenced-based interventions, case vignettes and dialogical inquiry through a Problem Based Learning framework.

title: SSCI 683 Principles of Spatial Data Analysis
description: The theoretical foundations and techniques of spatial analysis and the ways in which they have been used to identify spatial processes and patterns.

title: SSCI 680 Advanced Spatial Computing
description: The role of spatial computing in understanding the world, in knowing and communicating our relationships to specific places, and for navigating through those places.

title: SOWK 696 LGBT Psycho/Social/Political Issues
description: Overview of clinical, social and political issues with which social workers should be familiar when working with lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender clients.

title: SOWK 699a Advanced Applied Learning in Field Education
description: Advanced supervised field education where students practice social work skills and apply evidence-based interventions, including some that are specific to their academic department.

title: SSCI 601b Population, Health and Place Research Practicum
description: The use of population science, public health, and spatial science theory and practice to advance our understanding of one or more aspects of human well-being.

title: SSCI 600 The Geography of Life and Death
description: Meaning and significance of place and role of social, natural, and built environments in disease occurrence in different places and populations.

title: SSCI 601a Population, Health and Place Research Practicum
description: The use of population science, public health, and spatial science theory and practice to advance our understanding of one or more aspects of human well-being.

title: SSCI 599 Special Topics
description: Seminar in selected topics in the spatial sciences.

title: SWMS 425 Queer Los Angeles
description: Interdisciplinary study of queer Los Angeles through examination of histories, memoirs, essays, fiction, poetry, documentaries, narrative films, and local archives.

description: An advanced writing workshop that focuses on continuing development of the crafting of character, centering on depth, breadth, dimensionality, and authenticity.

description: Explores the theory and practice of staging community-based popular theatre, including Theatre of the Oppressed, street theatre, witness theatre, agit-prop and festival theatre events.

description: Plays for the stage shall be written using public-domain poetry and prose as inspiration and source material, complemented with exploring poetry, prose, and varied dramas as context for the student writer. Students should be well-versed in literature, and have written in one or more genres.

description: An investigation of the role that collaboration plays in making ensemble work. MFA Actors will collaborate with MFA Dramatic Writers in creating an ensemble company.

title: THTR 500 Dramaturgical Perspectives and Approaches
description: Investigates art and craft of dramatic writing initiated/completed in other MFA in Dramatic Writing courses or that was submitted as a sample for program entry.

title: THTR 498 Production Analysis and Performance

title: THTR 499 Special Topics

title: THTR 496 Experimental Theatre Workshop II

title: THTR 497 Advanced Theatre Practicum

title: THTR 495 Experimental Theatre Workshop I

title: THTR 494 Raising Money for the Arts
description: Overview of fundraising techniques for non-profit theatre including grantsmanship, board development, direct mail soliciting, and money raising activities and events.

title: THTR 493a Periods and Styles
description: A survey of the influence of historical and cultural events on the evaluation of theatrical styles. Classical to Jacobean.

title: THTR 493b Periods and Styles
description: A survey of the influence of historical and cultural events on the evaluation of theatrical styles. Restoration to 20th century.

title: THTR 491 Theatre Organization and Administration
description: Budgets, contracts, box-office procedures, public relations; personnel and executive policies of the school, community, and professional theatre.

title: THTR 492 Producing Theatre
description: Analysis of all procedures involved in producing theatre (commercial or non-profit) including legal and business guidelines and contracts.

title: THTR 490x Directed Research
description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

title: THTR 488mw Theatre in the Community
description: Research and actively develop the theory of theatre as a moving political, social, economic and spiritual force of change within the local community.

title: THTR 489 Theatre Internship
description: Practical experience in the entertainment industry.

title: THTR 487 Promotion for the Performing Arts
description: Introduction and overview of all aspects of marketing the arts including both non-profit and commercial organizations.

title: PPD 644 Shaping the Built Environment
description: Introduction to the theories and concepts and good city form. Explores the options for designing more livable and sustainable urban communities.

title: POIR 649 International Law
description: Topics and cases illustrating general principles and problems in international law. MA and other students outside of POIR must obtain faculty permission to register for the course.

title: PHIL 462 Philosophy of Mind
description: Examination of contemporary theories of mind and its place in the natural world.

title: PHYS 516 Methods of Computational Physics
description: Introduction to algorithm development. Integration of ordinary differential equations; chaotic systems; molecular dynamics; Monte Carlo integration and simulations; cellular automata and other complex systems.

title: PPD 643 Leading Transformations Across Sectors: Integrative Seminar
description: Application and practice of leadership skills working across the public, private and nonprofit sectors. Skills include negotiation, collaboration, communication, political management and ethical responsibilities.

title: PM 513 Experimental Designs
description: Statistical methods for analysis of various experimental designs. Parametric analysis of variance (ANOVA), repeated measures methods, crossover designs, non-parametric ANOVA.

title: PM 612b Clinical Translational Research (CTR)
description: Analysis and interpretation of data to test clinical translational hypotheses.

title: PM 612a Clinical Translational Research (CTR)
description: First of three courses in CTR, a discipline that fosters multidirectional integration of basic, patient-oriented and population-based research with the long-term goal of improving public health.

title: PM 512 Principles of Epidemiology
description: Terminology/uses of epidemiology and demography; sources/uses of population data; types of epidemiologic studies; risk assessment; common sources of bias in population studies; principles of screening.

title: PM 511cL Data Analysis
description: Methods and applications for modeling longitudinal, time-to event and multi-level data. Includes laboratory using R package.

title: PTHL 312c Medicine and Pathology
description: An integrated approach to clinical, gross and microscopic study of basic disease processes, systemic pathology, oral pathology, internal medicine, pathophysiology, physical evaluation and emergency medicine for significant organ systems. Clinical-pathologic correlation stressed. Evaluation, classification, and differential diagnosis of oral lesions; disease recognition and dental treatment modification.

title: PTHL 312a Medicine and Pathology
description: An integrated approach to clinical, gross and microscopic study of basic disease processes, systemic pathology, oral pathology, internal medicine, pathophysiology, physical evaluation and emergency medicine for significant organ systems. Clinical-pathologic correlation stressed. Evaluation, classification, and differential diagnosis of oral lesions; disease recognition and dental treatment modification.

title: PTHL 312b Medicine and Pathology
description: An integrated approach to clinical, gross and microscopic study of basic disease processes, systemic pathology, oral pathology, internal medicine, pathophysiology, physical evaluation and emergency medicine for significant organ systems. Clinical-pathologic correlation stressed. Evaluation, classification, and differential diagnosis of oral lesions; disease recognition and dental treatment modification.

title: OPER 795h Clinic: Advanced Operative Dentistry
description: Advanced clinical and laboratorial treatment of patients in need of complex multidisciplinary treatment, with special emphasis on esthetic and bonded restorations. Open only to Advanced Operative Dentistry Certificate students.

title: OPER 795f Clinic: Advanced Operative Dentistry
description: Advanced clinical and laboratorial treatment of patients in need of complex multidisciplinary treatment, with special emphasis on esthetic and bonded restorations. Open only to Advanced Operative Dentistry Certificate students.

title: PAIN 723 Orofacial Pain and Headache
description: Foundational knowledge of orofacial neurogenic pain and headache disorders; prevalence, differential diagnosis, prevention and management.

title: OT 500c Clinical Problems in Occupational Therapy
description: Specific applications of occupational therapy practice in varied clinical/health settings. Seminar to integrate theory with application of intervention principles for various populations.

title: OT 500a Clinical Problems in Occupational Therapy
description: Specific applications of occupational therapy practice in varied clinical/health settings. Seminar to integrate theory with application of intervention principles for various populations.

title: OT 500b Clinical Problems in Occupational Therapy
description: Specific applications of occupational therapy practice in varied clinical/health settings. Seminar to integrate theory with application of intervention principles for various populations.

title: OT 499 Special Topics
description: Course content to be selected in occupational therapy and occupational science.

title: MUJZ 196 Jazz Combo I
description: Rehearsal and performance of literature for jazz chamber groups.

title: PPD 507 Six-Sigma Methods and Applications
description: Comprehensive study of Six Sigma and Lean metrics, methods, and systems with their applications to manufacturing, services, quality improvement and management.

title: MUJZ 195L Jazz Elements I
description: Study of compositional, improvisational, performance, and arranging elements found in jazz. Students will model influential groups and jazz artists.

title: MUJZ 180 Techniques of Jazz Improvisation
description: Development of improvisational skills through instrumental performance.

title: MUJZ 153 Individual Instruction
description: Registration Restriction: Open only to jazz studies majors.

title: MUJZ 150 Beginning Jazz Improvisation
description: Development of beginning improvisational skills including underlying principles of theory, harmony, jazz ear training, and jazz style.

title: OT 441L Foundations: Neuroscience
description: Application of basic neural function to the analysis of daily living tasks and activities; review of pathological conditions that interfere with performance in occupation.

title: OT 490x Directed Research
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: OT 440L Foundations: Kinesiology
description: Review of joint and muscle structure and function; application of basic biomechanical, neuromuscular and musculoskeletal principles to the analysis of everyday activities and therapeutic interventions.

title: OT 405 Foundations: Occupation
description: Introduction to basic tenets of occupational therapy history and practice, the profession's language, and foundations of occupational science; incorporates experience and self-analysis of occupation.

title: OT 406L Foundations: Creativity, Craft and Activity Analysis
description: Exploration of craftsmanship in both historical and contemporary contexts; engagement in the craft experience to encourage creativity and to develop proficiency in analysis of performance.

title: OT 390 Special Problems
description: Supervised, individual studies. No more than one registration permitted. Enrollment by petition only.

title: OT 375 The Narrative Structure of Social Action: Narrative, Healing and Occupation
description: Narrative as guide and structure of practical action. Special emphasis on chronic illness and disability and narrative structure of clinical interactions.

title: OT 360 Creating the Self through Narrative: Acts of Life Story Production
description: Analysis of life stories, life histories, and testimonies in social interactions, texts, and films. Life stories are an occupation to re-create the "Self" in response to conflict and change.

title: OT 370 Understanding Autism: Participation Across the Lifespan
description: Introduction to Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) from a neurodevelopmental perspective, with a focus on the daily living experience and occupational participation for individuals with ASD.

title: OT 355 Occupational Reconstructions and Social Transformations
description:
The use of occupations -- meaningful, purposeful activities --
 to restore identity, agency, health, well-being, skills, and political power to populations in problematic situations, such as wars and natural disasters.

title: OT 350 Disability, Occupations, and the Health Care System
description: Exploration of the ways in which ablebodyism, sexism, racism, classism and homophobia contribute to occupational opportunities or barriers and weave their way into health care.

title: OT 340 Occupational Foundations of Human-Animal Interaction
description: Explores how interactions with companion animals expand human capacity for action and contribute to human health, well-being and participation,in different cultural contexts, across the life-span.

title: OT 333 Sports Ethics
description: Critically examines ethical issues central to the world of sports that range from matters of fair play and cheating to performance-enhancing drugs and gene-doping.

title: OT 330 Perspectives on the Daily Life of Families
description: Examines family structures and processes, the occupational dimensions of families, and the meanings embedded in the acts of daily life of contemporary families.

title: OT 325 The Brain: Mind, Body, and Self
description: Exploration of neuroscience as it impacts everyday living, from the fundamentals of neurons and synapses, to the neural basis of language, empathy, and social interaction.

title: OT 320 The Nature of Human Occupation: Form, Function, and Meaning
description: The complex nature of human occupation is covered from an interdisciplinary perspective. Emphasis is on how occupation contributes to human experience in a lived world.

title: OT 312 Creating a Sustainable Lifestyle
description: Scientists and policymakers advocate lifestyle changes as crucial to solving the environmental crisis. Investigation into the development of habits that promote environmental sustainability and personal wellbeing.

title: OT 310 Creativity Workshop
description: Theories and practice of the creative process in varied media, genres and occupations. Explores creativity in the arts, sciences, professions, evolution, daily life, and culture.

title: OT 299 Special Topics
description: Recent developments in occupational therapy and occupational science for undergraduate students.

title: OT 300 Occupational Expressions of Diverse Identities and Lifestyles
description: Exploration of the diverse ways occupational practices become central to identity, reify standard social ideologies, and are manipulated to redress conventional standards.

title: OT 280 Essential Occupations of Emerging Adulthood
description: Examination of challenges associated with the emerging adulthood stage of development through an occupational science lens; strategies to promote health and well-being for this population.

title: OT 261 Human Physiology for Allied Health Professions
description: Overview of human physiology emphasizing systems that sustain homeostasis and motion with a focus on biological foundations for a healthy lifestyle. Relevant pathophysiologic issues discussed.

title: OT 260 Human Functional Anatomy for Allied Health Professions
description: Lecture and cadaver lab-based, human anatomy course focused on the interaction of anatomical systems relative to functional activity, health and wellness.

title: OT 251x Across the Lifespan: Occupations, Health and Disability
description: Exploration of the transformative power of occupation throughout the lifespan for all individuals.

title: MUJZ 142a Jazz Ear Training
description: Sight-singing and melodic/rhythmic reading and dictation applied to jazz repertoire. Includes vocalization of scales and chord patterns and study of rhythmic reading and jazz articulation.

title: MUJZ 142b Jazz Ear Training
description: Sight-singing and melodic/rhythmic reading and dictation applied to jazz repertoire. Includes vocalization of scales and chord patterns and study of rhythmic reading and jazz articulation.

title: MUJZ 141b Basic Keyboard Skills for the Improviser
description: Reading skills related to jazz accompanying, including the ability to identify and play chords on the piano utilizing different voicings.

title: MUJZ 141a Basic Keyboard Skills for the Improviser
description: Reading skills related to jazz accompanying, including the ability to identify and play chords on the piano utilizing different voicings.

title: MUJZ 105b Jazz Theory
description: Study of basic and advanced concepts of jazz melody, harmony and form. Includes functional chord idioms and relationships, compositional and improvisational devices, and song forms.

title: MUJZ 105a Jazz Theory
description: Study of basic and advanced concepts of jazz melody, harmony and form. Includes functional chord idioms and relationships, compositional and improvisational devices, and song forms.

title: MUJZ 101x Non-Major Beginning Individual Instruction
description: Individual instruction at the beginning level designed for non-music majors with no previous experience.

title: MUJZ 100mx Jazz: America's Music
description: Music of the jazz greats. Experience through live performances, field trips, readings, recordings, videos and guest lectures.

title: MUIN 790 Research
description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

title: MUIN 599 Special Topics
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: MUIN 590 Directed Research
description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

title: MUIN 598 Internship

title: MUIN 570 The Music Industry

title: MUIN 540 Artist Management: Campaign Execution and Hindsight Analysis

title: MUIN 542 Developing Copyright Laws and Business Models

title: MUIN 541 Data Analytics: Music Marketing Decisions and Presentations
description: The when, why and how data analysis tools are used to assist music professionals and better support marketing decisions, beyond the realm of intuition and aesthetic appeal.

title: MUIN 530 Mentorship

title: MUIN 525 Concert Promotion, Venue Management and Event Planning

title: MUIN 522 Music Marketing, Branding and Campaigns

title: MUIN 526 Music Supervision, Production and Creative Licensing

title: MUIN 521 Music Industry/Producers Forum

title: MUIN 520 Artist Management: Campaign Planning, Pitching, Partnerships
description: Lecture and experiential learning focused on the role of an artist's personal manager including developing their story, assets and strategy for various product release campaigns.

title: OT 250 Introduction to Occupational Science and Occupational Therapy
description: Introduction to concept of occupation and overview of human drive for meaningful activity; impact of occupations on health and wellbeing; analysis of personal occupational patterns; selected therapeutic applications.

title: OT 220 Lifestyle Design: Introduction to Occupational Therapy
description: Introduction to theoretical concepts concerning the relationship of engagement in activities (occupations) to health and well being. Application of these perspectives to students' own lives.

title: OT 200 Medical Terminology for Health Professions
description: Foundation of medical terminology and hospital abbreviations useful for practice in health care.

title: OT 101 Caring For Your Self: Engaging in Healthy Habits and Routine
description: Application of occupational science evidence and occupational therapy principles of lifestyle and self-care behavior change to support self-analysis and integration of healthy habits and routines.

description: Culmination of the four-year course of study. Affords students the opportunity to experience guided work to meet the professional demands of the industry.

title: MUIN 445 International Music Industry

title: MUIN 444 Music Supervision

title: MUIN 410 Marketing, Branding and Strategic Alliances in Music
description: An in-depth study of music marketing, non-traditional revenue streams for artists, musicians, and labels including artist endorsements, artist tour sponsorships, digital music programs, music licensing, merchandise, and a primary focus on brand partnership deals in the music space.

title: MUIN 385 Radio in the Music Industry

title: MUIN 372 Business and Legal Aspects of the Music Industry
description: An intermediate/advanced-level survey of music copyright law, artist contract analysis, infringement case studies as they affect modern/emerging business models and global music licensing.

title: MUIN 370 Music Publishing and Licensing

title: MUIN 340 Introduction to Sound Reinforcement

title: MUIN 360 Introduction to Music Law

description: Economic considerations of home, studio and location recording. Equipment, labor, facilities, media, legal and tax considerations will be explored.

title: MUIN 286 Record Production Management
description: Function of the record producer, studio procedures, music business law, union relations, artist management, copyright and publishing agreements, record company structure.

title: MUIN 272x Basics of the Music Industry

title: MUIN 280 Communications in the Music Industry

title: MUIN 270 Introduction to the Music Industry
