description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: MUSC 598 Internship in Music
description: Practical work experience in the student's field of study, at an off-campus location. Students are individually supervised by faculty.

title: MUSC 475 Musician's Health and Wellness
description: Interactive exploration of injury prevention, body awareness disciplines, effective practice strategies, warm-ups and stretches, performance anxiety, hearing protection, and other pertinent wellness topics for musicians.

title: MUSC 496 Careers in Music
description: A study of the practical aspects of the music business, including the history, procedures, standard practices, economics and technologies employed by the music industry.

title: MUSC 470 Contemporary Popular Music: A Global Perspective
description: Contemporary popular music in global culture; includes performance and collaboration opportunities with local musicians.

title: MUSC 465 Music, Television and American Culture
description: An exploration of the social and cultural impact of music written for, popularized by, or exploited by American television from the 1950s through today.

title: MUSC 460 Film Music: History and Function from 1930 to the Present
description: A survey of the art and craft of film music as practiced by outstanding composers in motion pictures.

title: MUSC 455 Songwriting III: The Performing Songwriter
description: Continuation of Songwriting I and II with emphasis on the development of performance skills of original popular music in preparation for songwriting showcases.

title: MUSC 444 American Roots Music: History and Culture
description: The history, genre, styles, songs, lyrics, and influences of American vernacular music in the 20th century, including the background that spawned these musical genres.

title: MUSC 424 Iconic Figures of Popular Music
description: Music, life, recordings, and attendant musical, cultural and political influences of a seminal musician or group in 20th or 21st century popular music.

title: MUSC 430m Music and the Holocaust
description: Study of the creation and performance of Holocaust related music from 1933 to the present, including interaction with other arts.

title: MUSC 423 Classic Rock: Popular Music of the Sixties and Seventies
description: Critical examination of the lyrics, structure, associated mythology, technology, and evolving styles of popular music reflecting the turbulent societal changes during the Sixties and Seventies.

title: MUSC 422 The Beatles: Their Music and Their Times
description: Music, lyrics, recordings, production techniques, career strategy, social ramifications, and especially the technological impact of the musical group known as The Beatles.

title: MUSC 373g Writing About Popular Music
description: Immerses students in criticism, scholarship, and creative writing dealing with popular music. Students participate in that discourse through developing their own authorial voices.

title: MUSC 372g Music, Turmoil and Nationalism
description: An exploration of musical practices and styles which reflect and shape national identities and which focus on those created in response to political turmoil in many forms.

title: MUSC 371g Musical Genre Bending
description: The aesthetic and ethical issues of genre-bending music in 20

title: MUSC 355 Songwriting II
description: Continuation of Songwriting I; particular emphasis on the analysis of the techniques of important popular songwriters and the application of these techniques to original songs.

title: MUSC 320gmw Hip-hop Music and Culture
description: A history of hip-hop music from its inception to the present: its musical processes and styles, as well as attendant social, political and cultural issues.

title: MUSC 255 Songwriting I
description: Development of musical and lyrical skills, composing, listening, analysis, and critiques of popular original music.

title: MUSC 250gmw The Music of Black Americans
description: A chronicle of the musical contribution of Africans and African Americans to American society and to the foundations of musical genres and styles throughout the world.

title: MUSC 210g Electronic Music and Dance Culture
description: The origins and development of EDM and its relatives such as disco, house, techno, rave and electronica, focusing on cultural and technological influences.

title: MUSC 200gmw The Broadway Musical: Reflections of American Diversity
description: A uniquely American genre, the Broadway musical serves as a catalyst for inquiry into human diversity, cross-culturalism, and significant social and political issues.

title: MUSC 115gp Western Music as Sounding History
description: An introduction to Western art music and culture from the Medieval, Renaissance, Baroque, Classical, Romantic and Modern eras through reading, listening, analyzing and writing about music.

title: MUSC 110 Freshman Forum
description: Introduction to issues and skills relevant to the professional musical world of today.

title: MUJZ 790 Research
description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

title: MUSC 102gw World Music
description: Exploration of music and cultures of the world. Engagement with international musicians, global issues, field work and musical diasporas in Los Angeles.

title: MUJZ 688 Special Topics in Jazz Performance
description: Examination and analysis of solo and compositional repertory of the jazz idiom through transcription and comparative research. Specific emphasis to be determined by the Jazz Studies department.

title: MUJZ 653 Performance
description: Individual or master class instruction for DMA Performance majors.

title: MUJZ 599 Special Topics
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: MUJZ 588 Special Studies in Jazz Performance
description: Performance problems, composers and/or stylistic analysis of music from the jazz idiom. Specific emphasis to be determined by the Jazz Studies department.

title: MUJZ 590 Directed Research
description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

title: MUJZ 554 Graduate Certificate Performance
description: Individual instruction and related lab participation for Graduate Certificate students.

title: MUJZ 553 Individual Instruction
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: MUJZ 551 Graduate Jazz Improvisation
description: Development of proficiency in improvising to advanced jazz concepts, including transposition, substitute harmony, superimposed harmony, atypical harmonic schemes and contemporary chord and scale types.

title: MUJZ 547 Jazz Composition
description: Application of theoretical and compositional techniques used in jazz to written music. Analysis and performance of historical and contemporary examples will be included.

title: MUJZ 545 Jazz Ensemble Development
description: Techniques, approaches, teaching materials, and music useful in developing jazz ensembles in educational settings, from junior high school through college.

title: MUJZ 501 Individual Instruction
description: Secondary instruction for graduate music majors or instruction for graduate non-music majors.

title: MUJZ 499 Special Topics
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: MUJZ 486 Jazz Masters from World War II to the Present
description: Examination of major jazz artists from World War II to the present with emphasis on the innovators of each period. Detailed analysis of selected repertoire.

title: MUJZ 490x Directed Research
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: MUJZ 452 Individual Instrument Performance Class II
description: Solo and orchestra repertoire, professional preparation, reed making, and other matters appropriate to group study. Required of all third and fourth year wind and percussion majors each semester in residence.

title: MUJZ 453 Individual Instruction
description: Registration Restriction: Open only to jazz studies majors.

title: MUJZ 451 Advanced Jazz Improvisation
description: Development of advanced improvisational skills, including Lydian-chromatic and bi-modal techniques, through instrumental performance.

title: MUJZ 450 Intermediate Jazz Improvisation
description: Development of intermediate improvisational skills including underlying principles of theory, harmony, jazz ear training, and jazz style.

title: MUJZ 419m The Jazz Experience: Myths and Culture
description: An examination of the music, culture, and mythology of jazz revealed through the study of jazz fiction, film, poetry, and recorded examples.

title: MUJZ 443 Jazz Pedagogy
description: Concepts, methods, and resources; examination and comparison of textbooks, recordings, tapes, and materials related to the study and teaching of jazz.

title: MUJZ 400 Arranging for Jazz Ensemble
description: Scoring for jazz ensemble with emphasis on writing for sections of like and mixed instruments as well as full ensemble.

title: MUJZ 403 Studio Singing Techniques
description: Study of technique, theory and aural skills as applied to studio singing; critical listening; study of various styles; ear training and sight singing as these apply to working in a studio.

title: MUJZ 396 Jazz Combo II
description: Preparation and performance of literature for jazz combos.

title: MUJZ 395 Jazz Elements II
description: Advanced study of compositional, improvisational, performance, conducting, and arranging elements found in the jazz repertory. Students will be encouraged to forge individual musical expressions.

title: MUJZ 353 Individual Instruction
description: Registration Restriction: Open only to jazz studies majors.

title: MUJZ 390 Special Problems
description: Supervised, individual studies. No more than one registration permitted. Enrollment by petition only.

title: MUJZ 347 Jazz Composition
description: Duplicates Credit in former MUCO 347.

title: MUJZ 350g A History of Jazz Music
description: A history of jazz music and the styles of music considered antecedents to jazz.

title: MUJZ 342a Aural Skills for Improvisers
description: Sight-singing and dictation applied to jazz repertoire. Vocalization of modal and synthetic jazz scales and chordal qualities.

title: MUJZ 311 Vocal Jazz Techniques
description: Development of skills needed for the professional vocal jazz musician. Study of the standard jazz repertoire, vocal improvisation, lead sheet writing, and working with rhythm sections.

title: MUJZ 342b Aural Skills for Improvisers
description: Sight-singing and dictation applied to jazz repertoire. Vocalization of modal and synthetic jazz scales and chordal qualities.

title: MUJZ 305b Advanced Jazz Theory
description: Analysis and transcription of jazz performances and scores, encompassing questions of style, form, harmonic and melodic language, and considerations of rhythm.

title: MUJZ 341 Keyboard Skills for Improvisers
description: Reading skills related to jazz accompanying; "fake" books, chord progressions commonly used in jazz.

title: MUJZ 301 Individual Instruction
description: Intermediate and advanced instruction: secondary emphasis for music majors, principal emphasis for music minors and BA music majors.

title: MUJZ 305a Advanced Jazz Theory
description: Analysis and transcription of jazz performances and scores, encompassing questions of style, form, harmonic and melodic language, and considerations of rhythm.

title: MUJZ 300x Non-Major Individual Instruction
description: Intermediate and advanced instruction designed for non-music majors.

title: MUJZ 286b The History of Jazz
description: A study of the evolution of American jazz music from its roots in Africa to the present day. Includes an introduction to world music elements.

title: MUJZ 286a The History of Jazz
description: A study of the evolution of American jazz music from its roots in Africa to the present day. Includes an introduction to world music elements.

title: MUJZ 253 Individual Instruction
description: Registration Restriction: Open only to jazz studies majors.

title: MUJZ 252 Individual Instrument Performance Class I
description: Solo and orchestra repertoire, professional preparation, reed making, and other matters appropriate to group study. Required of all first and second year wind and percussion majors each semester in residence.

title: MUJZ 218a Afro-Latin Percussion Instruments
description: Instruction in the performance of percussion instruments associated with African, South American, and Caribbean music traditions, with special emphasis on adaptation to jazz music.

title: MUJZ 218b Afro-Latin Percussion Instruments
description: Instruction in the performance of percussion instruments associated with African, South American, and Caribbean music traditions, with special emphasis on adaptation to jazz music.

title: MUJZ 200a Jazz Styles Analysis
description: Theoretical skills and analytical techniques related to jazz styles from Dixieland to the present. Styles through Progressive Swing.

title: MUJZ 200b Jazz Styles Analysis
description: Theoretical skills and analytical techniques related to jazz styles from Dixieland to the present. Bebop to the present.

title: OMOD 506 Infection Control
description: Infection control and clinical asepsis in the dental office; ethical and legal aspects; specific agents of disease; epidemiology.

title: OMOD 505 Oral Medicine
description: Detection, recognition, assessment, management and treatment modification of medical conditions presented by dental patients.

title: OMOD 502 Chronic Orofacial Pain
description: Current concepts of pain mechanisms; application to differential diagnosis, treatment, and management of chronic head, neck, and dental pain.

title: OMOD 501 Emergency Dental Treatment
description: Dental emergencies in a general dental practice; emphasis on diagnosis of pain, trauma, infections, abscesses, myofacial problems, pulpal considerations, restorative goals; interrelationship of these areas.

title: OFP 730c Case Portfolio Preparation
description: Select, prepare and defend an e-Portfolio, which includes 18 patient cases that have been documented.

title: OFP 730b Case Portfolio Preparation
description: Select, prepare and defend an e-Portfolio, which includes 18 patient cases that have been documented.

title: OFP 730a Case Portfolio Preparation
description: Select, prepare and defend an e-Portfolio, which includes 18 patient cases that have been documented.

title: OFP 724 Psychological and Psychometric Assessment
description: Discuss practical aspects of psychological issues (diagnosis and treatment) and psychometrics as they impact patients in an orofacial pain clinic.

title: OFP 723 Systems Physiology, Motor Disorders, and Sleep Apnea
description: Understanding the diagnosis, mechanism and management of oral motor and sleep disorders and the physiology associated with the masticatory system.

title: OFP 710 Knowledge Assessment
description: Intensive calibration/training/seminar sessions students develop and demonstrate the program required skills.

title: OFP 707 Pharmacology Series
description: Focuses on the pharmacologic principles and appropriate use of specific pharmaco-therapeutic classes of drugs including analgesics, DMARDs, anxiolytics, anti-convulsants, anti-fungals; and injectable agents.

title: OFP 706 TMD, Orthopedics, Rheumatology, and Physical Therapy
description: Discuss the prevalence, diagnosis, prevention and management for the temporomandibular, arthrogenous, motor, mobility and growth disorders occurring in the oral, maxillofacial and neck regions.

title: OFP 705 Neurogenic Based Oral and Facial Pains
description: Covers the prevalence, diagnosis, prevention and management for various neurogenic orofacial pain and headache disorders occurring in the oral, maxillofacial and neck regions.

description: Residents must complete their capstone research project in a topic in the area of their chosen focus/specialization.

title: OFPM 730e Case Portfolio Preparation by Online OFPOM Residents
description: Multiple elements including weekly online conferences, presentations and discussions of de-identified patient cases; learning need assignments; preparation and defense of case-based e-Portfolio.

description: Multiple elements including weekly online conferences, presentations and discussions of de-identified patient cases; learning need assignments; preparation and defense of case-based e-Portfolio.

description: Multiple elements including weekly online conferences, presentations and discussions of de-identified patient cases; learning need assignments; preparation and defense of case-based e-Portfolio.

description: Multiple elements including weekly online conferences, presentations and discussions of de-identified patient cases; learning need assignments; preparation and defense of case-based e-Portfolio.

title: OFPM 730b Case Portfolio Preparation by Online OFPOM Residents
description: Multiple elements including weekly online conferences, presentations and discussions of de-identified patient cases; learning need assignments; preparation and defense of case-based e-Portfolio.

description: Residents complete their capstone research project in a topic in the area of their chosen focus/specialization.

title: OFPM 729a Capstone Project for OFPOM Residents
description: Residents complete their capstone research project in a topic in the area of their chosen focus/specialization.

title: OFPM 728 Case Presentations by OFP-OM Residents
description: Case presentations by Orofacial Pain/Oral Medicine residents in which each resident presents and defends the diagnostic and treatment methods selected for a particular case.

title: OFPM 727 Infectious Disease, Oral Microbiology and Virology for Dental Residents
description: Seminar organized around infectious diseases in the oral, pharyngeal and nasal region.

title: OFPM 726 Immunology and Immunosuppression for Dental Residents
description: Seminar course on immunology and immunosuppression as it relates to diseases in the oral and maxillofacial region.

title: OFPM 725 Epidemiology, Nutrition and Aging for Dental Residents
description: Seminar on the epidemiology of oral disease and nutritional topics as related to the aging patient.

title: OFPM 723 Systems Physiology, Motor Disorders and Sleep Apnea for Dental Residents
description: Seminars on various topics relating to oral motor disorders and sleep disordered breathing (as it relates to the mandible and tongue.)

title: OFPM 724 Psychological and Psychometric Assessment for Dental Residents
description: Seminars on various topics relating to biobehavioral diagnosis and, where appropriate, psychological management of patients with chronic illness in the orofacial region.

title: OFPM 722 Internal Medicine and Systemic Disease for Dental Residents
description: Seminars on common systemic diseases and the potential interactions with oral disease and treatment.

title: OFPM 721 Neurosciences for Dental Residents
description: Seminars on the neurophysiologic and neuroanatomic bases of chronic orofacial pain disorders.

title: OFPM 710b Knowledge Assessment for OFPOM Residents
description: Several intensive calibration/training/ sessions based on content that the resident is expected to have mastered by the end of the program, specifically in the field of Oral Medicine.

title: OFPM 710a Knowledge Assessment for OFPOM Residents
description: Includes several intensive calibration/training sessions, with multiple practical demonstrations of methods and techniques. Skill development includes TM joint injection, myofascial palpation, oral cancer screening, biopsy, trigger-point injections and salivary gland cannulation, with mock and virtual patients.

title: OFPM 709 Headaches for Dental Residents
description: Seminars on the diagnosis, prevention and management (including pathophysiologic mechanisms) of episodic and chronic headache disorders.

title: OFPM 707 Pharmacology Series for Dental Residents
description: Seminars on common medications used in the practice of oral medicine and chronic orofacial pain.

title: OFPM 706 TMD, Orthopedics, Rheumatology and Physical Therapy for Dental Residents
description: Seminars on various topics relating to the diagnosis and management of Temporomandibular disorders.

title: OFPM 705 Neurogenic Based Oral and Facial Pains for Dental Residents
description: Seminars on the diagnostic and therapeutic procedures appropriate for chronic neurogenic based pain disorders that occur in the orofacial region.

title: OFPM 704 Bony Pathology, Radiology and Advanced Imaging for Dental Residents
description: Review of the oral and maxillofacial region osseous and odontogenic pathologies and the various imaging methods used to examine this anatomic region.

title: OFPM 703 Local Anesthesia, Minor Surgery and Biopsy Procedures for Dental Residents
description: Seminars on local anesthesia methods and minor surgical procedures appropriate for the oral and maxillofacial region.

title: OFPM 702a Soft Tissue Disease for Dental Residents
description: Seminars on the various mucosal, cutaneous, gingival and salivary diseases and lesions in the oral and maxillofacial region.

title: OFPM 702b Soft Tissue Disease for Dental Residents
description: Seminars on the various mucosal, cutaneous, gingival and salivary diseases and lesions in the oral and maxillofacial region.

title: OFPM 701 CPR, Blood and Airborne Infections and Common Emergencies for Dental Residents
description: CPR training, review of common dental emergencies, and blood and airborne pathogens in dental patients.

title: OCCL 601 Advanced Concepts of Occlusion
description: Historical perspective of occlusion; occlusal equilibration, effect of occlusal adjustment, instrumentation useful in occlusal therapy. Includes clinic and laboratory experience.

title: OCCL 522 Occlusion Laboratory
description: Laboratory experience in functional analysis and correction of occlusal disharmonies.

title: OCCL 521b Dental Morphology and Function
description: Fundamentals of tooth form; principles of occlusion.

title: OCCL 521a Dental Morphology and Function
description: Fundamentals of tooth form; principles of occlusion.

title: OCCL 502 Occlusion
description: Principles of occlusion as related to clinical application of techniques and procedures to diagnose and treatment plan malfunctions of the stomatognathic system.

title: OCCL 310 Fundamentals of Dental Morphology
description: Fundamentals of tooth form; carving of the permanent teeth.

title: NURS 608 Clinical Practicum: Family Primary Care
description: Prepares the family nurse practitioner student for entry into practice in the diagnosis and managment of patients with acute, complex, and chronic illnesses in the primary care setting.

title: NURS 606 Health Policy Principles in Changing Health Care Contexts
description: Foundation for leadership in interprofessional collaborative endeavors to address health policy that prepares learners to analyze and influence health policy and explores the role of nurse practitioners in the creation and modification of health policy.

title: NURS 605 Professional Issues in Advanced Practice Nursing
description: The professional role and legal responsibilities of the nurse practitioner at entry to clinical practice and throughout a career are explored.

title: NURS 604 Clinical Practicum: Management of Adult Patients with Complex Medical Issues
description: Application of theoretical concepts studied in NURS 600.  Comprehsive assessments, formulation of differential diagnoses, and the development of plans of care to manage acute and chronic complex in a variety of practice settings.

title: NURS 602 Research/Analytical Methods
description: Understanding and applying commonly used research methodologies and data analysis techniques in healthcare research.

title: NURS 603 Transforming Research Evidence into Practice
description: Preparing the advanced practice nursing student to critically evalute knowledge, research and evidence for implementation of best practices in healthcare in order to deliver safe, ethical, culturally sensitive evidence based care for patients in diverse settings.

title: NURS 601 Clinical Practicum: Management of the Childbearing/Childrearing Family
description: Clinical practicum is intended to prepare FNP students to provide primary health care to childbearing/childrearing families from preconception through adolescent phase of the life cycle.

title: NURS 507 Theory: Clinical Management of the Childbearing/Childrearing Family
description: Diagnosing and managing childbearing women from preconception through uncomplicated pregnancy and postpartum periods and providing primary care to children and their families from newborn through adolescence periods.

title: NURS 505 Clinical Practicum: Management of Adult Patients
description: Primary health care to patients throughout the life cycle with a focus on the prevention of disease, health maintenance, and the diagnosis and management of patients with common illnesses.

title: NURS 600 Theory: Clinical Management of Adult Patients with Complex Medical Issues
description: The scope of practice and responsibilities of the family nurse practitioner in the diagnosis and management of patients with acute, complex and chronic illnesses are explored.

title: NURS 504 Pharmacology for Advanced Practice Nursing
description: Advanced pharmacology including pharmacodynamics, pharmacokinetics, and pharmacotherapeutics of all broad categories of agents.

title: NURS 502 Advanced Health Assessment Across the Life Span
description: Development of advanced critical thinking and clinical judgement skills through comprehensive health assessment. Health promotion and health maintenance content is utilized to assess health status and evaluate health risk among individuals and groups.

title: NURS 503 Theory: Clinical Management of Adult Patients
description: The scope of practice and responsibilities of the family nurse practitioner in prevention of disease, health maintenance, and the diagnosis and management of patients with common illnesses are explored.

title: NURS 501 Pathophysiology for Advanced Nursing Practice
description: Recent (within five years), satisfactory completion of undergraduate courses that include Organic Chemistry, Nutrition, Anatomy and Physiology. It is expected that enrolled students have reviewed their undergraduate course work in human anatomy and physiology, and possess a working knowledge of cell biology, biochemistry, nutrition, and human genetics at the undergraduate level.

title: NURS 500 Bridge Course
description: Key concepts from chemistry, biochemistry, genetics, cell biology, metabolism, microbiology, and immunology in an 8-week format. Successful completion of this unique preparatory course is expected to position students for success in the graduate level pathophysiology and pharmacology courses.

title: NSCI 794z Doctoral Dissertation
description: Registration Restriction: Open only to doctoral students in Neuroscience Graduate and Neuroscience majors.

title: NSCI 794d Doctoral Dissertation
description: Registration Restriction: Open only to doctoral students in Neuroscience Graduate and Neuroscience majors.

title: NSCI 794b Doctoral Dissertation
description: Registration Restriction: Open only to doctoral students in Neuroscience Graduate and Neuroscience majors.

title: NSCI 794c Doctoral Dissertation
description: Registration Restriction: Open only to doctoral students in Neuroscience Graduate and Neuroscience majors.

title: NSCI 794a Doctoral Dissertation
description: Registration Restriction: Open only to doctoral students in Neuroscience Graduate and Neuroscience majors.

title: NSCI 790 Research
description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

title: NSCI 599 Special Topics
description: Special topics providing background for instruction and research in neuroscience through lectures, discussions, assigned readings and student presentations.

title: NSCI 596 Internship for Curricular Practical Training
description: Part-time or full-time, practical work experience in the student's field of study. The internship must be located at an off-campus facility. Students are individually supervised by faculty. May not be taken until the student has completed at least one semester of enrollment in the graduate program with a cumulative 3.0 GPA.

title: NSCI 540 Advanced Seminars in Neuroscience
description: Advanced topic based seminarstyle courses in the diverse areas of Neuroscience.

title: NSCI 539 Seminar in Neurobiology
description: Registration Restriction: Open only to master and doctoral students.

title: NSCI 541 Advanced Seminars in Neuroscience
description: Advanced topic-based, seminar-style courses in the diverse areas of Neuroscience.

title: NSCI 532 Systems and Behavioral Neurobiology
description: Systems and behavioral neurobiology: hierarchical mechanisms controlling behavior, experimental techniques; perceptual (visual, auditory, somatosensory) systems; sensorimotor systems; motivated behavior; learning, memory and adaptation.

title: NSCI 531 Molecular and Cellular Neurobiology
description: Introduces fundamental principles of advanced molecular and cellular neurobiology including proteins and nucleic acids, cell biology of neurons and glia, synaptic transmission and neuronal signaling.

title: NSCI 525 Advanced Overview of Neurosciences II
description: Sensory and motor systems, cognitive neuroscience, behavioral systems, computational neuroscience.

title: NSCI 524 Advanced Overview of Neurosciences
description: Study of the nervous system at multiple levels through the analysis of four themes: motor control; emotion, motivation, and decision-making; memory and learning; and vision.

title: NSC 454 Leadership and Management II
description: Introduction to primary duties of junior naval officers; counseling and interviewing techniques; review of basic administrative responsibilities at the division officer level.

title: NSC 453 Leadership and Management I
description: Principles of human relationships; principles of decision making and management at the junior officer level; theory and techniques of leadership.

title: NSC 392 Amphibious Warfare
description: Concepts of seaborne military operations; relationship of factors involved; characteristic operations of World War II; amphibious operation planning.

title: NSC 343 Evolution of Warfare
description: Causes and practice of warfare from ancient times; impact of changes in strategy, tactics, and technology; modern revolutionary warfare, global conflict, and politico-military relationships.

title: NSC 335 Navigation
description: Purposes, methods, and instruments of navigation; terrestrial and celestial navigation and nautical astronomy; time diagrams; lines of position by observation of celestial bodies.

title: NSC 337 Naval Ships Systems II (Weapons)
description: Systems approach to naval weapons; linear analysis of ballistics; weapons control systems configurations and dynamics. Field trips.

title: NSC 283 Naval Ships Systems I (Engineering)
description: Types, structure, and purpose of Naval ships, compartmentation, propulsion systems, auxiliary power systems, interior communications, ship control; ship design and stability.

title: NSC 251 Seamanship and Ship Operations
description: Vector solutions of relative motion, tactical problems; tactical communications, instructions; fleet communications, organizations; rules of the Nautical Road; aviation and maritime meteorology; operation plans and orders.

title: NSC 137 Seapower and Maritime Affairs
description: Analysis of U.S. Navy development and campaigns; evolution of strategic, tactical, and maritime doctrines; interaction of naval affairs with national security and domestic policies.

title: NSC 135 Introduction to Naval Science
description: Introduction to the structure, principles, and practices, lines of command and control, and functions of the various components of the naval service.

title: NIIN 597 Current Topics in Neuroimaging Informatics
description: Leading researchers in the areas of basic and clinical brain imaging, computational methods, and informatics formally discuss their work for which students provide written critical review and comment.

title: NIIN 598 Neuroimaging and Informatics External Speaker Seminar Series
description: Reading and discussion of recent papers by the INI speaker of the week and attendance at the speaker's seminar.

title: NIIN 560 Brain Architecture and Neuroanatomic Exploratory Techniques in Animal Models
description: Introduction to basic theories and methodological approaches to neuroanatomy in animal models including histology, microscopy, behavioral investigations, and neuroinformatics.

title: NIIN 570 Neuroimaging Genetics
description: Lectures on human genetics and epigenetics. Discuss how applying these concepts to brain imaging advances our understanding of healthy development and neurological disease. Emphasis on critical thinking applied both to designing neuroimaging genetics studies and to constructively assessing peer work and existing neuroimaging genetics literature.

title: NIIN 540 Neuroimaging Data Processing Methods
description: Comprehensive investigation of data processing methods, software strategies, and workflow design and execution methodologies.

title: NIIN 510 Fundamentals of Human Neuroimaging
description: Survey of anatomical and functional neuroimaging approaches and their use to explore the healthy as well as diseased human brain.

title: NIIN 520 Experimental Design for Neuroimaging
description: Examine experimental design approaches for experimental and clinical neuroimaging investigation. Topics on how to develop rigorous experiments to test theories of cognitive and clinical neuroscience.

title: NIIN 550 Computational Modeling in Neuroimaging
description: Addresses the current neuroinformatics approaches to large-scale data representations, mining, and visualization in brain imaging.

title: NIIN 530 Neuroimaging Data Acquisition w/ Magnetic Resonance Imaging
description: Introduces the various approaches used to image the living brain using MR-based techniques. Covers neuroimaging scanning technologies, pulse sequence design, and sources of image artifact.

title: PAIN 721 Advanced Therapeutics
description: Patients who suffer from chronic pain often fail to respond to basic treatments. Therefore it is crucial for clinicians to be familiar with different treatment options.

title: PAIN 722 Palliative Care in End of Life
description: Key concepts in palliative medicine and hospice care, ranging from management of common symptoms, to best practices in communication with patients and their families.

title: PAIN 720 Physical and Occupational Therapies
description: Physical and Occupational Therapy techniques to assess and treat chronic pain.

title: PAIN 719 Building a Practice:  Institutional or Private
description: Building and managing a Pain Practice. Topics include the scope of practice, stratification of care, and marketing.

title: PAIN 718 Complementary Approaches
description: Treatment options in pain management; framework for integrative models of care.

title: PAIN 717 Psychological Aspects of Chronic Pain
description: Information and demonstration on specific psychological treatments to decrease pain levels and manage pain flares.

title: PAIN 716 Neuropathic Pain
description: Focus on pain caused by nervous system dysfunction; assessment, physiology, diagnoses and treatment.

title: PAIN 715 History of Pain:  Theory and Treatment
description: Trace through history our collective understanding of pain by examining the people, theories, and technologies which have brought us to our modern understanding.

title: PAIN 714 Public Policy and Legal issues
description: Public Policy and Legal Issues in Pain Medicine including the California Medical Board Guidelines for Pain Medication, CURES, and legislation related with the discipline.

title: PAIN 713c Case Studies
description: Multiple elements including weekly online discussions of cases; learning need assignments; defense of an 18 cases or scenarios e-Portfolio.

title: PAIN 713d Case Studies
description: Multiple elements including weekly online discussions of cases; learning need assignments; defense of an 18 cases or scenarios e-Portfolio.

title: PAIN 712d Pain Medicine Capstone
description: Collaborative research project or supervised internship (practicum) incorporating a service learning approach.

description: Multiple elements including weekly online discussions of cases; learning need assignments; defense of an 18 cases or scenarios e-Portfolio.

title: PAIN 713b Case Studies

title: PAIN 712a Pain Medicine Capstone
description: Collaborative research project or supervised internship (practicum) incorporating a service learning approach.

title: PAIN 712c Pain Medicine Capstone
description: Collaborative research project or supervised internship (practicum) incorporating a service learning approach.

title: PAIN 711 Research Methodology
description: Conduct a systematic review, research question, searching the literature, summarizing the evidence and interpreting the findings.

title: PAIN 712b Pain Medicine Capstone
description: Collaborative research project or supervised internship (practicum) incorporating a service learning approach.

title: PAIN 709 Pain Classification and Diagnosis - Part 2
description: Knowledge and ability to recognize fine differences in various common pain conditions.

title: PAIN 710 Advanced Pain Physiology and Neuroscience
description: Advanced neurophysiology of pain including immunology and epigenetics, neuropathic pain, inflammation, with a series of lectures and sessions to analyze clinical cases.

title: PAIN 708 Opioids
description: Explores opioid therapeutics including proper use, dosing, side effects and its management, use in special populations, and legal/ethical considerations for prescribers and dispensers.

title: PAIN 707 Pain Neuroscience
description: Anatomy of peripheral and central nociceptors, molecular mechanisms that underlie primary responses, neural networks, and neural mechanisms involved in hyperalgesia and allodynia.

title: PAIN 705 Pain Assessment:  History and Physical Examination
description: Evaluation of patients suffering from pain, distinguishing between types of pain that may be acute or chronic.

title: PAIN 706 Musculoskeletal Anatomy and Pathology
description: Anatomical survey of the human musculoskeletal system, focused on common pathologies that generate pain.

title: PAIN 704 Pain and Society: Epidemiology and Cultural issues
description: Explores the societal issues related to pain, including the role of culture, ethnicity, caregiving, social and psychological factors related to pain and pain management.

title: PAIN 703 Psychological Aspects of the Pain Experience: Individual and
description: Explore the psychological and social perspectives that influence chronic pain, reinforcing the need to look beyond the initial physical diagnosis.

title: PAIN 702 Pain Classification and Diagnosis - Part 1
description: Introduction of pain classification and diagnosis to familiarize the student with a standardized approach to painful conditions.

title: PAIN 701 Pharmacotherapeutics for Pain
description: Introduction into the complex area of treatment with opioids and other pharmacological options.

title: OT 794d Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: OT 794z Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: OT 794c Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: OT 794b Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: OT 794a Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: OT 790 Research
description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

title: OT 686 Residency
description: Residency involving development, administration, evaluation, or policy formulation for occupation-centered programs in clinical or community settings. Development of portfolio for professional doctorate. Graded CR/NC.

title: OT 661 Grant Writing for Occupational Science
description: Integration of theory, research design, and methods to develop competitive grant applications for the study of occupation, with a focus on federal granting agencies.

title: OT 655 Work and Leisure
description: Ontogenesis and phylogenesis of work and leisure. Systems view of person/environmental interactions affecting competence and satisfaction with activity. Occupation and the need for mastery.

title: OT 660 Research Practicum
description: Experiential learning through immersion in one or more externally funded research groups in the Division, enabling intense participation in multi-skilled research groups.

title: OT 650 Development of Adaptive Skills
description: Critical analysis of occupation as means and product of human adaptation. Adaptive skill development from traditional and occupational science approaches. Research methods and results.

title: OT 648 Researching Occupation: Engagement, Meaning, and Society
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: OT 647 Producing New Knowledge in Occupational Science
description: Problems, theory, methods and contexts of research in occupational science, as a discipline that seeks to understand, explain, and promote human flourishing.

title: OT 649 Researching Occupation: Function, Participation, and Health
description: Approaches to studying health and wellbeing in everyday living from biological to population levels, including prevention, wellness, chronic illness, disability, and rehabilitation, emphasizing quantitative methods.

title: OT 646 Intersections of Occupational Science and Human Development
description: Analysis of occupational science perspectives related to human development and participation in sociocultural practices and examination of developmental theories and their relationship to occupational science.

title: OT 645 Narrative, Healing and the Culture of Biomedicine
description: Introduction to narrative as analytic framework for considering chronic illness, disability, occupation, and the moral and cultural influences on the clinical reasoning of health professionals.

title: OT 644 Foundations of Research on Activity and Health
description: Examination of effectiveness and efficacy research, study design and methodology, dimensions of adaptation and research methods through the lens of two division-based research programs.

title: OT 642 Therapeutic Uses of Self: Psychodynamic Perspectives
description: Survey of the diversity of analytic conceptions of subjectivity and intersubjectivity. Emphasis on the way these ideas influence the notion of therapeutic efficacy within Occupational Science.

title: OT 643 Meaningful Engagement in Everyday Life
description: Exploration of the subjective experience of meaningful engagement in work, play, and the occupational pursuits of everyday life, drawing on contributions from the social sciences.

title: OT 640 Conceptual Foundations of Occupational Science
description: Analysis of the conceptual foundations and methodological orientations for occupational science, understandings of disciplinary perspectives, formulation of theoretical arguments, and the interpretation of research data.

title: OT 641 The Nature of Occupation
description: Theoretical and historical foundations for the study of occupation, engagement in living and learning in everyday life.

title: OT 621 Occupational Therapy Leadership: Contemporary Issues
description: Examination of themes in occupational therapy related to power, confidence, and identity; development of leadership skills; analysis of the impact of policy and advocacy on occupational therapy.

title: OT 612 Information Processing and Occupation
description: Phylogenesis and ontogenesis of human information processing capacity enabling engagement in occupation; components and contributions to adaptation and coping.

title: OT 620 Current Issues in Occupational Science and Occupational Therapy
description: Review of current occupational science research as it is applied to practice; examination of leadership opportunities; development of proposal focusing on chosen area of study.

title: OT 610 Sensory Integrative Dysfunction
description: Differential evaluation of sensory integrative dysfunction; theory and procedure for enhancing the processing of sensory data by children with learning and behavior disorders.

title: OT 599 Special Topics
description: Recent developments in occupational therapy and occupational science.

title: OT 596 Internship for Curricular Practical Training
description: Part-time or full-time, practical work experience in the student's field of study. The internship must be located at an off-campus facility. Students are individually supervised by faculty. May not be taken until the student has completed at least one semester of enrollment in the graduate program with a cumulative 3.0 GPA.

title: OT 594a Master's Thesis
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: OT 594z Master's Thesis
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: OT 594b Master's Thesis
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: OT 590 Directed Research
description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

title: OT 586 Clinical Internship with Seminar
description: Clinical internship to qualify for professional certification. Seminar to integrate theory with application of treatment principles for various populations.

title: OT 585 Advanced Seminar in Occupational Science
description: Advanced analysis of occupational science concepts including dimensions of occupation and the impact of occupation on health and wellbeing; factors associated with participation in occupation at the individual, community and global levels.

title: OT 584 Clinical Applications of Telehealth Technologies in OT
description: Interactive course exploring the history of telehealth technologies; includes definitions, care models, remote services, applications, activity monitoring devices, technology enabled therapy, legislation, reimbursement.

title: OT 583 Current Applications of Lifestyle Redesign
description: Interactive practicum exploring the Lifestyle Redesign® approach to preventing and managing chronic health conditions. Topics include therapeutic process, lifestyle module design and service delivery models.

title: OT 582 Occupational Science Foundations of Lifestyle Redesign
description: Overview of the foundations and philosophy of Lifestyle Redesign®.  Includes theoretical underpinnings, therapeutic methods , and examination of how occupational science informs Lifestyle Redesign

title: OT 581 Quantitative Research for the Practicing Clinician
description: Traditions and methods of quantitative research for practicing clinicians; emphasis on formulation of clear clinical questions; finding, evaluating, and applying evidence to a clinical problem.

title: OT 577 Seminar in Occupational Therapy
description: Registration Restriction: Open only to Occupational Therapy majors.

title: OT 578 Therapeutic Communication: Facilitating Change in Clients
description: Exploration of selected therapeutic communication styles intended to facilitate change including motivational interviewing, mindfulness practices, and cognitive approaches to therapeutic intervention.

title: OT 576 Universal Design
description: Examination of the concepts and principles of universal design and the benefits of the approach for people with disabilities and for all individuals.

title: OT 574 Enhancing Motor Control for Occupation
description: Laboratory examining approaches to assessment and remediation of motor control following upper motor neuron lesions. An occupation-based approach to Neurodevelopmental Treatment (NDT) will be emphasized.

title: OT 575 Dysphagia Across the Lifespan: Pediatrics through Geriatrics
description: A comprehensive investigation of the anatomy and physiology of normal and abnormal swallowing. Didactic and hands-on study of assessment and treatment interventions will be addressed.

title: OT 573 Hand Rehabilitation
description: Occupation-based evaluation and intervention for individuals with acute and chronic hand disorders. Topics include scar management, splinting, peripheral nerve injury, wound healing and physical agent modalities.

title: PHED 131 Step Aerobics
description: Development of physical fitness components through step aerobics; total body workout utilizing step movements and body sculpting exercises.

title: PHED 129b Cardio Group Fitness
description: Group exercise teaching techniques and application of fitness principles through weekly workouts; group fitness certification exam preparation.

title: PHED 124 Walking for Fitness
description: Develop a strong fitness foundation through walking; fitness assessment and individualized programs; gait biomechanics and power walking; injury prevention; strategies for special populations.

title: PHED 123 Yoga Therapy
description: Holistic discipline combining traditional yoga techniques with a modern medicine approach to treating a variety of health conditions; includes physical, mental and breathing practice.

title: PHED 129a Cardio Group Fitness
description: Group fitness instruction incorporating a variety of training methods such as cycling, HITT (high intensity interval training), step, circuits; nutritional guidelines.

title: PHED 122 Kundalini Yoga and Meditation
description: Ancient yoga practice combining postures, meditation, breathing, mantras and focus techniques; designed to improve mind body awareness, balance, strength, flexibility, techniques and nervous system function.

title: PHED 121 Yoga for Athletic Performance
description: Skills and strategies for injury prevention and recovery from athletic training; application of yoga principles to improve posture, strength, flexibility, core stability and concentration.

title: PHED 120b Yoga
description: A continuing study of intermediate and advanced yoga postures, breathing techniques and meditation as a means toward relaxation and stress-reduction.

title: OT 571 Assistive Technology
description: Principles of assessment, selection, training, and follow-up with clients in the use of assistive technologies to enable and enhance participation in a meaningful occupation.

title: PHED 120c Yoga
description: In-depth study of hatha yoga and its history; includes advanced asanas and meditation as a means toward overall health and wellness.

title: OT 572 Ergonomics
description: Focus on the effects of physical design in the workplace on users' injury rate, behavior, performance and stress levels. Intervention for repetitive motion included.

title: OT 567 Contemporary Issues: Occupational Therapy in Early Intervention
description: Exploration of occupational therapy in early intervention settings including; relevant legislation, family-centered care, cultural context, documentation, ethics, and neuroscientific foundations of infant mental health.

title: OT 566 Healthcare Communication with Spanish-Speaking Clients
description: Development of communicative proficiency and accuracy in Spanish within a therapeutic context.  Introduction to Spanish language, adaptive communication strategies, and ethics in language-discordant communication.

title: OT 564 Sensory Processing and Sensory Integration
description: Comprehensive overview of the basic neurobehavioral principles underlying sensory processing and sensory integration, patterns of dysfunction, and their relationship to everyday occupations and intervention.

title: OT 563 Occupational Therapy in Primary Health Care Environments
description: Examines the emerging role of occupational therapy in primary care, including the need occupational therapy can address in primary care.

title: OT 565 Sensory Integration Interventions
description: Foundations and application of sensory integration principles in clinical practice, schools and community.  Includes critique and integration of evidence, effective communication with parents, and documentation.

title: OT 562 Advanced Hand Rehabilitation and Certification (PAMs)
description: Evidence-based and occupation-based practice for hand and upper extremity conditions; application of PAMs as preparatory for occupation. Applicable toward California educational requirements for advanced practice.

title: OT 561 Occupational Therapy in Acute Care
description: Knowledge and skills for occupational therapy practice in acute care settings using a systems-based approach; includes an experiential learning component at Keck Hospital of USC.

title: OT 560 Contemporary Issues in School-Based Practice
description: Current issues in school-based occupational therapy evaluation, ongoing assessment and intervention. Topics include successful collaboration in inclusive classrooms and on IFSP and IEP teams.

title: OT 540 Leadership Capstone
description: Professional capstone in leadership, advocacy, ethical reasoning, professional behavior, and public policy as it impacts the practice of occupational therapy; independent professional externship.

title: OT 545 Advanced Seminar in Occupational Science
description: Advanced analysis of occupational science concepts including dimensions of occupation and the impact of occupation on health and wellbeing; factors associated with participation in occupation at the individual, community and global levels.

title: OT 537 Occupation-Centered Programs for the Community
description: Development of a proposal for new or extended services; includes trends analysis, needs assessment, literature review, marketing plan, mock funding request, program evaluation and presentation.

title: OT 538 Current Issues in Practice: Adulthood and Aging
description: Exploration of adulthood, aging and occupation; current topics related to aging population and occupational therapy to promote health and participation throughout the lifespan.

title: OT 534 Health Promotion and Wellness
description: Examination of relationship of occupation to health, wellbeing, participation; critical thinking about lifestyle factors influencing occupational engagement; occupational science and wellness in occupational therapy practice.

title: OT 523 Communication Skills for Effective Practice
description: Principles of written, verbal and non-verbal communication with professionals, clients and families, from a personal and professional perspective; group interventions; interview skills; advocacy as communication.

title: OT 525 Qualitative Research for Evidence-Based Practice
description: Traditions and methods of qualitative research; development of skills for research design, implementation and dissemination; critique of qualitative research for evidence-based practice and occupational science.

title: OT 521 Clinical Reasoning
description: Dynamic look at creation and application of professional knowledge and expertise; examines interrelationship between theory and practice; incorporates narrative and illness experiences in clinical reasoning.

title: OT 515 Neuroscience of Behavior
description: Foundation for understanding neural functions involved in typical/atypical behaviors; review of neural circuitry, experimental methods, basic behavioral systems, higher order cognitive functions and associated disorders.

title: OT 518 Quantitative Research for Evidence-Based Practice
description: Traditions and methods of quantitative research; emphasis on formulation of clear clinical questions; finding, evaluating, and applying evidence to a clinical problem; includes journal club.

title: OT 503L Practice Immersion: Pediatrics
description: Scientific and theoretical underpinnings and knowledge and skills necessary for occupational therapy evaluation and intervention in pediatrics; incorporates related Level I Fieldwork.

title: OT 511 Therapeutic Use of Self
description: Exploration of efficacy, therapeutic use of self, empathy and mindfulness; development of self-awareness to support the art, craft and skill of effective therapeutic relationships.

title: OT 502L Practice Immersion: Mental Health
description: Scientific and theoretical underpinnings and knowledge and skills necessary for occupational therapy evaluation and intervention in mental health practice; incorporates related Level I Fieldwork.

title: PHED 120a Yoga
description: Introduction to meditation, breathing techniques and postures as a means towards relaxation; increase muscle flexibility; understanding of basic anatomy and nutritional guidelines.

title: PHED 115 Surfing
description: Students will need to pass a swim test BEFORE being allowed to participate in the course. Swim test includes the following: continuous 150 yard swim in under 3 minutes; treading water for 10 minutes; surface dive with brick retrieval; and a 25 yard under water swim.

title: PHED 110a Swimming
description: Instruction and practice in basic strokes for beginners and intermediate swimmers; elementary springboard diving; water safety techniques; endurance training as a fitness program.

title: PHED 110b Swimming
description: Advanced instruction and practice of strokes; advanced endurance training.

title: PHED 114 Lifesaving
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: PHED 106b Physical Conditioning
description: Advanced training methods focusing on continuing gains in fitness level.

title: PHED 108 High Stress Physical Conditioning
description: Rigorous physical conditioning with emphasis on distance running and development of cardiovascular and upper body strength. A challenging regimen to enhance stamina and endurance.

title: PHED 106a Physical Conditioning
description: Improvement in cardiorespiratory endurance, body composition, muscle endurance and flexibility; running, circuit training, resistance exercises; fitness principles and nutrition to develop individualized program.

title: PHED 104a Self-Defense
description: Basic instruction of self-defense for beginners; strategies for standing and ground fighting situations with and without weapons.

title: PHED 104b Self-Defense
description: Intermediate instruction involving more advanced fighting strategies and techniques.

title: PHED 102b Weight Training
description: Training techniques and application of advanced weight training principles through weekly workouts; personal trainer certification exam preparation.

title: PHED 102a Weight Training
description: Improvement of body shape, muscle endurance, and muscle strength; understanding of weight training and nutrition principles that can be utilized for future weight training development.

title: PHBI 660 Understanding Diseases of Ion Transport
description: Examination of the genetics, biochemical mechanisms, and physiological characteristics of diseases caused by inherited mutations in ion channels and ion transport proteins.

title: PHBI 651 Molecular Modeling and Kinetic Simulations in Membrane Transport
description: Introduction to the principles of mathematical modeling of biological systems and molecular dynamics simulations, with emphasis on membrane transport.

title: PHBI 650 Mechanisms of Ion and Solute Transport Across Cell Membranes
description: Biophysical examination of the mechanisms of ion and solute transport across cell membranes; emphasis on the structures of transport proteins and kinetic models of transport.

description: Three trimester course discussions and case conferences related to treatment of patients with oral and facial anomalies: includes interceptive and corrective orthodontics, preventive and restorative treatment, and selected oral surgery-prosthetic rehabilitative procedures.

description: Discussions and readings pertaining to the analysis and incorporation of the many components of prevention into the contemporary pediatric dentistry practice.

title: PCPA 586 Advanced Topics in PA Studies: Research

title: PCPA 583 Advanced Topics in PA Studies: Education
description: Seminar format: students explore educational theories and methods used by PAs in a variety of settings, including clinical practice, classroom and community.

description: Basic instruction in normal/abnormal states of organ systems in the study of human disease. The third of three courses that includes instruction in pathophysiology, pharmacology, diagnostic studies, and medicine.

title: PCPA 546 Topics in Medicine II
description: Basic instruction in normal/abnormal states of organ systems in the study of human disease. The second of three courses that includes instruction in pathophysiology, pharmacology, diagnostic studies, and medicine.

title: PCPA 543 Topics in Medicine I
description: Basic instruction in normal/abnormal states of organ systems in the study of human disease. The first of three courses that includes instruction in pathophysiology, pharmacology, diagnostic studies, and medicine.

title: PERI 701a Seminar: Review of Current Periodontal Literature
description: Review and critical evaluation of the current periodontal literature.

description: Supervised treatment of periodontal disease at all levels of complexity.

title: PERI 602 Current Controversies in Periodontology
description: Examination of the major controversies in the field of periodontology; emphasis on the efficacy of current treatment modalities and future trends.

description: Supervised treatment of periodontal disease at all levels of complexity.

title: PERI 561d Clinic: Periodontal Therapy I
description: Supervised treatment of periodontal disease at all levels of complexity.

description: Supervised treatment of periodontal disease at all levels of complexity.

description: Laboratory and clinical development of periodontal therapy procedures; basic instrumentation principles.

title: PERI 550a Clinic: Introductory Periodontal Therapy
description: Laboratory and clinical development of periodontal therapy procedures; basic instrumentation principles.

title: PERI 504 Advanced Periodontics
description: Periodontics as related to endodontics, orthodontics, and restorative dentistry; bone induction, osseous grafting, splinting, management of furcation lesions; maintenance, recall, and referral.

title: PERI 521 Periodontal Surgery
description: General principles and methods of surgical periodontal treatment; includes laboratory exercises.

title: PERI 502 Periodontal Diseases and Elements of Therapeutic Judgment
description: Periodontal pathologic processes; pathogenesis, classification and clinical features of gingivitis; periodontitis; other related diseases of periodontium including diagnosis and initial phases of treatment.

title: PERI 415 Basic Periodontal Therapy
description: Basic therapeutic modalities of periodontal treatment; general principles and methods of surgical periodontal treatment.

title: PERI 310b Introduction to Periodontal Diseases
description: Introduction to periodontal disease; emphasis on identification of normal periodontium, distinguishing of gingival and periodontal diseases; includes data collection and classification of gingival and periodontal diseases.

title: PEDO 790b Directed Research: Pediatric Dentistry
description: An examination and analysis of clinical and laboratory problems in dentistry for children leading to completion of an original research project.

title: PERI 310a Introduction to Periodontal Diseases
description: Introduction to periodontal disease; emphasis on identification of normal periodontium, distinguishing of gingival and periodontal diseases; includes data collection and classification of gingival and periodontal diseases.

title: PEDO 790a Directed Research: Pediatric Dentistry
description: An examination and analysis of clinical and laboratory problems in dentistry for children leading to completion of an original research project.

title: PEDO 774 Clinical Genetics in Pediatric Dentistry
description: Genetic principles of oral, facial and cranial malformations; technique and theory of clinical genetics, differential diagnosis and treatment of disorders of the craniofacial complex.

title: PEDO 773 Hospital Pediatric Clinics
description: Observation and participation in affiliated hospital clinics: anesthesiology, hematology, and genetic clinics; grand pediatric rounds and other conferences.

title: PEDO 772e Clinic: Interceptive Orthodontics
description: Clinical application and treatment procedures for tooth guidance, preventative and interceptive orthodontics.

title: PCPA 530 Basic Medical Sciences
description: A one-semester overview of clinical anatomy, physiology, pathophysiology, and pathology essential to understanding disease mechanisms commonly encountered in primary care and specialty practices of medicine.

title: PCPA 529 Clinical Skills III
description: Laboratory experiences with basic clinical skills essential to medical practice. Third of four courses.

title: PCPA 523 Clinical Skills I
description: Laboratory experiences with basic clinical skills essential to medical practice. First of four courses.

title: PCPA 526 Clinical Skills II
description: Laboratory experiences with basic clinical skills essential to medical practice. Second of four courses.

title: PCPA 509 Behavioral Sciences III
description: Last of three-semester sequence in current topics in behavioral medicine, psychological and cultural factors in health and illness, interpersonal and sociological aspects of patient care, and competencies for PA practice.

title: PCPA 506 Behavioral Sciences II
description: Second of three-semester sequence in current topics in behavioral medicine, psychological and cultural factors in health and illness, interpersonal and sociological aspects of patient care, and competencies for PA practice.

title: PCPA 503 Behavioral Sciences I
description: First of three-semester sequence in current topics in behavioral medicine, psychological and cultural factors in health and illness, interpersonal and sociological aspects of patient care, and competencies for PA practice.

description: Clinical application and treatment procedures for tooth guidance, preventative and interceptive orthodontics.

title: PATH 581 Essentials of Animal Experimentation
description: A course providing basic information on the issues and responsibilities of investigators using animals in biomedical research.

title: PATH 575 Frontiers of Pathology
description: Weekly research lectures by leading investigators in the field of homeostatic response to injury such as cell death, inflammation, fibrosis and regeneration.

title: PATH 570d Seminar in Pathology
description: Recent advances in the understanding of diseased cells and tissues are reported and discussed using standard seminars, as well as autopsy organ reviews.

title: PATH 570c Seminar in Pathology
description: Recent advances in the understanding of diseased cells and tissues are reported and discussed using standard seminars, as well as autopsy organ reviews.

title: PATH 570b Seminar in Pathology
description: Recent advances in the understanding of diseased cells and tissues are reported and discussed using standard seminars, as well as autopsy organ reviews.

title: PATH 650 Stem Cell Biology and Medicine
description: Basic principles, available embryonic and adult stem cells, principles of organogenesis and regeneration, animal models, delivery of engineered tissues to patients, promise and limitations of stem cells. Open to master's and PhD students on the Health Sciences Campus and to medical and post-doctoral fellow trainees only.

title: PATH 570a Seminar in Pathology
description: Recent advances in the understanding of diseased cells and tissues are reported and discussed using standard seminars, as well as autopsy organ reviews.

title: PATH 631 Viral Oncology
description: Broad aspects of RNA and DNA viral oncology from epidemiology to molecular genetics.

title: PATH 554 Methods in Molecular Pathology
description: Theory and practice methods useful in experimental pathology; experimental design; statistical analysis; literature analysis; laboratory and radiation safety.

title: PATH 553 Methods in Cellular and Clinical Pathology
description: Includes advanced techniques in cell biology, protein and immunochemistry. A practical approach to acquaint new graduate students with current methodologies and applications used in biomedical research.

title: PATH 500b Basic and Applied Systemic Pathology
description: Clinical, gross, and microscopic study of basic disease processes. Pathophysiology of major organ systems; etiology, pathogenesis and histopathology of important diseases; oral manifestations, clinical recognition.

title: PATH 500a Basic and Applied Systemic Pathology
description: Clinical, gross, and microscopic study of basic disease processes. Pathophysiology of major organ systems; etiology, pathogenesis and histopathology of important diseases; oral manifestations, clinical recognition.

title: PTHL 701 Clinicopathologic Conference
description: Clinicopathologic correlation of diseases of the head and neck. Presented at LAC+USC Medical Center.

title: PTHL 504b Seminar: Oral Pathology
description: Clinico-pathologic discussion of oral pathosis cases. A variety of "unknown" cases representing diagnostic problems are analyzed. Etiology, pathogenesis, clinical/radiographic features, therapy and prognosis are stressed.

title: PTHL 601 Advanced Oral Pathology Seminar
description: Detailed discussion and analysis of many cases representing a wide variety of oral pathologic conditions stressing differential diagnosis and clinical-pathologic correlations.

title: PTHL 504a Seminar: Oral Pathology
description: Clinico-pathologic discussion of oral pathosis cases. A variety of "unknown" cases representing diagnostic problems are analyzed. Etiology, pathogenesis, clinical/radiographic features, therapy and prognosis are stressed.

title: PTHL 501 Oral Pathology
description: Clinical radiographic, gross and microscopic characteristics of mucosal, skin, fibroseous and salivary gland diseases; odontogenic tumors and cysts; benign and malignant neoplasms and iatrogenic conditions.

title: PM 511bL Data Analysis
description: Statistical methods for analysis of categorical data including dichotomous, ordinal, multinomial and count data, using Stata package. Includes laboratory.

title: PM 510L Principles of Biostatistics
description: Concepts of biostatistics; appropriate uses and common misuses of health statistics; practice in the application of statistical procedures; introduction to statistical software including EXCEL, SPSS, nQuery.

title: PM 511aL Data Analysis
description: Major parametric and nonparametric statistical tools used in biomedical research, computer packages including SAS. Includes laboratory.

title: PM 509 Comparative Health Care Systems
description: Macro-level analysis of the structure and delivery of health care services around the world, including an examination and comparison of health system performance.

title: PM 508 Health Service Delivery in the U.S.
description: Historical development of the American health care system; determinants of health care utilization; role of health care providers; health policy; public health services; and health care finance.

title: PM 506 Overcoming Real World Challenges in Global Health
description: Overview of program implementation challenges in global health contexts, including best practices for establishing effective cross-cultural collaborations, working with key leaders, and operationalizing complex interventions.

title: PATH 551 Pathobiology of Disease
description: Relationship between histopathological and clinical manifestations of disease and their underlying molecular mechanisms. Topics include inflammatory, developmental, environmental, degenerative, and neoplastic disease processes.

title: PATH 550 Introduction to Pathology
description: Normal histology and introduction to basic pathological concepts. Provides a solid and basic understanding of normal structures and how they relate to function.

title: PM 505 Training and Curriculum Design in Public Health
description: Curriculum writing and training skills applied to public health needs and settings. Covers adult learning theories, assessment of learning needs, curriculum design, training design, conduct and evaluation.

title: PM 507 Public Health Services Research Methods
description: A practical examination of methods and data sources used to evaluate public health services and conduct policy research and evaluation within health care delivery systems.

title: PM 504 Quality in Health Care
description: Examines quality assessment at different levels of the health care system including health plans, physicians, hospital and integrated system performance.

title: PM 501 Foundations in Health Education and Promotion
description: Overview and application of behavioral theories to the field of health education and promotion. Examines the determinants of health behavior and strategies for change at the individual, group and community level.

title: PM 502 Foundations of Public Health
description: Overview of public health concepts and issues, including population health; ethics; health disparities, determinants, and systems of care; global health; policy; health promotion; environmental health.

title: PM 500 Foundations of Health Behavior
description: Overview of behavioral theory and research in disease prevention and health promotion and in adaptation of chronic disease, including an introduction to measures of outcomes.

title: PM 503 Practice of Public Health
description: Introduction to the application of strategies and tools for practice in public health, including policy advocacy, leadership and management, program planning and evaluation, health communication.

title: PLUS 694z Planning, Design and Development Professional Dissertation
description: Credit on acceptance of planning, design and development professional dissertation.

title: PLUS 694d Planning, Design and Development Professional Dissertation
description: Credit on acceptance of planning, design and development professional dissertation.

title: PLUS 694b Planning, Design and Development Professional Dissertation
description: Credit on acceptance of planning, design and development professional dissertation.

title: PLUS 694c Planning, Design and Development Professional Dissertation
description: Credit on acceptance of planning, design and development professional dissertation.

title: PLUS 694a Planning, Design and Development Professional Dissertation
description: Credit on acceptance of planning, design and development professional dissertation.

title: PLUS 692 Conspectus Preparation
description: Preparation of a case study of a specific planning and/or development project that defines the student's field of study.

title: PLUS 680 Advanced Urban and Regional Transportation Planning
description: Social and environmental impacts; incentive structures; alternate travel; investment guidelines; technological change.

title: PLUS 672 Integrating Concepts for Action
description: Registration Restriction: Open only to online Master of Urban Planning (executive) students

title: PLUS 671 Leading a Collaborative City
description: Leadership skills for planning and development; cross-sectoral collaboration, negotiation, and theories of organizational leadership; metrics for performance assessment, project management, and team building in organizations.

title: PLUS 670 Communicating Data for Planning and Development
description: Methods and techniques for data visualization; application to planning and development contexts; critical assessment of data presentation approaches and methods.

title: PLUS 668 Big Data for Planning and Development
description: Introduction to data and visualization trends in relation to urban planning and development; train leaders to manage teams and leverage data and information technology resources.

title: PLUS 669 Designing Livable Environments II
description: Studio setting; students will go through a design charrette, site visit, and develop an understanding of design principles

title: PLUS 667 Effective Engagement with Stakeholders
description: Approaches and challenges to community engagement; different conceptualizations of citizen; micro-scale forum and macro-scale methods; use of  media for participation in communities.

title: PLUS 665 Economics for a Productive City
description: Basic concepts of urban and land economics with an emphasis on how planning and development are shaped by the metropolitan economic context; how key theoretical elements inform planning and development questions.

title: PLUS 664 Urban Political Economy and Urban Development
description: Planning and development within a complex political landscape; budgetary and fiscal politics, metropolitan fragmentation and sub urbanization, immigration, and race, gender, and ethnicity in urban politics; implications for planning and development.

title: PLUS 663 Designing Livable Environments I
description: Studio setting; students will go through a design charrette, site visit, and develop an understanding of design principles.

title: PLUS 662 Planning and Development Case Study
description: Case study project; students analyze a project and develop recommendations for financing and regulatory issues.

title: PLUS 661 Politics and Process of Urban Development
description: Introduction of concepts of formal and informal political institutions with a focus on planning and urban issues at the local, state and national levels; theories and methods to understand contemporary planning conflicts.

title: PLUS 653 Leading Change and Innovation in Urban Communities
description: In-depth study of the role of public, private, and non-profit leaders in effecting change in public policy and planning practice, with special attention to the goals and processes of social innovation in urban communities.

title: PLUS 660 Economics of a Productive Development - A Public/Private Perspective
description: Introduction to the economic and financial aspects of real estate development; tools and methods of financial analysis; public and private perspectives.

title: PLUS 652 Place, Institutions, and Governance
description: Concept of place; investigation of the problems and issues confronting metropolitan communities; how the actions of public, private and nonprofit sectors can effect various areas including economics, health, civic life, and the environment; contemporary issues in policy, planning and development; theoretical frameworks for solutions.

title: PLUS 650 Public Policy and Globalization
description: Challenges of public policymaking and administration; conceptual foundations of public policy as well as the practical and political constraints on government action; theories, models, and analytical frameworks both domestic and abroad.

title: PLUS 651 Applied Research Design and Inquiry
