description: Provide foundation in applied research skills required for advanced practice in policy, management, planning and development; design and use of applied research; development of research designs; constraints on application of research; translation of findings.

title: PLUS 635 Urban Finance
description: The theory of fiscal federalism and municipal finance, with examples from the USA and other countries, public/private partnerships in urban development, and government decentralization.

title: PLUS 640 International Urban Development
description: Study of urbanization in developing countries; special attention to urban growth, migration, city size, land use, and urban management. Comparative case studies.

title: PLUS 633 Seminar in Comparative Housing Policy and Urban Planning Programs
description: Comparative examination of urbanization experience in selected areas and cities throughout the world; housing policies, urban planning approaches, financial, administrative, legal, and other techniques.

title: PLUS 631 Seminar in Physical Planning and Design in Developing Countries
description: Issues in comparative urbanism; planning and design in developing countries: slums and squatters, housing and infrastructure, new towns, land policy, conservation and redevelopment, city design.

title: PLUS 632 National Urban Policy in Developing Countries
description: The problems of the primate city, the role of intermediate cities, and the implicit spatial impacts of macro and sectoral policies.

title: PLUS 626 Information Systems for Planning and Development
description: Structure, content, and applications of formal information systems in planning and policy making emphasizing social accounts and indicators, censuses, social reporting, and "futures" research.

title: PLUS 615 Behavioral Issues in Environmental Design
description: Planning and design of the physical environment for human activities, e.g., user preferences, privacy, territoriality, stress and adaptation, cognitive mapping, lifestyles.

title: PLUS 623 Politics of Planning and the Urban Environment
description: Historic roots of property rights and obligations related to public policy, focus on current issues and discourse.

title: PLUS 612 Analysis of Quantitative Data for Planning and Development
description: Planning and development case study approach to identifying data needs, acquisition, evaluation, manipulation, analysis, and multimedia presentation.

title: PLUS 603 Planning and Development Paradigms
description: Introduction to historic, prevalent, and alternative paradigms of professional planning and development practice; seminar format and case studies.

title: PLUS 600 Environmental Goods in Planning and Development
description: Production, distribution, and valuation of environmental goods with attention to amenity concepts, externalities, public goods, consumer behavior; as characterized in economics, political science, sociology, psychology.

title: PJMT 555 Project Management Capstone
description: Utilize skills gained throughout the program to demonstrate the ability to plan and implement a project from conception to conclusion.

title: PJMT 550 Portfolio Management
description: Structured approach to design, build, and manage a project portfolio, focusing on strategic implementation and operational initiatives to create sustainable value.

title: PJMT 545 Program Management
description: Managing and coordinating multiple organizational projects with a focus on project alignment, organizational goals, performance maximization, risk minimization, and program success.

title: PLUS 601 Advanced Planning Theory I
description: Value hierarchies, means-ends continuums, and the nature of social action; problems of prediction and choice under conditions of uncertainty; alternative planning strategies.

title: PJMT 540 Organizational Change Management and Business Relationships
description: Students learn to cultivate the necessary components for stakeholder management on nearly any change within an organization through change management and business relationship management.

title: PJMT 535 Specialized Project Management
description: Explores several industries and entities and their developed project management methodologies to meet industry-specific needs through traditional approaches and partnerships in various sectors.

title: PJMT 530 Quality and Process Improvement
description: Quality and performance improvement projects and methodologies used to implement them with a focus on Six Sigma, Lean, and Total Quality Management.

title: PJMT 525 Agile Project Management Methodologies
description: Agile project management concepts and a set of frameworks that covers the people, products, and techniques required to successfully implement projects.

title: PJMT 520 Risk Management
description: Coursework will enable students to prepare a comprehensive risk management plan and discover different approaches to identify, assess, and quantify risks and their impacts.

title: PJMT 515 Cost Estimation and Forecasting
description: Approaches to project cost estimation and the tools and methodologies best suited for estimates and forecasts that need to be prepared.

title: PJMT 510 Schedule Management
description: Structured approach to project schedule management, demonstrating how to be proactive and in control of projects by implementing effective schedule management.

title: PJMT 505 Requirements Elicitation and Business Analysis
description: Tasks, techniques, and perspectives on how to approach business analysis along with methods for developing requirement process tools and techniques and best practices.

title: PJMT 500 Principles of Project Management
description: Concepts including delivering project scope within cost, schedule, and resource constraints and the exploration of the traditional or waterfall project management methodology will be explored.

title: PHYS 794z Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: PHYS 794d Doctoral Dissertation
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture, Lab

title: PHYS 794c Doctoral Dissertation
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture, Lab

title: PHYS 794b Doctoral Dissertation
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture, Lab

title: PHYS 794a Doctoral Dissertation
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture, Lab

title: PHYS 790 Research
description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

title: PHYS 750o Off Campus Studies
description: Course work taken on campus at Caltech as part of the Caltech- USC cross-registration program.

title: PHYS 740 Selected Topics in Condensed Matter Physics
description: Course content will vary yearly with current interest. Topics covered may include theory of superconductivity, high temperature superconductivity, Green's functions in condensed matter physics, magnetism and transport in disordered metals.

title: PHYS 720 Selected Topics in Theoretical Physics
description: Course content will vary yearly with current interest. Topics covered may include field theory, many body theory, Green's functions, dispersion theory, and group theory.

title: PHYS 730 Selected Topics in Particle Physics
description: Various advanced phases of particle physics. Content will vary yearly; emphasis on superstring theories, advanced topics in quantum gravity, and field theory.

title: PHYS 710 Selected Topics in Experimental Physics
description: Course content will vary yearly with current interest. Topics covered may include superconducting quantum interference devices, scanning tunneling microscopy, and laser cooling and trapping of single atoms.

title: PHYS 692 Internship
description: Field application of physics in a business or industry setting; part-time employment. Project to be jointly defined by student, employer and professor.

title: PHYS 690 Introduction to Physical Biology
description: Introduces students to the role of physics in biology. Considers both experimental and more fundamental points of view. Explores a few current research directions.

title: PHYS 684 Advanced String Theory
description: Advanced string theory. Strong coupling and nonperturbative techniques. D-branes, black holes, duality, AdS/CFT. Applications in particle, nuclear and condensed matter physics, and quantum gravity.

title: PHYS 682 Supersymmetric Field Theory
description: Supersymmetry algebra, Coleman-Mandula theorem, N=1 and N=2 Yang-Mills theory, Seiberg duality, holomorphy, introduction to Seiberg-Witten theory, electromagnetic duality, BPS states.

title: PHYS 680 Advanced Quantum Field Theory
description: Renormalization, quantization of gauge theories, non-Abelian gauge theories, quantum chromodynamics, spontaneous symmetry breaking, the standard model, anomalies.

title: PHYS 678 Relativistic Quantum Field Theory
description: Computational methods in relativistic quantum field theory: Feynman path integral, covariant perturbation theory, regularization, renormalization group, and non-perturbative techniques.

title: PHYS 669a Group Theory and Symmetries in Physics
description: Abstract group theory; representation theory; point groups; selection rules; crystal tensors; molecular vibrations; rotation group; SU(2); Wigner-Eckart theorem; crystal-field splitting; time-reversal symmetry; gauge invariance; SU(3) and quarks.

title: PHYS 669b Group Theory and Symmetries in Physics
description: Application of group theory in field theory and particle physics: Lie groups and representations, Young tableaux, Dynkin diagrams, Poincare group, classical groups and supergroups, gauge theories.

title: PHYS 670 High Energy Physics
description: Elementary particles and the fundamental forces acting on them. Quarks, leptons, symmetries, gauge invariance, spontaneously broken symmetry, electroweak theory, quantum chromodynamics grand unified theory, strings.

title: PHYS 668 Advanced Quantum Mechanics
description: Relativistic wave equations; second quantization of Klein-Gordon, Dirac and Maxwell fields; applications in quantum electrodynamics and condensed matter physics.

title: PHYS 650 Topics in Current Research
description: Course content will vary each year. It will include topics of current interest in research conducted in academia and industry.

title: PHYS 660 Quantum Information Science and Many-Body Physics
description: Introduction to advanced techniques in theoretical many-body physics based on quantum information theory.

title: PHYS 640 Advanced Condensed Matter Physics
description: Magnetism, magnons; superconductivity; transport phenomena; many-body effects; interacting electron gas; Hartree-Fock theory; neutron and X-ray scattering; and other selected topics.

title: PHYS 596 Internship for Curricular Practical Training
description: Part-time or full-time, practical work experience in the student's field of study. The internship must be located at an off-campus facility. Students are individually supervised by faculty. May not be taken until the student has completed at least one semester of enrollment in the graduate program with a cumulative 3.0 GPA.

title: PHYS 630 Science of Nanoscale Materials
description: Fundamental physics of low dimensional systems, with an emphasis on nanoscale materials (e.g. nanodot, nanowire, graphene) and state-of-the-art research topics, including characterization of nanostructure materials, and device concepts that take the advantage of low dimensionality.

title: PHYS 594b Master's Thesis
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture, Lab

title: PHYS 594a Master's Thesis
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture, Lab

title: PHYS 593 Practicum in Teaching Physics and Astronomy
description: Practical principles for the long-term development of effective teaching within the physical sciences. Intended for teaching assistants in Dornsife College.

title: PHYS 594z Master's Thesis
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: PHYS 590 Directed Research
description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

title: PHYS 558b Quantum Mechanics
description: Approximation schemes and applications to atomic and molecular physics and scattering theory; identical particles; electromagnetic properties of atoms.

title: PHYS 558a Quantum Mechanics
description: General formulation of quantum mechanics with applications; theory of measurement; exactly solvable problems; angular momentum formalism.

title: PHYS 540 Solid State Physics
description: Fundamental concepts and techniques in solid state physics; electron gas at metallic densities; semiclassical transport; crystallography; band structure; phonons; screening; superconductivity; magnetic ordering.

title: PHYS 530 Relativity
description: Fundamentals of the special theory and applications to classical and quantum physics; the principle of equivalence; tensor analysis and Einstein's theory of gravitation; relativistic cosmology.

title: PHYS 520 Methods for Complex Systems
description: Probabilities, random walks, generalized central limit theorems, probabilities in thermodynamics, critical phenomena, self organized criticality, phenomenology of catastrophies, dynamical systems and examples from outside physics.

title: PHIL 460 Metaphysics
description: Systematic introduction to basic concepts, including identity, difference, existence, individuals, substance, quality, and relation; emphasis on idealism, materialism, and the ontology of intentionality.

title: PHYS 518 Thermodynamics and Statistical Mechanics
description: Principles of, and relations between, thermodynamics and statistical mechanics; ensembles, partition function formalism; quantum statistics of noninteracting particles; fluctuations.

title: PHIL 455 Phenomenology and Existentialism
description: Close study of major writings of Husserl, Heidegger, and Sartre.

title: PHIL 450 Intermediate Symbolic Logic
description: Systematic study of the metatheory of quantificational logic, with applications to questions of decidability and completeness of formal systems including Godel's Incompleteness Theorems.

title: PHIL 452 Modal Logic
description: Elements of propositional and quantified modal logic and the logic of counterfactual conditionals with an eye to some of their applications in contemporary philosophy.

title: PHIL 446 Aesthetics and the Film
description: Problems in the philosophy of art raised by film, such as the notion of "cinematic"; the nature of interpretation of films; criteria for evaluating films.

title: PHIL 445 Philosophy of the Arts
description: Principal theories of the nature of, and response to, art; examination of form and content in various arts; consideration of the role of criticism.

title: PHIL 443 Value Theory
description: The evaluation of individual and social ends; consideration of such topics as values and rational choice, the good of a person, hedonism, welfare, ideals, and utopias.

title: PHIL 442 History of Ethics to 1900
description: An historical and critical study of the great moral philosophers, including Plato, Aristotle, Aquinas, Kant, and the British moralists.

title: PHIL 440 Contemporary Ethical Theory
description: Ethical theories in the 20th century; contemporary theories of value and obligation; metaethical theories; intuitionism, naturalism, and non-cognitivism; concepts of justice, human rights, and freedom.

title: PHIL 437 Social and Political Philosophy
description: The nature of man and society, the nature and justification of state and government, political rights and political obligation, justice and equality.

title: PHIL 431 Law, Society, and Politics
description: A systematic presentation of the main philosophical perspectives on the interactions between law and the social-political aspects of our lives.

title: PHIL 430 Philosophy of Law
description: Philosophical theories about the nature of law, relations between law and morality, and analysis of normative concepts central to law, such as responsibility, punishment, negligence.

title: PHIL 428 Anglo-American Philosophy Since 1950
description: The maturing of the analytic tradition from the later Wittgenstein through Ryle, Strawson, Hare, Austin, Grice, Quine, Davidson, Kripke, and beyond.

title: PHIL 427 20th Century Anglo-American Philosophy
description: The nature and function of analysis as a philosophical method; the development of major metaphysical, epistemological, and ethical views; Russell, Wittgenstein, Carnap, Quine and others.

title: PHIL 426 20th Century European Philosophy
description: Main philosophers and movements from 1900, including the major developments within phenomenology and existentialism, the emergence of structuralism and hermeneutics.

title: PHIL 425 American Philosophy
description: Leading figures and movements in American philosophy; works of such philosophers as Jonathan Edwards, Charles Peirce, William James, John Dewey, and C.I. Lewis.

title: PHIL 424 19th Century Philosophy
description: Leading figures and movements in 19th century philosophy; works of such philosophers as Hegel, Schopenhauer, Mill, Nietzsche, and Bradley.

title: PHIL 423 The Critical Philosophy of Kant
description: Intensive study of the philosophical works of Kant.

title: PHIL 422 British Empiricism
description: Development of philosophy in Great Britain from the 17th to the 19th centuries; emphasis on Locke, Berkeley, and Hume.

title: PHIL 421 Continental Rationalism
description: Development of philosophy on the continent from the 17th to the 19th centuries; emphasis on the philosophical works of Descartes, Leibniz, and Spinoza.

title: PHIL 415 Aristotle
description: Intensive study of selected topics taken from Aristotle's writings in natural philosophy, in metaphysics, and in other areas of philosophy.

title: PHIL 411 Plato
description: Detailed study of the evolution of Plato's thought as revealed in selected dialogues.

title: PHIL 410 Early Greek Thought
description: A study of the Greek thinkers from Homer to the age of Socrates; emphasis on the pre-Socratic philosophers.

title: PHIL 390 Special Problems
description: Supervised, individual studies. No more than one registration permitted. Enrollment by petition only.

title: PHIL 363 Philosophy of Perception
description: Philosophical investigation of sense perception as it relates to issues in epistemology, metaphysics, the philosophy of mind, and the philosophy of science.

title: PHIL 385 Science and Rationality
description: Examination of the rationality of the scientific enterprise, and of the relation between science and human values.

title: PHIL 362 Possible Worlds
description: Introduction to possible worlds as a tool for asking and answering questions about what might be, what must be, and what can never be.

title: PHIL 361 Philosophy of Religion
description: The existence of God; mysticism, miracles and the possibility of disembodied existence; the problem of evil; religion and morality; the meaning of religious language.

title: PHIL 360 Epistemology and Metaphysics
description: Examination of problems in metaphysics and/or epistemology. Conducted at the intermediate level.

title: PHIL 352 Logic and Language
description: Introduction to modern symbolic logic, with applications to the philosophy of language, plus meta-logical and philosophical results about its scope and limits.

title: PHIL 355 Existentialism
description: A critical survey of major 19th and 20th century existentialist writers, including Kierkegaard, Dostoevsky, Tolstoy, Kafka, Nietzsche, Camus, and Sartre.

title: PHIL 351 Reasoning and Logic
description: Study of reasoning as a strategy for arriving at knowledge in dependence upon logical theory. Logical theories are developed alongside historically influential strategies of reasoning. Not open to freshmen.

title: PHIL 350 Symbolic Logic
description: Introduction to basic techniques of propositional and quantificational logic, and elements of probability. Especially useful to philosophy, mathematics, science, and engineering majors.

title: PHIL 347 Philosophy in Literature
description: Philosophical content in representative European and American literature; philosophical problems about literature such as the nature of truth and meaning in fiction.

title: PHIL 340 Ethics
description: Study of major philosophical theories of moral right and wrong, such as utilitarianism, Kantianism, egoism, virtue ethics, and theological ethics.

title: PHIL 345 Greek Ethics
description: Examination of the progress of the ethical thought and legal and political institutions of ancient Greece with an emphasis on the Nichomachean Ethics of Aristotle.

title: PHIL 337 History of Modern Political Philosophy
description: Analysis of some of the main political philosophies of the modern era; emphasis on the ethical and metaphysical foundations of political philosophy.

title: PHIL 335 Theoretical Models of Leadership
description: Political philosophers and social theorists on leadership: political obligation; the art of government; leadership in civil society and counter-cultural dissent; models of cosmopolitan leadership.

title: PHIL 330 Theories of Law
description: Examination of some of the major classical and contemporary theories of the nature and functions of law and of its relation to morality.

title: PHIL 320 History of Western Philosophy: Modern Period
description: The development of philosophy from the 16th to the 19th centuries; emphasis on Continental Rationalism, British Empiricism, and the philosophy of Kant.

title: PHIL 315 History of Western Philosophy: Ancient Period
description: Major figures in the history of Western philosophical thought from the pre-Socratics to the Hellenistic period; emphasis on Plato and Aristotle.

title: PHIL 317 History of Western Philosophy: Medieval Period
description: Central themes in Jewish, Christian and Islamic philosophy from late antiquity through the scholastic period.

title: PHIL 300 Introduction to the Philosophical Classics
description: An examination of philosophical works which have had a profound impact on the nature of Western thought.

title: PHIL 288gp Love and its Representation in Western Literature, Film, and Philosophy
description: Key works that have shaped the European and American cultural inheritance, with a special focus on the nature of love.

title: PHIL 286Lg Issues in Space and Time
description: Examining the nature of space and time, how they relate, and how material objects relate to them. Some included topics: substantivalism, temporal directionality, persistence, hyperspace.

title: PHIL 285Lg Knowledge, Explanation, and the Cosmos
description: The nature and limits of knowledge and explanation, and challenges in understanding the origin of the universe and the place of intelligent life within it.

title: PHIL 284gp Ideas on Trial
description: Historically significant trials, from the trial of Socrates to the present day, understood as vehicles for the expression of deep social and cultural attitudes.

title: PHIL 262g Mind and Self: Modern Conceptions
description: Philosophical problems about the nature of mind associated with the rise of modern science; topics include the mind/body relation, personal identity, rationality and freedom.

title: PHIL 258g Probability and Rational Choice
description: Explores formal tools for thinking about uncertainty. In an uncertain world, how is it rational to form our beliefs, make decisions, and interact with others?

title: PHIL 260gw Ethical Theory and Practice
description: Explores various conceptions of morality and what makes actions right or wrong, together with the implications of these views for concrete ethical issues.

title: PHIL 256g Science, Religion, and the Making of the Modern Mind
description: Exploration of the philosophical and religious implications of major scientific revolutions, such as those of Copernicus, Galileo, and Darwin.

title: PHIL 255p Existentialism in Philosophy, Literature and Film
description: A study of existentialist philosophy and its influence in 19th and 20th century culture, including both literature and film. Focus on works by Kierkegaard, Nietzsche, Camus, Sartre, Beauvoir, Dostoevsky, Godard, and others.

title: PHIL 246Lg Foundations of Cognitive Science
description: Introduction to research in interdisciplinary cognitive science, highlighting ideas and methods from philosophy, psychology, linguistics, neuroscience, and computer science.

title: PHIL 254gp Science, Knowledge and Objectivity
description: How does science differ from pseudo-science? When is it rational to accept a scientific theory? And do such theories provide genuine knowledge of reality?

title: PHIL 242 Theories of Art
description: An introduction to general theories of art and to issues concerning particular arts such as literature and drama, photography and film, painting, architecture and music.

title: PHIL 338 Political Economy and Social Issues
description: Contending politico-economic perspectives in modern Western thought and culture; absolutist, liberal, democratic, Marxist, anarchist, and other traditions, topics and issues.

title: PHIL 236g Issues in Space and Time
description: What is time?  What is the difference between past, present and future?  Is time-travel possible?  And what paradoxes might it give rise to?

title: PHIL 240g Mind, Self, and Consciousness
description: Explores philosophical questions about the human mind and consciousness, and how they relate to the brain and to the physical world more generally.

title: PHIL 222g Logic and Language
description: Introduces symbolic logic and explores its application to the philosophy of language, plus meta-logical and philosophical results about its scope and limits.

title: PHIL 178gw Moral Dilemmas in the Legal Domain
description: Philosophical theories of law and applications to controversies of importance to society and our legal system, such as free speech, civil disobedience, and self defense.

title: PHIL 174gw Freedom, Equality, and Social Justice
description: Explores the nature of justice, and how apparently conflicting ideals, such as freedom and equality, are to be balanced within a just society.

title: PHIL 172gmw Social Ethics for Earthlings and Others
description: A systematic study of contemporary issues in social and political philosophy engaging multimedia works of science fiction to illuminate classic Western moral and political theories.

title: PHIL 166gw Current Moral and Social Issues
description: Critical study of controversial social issues such as abortion, euthanasia, the death penalty, war and terrorism, sexual morality, affirmative action, and economic justice.

title: PHIL 168g The Meaning of Life
description: Explores philosophical treatments of the problem of the meaning or purpose of human life.

title: PHIL 141gp The Professions and the Public Interest in American Life
description: The study of the nature and role of professionals in life and society, forces that shape and direct them, foundations and applications of professional ethics.

title: PHIL 130g The Physical World and Our Place In It
description: Exploration of basic questions about the nature of reality. Topics may include personal identity, freedom and determinism, causation and laws of nature.

title: PHIL 138g Introduction to the Philosophy of Religion
description: Explores arguments for and against the existence of God, as well as questions about the nature and rationality of faith.

title: PHIL 122bg Reasoning and Argument
description: Techniques for constructing good arguments and for assessing and criticizing the arguments of others.

title: PHIL 122ag Reasoning and Argument
description: Techniques for constructing good arguments and for assessing and criticizing the arguments of others.

title: PHIL 120g Introduction to Formal Logic
description: Introduces formal tools for distinguishing between good and bad arguments or inferences. Covers both propositional logic and predicate logic.

title: PHIL 115g Ancient Greek Culture and Society
description: Focus on the literary achievement from the beginning of Greek literature to the fourth century with a special emphasis on the philosophers.

title: PHIL 110g Modern Foundations of Western Thought
description: Explores the writings of philosophers, from Descartes to Kant, who responded to, and helped to shape, the scientific and political upheavals of the modern period.

title: PHIL 104g Ancient Foundations of Western Thought
description: Explores writings of ancient philosophers who first raised, and continue to influence our thinking about, fundamental questions concerning nature, knowledge, justice, happiness, and death.

title: PHIL 102gp Historical Introduction to Philosophy
description: Introduction to the central philosophical works that have shaped western thought. Includes ancient, early modern and contemporary writings.

title: PHIL 100g Central Problems of Philosophy
description: Explores questions about human beings and their place in nature, including questions about knowledge, mind and body, freedom and determinism, and the existence of God.

title: PHED 165 Varsity Athletics
description: Participation in the university's inter-collegiate programs as sanctioned and governed by the PAC-10 Conference and/or the NCAA.

title: PHED 163 Health Coaching
description: Skills and strategies of coaching principles promoting healthy lifestyle change. Motivational communication techniques; goal setting; designing safe, effective exercise program; health coach certification exam preparation.

title: PHED 162 Principles of Athletic Coaching
description: Introduction to coaching strategies; team management; philosophy; ethics; leadership. Methodologies in sport specific training; skill progression; conditioning; athlete motivation; budgeting; fundraising.

title: PHED 161 First Aid
description: First Aid safety education and infant, child, and adult CPR; demonstrated proficiency and successful completion of exam prepares students for Red Cross certification.

title: PHED 160 Stress Management for Healthy Living
description: Instruction on the effects of stress as it relates to work, sport and academics; coping strategies are discussed and applied through physical conditioning interventions.

title: PHED 156b Basketball
description: Development of advanced skills; team strategy; offenses and zone defenses; drills and full court games.

title: PHED 156a Basketball
description: Basic skill development in dribbling, passing, shooting, rebounding and defense; rules, history, and etiquette; drills and full court games.

title: PHED 155b Golf
description: Development and reinforcement of swing mechanics, shot selection, etiquette and rules; application of course strategies on golf course and driving range.

title: PHED 154b Soccer
description: Advanced development of skills, positioning, tactics and conditioning.

title: PHED 155a Golf
description: Basic skills development and knowledge in stance, grip and swing mechanics; course strategy; use of woods, irons and putting; history rules and etiquette.

title: PHED 154a Soccer
description: Development of basic skills for beginners, intermediate and advanced players; rules, positioning elements of play, small group and team tactics; full field scrimmages.

title: PHED 153 Futsal
description: Fundamental instruction of skills and tactics specific to Futsal; rules; strategies; elements of play that differ from soccer; conditioning, drills, and games.

title: PHED 150 Table Tennis
description: Fundamental instruction of basic strokes for beginning and intermediate players; rules, scoring strategies; singles and doubles; practices and match play.

title: PHED 145 Handball
description: Instruction and practice of serving, ceiling shots, lobs, three wall shots and passing; rules, offensive and defensive strategies; sport specific conditioning; fundamental drills and games.

title: PHED 143b Racquetball
description: Development of advanced skills and strategies; singles and doubles practice and competition.

title: PHED 143a Racquetball
description: Instruction of basic stroke technique for beginners and intermediate players; rules, scoring, game tactics; practice of strokes and competition.

title: PHED 140c Tennis
description: Development of strokes and strategies for advanced tournament players; drills and matches.

title: PHED 140b Tennis
description: Reinforcement of basic strokes and instruction of advanced strokes; advanced strategies; singles and doubles; practice and match play.

title: PHED 140a Tennis
description: Fundamental instruction of basic strokes for beginners and intermediate players; rules, scoring, court etiquette, strategies; singles and doubles; practice and match play.

title: PHED 139b Volleyball
description: Advanced techniques; focus on offenses and defenses used in game situations.

title: PHED 139a Volleyball
description: Introduction to beginning and intermediate volleyball skills, rules, game tactics, and strategies. Emphasis on the development of: passing, setting, hitting, serving, blocking, and digging.

title: PHED 135 Backpacking
description: Acquisition of backpacking knowledge and skills; conditioning plan; nutrition and equipment selection; ethics and environmental considerations; navigation, safety and wilderness first aid; trip planning.

title: PHED 134 Hiking
description: Introduction to hiking; specific conditioning to develop muscle strength and endurance; equipment; various terrain, weather conditions, safety; environmental impact and trail etiquette.

title: PHED 138 Beach Volleyball
description: Fundamental instruction of skills and tactics specific to sand volleyball and related physical conditioning; rules and strategies; history and culture.

title: PHED 133 Rock Climbing
description: Acquisition of basic rock climbing skills, muscle strength, endurance and balance, climbing safety, ethics and environmental considerations; understanding equipment, problem solving.

title: PM 611 Advanced Topics in Epidemiology
description: Review of current epidemiologic research contained in recent medical literature; emphasis on critique of studies and interpretation of findings.

title: PM 610 Seminar in Biostatistics and Epidemiology
description: Special topics of current interest to provide background for research in biostatistics and epidemiology. Based largely on student dissertation research.

title: PM 605 Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis
description: Theoretical basis and practical approaches for identifying, summarizing and interpreting current bodies of scholarly information addressing a defined research question.

title: PM 604 Health Behavior Research Methods
description: Health research/evaluation philosophies, approaches, and development of skills for development and critique of health behavior research projects/studies.

title: PM 603 Structural Equation Modeling
description: Factor analytic and structural equation modeling approaches to health behavior research — conceptual, practical and mathematical.

title: PM 602 Basic Theory and Strategies for Compliance/Adaptation
description: Behavioral and psychosocial demands of acute and chronic diseases. Comparison of theoretical models of compliance and adaptation with intervention methods to improve compliance and adaptation.

title: PM 599 Special Topics
description: Special topics relevant to the study of selected issues and areas of health behavior research or other aspects of preventive medicine.

title: PM 597 Capstone in Public Health
description: Provides the culminating, integrative learning experience for students enrolled in the Master of Public Health program.

title: PM 601 Basic Theory and Strategies in Prevention
description: Psychosocial basis of healthhazardous lifestyle behaviors and preventive strategies.

title: PM 594b Master's Thesis
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: PM 594z Master's Thesis
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: PM 595 Internship for Curricular Practical Training
description: Part-time or full-time, practical work experience in the student's field of study. The internship must be located at an off-campus facility. Students are individually supervised by faculty.

title: PM 594a Master's Thesis
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: PM 593 Public Health Practicum
description: Field placement in a community agency, such as a county health department or community-based organization.

title: PM 596 Practicum in Public Health
description: Applied practical experience through field placement in federal, state, and/or local public health agencies/organizations, including community-based organizations; research and school-based settings.

title: PM 591 Machine Learning for the Health Sciences
description: Introduces Masters and Ph.D. students in the Health Sciences to Machine Learning methods and their Biomedical applications.

title: PM 590 Directed Research
description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

title: PM 589 Global Health Governance and Diplomacy in Practice in Geneva (World Health Assembly)
description: Investigates the way health is organized and administered at the global level by integrating students directly into the World Health Assembly (WHA), the decision-making body of the World Health Organization.

title: PM 587 Qualitative Research Methods in Public Health
description: Introduction to common uses of qualitative research methods in public health research and application. Methods include ethnography, participant observation, open-ended interviewing, and focus groups.

title: PM 586 Reproductive and Perinatal Epidemiology
description: Introduction to reproductive health, from preconception to the neonatal and early period of human development. Heavy emphasis on the methods and public health implications.

title: PM 588 The Practice of Epidemiology
description: Provides students with hands on experience of the common methods used in conducting epidemiological studies, and designing and obtaining funding for research projects.

title: PM 585 Child Health Policy
description: History of child health and social welfare programs during the past century. Issues examining health status and health service delivery, the role of health care financing and health policy.

title: PM 583 Foundations of Early Childhood Mental Health
description: Overview of major infant and early childhood mental health issues, relating to the status of child mental health and the importance of comprehensive systems of care for children that support resilience and respond to biological and psychosocial mental health risks.

title: PM 584 Systems of Care for Children with Special Needs
description: Examines and evaluates principles, policies, programs and practices (systems) that have evolved to identify, assess and meet the special needs of children and families. Includes both historical and current perspectives.

title: PM 582 Epidemiology and Prevention of Pediatric Injuries
description: Examines the incidence and causes of injuries to children from birth to adolescence, risk factor distributions and approaches to prevention.

title: PM 581 Quality and Inequality in Health Care: Examination of Health Services
description: Social inequalities, including racial/ethnic disparities and income related inequalities are examined in the context of access and delivery of health care in the U.S.

title: PM 580 Foundations of Child Health
description: Overview of issues related to infant, child and adolescent health, including special health considerations at different points in the developmental cycle, health care systems and policies and health disparities.

title: PM 578 Global Health Governance and Diplomacy
description: Investigates the way health is organized and administered at the global level, emphasizing the role of international diplomacy and law in governing health.

title: PM 579 Statistical Analysis of High-Dimensional Data
description: Overview of statistical issues and solutions to high dimensional data analysis. Use of Bioconductor and R, with applications in molecular biology.

title: PM 577 Global Health, Law and Human Rights
description: Highlights the complex interactions between global health, law and human rights, emphasizing the use of human rights in public health thinking and practice.

title: PM 576 Global Health Research and Programs
description: Introduction to the core concepts and methods of planning and implementing health-related programs and research in resource-constrained settings.

title: PM 574 Programming In Modern Statistical Software
description: Programming using SAS Software, including branching, sub-setting, PDV, looping, by-group processing, array, combining data functions, ODS, and macros.

title: PM 575 Statistical Methods in Environmental Epidemiology
description: Study designs, exposure time response, longitudinal, spatial, ecologic correlation and mechanistic models, measurement error interactions, measurement error, public policy implications.

title: PM 570 Statistical Methods in Human Genetics
description: An introductory course in the statistical methods used in the analysis of human genetic data.

title: PM 571 Applied Logistic Regression
description: An introduction to the logistic regression model, emphasizing practical data analysis techniques.

title: PM 569 Spatial Statistics
description: An introduction to statistical methods for analyzing and interpreting spatially referenced data topics include: geostatistics, areal data, point pattern data and visualization.

title: PM 567 Public Health Disaster Management and Response
description: Definition and chronology of natural and man-made disasters and their effects on the global community. Structure and organization of disaster management systems and the role of humanitarian organizations.

title: PM 565 Introduction to Global Health
description: Current public health issues and research topics relating to 21st century challenges and threats. Lessons learned and best practices to strengthen public health systems and enhance public health readiness and preparedness.

title: PM 568 Ethical Issues in Public Health
description: Ethical principles in the distribution of health resources, conduct of global public health research, and implementation of public health initiatives across different nations, cultures, religions.

title: PM 564 Public Health Leadership and Management
description: Introduction to leadership and management concepts, tools, and practices in the context of domestic and global public health and healthcare delivery settings.

title: PM 563 Organizing and Mobilizing Communities for Public Health
description: Survey of effective community organizing and mobilization efforts in the U.S. and abroad, using participatory, organizational, community empowerment and public-private partnership models.

title: PM 562 Intervention Approaches for Health Promotion and Disease Prevention
description: Approaches for modifying health behavior in various settings and within diverse populations. Emphasis on practical considerations necessary to design and implement interventions with demonstrated effectiveness.

title: PM 561 Promoting Dietary Change
description: Development, implementation, and evaluation of dietary interventions at community and individual levels. Discussion of lifespan, culture, socioeconomic, and environmental factors.

title: PM 560 Statistical Programming With R
description: The contents include: R objects, control structure, data input and output, subsetting objects, data manipulation and aggregations, character manipulation, graphics, and writing user-defined functions.

title: PM 558 Environmental Epidemiology: Concepts, Methods, and Practice
description: Examine epidemiologic methods, concepts, and statistical approaches; case-study seminars with structured critiques of current literature on human-environment interactions affecting public health.

title: PM 557 Global Environmental Health
description: Examination of the health effects of global environmental changes, including climate change, globalization, food safety, air pollution, water pollution, and radiation.

title: PM 556 Environment and the Brain
description: An examination of the effects of environmental exposures on the brain, addressing both human health and neurobiologic correlates throughout the lifespan.

title: PM 554 Health Effects of Environmental Contaminants
description: Examines the interrelationships among biology, the environment and health, including the fundamental principles of basic toxicology and biology underlying environmental health effects.

title: PM 555 Environmental Health, Policy and Practice
description: Examination of environmental public health policies/regulations, the role of science in assessment and policy initiatives, barriers to change, and competing interests that influence policy adoption.

title: PM 553 Human Exposure Assessment for Public Health
description: Examination of important routes of exposure to toxic materials; how to measure exposure; strengths and weaknesses of different measurement techniques; design of exposure assessment studies.

title: PM 552 Statistical Methods in Clinical Trials
description: Stochastic failure process; parametric models for survival data; sample size estimation procedures for clinical trials; multivariate regression models for binary outcome and censored survival data; computer programs; multiple failure modes and competing risks.

title: PM 551 Statistical Methods in Genome-Wide Association Studies
description: Provides epidemiologists with an overview of current statistical problems and approaches in the design and analysis of genome-wide association studies.

title: PM 547 Public Health Policy and Politics
description: Examination of major policy issues in the U.S. health care delivery system to understand policy options in reforming health care and reducing health care disparities.

title: PM 548 Prevention and Public Policy
description: Introduction to prevention policy framework; examination of how the application of epidemiology and behavioral aspects of diseases shapes the development of public health policy.

title: PM 546 Biological Threats and Terrorism
description: History of biowarfare and bioterrorism; proper surveillance techniques, capacity building for public health and medical communities, and the importance of effective communications. Methods of preparedness, prevention and response are examined.

title: PM 544L Multivariate Analysis
description: Exploratory and inferential techniques for multivariate data, Hotelling's T2, multivariate analysis of variance, classification analysis, principle components, cluster analysis, factor analysis. Involves computer use.

title: PM 542 Social Network Analysis
description: Theory, methods and procedures of network analysis with emphasis on applications to public health programs.

title: PM 541 Obesity, Metabolism and Health
description: Overview of the epidemiology of obesity, related health conditions and mechanisms related to energy balance, food intake and genetics. Discussion of prevention and treatment strategies.

title: PM 540 Maternal and Child Nutrition: Practice and Policy
description: Physiological basis for good nutrition during pregnancy and childhood through adolescence. Design, implementation and evaluation of public health nutrition programs and policies serving women and children.

title: PM 539 Nutrient-Drug Interactions
description: Examines the various ways foods, and the nutrients contained in them, interact with medications used to treat chronic health conditions.

title: PM 538 Introduction to Biomedical Informatics
description: Overview of current topics, enabling technologies, research initiatives, and practical considerations in biomedical informatics.

title: PM 536 Program Evaluation and Research
description: Overview of concepts, tools, data collection, analysis methods and designs used to evaluate health promotion programs. Examples from substance abuse prevention, family planning and reproductive health programs.

title: PM 537 Chronic Disease Epidemiology
description: Overview of causative factors and demographic distribution of major chronic diseases in the western world. Epidemiologic concepts, methods and research design as applied to chronic disease prevention will be emphasized.

title: PM 535 Nutrition in Public Health
description: Principles related to developing effective programs and services to improve the health and nutrition within a community. Attaining and maintaining nutritional health related to biology, lifestyle choices, environments, and health care delivery systems.

title: PM 534 Statistical Genetics
description: Familial aggregation, segregation analysis, linkage analysis, association, regressive models, gene-environment interactions, genetic heterogeneity and linkage disequilibrium.

title: PM 550 Sample Surveys
description: Theory of sampling and design of sample surveys; bias and precision; finite populations; stratification; cluster sampling; multistage, systematic sampling; non-sampling errors.

title: PM 533 Genetic and Molecular Epidemiology
description: Genetic principles; design and analysis of family studies; introduction to likelihood estimation; segregation and linkage analysis; biomarkers of exposure, susceptibility, and disease; laboratory methods; susceptibility genes; association and linkage disequilibrium.

title: PM 532 Genetics in Public Health and Preventive Medicine
description: History and philosophy of public health genetics and mechanisms of genetic diseases. Epidemiologic methods used to identify genetic diseases in individuals, families, and populations. Emphasis on prevention and relevant ethical issues.

title: PM 531 Research Methods in Nutrition
description: In-depth discussion of nutrition research including nutrition assessment, measurement of dietary intake, study design, statistical issues, critical appraisal, and translation into practice.

title: PM 530 Biological Basis of Disease
description: With a physiological overview, differentiates genetic and environmental disease; emphasis on the relationships between lifestyle, behavior, and health.

title: PM 529 Environmental Health: An Epidemiological Approach
description: An overview of environmental health, identifying issues in assessing effects of exposure on health and potential interventions for reducing adverse health risks.

title: PM 545L Introduction to Time Series
description: Transfer function models; stationary, nonstationary processes; moving average, autoregressive models; spectral analysis; estimation of mean, autocorrelation, spectrum; seasonal time series.

title: PM 528 Program Design and Evaluation
description: Core concepts, methods and values of public health program planning and evaluation, including community needs assessment, writing objectives, designing health promotion programs, process and outcome evaluation.

title: PM 543L Nonparametric Statistics
description: Distribution-free methods for comparisons of two or more samples, tests of randomness, independence, goodness of fit; classification, regression. Comparison with parametric techniques.

title: PM 526 Communications in Public Health
description: Application of communication theories and methods to community health problems. Includes background assessment, program design, evaluation, social marketing, media advocacy, review of major health campaigns.

title: PM 525 Culture and Health: Global Perspectives
description: International variations in health status with a focus on the impact of socioeconomic status, politics, environment, education and gender in etiology of illness, access to health care, progression of disease, and recovery.

title: PM 527 Epidemiology of Infectious Disease
description: Survey of natural history of infectious disease, methods of disease control and outbreak investigation, and an overview of the epidemiology of injury.

title: PM 524c Practicum in Health Behavior
description: Practical experience in a variety of field settings to gain a certain type of skill such as curriculum development, media production, and patient education. Practicum in health behavior topics.

title: PM 524a Practicum in Health Behavior
description: Practical experience in a variety of field settings to gain a certain type of skill such as curriculum development, media production, and patient education. Practicum in prevention.

title: PM 524b Practicum in Health Behavior
description: Practical experience in a variety of field settings to gain a certain type of skill such as curriculum development, media production, and patient education. Practicum in compliance.

title: PM 522b Introduction to the Theory of Statistics
description: Theory of estimation and testing, inference, analysis of variance, theory of regression.

title: PM 523 Design of Clinical Studies
description: Design, conduct, and interpretation of results of clinical trials; emphasis on principles affecting structure, size, duration of a trial, and the impact of ethical and practical considerations.

title: PM 522a Introduction to the Theory of Statistics
description: Density distribution and hazard functions; normal, chi-square, student's t and F distributions; and sampling procedures for single factor and multiple factor designs, distributions.

title: PM 521a Seminar in Nutrition
description: Duplicates Credit in former PHNU 520ab.

title: PM 521b Seminar in Nutrition
description: Duplicates Credit in former PHNU 520ab.

title: PM 520L Advanced Statistical Computing
description: Techniques for the solution of statistical problems through intensive computing; iterative techniques, randomization tests, the bootstrap, Monte Carlo methods..

title: PM 519 Introduction to Human Nutrition
description: Dietary role of carbohydrates, proteins, lipids, vitamins, and minerals in metabolism; nutritional assessment; nutritional deficiencies. Focus on the role of nutrition in the prevention and treatment of chronic disease.

title: PM 518b Statistical Methods for Epidemiological Studies I, II
description: Statistical methods for binary outcomes by introducing techniques for cross classified risks and rates and regression models for individual data.

title: PM 518a Statistical Methods for Epidemiological Studies I, II
description: Principles and methods used in epidemiology for comparing disease frequencies between groups. Restricted to the analysis of binary outcome variables.

title: PM 517b Research Methods in Epidemiology
description: Overview of epidemiologic research in cancer. Selected cancer sites will be covered to highlight study design and conduct, exposure assessment, data analysis and interpretation.

title: PM 517a Research Methods in Epidemiology
description: Study design, ascertainment of study objects, questionnaire development, various methodological issues in data analysis and interpretation including bias, measurement error, confounding and effect modification.

title: PM 516b Statistical Problem Solving
description: An overview of the tools used by statisticians for solving statistical problems.

title: PM 516a Statistical Problem Solving
description: An overview of the tools used by statisticians for solving statistical problems.

title: PM 515 Multivariate Statistics in Health Behavior Research
description: Advanced training in multivariate statistical techniques involving general linear modeling, mixed modeling and basic latent variables analysis in health behavior research

title: PM 514 Sexually Transmitted Infections: a Systems Approach
description: Exploration of the interplay between systems, policy, advocacy, programs, and research with sexually transmitted infections. Issues such as health literacy, access to care, and evidence-based interventions designed to avert disparities in health, especially sexual health, will be evaluated.

title: PHRD 624 Community Pharmacy Practice
description: Exploration of the pharmacy profession and the practice of community pharmacy. Includes didactic instruction and Community Pharmacy Practice Experiences (IPPEs).

title: PHRD 623 Case Conference 5
description: Registration Restriction: Open only to Doctor of Pharmacy students

title: PHRD 622 Case Conference 4
description: Registration Restriction: Open only to Doctor of Pharmacy students.

title: PHRD 621 Pharmacy Practice and Professionalism 6
description: A seminar series covering leadership, professionalism and professional development for pharmacy practice. Includes practical experience placements (IPPE).

title: PHRD 620 Pharmacy Practice and Professionalism 5
description: A seminar series covering leadership, professionalism and professional development for pharmacy practice. Includes practical experience placements (IPPE).

title: PHRD 616 Pharmacy, Law and Ethics
description: To provide students with an understanding of ethical issues that arise in pharmacy practice along with state and federal statutes, regulations, and pharmacy-related cases.

title: PHRD 619 Therapeutics: Cardiovascular System
description: Integration of biomedicinal chemistry, pharmacology, pharmacokinetics, and therapeutics with emphasis on pharmaceuticals affecting cardiovascular and circulatory diseases.

title: PHRD 614 Pharmaceutical Economics and Outcome Studies
description: Economic analysis of the U.S. health care system, the pharmaceutical industry, and the profession; economic assessment of drug therapy costs and health care outcomes applying pharmacoeconomic research methodologies.

title: PHRD 612 Therapeutics XI
description: Updates students on recent advances in clinical areas, prepares students for advanced practice experiences and assessment of clinical readiness via a final examination.

title: PHRD 610 Therapeutics: Special Populations
description: Focuses on the pharmacology, pharmacokinetics, medicinal chemistry and clinical therapeutics that apply to pharmaceutical care of pediatric, geriatric and chronic pain patients.

title: PHRD 611 Therapeutics: Infectious Diseases
description: Integration of biomedicinal chemistry, pharmacology, pharmacokinetics, and therapeutics, with emphasis on the therapy of infectious diseases caused by bacterial, viral, parasitic, and fungal organisms.

title: PHRD 608 Therapeutics: Oncology
description: Integrated teaching of biomedicinal chemistry, pharmacology, clinical pharmacokinetics and therapeutics of drugs, with emphasis on pharmaceuticals for managing oncological diseases.

title: PHRD 607 Nutrition
description: Biomedical knowledge is correlated with assessments of clinical case management problems to understand the interrelationship between nutrition and health in both hospitalized and healthy patients.

title: PHRD 606 Therapeutics VIII
description: Advanced topics and clinical therapeutics of drugs, with emphasis on the treatment of infectious disease: bacterial, microbial, viral, parasitic and fungal.

title: PHRD 605 Therapeutics VII
description: Integrated teaching of the biomedicinal chemistry, pharmacology, clinical pharmacokinetics, and therapeutics of drugs; with emphasis on chemotherapy of infectious disease: bacterial, microbial, viral, parasitic, and fungal.

title: PHRD 603 Therapeutics: Endocrine System
description: Integration of biomedicinal chemistry, pharmacology, pharmacokinetics, and therapeutics with emphasis on the endocrine and reproductive system.

title: PHRD 601 Therapeutics V
description: Integrated teaching of biomedicinal chemistry, pharmacology, clinical pharmacokinetics, and therapeutics of drugs, with emphasis on pharmaceuticals affecting cardiovascular and circulatory diseases. CPR certification.

title: PHRD 599 Special Topics
description: Registration Restriction: Open only to graduate students in the School of Pharmacy

title: PHRD 570 Therapeutics: Central Nervous System
description: Integration of biomedicinal chemistry, pharmacology, pharmacokinetics, and therapeutics with emphasis on the central nervous system.

title: PHRD 572 Therapeutics: General Medicine and Inflammatory Disorders
description: Integrated approach to the management of common renal, liver, pulmonary, gastrointestinal, joint and integumental related disorders, as well as inflammatory disorders.

title: PHRD 568 Principles and Leadership in Community Health 1
description: Introduction to public health and the development of community health programs. Topics include health education, health communication, and behavioral determinants of health and disease.

title: PHRD 569 Principles and Leadership in Community Health 2
description: Builds upon students' knowledge of the field of public health and community health programs to evaluate the efficacy of community-based interventions.

title: PHRD 566 Pharmacy Practice and Professionalism 4
description: A seminar series covering leadership, professionalism and professional development for pharmacy practice. Includes practical experience placements (IPPE).

title: PHRD 567 Pharmacy Law
description: Provide an introduction to the legal and ethical issues in pharmacy practice. Includes state and federal statutes, regulations, and pharmacy-related cases.

title: PHRD 565 Pharmacy Practice and Professionalism 3
description: A seminar series covering leadership, professionalism and professional development for pharmacy practice. Includes practical experience placements (IPPE).

title: PHRD 564 Case Conference 2
description: Registration Restriction: Open only to Doctor of Pharmacy students

title: PHRD 563 Case Conference 1
description: Registration Restriction: Open only to Doctor of Pharmacy students

title: PHRD 562 Therapeutics IV
description: Integrated teaching of biomedicinal chemistry, pharmacology, clinical pharmacokinetics, and therapeutics of drugs with an emphasis on treating diseases of the renal, GI and pulmonary systems.

title: PHRD 561 Pharmacy Practice and Experience III
description: Introductory Pharmacy Practice Experiences (IPPEs) in hospital and community settings. Includes; didactic instruction, laboratory practicums, IV training and practical experience hours.

title: PHRD 560 Therapeutics III
description: Integrated teaching of biomedicinal chemistry, pharmacology, clinical pharmacokinetics, and therapeutics of drugs, with emphasis on pharmaceuticals treating diseases associated with the central nervous system.

title: PHRD 559 Therapeutics: Pharmacokinetics
description: Integrated teaching of basic and clinical pharmacokinetic/pharmacodynamic concepts.

title: PHRD 556 Pharmacy Education 2
description: Registration Restriction: Open only to Doctor of Pharmacy students

title: PHRD 554 Public Health and Epidemiology
description: Introduction to epidemiology, environmental health, health education, health care organizations and financing. Orientation to social and governmental controls on the health care system.

title: PHRD 555 Pharmacy Education 1
description: Understanding and application of learning theory and teaching methodology, small group teaching, active learning, student motivation, basic assessment methods, and general online teaching tools.

title: PHRD 553 Management within Health Care Organizations
description: Management of the professional practice of pharmacy in organized health care systems. Introduction to formulary development and outcome analysis.

title: PHRD 552 Pharmaceutics III
description: Principles and applications of controlled, targeted, and self-regulating drug delivery. Methods to deliver therapeutic peptides, proteins and genetic materials.

title: PHRD 551 Immunology
description: Basic principles of immunology and their application to the understanding and treatment of immunologically-mediated diseases. Provides the scientific basis of immunotherapy and immunodiagnosis.

title: PHRD 520 Pharmacists' Patient Care Process
description: Ensure competency in the Pharmacists' Patient Care Process (PPCP), which is universally used to provide care to individuals by pharmacists in the health care system.

title: PHRD 521 Medicinal Chemistry
description: Principles of medicinal chemistry for common drugs. Mechanism of action,  interactions with protein targets, structure-activity relationships, effects of chirality, and physicochemical properties.

title: PHRD 517 Pharmacogenetics
description: Principles of gene expression and the influence of genetics on the effectiveness of drug therapy.

title: PHRD 515 Metabolism and Cell Biology
description: Basic principles of drug action and receptor actions. Includes their application to the understanding and treatment of disease. Provides the scientific basis of pharmaceutical action.

title: PHRD 516 Non-Prescription Therapies
description: Introduction to self-care health. Includes OTC products, dosages, pharmacology, efficacy, cost, side effects, adverse reactions, contraindications, and drug interactions.

title: PHRD 514 Calculations and Compounding
description: Knowledge and experience in pharmacy calculations, compounding, and sterile IV compounding.

title: PHRD 512 Pharmacy Practice and Professionalism 2
description: A seminar series covering leadership, professionalism and professional development for pharmacy practice. Includes practical experience placements (IPPE).

title: PHRD 511 Pharmacy Practice and Profesionalism 1
description: A seminar series covering leadership, professionalism and professional development for pharmacy practice. Includes practical experience placements (IPPE).

title: PHRD 508 Pharmacy Literature Analysis and Drug Information
description: Literature evaluation and biostatistics of clinical and health services research, and drug information services. Emphasis on drug therapy, patient outcomes, and formulary development.

title: PHRD 507 Health Care Delivery Systems
description: Introduction to understanding the structure of the health care system. Includes health care financing and the role of pharmacy and the pharmacist in health systems.

title: PHRD 504 Biological Systems II
description: Integration and application to pharmacy of anatomy, histology, physiology and pathophysiology using an organ-based approach.

title: PHRD 503 Biological Systems I
description: Integration and application to pharmacy of anatomy, histology, physiology and pathophysiology using an organ-based approach.

title: PHRD 501 Pharmaceutics I
description: Introduction to physicochemical principles of dosage forms; properties of molecules in dosage forms, stability of pharmaceuticals, absorption, and metabolism.

title: PHRD 502 Pharmaceutics II
description: Principles involved in molecules movement across biological barriers. Properties, characteristics, application of homogeneous and heterogeneous dosage forms, liquid, semi-solid and solid.

description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: PHIL 700x Dissertation Seminar
description: A focused environment in which to present and evaluate dissertation work-in-progress. Focus on peer and faculty feedback, developing professional presentation skills, improving critical communication skills.

title: PHIL 790 Research
description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

title: PHIL 599 Special Topics
description: Major trends of current thought; specific topics to be announced.

title: PHIL 594z Master's Thesis
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: PHIL 594b Master's Thesis
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit
