description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: PHIL 590 Directed Research
description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

title: PHIL 593x Teaching Philosophy
description: Basic principles of philosophical pedagogy, with emphasis on practical applications and the importance of career-long skill development. Required for first-semester teaching assistants in philosophy.

title: PHIL 585 Seminar in Philosophy of Science
description: Advanced topics in the philosophy of science.

title: PHIL 589 Writing for Publication in Philosophy
description: Intensive writing seminar in which students read cutting-edge philosophy and take supervised steps towards crafting critical essays for publication.

title: PHIL 570 Seminar in Epistemology
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: PHIL 565 Philosophy of Language
description: Philosophical issues in the empirical study of language concerning the relationship between linguistic meaning and the use of sentences to assert and convey information.

title: PHIL 562 Philosophy of Mind
description: Contemporary approaches to a variety of questions about the nature of mental states and our knowledge of them.

title: PHIL 584 Seminar in the Philosophy of Physics
description: Selected topics in various specialty areas within the philosophy of physics.

title: PHIL 560 Seminar in Metaphysics
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: PHIL 551 Seminar in the Philosophy of Logic
description: Advanced topics in logic and/or philosophy of logic.

title: PHIL 550 Advanced Topics in Formal Logic
description: Consistency and completeness of the predicate calculus; truth and validity; rudiments of model logic.

title: PHIL 545 Seminar in Aesthetics
description: Advanced topics in the philosophy of the arts. Contemporary views on such problems as the nature of art and the role of criticism.

title: PHIL 636 Seminar in Semantics
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: PHIL 540 Seminar in Ethics
description: Advanced topics and literature in ethical theory.

title: PHIL 537 Seminar in Social and Political Philosophy
description: Advanced literature on selected topics in social and political philosophy, including the nature of law, man, and society; ideals such as justice and freedom.

title: PHIL 530 Seminar in Philosophy of Law
description: Theories of the nature of law; emphasis on recent writing; legal concepts such as rights, powers, liability, legal responsibility, law, and morality.

title: PHIL 525 Seminar in Phenomenology
description: The origin, principles, and development of the phenomenological movement from Brentano to Merleau-Ponty.

title: PHIL 520 Studies in Modern Philosophy
description: Problems in research in selected portions of modern philosophy.

title: PHIL 515 Studies in Ancient and Medieval Philosophy
description: Problems in research in selected portions of ancient and medieval philosophy.

title: PHIL 510 Philosophical Logic
description: Applications of logical theory to contemporary philosophical research. Elements of model theory, recursion theory; Goedel's Incompleteness results; modal logic and its interpretations.

title: PHIL 501 Seminar in Recent Philosophy
description: Contemporary philosophical issues and literature.

title: PHIL 503 Introduction to Contemporary Philosophical Literature on Value
description: Analysis of selected philosophical problems and theses of current interest; explication of major contemporary papers and/or books is emphasized.

title: PHIL 505 Pro-Seminar in Central Topics in Contemporary Philosophy
description: Key developments in central areas of philosophy are used to provide training in philosophical analysis, criticism, and the writing of precise philosophical prose.

title: PHIL 499 Special Topics
description: Selected topics in various specialty areas within philosophy.

title: PHIL 500 Introduction to Contemporary Philosophical Literature
description: Analysis of selected philosophical problems and theses of current interest; explication of major contemporary papers and/or books is emphasized.

title: PHIL 494 Senior Thesis
description: Independent studies for philosophy majors, and guidance in the preparation of the senior thesis for students who wish to graduate with honors in philosophy.

title: PHIL 490x Directed Research
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: PHIL 486 Methodologies of the Sciences
description: Comparison of the methodologies of the natural, social, and/or behavioral sciences; consideration of such topics as the concept of scientific law, prediction, explanation, confirmation.

title: PHIL 485 Development of Physical Science
description: Concepts central in the advance of physical science such as the concepts of space, time, mass, force; philosophical problems concerning quantum mechanics.

title: PHIL 480 Philosophy of Mathematics
description: The nature of mathematical truth and the nature of mathematical entities.

title: PHIL 484 Philosophy of Physics
description: A comprehensive introduction to two of the central areas of modern philosophy of physics: the philosophy of spacetime, and the philosophy of quantum mechanics.

title: PHIL 473 Wittgenstein
description: A detailed study of the philosophical works of Ludwig Wittgenstein.

title: PHIL 472 Moral Philosophy
description: In-depth study of some important work from the last few decades concerning the nature and status of moral reasons, moral obligations, and moral discourse.

title: PHIL 470 Theory of Knowledge
description: Examination of contemporary accounts of the nature, scope, sources — and value — of human knowledge and justified belief.

title: PHIL 471 Metaphysics and Epistemology
description: Classic issues in epistemology and the philosophy of language, leading up to the application of context-sensitivity in language to the problem of skepticism.

title: PHIL 465 Philosophy of Language
description: The nature of communication, meaning, reference, truth, necessity, speech acts, convention, and language.

title: POIR 648 International Human Rights Law and Policy
description: Historical and contemporary consideration of human rights issues in world politics. Examination of philosophical foundations of human rights and institutions that enforce international standards. MA and other students outside of POIR must obtain faculty permission to register for the course.

title: PHIL 463 Theories of Action
description: Systematic investigation of action, the mental states involved in action, the reasoning processes that lead to action, and related concepts including intentionality and free will.

title: POIR 641 Comparative Judicial Policies, Processes, and Behavior
description: Cross-national and intranational comparative analysis of judicial policies, institutions, and processes; legal and judicial elites. MA and other students outside of POIR must obtain faculty permission to register for the course.

title: POIR 642 Institutions in Comparative and International Politics
description: Explores major strands of institutional theory and assesses scholars' views on design of institutions, institutional change, and effects of institutions on behavior and outcomes.

title: POIR 640 Comparative Politics
description: Survey of literature; examination of approaches, concepts, and issues in the field of comparative politics.

title: POIR 636 Seminar in African Politics
description: Comparative and international politics of Africa. Analysis of ideologies, political behavior, and institutions in African nations. MA and other students outside of POIR must obtain faculty permission to register for the course.

title: POIR 637 Chinese Politics
description: Governmental process in the People's Republic of China including leadership, ideology, political institutions, behavior, and participation. MA and other students outside of POIR must obtain faculty permission to register for the course.

title: POIR 633 East Asian Politics
description: Comparative politics of East Asia; modernization; the roots of political thought and behavior; peripheral area relationships; modern political processes and institutions. MA and other students outside of POIR must obtain faculty permission to register for the course.

title: POIR 632 Latin American Politics
description: Comparative analysis of the political structure and institutions of Latin America; participation and alienation; democracies and dictatorships; political science and comparative politics. MA and other students outside of POIR must obtain faculty permission to register for the course.

title: POIR 630 European Politics
description: Selected research topics in comparative European politics; political behavior, parties, legislative and executive institutions and processes. MA and other students outside of POIR must obtain faculty permission to register for the course.

title: POIR 627 Urban Politics
description: Problems of government and politics in urban, county, and metropolitan areas. Local and community politics. MA and other students outside of POIR must obtain faculty permission to register for the course.

title: POIR 625 Political Parties
description: Parties and organizations in the political system; formal and informal organization and roles; party systems; partisanship; and electoral rules. MA and other students outside of POIR must obtain faculty permission to register for the course.

title: POIR 626 Executive and Legislative Institutions
description: Theory and empirical analysis as it relates to the study of political institutions. Legislative politics, executive branch politics, and legislative-executive relations and bargaining. MA and other students outside of POIR must obtain faculty permission to register for the course.

title: POIR 624 American Constitutional Law and Theory
description: Contemporary debates and research on the nature of constitutional interpretation, separation of powers, federalism, civil and political rights and liberties. MA and other students outside of POIR must obtain faculty permission to register for the course.

title: POIR 623 Public Law
description: Problems and research in American constitutional and administrative law and in modern jurisprudence. MA and other students outside of POIR must obtain faculty permission to register for the course.

title: POIR 622 Political Attitudes and Behavior
description: Determinants, nature, and consequences of political attitudes and behavior exploring psychological-sociological models, political socialization and learning, and factors affecting trends in attitudes and behavior. MA and other students outside of POIR must obtain faculty permission to register for the course.

title: POIR 621 American Politics Field Seminar Part II
description: A theoretical and empirical overview of the American politics field. Theoretical topics include behavioralism, rational choice, political psychology; empirical topics include causality.

title: POIR 620 American Politics and Policy Processes
description: Survey of literature; examination of approaches, concepts, and issues in the field of American politics and policy processes.

title: POIR 619 Supreme Court Politics
description: Role of the Supreme Court in American political institutions. Influences on judicial decision making; appointment and decision making processes; scope of judicial power. MA and other students outside of POIR must obtain faculty permission to register for the course.

title: POIR 617 Maximum Likelihood Estimation
description: Maximum likelihood estimation of binary choice models, duration models, count models, and other models in political science, international relations, and social sciences. MA and other students outside of POIR must obtain faculty permission to register for the course.

title: POIR 618 Problems of American Politics
description: Theoretical and methodological problems in American politics with emphasis on emerging research paradigms. MA and other students outside of POIR must obtain faculty permission to register for the course.

title: POIR 614 Experimental Political Science
description: Introduction to experimental techniques and applications of experiments in political science. Addresses both the advantages and disadvantages of experiments in political science research.

title: POIR 610 Research Design
description: The course will cover the design of experimental and observational research. We will examine both quantitative and qualitative approaches to social science research.

title: POIR 600 Political Theory
description: Survey of literature; examination of approaches, concepts, and issues in the field of political theory.

title: POIR 615 Formal Models of Politics
description: Introduces basics of game theory and surveys foundational models of American, comparative, and international politics.

title: POIR 599 Special Topics
description: Subjects in one or more fields in political science.

title: POIR 593 Practicum in Teaching Politics and International Relations
description: Practical principles for the long-term development of effective teaching within political science and international relations disciplines. Intended for teaching assistants in Dornsife College.

title: POIR 590 Directed Research
description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

title: POIR 581 International Relations of the Middle East
description: Examination of salient issues in regional politics such as colonialism, nationalism, identity, religion, development and war. MA and other students outside of POIR must obtain faculty permission to register for the course.

title: POIR 561 Japanese Foreign Policy and International Relations of East and Southeast Asia
description: Research problems in political, economic, and security issues in East and Southeast Asia, with special emphasis on the role of Japan. MA and other students outside of POIR must obtain faculty permission to register for the course.

title: POIR 563 Chinese Foreign Policy
description: Research problems in political, economic, military, and ideological issues. MA and other students outside of POIR must obtain faculty permission to register for the course.

title: POIR 613 Topics in Quantitative Analysis
description: Introduces statistical models beyond the standard linear regression model. Topics include maximum likelihood estimation, generalized linear models, and advanced methods.

title: POIR 557 Africa and U.S. Foreign Policy
description: Research problems on international issues arising from the emergence of Africa. MA and other students outside of POIR must obtain faculty permission to register for the course.

title: POIR 555 Democracy and Democratization in Comparative Perspective
description: Seminar generates and tests theories of democratization. Readings will focus on Europe, Latin America, Soviet Eurasia emphasizing core theoretical and methodological aspects. MA and other students outside of POIR must obtain faculty permission to register for the course.

title: POIR 556 Latin America and U.S. Foreign Policy
description: Latin American challenges to U.S. policymakers; U.S. success in achieving its goals; alternative explanations of U.S. behavior. MA and other students outside of POIR must obtain faculty permission to register for the course.

title: POIR 551 International Political Economy of the Pacific Rim
description: Political economy of the Pacific Rim; trade, investment and development strategies. The role of Japan's increasing economic power and that of the changing U.S.–Japan relations and their implications to the rest of the Pacific Rim region. MA and other students outside of POIR must obtain faculty permission to register for the course.

title: POIR 550 Economic Bargaining Theory and Practice
description: Development of analytical skills and strategies for negotiations over economic and political problems, through study of recent cases, bilateral bargaining, and multilateral bargaining. MA and other students outside of POIR must obtain faculty permission to register for the course.

title: POIR 548 The International Political Economy of Development
description: The political aspects of economic growth, efficiency and distribution are explored for underdeveloped nations in a political science and international relations context. MA and other students outside of POIR must obtain faculty permission to register for the course.

title: POIR 611 Introduction to Regression Analysis
description: The course will introduce students to regression analysis and its application to social science research.

title: POIR 545 Critical Issues in Politics and Policy
description: Selected topics in political science and policy; focus on current issues shaping the U.S. and the world. MA and other students outside of POIR must obtain faculty permission to register for the course.

title: POIR 546 Environmental Policy
description: Issues and theories involved in the formulation, implementation, and effectiveness of different environmental policies. MA and other students outside of POIR must obtain faculty permission to register for the course.

title: POIR 547 Political Economy of Global Space and Environment
description: Regimes in an anarchic world will be examined, particularly global spaces and resources in political economy. MA and other students outside of POIR must obtain faculty permission to register for the course.

title: POIR 612 Qualitative Research Design
description: Design multiple research approaches using qualitative evidence to evaluate the observable implications of theory. Learn deductive, construct, internal, external, and conclusion validity.

title: POIR 544 Religion, Politics, and Conflict
description: How religion has emerged as a powerful force in politics. Conflict resolution, fundamentalism, terrorism, war, American foreign policy and global civil society. MA and other students outside of POIR must obtain faculty permission to register for the course.

title: POIR 540 Law and Public Policy
description: The study of law in political science; law and politics in organized societies; law as a policy science; legal and political institutions; administration of justice; political forces influencing legal change. MA and other students outside of POIR must obtain faculty permission to register for the course.

title: POIR 543 Politics of International Monetary and Trade Relations
description: Political analysis of international monetary and trade relations; emphasis on interactions among industrialized nations.

title: POIR 539 Conflict Processes
description: Seminar in international conflict, crisis and war. General perspectives on factors that bring about war or peace. Focus on ethnopolitics and conflict processes. MA and other students outside of POIR must obtain faculty permission to register for the course.

title: POIR 541 Politics of the World Economy
description: Survey of approaches to international political economy. Intellectual roots; the management of collective goods; North-South relations are examined. MA and other students outside of POIR must obtain faculty permission to register for the course.

title: POIR 534 East Asian Security Issues
description: Security politics of China, Japan, ASEAN states, and Southwest Pacific nations; their strategic relations with the superpowers; regional security initiatives: nuclear-free zone politics, ZOPFAN, and indigenous military capacities. MA and other students outside of POIR must obtain faculty permission to register for the course.

title: POIR 535 North African and Middle Eastern Politics
description: The politics of the Middle East and North Africa (MENA) including nation-building; mobilization of human and natural resources; political recruitment, integration, socialization, and conflict. MA and other students outside of POIR must obtain faculty permission to register for the course.

title: POIR 531 Strategy and Arms Control
description: Impact of nuclear weapons on U.S. and U.S.S.R. postwar military policies and strategies; evolution of postwar deterrence postures; development of superpower arms control since 1945. MA and other students outside of POIR must obtain faculty permission to register for the course.

title: POIR 525 State and Society in International Relations
description: Assesses the challenges to nation-states and world order presented by trans-border cultural flows, new technologies, and changing patterns of political participation. MA and other students outside of POIR must obtain faculty permission to register for the course.

title: POIR 521 Foreign Policy Analysis
description: Survey of principal theoretical and empirical approaches to foreign policy analysis; such as bureaucratic politics, game theory, formal theory, rational choice theory, and other topics. MA and other students outside of POIR must obtain faculty permission to register for the course.

title: POIR 526 Migration and Diaspora in International Politics
description: Examines issues of migration, the relationship between citizen and state, economic factors triggering emigration/immigration, transnationalism, and explores the phenomenon of diasporas. MA and other students outside of POIR must obtain faculty permission to register for the course.

title: POIR 542 Foreign Economic Policies of Industrial Capitalist States
description: Seminar comparing the political economy and economic policies of countries; evaluation of alternative research methods and theories.

title: POIR 520 Formulating US Foreign Policy: How Washington Works
description: Analyzes U.S. foreign policy, with emphasis on numerous inputs to the decision-making process, from media to conceptions of the national interest to organizational processes. MA and other students outside of POIR must obtain faculty permission to register for the course.

title: POIR 519 Field Research Methods in Political Science and International Relations
description: Methods of social science field research in political science and international relations. MA and other students outside of POIR must obtain faculty permission to register for the course.

title: POIR 518 Historical Memory and Public Diplomacy
description: Analyzes national identity formation and justification of foreign policy goals, particularly its impact on international relations. MA and other students outside of POIR must obtain faculty permission to register for the course.

title: POIR 516 Advanced Research Methods: Text, Talk and Context
description: Text and discourse analysis methods and strategies. Themes include the roles of ideas, identities, policies and interests in various institutional contexts. MA and other students outside of POIR must obtain faculty permission to register for the course.

title: POIR 517 International Policy Analysis
description: Game theory and other methodologies applied to the study of international relations. Topics include global and regional public goods, collective action, externalities, treaty information, market failures. MA and other students outside of POIR must obtain faculty permission to register for the course.

title: POIR 510 Gender, War and Peace
description: Examination of the extent to which conflict and its resolution have depended on stereotypically gendered associations of men with war and women with peace. MA and other students outside of POIR must obtain faculty permission to register for the course.

title: PMEP 794z Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: POIR 509 Culture, Gender, and Global Society
description: Cultural and gendered responses to economic globalization; topics include culture and security, identity politics, clashes of and accommodations among civilizations, modernity, post-modernity and world society. MA and other students outside of POIR must obtain faculty permission to register in the course.

title: PMEP 794d Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: PMEP 794c Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: PMEP 794b Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: PMEP 790 Research
description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

title: PMEP 794a Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: PMEP 698 Seminar in Pharmaceutical Economics and Policy
description: Current research in pharmaceutical economics and policy presented by outside scholars, faculty and students.

title: PMEP 596 Internship for Curricular Practical Training
description: Part-time or full-time, practical work experience in the student's field of study. The internship must be located at an off-campus facility. Students are individually supervised by faculty. May not be taken until the student has completed at least one semester of enrollment in the graduate program with a cumulative 3.0 GPA.

title: PMEP 590 Directed Research
description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

title: PMEP 551 Introduction to Health Econometrics
description: Introduction to statistical analysis and regression modeling for health economics and policy research. Topics include: statistical inference, principles of probability and statistics, regression models, and causal inference.

title: PMEP 552 Advanced Health Econometrics I
description: The expansion of students' knowledge of econometric methods emphasizing, but not limited to, applications to health economics. Serves as a prelude to the advanced study of microeconomics.

title: PMEP 553 Advanced Health Econometrics II
description: Covers the transition to independent producers of high-quality empirical research on health and health care. Peer-reviewed research will serve as case studies for class discussion and may address empirical methods.

title: PMEP 547 Programming Methods for Empirical Analysis of Health Data
description: Introduction to methods for analysis of large health data sets, including data selection, SAS/Stata programming under Linux, and review of claims and survey data.

title: PMEP 539 Economic Assessment of Medical Care
description: Principles of cost-benefit analysis and medical cost-effectiveness analysis with applications in medical care and the pharmaceutical field.

title: PMEP 544 Health Economics II
description: Second of part series in techniques of microeconometric analysis to inform health policy. Topics include: patents and innovation, pharmaceutical regulation, hospital competition, physician practice.

title: PMEP 535 Behavioral Science and Policy in Healthcare
description: Use of acquired skills to develop and assess uses of behavioral science to affect health policy.

title: PMEP 526 Pharmacoeconomics II
description: Continued development of the use of the economic evaluation model, and application of the methods and techniques of economic assessment of pharmaceuticals and other medical technology.

title: PMEP 527 Pharmacoeconomics III
description: Advanced methods in economic health intervention assessment and pharmacoeconomics with special emphasis on microeconomic modeling and methods for assessing patient and health state preferences.

title: PMEP 525 Pharmacoeconomics I
description: Introduction to pharmacoeconomics with special emphasis on the role of pharmaceuticals and the pharmaceutical industry, insurance, managed care, regulation and pricing.

title: PM 794z Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: PMEP 509 Research Design
description: Introduction to the concept of research design and examples of the variant research methods utilized in the field. Both the conceptual and practical issues of research including development of the research question, selection of appropriate methods, data sources and analytic approaches to address the research question will be addressed.

Covers the structure of NIH and other grantmaking agencies, the grant review process, tailoring ideas to the grantmaker's priorities, research design, development of training and mentoring plans, and budgeting.

title: PM 612c Clinical Translational Research (CTR)
description: Multidisciplinary approach to clinical and translational research.

title: PHYS 514 Methods of Experimental Physics
description: Techniques of general utility in contemporary physics research, with emphasis on the use of commercially available instrumentation.

title: PHYS 510 Methods of Theoretical Physics
description: Vector analysis; infinite, asymptotic Fourier series; complete sets; Dirac delta function; Fourier, Laplace transforms; Legendre functions; spherical harmonics; Sturm-Liouville theory; orthogonal polynomials; gamma-factorial function; complex variables.

title: PHYS 508b Advanced Electricity and Magnetism
description: Maxwell's equations, potentials and gauge transformations; electromagnetic waves; wave guides; electromagnetic radiation; special relativity.

title: PHYS 508a Advanced Electricity and Magnetism

title: PHYS 504 Advanced Mechanics
description: Newtonian formulation of dynamics; Hamilton's principle; Lagrangian formulation; rigid body motion; Hamiltonian formulation; Hamilton-Jacobi theory; vibrations.

title: PHYS 502 Advanced Optics
description: Interaction of light and matter; laser oscillation condition; optical resonators; spectroscopy; pumping mechanisms; characteristics of dielectric, semiconductor, gas, and liquid lasers; topics in nonlinear optics.

title: PHYS 500 Graduate Colloquium
description: Topics of current research interest in physics and astronomy. Lectures directed to physics graduate students by faculty of the department and by outside speakers.

title: PHYS 499 Special Topics
description: Lectures and discussions on specialized topics in physics.

title: PHYS 490x Directed Research
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: PHYS 495 Senior Project
description: An original project will be constructed applying computer technology (in either hardware or software) to produce a result useful in the physics classroom or laboratory.

title: PHYS 492L Senior Lab
description: Projects will include experiments in mechanics, thermodynamics, electricity and magnetism. Emphasis on laboratory work with discussion of theoretical background.

title: PHYS 493L Advanced Experimental Techniques
description: Development of modern experimental techniques, including computer interface with data acquisition hardware and data analysis by software, applied specifically to experiments in modern physics. Emphasis on laboratory work with discussion of theoretical background.

title: PHYS 440 Introduction to Condensed Matter Physics
description: Crystal structures, x-ray diffraction, thermal properties of solids, diamagnetism and paramagnetism, free-electron model of metals, semiconductors, ferromagnetism, super-conductivity, imperfections in crystals.

title: PHYS 438a Introduction to Quantum Mechanics and its Applications
description: Concepts and techniques of quantum mechanics; free and bound states, the hydrogen atom.

title: PHYS 430 General Relativity and Gravitation

title: PHYS 444 Physical Biology: From Molecules to Cells
description: Length, time, and energy scales of life; statistical mechanics of biomolecules and cellular processes; physics of cell shape; biological fluid dynamics; electron transfer and metabolism.

title: PHYS 438b Introduction to Quantum Mechanics and its Applications
description: Relativity, atomic spectra, quantum statistics, nuclear models, nuclear reactions, elementary particles.

title: PHYS 390 Special Problems
description: Supervised, individual studies. No more than one registration permitted. Enrollment by petition only.

title: PHYS 408b Electricity and Magnetism
description: Electromagnetic induction; AC circuits; Maxwell's equations.

title: PHYS 408a Electricity and Magnetism
description: Electrostatics; thermal, chemical, magnetic effects of steady currents; DC circuits.

title: PHYS 316 Thermodynamics and Statistical Mechanics
description: First, second, and third thermodynamic laws; thermodynamic potentials, applications; distribution laws, kinetic theory, transport phenomena, specific heats.

title: PHYS 304 Mechanics
description: Dynamics of particles, kinematics of rotations, rigid body motion, Lagrangian and Hamiltonian formalism, theory of small vibrations.

title: PHYS 200Lgx The Physics and Technology of Energy
description: Investigation of energy technologies, including development and implementation issues. Topics include the industrial revolution, electromagnetic induction, power transmission, combustion engines, fission and fusion.

title: PHYS 190 Physics Discovery Series

title: PHYS 173L Applied Physics III: Topics in Modern Physics

title: PHYS 172L Applied Physics II: Electricity, Magnetism and Optics
description: Electric and magnetic fields; electromagnetic waves; optics. Emphasizes applications in the areas of applied physics and engineering.

title: PHYS 473L Lasers and Optics Laboratory
description: Introductory design/research laboratory in lasers and optics, which typically includes fiber optics, photonics, electro-optics, optical sensors, optical communication, optical signal processing and computing.

title: PHYS 171Lg Applied Physics I: Mechanics
description: Mechanics, mechanical vibrations and waves, special relativity. Emphasizes applications in the areas of applied physics and engineering.

title: PHYS 163L Advanced Principles of Physics III

title: PHYS 472 Introduction to Lasers and Laser Systems
description: Electric dipole transitions; traveling wave and resonant amplifiers; laser pumping and rate equations; threshold, frequency, and power output of lasers; holography; laser communication systems.

title: PHYS 161Lg Advanced Principles of Physics I
description: Gateway to the majors and minors in Physics and Astronomy. Introductory treatment intended for well-qualified students. Dynamics of particles and rigid bodies, conservation laws, wave motion, thermodynamics, heat engines, entropy.

title: PHYS 153L Fundamentals of Physics III: Optics and Modern Physics
description: Geometrical optics, interference, diffraction, special relativity, quantum mechanics, atomic physics, solid state physics.

title: PHYS 162L Advanced Principles of Physics II
description: Electrostatics, magnetostatics, electrical circuits, electric and magnetic properties of matter, Maxwell's equations, electromagnetic waves, propagation of light.

title: PHYS 143L Special Laboratory III
description: for transfer students with equivalent lecture credit from another institution. For transfer students immediately after matriculation.

title: PHYS 152L Fundamentals of Physics II: Electricity and Magnetism
description: Electrostatics, magnetostatics, electrical circuits, wave motion, sound waves, electromagnetic waves.

title: PHYS 151Lg Fundamentals of Physics I: Mechanics and Thermodynamics
description: Gateway to the majors and minors in Physics and Astronomy. Statics and dynamics of particles and rigid bodies, conservation principles, gravitation, simple harmonic oscillators, thermodynamics, heat engines, entropy.

title: PHYS 142L Special Laboratory II
description: for transfer students with equivalent lecture credit from another institution. For transfer students immediately after matriculation.

title: PHYS 141L Special Laboratory I
description: for transfer students with equivalent lecture credit from another institution. For transfer students immediately after matriculation.

title: PHYS 100Lgx The Physical World
description: The fundamentals of physics presented with emphasis on the structure and beauty of physical laws. Practical component will relate these laws to commonly encountered events.

title: PHYS 125Lg Physics for Architects
description: Fundamental laws and principles of physics with emphasis on the application of physical principles to the problems of architecture.

title: PHTS 790 Research
description: Registration Restriction: Open only to students enrolled in the PHTS umbrella PhD program during their first year

title: PHTS 654 Computation in Drug Discovery and Development
description: Focuses on computational prediction of molecular association and ADME (absorption, distribution, metabolism, excretion) properties in drug discovery and development.

title: PHYS 135ag Physics for the Life Sciences
description: Fundamental laws and principles of physics emphasizing areas related to life sciences; prerequisite for biological sciences, medicine, dentistry, and pharmacy.

title: PHRD 796b Doctor of Pharmacy Capstone
description: Registration Restriction: Open only to Doctor of Pharmacy students.

title: PHYS 135bL Physics for the Life Sciences
description: Fundamental laws and principles of physics emphasizing areas related to life sciences; prerequisite for biological sciences, medicine, dentistry, and pharmacy.

title: PHYS 051x Problem Solving in Mechanics and Thermodynamics
description: Intensive practice in solving elementary problems within a student-centered learning environment.

title: PHRD 796a Doctor of Pharmacy Capstone
description: Registration Restriction: Open only to Doctor of Pharmacy students.

title: PHRD 794z Doctoral Dissertation
description: Dissertation research required for completion of Doctor of Philosophy in Clinical and Experimental Therapeutics.

title: PHRD 794d Doctoral Dissertation
description: Dissertation research required for completion of Doctor of Philosophy in Clinical and Experimental Therapeutics.

title: PHRD 752 Special Project APPE
description: The Special Projects advanced pharmacy practice experiences course gives students the opportunity to demonstrate competency in a variety of pharmacy practice settings.

title: PHRD 794b Doctoral Dissertation
description: Dissertation research required for completion of Doctor of Philosophy in Clinical and Experimental Therapeutics.

title: PHRD 794a Doctoral Dissertation
description: Dissertation research required for completion of Doctor of Philosophy in Clinical and Experimental Therapeutics.

title: PHRD 794c Doctoral Dissertation
description: Dissertation research required for completion of Doctor of Philosophy in Clinical and Experimental Therapeutics.

title: PHRD 790 Directed Research
description: Research leading to doctorate in Clinical and Experimental Therapeutics.

title: PHRD 751 Non-traditional Advanced Pharmacy Elective (APPE)
description: Pharmacy practice experience (internship) course in a non-traditional or emerging setting.

title: PHRD 750 Advanced Pharmacy Practice Elective (APPE)
description: Registration Restriction: Open only to Doctor of Pharmacy students

title: PHRD 731 Advanced Geriatrics APPE
description: Registration Restriction: Open only to Doctor of Pharmacy students

title: PHRD 738 Pharmaceutical Industry APPE
description: Practical experience within a pharmaceutical company may include: clinical affairs, drug development, research, and/or marketing process.

title: PHRD 725 International Pharmacy Practice Experience
description: Practical experience in the practice of pharmacy in the international setting. Students will visit an international pharmacy practice setting and complete a project.

title: PHRD 718 Hospital Pharmacy Practice APPE
description: Practical experience in the practice of hospital pharmacy. Administrative, practice-based and therapeutic competencies emphasized.

title: PHRD 714 Nuclear Pharmacy APPE
description: Registration Restriction: Open only to Doctor of Pharmacy students

title: PHRD 705 Community Pharmacy APPE
description: Pharmaceutical care principles applied to the community pharmacy environment. Participating in the development, implementation and outcome evaluation of patient care services in the community.

title: PHRD 701 Acute Care Clinical APPE
description: Application of pharmaceutical care principles to the adult patient population in an acute care environment. Pharmacology, pharmacokinetics, and disease state management will be emphasized.

title: PHRD 704 Primary Care APPE
description: Disease state management and a primary care setting. Modification and design of drug therapy regimens and primary patient care using a team based approach.

title: PHRD 688 Global Pharmacy

title: PHRD 677 Risk Assessment and Management in Pharmacy Practice
description: Specific risk management issues, legal and professional expectations of pharmacists, and assessing and avoiding risk.

title: PHRD 675 Travel Medicine
description: An elective course for emphasizing the role of the pharmacist in preventing and treating travel related medical conditions.

title: PHRD 673 Spanish for Pharmacists
description: Practical Spanish for pharmacists, including basic conversation of commonly prescribed drugs.

title: PHRD 671 Pharmacy Education Seminar
description: A seminar course with a focus on educational methods and teaching skills providing career development for students interested in academia.

title: PHRD 672 Introduction to Critical Care
description: Coupling evidence-based management with a case-based approach; reinforces the clinical thought processes to optimize pharmaceutical care in various critical care settings.

title: PHRD 670 Marketing and Development in the Pharmaceutical Industry
description: Basic and advanced strategies for marketing and development of new compounds or indication in the pharmaceutical industry.

title: PHRD 669 Health Care Needs of Special Populations
description: Health care needs of the poor will be examined through participation in a multidisciplinary community clinic setting focusing on medication counseling and compliance.

title: PHRD 668 Computing Application
description: Specialized knowledge and skills using computers in professional practice: telecommunication protocols, typical patient databases in hospital and community pharmacies, drug interactions, insurance billing, inventory control.

title: PHRD 666 Therapeutic Drug Monitoring
description: Application of pharmacokinetic and pharmacodynamic principles to individualize patient drug regimens.

title: PHRD 667 Drugs of Abuse
description: Specialized knowledge and skills in specific substance abuse-related areas. Each area will include addiction, wellness, and prevention components.

title: PHRD 665 Complementary/Alternative Therapeutics
description: Examines the therapeutic use of complementary/alternative medicines, such as herbal medicines, homeopathic drugs, vitamins and other nutritional supplements.

title: PHRD 664 Clinical Problem Solving
description: Integration of physical assessment, laboratory tests, history taking, and diagnosis to formulate decisions for optimal treatment plans in specific disease states.

title: PHRD 663 Pharmaceutical Development
description: Examination of pharmaceutical product development process including discovery, preclinical/clinical studies, regulatory-legal issues, and marketing.

title: PHRD 661 Pharmacy Practice in Women's Health
description: The pharmaceutical care of women patients is emphasized. Therapeutic, psychosocial factors and current research in women's health.

title: PHRD 662 Psychiatric Pharmacy Practice
description: Specialized knowledge and skills in psychiatric pharmacy practice including child, adult, and geriatric psychopharmacology applied to inpatient and outpatient treatment.

title: PHRD 660 Disease State Management I
description: The processes required to develop disease state management protocols based on data drawn from the medical research literature.

title: PHRD 659 Molecular Therapeutics: Signal Transduction
description: Principles of molecular therapeutics against signaling pathways; emphasis on biological mechanisms underlying hormone, growth factor, and neurotransmitter-mediated gene regulation, proliferation, and cell death.

title: PHRD 679 Toxicology and the Media
description: Increase knowledge of toxicology relevance in everyday life through the reading, critical analysis and discussion of articles about current toxicological issues in the media.

title: PHRD 678 Topics in Pharmacology: the Other Side of Drugs
description: Nexus of pharmacology and toxicology; therapeutic use and toxicology of common drugs; and prescribing these drugs in clinical practice.

title: PHRD 658 Sleep and the Pharmacologic Management of Its Disorders
description: Overview of normal sleep manifestations, and treatment of common sleep disorders, and the pharmacist's role in assessment, treatment, and referral.

title: PHRD 657 Basic Research Design
description: Laboratory, clinical, health economics or regulatory science research experience for pharmacy students. Projects performed working directly with faculty advisers.

title: PHRD 655 Geriatric Pharmacy I

title: PHRD 654 Health Systems Pharmacy II
description: Recognizing resources available for drug information, familiarity with institutional formularies, medication counseling, writing chart notes, and clinical activities at an off-campus health care institution.

title: PHRD 656 Geriatric Pharmacy II
description: Specialized knowledge and skills in gerontology and geriatric pharmacy including the pathophysiology of selected cardiovascular, endocrine, genitourinary gastrointestinal disorders, osteoarthritis, and osteoporosis.

title: PHRD 653 Health Systems Pharmacy I
description: Understanding formal and informal organizations in institutions, managed care, disease management, health care policy and financing, patients' chart organization, and clinical monitoring parameters.

title: PHRD 652 Community Pharmacy and Business Management II
description: A continuation of PHRD 651 highlighting the subspecialties available in independent pharmacy including but not limited to specialty pharmacy, 340B pharmacy, DME, compounding, LTC and infusion.

title: PHRD 651 Community Pharmacy and Business Management I
description: Development of specialized knowledge and skills in community pharmacy practice involving location analysis, pharmacy management principles, and introduction to business law concepts.

title: PHRD 650 APPE Gateway
description: Competency-based course to prepare and assess students for readiness to enter Advanced Pharmacy Practice Experience (APPE).

title: PHRD 639 Pharmacy Review
description: Supervised, individual studies. No more than one registration permitted. Enrollment by petition only.

title: PHRD 635 Scholary Project 2
description: Oral and poster presentation of the results of the Pharm.D. Scholarly Project.

title: PHRD 633 Pharmacy Management and Economics
description: Management principles for pharmacy practice, understanding of health care systems and pharmacoecomincs. Introduction to formulary management and outcome analysis.

title: PHRD 634 Scholarly Project 1
description: Collection and analysis of results in the Pharm.D. Scholarly Project and oral presentation and discussion of these results.

title: PHRD 626 Elective Pharmacy Practice
description: Exploration of the pharmacy profession and the practice of pharmacy. Includes an elective Introductory Pharmacy Practice Experience (IPPE) in Community, Hospital, or other pharmacy practice settings.

title: PHRD 625 Hospital Pharmacy Practice
description: Exploration of the pharmacy profession and the practice of hospital pharmacy. Includes didactic instruction and Hospital Pharmacy Practice Experiences (IPPEs).

title: PPD 502x Statistical Foundations for Public Management and Policy
description: Statistical analysis concepts and reasoning; sampling and data sources; focus on basic statistical applications in public management and policy analysis.

title: PPD 501b Economics for Policy, Planning and Development
description: Microeconomic analysis and modeling to incorporate Market failure and issues of uncertainty and information failure; organization models; policy instruments; policy and planning applications.

title: PPD 501a Economics for Policy, Planning and Development
description: Microeconomic theory as applied to policy, planning, and development; concepts of efficiency; macroeconomic issues.

title: PPD 503 Economics for Public Policy
description: Economic theory as applied to public policy. Concepts of efficiency and equity, analysis of market failure and policy interventions.

title: PPD 500 Intersectoral Leadership
description: Roles of public, private, nonprofit, and civil society sectors in policy, planning, and development. Leadership skills in negotiation, conflict resolution, institutional design, problem solving.

title: PPD 498 Senior Honors Seminar
description: Concepts, theories, and methods of analysis of a selected topic within the fields of public policy, management and planning. Students must have a 3.5 GPA in PPD courses; 3.0 GPA overall.

title: PPD 499 Special Topics
description: Duplicates Credit in former PLDV 499 and PPMT 499.

title: PPD 497b Senior Thesis
description: Writing of the honors capstone project in an area of interest related to the track of study; research and writing skills.

title: PPD 497a Senior Thesis
description: Writing of the honors capstone project in an area of interest related to the track of study; research and writing skills.

title: PPD 490x Directed Research
description: Duplicates Credit in former PLDV 490x and PPMT 490x.

title: PPD 485m U.S. Immigration Policy
description: Examination of the historical and contemporary components of U.S. immigration policy with emphasis on policies addressing legal permanent immigrants, refugees, asylees, the undocumented.

title: PPD 482 Comparative Public Administration
description: Methodology, theories, and models of comparison; functional processes of administration in developing and developed nations compared; role of bureaucracy in development and nation-building; ecology of administration.

title: PPD 478 Social Innovation
description: Strategies and processes of social innovation and change; examination of social change in the market, government, and within the nonprofit sector; dynamics; civic action and activism.

title: PPD 476 Politics and Administration
description: Administrative relationships to the policy processes; influence of political and economic pressures on administrative policy determination; political behavior by administrators; case analysis.

title: PPD 466 Urban Government and Management
description: Preparation and discussion of cases dealing with selected policy areas including transportation, housing, poverty, and environmental quality.

title: PPD 439 Housing and Community Development
description: Evolution of government housing and community development programs; present practices, e.g., housing elements, economic development, neighborhood rehabilitation; housing needs and market analysis; housing and health.

title: PPD 438 Local Economic Development
description: Economic development in a capitalist system, historic review, sectoral review, funding, strategizing, partnerships, evaluation; class project.

title: PPD 431 Undergraduate Policy, Planning, and Development Studio
description: Application of methods in the exploration of a specific project, policy, or organization from the multiple perspectives of the five tracks in the undergraduate program.

title: PPD 429 Urban Design Practicum
description: Application of design concepts and graphic skills to a local design problem sponsored by a local public or private client in a studio setting; site visits, community contact, presentations.

title: PPD 427L Geographic Information Systems and Planning Applications
description: Basic GIS concepts, ArcView and other GIS software, planning applications and databases, basic cartography; students select, research and prepare a planning GIS analysis project.

title: PPD 422 Transportation and Technology and the Future of Mobility
description: Introduction of the role that technology will play in facilitating shared mobility, disrupting transportation markets, and reshaping multi-modal urban transportation systems; analyses of governance issues; the interaction between private markets and regulators; changes in the nature of infrastructure and urban planning that will be required to accommodate the wired future of transportation.

title: PPD 421 Land Use, Environment, and Housing in Developing Countries
description: Comparative analysis of issues in the built environment in the US and abroad; development, land use, and the supply of housing; housing affordability; land tenure.

title: PPD 424 Art and the City
description: Role of art in modern society with a particular emphasis on the urban context including public spaces, the process of gentrification, and redevelopment; theoretical and research approaches.

title: PPD 416 Food Policy and Planning
description: Key issues related to the practice of food system planning; practice of creating and implementing food policies; understanding of food systems; issues around community food governance.

title: PPD 414 Community Health Policy and Planning
description: Historical perspectives on and the contemporary practice of community health planning; impact of culture, socioeconomics, and environment; policy dimensions; urban planning's role in enhancing and sustaining health.

title: PPD 420 Environmental Impact Assessment
description: Exploration of the role of the National Environmental Policy Act and the California Environmental Policy Act; study of environmental impact assessments including the regulatory aspects, stakeholder and participatory processes, and legal framework.

title: PPD 413 Administration of Health Care Organizations
description: Theory and practice; role of governing bodies, medical staffs and quality review committees; current trends; community responsibility; regulatory and oversight agencies.

title: PPD 415 Health Policy
description: Health policy analysis and challenges; price of health; structure of major sectors in health care; role of insurance in policy debates; trade-offs with policy decisions.

title: PPD 411d Sacramento Semester
description: Exploration of political, economic, and administrative climate of the state government; basic processes and functions considered through seminars, research projects, visitations, group discussions, and internships.

title: PPD 411c Sacramento Semester
description: Exploration of political, economic, and administrative climate of the state government; basic processes and functions considered through seminars, research projects, visitations, group discussions, and internships.

title: PPD 475 The Future of California
description: Challenges facing California; options for governmental and constitutional reform; opportunities for economic growth; demographic and cultural changes; education, environment, and other policy issues.

title: PPD 468 Cross-Cultural Negotiations: Communication and Strategy
description: Application of intercultural communication theories and negotiation theories in the preparation and execution of global negotiations; strategies for creating mutual gains and sustained partnerships.

title: PPD 411b Sacramento Semester
description: Exploration of political, economic, and administrative climate of the state government; basic processes and functions considered through seminars, research projects, visitations, group discussions, and internships.

title: PPD 411a Sacramento Semester
description: Exploration of political, economic, and administrative climate of the state government; basic processes and functions considered through seminars, research projects, visitations, group discussions, and internships.

title: PPD 410 Comparative Urban Development
description: Urbanization and urban development and growth through an international scope; globalizing cities.

title: PPD 407 Financial Management of Public and Nonprofit Organizations
description: Time value of money, risk, government bonds and tax-exempt financing, cost of capital, budgeting, financial statement analysis, and working capital management.

title: PPD 405 Fundraising for Policy and Planning
description: Fundraising in the nonprofit sector; role and structure of philanthropy; strategic issues in the solicitation of private funds for the public good; effect of fundraising on behavior of institutions.

title: PPD 403 Management Analysis I
description: Introduction to organizational and systems analysis; historical perspective; systems theory; information systems, procedure analysis; management planning; introduction to models.

title: PPD 402 Management of Public and Nonprofit Organizations
description: Contemporary management theory; the nature of complex organizations; organizational and intergovernmental arrangements; roles and responsibilities of managers; managerial and organizational effectiveness; organizational structure and dynamics.

title: PPD 404 Empirical Methods for Public Policy
description: Introduction to multivariate regression analysis for policy analysis; course begins with Ordinary Least Squares (OLS) estimation and covers some advanced topics such as panel data and experimental methods; application of these tools in a variety of policy contexts such as education, labor, and health.

title: PPD 390 Special Problems
description: Supervised, individual studies. No more than one registration permitted. Enrollment by petition only.

title: PPD 400 Topics in Public Policy and Urban Studies
description: Seminar in cross cutting topics in public policy and urban studies that engages students with faculty and scholars in interdisciplinary research and analysis of key problems and issues in the fields

title: PPD 382 International Development
description: Definitions and measurements of development; impact of globalization; concept and practice of international and development administration and planning at local, national, and global governance levels.

title: PPD 380b International Perspectives on Urban Problem Solving
description: Research on comparative urban public policy and administration utilizing case study approach; field research includes study in various foreign cities.

title: PPD 380a International Perspectives on Urban Problem Solving
description: Research on comparative urban public policy and administration utilizing case study approach; field research includes study in various foreign cities.

title: PPD 372m Public Service in an Urban Setting
description: Voluntary service in an urban, multicultural context: diverse meanings and practices, history, motivations, relationship to charity and change, dilemmas, public policies; service learning project required.

title: PPD 373 Public Policy and Planning Analysis
description: Applied analytic modeling and data manipulation; visual presentation; interpretation of data; needs assessment and market failure analysis; indexing; extrapolation and simple forecasting; simple risk analysis; benefit-cost analysis.

title: PPD 371 The Nonprofit Sector and the Public Interest
description: Theories of the voluntary nonprofit sector in society and its relationship to government and business; public policies toward the sector.

title: PPD 360 Urban Transportation Planning and Policy
description: Current transportation planning and policy critiques. Transportation planning; the relationship to urban structure; conventional and para-transit modes; analysis of local plans.

title: PPD 364 Technology and the City
description: Smart cities; connectivity and technological innovation; effects of technology on infrastructure management and efficiency; how public policy has responded to technological change and identify best practices; case studies on the impact of technology on cities.

title: PPD 358 Urban and Regional Economics
description: Basic concepts of urban and regional economies; how planners intervene in the urban market; housing, transportation, public goods; land use politics; fiscal issues; cost-benefit analysis.

title: PPD 361 Sustainable Communities, Policy and Planning
description: Policy and planning as shaped by sustainability theories; sustainability indicators; topics include water resources, air quality, land use regulations, environmental design, carrying capacity, ecological footprint analysis.

title: PPD 353 Philanthropy and Social Change
description: History, theories, philosophies, and practices of philanthropy; relationship between philanthropy and nonprofit world; grant-making procedures and relation to social innovation.

title: PPD 357 Government and Business
description: Interrelated roles of business and public institutions; effects of public policies and laws on business sector; incorporates public and business perspectives.

title: PPD 343 Terrorism, Homeland Security, and Public Policy
description: Overview of terrorism, government policies and practices, issues of civil liberties, challenges to public sector management.

title: PPD 342 Crime and Public Policy
description: Public policy agenda-setting, alternatives formulation, and implementation for crime and criminal justice; analysis of specific issues including crime control, death penalty and gun control.

title: PPD 344 Environmental Policy and Sustainable Development
description: Introduction to critical issues of environmental policy in looking toward a more sustainable future; the science and policy of climate change; equity and justice; the greening of industry, governing for sustainable development; policy tools in addressing issues of environmental protection and sustainability.

title: PPD 330 Introduction to Health Care Systems
description: Concepts and determinants of health and illness; health care delivery organizations and programs; the role of the administrator; issues in health care financing and access; quality evaluation; future trends.

title: PPD 340 The American System of Justice
description: Introduction to the system of justice administration: components — police services, judiciary, corrections; interrelationships and issues; management strategies for change.

title: PPD 325 Fundamentals of Health Policy and Management
description: Institutions, policies, and processes affecting health care policy and management; historical and philosophical roots; management of health care delivery; access and quality issues; responsiveness to public needs.

title: PPD 320 Organizational Behavior in Public Administration
description: Understanding human behavior in public organization: motivation, roles, communication; group behavior and decision-making in public context; managing conflict; leadership and change in public complex organizational systems.

title: PPD 315 Analytic Foundations for Public Policy
description: Qualitative methods of analysis; ethical and political implications of policy choices; issue diagnosis and policy design skills; critical reasoning and ethics; policy leadership.

title: PPD 318 Financial Accounting in Public and Nonprofit Organizations
description: Basic accounting principles and concepts necessary for the preparation and understanding of financial statements; accounting for service organizations in the public/nonprofit sector; fund accounting.

title: PPD 314 Public Policy and Law
description: Institutional foundations and analysis of public policy issues; policy formulation and implementation; application of theories; case analyses.

title: PPD 316 Human Resource Management for Public Organizations
description: Human resource development and management; values and processes in civil service career systems; training practices; human relations in supervision; personnel theory.

title: PPD 306 Visual Methods in Policy, Management, Planning and Development
description: Introduction to graphic design, photodocumentation, and geographic information systems as employed in planning, policy, and development. Visual explanations. Computer and by-hand applications.

title: PPD 313 Finance of the Public Sector
description: Justifications for and effects of government policies; tax and spending sides of government budgets; public goods; externalities; social insurance; redistribution and welfare; tax policy.

title: PPD 301 PPD Practices: Internship Seminar
description: Policy, planning, and development skills for practice; internship seminar; leadership, group dynamics and presentation skills; application of management; organizational diversity; reflection on experiences.

title: PPD 300 Social Justice Issues in Public Policy and Urban Planning
description: Social justice issues through the lens of public policy and urban planning with main focus on Los Angeles; critical thinking skills about the fields and their relevance to social justice

title: PPD 250m Cities in the Developing World
description: The transition from traditional to modern cities in the developing world. Primacy and dualism; comparative urbanism as an expression of cultural variation; contrast in Western cities.

title: PPD 303 Statistics for Policy, Planning, and Development
description: Statistical applications applied to the real world; techniques including probability, sampling; hypothesis formation and testing; correlation, and linear regression.

title: PPD 240g Citizenship and Public Ethics
description: Review of legal and ethical traditions of citizenship with emphasis on the latter; consideration of implications for current practice of public policy-making and management.

title: PPD 227 Urban Planning and Development
description: Gateway to BS, Public Policy, Management and Planning and minor in Planning and Development. City building and development process; who plans, politics of planning and development; major topics include land use, fiscal policy, transportation, sustainability, and economic development.

title: PPD 245g The Urban Context for Policy and Planning
description: The urban context for planning and policy decisions. Socioeconomic, physical, and spatial structure of cities; and the underlying demographic, economic, and social processes that drive their ongoing transformation.

title: POSC 440 Comparative Law and the Judicial Process
description: Analysis of courts in comparative perspective; judicial decision-making and development of public policy through the judicial process; theories of law and jurisprudence.

title: POSC 439 Critical Issues in American Politics
description: Intensive examination of critical issues of particular interest in the field of American politics.

title: POSC 436 Environmental Politics
description: The political realities of selected environmental issues; resolving and implementing social priorities; interests, attitudes, strategies, and tactics of pressure groups; institutional biases and opportunities.

title: POSC 437 Mass Media and Politics
description: Analysis of political content of mass media. Audience response to alternative sources of political information. Consideration of the institutional and economic as well as political aspects of the mass media.

title: POSC 435 Politics and the Economy
description: Major techniques, politics, and values involved in the allocation of social and economic resources. Includes such topics as determination of priorities in budgetary processes, economic regulation, control of environmental change, and policies for science.

title: PPD 225 Public Policy and Management
description: Institutions, legal context, and processes of public policy and management. Contemporary theories of public policy formulation, implementation, and evaluation. Public managerial challenges and reforms.

title: PPD 100m Los Angeles, The Enduring Pueblo
description: Gateway to the minor in Planning and Development. Ethnic history of Los Angeles, emphasis placed on architecture, planning, and development. Multiplicity of cross-connections shaped by race, ethnicity, religion, gender, and sexual orientation.

title: POSC 499 Special Topics
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: POSC 479 Critical Issues in Political Thought
description: Intensive examination of critical issues of particular interest in the field of political thought.

title: POSC 490x Directed Research
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: POSC 476 Contemporary Political Thought
description: 20th century political philosophy dealing with major movements in psychological, existential, socialist, and nationalist thought as they bear upon the crisis of political authority in our time.

title: POSC 469 Critical Issues in Comparative Politics
description: Intensive examination of critical issues of particular interest in the field of comparative politics.

title: POSC 464 Politics of Russia and Eastern Europe
description: Culture, society, and politics in Russia and in Eastern Europe. Contemporary political institutions and processes.

title: POSC 453 Political Change in Asia
description: Modernization and political development in China and Japan; Asia's economic "miracles" (Taiwan, Japan, Korea, etc.); nationalism and communist movements in East and Southeast Asia.

title: POSC 452 Critical Issues in Law and Public Policy
description: Intensive examination of special topics in the field of law and public policy.

title: POSC 463 European Politics
description: Institutions, cultures and politics of western Europe, eastern Europe and Russia; internationalization; historical and contemporary political, economic, and social change.

title: POSC 451 Politics of Resources and Development
description: Comparison of relationships between rich and poor countries involving political and economic resources and prospects for development; impact on industrialized states; interdependence; new international economic order.

title: POSC 450 Political Development
description: Choice of models in nation-building; party and other means of mass mobilization; elite recruitment and differentiation; peculiarities of cultures and subcultures; integration of ethnic and other minorities; political socialization and secularization; legitimization.

title: POSC 448b The Politics of Peace
description: Issues of social justice, large-scale social change, high technology, impacts on human survival, and uses of national and international institutions. Arms limitation, control, and disarmament.

title: POSC 449 Political Psychology
description: Psychological forces shaping politics and persons, processes and interactions; emphasis on political socialization and cognitive and affective orientations to politics.

title: POSC 448a The Politics of Peace
description: Issues of social justice, large-scale social change, high technology, impacts on human survival, and uses of national and international institutions. Human rights.

title: POSC 444 Civil and Political Rights and Liberties
description: An examination of debates and controversies surrounding the nature and scope of civil rights and civil liberties.

title: POSC 431 Political Economy of Central America
description: Focus on economic, social, and political structures and processes in the region and in specific countries, especially Guatemala, El Salvador, and Nicaragua.

title: POSC 432 Politics of Local Criminal Justice
description: Roles and behavior of major legal and political participants in the criminal justice system including the police, the legal profession, judges, and the public.

title: POSC 428 Latino Politics
description: Analysis of the historic and contemporary roles of Latinos in the American political system; patterns of political participation and representation are examined.

title: POSC 442m The Politics of Human Differences: Diversity and Discrimination
description: A comparative perspective on social and cultural forces that affect American laws and policies concerning discrimination on the basis of race or ethnicity, gender, sexual orientation, age, and disability.

title: POSC 427 Black Politics in the American Political System
description: The effects of the organization of the American political system and its operations on blacks and other minorities.

title: POSC 430 Political Economy of Mexico
description: Examination of contemporary Mexico: the role of the state in the Mexican economy; development of the government party and opposition groups.

title: POSC 443 Law in Film
description: Analysis of the depiction of law in film; use of film to explore topics in jurisprudence and the politics of law and courts.

title: POSC 426 The United States Supreme Court
description: Role of the court in American politics; overview of major decisions; the politics of appointment; the process of decision-making; impact of judicial decisions.

title: POSC 425 Legislative Process
description: Individual behavior and decision-making within legislatures; changing executive-legislative functions; legislative functions; relationships to political systems in comparative perspective.

title: POSC 422 Political Attitudes and Behavior
description: The citizen's political world; political socialization, opinion formation and dissemination; development of political cultures and subcultures; political mobilization; personality and politics.

title: POSC 424m Political Participation and American Diversity
description: Examines how diverse groups in the U.S. interact with the American political system.

title: POSC 423 Presidents and the Presidency
description: Presidential coalition; sources of presidential power; recent leadership styles; decision-making within the presidency.

title: POSC 421 Ethnic Politics
description: Analysis of the political behavior and roles of ethnic and racial groups in the American political system; public policy issues and patterns of political action are examined.

title: POSC 420 Practicum in the American Political Process
description: Fieldwork in governmental institutions and processes.

title: POSC 418 Environmental Sustainability and Public Participation
description: Examines civic participation in international, national, and local environmental politics and sustainability efforts.

title: POSC 398L Trial Advocacy: Theory and Practice
description: Course covering substantive law, evidence, public speaking and use of societal mores in courtroom advocacy.

title: POSC 410x Political Fellows Seminars
description: Political practitioners will teach on topics such as political strategy, campaigns and speechwriting.

title: POSC 390 Special Problems
description: Supervised, individual studies. No more than one registration permitted. Enrollment by petition only.

title: POSC 391 Honors I: Undergraduate Seminar
description: Selected topics in designated area of political science. Discussion of readings and presentation of papers.

title: POSC 377 Asian Political Thought
description: Major systems of political thought in Chinese, Japanese, and other Asian cultural traditions. Confucianism, Buddhism, Islam, and other classical systems and their present-day adaptations under the impact of communism and democracy.

title: POSC 392 Honors II: Undergraduate Thesis
description: Thesis written under supervision, based on research begun in Honors I.

title: POSC 395 Directed Governmental and Political Leadership Internship
description: Intensive experience in governmental and political offices. Minimum time requirement; evaluation by office and intern report required. Permission of the Director of the Institute of Politics and Government required.

title: POSC 441m Cultural Diversity and the Law
description: Jurisprudential approach to the study of cultural differences. Consideration of circumstances under which law should accommodate cultural diversity in the United States and abroad.

title: POSC 374 The American Founders: Visions, Values and Legacy
description: Analysis of the political thought of the American Founders; consideration of alternative visions of patriarchalism, republicanism, and liberal democracy; exploration of Founders' core values and their impact on issues of race, class, and gender.

title: POSC 371 European Political Thought II
description: Western political thought since the French Revolution. Rise of Marxist socialism, communism, anarchism, fascism, National Socialism, other doctrines; the democratic tradition; new theories of the state.

title: POSC 375 American Political Thought
description: Historical and topical review of American political philosophy from the Puritans to the present. Special emphasis on such recurrent themes as equality, democracy, and racism.

title: POSC 366 Terrorism and Genocide
description: Comparative analysis of the determinants of political violence, terrorism, and genocide and their social and moral consequences; application of theories to contemporary case studies.

title: POSC 365 World Political Leadership
description: Comparative analysis of theories of power and leadership; application to leaders from western democracies, Third World, and socialist countries. Societal consequences of their policies.

title: POSC 370 European Political Thought I
description: Basic concepts of Western political thought from Plato through the contract theorists.

title: POSC 363 Cities and Regions in World Politics
description: Cities and the rise of states; globalization and localization; federalism and decentralization; comparative politics of urban regions in developed and developing countries.

title: POSC 360 Comparative Political Institutions
description: Institutions and processes of advanced industrial societies; political culture, interest articulation and aggregation, the governmental process.

title: POSC 356 Politics in the People's Republic of China
description: The Chinese revolution; social, political, and economic developments in post-1949 China; China after Mao Zedong (Mao Tse-tung).

title: POSC 358 Politics of Sub-Sahara Africa
description: Theories of development and nation-building; revolutionary and evolutionary modernization; role of history, culture, socioeconomic conditions in affecting political structures and functions.

title: POSC 355 Politics of East Asia
description: Institutions and processes of advanced societies; political culture, interest articulation and aggregation, the governmental process.

title: POSC 351 Middle East Politics
description: Political development in the Middle East, emphasizing historical, cultural, and socioeconomic conditions affecting political structures and functions; modernization and countervailing social, economic, and religious forces.

title: POSC 352 Politics of Southeast Asia
description: Theories of development and nation-building; revolutionary and evolutionary modernization; role of history, culture, socioeconomic conditions in affecting political structures and functions.

title: POSC 350 Politics of Latin America
description: Theories of development and nation-building; revolutionary and evolutionary modernization; role of history, culture, socioeconomic conditions in affecting political structures and functions.

title: POSC 354 Japanese Politics
description: Contemporary Japanese politics, political economy, and political processes. How political systems are organized; roles of bureaucrats, politicians, interest groups, and social activists in policymaking.

title: POSC 347 Environmental Law
description: Introduces students to central concepts and theories in environmental law and regulation; analyzes present environmental laws and regulations.

title: POSC 345 International Law
description: Nature, origin, and development of international law; basic principles analyzed and illustrated with cases.

title: POSC 335 Political Parties, Campaigns, and Elections
