description: Organization and function of political parties, nominations and elections, strategy and tactics of campaigning, professional candidate management finance, political machines, voting behavior.

title: POSC 334 Interest Groups and Elite Behavior
description: Introduction to interest group and elite views of the American system, including recent interest group theory and findings and the general critiques of power distribution in American society.

title: POSC 340 Constitutional Law
description: Development of constitutional law by the courts; leading cases bearing on major constitutional issues; the federal system; powers of government; civil liberties.

title: POSC 333 Stigma and Society: Physical Disability in America
description: Political activity involving disabled persons; development of public policy regarding disabled citizens.

title: POSC 328 Asian American Politics
description: Examines political attitudes, behavior and participation of Asian Americans in diverse U.S. society.

title: POSC 325 State Politics
description: American state politics from a comparative perspective. Examines political processes, differing policy outcomes and the impact of social change on system performance.

title: POSC 323 Applied Politics
description: Provides students with the knowledge and skills necessary to become active in politics based on understanding the history, theory, and practices of public participation.

title: POSC 321 Urban Political Problems
description: Social problems and governmental policy in the urban environment, emphasizing such problem areas as education, environment, race, police and the system of criminal justice, and poverty.

title: POSC 315 Regulation of Elections and Political Finance
description: The role money plays in elections and public decisions: disclosure requirements, limits on campaign contributions and expenditures, regulation of radio/television time, tax incentives, public funding.

title: POSC 320 Urban Politics
description: Evolution of contemporary institutions; differing views of community power; major policies; state and federal relations to local governments; metropolitan community problems.

title: POSC 311 Political Analysis
description: Methodological and theoretical problems of micro-analytic studies in political science. Techniques of data collection and assimilation.

title: POSC 300 Principles, Institutions, and Great Issues of American Democracy
description: Underlying principles of American democracy; major issues of contemporary public policy in national and state institutions.

title: POSC 270 Introduction to Environmental Law and Politics
description: Overview of environmental policy, law and politics at the international, domestic and local levels. Social science gateway to the environmental studies major.

title: POSC 265gw Environmental Challenges
description: Examination of the challenges of environmental problem-solving at the personal, local, national and global scales, focused on the issue of climate change.

title: POSC 260 Global Ethnic Politics
description: A comparative analysis of multi-ethnic societies through case studies of inter-ethnic conflict and coexistence, conflict resolution, prevention of genocide and defense of human rights.

title: POSC 250 Critical Issues in Comparative Politics
description: Critical analysis of major issues in comparative politics such as dependency, crises in political legitimacy, political violence and terrorism, political corruption, genocide, and comparative revolutions.

title: POSC 255g Cultures, Civilizations and Ethnicities in World Politics
description: Theories and case studies of conflict and coexistence between cultures, civilizations and ethnic groups in the context of the countervailing force of Western socio-economic globalization.

title: POSC 248gw Human Rights
description: Overview of human rights controversies across the globe. Introduction to techniques of analysis for social issues, interdisciplinary research methods, and interpretation of complex political problems.

title: POSC 220g Critical Issues in American Politics: Presidential Election in Real Time
description: Examination of enduring political issues, as well as the political processes and institutions.

title: POSC 190b Politics and Society
description: Continuation of work begun in first semester.

title: POSC 326 Case Studies in Modern Leadership
description: Study of a single leader or small set of leaders, including the strengths and weaknesses that distinguish them and the cultural forces that nurture them.

title: POSC 322 Social Construction of Race and Citizenship
description: Comparative perspective on the social construction of race and citizenship. Social, economic and political experiences of selected groups in the U.S. are examined.

title: POSC 190a Politics and Society
description: Honors seminar for freshmen and sophomores.

title: POSC 130g Law, Politics and Public Policy
description: Interaction between law and politics; overview of the American legal system; value conflicts and public policy questions which arise within it.

title: POSC 120 Comparative Politics
description: Gateway to the major in political science. Comparative analysis of political institutions and processes in selected industrial, developing and socialist countries, in terms of contrasting ideologies, parties, elites, and economies.

title: POSC 165g Modern Times
description: Explores the current major social and political issues that confront scholars, leaders, and citizens in today's modern world.

title: POSC 110g Ideology and Political Conflict
description: Modern political ideologies; their assumptions, perceptions, and prescriptions regarding political stability and social injustice: anarchism, communism, socialism, liberalism, conservatism, and fascism.

title: POSC 100g Theory and Practice of American Democracy
description: Theoretical, institutional, and functional aspects of American national, state, and local government and politics; contemporary issues. Recommended for freshmen and sophomores.

title: PORT 390 Special Problems
description: Supervised, individual studies. No more than one registration permitted. Enrollment by petition only.

title: PORT 590 Directed Research
description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

title: PORT 316 Portuguese for Business and the Professions
description: Aimed at advanced-level students in Portuguese who wish to develop a working knowledge of Portuguese for business and/or for the professions.

title: PORT 342 Brazilian Cinema
description: Survey of Brazilian cinema, designed to introduce students to major themes and issues within Brazilian studies through the examination of important Brazilian films within their historical, social and political contexts.

title: PORT 250g Cultures of Brazil and Lusophone Africa
description: Comparative study of Brazil in the context of the Lusophone (Portuguese-speaking) world, especially Portugal's former colonies in Africa. Materials drawn from literature, visual culture, music and cultural theory.

title: PORT 300 Introduction to Social and Literary Studies
description: A third year Portuguese course aimed at advanced-level students in Portuguese. Examines and reviews the more complex Portuguese grammatical points, usage, and provide the students further opportunity to perfect their reading, writing and speaking abilities.

title: PORT 302 Introduction to Brazilian Literature
description: An introduction to Brazilian literature and culture exploring how Brazil has been understood and represented through spatial categories that have become, as it were, "common places" in Brazilian literary studies: the rural Brazil of the backlands, the tropical Brazil of the Amazon, the urban and cosmopolitan Brazil of the large cities, and how they relate to questions of identity and difference in the context of Brazilian society.

title: POSC 201x Law and Politics: Electing a President
description: Examination of the rules and realities of American politics, and the role politics plays in American life and culture.

title: PORT 225 Accelerated Portuguese II
description: Continuation of rapid acquisition of Portuguese language. Course follows a proficiency-oriented approach. Recommended for students with a background in Spanish or another Romance language.

title: PORT 240 Portuguese IV
description: Four-skills course with review of grammar. Writing and reading intensive. Authentic materials related to Lusobrazilian culture and civilization.

title: PORT 220 Portuguese III
description: Intensive work in listening comprehension, oral communication, reading and writing, with emphasis on free expression; readings related to Portuguese culture and civilization.

title: PORT 175 Accelerated Portuguese I
description: at least two years or equivalent of formal study of either Spanish or another Romance language, and/or fluent or native speakers of Spanish or a Romance language, including heritage speakers of Portuguese

title: PORT 120 Portuguese I
description: For students with no proficiency in Portuguese. Practice in listening comprehension, oral communication, elementary reading and writing.

title: PORT 150 Portuguese II
description: For students with some language proficiency in Portuguese; increased emphasis on listening, comprehension, oral communication, reading, and writing. Students will be required to take a Portuguese placement exam in the Spanish and Portuguese Department.

title: POIR 794d Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: Graded CR/NC.

title: POIR 794z Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: Graded CR/NC.

title: POIR 794c Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: Graded CR/NC.

title: POIR 794b Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: Graded CR/NC.

title: POIR 794a Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: Graded CR/NC.

title: POIR 790 Research
description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

title: POIR 680 International Security and Foreign Policy
description: Examination of the interconnected fields of international security and foreign policy, including decision making and patterns of interaction regarding international conflict.

title: POIR 662 Governance in International Relations
description: Rules and rule structures in international relations; major theoretical perspectives and empirical research.

title: POIR 670 International Political Economy
description: Survey of approaches to international political economy. Intellectual roots; the management of collective goods; North-South relations are examined.

title: POIR 660 Introduction to International Relations Theory
description: The primary objective of this course is to introduce PhD students to theoretical and empirical issues related to the study of international relations.

title: POIR 661 International Relations Theory: Advanced
description: Examines the specialized nomenclature of international relations and the varied interpretations of basic concepts of international theory; conceptual analysis and criticism.

title: POIR 650 Comparative Politics of East and Southeast Asia
description: Comparison of significant political phenomena between the countries in the East and Southeast Asia region and the long-term consequences of such comparisons.

title: PPD 642 Strategic Leadership of Organizations
description: Strategic analysis; strategic planning; leadership; performance measurement and management; control systems; organizational structure and networks; organizational culture; organizational learning and change.

title: PPD 640 Leadership Foundations: Competencies and Core Values
description: An intensive introduction to leading through core values. Focuses on developing leadership skills at the personal level to build a foundation for leadership at all levels.

title: PPD 641 Leading Individuals, Groups and Teams
description: Leadership styles in various settings; team demographics, and dynamics; problem-solving; decision-making; diversity and critical thinking skills; effect of culture on small group communication; managing conflict.

title: PPD 639 Introduction to Community and Economic Development
description: Theories of community and economic development and a contextual understanding of the forces that change the development and community life of urban areas.

title: PPD 637 Forecasting and Urban Planning: A Survey of Theory and Methods
description: Overview of forecasting methods and applications in urban planning processes used to determine urban futures; includes theoretical and institutional factors as well as quantitative methods.

title: PPD 638 Integrative Seminar
description: Individual research and preparation of an integrated comprehensive study coordinated with a sponsor such as a government agency or development firm.

title: PPD 635 Principles of Transportation Systems Analysis
description: Planning, design, modeling, and operation of inter- and intra-urban transportation networks. Analysis of contemporary engineering-economic issues relevant to transport, especially questions pertaining to infrastructure.

title: PPD 632 Planning Analysis and Evaluation
description: Methods of policy, program, and plan evaluation: economic principles and theoretical concepts introduced, followed by case studies.

title: PPD 636 Infrastructure and Modern Society
description: Survey of infrastructure issues that relates principles from multiple disciplines to the provision of vital services and encourages critical thinking within a systems context.

title: PPD 631 Geographic Information Systems for Policy, Planning, and Development
description: Introduction to GIS systems and usage in the public sector; spatial data; understanding software and the application of technology; analysis of data using GIS.

title: PPD 628 Urban Planning and Social Policy
description: Urban planning and social work: theory, values, techniques of inquiry, and problem-solving methods appropriate to urban planning and social work.

title: PPD 627 Design Skills for Urban Planners
description: Develop observation, description, analysis, and conceptualization skills related to urban spatial conditions; advance professional communication proficiencies.

title: PPD 630 Urban Economic Analysis
description: Economic models of cities and city development and structure; housing and land markets; transportation systems; problems of congestion and pollution; evaluation of urban policies.

title: PPD 626 Public/Private and Mixed Enterprises Planning
description: Case studies of planning and public/private and mixed enterprises; public production of private goods; privatization of public services; public/private partnerships; mixed enterprises.

title: PPD 625 Planning and Economic Development Finance
description: Fundamentals for economic development professionals and policy makers including feasibility analysis and the financing of facilities, social services, and community-based enterprises.

title: PPD 624 Local Economic Development: Theory and Finance
description: Socioeconomic change, economic development theory, assessment techniques, and economic indicators in the context of planning and development policies and programs.

title: PPD 622 Seminar in Urban Development
description: Central city housing and renewal problems and policies. Site selection, organization; land valuation, acquisition, disposition; relocation and management; reuse; site planning and development; politics; financing.

title: PPD 623 Community Development and Site Planning
description: Urban form and emerging community design practices; design project development; evaluation and assessment of site planning in cities and local communities.

title: PPD 620 General Plans
description: Assessment of a recently adopted general plan, analysis of the general plan process, and detailed review of each major element and issue.

title: PPD 621 Environmental Impacts
description: Legal, political/institutional, and technical aspects of environmental impact reports for urban planning.

title: PPD 619 Smart Growth and Urban Sprawl: Policy Debates and Planning Solutions
description: Determinants and analytical models of land use; interaction of land uses with environmental quality and natural resources, land use policy instruments; regulation, taxation, public services.

title: PPD 618 Housing Facilities and Community Development
description: Structure of the building industry and technology. Housing markets and programs; environmental standards. Community development and redevelopment. Planning, program development, finance, and coordination of public facilities and services.

title: PPD 617 Urban Demography and Growth
description: Theory and policy regarding population change in urban areas; housing; cohort analysis; immigration; ethnicity; employment; education. Methods of graphic representation; census data manipulation, interpretation, forecasting.

title: PPD 616 Participatory Methods in Planning and Policy
description: Approaches to community participation, introducing students to the theories behind participatory methods as well as to the skills to implement them.

title: PPD 615 Comparative Urbanization, Development, and Inequality
description: Theories of inequality, dependency and dualism in relation to urbanization, growth, and poverty in developing countries; development and underdevelopment; core-periphery linkages.

title: PPD 614 Management in Planning Practice
description: Administrative, management, political, and other problems faced by the practicing professional planner.

title: PPD 613b Policy, Planning, and Development International Laboratory
description: Research methods for intensive practical field research and evaluation; policy, management and planning practice in intercultural contexts; preparation for professional-level consulting abroad.

title: PPD 613a Policy, Planning, and Development International Laboratory
description: Research methods for intensive practical field research and evaluation; policy, management and planning practice in intercultural contexts; preparation for professional-level consulting abroad.

title: PPD 612 Research and Analytical Techniques
description: Professional practice-oriented analytic skill; fundamentals of data manipulation; spreadsheet applications and forecasting; and communication of results.

title: PPD 611 Policy Issues in Planning and Development
description: Overview of policy issues in planning and development professions in the U.S. and abroad. Special attention to collective decision making, role of institutions, and ethics.

title: PPD 609 Physician Practice Management
description: Overview of medical practice management issues, structures, systems and strategies for effective clinical and financial performance of physician organizations.

title: PPD 608 Leadership Symposium in Health Management and Policy
description: A forum for leading executives and policymakers to address ways they or their organizations improve healthcare financing, delivery and management, in the U.S. and internationally.

title: PPD 607 Introduction to Public Health Policy
description: Public health policy and analysis methods; evaluation of the public health system and safety net programs.

title: PPD 610 Managed Care Contracting
description: Provides practical and strategic decision-making skills in managed care contracting, including contract types, terms and conditions; financial assessment; proposal development and analysis; and negotiation.

title: PPD 606 Urban Health Policy
description: Addresses current U.S. health policy issues and the critical processes that shape them, with an emphasis on urban populations; institutional, economic, social, ethical, and political factors.

title: PPD 605 Frontline Issues in Health Services Administration and Policy
description: Emphasis on current or emergent issues in the health care industry. Focus on impact of recent health legislation and/or health care system responsiveness.

title: PPD 603 Marketing of Health Services
description: Assessing community needs and organizational service capabilities; evaluating competition; qualitative and quantitative market research methods; market communications and advertising; developing marketing plans.

title: PPD 604 Seminar in Hospital Administration
description: Hospital systems and functions; managerial processes, theory, and practice; governance structures; legal, regulatory, administrative, and professional requirements; medical and professional staff; multi-institutional arrangements; controls.

title: PPD 602 Strategic and Operational Planning for Health Services
description: Strategic, institutional, and program planning theory and methods; governmental and legal requirements, certificate of need processes, reimbursement controls; financing and marketing considerations, practices, and methods.

title: PPD 601 Management of Long-Term Care Organizations
description: History, development, trends; major policy issues; organization of systems; principles and techniques of administration; management of institutional and community based programs.

title: PPD 599 Special Topics
description: Selected topics in public policy, management and planning.

title: PPD 596 Internship for Curricular Practical Training
description: Part-time or full-time, practical work experience in the student's field of study. The internship must be located at an off-campus facility. Students are individually supervised by faculty. May not be taken until the student has completed at least one semester of enrollment in the graduate program with a cumulative 3.0 GPA.

title: PPD 600 Management of Managed Care Organizations
description: Managed care arrangements, interorganizational relations, management practices and controls, medical staff relations, strategic planning, marketing, utilization review, quality assurance, outcomes measures.

title: PPD 594z Master's Thesis
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: PPD 594b Master's Thesis
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: PPD 590 Directed Research
description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

title: PPD 594a Master's Thesis
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: PPD 587 Risk Analysis
description: Concepts of risk analysis, risk in engineered systems, environmental risk, security risks; fault trees, event trees, risk simulations; risks and decision-making.

title: PPD 572 Special Issues in International Public Policy
description: Current international public policy on issues such as governmental reform, regulation, social welfare, poverty alleviation and international aid. Policy framework and in-depth analysis of specific topics of relevance to governmental agencies and international organizations.

title: PPD 569 Applied International Policy Analysis and Management Project
description: Enables students to integrate theory, research and practice into an applied project of their own choosing. The output of this course is a professional report in a selected public policy or management area.

title: PPD 571 International Public Policy and Management Seminar
description: An introduction to the concepts and methods of public policy analysis and management. Highlights some of the constraints of the policy process. Includes examples from the United States but also presents comparative views of the contours of public policy in both developed and developing nations. The course applies public policy and management frameworks to selected areas of social policy.

title: PPD 568 Environmental Governance and Sustainability
description: Introduction to leading issues of environmental governance and policy in looking toward a more sustainable future; normatively important concerns and the social, cultural, and political dimensions; thematic look from values to action.

title: PPD 570 Applied Statistics for Planning, Policy and Management
description: Use of statistical reasoning to answer questions related to public policy and management. Students will review and understand selected statistical techniques for analyzing data and for addressing public policy and management questions of interest using applied data analysis.

title: PPD 561b Policy Analysis Practicum
description: Application and integration of the knowledge and techniques of analytic, quantitative, managerial, political and ethical analyses to specific public policy problems.

title: PPD 559 Policy Implementation and Evaluation
description: Theoretical approaches, critical issues, and research methods in public policy implementation. Field-based research project.

title: PPD 560 Methods for Policy Analysis
description: Examination of methods used in the analysis of policy methods, including cost benefit analysis, decision and risk analysis, and applied social science methods.

title: PPD 555 Public Policy Formulation and Implementation
description: Political and organizational perspectives on policy making process; agenda setting, policy design, adoption, implementation, evaluation, modification or termination. Policy leadership skills: negotiation and strategic mapping.

title: PPD 558 Multivariate Statistical Analysis
description: Applied multivariate statistics in support of policy, management, and planning problem solving. Includes regression analysis, logit models, and an introduction to time-series models and multi-equation estimation.

title: PPD 554 Foundations of Policy Analysis
description: Introduction to public policy analysis; issue diagnosis and policy design; analytic reasoning and argumentation; the role of the public policy professional; ethical issues in policy analysis.

title: PPD 561a Policy Analysis Practicum
description: Application and integration of the knowledge and techniques of analytic, quantitative, managerial, political and ethical analyses to specific public policy problems.

title: PPD 545 Human Behavior in Public Organizations
description: Behavior in organizations; focus on personal, interpersonal, and group level factors that influence such behavior.

title: PPD 557 Modeling and Operations Research
description: Management science methods that support decision making in policy, management, and planning settings. Includes linear programming, queuing theory, decision analysis, and forecasting.

title: PPD 543 Internship Seminar
description: Supervised study of management, analytical, or other professional activities in government; integration of theory, practice and relevant literature.

title: PPD 542 Policy and Program Evaluation
description: Methods and models for policy and program evaluation; methods of collecting and analyzing evaluation data; processes for linking evaluation to policy formulation and program management.

title: PPD 546 Capstone in Public Administration
description: Constitutionally accountable and ethical practice, individually and organizationally; applications of core competencies; practical inquiry, analysis, systems; comparative frameworks; citizenship and public service.

title: PPD 540 Public Administration and Society
description: Administrative concepts, institutions, legal systems, and practices; values; facilitation of responsibilities and rights; professional applications for personal, private sector, and public achievement.

title: PPD 541 Public Financial Management and Budgeting
description: Financial management applied to public and nonprofit organizations; financial valuation, financial markets, budgeting, tax administration, debt financing, cost-benefit analysis and financial analysis.

title: PPD 533 Planning History and Urban Form
description: History of urban planning with an emphasis on the evolution of how planning shaped the physical environment in response to political, economic, and social issues.

title: PPD 532L International Planning and Development Laboratory Workshop
description: Application of planning principles and methods to specific urban planning problems abroad; involves preparation in the spring semester and an overseas field visit and a collaborative practicum.

title: PPD 531L Planning Studio
description: Application of methods in planning, programming, research, and evaluation in a professional context; data collection and analysis; case studies; practical applications.

title: PPD 530 Historical Analysis of Urban Form and Planning Practice
description: Awareness, analysis, understanding, and influencing the city building process locally and regionally; isolate and exercise tools and methods of visual literacy.

title: PPD 527 The Social Context of Planning
description: Examination of the formation of the modern urban environment with its consumer culture, social classes, and racial and ethnic diversity.

title: PPD 529 Legal Environment of Planning
description: Understanding of the legal system and its processes and laws applicable to land use and development and the legal nature of powers of public and private entities.

title: PPD 526 Comparative International Development
description: Introduction to comparative international development with a focus on regional growth and urban development.

title: PPD 525 Statistics and Arguing from Data
description: Fundamentals of probability and statistics, planning analysis techniques, computing standards, and understanding of the rhetoric related to statistical analysis.

title: PPD 524 Planning Theory
description: Development of a critical perspective by becoming more aware of the intellectual roots of the planning profession, with a focus on practical outcomes of actions.

title: PPD 521b Information Technology Management Systems in Health Care
description: Principles and methods of systems analysis; assessment; strategic planning, design consideration; e-health and e-commerce system trends; health care information systems application areas; regulatory requirements. Analytic methods used to develop data-driven solutions; specific problems in health care organizations; integrating data; communicating data; interpretation; exploration of new approaches for improvement.

title: PPD 520 Economic Approaches to Health Policy Analysis
description: Evaluation of current major health policy challenges and issues; economic analysis of behavioral responses to change in health care policy; new legislation; policy trade-offs.

title: PPD 521a Information Technology Management Systems in Health Care
description: Principles and methods of systems analysis; assessment; strategic planning, design consideration; e-health and e-commerce system trends; health care information systems application areas; regulatory requirements.

title: PPD 518 Quality of Care Concepts
description: Quality issues and complexities affecting health care; fundamentals of quality improvement programs; examination of quality issues and improvement programs in various health care venues; strategies.

title: PPD 519 Methods and Applications of Health Services Research
description: Examination of policy and management issues for empirical research; indicators and measurement of outcomes; impact on policy and management decisions; methodology; analysis of quantitative and qualitative data.

title: PPD 517 Concepts and Practices in Managing Health Care Organizations
description: Application of principles of health administration. Role of managers; managing people and programs; human resource management concepts and applications; working with professionals; governance; public relations.

title: PPD 516 Financial Accounting for Health Care Organizations
description: Accounting as a management tool; accounting systems; basic accounting concepts and procedures; budgets; financial statements.

title: PPD 514 Economic Concepts Applied to Health
description: Relationships between economic characteristics and health status; impact of economy on health services industry; demand and resources for health services; utilization, prices, costs, health insurance.

title: PPD 513 Legal Issues in Health Care Delivery
description: Rights of consumers; health-related powers of governments; rights and responsibilities of health care providers; interrelationships of rights, powers, and responsibilities.

title: PPD 512 Health Administration Residency Seminar
description: Supervised study of health care administration, governance, professional staff relations, internal operations and controls, legal and regulatory requirements, management policy and strategy.

title: PPD 511 Health Information Systems
description: Conceptual framework for data base development; relational data management; use of health statistics; health indicators; confidentiality, security, privacy.

title: PPD 509 Problems and Issues in the Health Field
description: Principles of epidemiology; disease trends, treatment efficacy, influences on utilization; health promotion, disease prevention and health protection; intergovernmental relationships; management of public health programs.

title: PPD 510b Financial Management of Health Services
description: Changing practices, emerging issues, strategies and innovations in financial planning, management, and regulation; federal and state policies and requirements.

title: PPD 510a Financial Management of Health Services
description: Accounting principles, financial reports, managerial finance, financial planning, capital investments, working capital analysis; elements of budgeting and reimbursement; performance standards; reporting; developing a management system.

title: PPD 515 Strategic Management of Health Organizations
description: Application of principles of health administration in several practice settings. Decision-making; strategic management; organizational performance; communication; provider comparisons.

title: PPD 508 Health Care Operations Improvement
description: Improving operations, patient flow, quality and processes. Students will become familiar with methods for implementing change in health care settings such as hospitals or clinics.

title: MTAL 501 Historical Foundations of Music Education
description: A contextual exploration of the historical development of American music education.

title: MTAL 500 Research Foundations in Music Teaching and Learning
description: Introductory exploration of types of research linked to research literature in music teaching and learning; interpreting research reports; organizing and writing research proposals and reports.

title: MPGU 150 Functional Skills for the Popular Guitarist
description: Study of theory, technique and fingerboard organization of melodic and harmonic topics as applied to guitar.

title: MS 102 Basic Leadership
description: Establishes foundation of basic leadership fundamentals such as problem solving, communications, briefings and effective writing, goal setting, techniques for improving listening and speaking skills and an introduction to counseling.

title: MPPM 250 Keyboard Proficiency for the Popular Musician
description: Development of practical keyboard skills, including reading and realizing chord symbols, basics of voice leading, study of various harmonic and rhythmic styles.

title: MKT 599 Special Topics
description: Examination of current literature and emerging and timely topics in marketing, social marketing, consumerism, macromarketing, marketing of individuals, organizations, and ideas.

title: MKT 598 Special Topics
description: Current trends, recent developments, and emerging topics in marketing. Graded CR/NC.

title: MPPM 240 Drumming Proficiency for the Popular Musician
description: Beginning and elementary instruction in drum set techniques.

title: MDES 301g The Global Middle East
description: Explores the modern Middle East by focusing on the process of globalization.

title: LAW 817 International Arbitration
description: Examines methods of dispute resolution used in other countries and compares them to those employed in the United States.

title: MUHL 561 Studies in World Music II
description: The indigenous and syncretic musics of the post-Soviet political landscape, the Far East, the Middle East, and Latin America.

title: MUHL 560 Studies in World Music I
description: The indigenous and syncretic musics of Africa, India, Indonesia, and the Balkan countries.

title: LBST 570 Ecology of Night
description: Explore the world of night. Human perception of the stars and the role of night in history. Impact of artificial lighting on non-human species and habitat.

title: LBST 560 Effects of Traumatic Life Experiences
description: Examination of the psychological and emotional effects of extreme trauma and survivor consequences.

title: LAW 818 Entrepreneurial Opportunities in Online Dispute Resolution
description: Presents the theoretical groundwork of online dispute resolution (ODR) and prepares students to be successful neutrals in ODR settings.

title: MPTX 502 Pharmacology
description: Fundamentals of pharmacology in the context of the rapidly developing knowledge of related disciplines.

title: MPVA 441 English and German Diction
description: Principles of pronunciation and enunciation; use of international phonetic alphabet.

title: MPTX 596 Internship for Curricular Practical Training
description: Part-time or full-time, practical work experience in the student's field of study. The internship must be located at an off-campus facility. Students are individually supervised by faculty. May not be taken until the student has completed at least one semester of enrollment in the graduate program with a cumulative 3.0 GPA.

title: LAW 689 Digital Media Transactions
description: Focuses on the business, legal, and financial issues that relate to the creation, financing, and exploitation of digital media.

title: LAW 690 Entertainment Law in Practice
description: Develops legal, analytical, and client management skills required to represent entertainment industry clients in all areas of the entertainment industry.

title: LAW 687 Immigration Detention and Appellate Clinic
description: A one-semester clinical course where students represent non-citizens in appellate matters before the Board of Immigration Appeals and the U.S. Court of Appeals, and in petitions for writs of habeas corpus before the U.S. District Court.

title: LAW 686 Civil Rights: The Enforcement of the Constitution
description: Gives students operational significance to the abstractions presented in the Constitutional Law courses by investigating civil rights litigation.

title: LAW 685 Civil Discovery
description: Focuses on the discovery phase of pre-trial litigation and many of the skills new lawyers are called upon to use right out of law school.

title: LAW 684 Suing the Government
description: Deals with suits against federal and state governments. Intended for aspiring government workers or representatives of plaintiffs who sue a government official or entity.

title: LAW 683 Fact Investigation and Discovery
description: Introduction to a practice-oriented approach to interviewing and counseling clients. Enables students to develop a useful framework for effectively interviewing and representing clients.

title: MATH 530b Stochastic Calculus and Mathematical Finance
description: Advanced topics in stochastic analysis, asset pricing in continuous time, stochastic control, Hamilton-Jacobi-Bellman equations, incomplete markets, American options, exotic options, term structure of interest rates.

title: MATH 407 Probability Theory
description: Probability spaces, discrete and continuous distributions, moments, characteristic functions, sequences of random variables, laws of large numbers, central limit theorem, special probability laws.

title: MATH 594a Master's Thesis
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: MATH 594b Master's Thesis
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: MATH 590 Directed Research
description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

title: MATH 592 Computational Molecular Biology Internship
description: Industrial or genome-centered internship for students in the Computational Molecular Biology master's program. Real-world experience in applications.

title: MATH 585 Mathematical Theory of Optimal Control
description: Deterministic control: calculus of variations; optimal control; Pontryagin principle; multiplier rules and abstract nonlinear programming; existence and continuity of controls; problem of Mayer; dynamic programming.

title: MATH 580 Introduction to Functional Analysis
description: Basic functional analysis in Banach and Hilbert spaces. Weak topologies, linear operators, spectral theory, calculus of vector-valued functions. Banach algebras.

title: MATH 578a Computational Molecular Biology
description: Applications of the mathematical, statistical and computational sciences to data from molecular biology. Algorithms for genomic sequence data: sequence and map assembly and alignment, RNA secondary structure, protein structure, gene-finding, and tree construction.

title: MATH 578b Computational Molecular Biology
description: Applications of the mathematical, statistical and computational sciences to data from molecular biology. Statistics for genomic sequence data: DNA sequence assembly, significance of alignment scores, hidden Markov models, genetic mapping, models of sequence evolution, and microarray analysis.

title: MATH 574 Applied Matrix Analysis
description: Equivalence of matrices; Jordon canonical form; functions of matrices; diagonalization; singular value decomposition; applications to linear differential equations, stability theory, and Markov processes.

title: MATH 576 Applied Complex Analysis and Integral Transforms
description: Review of basic complex analysis; integral transforms of Laplace, Fourier, Mellin, and Hankel; applications to solutions of ordinary and partial differential equations; Wiener-Hopf technique.

title: MATH 572 Applied Algebraic Structures
description: Elementary predicate logic, model theory, axiomatic set theory; relations, functions, equivalences; algebraic and relational structures; graph theory; applications of lattices, Boolean algebras; groups, rings, field.

title: MATH 570b Methods of Applied Mathematics
description: Measure theory, convergence, Lebesgue spaces, Riesz's theorem, Integration theorems, compact and self-adjoint operators, spectral theory, resolution of the identity, differential operators, quantum mechanics.

title: MATH 570a Methods of Applied Mathematics
description: Metric spaces, compactness, completion, fixed-point theorems, abstract spaces, linear operators, functionals, duality, conjugates, Lp spaces, Fourier transform. Applications from Engineering, Natural and Social sciences.

title: MATH 565a Ordinary Differential Equations
description: Existence, uniqueness and continuation of solutions, differential inequalities, linear systems, Sturm-Liouville theory, boundary value problems, Poincare-Bendixson theory, periodic solutions, perturbations, stability, fixed point techniques.

title: MATH 565b Ordinary Differential Equations
description: Existence, uniqueness and continuation of solutions, differential inequalities, linear systems, Sturm-Liouville theory, boundary value problems, Poincare-Bendixson theory, periodic solutions, perturbations, stability, fixed point techniques.

title: MATH 555a Partial Differential Equations
description: Second-order partial differential equations of elliptic, parabolic, and hyperbolic type; in particular, potential and wave equations.

title: MATH 555b Partial Differential Equations
description: Second-order partial differential equations of elliptic, parabolic, and hyperbolic type; in particular, potential and wave equations.

title: MATH 547 Mathematical Foundations of Statistical Learning Theory
description: Binary classification, empirical risk minimization, support vector machines, voting algorithms and AdaBoost, Vapnik-Chervonenkis combinatorics, concentration-of-measure inequalities, sparse recovery problems, high-dimensional convex geometry.

title: MATH 548 Sequential Analysis
description: Sequential decision procedures: sequential probability-ratio tests, operating characteristic, expected sample size, two-stage procedures, optimal stopping, martingales, Markov processes; applications to gambling, industrial inspection.

title: MATH 541b Introduction to Mathematical Statistics
description: Hypothesis testing, Neyman-Pearson lemma, generalized likelihood ratio procedures, confidence intervals, consistency, power, jackknife and bootstrap. Monte Carlo Markov chain methods, hidden Markov models.

title: MATH 542L Analysis of Variance and Design
description: Least squares estimation in the linear model, analysis of variance and covariance, F-test, multiple comparisons, multiple regression, selection of variables; introduction to experimental design. Includes laboratory.

title: MATH 533 Algebraic Combinatorics
description: Walks in graphs, random walks, group actions on boolean algebras, Young diagrams and tableaux, the Matrix-Tree Theorem.

title: MATH 535b Differential Geometry
description: Elementary theory of manifolds, Lie groups, homogeneous spaces, fiber bundles and connections. Riemannian manifolds, curvature and conjugate points, second fundamental form, other topics.

title: MATH 541a Introduction to Mathematical Statistics
description: Parametric families of distributions, sufficiency. Estimation: methods of moments, maximum likelihood, unbiased estimation. Comparison of estimators, optimality, information inequality, asymptotic efficiency. EM algorithm, jackknife and bootstrap.

title: MATH 540 Topology
description: Initial and final topologies, function spaces, algebras in C(Y), homotopy, fundamental group, fiber spaces and bundles, smashes, loop spaces, groups of homotopy classes, cw-complexes.

title: MATH 532 Combinatorial Analysis
description: Inversion formulas, generating functions and recursions, partitions, Stirling numbers, distinct representatives, Ramsey's theorem, graph theory, block designs, difference sets, finite geometrics, Latin squares, Hadamard matrices.

title: MATH 535a Differential Geometry
description: Elementary theory of manifolds, Lie groups, homogeneous spaces, fiber bundles and connections. Riemannian manifolds, curvature and conjugate points, second fundamental form, other topics.

title: MATH 525b Real Analysis
description: Metric spaces, contraction principle, category, Banach spaces, Riesz representation theorem, properties of Lp Hilbert spaces, orthogonal expansions, Fourier series and transforms, convolutions.

title: MATH 530a Stochastic Calculus and Mathematical Finance
description: Stochastic processes revisited, Brownian motion, Martingale theory, stochastic differential equations, Feynman-Kac formula, binomial models, basic concepts in arbitrage pricing theory, equivalent Martingale measure.

title: MATH 525a Real Analysis
description: Measure and integration over abstract measure spaces, Radon-Nikodym theorem, Fubini's theorem, convergence theorems, differentiation.

title: MATH 520 Complex Analysis
description: Theory of analytic functions — power series and integral representations, calculus of residues, harmonic functions, normal families, approximation theorems, conformal mapping, analytical continuation.

title: MATH 512 Financial Informatics and Simulation (Computer Labs and Practitioner Seminar)
description: Experimental laboratory trading for financial markets using double auctions: handling statistical packages for data analysis. Practical training in virtual market environments, using financial trading system software.

title: MATH 507b Theory of Probability
description: Dependence, martingales, ergodic theorems, second-order random functions, harmonic analysis, Markov processes.

title: MATH 510a Algebra
description: Group Theory: Isomorphism theorems, group actions, Sylow's theorems, simple and solvable groups; Field Theory: Galois correspondence, radical extensions, algebraic and transcendental extensions, finite fields.

title: MATH 510b Algebra
description: Commutative Algebra: Integrality, Hilbert Basis theorem, Hilbert Nullstellensatz; Modules: modules over PIDs, chain conditions, tensor products; Noncommutative Rings: Jacobson radical, Artin-Wedderburn theorem, Maschke's theorem.

title: MATH 505b Applied Probability
description: Markov processes in discrete or continuous time; renewal processes; martingales; Brownian motion and diffusion theory; random walks, inventory models, population growth, queuing models, shot noise.

title: MATH 507a Theory of Probability
description: Probability spaces; distributions and characteristic functions; laws of large numbers, central limit problems; stable and infinitely divisible laws; conditional distributions.

title: MATH 508 Filtering Theory
description: Theory of random differential equations and stochastic stability; optimum linear and nonlinear filtering, with discussion of asymptotic behavior of filter.

title: MATH 509 Stochastic Differential Equations
description: Brownian motion, stochastic integrals, the Ito formula, stochastic differential equations, analysis of diffusion processes, Girsanov transformation, Feynmann-Kac formula, applications.

title: MATH 505a Applied Probability
description: Populations, permutations, combinations, random variables, distribution and density functions conditional probability and expectation, binomial, Poisson, and normal distributions; laws of large numbers, central limit theorem.

title: MATH 504b Numerical Solution of Ordinary and Partial Differential Equations
description: Computationally efficient schemes for solving PDE numerically; stability and convergence of difference schemes, method of lines; fast direct and iterative methods for elliptic equations.

title: MATH 502b Numerical Analysis
description: Computational linear algebra; solution of general nonlinear systems of equations; approximation theory using functional analysis; numerical solution of ordinary and partial differential equations.

title: MATH 504a Numerical Solution of Ordinary and Partial Differential Equations
description: Initial value problems; multistep methods, stability, convergence and error estimation, automatic stepsize control, higher order methods, systems of equations, stiff problems; boundary value problems; eigen-problems.

title: LING 535 Syntax and Grammatical Theory
description: Principles and comparison of modern theories of grammar with special reference to syntax.

title: LING 533 Language Universals and Typology
description: Introduction to language universals and typology.

title: LING 534 Logic and the Theory of Meaning
description: An introduction to logic in preparation for advanced work in semantics and linguistic theory.

title: LING 532 Current Issues in Syntactic Theory
description: Original literature, focusing whenever possible on issues in comparative syntax and their implications for universal grammar. Course complements

title: LING 531b Phonology
description: Traditional views of phonology; generative phonology; current developments in phonological research and theory.

title: LING 531a Phonology
description: Traditional views of phonology; generative phonology; current developments in phonological research and theory.

title: LING 530 Generative Syntax
description: Introduction to syntax; transformational-generative syntax.

title: LING 527 Second Language Acquisition
description: Concepts and issues in theoretical approaches to the study of non-primary language acquisition; e.g., linguistic and processing universals, language transfer, language learnability, fossilization.

title: LING 512 Linguistic Variation and Language Changes
description: Linguistic relationships among various correlates of variation: social, psychological, and chronological. Focus on dialectical, registral, and historical variation; the constraints of production and perception in different modes and situations.

title: LING 505c Seminar in Linguistics
description: Colloquium for presentation and discussion of student research paper.

title: LING 505b Seminar in Linguistics
description: Preparation and presentation of M.A./Ph.D. screening papers; discussion of student research.

title: MATH 501 Numerical Analysis and Computation
description: Linear equations and matrices, Gauss elimination, error estimates, iteration techniques; contractive mappings, Newton's method; matrix eigenvalue problems; least-squares approximation, Newton-Cotes and Gaussian quadratures; finite difference methods.

title: MATH 502a Numerical Analysis
description: Computational linear algebra; solution of general nonlinear systems of equations; approximation theory using functional analysis; numerical solution of ordinary and partial differential equations.

title: MATH 500 Graduate Colloquium
description: Lectures directed to mathematics graduate students by faculty of the department and by outside speakers. Problem solving workshops.

title: MATH 499 Special Topics
description: Lectures on advanced material not covered in regularly scheduled courses. No more than two registrations allowed.

title: MATH 490x Directed Research
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: MATH 471 Topics in Linear Algebra
description: Polynomial rings, vector spaces, linear transformations, canonical forms, inner product spaces.

title: MATH 475 Introduction to Theory of Complex Variables
description: Limits and infinite series; line integrals; conformal mapping; single-valued functions of a complex variable; applications. Primarily for advanced students in engineering.

title: MATH 467 Theory and Computational Methods for Optimization
description: Methods for static, dynamic, unconstrained, constrained optimization. Gradient, conjugate gradient, penalty methods. Lagrange multipliers, least squares, linear, nonlinear dynamic programming. Application to control and estimation.

title: MATH 466 Dynamic Modeling
description: Formulation and study of models arising in population dynamics, growth of plankton, pollution in rivers, highway traffic, morphogenesis and tidal dynamics: stability, oscillations, bifurcations, chaos. The lab will consist of computer simulation of models using commercially available software.

title: MATH 465 Nonlinear Dynamics in Science and Engineering
description: Nonlinear models, bifurcations, discrete and continuous dynamics, stability, dissipative and reversible systems, Poincare maps, Lyapunov exponents, fractal dimension. Applications stressed: Economics, Engineering, Biology, Physics.

title: MATH 458 Numerical Methods
description: Rounding errors in digital computation; solution of linear algebraic systems; Newton's method for nonlinear systems; matrix eigenvalues; polynomial approximation; numerical integration; numerical solution of ordinary differential equations.

title: MATH 450 History of Mathematics
description: Evolution of mathematical ideas and techniques as seen through a study of the contributions of eminent mathematicians to the formulation and solution of celebrated problems.

title: MATH 440 Topology
description: Cardinals, topologies, separation axioms. Compactness, metrizability, function spaces; completeness; Jordan curve theorem.

title: MATH 447 Mathematics of Machine Learning
description: Mathematical aspects of Machine Learning. PAC Learning, VC-dimension and complexity. Linear predictors (regression, perceptron, SVM). Convex learning and gradient descent. Neural networks and backpropagation.

title: MATH 435 Vector Analysis and Introduction to Differential Geometry
description: Vectors, elements of vector analysis, applications to curves and surfaces, standard material of differential geometry.

title: MATH 434 Geometry and Transformations
description: The Euclidean plane and its isometries. Models for the hyperbolic metric, isometries, linear fractional maps, geodesics. Gluing constructions. Knot theory and invariants.

title: MATH 445 Mathematics of Physics and Engineering II
description: Vector field theory; theorems of Gauss, Green, and Stokes; Fourier series and integrals; complex variables; linear partial differential equations; series solutions of ordinary differential equations.

title: MATH 432 Applied Combinatorics
description: Mathematical induction, counting principles, arrangements, selections, binomial coefficients, generating functions, recurrence relations, inclusion-exclusion, symmetric groups, graphs, Euler and Hamiltonian circuits, trees, graph algorithms; applications.

title: MATH 430 Theory of Numbers
description: Introduction to the theory of numbers, including prime factorization, congruences, primitive roots, N-th power residues, number theoretic functions, and certain diophantine equations.

title: MATH 425b Fundamental Concepts of Analysis
description: Implicit function theorems, Jacobians, transformations, multiple integrals, line integrals.

title: MATH 425a Fundamental Concepts of Analysis
description: The real number system, metric spaces, limits, continuity, derivatives and integrals, infinite series.

title: MATH 408 Mathematical Statistics
description: Principles for testing hypotheses and estimation, confidence intervals, methods of moments, maximum likelihood, information inequality, likelihood ratio tests, goodness of fit and nonparametric methods.

title: LING 505a Seminar in Linguistics
description: Exploration of the professional world of linguistics for first semester graduate students.

title: LING 501a Experimental Methods in Linguistics
description: Univariate and bivariate statistical methods with applications to linguistic research; introduction to statistical computer packages.

title: MATH 410 Fundamental Concepts of Modern Algebra
description: Sets; relations; groups; homomorphisms; symmetric groups; Abelian groups; Sylow's theorems; introduction to rings and fields.

title: LING 499 Special Topics
description: Investigation of selected topics in linguistics.

title: LING 501b Experimental Methods in Linguistics
description: The application of advanced multivariate statistical methods to linguistic research.

title: LING 480 Linguistic Structures
description: Analysis of grammatical structures of an individual language.

title: LING 485 Field Methodology
description: Elicitation techniques and methodological principles; recording and analysis of phonological, syntactic, and semantic structures; practical approaches to procedures used in urban, rural, and "primitive" settings.

title: LING 490x Directed Research
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: LING 466 Word and Phrase Origins
description: Introduction to historical-comparative word study; history of ideas concerning language relationships; types of semantic change; hidden metaphors in English word-stock.

title: LING 497 Honors Thesis
description: Writing of the honors thesis. Registration is restricted to honors students.

title: LING 450 New Horizons in Forensic Speaker Identification
description: Overview of methods used to identify voices on the basis of their characteristic speech patterns.

title: LING 415 Phonetics
description: Familiarization with the articulation and transcription of speech sounds. Also vocal tract anatomy, acoustics, speech technology, non-English sounds, perception. Includes laboratory exercises.

title: LING 410 Second Language Acquisition
description: Theories of second language acquisition in children and adults; comparison of first and second language acquisition including psychological, social, and individual factors.

title: LING 411x Linguistics and Education
description: Practical classroom approaches to children's language; relationships between writing, reading, and speaking; social and regional dialects; traditional, structural, and generative-transformational grammars.

title: LING 412 Language and Law
description: Principles of semantics; analysis of speech acts including informing, promising, threatening, warning; linguistic analysis of consumer contracts and advertisements; readability studies.

title: LING 409 Linguistic Structure of English
description: An overview of the syntactic, semantic, pragmatic structures of English as they relate to the theoretical literature on language acquisition.

title: LING 403 Advanced Semantics
description: Duplicates Credit in former LING 201.

title: LING 402 Advanced Syntax
description: Duplicates Credit in former LING 402b.

title: MATH 390 Special Problems
description: Supervised, individual studies. No more than one registration permitted. Enrollment by petition only.

title: MATH 400 Foundations of Discrete Mathematics
description: Methods of proof, predicate calculus, set theory, order and equivalence relations, partitions, lattices, functions, cardinality, elementary number theory and combinatories.

title: MATH 395 Seminar in Problem Solving
description: Systematic approach to solving non-standard and competition level math problems on inequalities, infinite sums and products, combinatorics, number theory, and games.

title: MATH 308 Statistical Inference and Data Analysis II
description: Confidence intervals, hypothesis testing, pvalues, likelihood ratio, nonparametrics, descriptive statistics, regression, multiple linear regression, experimental design, analysis of variance, categorical data, chi-squared tests, Bayesian statistics.

title: MATH 370 Applied Algebra
description: Induction, Euclidean algorithm, factorization, congruence classes, Rings, RSA algorithm, Chinese remainder theorem, codes, polynomials, fundamental theorem of algebra, polynomial multiplication, Fourier transform, and other topics.

title: MATH 265 Mathematical and Computational Methods for Neuroscience
description: Differential calculus of multivariable functions, optimization, elementary linear algebra and matrix theory, principal component analysis, elementary differential equations, systems, qualitative theory, numerical methods, scientific computation.

title: MATH 245 Mathematics of Physics and Engineering I
description: First-order differential equations; second-order linear differential equations; determinants and matrices; systems of linear differential equations; Laplace transforms.

title: MATH 307 Statistical Inference and Data Analysis I
description: Probability, counting, independence, distributions, random variables, simulation, expectation, variance, covariance, transformations, law of large numbers, Central limit theorem, estimation, efficiency, maximum likelihood, Cramer-Rao bound, bootstrap.

title: MATH 227 Enhanced Calculus III
description: ; vectors and vector spaces functions of several variables, partial differential equations, optimization theory, multiple integration; Green's Stokes', divergence theorems.

title: MATH 229 Calculus III for Engineers and Scientists
description: ; vectors, vector valued functions; differential and integral calculus of functions of several variables; Green's theorem. Engineering and physics applications.

title: MATH 226g Calculus III
description: ; vectors, vector valued functions; differential and integral calculus of functions of several variables; Green's theorem.

title: MATH 225 Linear Algebra and Linear Differential Equations
description: Matrices, systems of linear equations, vector spaces, linear transformations, eigenvalues, systems of linear differential equations.

title: MATH 127 Enhanced Calculus II
description: Applications of integration, review of techniques of integration, infinite sequences and series, some beginning linear algebra, ordinary differential equations. Designed for students who earn a score of 4 or 5 on the Advanced Placement Calculus AB Examination, or a score of 3 or 4 on the BC Examination. Admission to course by departmental approval.

title: MATH 200 Elementary Mathematics from an Advanced Standpoint
description: An explication of arithmetic and geometry, including the algebraic operations, number bases, plane and solid figures; and coordinate geometry.

title: MATH 208x Elementary Probability and Statistics
description: Descriptive statistics, probability, discrete and continuous random variables, expectation and variance, sampling, Central Limit Theorem, estimation, hypothesis testing, correlation and regression. Emphasis on health science.

title: MATH 126g Calculus II
description: : trigonometric functions; applications of integration; techniques of integration; indeterminate forms; infinite series; Taylor series; polar coordinates.

title: MATH 129 Calculus II for Engineers and Scientists
description: Trigonometric functions; applications of integration; techniques of integration; indeterminate forms; infinite series; Taylor series; polar coordinates. Engineering and physics applications.

title: MATH 125g Calculus I
description: Limits; continuity, derivatives and applications; antiderivatives; the fundamental theorem of calculus; exponential and logarithmic functions.

title: MATH 117g Introduction to Mathematics for Business and Economics
description: Functions, graphs, polynomial and rational functions, exponential and logarithmic functions, matrices, systems of linear equations.

title: MATH 118gx Fundamental Principles of Calculus
description: Derivatives; extrema. Definite integral; fundamental theorem of calculus. Extrema and definite integrals for functions of several variables.

title: MATH 114x Foundations of Statistics
description: An introduction to the basic tools of statistics. Descriptive statistics; probability; expected value; normal approximation sampling; chance models; tests of significance.

title: MATH 108g Contemporary Precalculus
description: Equations and inequalities; functions; graphs; polynomial and rational functions; exponential, logarithmic, and trigonometric function; analytic geometry.

title: LING 401 Advanced Phonology
description: Duplicates Credit in former LING 401b.

title: LING 390 Special Problems
description: Supervised, individual studies. No more than one registration permitted. Enrollment by petition only.

title: LING 385L Human Language as Computation
description: Study of language as a complex natural system that requires elaborate mental computation.

title: LING 380 Languages of the World
description: Introduction to the world's linguistic diversity; number of languages spoken and where; grammatical structure and social function of selected languages.

title: LING 375 Sociolinguistics
description: Linguistic and cultural pluralism in the U.S.; distributional and structural characteristics of selected urban and minority dialects; the relationship between dialects and "media standard."

title: LING 322g Language Contact and Language Acquisition
description: The emergence of new languages, spoken and signed, in socio-historical situations, where linguistic input is degraded and insufficient to support the ordinary language acquisition process.

title: LING 325g Language and Number
description: Analysis of the formal properties of linguistic expressions of number with the goal of understanding the structures that underlie language and numerical reasoning.

title: LING 307 Introduction to Speech-Language Pathology
description: Introduces the breadth of possible communication disorders with a particular focus on the duties of the professionals who assist people with these disorders.  Explores both the diagnostic criteria and common interventions for disorders such as Language Impairment, stuttering, swallowing, and dementia.

title: LING 303 Logic and Meaning in Natural Language
description: Introduction to meaning in natural language and the methods from logic applied to its study.

title: LING 301 Introduction to Phonetics and Phonology
description: Duplicates Credit in former LING 401a.

title: LING 302 Introduction to Syntax and Semantics
description: Duplicates Credit in former LING 402a.

title: LING 295g The Ancient Near East: Culture, Archaeology, Texts
description: An investigation of the peoples of the ancient Near East, focusing upon the writings which they produced, their languages and scripts, and their archaeological remains.

title: LING 285Lg Human Language and Technology
description: Study of human linguistic competence and technologies that simulate it. Grammar, parsing, text generation; semantics, pragmatics, sense disambiguation; phonetics, speech synthesis, speech recognition.

title: LING 210g Introduction to Linguistics
description: Empirical study of the sounds and structures of human language; syntax and semantics; language change; linguistic universals.

title: LING 265x Hindi IV
description: Reading of modern Hindi authors, review of grammar, composition, oral conversation, and collateral reading.

title: LING 255 Hindi III
description: ; intensive work in listening comprehension, oral communication, reading and writing short essays; introduction of readings and periodicals related to Hindi culture and civilization.

title: LING 125 Hindi I
description: Introduction to current Hindi. Oral practice, listening and reading comprehension; grammar necessary for simple spoken and written expression.

title: LING 155 Hindi II
description: . Reading of simple Hindi prose, practice in pronunciation, the grammar essential for reading comprehension and writing.

title: LING 115gw Language and Society
description: Discourse patterns among diverse social groups in institutional and interpersonal settings; interrelationships among language practices and gender, socioeconomic status, ethnicity; social structures and cultural values as reflected in language policies and practices.

title: LING 110Lg In a Word
description: Words as a gateway to the human mind. How words are stored, comprehended and retrieved. How words are constructed. Words and concepts. Words and social constructs. The processing and the acquisition of words in normal and atypical children and adults.

title: MATH 040x Basic Mathematical Skills
description: Review of Algebra. Real numbers, linear equations and inequalities, functions, graphs, systems of equations, exponents, polynomials, factoring, rational expressions, radicals, quadratic equations and solutions.

title: LING 374 Language and Society in East Asia
description: The interaction of language with society in countries of East Asia: language and identity, the politicization of language, language change, language and gender.

title: LIM 591 Research and Professional Applications
description: Apply concepts learned during the MMLIS program and investigate research questions and professional problems of concern to employers, their institutions and the profession at large. Open only to Library and Information Science majors.

title: LIM 598 Capstone in Library and Information Management
description: Student-driven research or project-based experience that integrates the knowledge from course work and applies it to current issues in the field.

title: LIM 599 Special Topics in Library and Information Management
description: Selected topics reflecting current trends and recent developments in library and information management.

title: LIM 562 Library and Information Technology Management
description: Overview of management of library information technologies including computer networks, design, architecture, cloud technologies, data management, and technology planning as well as emerging technologies.

title: LIM 560 Rare Books and Manuscripts
description: An overview of the organization, management, public and technical service operations and outreach involved in the development and operation of rare and special collections.

title: LIM 561 Library Program Development and Evaluation
description: An overview of library program development and evaluation with an emphasis upon linking student learning outcomes to library programs. Qualitative and quantitative methods are covered.

title: LIM 559 Marketing and Communications Strategies for Libraries
description: An introduction to essential marketing concepts such as brand platform, value proposition and message development and their application in a library environment.

title: LIM 558 Art and Museum Librarianship
description: An examination and critical analysis of resources, research and literature in art and museum librarianship including collection development and management, access, reference and service patterns.

title: LIM 557 Cinematic Arts Librarianship
description: An examination and critical analysis of resources, research and literature in cinematic arts librarianship, including collection development and management, access, reference and service patterns.

title: LIM 555 Social Science Librarianship
description: An examination and critical analysis of resources, research and literature in social science librarianship, including collection development and management, access, reference and service patterns.

title: LIM 556 Health Sciences Librarianship
description: An examination and critical analysis of resources, research and literature in health sciences librarianship, including collection development and management, access, reference and service patterns.

title: LIM 554 Science Librarianship
description: An examination and critical analysis of resources, research and literature in science librarianship, including collection development and management, access, reference and service patterns.

title: LIM 553 Corporate and Business Librarianship
description: An examination and critical analysis of resources, research and literature in corporate librarianship, including collection development and management, access, reference and service patterns.

title: LIM 552 Strategic Information and Competitive Analysis
description: Searching sophisticated for-fee and free sources of information unique to particular industry client groups, synthesizing and translating information ethically to critical intelligence.

title: LIM 551 Advanced Research Methods in Library and Information Management
description: , this course provides advanced research methods and analytical techniques and the application of these skills to complex library issues.

title: LIM 534 Library Fundraising and Development
description: An overview of fundraising and development including the internal organization of the fundraising and development enterprise, the cultivation of donors and related issues.

title: LIM 550 Information Behaviors, Ethics and Policy
description: A study of information behaviors, policies and ethics including social networks, the interactive effects of information on users, users on information.

title: LIM 533 Operations Research in Libraries
description: Overview of theory and best practices in operations research and how it can be applied in a broad range of library and other information-focused settings.

title: LIM 531 Global Perspectives in Librarianship
description: An investigation of the theory and practice of librarianship in the context of international approaches to knowledge creation, research, learning, information discovery and presentation.

title: LIM 532 The Social Context of Information
description: An examination of information in the context of social networks, media, and other cultural structures that inform teaching, learning and research.

title: LIM 530 Library Resource Management
description: An overview and assessment of planning, design, allocation and implementation of library finance and resource distribution in a variety of settings.

title: LIM 523 Information Delivery in the Digital Environment
description: An inventory and description of digital competencies, assessments and techniques followed by instruction, practice and testing of these competencies in simulated situations.

title: LIM 522 Metadata and Taxonomies
description: An overview of developing and assessing metadata for digital resources including the different types of metadata schema, data dictionaries, taxonomies and emerging metadata standards.

title: LIM 521 Database Management Systems for Information Professionals
description: An overview of and instruction in the skills required to build library and archival relational databases including data integrity, security, maintenance and extraction.

title: LIM 520 Library Information Systems Analysis and Design
description: The analysis and design of information systems from the perspectives of information theory, technology, retrievability, storage and shelf life, copyright, privacy and related issues.

title: LIM 513 Multicultural Information Perspectives
description: An examination of critical issues, theories and research in educating and serving diverse populations with an emphasis on social, cultural and linguistic imperatives.

title: LIM 512 Instructional Technologies for Educators
description: An overview and critical analysis of past and current instructional technologies used primarily in academic libraries.

title: LIM 503 Information Description, Organization, and Retrieval
description: An overview and critical analysis of current practices of information organization, cataloguing, access and reference services, including a conceptual understanding of these skills.

title: LIM 510 Academic Librarianship
description: An examination of current research and future trends in academic librarianship, emphasizing the necessary partnership among information culture and technology, academic research and instruction.

title: LIM 504 Research Methods in Library and Information Management
description: An overview of research methods in information management including the conceptualization of research problems, literature reviews, research design, sampling, measurement, data collection and data analysis. Open only to MMLIS students.

title: LIM 502 Collection Development and Management
description: The development of library collections in all formats emphasizing clientele interest, usage patterns, bibliographical and Website sources. Open only to MMLIS students.

title: LIM 501 Fundamentals of Library Leadership and Management
description: Fundamentals of library leadership and management from past, present and future perspectives, including selected case studies.

title: LIM 511 Instructional Strategies for Information Professionals
description: An overview of research in learning emphasizing the role of academic librarians as instructors and facilitators of information navigation.

title: LIM 500 Fundamentals of Library and Information Science
description: An overview of the history of recorded knowledge from ancient times to the digital age informed by the cultural implications of those eras. Open only to MMLIS students.

title: LBST 599 Special Topics
description: Current issues, trends, and developments in liberal studies.

title: LBST 590 Directed Research
description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

title: LBST 585b Master's Project
description: A summative research project completed in consultation with the student's committee. Departmental approval.

title: LBST 585a Master's Project
description: A summative research project completed in consultation with the student's committee. Departmental approval.

title: LBST 585z Master's Project
description: A summative research project completed in consultation with the student's committee. Departmental approval.

title: LBST 572 Controversies in Science, Medicine and Ethics
