description: Focus on how scientific developments drive ethical issues in medicine. Exploration of ethical dimensions of issues such as stem cells, genetic engineering and reproductive technology.

title: LBST 574 Advances in Genetics and Evolutionary Biology
description: How DNA directs an organism's development and how our DNA can be "read" to understand human diversity, diseases, defects, and evolution.

title: LBST 571 Food, Fashion and Furniture: Commodities in the Global Economy
description: Analysis of commodities from origin to consumption illustrates the global impact of everyday choices.

title: LAW 681 Analytical Methods for Lawyers
description: Teaches important business and economic concepts that will assist with problems lawyers in every practice area routinely encounter.

title: LAW 682 Jessup Moot Court Oral Arguments
description: Students prepare oral arguments on the issues in a problem that is the basis for the Jessup International Moot Court competition. Participation is by faculty selection only.

title: LAW 680b Review of Law and Social Justice Editing
description: Supervision of research and writing, and final editing of articles and comments for publication in the Review of Law and Social Justice. For officers of the Review.

title: LAW 680a Review of Law and Social Justice Editing
description: Supervision of research and writing, and final editing of articles and comments for publication in the Review of Law and Social Justice. For officers of the Review.

title: LAW 679 Review of Law and Social Justice Writing
description: Writing, source-checking, and preliminary editing of articles and comments for publication in the Review of Law and Social Justice.

title: LAW 680 Mediation Theory and Practice
description: Develop knowledge and skills associated with the mediation process as a third party neutral. Explore mediation theories, practices, ethical issues and policies.

title: LAW 678b Review of Law and Social Justice Staff
description: Writing, source-checking, and preliminary editing of articles and comments for publication in the Review of Law and Social Justice. For second-year students serving as staff members on the Review.

title: LAW 678a Review of Law and Social Justice Staff
description: Writing, source-checking, and preliminary editing of articles and comments for publication in the Review of Law and Social Justice. For second-year students serving as staff members on the Review.

title: LAW 675 Mental Health Law
description: Studies the important issues at the intersection of law and psychology/psychiatry, both civil and criminal.

title: LAW 674 Advanced Secured Transactions Workshop
description: Provides hands-on experience in the various tasks typically required in structuring, documenting and closing a personal property secured transaction.

title: LAW 673 Deal Strategy, Structure and Negotiation
description: Examines the legal and business skills, concepts and practices, involved in structuring, drafting and negotiating financing, production and distribution deals in the entertainment industry.

title: LAW 672 Jessup Moot Court Briefs
description: Students prepare for competition by writing a brief on the issues in a problem that is the basis for the Jessup International Moot Court Competition. Participation is by faculty selection only.

title: LAW 670 Advanced Moot Court Oral Arguments
description: Preparation of oral arguments in approved moot court competitions, such as national and state prize rounds (other than Hale Moot Court Program).

title: LAW 671 Advanced Moot Court Briefs
description: Preparation of briefs in approved moot court competitions, such as national and state prize rounds (other than Hale Moot Court Program).

title: LAW 668 Hale Moot Court Oral Advocacy
description: Invitation-only course for students in the Hale Moot Court Honors Program. Students present an oral argument and judge first-year student rounds.

title: LAW 669 Moot Court Supervision
description: Evaluation and supervision of the preparation of briefs and oral arguments in the Hale Moot Court honors competition.

title: LAW 667 Hale Moot Court Brief
description: Invitation-only course offered to second-year students as part of the Hale Moot Court Honors Program. Students write an appellate brief. Open only to students in JD program (including dual degrees).

title: LAW 665 Art Law
description: Provides an overview, often from a litigation perspective, of legal issues affecting artworks and cultural property.

title: LAW 664 Patient Privacy Law
description: Emphasizes the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA) and other important federal and state privacy laws, and their enforcement.

title: LAW 663 Health Care Law, Business and Finance
description: Covers health care business fundamentals, financial risk and return, capital budgeting, and long-term financial analysis and planning, as it relates to law.

title: LAW 662 Public International Law
description: Principles of international law involving relations among governments. The function of international tribunals and organizations.

title: LAW 661 National Security Law
description: Examination of the nature of United States' national security law, focusing on how it is created, violated and enforced.

title: LAW 660 Trademark Law in Practice
description: A rigorous introduction to a law of trademarks. A trademark can be any word, symbol, design, sound, fragrance or product configuration that is used to distinguish the goods or services of one person from those of another, and to indicate the origin of the goods or services.

title: LAW 658 Mergers and Acquisitions
description: Problems of integrating the corporate, securities, tax, business, antitrust, accounting and contractual aspects of corporate mergers and acquisitions.

title: LAW 656 The Business of Entertainment, Media and Technology
description: Introduces aspiring attorneys to important concepts in the entertainment business, and builds context for more advanced courses in entertainment, media, technology and intellectual property law.

title: LAW 659 Legal Issues in the Motion Picture Industry
description: Involves the legal and business principles involved in structuring, negotiating and documenting agreements relating to the development, production and distribution of theatrical motion pictures.

title: LAW 657 International Protection of Intellectual Property
description: The laws concerning how to enforce and exploit rights protecting media creations, marketing symbols, computer programs, new technologies, designs, know-how, and data across national borders.

title: LAW 655 Environmental Law
description: Focus on environmental law policy and practice. This course is a combination of regulatory and private law, with a special emphasis on disputes and regulations involving contamination in soil, water and air.

title: LAW 654 Television and Digital Media
description: An in-depth study of television industry legal concepts, contracts, business structures and economic models.

title: LAW 653 Music Law in Practice
description: Focus on contract drafting and negotiation issues relevant to an artist's pursuit of a career in the music business.

title: LAW 652 Cyber Crime and Policy
description: Examines the legal and policy issues involved with the emergence of cyber crimes and cyber security issues, including government access and privacy issues.

title: LAW 650 Entertainment Law
description: An examination of how the courts are handling selected, "cutting edge" topics in entertainment law. The topics will include the scope of and limitations on the right of publicity; fair use and parody defenses to copyright infringement; future technology clauses in rights contracts; and copyright and defamation issues arising in the online world.

title: LAW 651 Entertainment Law Practicum
description: Supervised internship for students enrolled in

title: LAW 649 Insurance
description: The pooling of risks and distributing of losses. Actuarial foundation and contract problems of insurance.

title: LAW 648 Topics in Entertainment Law
description: Contemporary topics in the field of entertainment law.

title: LAW 647 Bankruptcy: Debtors and Creditors I
description: Bankruptcy of the poor, imprudent or unlucky, and of unsuccessful businesses. The mechanisms of our law for distributing the debtor's property and discharging his obligations.

title: LAW 646 Advanced Topics in Employment Discrimination
description: Reviews recent Supreme Court decisions and legal scholarship with attention to statutory interpretation, consistency with constitutional antidiscrimination standards, and consistency with current understandings about discrimination.

title: LAW 645 Transactional Practice — The Syndicated Loan Agreement
description: Involves issues including loan restructuring; what loan agreements cover; how representations, covenants, default and financial and repayment terms interrelate; and how security documents fit in.

title: LAW 643 Securities Fraud Litigation
description: Examination of the laws governing fraud in securities markets. Focus on several sections of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, including fraudulent statements and insider trading, fraud in the takeover context, fraud in proxies, and controlling personal liability.

title: LAW 644 Corporate Taxation
description: Tax principles and practice applicable to business, especially problems of formation, liquidation, and reorganization.

title: LAW 642 Secured Transactions
description: This is a course on Chattel paper and secured transactions involving personal property under Article 9 of the Uniform Commercial Code and some related bodies of law.

title: LAW 641 Commercial Law
description: Commercial transactions involving secured financing (other than land). Government regulation of such sales and borrowing through Article 9 of the Uniform Consumer Credit Code and other recent legislation.

title: LAW 640 Financial Institution Regulation
description: Introduces foundational concepts on general financial institution compliance, including compliance methods and regulatory rules affecting banks, securities firms, funds, and financial services.

title: LAW 639 Law and Literature
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: LAW 638 Topics in Alternative Dispute Resolution
description: Examines selected topics in negotiation, mediation, or alternative dispute resolution. May be repeated with permission of the instructor as topics vary.

title: LAW 637 International Trade Policy
description: Examination of the institutions and laws that regulate international economic relations. Students will be introduced to the major international agreements and national laws that regulate international trade goods, services and capital.

title: LAW 636 Labor Law
description: The interrelation of labor, business, and government in collective bargaining, federal regulation of union and management practices and pressures, especially through the Taft-Hartley Act.

title: LAW 635 Employment Discrimination Law
description: Examines the regulation of employment discrimination under federal law. Pays primary attention to issues of race, sex, age and disability discrimination.

title: LAW 634 Legal Analysis of Evidence
description: Legal analysis of the rules of Evidence using problems designed to improve analytic skills and problem-solving. Taken in conjunction with Evidence.

title: LAW 633 Business Principles in Law
description: Focuses on fundamental business concepts, including, business strategy, management, sales and marketing, finance and risk, as they relate to law.

title: LAW 632 Business for Lawyers
description: This course introduces law students to the tools, concept, and language of business. It is premised on the belief that to excel as a business lawyer, one must understand the business world from the perspective of the clients one counsels and assists. The course will cover, in compressed form, the basic subjects from the MBA program which are most useful to lawyers.

title: LAW 631 Mediation Clinic II
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: LAW 630 Mediation Clinic I
description: Students receive the training required to become professional mediators for civil cases in the L.A. County Superior Court, and mediate these cases.

title: LAW 629 Real Estate Law and Business II (Finance and Development)
description: A survey of the major types of financing used for real estate and the basic techniques used to make real estate investment and financing decisions.

title: LAW 628 Real Estate Problems
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: LAW 627 Business Planning
description: Covers each phase of the structuring, formation, financing and operation of a new media enterprise.

title: LAW 626 International Investment Law and Arbitration
description: Provides students with understanding of protection offered to foreign investment and investors through bilateral investment treaties and multilateral and regional investment and free trade agreements.

title: LAW 624 Water Law
description: Covers the regulation of groundwater and surface water by the courts and the State Water Resources Control Board.

title: LAW 625 Remedies
description: Comparison of the remedial goals of contracts, torts, and property and the impact of procedural devices in law and equity. Damages, injunctions, specific performance and restitution. Remedial theory and transactional application.

title: LAW 622 Money in Politics
description: Studies the statutes and cases governing campaign finance in America and the latest research into their effects.

title: LAW 619 Employment Law
description: Examination of the evolving role of work in our society and the nature and scope of legal regulation of the employment relationship.

title: LAW 618 Advanced Contracts
description: Students work in groups using principles of contract design analyzing concrete cases based on actual events in transactions handled by a large commercial law firm.

title: LAW 617 History of American Law
description: Explores the interaction of law, culture, and politics in American society from the Revolution through the New Deal.

title: LAW 620 Mortgage Law
description: Deals with the rights and remedies of mortgage lenders and borrowers after the mortgage loan has gone into default.

title: LAW 616 Restitution
description: Comprehensive study of restitution, the common law action for unjust enrichment. Addresses unjust enrichment as a freestanding wrong, not just as a remedy.

title: LAW 614 Accounting for Lawyers
description: The lawyer's skills needed to understand the financial affairs of a business client.

title: LAW 615 Election Law
description: Consideration of legal regulation of the right to vote and otherwise to participate in the electoral process.

title: LAW 612 California Civil Procedure
description: Examines the California rules of civil procedure. Emphasizes California law, with some discussion of the differences between state and federal procedure.

title: LAW 613 Corporate Governance
description: Examines the purpose, evolution and history of corporate governance standards, priorities and culture of boards, shareholder/stakeholder engagement, and corporate social responsibility, as it relates to law.

title: LAW 610 Antidiscrimination Law
description: Surveys federal constitutional and statutory mechanisms designed to fulfill the promise of equality under the law.

title: LAW 611 Advanced Topics in Constitutional Law
description: Seminar for students who aspire to write publishable research articles or notes on constitutional law topics.

title: LAW 609 Contemporary Issues in Human Resource Compliance
description: Explores regulations and compliance issues as well as related problem-solving techniques in the workplace.

title: LAW 608 Evidence
description: The purpose and character of trial. Problems of adversary presentation and the nature of proof. The basis for admission and exclusion of evidence in judicial proceedings.

title: LAW 605 Real Estate Law and Business I (Transactions)
description: The land transfer process: arrangements between buyers and sellers, brokers, escrows, recorders, title companies. Real estate financing through mortgages and other land security devices.

title: LAW 606 Land Use Controls
description: Concentrates on the major topics of Land Use and Environmental law in the 21st Century.

title: LAW 607 Gifts, Wills, and Trusts
description: Gratuitous transfer of wealth, especially the transmission of wealth from one generation to the next as a settlement of family affairs. Comparative analysis of the legal mechanisms of gifts, wills, and trusts. Introduction to problems of fiduciary administration.

title: LAW 604 Real Estate Transactions Problems
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: LAW 603 Business Organizations
description: Organization of economic activity — especially the modern corporation — as institutions of social power. The roles of managers, owners, and public regulatory agencies in shaping processes of decision-making.

title: LAW 602 Criminal Procedure
description: Criminal procedure in the courts, and the regulation of law enforcement by the courts through rules of evidence and interpretation of the Bill of Rights.

title: LAW 601 Advanced Legal Writing Practicum
description: Requires students to draft legal documents they were not exposed to in the first-year writing course, such as client letters, demand letters, and contracts.

title: LAW 600 Taxation
description: Federal tax statutes, technical issues and social problems involved in tax planning, tax litigation, and reform of the tax laws.

title: LAW 599 Special Topics
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: LAW 598 Regulatory Compliance
description: Provides an overview of regulatory compliance law and the ways that various organizations ensure compliance with governing laws and regulations.

title: LAW 596 Internship for Curricular Practical Training
description: Part-time or full-time, practical work experience in the student's field of study. The internship must be located at an off-campus facility. Students are individually supervised by faculty. May not be taken until the student has completed at least one semester of enrollment in the graduate program with a cumulative 3.0 GPA.

title: LAW 580 Wicked Problems Practicum
description: A year-long project addressing an urgent public policy issue that is both multifaceted and intractable.

title: LAW 574 Health Care Compliance
description: Provides background on about the importance of compliance for health care organizations and legal challenges facing the health care industry.

title: LAW 579 Global Regulatory Compliance
description: Introduction to regimes that regulate business practices on a global level and compliance of such regimes, such as Foreign Corrupt Practices Act, OECD Anti-Bribery Convention, and other regulations.

title: LAW 572 Practical Mediation Skills Clinic
description: Students learn basic and advanced mediation skills, practice their skills in simulated mediations, and upon certification by the instructor, mediate in the Los Angeles County courts.

title: LAW 571 Organizational Conflict
description: Origin and types of conflicts which arise within organizations. Designing systems to prevent conflict from developing or escalating and developing a culture of collaboration and creativity.

title: LAW 570 ADR Legal Principles
description: Survey course for students who have not earned a J.D. in a U.S. law school to gain an understanding of the legal framework for the dispute resolution processes in which they participate.

title: LAW 573 ADR Specialized Study
description: ADR Specialized Study projects reflect substantial research and study which result in meaningful written work, generally 10 to 15 pages in length per unit of credit.

title: MPVA 440 Italian and French Diction
description: Principles of pronunciation and enunciation; use of international phonetic alphabet.

title: MPVA 438 Foundations of Vocology
description: Voice physiology, voice hygiene, voice acoustics, and the cognitive substrates of Motor Learning.

title: MPVA 412 Musical Theatre Workshop II
description: Stylistic and technical features of dramatic and musical elements involved in performance of the Broadway musical and standard operetta repertory; staging of scenes.

title: MPVA 407 Directing for the Operatic Stage
description: Various approaches to operatic style; basic blocking; stage management. Student direction of scenes produced in USC Opera.

title: MPVA 406 Opera Coaching Techniques
description: Score study for pianists, coaches, and conductors; role analysis; transcription techniques for one or two pianos of an orchestral score.

title: MPVA 405 USC Opera
description: Preparation, rehearsal, and performance of operatic works and excerpts; study of different operatic styles; public appearances. By audition only.

title: MPVA 404 Word and Music in Opera
description: Performance class for singers and pianists; analysis of recitatives, arias, and ensembles of various operatic styles; study of the technique of effective musical delivery. By audition only.

title: MPVA 403 Acting for Singers II
description: . Acting of operatic roles in different periods and styles; specific recital and audition techniques.

title: MPVA 390 Special Problems
description: Supervised, individual studies. No more than one registration permitted. Enrollment by petition only.

title: MPVA 402 Musical Theatre Workshop I
description: Study of the acting, musical and movement elements involved in the performance of the Broadway musical repertoire.

title: MPVA 353 Individual Instruction
description: Weekly individual instruction and vocal performance forum.

title: MPVA 301 Individual Instruction
description: Intermediate and advanced instruction: secondary emphasis for music majors, principal emphasis for music minors and all BA music majors.

title: MPVA 253 Individual Instruction
description: Weekly individual instruction and vocal performance forum.

title: MPVA 241 Intermediate Class Voice
description: Continued development of the fundamentals of singing, diction, and repertoire building.

title: MPVA 300x Non-Major Individual Instruction
description: Credit Restriction: Not available for credit to music majors

title: MPVA 203b Acting for Singers I
description: Use of dramatic techniques in the interpretation and performance of music; basic acting techniques for the operatic and recital stages; sensory exercises, movement, improvisation, relaxation and make-up.

title: MPVA 203a Acting for Singers I
description: Use of dramatic techniques in the interpretation and performance of music; basic acting techniques for the operatic and recital stages; sensory exercises, movement, improvisation, relaxation and make-up.

title: MPVA 153 Individual Instruction
description: Weekly individual instruction and vocal performance forum.

title: MPVA 101x Non-Major Beginning Individual Instruction
description: Individual instruction at the beginning level designed for non-music majors with no previous experience.

title: MPVA 141 Class Voice
description: Introduction to the fundamental principles of singing: breath control, tone production, diction, and the use of appropriate song material.

description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

description: Contemporary advances in molecular pharmacology and toxicology research. Registration required during each year of residency.

title: MPTX 790 Research
description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

title: MPTX 602 Science, Research and Ethics
description: A discussion of the unique technological and philosophical issues that challenge modern scientists and a discernment of ethical responses to those challenges.

title: MPTX 630 Directed Field-Research Project
description: Research/policy analysis conducted under preceptor supervision in an industrial or governmental setting.

title: MPTX 594z Master's Thesis

description: Special topics in Molecular Pharmacology and Toxicology.

description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: MPTX 590 Directed Research
description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

title: MPTX 526 Chemistry Manufacturing and Controls
description: Provides a firm foundation in the domestic and international CMC process, from concept to commercialization of new active pharmaceutical ingredients and products.

title: MPTX 522 Introduction to Clinical Trial Design and Statistics
description: Clinical designs and statistics commonly used to test medical products in general populations and special patient groups.

title: MPTX 519 Global Regulation of Medical Products
description: Regulatory requirements governing medical products in European Union, Asia and other global markets.

title: MPTX 524 Introduction to Food Science and Technology
description: Discusses the basic and applied concepts of food science and food safety, and demonstrates the principles of food chemistry, sensory evaluation, and product development.

title: MPTX 518 Writing Regulatory Drug Submissions
description: Developing form and content for investigational drug applications, new drug applications, biologic licensing applications to FDA; common technical documents; considerations of writing style.

title: MPTX 517 Structure and Management of Clinical Trials
description: Development and execution of clinical trials: bioethical principles, good clinical practices, project management and documentation.

title: MPTX 516 Medical Products and the Law
description: undergraduate degree in pharmacy, medicine or independent health sciences, engineering or equivalent mix of post-secondary training and industry experience.

title: MPTX 514 Regulation of Food and Dietary Supplements
description: undergraduate degree in pharmacy, medicine or independent health sciences, engineering or equivalent mix of post-secondary training and industry experience.

title: MPTX 515 Quality Systems and Standards
description: undergraduate degree in pharmacy, medicine or independent health sciences, engineering or equivalent mix of post-secondary training and industry experience.

title: MPTX 512 Regulation of Pharmaceutical and Biological Products
description: Ensuring safety and effectiveness of new drugs and biologics; marketing and monitoring approved pharmaceutical/biological products; management of genetically engineered products.

title: MPTX 513 Regulation of Medical Devices and Diagnostics
description: undergraduate degree in pharmacy, medicine or independent health sciences, engineering or equivalent mix of post-secondary training and industry experience.

title: MPTX 511 Introduction to Medical Product Regulation
description: Introduction to regulatory environments surrounding medical product development, manufacturing and marketing; operation of federal, state and international regulatory bodies.

title: MPTX 500 Molecular Pharmacology and Toxicology I
description: This is the first part of a two-semester introductory and survey course for the molecular pharmacology and toxicology degree program.

title: MPTX 501 Molecular Pharmacology and Toxicology II
description: The second part of the two-semester course covers the general aspects of molecular pharmacology and toxicology on the basis of biochemical, molecular, biological and environmental approaches.

title: MPST 754 Artist Diploma Performance
description: Individual instruction and related lab participation for Artist Diploma students.

title: MPST 599 Special Topics
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: MPST 590 Directed Research
description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: MPST 472 Orchestra Repertoire – Strings
description: Orchestral literature for string players, covering a broad spectrum of the repertoire; emphasis on preparation for auditions.

title: MPST 471b String Pedagogy

title: MPST 471a String Pedagogy
description: Survey of teaching literature; techniques of teaching beginning, intermediate, and advanced students.

title: MPST 463 Harp Performance Class
description: . Required of all third and fourth year harp majors each semester in residence.

title: MPST 263 Harp Performance Class
description: Study of solo and orchestra repertoire, professional preparation, and teaching technique. Required of all first and second year harp majors each semester in residence.

title: MPST 301 Individual Instruction
description: Intermediate and advanced instruction on secondary instrument for music majors, on principal instrument for music minors and BA music majors.

title: MPST 262 Double Bass Performance Class
description: Study of solo and orchestra repertoire, professional preparation, and teaching techniques. Required of all first and second year double bass majors each semester in residence.

title: MPST 300x Non-Major Individual Instruction
description: Intermediate and advanced instruction designed for non-music majors.

title: MPST 153 Individual Instruction
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: MPST 253 Individual Instruction
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: MPST 163 Class Harp
description: Basic instruction in the fundamentals of solo harp playing, note reading, and basic musicianship.

title: MPST 101x Non-Major Beginning Individual Instruction
description: Individual instruction at the beginning level designed for non-music majors with no previous experience.

title: MPPM 790 Research
description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

title: MPPM 599 Special Topics
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: MPPM 590 Directed Research
description: Research leading to the Master's Degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

title: MPPM 499 Special Topics
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: MPPM 450a Final Project
description: Major collaborative performance project in popular music.

title: MPPM 450b Final Project
description: Major collaborative performance project in popular music.

title: MPPM 490x Directed Research
description: Registration Restriction: Open only to juniors and seniors.

title: MPPM 370 The Vocal Edge: Contemporary Vocal Performance Techniques
description: A study of the practical aspects of vocal performance and skills necessary to increase one's opportunities within the music industry.

title: MPPM 420 Popular Music Performance Styles and Genres
description: The detailed exploration of a specific style or genre in Popular Music through study of repertoire, history and practice with particular emphasis on performance.

title: MPPM 325a Arranging in Popular Music
description: Principles and techniques of arranging for voice and rhythm section in the popular music idiom.

title: MPPM 350g A History of Popular Music
description: The history of popular music particularly as developed in America in the 20

title: MPPM 340 Intermediate Drum Set Proficiency
description: Intermediate level instruction in drum set performance including accompaniment techniques, fills, beat and brush patterns in jazz, Afro-Caribbean and Brazilian styles, interpreting drum charts.

title: MPPM 325b Arranging in Popular Music
description: Writing and arranging for small groups of brass, wind, and/or string instruments with rhythm section in the popular music idiom.

title: MPPM 320 Popular Music Performance II
description: Development of ensemble and communication skills through the performance and interpretation of American popular music in concert and studio settings. Development of original compositions.

title: MPPM 301 Individual Instruction
description: Intermediate and advanced instruction on secondary instrument for all majors and minors except MPPM.

title: LBST 555 Constructions of Childhood
description: Analysis of the concept of childhood from its 18th-century origins. Applications of age studies, language, and cultural construction through fiction, history, film, and other media.

title: MPPM 253 Individual Instruction
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: LBST 554 Century City: 100 Years of LA Literature and Culture
description: The history of Los Angeles since 1910, using literary, historical, autobiographical, and cinematic texts to consider issues of geography, economics, race, class, gender, and sexuality.

title: LBST 550 Theories and Methods of Analysis in Cultural Studies
description: Development of cultural studies as a fast-growing area of intellectual inquiry. Case study analysis of race/ethnicity, history and memory, space, postmodernism, globalization, censorship, and originality.

title: LBST 551 Narrative Forms
description: Study of narrative in literature, film, sociology, psychology and history; how narrative conventions shape humans' experience and understanding of society, past and present.

title: LBST 548 Contemporary Fiction in Social Context
description: Study of novels and short stories to examine how societal pressures and cultural identity constrain individual actions, with attention to family, gender, class, ethnicity, others. Open only to graduate students.

title: LBST 547 Acts of Interpretation: Literature, Film, and Methodology
description: Analysis of literature, film, and methodologies for approaching issues of interpretation, readership, and spectatorship. Examination of how interpretation varies across gender, race, class, and sexuality.

title: LBST 545 Imagining the American West
description: Explores Western myths and realities through literature, history, film, and painting. Examines why American culture places questions about national pasts and futures in the West.

title: LBST 542 The Culture of Comedy
description: Historical and synchronic ideas of comedy. Ways in which philosophers, artists, and everyday individuals adapt in our ever-changing world.

title: LBST 544 Representations of Los Angeles
description: Study of literary, artistic and/or dramatic expressions of Los Angeles and its inhabitants in modern and historical literature, art, photography, film, television, and architecture.

title: LBST 541 Opera, Culture, History, and Thought
description: Analysis of cultural, historic, philosophical, political, and literary movements and themes through the medium of opera.

title: LBST 540 Hell, Purgatory, and Paradise: Dante's Divine Comedy
description: In-depth reading and analysis of Divine Comedy, in order to develop appreciation for changing values from medieval, to Renaissance and contemporary culture.

title: LBST 537 Empire and Social Reform in America 1890–1917
description: Analysis through literary and historical texts of American public life, culture, and social justice during the era of U.S. ascendancy as a world power.

title: LBST 535 Great Works, Great Challenges
description: Analysis of works of literature, drama, and poetry and their relationship to their historical contexts.

title: LBST 531 The Hero/Heroine in History
description: Analysis of human agency in history and whether individual men and women are capable of altering the course of history by their actions.

title: LBST 532 Ideas on Trial
description: Examination of great trials in history as indicators of changing social and cultural attitudes.

title: LBST 530 Portraits of Leadership
description: Analysis of different forms of cultural leadership in their historical, literary, and philosophical context.

title: LBST 527 Information Systems From Libraries to the Internet
description: History and sociology of information systems. Philosophical and literary implications of writing, archives, libraries, printing, and publishing from the ancient world to the Internet age.

title: LBST 525 The Revolution That Made America
description: Ideas and politics of the world's first modern revolution, which transformed 13 colonies into a nation.

title: LBST 516 Urban Conservation Biology
description: Analysis of plant and animal distribution in urban landscapes. Exploration of major threats to urban biodiversity and nature conservation controversies and successes.

title: LBST 520 Tradition and the Modern World
description: Studies the continuing interplays between tradition and novelty; between locale and globalization; and between heritage and post-modernity with a focus on a specific locale.

title: LBST 514 Ideas of Nature in American Culture
description: Examination of how Americans have used nature to think about themselves, environmentalism, American identity, gender/class relations, the American West, and the mythology of Los Angeles.

title: LBST 512 Language in a Globalizing World
description: Examination of the relationship between language and geopolitical change, endangered and minority languages, and the public policy implications of multilingualism and multiculturalism.

title: LBST 510 Cities and Globalization
description: Contemporary urban theory and comparative urban analysis. Emphasis on the role of globalization in shaping urban form and problems.

title: LBST 507 Great Western Cities
description: Examination of Western civilization in the urban context, focusing on several great cities in their "golden age" of creativity, accomplishment, and influence.

title: LBST 505 East Asian Humanities: Classics of China, Korea, and Japan
description: Examination of major themes in East Asian culture through primary texts in translation.

title: LBST 503 Self-Justifying Fictions
description: Theoretical approaches to the study of literature, including formal and cultural analysis and the ethics and social impact of the humanities.

title: LAW 894 Advanced Mediation Clinic
description: Students learn mediation skills, conduct live mediations and help to run the regular Mediation Clinic.

title: LBST 500 Introduction to Liberal Studies: Methods of Knowing
description: Introduction to research methods in the social sciences, humanities, and natural sciences; then methods for applied interdisciplinary research.

title: LAW 893 Advanced Clinical Training
description: For third-year students who wish to continue their clinical training.

title: LAW 892 Post-Conviction Justice Seminar II
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: LAW 890 Directed Research
description: One CR/D/F unit for a research proposal approved by a full- or part-time faculty supervisor; up to four graded units with academic dean's approval of proposal by LLM or third-year JD student to produce a publishable paper under full-time professor.

title: LAW 891 Post-Conviction Justice Seminar I
description: Examines the substantive rights of federal prisoners with respect to parole, sentencing, validity of conviction and conditions of confinement and the procedural mechanisms by which to enforce those rights. Under faculty supervision, students provide legal assistance to federal inmates in administrative and judicial proceedings.

title: LAW 889 Law Informed by Faith
description: Considers the role of faith in a lawyer's life and work. Discusses issues in constitutional law, tort law, criminal law, professional responsibility and more.

title: LAW 888 First Amendment: Law and Religion
description: Explores the laws that govern and affect religious groups and religious belief-systems and religious experience in the United States.

title: LAW 887 Religious Freedom and its Limits
description: Surveys constitutional doctrines pertaining to the Free Exercise and Establishment Clauses of the First Amendment and the emergent doctrine regarding the application of the federal Religious Freedom Restoration Act and its state offspring.

title: LAW 886 Justice and the Foundations of Liberalism
description: Discusses John Rawls' A Theory of Justice (1971), critical reactions to it and some possible extensions of Rawls' theory of justice.

title: LAW 885 Advanced Legal Writing: A Partnership with Public Counsel
description: Write office memoranda and sample pleadings modeled after real legal issues faced by attorneys at Public Counsel.

title: LAW 884 Constitutional Law: Equality and Liberty
description: Focuses on individual rights and liberties, with special attention paid to equal protection and substantive due process.

title: LAW 883 Advanced Legal Writing for International Business Lawyers
description: Develop communication skills for international transactional practice. Practice drafting memoranda, letters, and other communications to partners, clients, and other attorneys. Practice negotiation in intercultural setting.

title: LAW 882 Advanced Legal Writing for Pretrial Practice
description: Hone written advocacy skills for pretrial litigation practice. Draft motions, letters, and other communications to court, opposing counsel, and client. Practice oral communication through exercises.

title: LAW 881 Constitutional Innovation
description: Examines the U.S. Constitution in transnational perspective. The focus is democracy; slavery, emancipation, and freedom; empire; and governmental structures.

title: LAW 880 Treating Difference Equally
description: Comparative look at the legal treatment of religious, cultural, gender and sexual differences and differences in physical and mental ability.

title: LAW 879 Future Property Interests
description: Combines state and national statutory and common laws relating to present and future property interests important to the preparation of gifts, trusts, wills and deeds.

title: LBST 502 The Anthropology of Popular Culture
description: The relationship between anthropology and popular culture is explored through a critical examination of the category "popular culture."

title: LAW 878 Evolutionary Game Theory and the Law
description: Uses the Evolutionary Game Theory methodology to explore the dynamics of cooperative interaction among people, and the role that legal punishment plays.

title: LAW 875 Current Constitutional Problems Seminar
description: Seminar course devoted to different methods of reading the Constitution.

title: LAW 874 Media Law in the Digital Age
description: Explores the interplay between the law, politics, and media, particularly mass media, in the digital age.

title: LAW 877 Major Trends in American Legal Thought
description: Survey of major trends in American legal thought.

title: LAW 872 Advanced Legal Writing and Advocacy: Appellate Advocacy
description: Students will research, write, and rewrite an appellate brief and may work on motions and oral advocacy as well.

title: LAW 873 Judicial Opinion Writing
description: Students write a majority opinion and a dissenting opinion based on cases pending before the U.S. Supreme Court. This is a writing-intensive course.

title: LAW 871 First Amendment
description: Freedom of expression (political speech, symbolic expression, obscenity, commercial speech, defamation), rights of access to the media, religious protection and prohibition of establishment of religion.

title: LAW 870 Legal Writing Fellows
description: Assist in teaching writing and advocacy. Responsibilities include helping prepare lesson plans and drafting writing assignments and sample answers; leading class exercises; and judging first-year moot court practice rounds.

title: LAW 869 Family Law Mediation Clinic
description: Teaches the skills and substantive area of the law necessary to successfully mediate cases in the Edelman Children's courthouse in Monterey Park.

title: LAW 868 Business Enterprise Taxation
description: Examination of the taxation of corporations, partnerships, and limited liability companies.

title: LAW 867 Corporate Fraud
description: Introduces law students to the real world issues of major civil and criminal corporate fraud.

title: LAW 866 Counterterrorism, Privacy and Civil Liberties
description: Explores the spectrum of interrelated legal and policy issues known as "homeland security" since the events of September 11, 2001.

title: LAW 865 Legislative Policy Practicum
description: Provides students with an opportunity to participate in realworld advocacy on juvenile justice issues.

title: LAW 864 Sovereign Debt
description: Examines the legal regimes that exist to address the problems that arise when a sovereign cannot pay back what it owes.

title: LAW 863 International Negotiations and Mediation
description: Introduction to negotiation and mediation from an international perspective. Development of essential skills for effective client representation in negotiation and mediation.

title: LAW 861 International Law Seminar
description: Investigation of selected problems of international law. May be repeated with permission of the instructor as topics vary.

title: LAW 862 Iraqi Refugee Assistance Project Seminar
description: Formally instructs students on U.S. and international refugee law and policy regarding the Iraqi refugee humanitarian crisis.

title: LAW 860 International Criminal Law
description: Covers the prosecution, trial and punishment of individuals suspected of crimes considered among the most serious violations of international humanitarian and human rights law.

title: LAW 859 Communications Law: Internet, Television and Other Media
description: Concentrates on the regulation of broadcast television, cable television, telephone, and spectrum management.

title: LAW 858 Law and Psychology
description: Examines the psychological factors that hinder the making of accurate factual findings.

title: LAW 857 Legal Design Challenge
description: Students develop a proposal in response to the call for solutions to global supply chains problems from the Hague Institute for the Internationalisation of Law.

title: LAW 856 Transnational Human Rights Litigation
description: Provides an introduction to the legal and political issues raised by cases involving international human right violations.

title: LAW 855 Topics in Maritime and Admiralty Law
description: Taught in honor of James Ackerman, USC Law graduate of 1948, this class examines selected topics in maritime and admiralty law. May be repeated with permission of the instructor as topics vary.

title: LAW 854 Legal Design Lab
description: Students work in teams to develop innovative ways of addressing shortcomings in our legal systems to improve access, quality, efficiency and global integration and prosperity.

title: LAW 851 Topics in Criminal Law and Criminology
description: Selected topics in criminal law or criminology. May be repeated with permission of the instructor as topics vary.

title: LAW 850 International Human Rights Clinic II
description: Continuation of the International Human Rights Clinic.

title: LAW 849 International Human Rights Clinic I
description: Students work under close faculty supervision on cases and projects that involve the application of international law to address human rights violations.

title: LAW 847 Refugee and Forced Migration Law
description: Examines refugee law and forced migration, including the causes and consequences of forced migration and the responses to forced migration.

title: LAW 846 Mathematical Modeling of Law and Society
description: Explores the use of mathematical modeling as a way of describing the dynamic relationships between legal regulation and the social behavior that law regulates.

title: LAW 845 Negotiation Skills
description: Develops students' negotiating skills through role plays, reflection and instructor feedback.

title: LAW 844 Prepare for Trial Like a Master
description: Allows students to practice trial techniques and covers cutting-edge techniques in trial preparation.

title: LAW 843 Tax Policy Seminar
description: Students will write and present papers discussing topics in tax policy.

title: LAW 842 Partnership Taxation
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: LAW 841 Copyright, Trademark and Related Rights
description: An introductory survey of statutory and case law, and underlying policy issues, concerning copyright, trademark and certain related legal rights.

title: LAW 840 Copyright and Fictional Characters
description: Involves the treatment of fictional characters by the courts and in new media and the fundamental copyright concepts that have shaped that treatment.

title: LAW 839 Copyright Law in Practice
description: Study of federal copyright law, analysis of property rights and interests created thereunder. Manner in which these rights can be exploited in the various entertainment media.

title: LAW 838 Patent Drafting and Prosecution
description: Students learn how to prepare and prosecute U.S. patent applications, as well as an overview of design and foreign patent prosecution.

title: LAW 837 Diversity: Legal and Social Perspectives
description: Examine legal and social perspectives on the concept of diversity.

title: LAW 835 Transactional Due Diligence
description: Prepares students to handle due diligence projects at the level of a first-year or second-year transactional associate through hands-on, practical training.

title: LAW 834 Veterans Legal Practicum
description: Allows students to hone their legal skills while representing veterans of the United States Armed Forces in administrative proceedings.

title: LAW 833 Labor Arbitration
description: Introduces students to the National Labor Relations Act, collective bargaining and the labor arbitration process. Students also prepare labor arbitration briefs.

title: LAW 831 International Business Negotiations
description: Simulated negotiation of an international transaction; will address legal and related business issues that commonly arise in international deals.

title: LAW 830 Law Firm Economics and the Public Interest
description: Introduces students to the tools needed to work in a large law firm pro bono practice.

title: LAW 829 Cross-Cultural Dispute Resolution
description: Brings an international perspective to understanding the impact of culture in the most commonly used international and domestic dispute resolution practices (negotiation, mediation, and arbitration).

title: LAW 828 Mediation Advocacy
description: Introduces students to the process of mediation, explores the philosophical approaches to mediation and different styles of mediating, develops a working knowledge of the stages of mediation, and cultivates students' skills to become effective advocates throughout each stage of the process.

title: LAW 827 Counseling the Startup Company
description: Role of the attorney in startup firms: business plan, employment agreements, lease, stock option plan, financing documents and distribution and strategic partnership arrangements.

title: LAW 826 Employment Dispute Mediation
description: Provides hands-on experience in mediation of the complex issues of disability, wage and hour, sex and sex harassment, age, race, religion, and national origin.

title: LAW 825 International Arbitration Competition
description: Covers basic aspects of international commercial arbitration and prepares a USC Law School team for participation in the Willem C. Vis International Commercial Arbitration Moot.

title: LAW 824 Arbitration Advocacy
description: Helps students understand the basic approaches to preparing and presenting cases in the arbitration context.

title: LAW 823 Statutory Interpretation
description: Examines the change and evolution of law to discover its political roots and the ways policy making branches work to make and implement law.

title: LAW 822 Alternative Dispute Resolution Clause Drafting
description: Explores a variety of contract provisions, and teaches students the important drafting skills necessary to achieve a client's goal.

title: LAW 820 Pretrial Advocacy
description: Examines conceptual and practical aspects of interviewing, counseling, negotiation, settlement, drafting, and formal advocacy in the handling of legal cases.

title: LAW 821 Trial Advocacy
description: Examines decision-making by counsel in the litigation of cases. Emphasis is given to decisions involving tactics and strategies and their implications for the functioning of legal institutions and substantive doctrine. Extensive use of simulated trial practice exercises.

title: LAW 819 ADR Ethics
description: Provides law students, lawyers and professional neutrals with an in-depth examination of the rules guiding our behavior in various dispute resolution processes.

title: LAW 816 Dealmaking in the Entertainment Industry
description: Examines the major components of deals in the entertainment industry, and provides students the opportunity to learn real-world negotiating skills in the process.

title: LAW 815 Deals
description: Examines the collaboration between business people aiming to accomplish a goal and lawyers translating their business objectives into contract language to achieve the goal.

title: LAW 814 Current Issues in Alternative Dispute Resolution
description: Examines the current issues and topics that practitioners face when seeking to resolve conflicts with the help of ADR.

title: LAW 812 Patent Litigation
description: Provides students with a deep immersion into federal court litigation, with a focus on effective oral and written advocacy in the context of patent litigation.

title: LAW 813 Arbitration in the United States
description: Introduces students to the range of issues addressed by the Federal Arbitration Act and state arbitration laws.

title: LAW 809 Deposition Strategies and Techniques
description: Emphasizes strategies and tactics in asking and objecting to questions at a deposition in a civil case. Students will conduct mock depositions.

title: LAW 811 Health Law and Policy
description: Explores the statutes and regulations that govern the health care system and the policies that shape its development.

title: LAW 808 Medical-Legal Community Partnership Seminar and Practicum
description: Medical and law students, in conjunction with public policy advocates, work together to identify and improve health outcomes for vulnerable populations.

title: LAW 810 Patent Law
description: Patent laws, litigation, and the process of prosecuting the patent application. The concept of invention and ownership of rights under patents.

title: LAW 804 Information Privacy Law
description: Surveys the legal framework concerning information privacy in the U.S., including developments in constitutional, tort, contract, property and statutory law to address emerging privacy threats.

title: LAW 801 Venture Capital and Emerging Companies
description: Introduces students to the unique legal and financial aspects of the venture capital industry and the skills needed to represent entrepreneurs and venture capital investors.

title: LAW 802 Psychology for Lawyers
description: Exposes students to the psychological research on cognitive errors and biases that threaten to compromise a lawyer's performance. Also examines ethical issues and professional happiness.

title: LAW 798 Law, Mental Health and Ethics
description: Focuses on one or two topics per year at the intersection of law, mental health and ethics and explores them from an interdisciplinary perspective.

title: LAW 793 Law and Economics Seminar
description: Key concepts and cutting-edge research in law and economics. Workshops with leading scholars from around the country.

title: LAW 792 Law and Philosophy
description: Examination of the best scholarly work currently done by legal, moral and political philosophers. Open only to law students.

title: LAW 796 Immigration Clinic II
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: LAW 791 Law and Society
description: Examines where the law comes from, how it operates in society, and how it shapes and is shaped by competing social economic, and political institutions.

title: LAW 790 Legal Externship Seminar
description: Designed to support student learning at externship field placements, and support student growth in becoming ethical, professional, confident and successful law students and attorneys.

title: LAW 787 International Sales of Goods
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: LAW 786 Core Competencies for Litigators
description: An introduction to the various approaches and techniques litigators use when interviewing, counseling, negotiating, and analyzing facts.

title: LAW 784 Theories of International Law
description: Explores theories of international law, examining classical and modern ideas of international legal obligations. Students develop their own intellectual structures for explaining international norms.

title: LAW 783 General Counsel Practicum
description: Students will work under the direction of an experienced attorney in a general counsel's office.

title: LAW 782 Externship II
description: Registration Restriction: Open only to law students

title: LAW 781 Externship I
description: A judicial externship allows a student to gain hands-on legal experience in legal settings. Students will be assigned to a legal services program, government agency, or state or federal judge under faculty supervision.

title: LAW 779 Regulated Industries
description: Provides students with an understanding and an appreciation of regulated industries.

title: LAW 780 Intellectual Property and Technology Law Clinic II
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: LAW 778 Sales
description: Analysis of the buying and selling of goods both in domestic and international transactions with a heavy focus on Article 2 of the Uniform Commercial Code.

title: LAW 776 Immigration Clinic I
description: Students represent clients before Immigration and Customs Enforcement, the Immigration Court, and certain law enforcement agencies in cases including applications for relief under the Violence Against Women Act, for asylum, and for relief against deportation.

title: LAW 777 Administrative Law and Regulatory Policy
description: Legal principles subject to judicial control and the alternative ways in which agencies can be organized to serve their purposes.

title: LAW 773 Internet Law
description: Integration of cyberspace and the Internet into existing legal structures. Topics include: First Amendment issues; intellectual property, privacy and child protection; criminal activity and governance and jurisdictional activities.

title: LAW 775 Immigration Law
description: The development of immigration law to its present state.

title: LAW 772 Intellectual Property
description: The protection of intellectual property and encouragement of creativity. Explores copyright, trademarks, patents, and selected state law theories.

title: LAW 770 Technology Transactions
description: Provides students with the foundation for advising clients on transactions involving patents, trade secrets and other technology-related rights.

title: LAW 771 Intellectual Property and Technology Law Clinic I
description: Provides law students with the ability to represent clients (under the supervision of the professor) in cutting-edge issues of intellectual property and technology law.

title: LAW 769a Law Review Editing
description: Supervision of research and writing, and final editing of articles and comments for publication in the Southern California Law Review. For officers of the Review.

title: LAW 769b Law Review Editing
description: Supervision of research and writing, and final editing of articles and comments for publication in the Southern California Law Review. For officers of the Review.

title: LAW 768 Law Review Writing
description: Writing, source-checking and preliminary editing of articles and comments for publication in the Southern California Law Review.

title: LAW 767b Law Review Staff I
description: Writing, source-checking, and preliminary editing of articles and comments for publication in the Southern California Law Review. For second-year students serving as staff members on the Review.

title: LAW 767a Law Review Staff I
description: Writing, source-checking, and preliminary editing of articles and comments for publication in the Southern California Law Review. For second-year students serving as staff members on the Review.

title: LAW 765 Topics in Intellectual Property Law
description: Analyzes selected contributions to intellectual property scholarship and explores some challenging problems in contemporary intellectual property law.

title: LAW 764 International Business Transactions
description: Survey of legal aspects of international trade and investment transactions, including tax considerations.

title: LAW 766 Writing for Publication Seminar
description: Special seminars to provide a forum for students who wish to produce a paper for academic publication to receive guidance and feedback.

title: LAW 763 Federal Courts: The Federal System II
description: Problems of adjudication in a federal system. Allocation of authority between federal and state courts and among Congress, the Executive and the Courts; choice of federal and state law; jurisdiction of federal courts and significant rules of practice.

title: LAW 762a Interdisciplinary Law Journal Editing
description: Supervision and final editing of articles and comments for publication in the Interdisciplinary Law Journal.

title: LAW 762b Interdisciplinary Law Journal Editing
description: Supervision and final editing of articles and comments for publication in the Interdisciplinary Law Journal.

title: LAW 761 Interdisciplinary Law Journal Writing
description: Students will write journal notes as members of the Interdisciplinary Law Journal.

title: LAW 758 Identity Categories
description: Drawing on feminist legal theory, critical race theory, and lesbian/gay/bisexual and queer theory, this seminar will explore the treatment of identity categories in United States law.

title: LAW 756 Law Firms and In-House Law Departments
description: Examines the current status and possible future trajectories of large law firms and in-house law departments.

title: LAW 752 Digital Media Transactions: Policy and Practice
description: Considers the policy and practice of digital media law in several disciplines including music, social media and other models for online content creation and distribution. Open only to Law School students.

title: LAW 753 Antitrust Law I
description: Laws designed to preserve and promote business competition, with heavy emphasis on the federal antitrust laws.

title: LAW 760a Interdisciplinary Law Journal Staff
description: Source-checking and preliminary editing of articles and comments for publication in the Interdisciplinary Law Journal. For third-year students serving as staff members on the Journal.

title: LAW 757 Sex, Gender and the Law
description: Explores law's response to questions of sex discrimination and gender identity and expression, with emphasis upon legal issues facing transgender and intersex persons.

title: LAW 754 Antitrust and Intellectual Property Law
description: Covers the interface between antitrust law and intellectual property law.

title: LAW 760b Interdisciplinary Law Journal Staff
description: Source-checking and preliminary editing of articles and comments for publication in the Interdisciplinary Law Journal. For third-year students serving as staff members on the Journal.

title: LAW 751 Sexual Orientation and the Law
description: Explores the ways in which American law has responded to the diversity that exists within human sexual orientation.

title: LAW 750 Choice of Law
description: Introduces students to the doctrines of choice of law. This field determines which state's law applies when events causing disputes happen in several locations.

title: LAW 749 Securities Regulation
description: Regulation by state and federal agencies of issuance of, and trading in, stocks, bonds, and other securities. Particular reference to SEC regulations.

title: LAW 746 Critical Race Theory
description: Intersectionality, destruction and critical historiography; specifically affirmative action in education, hate speech and immigration reform.

title: LAW 740 Law of the City
description: Reviews and discusses the laws and the lawsuits that shape daily life in the city.

title: LAW 743 Federal Criminal Law
description: Covered topics include offenses relating to fraud and political corruption, terrorism, narcotics, money laundering, organized crime, false statements and obstruction of justice.

title: LAW 739 Reproductive Rights and Justice
description: Students will acquire a basic familiarity with the constitutional rules governing reproductive rights, and with legal and sociolegal theories that interpret and challenge those rules.

title: LAW 737 Small Business Clinic II
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: LAW 736 Small Business Clinic I
description: Students provide legal assistance to small businesses, entrepreneurs and non-profit organizations that cannot pay market rates for legal services.

title: LAW 734 Local Government Law
description: Study and evaluation of the municipal and regional legal institutions. Emphasis on the crises in financing and governing the urban society.

title: LAW 733 Business Bankruptcy
description: Reorganization of failing corporations under Chapter XI of the Bankruptcy Act. Claims, protective committees, plans, tax considerations.

title: LAW 732 Bioethics and Law Seminar
description: Covers legal and law-related issues, including constitutional law perspectives, concerning biomedical technologies.

title: LAW 727 Partnerships and Limited Liability Companies
description: Deals with the formation, features and functions of general partnerships, limited partnerships and limited liability companies. Also focuses on business planning, recognizing business and legal objectives and selecting the appropriate entity to accomplish these objectives.

title: LAW 726 Stereotypes, Prejudice, and the Rule of Law
description: An examination of the role of race (and other markers of social marginality) in the administration of justice in American courts.

title: LAW 725 Bioethics and Law
description: Legal, ethical and economic problems of advanced biological technologies, for example, behavior, genetic, and reproductive control; control of the processes of dying; organ transplantation and the use of artificial organs; regulation of scientific research and human experimentation.

title: LAW 722 Litigating Land Use Cases
description: Covers leading land use appellate cases, developing and implementing winning strategies with clients, formulating and articulating sensible arguments and rebuffing flawed arguments.

title: LAW 723 Children and the Law
description: Explore areas of law that cover children and require students to think critically and practically about children's role in the legal system.

title: LAW 721 Class Actions
description: Studies the theory and practice of class action litigation in the United States.

title: LAW 720 Topics in Corporate Law
description: Executive malfeasance, shareholder rights, securities class actions, asset securitizations, hedge fund regulation and corporate social responsibility from a theoretical and corporate finance framework.

title: LAW 719 Corporate Finance
description: Legal and economic aspects of corporate finance including capital structure, policy, mergers, takeovers, and freeze-outs; analysis of policy relating to present law and possible reforms.

title: LAW 718 Sports Law in Practice
description: Sports law is a blend of contract, labor, antitrust, agency, tax, intellectual property, tort, civil rights and constitutional law.

title: LAW 717 Estate Planning
description: Legal and tax considerations important to the lawyer advising his client on the transmission of wealth from one generation to the next.

title: LAW 716 Race and Gender in the Law
description: Investigates the experience of women and people of color as they have encountered legal institutions and processes.

title: LAW 715 ADR Law and Policy: Mediation and Arbitration
description: Exploration of the origin, development, and practice of mediation, arbitration and other forms of ADR, emphasizing the policies underlying these increasingly significant and evolving areas.

title: LAW 713 International Human Rights
description: This course will address the international law and institutions which have developed since World War II for the protection of human rights.

title: LAW 712 Negotiation Theory and Application
description: Develops enhanced negotiation skills and a working understanding of ADR processes and procedures in an interactive classroom experience.

title: LAW 714 U.S. Foreign Policy and International Law
description: Discusses current U.S. foreign policy challenges and the underlying international legal issues and principles which shape them.

title: LAW 710 Contract Drafting and Analysis
description: Students present to the class their assessment of assigned contracts, then draft their own contracts, interpret a complex contract, followed by team-based rewrites.

title: LAW 711 Access to Justice Practicum
description: Real world advocacy projects involving issues such as civil rights, disability rights, foster care, welfare, and health care, among others.

title: LAW 709 Contract Drafting and Negotiation
description: Contract Drafting and Negotiation will teach students the mechanics of drafting and negotiating sophisticated contracts from a variety of legal disciplines including entertainment law, real estate law and general corporate law.

title: LAW 708 Contract Drafting, Analysis and Negotiation
description: Covers the fundamentals of reviewing and analyzing business contracts and strategies for negotiating business issues with an emphasis on developing practical skills.

title: LAW 706 Public Health Law
description: Provides an introduction to the legal foundations of the public health system in the United States.

title: LAW 707 Global Health, Law and Human Rights
description: Highlights the complex interactions between health, law and human rights, emphasizing the use of human rights in public health thinking and practice.

title: LAW 705 Community Property
description: The law of community property, including disposition of property on dissolution of the marriage and questions of conflict of laws. May be offered as a reading course.

title: LAW 704 Poverty Law
description: An introduction to the problem of poverty in the United States and to the response of government and the legal system to the problems of the poor.

title: LAW 703b Children's Legal Issues
description: Students will work on cases in the following areas: (1) Dependent and neglected children: All children who are wards of the court must have legal counsel. (2) Children with AIDS: Legal implications of such issues as health care and custody. (3) Guardianships or other temporary arrangements for children whose parents are terminally ill or are otherwise unable to care for them.

title: LAW 703a Children's Legal Issues
description: Students will work on cases in the following areas: (1) Dependent and neglected children: All children who are wards of the court must have legal counsel. (2) Children with AIDS: Legal implications of such issues as health care and custody. (3) Guardianships or other temporary arrangements for children whose parents are terminally ill or are otherwise unable to care for them.

title: LAW 702 Children, Sexuality and the Law
description: Explores laws designed to protect children from sexual abuse and exploitation, with a limited emphasis on foreign and international law for comparative perspective.

title: LAW 701 Child Interviewing Seminar
description: Students learn how to effectively interview child witnesses. Students will practice mock interviews, and may be eligible to conduct actual interviews of child witnesses.

title: LAW 700 Health Care Regulations
description: Regulation of the medical profession; the physician-patient relationship; professional and institutional liability; health care institutions and delivery systems; quality control; access to health care services and problems of distribution and rationing; cost control, including government and private health care programs; patient rights; antitrust.

title: LAW 698 The Legal and Social Determinants of Health
description: Explores how legal, social, cultural and economic factors contribute to health disparities and the role that physicians and lawyers can play in advocating for patients and policy change.

title: LAW 697 Foreign Relations and National Security Law
description: This course will examine the statutory, constitutional, and international legal structures that form the base of American diplomacy.

title: MUHL 499 Special Topics
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: MUHL 550 Music and the Holocaust
description: Study of the creation and performance of Holocaust-related music from 1933 to the present, including interaction with other arts.

title: MUHL 490x Directed Research
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: MUHL 476 Music Criticism
description: Procedure and practice in forming critical judgments of music and in writing music criticism; practical journalism; professional and community ethics.

title: MUHL 403 Armenian Musical Culture
description: Study of the four branches of Armenian music within the context of past and present Armenian culture.

title: MUHL 390 Special Problems
description: Supervised, individual studies. No more than one registration permitted. Enrollment by petition only.

title: MUHL 351 Western Art Music History II
description: A study of the musical styles and genres in the late modern and contemporary eras within their historical context. Detailed analysis of selected works.

title: MUHL 333 Music History Review
description: Supervised review of the materials covered in undergraduate music history courses for students whose music history examinations indicate the need for further study.

title: MUHL 350g Western Art Music History I
description: A study of the musical styles and genres from antiquity through early modern periods within their historical context. Detailed analysis of selected works.

title: MUHL 332 Studies in Musical Culture
description: Special musical repertoires, issues, and critical problems; emphasis determined by the department.

title: MUHL 250g Music and Ideas
description: A topical study of critical issues and cultural relationships found in music from antiquity to the present and across musical genres and styles.

title: MUHL 232 Music History II
description: A study of the musical styles and genres from c. 1680 to c. 1850 within their historical context. Detailed analysis of selected works.

title: MUHL 331 Music History III
description: A study of the musical styles and genres from c. 1850 to the present within their historical context. Detailed analysis of selected works.

title: MUHL 231 Music History
description: A study of the musical styles and genres from antiquity to c. 1680 within their historical context. Detailed analysis of selected works.

title: MUEN 532 Jazz Chamber Music

title: MUEN 544 Vocal Chamber Music

title: MUEN 531 Guitar Big Band

title: MTAL 791 Pedagogical Writing and Media in Music Education
description: Development of skills in pedagogical writing for professional journals, text books, and multimedia publications, and knowledge of publishing procedures for compositions and arrangements.

title: MTAL 721 Qualitative Research in Music Teaching and Learning
description: Survey of theories, concepts and tools for designing, conducting and evaluating qualitative studies in music teaching and learning.

title: MTAL 720 Quantitative Research in Music Teaching and Learning
description: Survey of theories, concepts and procedures for designing, conducting and evaluating quantitative research studies in music teaching and learning.

title: MTAL 652 Pedagogy for Collegiate Teaching
description: A preparation for teaching in the modern university environment, examining the role of the professor, and focusing on the development of innovative collegiate teaching skills.

title: MTAL 650 Pedagogy for Collegiate Music Appreciation and Fundamentals
description: Design and teaching strategies for collegiate music appreciation and fundamentals classes developed for the adult, non music major student.

title: MTAL 615 Assessment and Reflective Practice
description: Examination of major aspects of measurement and evaluation that comprise the art of assessment of music teaching and learning.

title: MTAL 608 Creative Thinking in Music
description: Review of important developments in research and practice for the encouragement of creative thinking in music for music teaching and learning.

title: MTAL 606 Internship in Collegiate Music Education
description: Students intern with USC professors in training music teachers in traditional and alternative music education practices.

title: MTAL 607 Alternative Models in Music Teaching and Learning
description: Exploration of community music programs in the U.S. and beyond with emphasis on philosophical, sociological, structural and cultural bases for the diverse programs.

title: MTAL 605 College Teaching in Music Education
description: Exploration of music education faculty duties at the collegiate level, such as teaching general/secondary methods, working with student teachers, leading professional organizations, and conducting research.

title: MTAL 599 Special Topics
description: Selected topics of current interest reflective of changing trends in music education.

description: Registration Restriction: Open only to master students

description: Registration Restriction: Open only to master students
