description: Seminar. Review and discuss current research in Organizational Theory, Organizational Behavior and Strategy. Presentations by faculty, visiting researchers, and advanced students.

title: MOR 604 Research Methods in Strategy and Organization
description: Survey of research methods with focus on designing and implementing empirical research projects and critical issues faced by researchers.

title: MOR 602 Seminar in Organization Theory
description: Registration Restriction: Open only to Business Administration and Public Policy and Management doctoral students.

title: MOR 599 Special Topics
description: Registration Restriction: Online registration open only to graduate accounting and business students

title: MOR 601 Seminar in Organizational Behavior
description: In-depth review of the theories and empirical research in the discipline of organizational behavior. Topics include: personality, motivation, job design, leadership, and others.

title: MOR 605 Research Methods in Organizational Behavior
description: Design and analysis of behavioral research; methods may include experiments, survey research, qualitative research, statistical analysis, special topics. Emphasis on rigor, validity and statistical power.

title: MOR 603 Seminar in Strategic Management
description: Survey of strategic management. Topics include historical overview of strategic management, research methods used, current theory, and empirical research on the developing of paradigms.

title: MOR 598 Special Topics
description: Registration Restriction: Online registration open only to graduate accounting and business students

title: MOR 597 Consulting Project in Management and Organization
description: Individual or team project solving real business problems for an existing business entity, domestic and/or international. Proposal, field research, analyses and oral and written presentations.

title: MOR 596 Research Practicum in Management and Organization
description: Hands-on practical experience working with a Marshall faculty member in the Management and Organization Department on an ongoing research project.

title: MOR 593 Independent Research in Management and Organization
description: Independent research beyond normal course offerings. Proposal, research and written report/paper required.

title: MOR 595 Internship in Management and Organization
description: Supervised on-the-job business experience in the student's area of interest. (Curricular Practical Training.)

title: MOR 592 Field Research in Management and Organization
description: Individual or team projects studying the management practices of an industry, company, government agency, country, geographic region, etc. Proposal, data collection, analyses, and written report.

title: MOR 588 Corporate Strategy and Competitive Dynamics
description: Central challenges facing executives in multi-business firms; toolkit for analyzing and executing strategic and operational aspects of corporate advantage, M&As and competitive dynamics.

title: MOR 590 Directed Research
description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

title: MOR 579 The Business of Sports Entertainment
description: Business practices and issues in different sports markets including growth opportunities and innovative marketing strategies for attracting and retaining fans and corporate sponsors. Industry speakers.

title: MOR 573 Corporate Environmental and Social Issues
description: Exploration of competing perspectives on business's role vis-a-vis investors, government, environment, customers, suppliers, employees, unions, NGOs, etc.

title: MOR 571 Leadership and Executive Development
description: Contemporary approaches to leadership, including corporate practices to develop leaders; examples of successful and derailed executives. Students self-assess personal leadership and draft development plans. Readings, speakers, cases.

title: MOR 572 Leadership and Self-Management
description: Successful leaders are effective at self-managing their thoughts, emotions and actions. Concepts and methods for developing essential self-management skills.

title: MOR 569 Negotiation and Deal-Making
description: Strategies and dynamics of deal-making; practical skills necessary to win in a range of business transactions conducted in domestic and international settings. Cases, role-playing, films and simulations.

title: MOR 570 Leading Effective Teams
description: Analytical and behavioral tools that will enable students to effectively diagnose complex work group dynamics and take action to improve group performance.

title: MOR 567 Interpersonal Influence and Power
description: Legitimate and effective use of power to resolve conflicts and mobilize action through understanding the talent and self-interest of people involved in decision-making. Readings, cases.

title: MOR 566 Environmental Sustainability and Competitive Advantage
description: How business is changing in order to respond to environmental sustainability challenges — adapting strategy, product design, operations, marketing, and accounting. Cases and speakers.

title: MOR 564 Strategic Innovation: Creating New Markets
description: How firms in rapidly changing global environments innovate to develop new markets, products and services, delivery systems and organizational processes and competencies.

title: MOR 565 Alliances and Cooperative Strategy
description: Essential issues and problems of cooperative strategy. Recognize and evaluate collaborative opportunities to develop and assess an overall cooperative strategy. Readings, cases and group project.

title: MOR 560 Managerial Judgment and Decision-Making
description: Development of skills and insight into making effective strategic, financial, and management decisions including awareness of hazards of decisions, issues of rationality, and risk taking.

title: MOR 568 Power and Politics in Organizations
description: Explores current theories of power, politics and leadership within the organizational dynamic. Individual bases of power will be related to assessments of motives and skills.

title: MOR 562 Strategic Choice and Valuation Analysis
description: Advanced strategic planning using tools of scenario development and activity valuation for assessing market entry, expansion and business portfolio configuration. Exercises, cases and project.

title: MOR 561 Strategies in High-Tech Businesses
description: How high-tech companies achieve competitive advantage through leveraging technical, management and financial resources. Technology trends and industry evolution. Focus on electronics and bio-technology. Cases and speakers.

title: MOR 557 Strategy and Organization Consulting
description: How consultants assist clients to formulate strategic plans and realign organizations; approaches used by major consulting firms; information about consulting industry, fee-setting and proposals. Consultant speakers and project.

title: MOR 559 Strategic Renewal and Transformation
description: Dynamic strategic planning; how businesses re-invent themselves; why change is difficult; politics of change process; leadership steps for implementing successful strategic changes. Cases and readings.

title: MOR 555 Designing High Performance Organizations
description: Theory and practice of organization design. How to maximize organization performance by aligning structure, rewards, staffing, processes, and culture with strategy and environment.

title: MOR 554 Leading Innovation and Change
description: Practical knowledge on helping organizations develop innovations and lead change to leverage them. Exploration of innovation and change in different organizations and competitive environments.

title: MOR 551 Human Capital Performance and Motivation
description: Frameworks for enhancing human capital performance motivation at work, including pay/incentive systems, job design, employee involvement, leadership behavior and self-managed teams. Cases, project and speakers.

title: MOR 548 Competitive Advantage Through People
description: How firms develop employee talent as a source of competitive advantage. Strategic implications of contemporary practices in recruitment, work systems, training, compensation, and employee relations. Speakers and cases.

title: MOR 547 Mergers and Acquisitions: Integration and Organization
description: Organize successful mergers and acquisitions with focus on managing and synthesizing the integration process and impact on people and organizations across functions.

title: MOR 545 Corporate Governance and Board Leadership
description: Corporate Governance is the system by which corporations are directed and controlled. Includes rights and responsibilities of stakeholders; rules and procedures for decision-making.

title: MOR 543 Leading with Mindfulness and Compassion
description: Explores mindfulness (non-judgmental awareness), compassion and their relationship to leadership. Focus is on clarity in productivity using evidence-based cases and direct practice. Graded CR/NC.

title: MOR 542 Strategic Issues for Global Business
description: Globalization strategies from entry to maturity; alternative approaches from going alone to alliances; strategy implementation issues in different cultures and political systems. Cases, videos and speakers.

title: MOR 499 Special Topics
description: Selected topics reflecting current trends and recent developments in organizational behavior, business strategy and organizational theory.

title: MOR 492 Global Strategy
description: Examination of corporate strategy practices in an international context. Effects of cultures, political systems, markets, and economic systems on developing effective global strategies.

title: MOR 495 International Management and Internship
description: International internship. Develop general/cross-cultural knowledge and management skills, gain an understanding of cross-cultural issues, and develop insights working in international businesses.

title: MOR 479 The Business of Sports
description: Addresses the business side of the sports industry; examines professional sports franchises, amateur athletics, and collegiate sports and how they relate to corporate America, the media, and the public sector.

title: MOR 478 The Art of Leadership - Practical Leadership
description: Application of leadership skills using goal-setting, self-knowledge and execution opportunities. Open only to students in the USC Warren Bennis Scholars program.

title: MOR 476 The Art of Leadership - Leading on a Global Stage
description: Study of leaders and applied theory to gain an understanding of what is involved in taking public leadership roles on a global level. Open only to students in the USC Warren Bennis Scholars Program.

title: MOR 475 The Art of Leadership - Self Discovery
description: Introductory leadership. Self-examination of personal leadership styles using survey tools, comparative models and in-class exercises.

title: MOR 472 Power, Politics and Influence
description: Theories and practices about how power, politics and influence affect organizational life. Knowledge and skills for diagnosing and managing these features of an organization.

title: MOR 477 The Art of Leadership - Change Leadership
description: Examination of practical challenges facing every leader through a series of in-class discussions and field trips to meet recognized leaders in the social impact sphere. Open only to students in the USC Warren Bennis Scholars Program.

title: MOR 473 Designing and Leading Teams
description: Theories and practices for developing and leading teams. Skills for creating team structures and facilitating team processes. Knowledge for diagnosing team problems and devising solutions.

title: MOR 471 Managing and Developing People
description: Management of the human resource function for organizational performance.

title: MOR 469 Negotiation and Persuasion
description: Theories, strategies, and ethics underlying negotiation and persuasion in contemporary organizations and societies. Emphasizes the knowledge and skills needed for effective negotiation and persuasion.

title: MOR 470 Global Leadership
description: Major theories and practices of leading people in multinational firms. Skills for facilitating cooperation, communication, and motivation among people from different cultures.

title: MOR 466 Business and Environmental Sustainability
description: Focuses on how businesses both contribute to and can help address environmental sustainability challenges and the role of the broader political-economy in shaping that interaction.

title: MOR 465 Dynamic Strategies for the Business Lifecycle
description: Theories and methods for analyzing and developing strategy. Fundamental tools for strategic planning. Advanced methods for analyzing industries and competitors, and determining the scope of the firm.

title: MOR 463 Organization Change and Development
description: Theories and methods of introducing change in organizations. Techniques for analyzing organizations, developing change programs, and implementing changes. Ethical and career issues of change management.

title: MOR 451 Mastering Decision Making
description: Understand the nature, causes, and consequences of deviations from rational choice. Develop frameworks for controlling biases, improving your decision-making, and influencing other people's decisions.

title: MOR 462 Management Consulting
description: Role of professional consultants; data gathering methods; consulting approaches from strategy, finance, operations, information systems, marketing, and human resources; action planning; ethical and career issues.

title: MOR 421 Social and Ethical Issues in Business
description: The free-enterprise system examined from the perspective of modern corporations and their critics; business ethics in relation to personal/external values.

title: MOR 431 Interpersonal Competence and Development
description: An exploration of the nature of relationships at work; focus on analytical skills and self-assertion necessary to have effective, rewarding relationships.

title: MOR 385gm Business, Government and Society
description: Explores business-government-society interaction. Examines how diverse interests and identities (social class, race, nationality and gender) affect the conduct and organization of business.

title: MKT 699 Special Topics

title: MKT 621 Research Forum

title: MOR 461 Design of Effective Organizations

title: MKT 618 Consumer Behavior and Decision Making

description: Applications of advanced research techniques and designs to marketing problems; review and critique of current literature; development and defense of student's own research proposal.

title: MKT 613 Marketing Models in Consumer and Business-to-Business Markets
description: Modeling research on marketing with a focus on channel structure, franchising and sales force compensation, innovation and diffusion, inter-store composition, sales promotions, and market segmentation.

title: MS 401 Leadership and Management I

title: MS 202 Leadership and Teamwork
description: Study examines how to build successful teams, various methods for influencing action, effective communication in setting and achieving goals, the importance of timing the decision, creativity in the problem solving process, and obtaining team buy-in through immediate feedback.

title: MS 201 Individual Leadership Studies
description: Students identify successful leadership characteristics through observation of others and self through experimental learning exercises. Students record observed traits (good and bad) in a dimensional leadership journal and discuss observations in small group settings.

Focuses on the following anatomical regions: Axial Skeleton, Upper and Lower Limbs, and Thoracic Cavity.

Covers a variety of topics including: skeletal development; functional interpretation of bone and bony processes; osteological and dental pathology; human anatomical variation; laboratory analyses and imaging techniques; methods for estimating age, sex, and stature; and comparative osteology.

title: GEOL 534L Mechanics of Lithospheric Deformation

title: GEOL 536 Principles of Geomagnetism and Paleomagnetism

title: GEOL 535L Microstructures and Deformation Mechanisms

title: GEOL 532 Advanced Geologic Mapping
description: Principles of mapping geologically complex terranes of different structural style. Fieldwork will be coordinated with seminar review of diverse structural phenomena. Field trips.

title: GPR 605b Review of General Dentistry Literature
description: Residents learn how to research various topics and to critically review each article in order to practice evidence-based dentistry.

title: GEOL 533L Continental Margin Arcs

title: GPR 605a Review of General Dentistry Literature
description: Residents learn how to research various topics and to critically review each article in order to practice evidence-based dentistry.

title: FPRO 561a Clinic: Fixed Prosthodontics I
description: Clinical application of fixed prosthodontic principles in patient treatment.

title: FREN 794a Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: FREN 790 Research
description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

title: DES 203 Digital Tools for Design

title: FBE 460 Mergers, Acquisitions and Restructuring

title: FBE 565 Economics of Urban Land Use: Feasibility Studies

title: FBE 563 Theory of International Trade

title: FBE 560 Mergers and Acquisitions
description: Practical application of the critical components of mergers and acquisitions: deal flow strategies, preliminary negotiations, deal structures, due diligence, valuation, post-merger integration, and regulations.

title: FBE 564 International Financial Management
description: Financial management of the multinational firm; legal entities and taxation abroad; risk in foreign operations; strategies in foreign exchange, money and capital markets and institutions.

title: FBE 558 Law for Structuring, Financing, and Managing Businesses
description: Legal environment of agency law, general and limited partnerships, limited liability companies, corporate formation and financing, corporate governance, securities law, acquisitions, bankruptcy, and business ethics.

title: FBE 557 Business Law and Ethics
description: Business law of traditional and e-contracts, UCC, crimes, torts, employment, ethics, social responsibility, intellectual property, digital law, e-commerce, accountants' liability, property, estates, and government regulation.

title: FBE 559 Management of Financial Risk
description: Analysis of commodity, futures, and options contracts; theoretical and empirical approaches; spot and futures price relationships, speculation and hedging strategies; market efficiency.

title: FBE 555 Investment Analysis and Portfolio Management
description: Analysis and management of common stocks and fixed income securities; development of modern portfolio theory and the efficient market hypothesis; organization of securities markets.

title: FBE 553b Applied Portfolio Management
description: Application of advanced portfolio management techniques in a laboratory setting. Bond portfolio management, quantitative stock screens, derivatives trading, portfolio optimization. Off-site visits and presentations.

title: FBE 554 Trading and Exchanges
description: Theories, practices, and technologies of trading at exchanges and in dealer networks. Sources of liquidity, volatility, profitability, and institutional change. Domestic and international public policy issues.

title: FBE 550 High Yield Bond Investing - Managing Credit Risk
description: Review the structure of the high yield bond market. Develop a practical approach to assess credit risk and understand how deals are structured and priced.

title: FBE 553a Applied Portfolio Management
description: Application of portfolio management techniques in a laboratory setting. Stock selection, asset allocation, industry analysis, investment thesis research; off-site visits; oral and written presentations.

title: FBE 540 Hedge Funds
description: Introduction to the investment strategies used by hedge funds, the quantitative tools and business plans used to implement them.

title: FBE 535 Applied Finance in Fixed Income Securities
description: The basic principles underlying fixed income securities and how these principles apply to the practical aspects of fixed income management.

title: FBE 543 Forecasting and Risk Analysis
description: Application of econometric tools and versions of Capital Asset Pricing Models to estimate financial risk and stock market risk premia for portfolio management.

title: FBE 533 CEO Pay, Corporate Governance, and the Politics of Finance
description: Explores how value is created (or destroyed) in organizations, focusing on compensation and incentive systems and the causes and consequences of government (and populist) intervention.

title: FBE 532 Corporate Financial Strategy
description: Linkage between financial theory and policy and corporate strategy; the role of financial managers in developing corporate strategy; applications of concepts and techniques using cases.

title: FBE 529 Financial Analysis and Valuation
description: An applications-oriented course to develop the financial and accounting tools required to do financial planning valuation and assessment of financial performance.

title: FBE 531 Corporate Financial Policy and Corporate Governance
description: Advanced analysis of the determinants of corporate capital structure and payout policies, allocation and value of corporate control, and security issuance and retirement.

title: FBE 526 Macroeconomic Analysis for Business
description: The economic environment of business: American economic and social goals and policies and their impact on business; growth, stability, and the new priorities; international forces influencing business.

title: FBE 527 Entrepreneurial Finance: Financial Management for Developing Firms
description: Internal financial management of developing firms. Cash flow analysis; capital budgeting; sources of financing; risk analysis; measurement of profits; and mergers and acquisitions.

title: FBE 525 Financial Institution Management, Strategy and Valuation
description: Application of economic and financial analytic techniques to the managerial problems of financial institutions and implications for financial firm strategy and valuation.

title: FBE 524 Money and Capital Markets
description: Review of financial institutions and markets, the determinants of interest rates, the impact of government regulation and policy on the financial system.

title: FBE 523 Venture Capital and Private Equity
description: Advanced analysis of the economics of the private equity markets. Consider and value private securities in venture capital, initial public offerings, and leveraged buyouts.

title: FBE 506b Quantitative Methods in Finance
description: The development of multivariate mathematical and statistical methods used in modern finance and economics and applications of these methods.

title: FBE 506a Quantitative Methods in Finance
description: The development of single and bivariate mathematical and statistical methods used in modern finance and economics and applications of these methods. Duplicates credit in FBE 506.

title: FBE 501 Investment Banking Fundamentals
description: The role of an investment banking associate. Students will effectively function as a junior banker through a sell-side merger and acquisition (M & A) process.

title: FBE 498x Business Field Project (Undergraduate)
description: Individual or team projects studying the business practices, needs, and opportunities of an entity. May include international research and travel and oral and written presentations.

title: FBE 495x Practicum in Business Issues (Internship)
description: Combined classroom discussion and structured, supervised field application of business theories and practices within a part-time employment context. Open only to undergraduate students in Finance and Business Economics certificate.

title: FBE 499 Special Topics
description: Current developments in the field of finance and business economics; topics to be selected each semester.

title: FBE 491 Real Estate Finance Colloquium
description: The roles of economics and finance in real estate. Lessons from history, the origin of real estate bubbles, how real estate markets work.

title: FBE 470 Advanced Real Estate Analysis
description: Mixed lecture/case approach covering market analysis, asset valuation, ownership structure, negotiation, asset management, corporate real estate, portfolio management, and affordable housing, appraisal and advanced financial modeling.

title: FBE 489 Real Estate Capital Markets
description: Topics in real estate capital markets including markets for debt and equity; residential and commercial mortgages and mortgage-backed securities; REITs; institutional sources of capital.

title: FBE 465 Real Estate Analysis and Computer Modeling
description: Real estate valuation. Three approaches to valuation: Market comparison, income, and cost. Highest and best use analysis. State of the art real estate software.

title: FBE 466 Management of Real Estate Development: Feasibility Studies
description: By means of a significant real-world case study chosen each term, the development process is examined from the interrelated perspectives of finance, market analysis, and design and construction technology. Team-generated development proposals are proposed and presented in a consulting environment that includes industry participants.

title: FBE 458 Law, Finance and Ethics
description: Law and ethics of agency, partnerships, corporations, limited liability companies, governmental regulation, mergers, creditor rights, secured transactions, bankruptcy, securities regulation, and antitrust.

title: FBE 462 International Trade, Finance and Commercial Policy
description: Commercial policies, treaty relationships, examination of policies influencing world trade and finance, the international financial system, exchange rates.

title: FBE 459 Financial Derivatives
description: A rigorous introduction to the pricing and corporate use of financial derivatives — futures, options, forwards, and swaps — on stocks, exchange rates, bonds, and commodities.

title: FBE 453b Advanced Practicum in Investment Management
description: Application of advanced investment management techniques in a laboratory setting. Bond portfolio management, quantitative stock screens, derivatives trading, portfolio optimization. Off-site visits and presentations. Open only to senior business majors.

title: FBE 453a Advanced Practicum in Investment Management
FBE 440 Trading and Exchanges
description: Theories, practices, and technologies of trading at exchanges and in dealer networks. Sources of liquidity, volatility, profitability, and institutional change. Domestic and international public policy issues.

title: FBE 443 Introduction to Forecasting and Risk Analysis
description: Introduction to econometric tools and versions of Capital Asset Pricing Models to estimate financial risk, stock market risk premia and to project economic activity.

title: FBE 441 Investments
description: Theories and applications of investment decision-making; the behavior of security prices, portfolio theory, asset pricing models, market efficiency, bond valuation and term structure, derivative securities.

title: FBE 437 Entrepreneurial Finance: Financial Management for Developing Firms
description: Internal financial management of developing firms. Cash flow analysis; capital budgeting; sources of financing; risk analysis; measurement of profits; and mergers and acquisitions.

title: FBE 436 Financial Management of Multinational Corporations
description: International scope and dimension of financial planning; working capital management; financing and investment decisions of multinational corporations.

title: FBE 433 Corporate Governance and CEO Pay
description: Explores how value is created (or destroyed) through incentive compensation and corporate governance. Focus on bonuses, stock options, executive compensation, and financing policies.

title: FBE 435 Applied Finance in Fixed Income Securities
description: Emphasis on hedging tools necessary for portfolio managers. Introduction of all securities available in fixed income and provision of tools to analyze investments.

title: FBE 432 Corporate Financial Strategy
description: Linkage between financial theory and policy and corporate strategy, the role of financial managers in developing corporate strategy; applications of concepts and techniques using cases.

title: FBE 431 Financial Policies and Corporate Governance
description: Presentation of the theory and institutional details of corporate finance, with emphasis on debt and dividend policies, governance/voting rights, and security issuance and retirement.

title: FBE 429 International Business Law
description: Introductory course on the legal and regulatory environment of international business transactions.

title: FBE 427 Real Estate Law
description: Principles of law regarding real property transactions; buyer-seller, debtor-creditor, landlord-tenant relationships; environmental law and land use control; investments and syndication.

title: FBE 428 Principles of Employment Law
description: Survey of current employment law topics including employment discrimination arising within modern workplaces. Legal and business strategies for managing diversity for organizational success.

title: FBE 423 Introduction to Venture Capital and Private Equity
description: Introduction to venture capital and private equity. Topics include fundraising, valuation of new firms and venture capital securities, and exiting investments through public offerings.

title: FBE 421 Financial Analysis and Valuation
description: This course develops and uses tools of financial analysis to evaluate the performance and assess the value of individual companies in an industry context.

title: FBE 402 Government and Business
description: American mixed capitalism, welfare, market failure, and the role of government in business; regulation and the public utilities, antitrust policy, and current topics in regulation-deregulation.

title: FBE 403 Introduction to the Legal Environment of Business
description: Legal principles of business: litigation process, constitutional law, torts, product liability, crimes, contracts, sales and leases, intellectual property, international law, agency, employment law, and ethics.

title: FBE 400x Introduction to Real Estate Finance and Development
description: Case analysis examining economic and financial aspects of real estate decisions for non-business majors. Focuses on dynamics of financing, markets and the development process.

title: FBE 416 Managerial Economics
description: Application of microeconomic theory to problems of the firm, quantification of demand and cost relationships; pricing policies.

title: FBE 391 Real Estate Finance and Investment
description: Introduction to income-producing real estate from the perspective of finance, market analysis, capital markets, development and investment. Includes focus on analytical techniques and computer applications.

title: FBE 299 Special Topics
description: Introduction to current developments in finance and business economics.

title: DES 599 Special Topics
description: Selected topics in the various specialty areas within design at the graduate level. Topic will vary from semester to semester.

title: FBE 206 The Power of Personal Finance
description: Develop knowledge and skills in areas of money management, budgeting, financial goal attainment, insurance, credit cards, and investments.

title: DES 594z Master's thesis
description: Registration Restriction: Open only to master students

title: FBE 324 The Financial System
description: Financial intermediaries in the flow of funds; aggregate financial asset analysis; money markets and interest rates; government debt and its economic effects.

title: DES 594a Master's Thesis
description: Registration Restriction: Open only to master students in the USC Roski School of Art and Design

title: DES 594b Master's Thesis
description: Registration Restriction: Open only to master students in the USC Roski School of Art and Design

title: DES 550 Advancement
description: Registration Restriction: Open only to master students in the USC Roski School of Art and Design

title: DES 590 Directed Research
description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

title: DES 591 Field Internship Experience

title: DES 543 Design Study Tour

title: DES 540 Design Pedagogy
description: A critical examination and application of the issues, theories, and ideas that support the studio practice and teaching of contemporary design.

title: DES 523 Design Theory
description: A critical examination of issues, theories, movements and practices that are relevant to the contemporary professional designer.

title: DES 530 Design Studio Co-Lab
description: A critical examination of contextual issues, theories, movements and ideas that are relevant to the contemporary design practice in collaboration with a professional client.

title: DES 520 Individual Studies
description: Investigation of creative problems through various design media.

title: DES 514 Designers in Residence Forum
description: Seminar in the professional practice of design featuring formal presentations and mentoring opportunities by designers in residence.

title: DES 513 Visiting Designers Forum
description: Professional practice of design featuring formal presentations by visiting designers.

title: DES 503 Contemporary Issues in Design
description: An analytic seminar of topics, ideas and concepts in the contemporary design world.

title: DES 499 Special Topics
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: DES 494b Senior Thesis
description: Research and writing of a senior-level thesis or thesis project under the supervision of a faculty committee.

title: DES 433 International Design Study Tour
description: An immersive experience in the design culture of a global city or region that includes a short (two-week or less) international trip.

title: DES 494a Senior Thesis
description: Research and writing of a senior-level thesis or thesis project under the supervision of a faculty committee.

title: DES 432 Special Projects in Design
description: Students work on projects for outside clients, and receive instruction in professional practices, advanced design techniques, and sophisticated technology. By invitation or portfolio review only. Only open to upper division students.

title: DES 418 Independent Studies in Design
description: Independent research of specific topics under the direction of a faculty member. Administrative and faculty approval required.

title: DES 333 New York Design Study Tour
description: Historical and contemporary aspects of the New York design world, including a one-week trip to New York City to visit design firms, studios and museums. Airfare and accommodations extra. By application only.

title: DES 413 Professional Practice in Design
description: A summation of one's practice, with a focus on transitioning to a career as a professional designer.

title: DES 402 Advanced Design Projects
description: Advanced information design within a flexible curriculum. Emphasis on team-oriented projects.

title: DES 302 Design III
description: Advanced exploration of typography and image-text integration, including collaborative projects, pre-press and proofing techniques, narrative concepts and information architecture.

title: FREN 696 Topics and/or Themes in Francophone Literature
description: Advanced seminar with varying focus on the Francophone literature and culture of West Africa, North Africa, the Caribbean, Quebec and Southeast Asia.

title: DES 213 Digital Tools in 3D Design
description: 3D digital modeling, rendering, digital capture and production methods for product, package and environmental design.

title: DES 322 Publication Design
description: Application of layout, typography, design principles and image making in the design and production of books, magazines, zines and digital books.

title: FREN 695 Topics and/or Themes in French Literature
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: FREN 604 Topics in Contemporary French Thought
description: Examines French thought from 1960 to the present day.

title: DES 313 Graphic Design in Fashion
description: An intensive studio and lecture course focusing on the applications of graphic design in fashion and related fields.

title: FREN 603 Seminar on an Author
description: Examines the work of a significant French author along with its critical and theoretical assessments.

title: FREN 592 Practicum in Teaching French
description: Introduction to the approaches and techniques of teaching French as a second language. Open only to master's and PhD students who will be assistant lecturers in French.

title: FREN 590 Directed Research
description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

title: FREN 540 Studies in French Literature and Philosophy
description: Examines literary and philosophical works side by side in any historical period or periods in France.

title: FREN 550 Studies in Literature and Other Media
description: Survey-like review of the interaction between verbal and other artistic media such as print, music, dance, theater, and painting and the visual arts.

title: FREN 520 Studies in Diaspora and Transnationalism
description: Introduction to contemporary literature and thought on the dynamics of diaspora, transnationalism, and globalization.

title: FREN 530 Studies in a Genre
description: Studies one of the genres in French literature (including novel, poetry, drama, and essay) in any historical period or periods.

title: FREN 504 Studies in Francophone Literature and Thought
description: Topics in Francophone literature and intellectual history of Africa, Asia and the Americas. Emphasis on colonial history and political and aesthetic concerns.

title: FREN 501 Early Modernities
description: Broad introduction to French culture from the late Middle Ages through the 18th century; investigation of works of literature, philosophy, and visual culture.

title: FREN 503 Modernities
description: An intellectual genealogy of French modernity and modernism through the examination of canonical literary texts and theories.

title: FREN 499 Special Topics
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: FREN 490x Directed Research
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: FREN 464 Colloquium: French Civilization
description: Selected topics such as the press, educational institutions, French cinema today, and French colonial history. Conducted in French.

title: FREN 449 Studies in French Civilization
description: (Paris Semester only) An analysis of the prestige of Paris, past and present, based upon close examination of literary texts and graphic materials, and visits to sites and monuments.

title: FREN 410 Actualités Françaises
description: Present day French life through readings in French periodicals and viewing of French films and art exhibits. Non-majors prepare assignments in English. Conducted in French. Spring semester in Paris only.

title: FREN 432 French Theatre
description: (Paris Semester only) A survey of French theatre from the 17th century to the present. Students read plays ranging from classical comedy and tragedy to modern movements. Live theatre performances will supplement class work. Taught in French.

title: FREN 446 Contemporary French Thought
description: Readings in structuralism, post-structuralism, feminism, and deconstruction. Conducted in French.

title: FREN 403 Studies in Colonialism and Postcolonialism
description: Study and analysis of colonialism and postcolonialism in French and Francophone contexts.

title: FREN 404 Studies in an Author
description: Close readings in works of a single influential French or Francophone author. Focused study of style, creative developments, historical context. Conducted in French.

title: FREN 402 Studies in Modernity
description: Study and analysis of representative works and major intellectual, cultural, and artistic trends from the modern period (post-1789).

title: FREN 392 Seminar in Literary and Cultural Studies
description: Selected topics in French and Francophone literature and culture. Conducted in French.

title: FREN 401 Studies in Early Modernity
description: Study and analysis of representative works and major intellectual, cultural, and artistic trends from the early modern period (pre-1789).

title: FREN 390 Special Problems
description: Supervised, individual studies. No more than one registration permitted. Enrollment by petition only.

title: FREN 382 Paris Avant-Gardes
description: Exploration of experimental artistic collaborations between poets, novelists, art critics and artists of the Paris Avant-gardes in 19th and 20th century. Taught in French. Paris Semester.

title: FREN 375gmw Global Narratives of Illness and Disability
description: Study of difference as represented through French, Francophone and related narratives of disability and illness, with attention to race and gender. Conducted in English.

title: FREN 373g Remembering Loss, Writing Memory
description: An exploration into how genocides and episodes of mass violence have been thought about, remembered and expressed in France and the Francophone world. Conducted in English.

title: FREN 370gm Equality and Difference around the Enlightenment
description: 18th - and 20th century debates around the idea of equality and the notion of difference. Relevance of the Enlightenment to contemporary discussions of identity, citizenship, and human rights. Conducted in English.

title: FREN 360 Business and Technical French
description: Specific vocabulary and formulae used in international commerce. Attention given to developing vocabulary and standard forms appropriate to individual career objectives.

title: FREN 351 Introduction to Research in French and Francophone Cultures
description: Introduction to research methods through the study of a specific topic in French and/or Francophone literature and culture.

title: FREN 320g The French New Wave and its Legacy
description: Film-making in France from the earliest experiments to current trends. Emphasis on the political, social, historical context of French films. Taught in English. Reading knowledge of French recommended.

title: FREN 330 Critical Writing in French

title: FREN 315 Inside the Courts: the French Legal Language and Culture
description: Broaden understanding of differences between American and French cultures; acquire specialized vocabulary; develop ability to address legal issues in writing and orally. Taught in French.

title: FREN 310 Media French
description: Analysis of French media. Practice in sustained conversation. Emphasis on spoken sentence patterns.

title: FREN 300 French Grammar and Composition
description: Grammatical structure and vocabulary building with practical application to written composition.

title: FREN 250 French IV

title: FREN 236x Professional Communication in French

title: FREN 235x Intermediate Conversational French: Culture, Society, and Communication
description: Designed for non-majors/minors interested in maintaining and developing French language competency. Builds vocabulary, ease of communication, and cultural knowledge through discussion of contemporary topics.

title: FREN 120 French I
description: Introduction to current French. Oral practice, listening and reading comprehension; grammar necessary for simple spoken and written expression.

title: FREN 150 French II
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: FREN 020x Course in Reading French

title: FREN 015x French 150 Language Practicum

title: FREN 220 French III
description: . Review of structural patterns of French; selected cultural and literary readings; conversation and composition.

title: FREN 012x French 120 Language Practicum
description: English grammar as it relates to French in order to improve students' French language skills; explicit pronunciation and intonation practice.

title: FPRO 601 Advanced Fixed Prosthodontics

description: Clinical application of fixed prosthodontic principles in patient treatment.

description: Clinical application of fixed prosthodontic principles in patient treatment.
