description: Intensive training in journal club and research talk presentations for graduate students in the Biology of Aging PhD program.

title: GERO 628 Theories of Aging
description: An examination of the nature and adequacy of existing explanations of aging. Focus will be on psychological, sociological, and biological paradigms, and on the epistemology of theory.

title: GERO 620 Psychology of Aging
description: Overview of topics in the psychology of aging. Includes research and theory bearing on cognitive, personality, adaptive, and social processes throughout the adult life span. Open only to doctoral students.

title: GERO 613 Health and Aging
description: Examination of changes in health related to age, changes in health in populations over time, and the key health issues facing older persons.

title: GERO 603 Research Integrity
description: Explores scientific integrity, mentoring, scientific record keeping, authorship, peer review, animal and human experimentation, conflict of interest, data ownership and intellectual property, and genetic technology.

title: GERO 602b Seminar on Discoveries in Biogerontology
description: Critical analyses of primary scientific data and interpretations presented in the literature.

title: GERO 601 Molecular Genetics of Aging
description: Explores concepts of molecular and genetic regulation of healthy aging, lifespan, and age-related diseases.

title: GERO 602a Seminar on Discoveries in Biogerontology
description: Critical analyses of primary scientific data and interpretations presented in the literature.

title: GERO 599 Special Topics
description: Examination of special topics in the area of gerontological study.

title: GERO 600 Geroscience: Molecular and Cellular Biology
description: Emphasizes the molecular and cellular biology of aging and age-related pathology and other aspects of basic aging research, including evolutionary biology, demography, epidemiology and bioinformatics.

title: GERO 594z Master's Thesis
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: GERO 594b Master's Thesis
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: GERO 594a Master's Thesis
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: GERO 593 Research Methods
description: An introduction to research methods and their application to gerontology including problem formation, research design, data collection, descriptive and analytic statistics, interpretation, and report preparation.

title: GERO 592 Multidisciplinary Research Seminar in Aging
description: Multidisciplinary perspectives on current research in gerontology, including physiology, neurobiology, health and medicine, psychology, sociology, and public policy. Topics will change each semester.

title: GERO 590 Directed Research
description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

title: GERO 589 Case Studies in Leadership and Change Management
description: Examination of case studies of issues affecting the aging services industries and the role industry leaders play in reacting to change.

title: GERO 591 Field Practicum
description: Supervised experiential learning in one or more organizations that serve older adults; includes a regularly scheduled seminar.

title: GERO 585 The Aging Family
description: Family processes and structure in families with aged persons will be reviewed, including marital and family therapy and intervention strategies.

title: GERO 570 Corporate Policies and Aging
description: An introduction to the evolving roles of corporations in an aging society including such topics as retaining older workers, retiree benefits, and the mature consumer.

title: GERO 557 Geriatric Care Management
description: Overview of concepts, issues, and approaches to geriatric care management. Includes analysis and practice of a variety of care management clinical skills.

title: GERO 560 Micronutrients, Health, and Longevity
description: Explores the basis of nutrition needs for vitamins, major minerals and trace minerals including nutrient interaction and their role in health and longevity.

title: GERO 555 Integrating Gerontology: A Multidisciplinary Approach
description: Aging (commonalities and distinctions) as addressed by biologists, psychologists, and sociologists. Topics include research perspectives, normative aging, functional decline and disability, and aging and society.

title: GERO 556 Program Development
description: Principles and procedures of assessing needs, collecting resources, designing activities, and implementing programs for older people in a variety of community and institutional settings.

title: GERO 554 Evaluation: Incorporating Evidence-Based Practices
description: Examination of the evaluation of health and service delivery in aging services industries.

title: GERO 550 Administration and System Management in Programs for Older Adults
description: Application of theories of administration and system management to public and volunteer programs and services for older adults including residential institutions and community programs.

title: GERO 543 Continuum of Care: Systems Perspective
description: Structural and organizational aspects of institutional and community programs; public policies, fiscal management, regulation, administration; obstacles to interagency coordination; the continuum of care.

title: GERO 541 Health Care Delivery Models: Comparative Approaches
description: Examination of current trends and future prospects of finance and reimbursement systems. Topics include major legislation and programs such as Medicare and Medicaid.

title: GERO 551 Applied Policy Skills in Aging
description: An overview and application of techniques and approaches used in the definition and analysis of policy problems in aging.

title: GERO 540 Social Policy and Aging
description: Major legislation and programs; examination and analysis of policy-making and political processes affecting development and implementation of programs for older persons.

title: GERO 530 Life Span Developmental Sociology
description: Life span perspective on the sociological theories of marriage and the family, inter-generational relationships, work and retirement, and other forms of social organization.

title: GERO 522 Counseling Older Adults and Their Families
description: Theory and application of assessment and intervention techniques with older adults and their families. Topics include: treatment modalities, psychopathology, ethical and legal issues, brain disorders.

title: GERO 529 Seminar in Psychological Aspects of Aging
description: Psychological changes in the later years; perception; sensory factors; intelligence and memory; psychophysiological measures; personality; psychopathology.

title: GERO 518 Current Topics in Clinical Nutrition
description: Discuss various factors that affect nutrition and aging. Topics include allergies in nutrition, food toxins, weight factors, and prevention and treatment of multiple organ systems.

title: GERO 520 Life Span Developmental Psychology
description: Behavior from adulthood to old age; study of major components of behavior such as perception, cognitive processes, personality, intergenerational relationships, sexuality, and life styles.

title: GERO 517L Advanced Therapeutic Nutrition
description: Application of nutrition science, physiology, biochemistry, and metabolism to evaluate critically ill patients and plan nutrition intervention and monitoring.

title: GERO 515L Food Production and Food Service Management
description: A study of principles and procedures for food systems including techniques of food preparation, development, modification and evaluation of recipes, menus and products.

title: GERO 513 Fundamentals of Nutrition: Macronutrients
description: A study of the principles of human nutrition throughout the life cycle. Current topics and controversies in nutrition and health are discussed.

title: GERO 512 Communicating Nutrition and Health
description: Overview of current understanding of the dietary and nutritional needs of individuals across their lifespan.

title: GERO 511 Fundamentals of Clinical Nutrition Screening and Assessment
description: Examines tools and resources used to evaluate the nutrition status of individuals across the lifespan including biochemical, anthropometric and subjective global assessment. Open only to graduate students.

title: GERO 510 Physiology of Development and Aging
description: Examination of lifespan physiology of human development, growth, and aging; major emphasis in the physiology of the later years and implications for health maintenance.

title: GERO 509 Mindful Aging: Spirituality, Gratitude, and Resilience
description: Fosters vital imaginative connections to transform one's understanding and experience of the aging process from within, in order to re-envision the aging process as a spiritual journey.

title: GERO 508 The Mind and Body Connection through the Lifespan
description: An introduction to mind-body processes involved in healthy aging. Examines the interplay of emotions, beliefs, and behaviors in shaping health-relevant biological processes.

title: GERO 507 End of Life Care
description: Examination of programs related to end of life care. Cultural competencies in working with a diverse population on end of life issues.

title: GERO 506 Technological Innovations in Aging (Gerontechnology)
description: Reflections on shifts in preferences for aging in place and the market ramifications of innovations in science and technology on older consumers and service providers.

title: GERO 505 Housing and Community Policies and Programs
description: Examination of the behavioral and social consequences of design and the environment to create a more satisfying physical environment for both frail and active older adults.

title: GERO 502 Marketing and Shifts in Consumer Decision Making
description: Branding, marketing, and consumer behavior through examination of established, transitioning and emerging aging services and organizations.

title: GERO 504 Current Issues in Aging Services Management
description: Basic skills needed for an executive working in an aging services environment. Recommended for entry level administrators and managers.

title: GERO 501 Applied Legal and Regulatory Issues in Aging
description: Analysis of shifting legal and regulatory issues affecting the delivery of aging services.

title: GERO 500 Perspectives on a Changing Society: An Introduction to Aging
description: Analysis of physical, mental, and social age-related changes as well as implications of population aging trends for individuals and society.

title: GERO 499 Special Topics
description: Examination of special topics in the area of gerontology.

title: GERO 498 Nutrition, Genes, Longevity and Diseases
description: Examines the role of nutrition and genes and the impact each has on longevity and diseases, particularly diseases related to aging. Offered in Genoa, Italy.

title: GERO 497b Honors Seminar
description: Advanced study of empirical approaches in gerontology. Preparation, progress, presentation, and evaluation of Senior Honors Thesis research.

title: GERO 497c Honors Seminar
description: Advanced study of empirical approaches in gerontology. Preparation, progress, presentation, and evaluation of Senior Honors Thesis research.

title: GERO 497a Honors Seminar
description: Advanced study of empirical approaches in gerontology. Preparation, progress, presentation, and evaluation of Senior Honors Thesis research.

title: GERO 495 Practicum in Geriatric Care
description: Supervised experience in a geriatric health care setting which allows students to put theories and ideas into practice. Graded CR/NC. Lecture, discussion, and fieldwork.

title: GERO 494 Emotion-Cognition Interactions and Aging
description: Covers the paradox of emotion in aging, as well as how stress and emotion influence cognition and the brain across the lifespan.

title: GERO 493p Longevity and Death among Ancient and Modern European Populations (Italy)
description: The discoveries of ancient humans and bodies that have been preserved illuminate the connection between diet, health, and disease.

title: GERO 496 Introduction to Clinical Geriatrics
description: Medical problems of older adults emphasizing common geriatric syndromes, chronic illness, and alternative approaches to primary health care of older persons and their families. Upper division standing.

title: GERO 492 Senior Seminar
description: An in-depth integration of major research and professional themes in the study of human development and aging.

title: GERO 491 Practicum
description: Supervised experience in one or more community agencies.

title: GERO 490x Directed Research
description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

title: GERO 483 Global Health and Aging
description: Overview of the impact aging populations will have on global institutions from a variety of perspectives. Examination of public health policy issues.

title: GEOL 531 Plate Interactions: Geological Aspects
description: Principles and geometrics of plate tectonics; geologic characteristics of modern plate boundaries of divergent, convergent, transform type; ocean basin and orogen development from worldwide examples. Field trip.

title: GEOL 530 Modern Perspectives on Crustal Dynamics
description: Deformation mechanisms, strength and structure of the crust. Fractal scaling in structures and dynamic processes. Geodetic measurement of crustal deformation and spatio-temporal patterns of seismicity.

title: GEOL 525 The Science of Climate Change
description: Introduction to the fundamental aspects and the factors that influence ocean and atmospheric behavior, and how the earth's climate has varied in the past.

title: GEOL 521L Advanced Structural Geology
description: Advanced field and theoretical aspects of rock deformation, strain and stress analyses, and evolution of structural systems. Includes lab, field trip(s), and class project.

title: GEOL 520 Biosedimentology
description: Ancient and recent borings and bioturbation structures and their utilization in stratigraphic, paleoenvironmental, paleoecological, sedimentological, and geochemical studies.

title: GEOL 514 Marine Geology
description: Origin and characteristics of ocean basins; marine sedimentary environments; shoreline classification and character; evolution of oceanic features.

title: GEOL 511L Depositional Systems
description: Analysis of depositional systems, including conceptual methods of lithostratigraphy, biostratigraphy, chronostratigraphy, and paleoecology; description of major depositional environments.

title: GEOL 515 Introduction to Atmospheric Science
description: Elementary physical principles underlying the behavior of Earth's atmosphere. Dry and moist thermodynamics, radiative transfer, conservation laws, fundamental dynamical balances, instability theory, cloud physics.

title: GEOL 510L Advanced Stratigraphic Field Methods
description: Stratigraphic field methods and computer-assisted data analysis. Field trips incorporating vertical and lateral facies analysis; collection of paleocurrent, fabric, paleomagnetic, photogeologic and compaction data.

title: GEOL 505 Introductory Graduate Seminar in Earth Sciences
description: Lectures by Earth Sciences faculty about current research; introduction of new graduate students to the breadth of current research; applying for research funding; practicing effective research presentations.

title: GEOL 501 Paleobiology
description: Concepts and methods for functional morphologic analysis of fossil marine invertebrates. Systematics theory and methodology, macro evolution, and broad biotic trends in the Phanerozoic.

title: GEOL 499 Special Topics
description: Special topics in the earth sciences. Field trip required when appropriate to the topic.

title: GEOL 500 Marine Paleoecology
description: Principles of marine paleoecology; interrelationships between marine organisms and their environment in geologic time.

title: GEOL 494x Senior Thesis
description: Writing of a thesis under individual faculty super vision.

title: GEOL 491x Earth Sciences Internship
description: Local, national, and international internships providing earth sciences experience in a professional setting.

title: GEOL 490x Directed Research
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: GEOL 485L Tectonic Geomorphology
description: Focuses on the analysis of landforms that develop and evolve in tectonically active settings through the interplay of tectonics, climate, and surface processes.

title: GEOL 470L Environmental Hydrogeology
description: Concepts in hydrogeology and application to environmental problems. Topics include groundwater and surface water hydrology, chemistry, and contamination. Includes labs, guest lectures, and field trips.

title: GEOL 441 Seismic Exploration Geophysics
description: Seismic wave theory, ray theory, reflection, refraction, data processing, signal enhancement, field instrumentation and techniques on land and at sea; geological interpretation of seismic data. One field trip.

title: GEOL 465L Field Geology
description: Ten days to four weeks of field study in an area of geological complexity, with preparatory instruction.

title: GEOL 460L Geochemistry
description: Composition, origin, and evolution of the earth; principles of physical chemistry applied to aqueous systems; reaction-diffusion modeling and problems in sedimentary geochemistry; global (bio)geochemical cycles and environmental problems.

title: GEOL 450L Geosystems
description: Geosystems, such as mantle convection, active faults, climate, and the carbon cycle, will be studied using numerical models and concepts such as chaos, universality, emergence, and intermittency.

title: GEOL 433L Paleontology and Evolution in Deep Time
description: Origin and evolution of life; Precambrian life; evolutionary history of major groups during the Phanerozoic; mass extinctions; deep time and evolutionary processes.

title: GEOL 440L Geophysics and Geoengineering
description: Plate tectonics, magnetic and gravity fields, earthquakes, seismic waves, reflection and refraction seismics, heat transport, mantle convection, deep Earth structure, data analysis. Includes field trip.

title: GEOL 425L Data Analysis in the Earth and Environmental Sciences
description: Introduction to mathematical methods giving insight into earth and environmental data. Topics include probability and statistics, timeseries analysis, spectral analysis, inverse theory, interpolation.

title: GEOL 432L Introduction to Field Techniques
description: Introduction to field techniques used in a variety of Earth Science disciplines. Field and digital techniques for map making including use of GIS, GPS, and digital tablets. Field analyses of rocks and rock structures. Map interpretation and digital processing of field data. Includes weekly labs and some weekend field trips.

title: GEOL 387bg Undergraduate Team Research
description: A GE course in Earth Science. b. Multidisciplinary, learner-centered, individual and team-based student research, abroad and in the U.S.; field data collection and interpretation, mentored by domestic and international scientists.

title: GEOL 390 Special Problems
description: Supervised individual studies. No more than one registration permitted. Enrollment by petition only.

title: GEOL 387cg Undergraduate Team Research
description: A GE course in Earth Science. b. Multidisciplinary, learner-centered, individual and team-based student research, abroad and in the U.S.; field data collection and interpretation, mentored by domestic and international scientists.

title: GEOL 387ag Undergraduate Team Research
description: A GE course in Earth Science. b. Multidisciplinary, learner-centered, individual and team-based student research, abroad and in the U.S.; field data collection and interpretation, mentored by domestic and international scientists.

title: GEOL 351L Climate Systems
description: Introduces systems behavior in the context of climate dynamics. Modules of instruction geared to climate system application to real world problems.

title: GEOL 412 Oceans, Climate, and the Environment
description: Fundamentals of climate including atmosphere and ocean. Topics include radiative energy balance, ocean-atmosphere linkages and approaches to study climate while building quantitative and qualitative skills.

title: GEOL 320L Surficial Processes and Stratigraphic Systems
description: Processes of erosion, sediment transport, and deposition that shape the land surface; landscape response to tectonism; recognition and interpretation of depositional environments in the stratigraphic record.

title: GEOL 321L Structural Geology and Tectonics
description: Field and theoretical aspects of rock deformation, analysis of structural systems, and stress and strain; orogenic belts and plate tectonics; introduction to field techniques and construction of geologic maps.

title: GEOL 316L Petrologic Systems
description: Formation and identification of igneous, metamorphic and sedimentary rocks; interpretation of tectonic and environmental settings based on rock type and chemistry.

title: GEOL 305L Introduction to Engineering Geology
description: Principles of geology with emphasis on structural geology, hydrogeology and geological hazards; basic geologic considerations in civil engineering practice; introduction to mineralogy and petrology. Field trip required.

title: GEOL 315L Minerals and Earth Systems
description: Minerals and their formation in Earth geosystems; includes discussions of mineral properties, crystal structures, uses and bio geochemical importance.

title: GEOL 241Lg Energy Systems
description: Energy resources from a global perspective, including fossil fuels, nuclear, and renewable energy.

title: GEOL 445 Earth Climate: Past, Present, and Future
description: Examination of the tools used to reconstruct past climate change and a thorough discussion of past climate changes on earth with an emphasis on the recent past.

title: GEOL 240Lg Earthquakes
description: Causes of earthquakes and nature of large faults; earthquake hazard and risk; world's great earthquakes; understanding the Richter scale.

title: GEOL 150Lg Climate Change
description: Climate systems from the beginning of earth history to the present; tools and techniques used to reconstruct prehistoric climate records; effects of climate variations on development of life forms on earth.

title: GEOL 160Lg Introduction to Geosystems
description: Survey of natural geological/ environmental processes (systems) and variability active near the earth's surface in the region that houses most life (the biosphere).

title: GEOL 157Lg The  Logic of Climate Change: From Data to Deeds
description: Quantitative underpinnings of the scientific case for man-made climate change. Analysis of climate data, examination of potential causes, attribution of causes, and civilizational consequences.

title: GEOL 290L Special Laboratory
description: for students with equivalent lecture credit from another institution.

title: GEOL 130Lg The Nature of Scientific Inquiry
description: Examination of the scientific process: what constitutes science; evolution of ideas about the nature of space, time, matter, and complexity; paradigm shifts in the biological and earth sciences.

title: GEOL 126Lg The History of Life on Earth: A View from the Museum
description: Topically-driven exploration of evolution, environmental change, and the history of life on Earth via the fossil record with the Natural History Museum of Los Angeles as a laboratory. How the changing Earth and life co-evolved through time.

title: GEOL 115L Exploring California's National Parks
description: Overview of basic geologic principles and California geology taught through California's National Parks; additional focus on park history, policy, economics, and geologic hazards affecting parks. Lecture, 3 hours; laboratory, 2 hours. One all-day and one three-day field trip to a National Park required.

title: GEOL 125Lg Earth History: A Planet and Its Evolution
description: Basic principles of physics, chemistry, biology, and mathematics used in evaluating clues written in the rock record, and the processes that have shaped our planet.

title: GEOL 108Lg Crises of a Planet
description: Impact of civilization on planet earth, and impact of earth's natural evolution on society: earthquakes, volcanism, landslides, floods, global warming, acid rain, groundwater depletion and pollution; mineral and fossil fuel depletion, formation of the ozone hole.

title: GEOL 107Lg Oceanography
description: Physical, chemical, and geological character of the oceans and ocean basins. Origin of the oceans. Ocean processes and agents. Economic value of the oceans.

title: GEOL 105Lg Planet Earth
description: Geologic structure and evolution of planet earth. Principles of plate tectonics, rocks and minerals, processes of mountain building, continent and ocean formation, earthquakes, volcanism, development of landforms by running water and glaciers.

title: GEOG 794z Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: GEOG 794d Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: GEOG 794c Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: GEOG 794b Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: GEOG 794a Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: GEOG 790 Research
description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

title: GEOG 599 Special Topics
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: GEOG 390 Special Problems
description: Supervised, individual studies. No more than one registration permitted. Enrollment by petition only.

title: GEOG 431 California's Changing Landscapes
description: Type study of a region; distribution of physical and cultural phenomena; delimitation into natural regions; analysis of human-environment interaction in regions of the state. Field trips.

title: GEOG 490x Directed Research
description: Individual research and readings.

title: GEOG 257g Environment and Ethics
description: Examination of ethical issues in environmental context: systematic analysis of problems associated with protection and use of selected environments.

title: GEOG 360 Environmental Disasters
description: Evaluates the causes, effects, and responses to international environmental disasters. Emphasis is on contemporary case studies in a theoretical context.

title: GEOG 345 Conservation of Natural Resources
description: Interaction between resource conservation and people based on recent advances, current developments, and future resource utilization. Special attention to the western United States. Field trips.

title: GEOG 255 American Environmentalism
description: Geographic and historic approach to the growth of environmental awareness in the United States from Colonial times to the present. Extensive use of case materials.

title: GDEN 714 Topics in Gerontology
description: Gerontology topics for dentists including clinical assessment tools for aging patients, policy issues, myths, social supports, and consent and communication issues in the clinical setting. Open only to master's and professional dental students.

title: GDEN 715 Geriatric Dentistry Issues
description: Common geriatric dentistry topics including epidemiology of oral diseases, common dental diseases, their management and prevention protocols for older adult patients. Open only to master's and professional dental students.

title: GDEN 731 GDEN Case Portfolio Preparation for Dental Residents
description: Examination of clinical cases of geriatric patients with complex medical conditions through online conferences in preparation, development and defense of portfolio of multiple cases.

title: GDEN 730 OFPM Case Portfolio Preparation for Dental Residents
description: Examination of clinical cases of geriatric patients with orofacial pain and oral lesions through online conferences in preparation, development and defense of portfolio of multiple cases.

title: GDEN 713 Common Systemic Conditions in Older Patients
description: Lectures on topics pertinent to the aging patient that highlight the differences between aging physiologic changes and disease-caused conditions most common to this demographic. Open only to master's and professional dental students.

title: GDEN 732 Case Portfolio Defense for GDEN Students
description: Examination of clinical cases of geriatric patients with complex medical conditions through online conferences in preparation, development and in person defense of portfolio of multiple cases.

title: GDEN 711e Case Portfolio Preparation for GDEN Students
description: Examination of clinical cases of geriatric patients through online conferences. Development and defense of portfolio of multiple cases. Open only to master's and professional dental students.

title: GDEN 716 Knowledge Assessment for GDEN Certificate Students
description: Review of topics explored in the certificate program, including lectures and practical demonstrations or simulations and examinations of overall discipline knowledge. Open only to certificate in Geriatric Dentistry students. (Duplicates credit in GDEN 710)

title: GDEN 712c Capstone Research Project for GDEN Students
description: Production and defense of a research plan that demonstrates significant understanding of a topic in geriatric dentistry.

title: GDEN 712d Capstone Research Project for GDEN Students
description: Production and defense of a research plan that demonstrates significant understanding of a topic in geriatric dentistry.

title: GDEN 712b Capstone Research Project for GDEN Students
description: Production and defense of a research plan that demonstrates significant understanding of a topic in geriatric dentistry.

title: GDEN 711d Case Portfolio Preparation for GDEN Students
description: Examination of clinical cases of geriatric patients through online conferences. Development and defense of portfolio of multiple cases. Open only to master's and professional dental students.

title: GDEN 711c Case Portfolio Preparation for GDEN Students
description: Examination of clinical cases of geriatric patients through online conferences. Development and defense of portfolio of multiple cases. Open only to master's and professional dental students.

title: GDEN 712a Capstone Research Project for GDEN Students
description: Production and defense of a research plan that demonstrates significant understanding of a topic in geriatric dentistry.

title: GDEN 711b Case Portfolio Preparation for GDEN Students
description: Examination of clinical cases of geriatric patients through online conferences. Development and defense of portfolio of multiple cases. Open only to master's and professional dental students.

title: GDEN 711a Case Portfolio Preparation for GDEN Students
description: Examination of clinical cases of geriatric patients through online conferences. Development and defense of portfolio of multiple cases. Open only to master's and professional dental students.

title: FSEM 180 First Year College Seminar
description: A thematic seminar for entering students in the USC Dornsife College of Letters, Arts and Sciences, exploring an area of academic study, research, or creative work.

title: FSEM 101 Freshman Seminar
description: A seven-to-eleven week course offered for incoming freshmen; limited to 18 students. Letter graded.

title: GDEN 710 Knowledge Assessment for GDEN Students
description: Review of topics explored in the previous courses of the program, including lectures and practical demonstrations or simulations and examinations of overall discipline knowledge.

title: FSEM 100 Freshman Seminar
description: A seven-to-eleven week course offered for incoming freshmen; limited to 18 students.

title: FREN 794z Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: FREN 794d Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: FREN 794b Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: GERO 470 Aging and Business
description: An introduction to the dynamic roles of business in an aging society focusing on workplace issues, marketing to mature consumers, and careers for business gerontologists.

title: GERO 452 Economic Issues and the Aged
description: Analysis of economic factors associated with the aged; implications for individuals, society, and the economy; lifecycle economics, retirement, income maintenance, and social security.

title: GERO 481 Case Management for Older Adults
description: Overview of the concepts, characteristics, skills, and clinical issues of case management in a variety of settings serving older persons.

title: GERO 451 Policy and Program Development in Aging
description: Policy trends and changing roles of local, state, and federal agencies in planning, managing, and evaluating programs in comprehensive, coordinated systems of service for older persons.

title: GERO 475 Ethical Issues in Geriatric Health Care
description: Biomedical ethical issues that are encountered in working with geriatric patients. Examination of ethical theory and the application of theory to clinical settings.

title: FREN 794c Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: GERO 423 Psychological Development through Autobiography
description: Introduction to autobiography as a source of individual psychological development, with emphasis on integration of cognitive, emotional, and decision processes.

title: GERO 421 Managed Care for an Aging Society
description: Examines key legislation, policies, practice, and outcomes of managed care and how population aging affects health care delivery.

title: GERO 437 Social and Psychological Aspects of Death and Dying
description: Introduction and critical survey of the current issues, concepts, and research of the social and psychological aspects of death and dying.

title: GERO 416 Health Issues in Adulthood
description: Physiological, psychological, and social health problems of adults as they are impacted by health choices throughout life.

title: GERO 414 Neurobiology of Aging
description: Age-related changes in nervous system structure and function; relationship of brain changes to changes in cognitive function and perception; Alzheimer's and Parkinson's diseases. Lecture and discussion.

title: GERO 412L Exercise and Aging: Principles and Programs
description: Physiological, psychological, and sociological aspects of exercise. Laboratory involvement in assessment and evaluation of fitness.

title: GERO 415 Neuroaffective Disorders of Aging
description: Methods of studying, evaluating, and treating cognitive, psychiatric, and behavioral problems associated with medical conditions of old age.

title: GERO 411L Physiology, Nutrition, and Aging
description: Explores nutritional needs and the physiological, psychological, and sociological relationships to nutrition. Laboratory experiments in assessment and evaluation.

title: GERO 390 Special Problems
description: Supervised, individual studies. No more than one registration permitted. Enrollment by petition only.

title: GERO 385 Transitions in Adulthood
description: An exploration of the critical issues and transitions in the adult years, including careers, relationships, parenthood, and major turning points for personal development.

title: GERO 353g Social and Behavioral Foundations of Health and Aging
description: Explore social and behavioral foundations of health, longevity, and medicine, in the context of an increasingly diverse and long-lived population.

title: GERO 402 Housing for the Elderly: Policy, Programs, and Design
description: An overview of housing policies, programs and design for the elderly, including analysis and evaluation of past, current and proposed government programs.

title: GERO 380m Diversity in Aging
description: Exploring diversity in the older population and variability in the human aging process.

title: GERO 350 Administrative Problems in Aging
description: Analysis of the skills, approaches and issues involved in the planning, development, and implementation of programs directed at meeting the needs of older persons.

title: GERO 340 Policy, Values, and Power in an Aging Society
description: How Americans' political values affect public policy. Studies of landmark legislation to explore the social contract between generations and role of governments in social welfare.

title: GERO 330 Society and Adult Development
description: How social relationships affect adults of different ages; the changing contract across generations; interaction of culture, race, family and social values with adult development.

title: GERO 321 Introduction to Psychology and Aging
description: An introduction to the core curriculum in the study of Gerontology. Research perspectives on adult development and aging; methodological issues; personality and relationship issues; general mental and emotional components of aging; research methods.

title: GERO 315g A Journey into the Mind
description: Introduction to the brain and mind. A unique multimedia approach to stress how knowledge about the mind is gained from scientific and clinical investigations.

title: GERO 310 Physiology of Aging
description: Effects of normative aging processes on homeostatic mechanisms and how these changes relate to development of disorder and disease in later life.

title: GERO 320g Psychology of Adult Development
description: How psychologists study thinking, memory, emotions, personality, and behavior, and how people change in these throughout adulthood to old age.

title: GERO 200 Gerontology: The Science of Adult Development
description: Introduction to adult development through the lifespan; biological, psychological, and social processes; gerontology as a career for the future.

title: GERM 499 Special Topics
description: Intensive study of selected topics or regions.

title: GERM 470 Advanced Composition and Stylistics
description: Development of competence in written expression; fundamentals of style in expository writing. In German.

title: GERM 490x Directed Research
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: GERM 465 Germany East and West
description: Study of the ideological, economic, social, and cultural differences between East and West Germany between 1945 and 1990 and their impact on today's unified Germany. In English.

title: GERM 466 The German Speaking Nations
description: Focus on the culture, history, and society of Austria, East and West Germany, and Switzerland. In German.

title: GERM 430 Age of Goethe
description: Background and significance of the period; lyrics, major dramatic and prose works from 1770–1832; Storm and Stress; Classicism; Goethe and Schiller. In German.

title: GERM 460 Expressionism to the Present
description: Representative authors and works since 1910; World War I, Expressionism, New Objectivity, World War II; literature after 1945: East and West, Swiss and Austrian.

title: GERM 420 Profile of German Literature II
description: Survey of major trends, figures, and authors in German literature and culture of the 18th and 19th centuries within the European context. In German.

title: GERM 410 Profile of German Literature I
description: Survey of major trends in German literature within their historical and cultural contexts from the beginnings to the Baroque period. In German.

title: GERM 372g Literature and Culture in Berlin in the 1920s
description: Literature, culture, and society through works by figures such as Kaiser, Toller, Brecht/Weill, Piscator, Th. Mann, Doeblin, Lukacs, Heidegger, etc. Films: Caligari, Metropolis, Berlin, M, Blue Angel. In English.

title: GERM 390 Special Problems
description: Supervised, individual studies. No more than one registration permitted. Enrollment by petition only.

title: GERM 375g The German Exile Experience
description: Surveys the work of German intellectuals, writers, artists, and scientists in U.S. exile during the time of the Nazi government in the 1930s and 1940s.

title: GERM 370 Literature and Culture in Vienna at the Turn of the Century
description: Literature, culture, and society in Vienna 1890–1925; works by figures such as Schnitzler, Hofmannsthal, Kafka, Musil, Kraus, Schönberg, Kokoschka, Freud, Wittgenstein, and others. In English.

title: GERM 352 Colloquium on Poetry
description: Definition and analysis of lyric genre through a study of major poets, such as Goethe, Schiller, Heine, Rilke, and Hofmannsthal; poetic traditions from the 17th century to the present. In German.

title: GERM 340 German Prose Fiction from Goethe to Thomas Mann
description: Examines German prose fiction from the late 18th to the early 20th centuries, with particular emphasis on how narrative texts are constructed. In English.

title: GERM 353 Colloquium on Prose
description: Study of German prose from the 18th century to the present; emphasis on narrative and thematic perspectives in relation to social change and on modernism since Kafka. In German.

title: GERM 351 Colloquium on Drama
description: German drama from the 18th century, with emphasis on modernism (since Büchner) and the 20th century avant garde styles: Expressionist, Epic, Grotesque, Documentary, and Sprechtheater. In German.

title: GERM 335 Applied German Drama
description: Works of a German playwright in their social and cultural context, leading to a dramatization of one of the works. In German.

title: GERM 346 German Folklore and Popular Culture
description: Survey and analysis of folklore and cultural phenomena, including tales, legends, and myths; folk and popular music; beliefs and customs. In English.

title: GERM 360g 20th Century German Prose: Texts and Films
description: Aesthetic and historical analysis of major German 20th century novels, complemented by brief study of cinematic adaptation of each text. Texts in English; films with subtitles.

title: GERM 330 Introduction to Literary Studies
description: Review of essential literary terms, concepts, and critical methods through analysis and discussion of selected primary and secondary works. In German.

title: GERM 325 Composition and Conversation in Cultural History
description: Practice in oral and written German, emphasizing the cultural history of the German-speaking countries of Europe. In German.

title: GERM 320 Composition and Conversation on Contemporary Affairs
description: Practice in oral and written German, emphasizing contemporary cultural and social developments in the German-speaking countries of Europe. In German.

title: GERM 310 Business German I
description: Introduction to German business language structure including correspondence and oral communication. In German.

title: GERM 020x Course in Reading German
description: For graduate students who wish help in meeting the German reading requirement for the PhD degree. Emphasis on development of reading skills.

title: GERM 101 German I
description: Introduction to modern German. Oral practice, listening and reading comprehension. Basic structures necessary for simple spoken and written expression.

title: GERM 221 Conversational German IV
description: Conversational German in a variety of topical settings and vocabulary domains.

title: GERM 025x Course in Reading German
description: Continuation of 020x. Reading selections appropriate to candidate's major field.

title: GERM 201 German III, Conversation and Composition
description: Intermediate German. Increasing emphasis on listening and speaking skills and a review of basic structures of German. Discussion of cultural aspects.

title: GERM 102 German II
description: Continuation of German I. Introduction to German culture.

title: GERM 311 Business German II
description: . Terminology and style of commercial and legal texts, analyzed and applied in oral and written work. In German.

title: GEOL 794z Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: GEOL 794d Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: GEOL 794b Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: GEOL 794c Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: GEOL 794a Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: GEOL 790 Research
description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

title: GEOL 650 Recent Advances in Paleontology
description: Selected review of recent ideas in paleobiology, evolution, and paleoecology related to examining the current frontiers in paleontology.

title: GEOL 609 Seminar in Earthquake Physics
description: Current research on the physics governing earthquakes and faults, including results from continuum and fracture mechanics, statistical physics, lab experiments, and seismological observations.

title: GEOL 601 Seminar in Sedimentary Geology
description: Analysis and discussion of current topics in sedimentary geology; topics will be chosen by students and faculty to focus on areas of recent advances.

title: GEOL 599 Special Topics
description: Special topics in the earth sciences. Field trip required when appropriate to the topic.

title: GEOL 596 Internship for Curricular Practical Training
description: Part-time or full-time practical work experience in the student's field of study. The internship must be located at an off-campus facility. Students are individually supervised by faculty. May not be taken until the student has completed at least one semester of enrollment in the graduate program.

title: GEOL 594z Master's Thesis
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: GEOL 594a Master's Thesis
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: GEOL 594b Master's Thesis
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: GEOL 593 Practicum in Teaching the Liberal Arts
description: Practical principles for the long-term development of effective teaching within college disciplines. Intended for teaching assistants in Dornsife College.

title: GEOL 590 Directed Research
description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

title: GEOL 577L Micropaleontology
description: Microscopic fossils, especially foraminifera, their classification, the common genera, morphology, evolutionary trends; laboratory and field techniques.

title: GEOL 569L Igneous Petrology
description: Study of igneous and meta-igneous rocks from the basis of experimental and field data and theoretical considerations.

title: GEOL 568L Metamorphic Petrology
description: An introduction to advanced study of metamorphic mineral assemblages with use of experimental and field data.

title: GEOL 567 Stable Isotope Geochemistry
description: Theoretical basis; nuclide nomenclature, partition function ratios, mechanisms and rates of isotope exchange; mass spectrometry and extraction techniques; application of stable isotopes to geologic problems.

title: GEOL 566 Geochemistry Seminar
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: GEOL 564 Isotope Geochemistry
description: Variations in the isotopic composition of elements in the earth's crust with applications to geological problems, including geochronology, geothermometry, ore genesis, and crustal evolution.

title: GEOL 575 Organic Geochemistry
description: Advanced course on the fundamentals and frontiers of organic geochemistry. Topics include biomarker and isotope geochemical approaches to reconstructing past marine, terrestrial environmental change.

title: GEOL 558 Inverse Theory in the Earth Sciences
description: Short review of probability theory, and extensive coverage of linear inverse theory, including seismic imaging. Non-linear inverse problems and factor analysis.

title: GEOL 560 Marine Geochemistry
description: Principles of chemical sedimentology and aquatic chemistry; diagenesis, authigenesis, and the geochemical cycle.

title: GEOL 552 Advanced Seismology
description: Advanced methods of theoretical seismology for studying the generation of seismic waves from natural and artificial sources and the propagation through realistic earth models.

title: GEOL 557 Numerical Modeling of Earth Systems
description: The quantitative modeling of ordinary and partial differential equations as they arise in geology, geophysics, climate modeling and related fields with practical, numerical focus.

title: GEOL 555 Paleoceanography
description: Mesozoic and Cenozoic paleoceanography; analytical approaches applied to water mass history, paleocirculation, paleoproductivity, nutrient cycling, and paleotemperature reconstruction. Lecture, readings, and research project.

title: GEOL 553 Physics of Earthquakes
description: Basic physics of earthquakes and seismicity. Continuum elasticity; fracture mechanics; laboratory friction; damage rheology; physics of critical phenomena; spatio-temporal seismicity patterns; analysis of complex data sets.

title: GEOL 556 Active Tectonics
description: Aspects of deformation and associated seismicity at active plate margins around the world. Includes review of plate tectonics, seismology, geodesy, paleomagnetism, geodynamics, - Quaternary dating techniques, tectonic geomorphology, paleoseismology, and seismic hazard assessment. Two weekend field trips required.

title: GEOL 551 Introduction to Seismology
description: Basic elements of seismology for the study of the earth's interior and the tectonic process, utilizing observations of seismic waves.

title: GEOL 550 Chemical Equilibrium and Disequilibrium in Geology
description: Phase equilibria; phase diagrams; thermodynamics of aqueous and solid solutions; irreversible thermodynamics; kinetics, diffusion, and metasomatism, with applications to problems in petrology and geochemistry.

title: GEOL 538 Tectonic Evolution of Western North America
description: Geosynclinal and orogenic development of western North America from the Precambrian to present, in the light of plate tectonics concepts. Field trips.

title: GEOL 537 Rock Mechanics
description: Elasticity, fracture, and flow properties of rocks and minerals; effects of temperature, pressure, petrology, fractures, and interstitial fluids. Experimental techniques and geological applications.

title: GEOL 540 The Mantle System
description: Dynamics and structure of the deep earth and its relationship to earth evolution.

title: IML 499 Special Topics
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture, Lab

title: IML 500 The Praxis of Sonic and Visual Media
description: An introduction to digital authorship at the graduate level, with a focus on the potential of multimedia scholarship and networked dissemination.

title: IML 477 Embodied Storytelling and Immersive Docu-Narratives
description: Examination of art, media, and theatre, to create an immersive, installation-based intervention utilizing the embodied 360-degree docu-narrative form.

title: IML 466 Digital Studies Symposium
description: Lectures, presentations, and readings introducing cutting-edge digital media innovations and applications. Analysis of the critical and creative challenges of contemporary digital media practices.

title: IML 475 Media Arts Research Lab
description: A hands-on mentored research lab experience within the context of media art and in association with a real-world project.

title: IML 458 The Embedded Story: Designing Digital Landscapes and Languages
description: Exploration of the imagined territories where language and landscape originate, converge and are transformed. Students will collaborate to create media in cross-platform environments.

title: IML 490x Directed Research
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: IML 454 Advanced Techniques of Spatial Representation
description: Studio class exploring spatial perception and advanced techniques of 3-D representation, stereoscopy, panorama, projection mapping, modeling for real-time environments, parametric modeling, and 3-D fabrication.

title: IML 444 Thesis Project II
description: Registration Restriction: Open only to Media Arts and Practice majors.

title: IML 481 Mixed Realities: Histories, Theories and Practices
description: A comprehensive orientation to mixed reality, delving into its theories and histories while grounding students in a hands-on introduction to current tools and techniques.

title: IML 456 Nature, Design and Media
description: Investigation of the impact of natural patterns on digital media design. Explores the relationships among chaos, harmony, beauty, proportion, spirituality, holistic systems and shaped experience.

title: IML 440 Interdisciplinary Honors Thesis
description: Production of an interdisciplinary digital thesis project.

title: IML 450 Critical Play and Documentary Games
description: Investigation of the history and theory of games designed to prompt social change, with a hands-on component in the creation of documentary game projects.

title: IML 441 Thesis Project I
description: Exploration of theoretical and practical concerns of advanced digital media authorship.

title: IML 436 Hypercinemas Studio
description: A hands-on exploration of emerging cinematic technologies, situated within a historical context through both theoretical and practical analysis.

title: IML 435 Digital Narrative Design II
description: Exploration of advanced techniques in digital audio and video storytelling. Emphasis on nonlinearity, computer graphics, sound design and networked media.

title: IML 419 Emotion in Digital Culture
description: Project-based course examining emotion in relation to technology, digital culture and the human experience.

title: IML 420m New Media for Social Change
description: Creating real social change through multimedia, working in collaboration with a local nonprofit organization.

title: IML 430 Visual Communication and Experience Design
description: Studio course focused on visual design, UX/UI design and the creative process. Emulating design agencies and working with clients and creative briefs.

title: IML 428 Exploring and Creating Sonic Environments
description: Exploration of spatial sound practices, focusing on sound installation art, sonic visualization and audio storytelling techniques.

title: IML 422 Information Visualization
description: Visualizing information through diverse media platforms, with a focus on critical analysis and hands-on visualization.

title: IML 385 Design Fiction and Speculative Futures
description: The history, theory and methods of design fiction, focusing on design videos and physical prototypes as tools for exploring contemporary social, political and ethical life.

title: IML 400 Creative Coding for the Web
description: Analysis and development of scholarly media projects using diverse web authoring strategies, technologies and documentation.

title: IML 404 Tangible and Spatial Computing
description: Exploration of extended human computer interaction, including new forms of haptic, sonic and other sense modalities, through physical computing and spatial interfaces.

title: IML 354 Introduction to 3-D Modeling
description: An introduction to the history, theory and critical context of 3-D spatial representation, as well as foundational authoring skills in modeling interactive 3-D spaces.

title: IML 365 Future Cinema
description: Examination of the history of cinematic experimentation to provide a framework for understanding contemporary virtual reality, augmented reality, interactive installations and large-scale urban screens.

title: IML 340 Remixing the Archive
description: An intermediate level course which approaches archived material from multiple perspectives, in order to develop new avenues of expression, education, and research.

title: IML 335 Digital Narrative Design I
description: An introduction to audio and video techniques for digital storytelling across various platforms. Students will create multiple short-form projects using contemporary tools and technologies.

title: IML 328 Sonic Media Art
description: Survey of audio culture and sound technologies, focusing on developing sonic literacy and creating artwork using sound as a primary modality.

title: IML 320 Designing and Writing for Transmedia Narratives
description: Creating a story that uses three or more digital platforms (video, social media, games, comics, et cetera) with strategies drawn from entertainment, art and activism.

title: IML 346 Methods in Digital Research
description: Emphasizing rigorous multimedia research and authorship strategies, this course prepares students to undertake large-scale digital projects.

title: IML 309 Integrative Design for Mobile Devices
description: Hands-on investigation of opportunities and challenges offered by mobile interaction within both cultural and ideological contexts.

title: IML 300 Reading and Writing the Web
description: An introduction to a broad range of technical and theoretical issues surrounding the production of web-based content.

title: IML 295Lm Race, Class and Gender in Digital Culture
description: Critical analysis of the categories of race, class and gender within the diverse digital spaces of contemporary culture, from video games to the digital divide.

title: IML 310 Professionalism for Media Arts
description: Development of documentation and archival strategies, with an emphasis on techniques of personal and professional representation.

title: IML 288 Critical Thinking and Procedural Media
description: Investigation of the potentials of computational media to define new aesthetics, modes of representation and structures of communication.

title: IML 230 Fundamentals of Media Design
description: Introduction to the methods of visual design with respect to digital media authorship. Exploring the creative process through various conceptual workflows and hands-on techniques.

title: IML 203 Media Arts and Practice Studio II
description: Intermediate laboratory exploring computational systems through a series of critical design prompts. Emphasis on digital representation, time-based processes, abstract data and the relationship between humans and computers.

title: IML 202 Media Arts and Practice Studio I
description: Intermediate laboratory exploring the foundations of visual culture through a series of critical design prompts. Emphasis on the creative process, project documentation and the development of a personal design methodology.

title: IML 201 The Languages of Digital Media
description: An in-depth investigation of the close interrelationships among technology, culture and communication to form a solid foundation for digital authoring.

title: IML 140 Workshop in Multimedia Authoring
description: Introduction to the expressive potential of multimedia as a critical and creative tool, supplementing traditional forms of academic work.

title: IML 104 Introduction to Digital Studies
description: An introduction to the expressive range of screen languages in their cultural, historical, and technological contexts.

title: IDSN 585 Capstone
description: Faculty-mentored, applied project with individual and team components. Implement a prototype solution to a problem. Deploy relevant tools, methods, and processes learned throughout the program.

title: IDSN 570 Decisions and Solutions
description: Generate portfolio of solutions for a given "problem." Explore solutions and decisions, mechanisms for reducing uncertainty and risk. Includes quantitative and qualitative techniques.

title: IDSN 560 Narrative and Storytelling
description: Discipline-specific, cross-disciplinary, and shared approaches to exploring visual, written, and spoken storytelling using digital modalities. Topics include communication theory, narrative structures and content creation.

title: IDSN 545 Integrative Project
description: Faculty-mentored project paired with a Core course. Demonstrate individual and simultaneous skills and competency across fields and within cross-functional, cross-disciplinary teams.

title: IDSN 550 Opportunity and Uncertainty
description: Discipline-specific, cross-disciplinary, and shared approaches to recognizing/analyzing opportunities, identifying/framing problems, and developing/iterating solutions. Techniques gleaned from entrepreneurship, creative practices, critical thinking methods, ethnography, systems theory.

title: IDSN 540 Processes and Perspectives
description: Discipline-specific, cross-disciplinary, and shared approaches to products, services, projects, systems, organizational development. Topics include creative and user-focused perspectives, feasibility analytics, lean startup techniques.

title: IDSN 530 Technology Essentials
description: Overview of core information technology concepts, methods, and frameworks. Develop aptitude in using tools, applications and systems; learn basic programming languages and methodologies.

title: IDSN 525 Business Essentials
description: Overview of general business and management concepts and techniques that builds theoretical and analytical fluency and identifies and examines leadership and managerial challenges.

title: IDSN 520 Design Essentials
description: Overview of design language, process and product. Build fluency in applying core visual principles and design-based problem-solving techniques. Explore historical and contemporary design issues.

title: IDSN 510 Integrative Practices Residential
description: One-week campus residential. Introduction to program themes, content, concepts, theories, and processes. Opportunity to build skills and meet cohort, with an emphasis on team building.

title: HRM 555 Anticipating the Future of Human Resources
description: Explores the forces and emerging trends that are reshaping work, the workforce and workplace – and how to address these transformational changes and be effective as a Human Resources leader.

title: IDSN 505 Intensive
description: Optional short-term, primarily residential, learning experience paired with an event/activity. Intensive experience aligns with and extends the cross-disciplinary nature of the program.

title: HRM 550 Change Management and Organization Development
description: Identifies the common challenges in organizational change management and explores the limitations and opportunities of different models of organizational change.

title: HRM 545 Management of Diverse and Global Human Resources
description: Analyzes global diversity in today's environment, fostering a broad understanding of diversity and inclusion and the impact of diversity, inclusion, and inclusive behaviors on organizations.

title: IDSN 515 Professional Practices Residential
description: One-week off-campus residential. Applied, intensive workshop format focused on solutions for real-world problems with input from industry experts.

title: HRM 535 Employee Relations
description: Applies practical approaches to building positive employee and labor relations and solving related problems through increased employee motivation, effectiveness, and retention.

title: HRM 530 Learning and Development
description: Prepares students to identify, design, and implement effective learning and development interventions and strategies that drive results and enhance organizational competitiveness.

title: HRM 540 Human Resources Analytics
description: Examines and emphasizes strategies and techniques to enable improved organizational and human capital decisions by directing the organizational analytics for more actionable insights.

title: HRM 525 Total Rewards
description: Provides a comprehensive look at the employee rewards strategies that human resource practitioners promote and manage including compensation, performance management, benefits, and non-monetary rewards.

title: HRM 520 Talent Management
description: Examines talent management processes that impact employee experience and engagement and explores ways to improve data driven decision making processes including workforce and succession planning.

title: HRM 515 Organization Design
description: Equips students with a deeper understanding of how to design and develop organizations to increase performance and effectiveness and includes sections on strategy, work, and management processes.

title: HRM 510 Leadership in Human Resources
description: Focuses on developing the critical social intelligence skills needed to lead people and change through increased self-awareness, understanding of interpersonal differences, and greater influence.

title: HRM 505 Organizational Culture and Employee Outcomes
description: Prepares students to create, foster, and manage organizations in which people thrive and perform at their best in order to retain talent and reduce costs in a sustainable way.

title: HRM 500 Human Resource Strategy
description: Explores the strategic role that human resources management plays in providing organizations with sustained competitive advantages by unlocking the productive potential of employees' human and social capital.

title: HP 499 Special Topics
description: Lecture and discussion focused on specific topics within health promotion and disease prevention. Course topic will vary from semester to semester.

title: HP 490x Directed Research
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: HP 485 Global Health: Obesity and Nutrition
description: Overview of the epidemiology of obesity and related diseases and the etiology of obesity, including genetic, biological, behavioral, environmental and sociocultural correlations.

title: HP 480 Internship in Health Promotion and Disease Prevention
description: Field placement in a community agency such as a county health services agency, a not for profit voluntary agency or a health care setting.

title: HP 470 Case Studies in Global Health
description: Case study examination of programs and organizational structure underlying current international efforts addressing problems related to infection disease, chronic disease, global environmental change, emergencies and emerging disease epidemics.

title: HP 460 Adolescent Health
description: Survey of the development of healthy and the prevention of health-risk behaviors during adolescence. Prevention and promotion techniques will be explored emphasizing cultural differences.

title: HP 465 Health Status of Indigenous Peoples of America
description: Survey of indigenous people's health, including health conditions, special cultural and ethical considerations, the Indian health system, and the politics of indigenous health.

title: HP 450 Traditional Eastern Medicine and Modern Health
description: Overview of traditional Eastern approaches toward health and disease; relevance to modern health issues, emphasizing a comparison between traditional Chinese and modern Western medicine.

title: HP 446 Poisons, People, and Politics
description: Case studies of toxic exposures and investigation of the role of government, scientists, labor and industry in protecting against health threats caused by toxic exposures.

title: HP 448 Global Environmental Changes and Health
description: Discussion of global environmental changes, including climate change, air pollution, water pollution, radiation, and their impacts on human health.

title: HP 442 Chronic Disease Epidemiology
description: Overview of causative factors and demographic distributions of the major chronic diseases in the western world; epidemiologic concepts and research designs.

title: HP 441 Health Promotion in the Workplace
description: Covers phases of worksite health promotion; research, design, implementation and evaluation; concerns regarding escalating medical costs and the role of health promotion in offering solutions.

title: HP 434 Physical Activity and Health
description: Examination of the health impacts of physical inactivity; participation rates across subgroups; physical activity determinants; and interventions, programs, and policies to promote physical activity.

title: HP 440 Happiness, Well-Being, and Health
description: Explores human strengths that promote happiness/well-being and whether they influence physical health; mind-body relationships; and strategies for promoting hope, resilience, and quality of life.

title: HP 433 Advanced Topics in Nutrition
description: In-depth discussion of vitamins and minerals and their role in human nutrition; introduction to the role of vitamins and minerals in selected pathological conditions.

title: HP 432 Clinical Nutrition
description: Metabolism of carbohydrates, fats and protein; introduction to vitamins, minerals and dietary modifications in various pathological conditions.

title: HP 431 Behavior and Education Strategies for Nutrition and Fitness
description: Examination of dietary intake and exercise behaviors as they relate to health and illness; methods for measuring diet and exercise.

title: HP 430 Obesity and Health
description: Examination of causes and consequences of obesity, with emphasis on health risks of type II diabetes and cardiovascular disease.

title: HP 421 Violence as a Public Health Issue
description: Patterns and prevalence of violence; psychosocial, environmental, and biological influences on violent behavior; youth gangs; drugs and violence; family violence; and prevention and intervention strategies.

title: HP 412 Health Promotion and Prevention Policy
description: Overview of health promotion and drug prevention policy at local, state, and federal levels; methods for evaluating policy effectiveness and cost effectiveness.

title: HP 420m Gender and Minority Health Issues
description: Examines the nature and roots of health disparities among women, men, and different ethnic and age groups; methods for reducing such disparities; strategies for prevention services.

title: HP 422 AIDS in Society
description: Provides a broad examination of issues in HIV/AIDS, including behavioral, social, biological, clinical and ethical dimensions of the pandemic in the U.S. and elsewhere.

title: HP 411 Drug Intervention Program Design and Evaluation
description: Strategies for drug abuse prevention and intervention; introduction to techniques and research methods used in designing, conducting, and evaluating drug abuse prevention programs.

title: HP 409 Environmental Impacts on the Brain
description: An examination of the physical and chemical factors in the environment that contribute to neurodevelopmental disorders, cognitive function and neurodegeneration.

title: HP 408 Environmental Health in the Community
description: Survey of occupational and environmental health. Introduction to epidemiology, exposure assessment, toxicology, policy development, risk assessment, and effects of urban development on health.

title: HP 410 Issues in Prevention and Cessation of Drug Abuse
description: Examination of factors related to drug abuse behaviors; overview and assessment of drug abuse prevention and cessation programs; relapse prevention programs.

title: HP 405 Sexually Transmitted Diseases: A Global Public Health Priority
description: An overview of the magnitude and impact of STDs including prevention, diagnosis, and treatment of common STDs, STD/HIV interrelationship, global burden, trends, public health challenges, and STD/HIV prevention and control strategies and programs worldwide.

title: HP 404 Religion and Health
description: Differential relationships of religiosity and spirituality with health and risk behaviors, physical and mental health outcomes, coping skills and well-being across cultures and religions.

title: HP 403 Behavioral Medicine
description: Examines behavioral risk factors for illness, health-enhancing and health-compromising behaviors, stress/coping in promoting health and preventing illness, and behavioral management of chronic illness.

title: HBIO 442L Evaluation and Rehabilitation of Athletic Injuries
description: Application of scientific principles to evaluating and rehabilitating athletic injuries.

title: HBIO 441L Prevention of Athletic Injuries
description: Application of scientific principles to conditioning, protecting, and rehabilitating the athlete.

title: HBIO 439L Human Performance and Bioenergetics
description: Application of physiology, biomechanics and perceptual-motor principles to the study of skill acquisition and human performance.

title: HBIO 420L Applied Human Physiology
description: The physiology of the respiratory, cardiovascular, renal, musculoskeletal, digestive, endocrine, and nervous systems in humans, with application to human health and pathology.

title: HBIO 435 Neurobiology of Feeding Behavior and Obesity
description: Neurobiological systems that control feeding behavior and energy balance with an emphasis on the determinants of obesity.

title: HBIO 409 Metabolic Diseases
description: Examination of the etiology, prevention, and treatment of metabolic disorders such as diabetes mellitus and obesity that are major threats to public health.

title: HBIO 407L Endocrinology and Metabolism
description: Regulation of metabolic pathways and endocrinology in health and metabolic diseases.

title: HBIO 408L Biomechanics
description: Kinematic and kinetic analysis of human motion. Emphasis on performance enhancement and injury prevention.

title: HBIO 406 Theory and Method in Human Evolutionary Biology
description: Historical and theoretical approaches to major issues in the field of human evolutionary biology. Capstone course in which students will undertake an original independent research project.

title: HBIO 401L Physiology and Biomechanics of Movement
description: Terminology, structure and function of muscle, bone and endocrine systems; Effects of exercise and training on those systems.

title: HBIO 403L Forensic Science of the Bones
description: Comprehensive study of forensic anthropology; emphasis on identification of human remains and creation of biological profiles including age, sex, time and manner of death, etc.

title: HBIO 400L Motor Control and Learning
description: Theories of control and learning applied to motor performance; variables affecting performance in exercise, games, sports, and dance.

title: HBIO 405 Evolutionary Medicine
description: Evolutionary, cultural, and environmental factors in the emergence and existence of diseases; a Darwinian examination of illness in the human species.

title: HBIO 360 Nutrition and Disease
description: Principles of diet therapy for the prevention and treatment of human disease.

title: HBIO 370 Genetics and Disease
description: An overview of the genetic underpinning of human health and disease. Inheritance of mendelian diseases, common diseases, developmental diseases and cancer; prenatal testing, genetic counseling and genetic therapies.

title: HBIO 310 Sociopsychological Aspects of Sport and Physical Activity
description: Examination of the individual in a social environment related to sport and physical activity; personality, motivation, attitude, and group behavior viewed in physical activity contexts.

title: HBIO 320 Muscle Physiology
description: Analysis of the skeletal muscular system (anatomy, physiology, biochemistry, and development) and its functional properties under both normal and pathological conditions.

title: HBIO 308 Origins and Evolution of Human Behavior
description: Examination of the evidence for and against evolutionary bases of a range of human behaviors. Topics include sex differences, human reproductive strategies, race, IQ, human ecology.

title: HBIO 350 Nutrition and Homeostasis
description: Theories and principles of regulation of vitamin/mineral metabolism as it relates to homeostasis of organ systems.

title: HBIO 306 Primate Social Behavior and Ecology
description: Behavior and ecology of living nonhuman primates, with an emphasis on field studies of apes and monkeys. Topics include aggression, communication, reproduction, and cognition.

title: HBIO 302L Nutrition and Metabolism
description: Gastrointestinal physiology and energy metabolism as it relates to macronutrient intake. Theories and principles of nutrition and their impact on metabolic regulation.

title: HBIO 301L Human Anatomy
description: Major organ systems; functional implications of their relationships; gross and microscopic examination with an emphasis on practical skills in recognizing, dissecting, and differentiating anatomical structures.

title: HBIO 300 Evolution, Ecology, and Culture
description: The roles of biology, culture, and the environment in shaping human society, integrating evolutionary biology and cultural theory.

title: HBIO 250g The Pharmacology of Performance Enhancing Drugs
description: Evaluation of drugs, nutritional supplements, and ergogenic aids that are purported to enhance human athletic performance to promote weight and fat loss.

title: HBIO 205Lgx The Science of Sport
description: The physiological and nutritional basis of human performance. Factors that facilitate and limit athletic achievement.

title: HBIO 203L Individualized Exercise Prescription
description: Principles and theories related to exercise prescription; programs of weight-training, circuit-training, aerobics, flexibility, high and low-intensity training guidelines; safeguards and effectiveness.

title: HBIO 202Lg Nutrition for Life
description: To develop an understanding of Nutrition, especially as it pertains to optimal health and prevention of diseases. A study of macro and micro nutrients.

title: HBHV 601 Understanding Stress in Dental Practice
description: Investigation of the approaches to understanding and managing stress, especially the stress issues in dentistry.

title: HBIO 200Lg The Human Animal

title: HIST 185g Introduction to Armenian Studies and Armenian History

title: HIST 108g Histories of South Asia

title: HIST 107gp Introduction to the History of Japan

title: HIST 106g Chinese Lives: An Introduction to Chinese History

title: GSBA 522b Managerial Perspectives
description: Managerial careers, development of critical executive and managerial abilities, and the dynamics of organizational environment and systems as they impact managerial progression and work.
