title: GSBA 521a Corporate Finance
description: Basic principles of corporate finance; theory and application; management of short-term and long-term assets; financial instruments and markets; financial policy applications.

title: GSBA 519b Strategic Formulation for Competitive Advantage
description: Analyses of environments and competition, the basis of competitive strategy, strategy models, and the achievement of sustainable competitive advantage.

title: GSBA 519a Strategic Formulation for Competitive Advantage
description: Analyses of environments and competition, the basis of competitive strategy, strategy models, and the achievement of sustainable competitive advantage.

title: GSBA 518 Accounting Control Systems
description: Accumulation and interpretation of accounting data by management; profit planning; analysis of operations; systems for control of production and distribution costs; cost and profit centers for decentralized control.

title: GSBA 511 Microeconomics for Management
description: Microeconomic theory with business applications; consumer demand, production theory, cost theory, and market theory; decision-making within the firm under different market and regulatory environments.

title: GSBA 516 Essentials of Data Analysis and Modeling
description: Data collection, data analysis, and critical understanding of the role of data in making business decisions. Ways to quantify uncertainty and model decision problems.

title: GSBA 510 Accounting Concepts and Financial Reporting
description: Information systems for public reporting and for management decision-making; theory of asset and income measurement; interpretation and uses of accounting data and financial statements; analysis of cases.

title: GSBA 509 Marketing Management
description: Development of analytical, strategic, and planning skills. Application within an integrated strategic framework to the development of a comprehensive marketing plan for a product, service, and/or organization.

title: GSBA 506b Applied Managerial Statistics
description: Principles of probability theory and classical statistics applied to business decision problems; survey analysis, estimation and prediction methods, evaluation, and control techniques.

title: GSBA 506a Applied Managerial Statistics
description: Principles of probability theory and classical statistics applied to business decision problems; survey analysis, estimation and prediction methods, evaluation, and control techniques.

title: GSBA 505 Fundamentals of Business
description: Duplicates Credit in GSBA 506a, GSBA 506b, GSBA 510, GSBA 511, GSBA 516, GSBA 524, and GSBA 545.

title: GSBA 504b Operations Management
description: Formulation, modeling, analysis, and optimization of business decision problems; survey of concepts and techniques necessary to manage the operations function of a firm.

title: GSBA 504a Operations Management
description: Formulation, modeling, analysis, and optimization of business decision problems; survey of concepts and techniques necessary to manage the operations function of a firm.

title: GSBA 502 Management Communication for Leaders
description: Integrates leadership theory and practice with communication skills to improve individual, team, and organizational performance. Emphasizes interpersonal, presentation, and writing skills; teamwork; and value-based leadership.

title: GSBA 501 The Role of the Manager
description: Fundamental roles of a manager and skill sets necessary to performing these roles. Open only to online MBA students.

title: GRSC 850b The Professoriate: Preparing for the Future
description: Preparation for academic careers: various methodologies and approaches to teaching, learning, assessment, and research; statements of research and teaching philosophies; creation of online academic portfolio.

title: GRSC 850a The Professoriate: Preparing for the Future
description: Preparation for academic careers: various methodologies and approaches to teaching, learning, assessment, and research; statements of research and teaching philosophies; creation of online academic portfolio.

title: GRSC 810 Studies for Master's Examination
description: completion of all course work for the master's degree. Permission of the Graduate School.

title: GRSC 800 Studies for the Qualifying Examination
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: GRSC 791 Directed Research
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: GRSC 610 The Innovation Process: Development, Diffusion and Leadership
description: Exploration of general principles and evolution of innovation, theoretical perspectives on the innovation process, organizing and leadership for innovation, and practical tools for innovation development, diffusion, market acceptance, and business planning.

title: GRSC 615 Disciplinary Perspectives on Innovation
description: A deeper understanding of the innovation process via a survey of various disciplines' approaches to the subject.

title: GRSC 596 Internship for Curricular Practical Training
description: Part-time or full-time, practical work experience in the student's field of study. The internship must be located at an off-campus facility. Students are individually supervised by faculty. May not be taken until the student has completed at least one semester of enrollment in the graduate program with a cumulative 3.0 GPA.

title: GR 490x Directed Research
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: GR 499 Special Topics
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: GR 450 Readings in Greek Literature
description: Readings in various authors and genres of Greek literature.

title: GR 390 Special Problems

title: GR 365 Greek Lyric Poetry
description: Readings from Archilochus, Sappho, Alcaeus, Pindar, and other lyric poets.

title: GR 375 Plutarch
description: Readings of selected works by the Greek author Plutarch.

title: GR 355 Aristophanes
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: GR 362 Homer and the Greek Epic
description: Selections from the Iliad and/or Odyssey. Problems of oral composition and transmission.

title: GR 354 Greek Historians
description: Selections from such representative historians as Herodotus and Thucydides.

title: GR 353 Plato
description: Readings from the Republic or other dialogues.

title: GR 220 Greek III
description: Reading Greek literature. Introduction to reading and translation of classical Greek prose and poetry. Extensive grammar review.

title: GR 345 Greek Tragic Poets
description: Selected plays of Aeschylus, Sophocles, and Euripides.

title: GR 150 Greek II
description: Essentials of classical Greek grammar and vocabulary, continued. Basic reading skills.

title: GR 120 Greek I
description: Essentials of classical Greek grammar and vocabulary.

title: GPPD 600a Public Policy Capstone
description: Hands-on experience in policy analysis. Participants learn to work on a specific, client oriented public policy issue, assess policy alternatives, and write an official report.

title: GPPD 600b Public Policy Capstone
description: Hands-on experience in policy analysis. Participants learn to work on a specific, client oriented public policy issue, assess policy alternatives, and write an official report.

title: GPPD 580 Policy Challenges in International Development
description: Overview of the overarching issues of problem definition of "development" and the policy implications of new ideas for development as it faces a new set of challenges in an increasingly globalized, complex, and interconnected world.

title: GPPD 570 Institutions and Policy Processes
description: Policy formulation and implementation in a comparative context and in the context of an East-West dichotomy.

title: GPPD 560 Methods for Policy Evaluation
description: Methods utilized in the analysis of public policy choices; ex ante and ex post analysis; cost-benefit analysis; decision and risk analysis; applied social science methods.

title: GPPD 550 Quantitative Methods for Public Policy
description: Economic theory and statistical inference methods to estimate the relationship between economic, social and political variables; foundations of data-based argumentation, specifically in regards to public policy in an international context.

title: GPPD 540 Comparative Institutions and Policy Context
description: Theoretical and empirical foundations on how institutions affect policy performance; comparative institutional analysis and framework; approaches to organizing public action.

title: GPPD 530 Art and Craft of Public Policy Analysis
description: Foundations of public policy as a profession, and develops basic skills in policy analytic reasoning, policy design, normative analysis and ethics, and argumentation.

title: GPPD 520 Leadership in Public-Private Partnerships
description: Issues across public/private partnerships; leadership and followership in cross-sector settings; organizational and institutional designs; problem solving, negotiation and conflict resolution.

title: GPPD 510 Economic Foundations for Public Policy
description: Microeconomic foundations; analysis of public sector problems; markets; producer and consumer theory; private and social efficiency.

title: GPPD 500b Global Policy Challenges and Solutions
description: Consideration of current public policy issues through informed discourse and debate; analysis and policy arguments

title: GPPD 500a Global Policy Challenges and Solutions
description: Consideration of current public policy issues through informed discourse and debate; analysis and policy arguments.

title: GPR 733d Advanced and Maxillofacial Prosthodontics
description: Residents train to treat patients requiring various types of removable and fixed prosthetics, including Maxillofacial prostheses.

title: GPR 733c Advanced and Maxillofacial Prosthodontics
description: Residents train to treat patients requiring various types of removable and fixed prosthetics, including Maxillofacial prostheses.

description: Residents train to treat patients requiring various types of removable and fixed prosthetics, including Maxillofacial prostheses.

title: GPR 733a Advanced and Maxillofacial Prosthodontics
description: Residents train to treat patients requiring various types of removable and fixed prosthetics, including Maxillofacial prostheses.

title: HIST 490x Directed Research
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: HIST 487 The United States since 1939
description: A survey of the accelerating changes that transformed the nation's domestic life and revolutionized America's role in world affairs.

title: HIST 488 Teaching History in the Secondary Schools
description: Seminar in research methods, textbook and online research and teaching materials, and instructional approaches for teaching history in secondary schools.

title: HIST 484 The United States, 1919–1939
description: Postwar reaction and the Twenties; the Great Depression and the New Deal; diplomacy between the wars.

title: HIST 481 Producing Film Histories
description: History of film form and its institutions. Students will produce an original written or multimedia research project.

title: HIST 478 The United States, 1789–1850
description: The nation during the first six decades; development of American institutions; constitutional growth, expansion, sectionalism, and the Mexican War; the Compromise of 1850.

title: HIST 474 Sex, Gender, and Colonialism in Latin America, 1492 to 1820
description: Seminar overview of the historical literature on women, gender, and sexuality in colonial Latin America.

title: HIST 473 Colonial Latin America Seminar
description: The history of colonial Latin America, focusing on the transformation of native Americans and Europeans into participants in a new colonial tradition.

title: HIST 470 The Spanish Inquisition in the Early Modern Hispanic World
description: The Spanish Inquisition in Spain and Colonial Latin America, major theories and interpretations.

title: HIST 465 America in the Cold War World, 1945–1991
description: America's role in the Cold War and the impact of that conflict on its people, society and culture.

title: HIST 466 New World Orders: US and the Atlantic World, 1918-2018
description: Critical examination of attempts by the United States and major European powers to institute varying kinds of order across borders.

title: HIST 462 20th Century American Thought
description: Major American thinkers from John Dewey and Jane Addams to Martin Luther King and Richard Rorty, with emphasis on race, religion, politics, and gender.

title: HIST 464 Culture, Money, and Power: Japanese-American Relations since 1853
description: Examination of the role of cultural, economic, and military forces in shaping relations between two of the most important nations in the Asia/Pacific regions.

title: HIST 461 19th Century American Thought
description: Major American thinkers from Emerson and Margaret Fuller to William James and W.E.B. DuBois, with emphasis on race, religion, politics, and gender.

title: HIST 458 History of California
description: Exploration, colonization, and development of Hispanic California; coming of the Americans; political, economic, and cultural development of California since its acquisition by the United States.

title: HIST 460 War, Race, and the Constitution
description: Examines the World War II incarceration of Japanese Americans and its impact on issues of civil liberties as well as national security.

title: HIST 463 The Constitutional History of the United States
description: Historical influences on changes in the structure, practice, and interpretation of the American Constitution, including debates about institutional powers and civil/political rights and liberties.

title: HIST 457 The American West
description: The nation's westward movement from Colonial times to the present, with emphasis on the frontier's effect on American life and institutions.

title: GPR 711b Implantology
description: Residents recognize the importance of implant dentistry and various implant systems and their restorative options.

title: GPR 722 Occlusion, TMJ Dysfunction, Orofacial Pain
description: Residents review the important role that Occlusion plays in General Dentistry and neuromuscular problems of the head and neck.

title: GPR 711a Implantology
description: Residents recognize the importance of implant dentistry and various implant systems and their restorative options.

title: GPR 710d Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery
description: More advanced instruction in oral and maxillofacial surgery and related diseases as appropriate to the practice of general dentistry; extensive clinical experience.

description: More advanced instruction in oral and maxillofacial surgery and related diseases as appropriate to the practice of general dentistry; extensive clinical experience.

description: More advanced instruction in oral and maxillofacial surgery and related diseases as appropriate to the practice of general dentistry; extensive clinical experience.

description: Presentation of various techniques in current periodontal treatment.

description: Presentation of various techniques in current periodontal treatment.

description: Residents lead seminars with case presentations of complex multidisciplinary treatment plans, completed therapy and staff conferences.

description: Residents lead seminars with case presentations of complex multidisciplinary treatment plans, completed therapy and staff conferences.

title: GPR 705b Periodontal Treatment Procedures
description: Presentation of various techniques in current periodontal treatment.

title: GPR 702 General Dentistry Overview
description: Residents demonstrate the most appropriate and ideal restorative treatment utilizing various dental materials.

title: GPR 701 Treating Medically Compromised Dental Patients
description: Residents learn of various medical problems, how they relate to dental treatment and how to manage patients with various medical problems.

title: GPR 622 Forensic Dentistry
description: Introduction to Forensic Odontology. Residents to learn the principles of Dental Forensics.

title: GPR 611d Emergency Medicine
description: Residents utilize medical knowledge to detect and identify early signs of medical emergencies.

title: GPR 705a Periodontal Treatment Procedures
description: Presentation of various techniques in current periodontal treatment.

title: GPR 611b Emergency Medicine
description: Residents utilize medical knowledge to detect and identify early signs of medical emergencies.

title: GPR 611c Emergency Medicine
description: Residents utilize medical knowledge to detect and identify early signs of medical emergencies.

title: GPR 611a Emergency Medicine
description: Residents utilize medical knowledge to detect and identify early signs of medical emergencies.

title: GPR 605d Review of General Dentistry Literature
description: Residents learn how to research various topics and to critically review each article in order to practice evidence-based dentistry.

title: HIST 456 Race, Slavery, and the Making of the Atlantic World
description: Introduction to the literature of the Atlantic World with a focus on slavery and its role in the emergence of the modern era. Seminar enrollment limited to 15 students.

title: HIST 455 Advanced Topics in African-American History
description: Exploration of African-American history through primary and secondary sources employing a colloquium format with an emphasis on shared responsibility for comprehensive discussion and analysis.

title: HIST 453 The Age of Emancipation
description: Examines the evolution of racial status law in the long 19th century, with special emphasis on the relationship between slavery, segregation, and citizenship.

title: HIST 452 Beauty and the Body in Historical Perspective
description: Cultural constructions of the body and beauty from gender, ethnicity, age, and disability perspectives in Europe and the United States from 1800 to the present.

title: HIST 454 The World Pirates Made: Piracy and Privateering, 1500–1815
description: Research seminar on history of piracy and its role in rise of modern state and nation.

title: HIST 451 The Mexican Revolution
description: The roots, trajectory and outcome of the Mexican revolution of 1910.

title: HIST 446 Resistance to Genocide
description: Examination of theoretical approaches to and historical accounts of resistance to genocide. Students conduct original research on how people oppose or resist mass atrocities.

title: HIST 444 Mass Violence and Comparative Genocide in Modern World History
description: Systematic exploration of origins, developments, forms, and aftermath of mass murder of large population groups, one of the dark elements of modern world history.

title: HIST 441 Modern World History
description: Comparative patterns of historical change around the world, from ca. 1800 to the present.

title: HIST 443 Race and Religious Riots in Modern World History
description: Origins of riots against Mexicans, Chinese, Jews and other minority groups in Asia, Europe, Australia and the Americas.

title: HIST 438 Seminar in Pre-Modern Japanese History
description: A readings and research seminar dealing with one topic in the history of Japan before 1550. Topics will change each time the course is offered.

title: HIST 440 Early Modern World History
description: Comparative patterns of historical change around the world, from ca. 1500 to ca. 1800.

title: HIST 437 Seminar in Modern Chinese History
description: A readings and research seminar dealing with one topic in the history of China since 1600. Topics will change each time the course is offered.

title: HIST 432 Britain in the 18th Century
description: Political, social, and cultural aspects of British life from the accession of George I to about 1820.

title: HIST 430 The Indian Ocean World
description: History of the Indian Ocean world as a major arena of political, economic and cultural contact during the nineteenth and twentieth centuries.

title: HIST 429 Street Life: Urban Culture in Modern Europe
description: The 19th and 20th century European city as social artifact, cultural setting and object of fascination for its contemporary inhabitants.

title: HIST 425 The Era of the First World War
description: The background, causes, course, and aftermath of the First World War, with attention to the events in the United Kingdom and continental Europe.

title: HIST 428 Life and Death in Nazi Germany
description: Social, cultural and medical history of Nazi Germany, emphasizing the Nazi vision of a racially pure national community.

title: HIST 427 The German Question: Nation and Identity in Modern Central Europe
description: A seminar on the making, unmaking and remaking of the German nation-state, with particular attention to issues of race, class and gender in German identity.

title: HIST 422 European Intellectual and Cultural History: The 20th Century, 1920 to the Present
description: Intellectual and cultural trends of contemporary Europe, including Dadaism, Surrealism, Western Marxism, Fascism, Existentialism and Structuralism.

title: HIST 424 Family, Work, and Leisure in Russian History
description: Children and parents, love and marriage, work and leisure in the Russian village and city before and after the Revolution.

title: GPR 605c Review of General Dentistry Literature
description: Residents learn how to research various topics and to critically review each article in order to practice evidence-based dentistry.

title: HIST 421 European Intellectual and Cultural History: The Turn of the Century 1880–1920
description: Intellectual and cultural trends of turn-of-the-century Europe, including the avant-garde, the crisis of positivism, psychoanalysis and gender theory.

title: HIST 420 European Intellectual and Cultural History: The 19th Century, 1790–1870
description: Intellectual and cultural trends of 19th century Europe, including Romanticism, Conservatism, Liberalism, Socialism and Evolutionary Theory.

title: HIST 417 History of Soviet Russia: 1917–1991
description: The birth of the totalitarian regime, the emergence of the superpower and the socioeconomic, political and cultural developments that culminate in its demise.

title: HIST 416 History of Imperial Russia: 1689–1917
description: The evolution of imperial society, politics and culture from Peter the Great to the Bolshevik Revolution. The dilemmas of identity in a multinational empire.

title: HIST 414 Contemporary Europe
description: World War I and its aftermath; challenge of new culture values; World War II; problems of postwar adjustment.

title: HIST 415 Medieval and Early Modern Russia
description: The politics, society, and culture of medieval and early modern Russia; the emergence of empire and the roots of its Eurasian identity.

title: HIST 413 The Age of Revolution
description: The French and industrial revolutions and their interaction in 19th century Europe.

title: HIST 410 The Age of Humanism and Reformation
description: The thought, art, politics, and religion of western Europe in the 16th and 17th centuries; emphasis on the contribution of Christian humanism.

title: HIST 407 Europe in the 10th Century
description: Political, religious, and intellectual culture of Europe in the 10th century and beyond.

title: HIST 406 Special Periods in Medieval History
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: HIST 405 Traveling in the Early Medieval Mediterranean
description: Investigates the movement of people, products and ideas in the early medieval Mediterranean.

title: HIST 404 Seminar in Korean History
description: Exploration of issues and sources in Korean history; work on an individual research paper through an incremental process.

title: HIST 403 Carolingian Europe
description: Political, religious, and intellectual culture of Europe in the 8th and 9th centuries.

title: HIST 401 The Roman World
description: Rome at the crossroads of Europe and the Mediterranean; the rise of Rome to world power; social, cultural and political history of Republic and Empire.

title: HIST 395 Sex and the City: Constructing Gender in London, 1700-1900
description: Explores changes in gender expectations in England between 1700 and 1900 through readings and one-week travel to London

title: HIST 393g Quantitative Historical Analysis
description: Reading and doing quantitative research with historical data. Covers research designs, appropriate statistical analysis, and software packages for the use of historians.

title: HIST 392 The Southern California Armenian Diaspora
description: Explores concepts of identity, community- and state-building, diaspora, and migration through historical and ethnographic research in Southern California

title: HIST 390 Special Problems
description: Supervised, individual studies. No more than one registration permitted. Enrollment by petition only.

title: HIST 388 Women and Gender in North American History through 1920
description: Roles and relationships of women and men in North America from first contact to the 1920s, with special emphasis on race, marriage, and political culture.

title: HIST 386 American Legal History
description: An introduction to the study of law from a historical perspective; explores the interaction of law, culture, and politics from the Revolution through the New Deal.

title: HIST 385 Anglo-American Law before the 18th Century
description: The evolution of discourse, practices, and institutions in Anglo-American legal history from the later Middle Ages to the 18th century.

title: HIST 381 Cinema and History
description: Examines film as a means to narrate the past; treats the question of genre: epic, docudrama, the biopic, the music, adaptation, and such issues as authenticity and infotainment.

title: HIST 380 American Popular Culture
description: Rise of popular culture (sports, amusement parks, movies, and television) and its significance in American society from mid 19th century to the present.

title: HIST 377 Law and Society in Premodern China and Japan
description: A broad but deep look into the nature and development of law in two great East Asian civilizations, China and Japan, up to the modern era.

title: HIST 375 North Korean History
description: History of North Korea from before statehood to the present.

title: HIST 374 History of Mexico
description: The native cultures of Meso-America; colonial government, economy, and society; independence and 19th century liberalism; the Mexican revolution, 1910 to 1950.

title: HIST 372 Modern Latin America
description: Exploration of major themes and events in Latin American history from independence to the present.

title: HIST 369 Aztecs, Mayas, and other Indigenous Peoples of the Americas
description: Introduction to Pre- Columbian Mesoamerica and the Andes, the causes and consequences of the Spanish conquest, and the establishment of colonial societies and economies.

title: HIST 368 Afro-Latin America
description: History of people of African descent in Latin America; explores slavery and its legacy, the impact of liberalism and capitalism and of globalization and multiculturalism.

title: HIST 370 Spanish America, 1492–1821
description: Topics in Spanish colonialism in Americas, with a focus on how religious, sexual, and racial differences shaped colonial policies and practices.

title: HIST 367 Gender and Empire
description: Explores the relationship between gender and empire; Dutch, British, Belgian, and French Empires considered

title: HIST 366 The People's Republic of China
description: Politics, economy, society, and culture from 1949 to the present including the role of the communist party and the experiences of ordinary people.

title: HIST 365 The Second World War
description: Comparative analysis of the Second World War as a major transforming event of the 20th century. Its causes, conduct, and consequences for humanity.

title: HIST 362 Authenticity in Twentieth Century Popular Music
description: Explores how the idea of authenticity shaped American popular music and influenced iconic musicians in the twentieth century.

title: HIST 361 20th Century U.S. History
description: Critical turning points in the 20th century; sources of major social and political change. Course materials include primary documents and historic radio/television recordings.

title: HIST 363 Foundations of American Foreign Policy, 1776 to the Present
description: Evolution of American principles, roles and policies in international relations from the founding of the republic to the present.

title: HIST 360 19th Century U.S. History
description: The social, political, and economic history of the United States from the formation of the Constitution to 1900.

title: HIST 378m Introduction to Asian American History
description: Comparative examination of the social, economic, and political experiences of Asian immigrants and their descendants in the U.S., 1840s–present.

title: HIST 379 Arabs in America
description: Arab immigration and acculturation in the U.S. from late 19th century to present; emphasis on community formation, race, religion and gender.

title: HIST 356 The Old South
description: The South from Colonial days to 1860; slavery, the plantation system, politics; important social and economic problems.

title: HIST 373 History of the Mexican American
description: Racial and cultural background of Mexico; immigration and conquest; the Mexican in California and the southwest; the rise of contemporary Mexican- American consciousness.

title: HIST 354 Mexican Migration to the United States
description: Mexican migration from the 1850s to the present, emphasizing labor migrants to the United States.

title: HIST 355 The African-American Experience
description: An historical and social analysis of the African- American experience from Colonial times to the present.

title: HIST 352gp The American Civil War
description: The causes, course, campaigns, and consequences of the American Civil War, 1861–1865.

title: HIST 351 The American Revolution
description: Origins, course and consequences of the American Revolution; the post-war establishment of the Constitution.

title: HIST 349 Colonial North America 1600–1760
description: Colonial history of United States area, Canada, and Caribbean to 1760; Indians, European migration, plantation complexes, Puritan colonies, African slave migration, creole culture, borderlands, wars for empire.

title: INTB 651d Experience in Dental Teaching
description: Practical teaching experience in dental laboratory and clinic settings under faculty supervision. Includes instruction in effective methods.

title: INTB 652 Externship
description: Dental experience at an off-site location — not limited to clinical experience. Student participation must be approved by Associate Dean, Academic Affairs.

title: INTB 651c Experience in Dental Teaching
description: Practical teaching experience in dental laboratory and clinic settings under faculty supervision. Includes instruction in effective methods.

title: INTB 651a Experience in Dental Teaching
description: Practical teaching experience in dental laboratory and clinic settings under faculty supervision. Includes instruction in effective methods.

title: INTB 651b Experience in Dental Teaching
description: Practical teaching experience in dental laboratory and clinic settings under faculty supervision. Includes instruction in effective methods.

title: INTB 650f Dental Research Participation
description: Assist in research in basic science, biomedical, or clinical dental areas. Experience in research strategy, design and methods using practical scientific problem solving.

title: INTB 650d Dental Research Participation
description: Assist in research in basic science, biomedical, or clinical dental areas. Experience in research strategy, design and methods using practical scientific problem solving.

title: INTB 650c Dental Research Participation
description: Assist in research in basic science, biomedical, or clinical dental areas. Experience in research strategy, design and methods using practical scientific problem solving.

title: INTB 650e Dental Research Participation
description: Assist in research in basic science, biomedical, or clinical dental areas. Experience in research strategy, design and methods using practical scientific problem solving.

title: INTB 650a Dental Research Participation
description: Assist in research in basic science, biomedical, or clinical dental areas. Experience in research strategy, design and methods using practical scientific problem solving.

title: INTB 604 Clinics in Craniofacial Malformations
description: Diagnosis, treatment, and rehabilitation of craniofacial malformations; principles of health care of craniofacial malformation patients. Includes hospital clinical observation.

title: INTB 650b Dental Research Participation
description: Assist in research in basic science, biomedical, or clinical dental areas. Experience in research strategy, design and methods using practical scientific problem solving.

title: INTB 603 Systematic Approach to Scientific Writing
description: Study of dental research publication and review of writing principles; focus on logical arrangement of information, avoidance of common writing flaws, attainment of syntactical fluency.

title: INTB 601 Advances in Oral Biology
description: Review of basics of scientific methodology; comparison between and indications for scientific studies and case reports; critical review of current dental literature.

title: INTB 521 Basic and Medical Microbiology
description: Fundamentals of microbial structure, growth and physiology; major bacterial, viral and fungal diseases, symptoms, course, control and treatment; emphasis on diseases related to dental management.

title: INTB 504 Human Craniofacial Development and Genetics
description: Principles of human embryology and genetics; craniofacial developmental biology; molecular genetics, cytogenetics, clinical orofacial genetics, genetic counseling; bioethics.

title: HIST 353m Race and Racism in the Americas
description: Examination of selected topics in the historical development of racism with the goal of understanding the complex ways in which race has functioned in the modern world.

title: INF 599 Special Topics
description: Course content to be selected each semester from recent developments in informatics.

title: INF 570 Foundations of Communication Informatics
description: Modeling behavior and understanding network structures using graph theory and game theory. Using massive data to analyze group behavior.

title: INF 590 Directed Research
description: Research leading to the master's degree; maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

title: INF 560 Data Informatics Professional Practicum
description: Student teams working on external customer data analytic challenges; project/presentation based; real client data, and implementable solutions for delivery to actual stakeholders; capstone to degree.

title: INF 559 Introduction to Data Management
description: Function, design, and use of modern data management systems, including cloud; data management techniques; data modeling; network attached storage, clusters and data centers; relational databases; the map-reduce paradigm.

title: INF 557 Foresight for Engineers
description: Applying specialized engineering skillsets to exploring/conceiving of solutions to future challenges; use of techniques for systematically imagining/analyzing diverse possible future paths for engineering products.

title: INF 555 User Interface Design, Implementation, and Testing
description: Understand and apply user interface theory and techniques to design, build and test responsive applications that run on mobile devices and/or desktops.

title: INF 558 Building Knowledge Graphs
description: Foundations, techniques, and algorithms for building knowledge graphs and doing so at scale. Topics include information extraction, data alignment, entity linking, and the Semantic Web.

title: INF 554 Information Visualization
description: Graphical depictions of data for communication, analysis, and decision support. Cognitive processing and perception of visual data and visualizations. Designing effective visualizations. Implementing interactive visualizations.

title: INF 556 User Experience Design and Strategy
description: The practice of User Experience Design and Strategy principles for the creation of unique and compelling digital products and services.

title: INF 553 Foundations and Applications of Data Mining
description: Data mining and machine learning algorithms for analyzing very large data sets. Emphasis on Map Reduce. Case studies.

title: INF 552 Machine Learning for Data Informatics
description: Practical applications of machine learning techniques to real-world problems. Uses in data mining and recommendation systems and for building adaptive user interfaces.

title: INF 551 Foundations of Data Management
description: Function and design of modern storage systems, including cloud; data management techniques; data modeling; network attached storage, clusters and data centers; relational databases; the map-reduce paradigm.

title: INF 550 Overview of Data Informatics in Large Data Environments
description: Fundamentals of big data informatics techniques. Data lifecycle; the data scientist; machine learning; data mining; NoSQL databases; tools for storage/processing/analytics of large data set on clusters; in-data techniques.

title: INF 528 Computer Forensics
description: Preservation, identification, extraction and documentation of computer evidence stored on a computer. Data recovery; File System Analysis; Investigative Techniques and Methodologies; Forensic Reports and Presentations.

title: INF 549 Introduction to Computational Thinking and Data Science
description: Introduction to data analysis techniques and associated computing concepts for non-programmers. Topics include foundations for data analysis, visualization, parallel processing, metadata, provenance, and data stewardship.

title: INF 529 Security and Privacy in Informatics
description: Covers societal implications of information privacy and how to design systems to best preserve privacy.

title: INF 522 Policy: The Foundation for Successful Information Assurance
description: Background in computer security, or a strong willingness to learn. Recommended previous courses of study include degrees in computer science, electrical engineering, computer engineering, management information systems, and/or mathematics.

title: INF 525 Trusted System Design, Analysis and Development
description: Analysis of computer security and why systems are not secure. Concepts and techniques applicable to the design of hardware and software for Trusted Systems.

title: INF 527 Secure Systems Engineering
description: Previous degree in computer science, mathematics, computer engineering, or informatics; moderate to intermediate understanding of the fundamentals of information assurance, and distributed systems and network security. Knowledge and skill in programming.

title: INF 520 Foundations of Information Security
description: Background in computer security preferred. Recommended previous courses of study include computer science, electrical engineering, computer engineering, management information systems, and/or mathematics.

title: INF 521 Application of Cryptography to Information Security Problems
description: Application of cryptography and cryptanalysis for information assurance in secure information systems. Classical and modern cryptography. Developing management solutions.

title: INF 519 Foundations and Policy for Information Security
description: Threats to information systems; technical and procedural approaches to threat mitigation; policy specification and foundations of policy for secure systems; mechanisms for building secure security services; risk management.

title: INF 510 Principles of Programming for Informatics
description: Programming in Python for retrieving, searching, and analyzing data from the Web. Programming in Java. Learning to manipulate large data sets.

title: INF 526 Secure Systems Administration
description: Previous degree in computer science, mathematics, computer engineering, informatics, and/or information security undergraduate program. Also, it is highly recommended that students have successfully completed course work involving policy and network security.

title: INF 524 Distributed Systems and Network Security
description: Prior degree in computer science, mathematics, computer engineering, or informatics. It is recommended that students have a working understanding of communication networks and computer architecture, and some programming facility.

title: INF 454 Data Visualization and User Interface Design
description: Design of systems for data visualization; user interface design for exploring and interacting with data.

title: INF 429 Security and Privacy
description: Basic concepts in information security and privacy; implications of security and privacy breaches; security and privacy policies, threats, and protection mechanisms; security and privacy laws, regulations, and ethics.

title: INF 351 Foundations of Data Management
description: Data modeling, data storage, indexing, relational databases, key-value/document store, NoSQL, distributed file system, parallel computation and big-data analytics.

title: INF 352 Applied Machine Learning and Data Mining
description: Foundational course focusing on the understanding, application, and evaluation of machine learning and data mining approaches in data intensive scenarios.

title: INF 250 Introduction to Data Informatics
description: Fundamentals of data informatics: representation of data and knowledge, role of a data scientist, data storage/processing/analytics, machine learning, big data, and data visualization.

description: Writing the IDM senior thesis under the supervision of a faculty qualifying exam committee.

title: IML 605 Cinema to Post-Cinema and Beyond: History, Theory, Practice
description: Introduction to contemporary media theory, with attention to posthumanism, networks, and the post-cinematic, and a demonstration of these concepts in media art.

title: IML 604 Theories of Media Arts and Practice
description: Develops an anti-essentialist theory of technology adequate to the digital age that serves as a conceptual and critical framework for developing a contemporary technological imagination.

title: IML 603 Media Arts and Practice Colloquium/Professional Seminar
description: Orientation to the profession, opportunities, presentation and analysis of recent developments and applications in Media Arts and Practice.

title: IML 794a Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: IML 602 Practice of Media Arts
description: Introduction to a range of technologies and media types, while identifying and developing a specialization in one or more areas of practice.

title: IML 601 Seminar in Media and Design Studies
description: Creation of a work of digital culture, informed by cultural theory, and planned using current design methods and practices.

title: IML 600 Historical Approaches to Media Arts and Culture
description: Introduction to the historical specificities of "old" media (painting, print, photography, film, video, television) and to consequences of the convergences produced by "new" media forms.

title: IML 590 Directed Research
description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

title: IML 555 Digital Pedagogies
description: An exploration of varied pedagogical approaches and strategies informed by critical engagement with digital media and networked technologies.

title: IML 585 Creative Critical Writing Workshop
description: A writing workshop to explore innovative forms for critical writing, media-rich writing and video that borrow from creative nonfiction, the lyric essay, poetic/vernacular criticism.

title: IML 575 Graduate Media Arts Research Lab
description: A hands-on mentored graduate research lab experience within the context of media art and in association with a real-world project. Open only to graduate students.

title: IML 599 Special Topics
description: Detailed investigation of new or emergent practices in digital media; special subjects offered by visiting faculty; experimental subjects.

title: IML 535 Tactical Media Strategies
description: Integrating hardware, software and interactivity to explore new forms of expression. Emphasis on critical tactics (culture hacking, creative misuse) aimed at activism and social change.

title: IML 543 Transdisciplinary Media Design Practicum
description: Collaboration of artists and designers with non-art professionals to develop cross-disciplinary, media-based creative interventions.

title: IML 521 Non-Fiction Cinematic Practice II
description: Deepening skills in audio/video storytelling methods through a semester-long, non-fiction media project.

title: HP 365gmw Culture, Lifestyle, and Health
description: Comparison of national and international differences in health status as influenced by cultural practices and lifestyles within geographic, economic, and political environments.

title: HP 370g Introduction to Epidemiology: Methods and Applications
description: Examines the primary goals and methods of epidemiology, the study of factors that influence health and disease in individuals and populations.

title: HP 350L Health Behavior Research Methods
description: Introduction to the design, conduct and evaluation of health behavior research studies; quantitative and qualitative approaches to research and analysis.

title: HP 401 Cultural Competence in Medicine
description: Systematic development of specific professional skills for providing effective, culturally sensitive health services to diverse populations.

title: HP 345 Health Issues in Entertainment Media
description: Study of major chronic illnesses and their risk factors as a foundation for discussions about the portrayal of health and illness in entertainment media.

title: HP 340Lg Health Behavior Statistical Methods
description: Intermediate statistics for health behavior studies; topics include descriptive statistics, hypothesis testing, correlation and regression, and use of computer software in data analysis.

title: HP 290 Introduction to Research Apprenticeship
description: Individual research apprenticeship in health related fields under supervision of a departmental faculty member.

title: HP 300 Theoretical Principles of Health Behavior
description: Overview and analysis of predictors and consequences of health-related behaviors; theoretical viewpoints and strategies for behavior change.

title: HP 320 Biological and Behavioral Basis of Disease
description: Examination of the major systems of the human body; disease processes and behavioral risk factors.

title: HP 230 Nutrition and Health
description: Nutrition as it relates to health promotion across the lifespan and disease prevention. Discussion of nutrients, factors affecting food choices, food safety and global nutrition issues.

title: HP 270 Introduction to Global Health
description: Introduction to concepts of global health and disease control. Issues of globalization, global governance, emerging diseases, infectious disease treatment, and outbreak challenges.

title: HP 101 Current Issues in Medical Education and Healthcare
description: Current critical issues in healthcare delivery; strategies to succeed in medical school and as physicians.

title: HP 200 Introduction to Health Promotion and Disease Prevention
description: Introduction to strategiesfor promoting health and wellness. Includes self monitoring of health risk behavior, goal setting, and behavior changes.

title: HMGT 603 Developing and Monitoring of Quality and Patient Safety Outcomes
description: Overview of contemporary methods used to develop and monitor patient quality and safety outcomes; develop skill in data collection and analysis of clinical care outcomes; focus on operationalizing outcomes that matter to payers, organizations, and clinicians.

title: HMGT 602 Operational Efficiency Processes in Health Care Organizations
description: Improving productivity and efficiency of health care organizations combining the application of key operational analysis principles to improve quality, speed and productivity in the delivery of health care.

title: HMGT 601 Operations Management for Accountability
description: Hospital operations in the inpatient/outpatient setting; special emphasis on the growing requirement to more effectively manage across the continuum of care while assuming greater accountability in the delivery of care.

title: HMGT 570 Strategic Management
description: Provides skill development and application in the integrative discipline of strategic management including assessment, strategy formulation, implementation and control.

title: HMGT 600 Managing Risk
description: Overview of reimbursement models in clinical and institutional settings; legal, financial and clinical assumption of risk pursuant to new and evolving federal and state statutory and regulatory provisions.

title: HMGT 560 Customer-Focused Health Care Organization
description: Strategies for gaining and using customerderived data in planning, marketing and managing health care organizations.

title: HMGT 575 Managing and Improving Health
description: Methods for monitoring and improving the health of populations. Topics include outcomes management, risk-adjustment, development and implementation of practice guidelines.

title: HMGT 565 Managing the Organization's Financial Health
description: Executives confront and solve problems requiring use of accounting, finance, and management control principles; provides core financial skills for non-finance professionals.

title: HMGT 545 Systems Thinking and the Analysis of Data
description: Quality improvement and statistical tools for health managers. Covers analyzing processes; collecting and analyzing operational data; drawing valid conclusions from data.

title: HMGT 550 Law, Regulation, and Ethics
description: An intensive introduction to business and health care law, ethics and regulation; gives executives practical knowledge regarding legal consideration in business transactions.

title: HMGT 525 Managed Care Operations
description: Focuses on managerial, operational, and organizational aspects of managed care for integrated delivery systems, health plans, and medical groups.

title: HMGT 540 Health Economics, Financing and Reimbursement
description: Provides a framework for the economic analysis of health care issues and provides students with an opportunity to apply economic methods to a number of actual health care problems.

title: HMGT 520 Leading People and Health Care Organizations
description: An exploration of contemporary work force issues and skills development in organizational design, performance measurement, teamwork, conflict resolution, leadership, and change management.

title: HMGT 510 The Dynamics of Health Care Leadership
description: A five-day residential provides an intensive, multi-faceted learning experience in leadership, communication, managed care, systems thinking, and the health care environment.

title: HMGT 512 Information Technology and Patient Engagement
description: Strategic management and utilization of healthcare information technology in the delivery of healthcare; patient engagement and the use of technology to facilitate participation in their own care.

title: HIST 675 Seminar in 19th Century United States History
description: Research in historical problems of the Antebellum, Civil War, and Post-Civil War periods.

title: HIST 670 Illness and Healing in the Modern World

title: HIST 655 Seminar in Western American History
description: Selected topics in the history of the American frontier and the West.

title: HIST 635 Seminar in Chinese History
description: Directed research in historical problems.

title: HIST 630 Seminar in Japanese History
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: HIST 617 Seminar in Russian History
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: HIST 620 Research Seminar on Modern Visual Culture
description: A research seminar focusing on Western visual culture since the mid-18th century.

title: HIST 610 Seminar in Early Modern European History
description: Directed research in historical problems concerning the 17th and 18th centuries.

title: HIST 615 Seminar in Modern European History
description: Directed research in historical problems dealing with Europe since 1789.

title: HIST 605 Seminar in Medieval European History
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: HIST 608 Seminar on Premodern Europe
description: Directed research on topics from late antiquity to the 18th century. Students will work with both their faculty advisers and the course instructor.

title: HIST 595x Practicum in Teaching the Liberal Arts
description: Basic principles of history pedagogy, with emphasis on practical applications and the importance of career-long skill development. Required for first semester teaching assistants in history.

title: HIST 602 Seminar in Ancient History
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture
