title: HIST 593 The Art of Historical Writing
description: An analysis of conventional forms of historical representation and the artistic and scientific challenges to them. Laboratory training in innovative forms of historical writing will be stressed.

title: HIST 592 Historiography
description: Historical criticism; form and mechanics of presenting research; writers of history, their works and philosophies; theories of historical development.

title: HIST 591 Quantitative Historical Research
description: Teaches statistical concepts, methods, and tools for researching and interpreting the past.

title: HIST 660 Research Seminar on Transpacific Studies
description: Interdisciplinary research seminar foregrounding a multilateral approach towards understanding the political, cultural, economic, and military relations and conflicts between Asia, the Americas, and the Pacific.

title: HIST 590 Directed Research
description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

title: HIST 586 Studies in American Intellectual and Cultural History
description: Readings, analyses, and discussion of selected topics relating to the history of American thought and the arts.

title: HIST 587 Studies in the Politics of American Popular Culture
description: Selected themes, theories, and key works in the politics of American popular culture.

title: HIST 585 Studies in 20th Century American History
description: Readings and analyses in social and political problems, movements, and issues.

title: HIST 584 Seminar in American Social History
description: Creation of communities and societies; industrialization, urbanization, working class life; families, women, ethnicity; immigration; racism; mobility; reform and radicalism, leisure.

title: HIST 575 Studies in 19th Century United States History
description: Intensive readings and bibliography in the Early National, Jacksonian, Civil War, and Post-Civil War periods.

title: HIST 583 Studies in Urban History
description: Readings and analyses in the rise of the city and the impact of urbanization from the colonial era to the present.

title: HIST 567 Historical Scholarship on 19th Century America
description: Introduction to historiography and research in the political, economic, social, cultural, and intellectual history of the 19th century United States.

title: HIST 565 Studies in American International History
description: Readings and analyses of American policies, roles and principles in their interaction with peoples and nations of the world.

title: HIST 568 Historical Scholarship on 20th and 21st Century America
description: Introduction to historiography and research in the political, economic, social, cultural, and intellectual history of the 20th and 21st century United States.

title: HIST 566 Historical Scholarship on North America to 1800
description: Introduction to research in the fields of American Indian, colonial America, Atlantic world, and the early United States. Open only to graduate students.

title: HIST 561 Historiography of Colonial Mexico
description: Introduction to the historiography of Colonial Mexico from 1500 to 1821.

title: HIST 560 Transpacific History
description: Exploration of the connections and divergences in the Pacific region, 19th century to present. Topics include transnationalism, war, political economy, international relations, immigration, environmentalism, and race.

title: HIST 555 Studies in the American West
description: Zones of contact — physical, economic, political, ecological, symbolic, cultural, metaphorical — between peoples "west" of the Eurasian land mass since the rise of capitalist global expansion.

title: HIST 540 Studies in Modern East Asian History
description: Readings and analysis of a particular theme in modern Asian history, focusing on broad comparative issues like cultural identity, colonialism, nationalism, revolution, or interstate relations.

title: HIST 535 Studies in Japanese History
description: Selected topics in historical problems dealing with Japan.

title: HIST 536 Studies in Chinese History
description: Selected topics in historical problems dealing with China.

title: HIST 534 Studies in Modern Japanese History
description: Selected topics and historiography of modern Japan. Open only to doctoral students.

title: HIST 525 Studies in British History
description: Selected topics in English and British Empire history with emphasis on the 19th and 20th centuries.

title: HIST 520 Modernity and Its Visual Cultures
description: Western visual culture 1850–1930: historical background of changes in high and popular culture, technological reproducibility, display and spectacularization; recent literature and theoretical approaches.

title: HIST 517 Studies in Russian History
description: Readings, discussions, and student papers in modern Russian history.

title: HIST 515 Studies in Modern European History: Europe's 20th Century
description: Readings in the history and historiography of Europe in the 20th century.

title: HIST 514 Studies in Modern European History, 1789–1914
description: Readings and current bibliography in the history of Europe from the French Revolution to the outbreak of World War I; emphasis on cultural history approaches.

title: HIST 510 Studies in Early Modern European History
description: Readings of major interpretive studies on the 17th and 18th centuries.

title: HIST 511 Studies in Early Modern British History
description: Readings of major interpretive and historiographical studies on 16th and 17th century British history.

title: HIST 509 Studies in the Reformation
description: Readings, reports, and discussions of major problems, issues, and interpretations of the Reformation.

title: HIST 508 Studies in the Renaissance
description: Europe in the Renaissance: sources; secondary bibliography; and historiography.

title: HIST 506 Studies in Later Medieval History
description: Intensive study of subjects selected from the later Middle Ages, emphasizing source material, bibliography, and historiographic problems.

title: HIST 505 Studies in Early Medieval History
description: Intensive study of subjects selected from the early Middle Ages, emphasizing source material, bibliography, and historiographic problems.

title: HIST 500 Introduction to Graduate Historical Studies
description: Techniques, theories, and sub-disciplines of history.

title: HIST 498 Seminar on Selected Historical Topics
description: Advanced study in historical analysis and writing on selected topics and themes. Seminar enrollment limited to 15 students.

title: HIST 499 Special Topics
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: HIST 554 Readings in Chicano/Latino History
description: Readings, analyses, and discussion of various approaches, topics, and genres in the field of Chicano/Latino history.

title: HIST 495 American Lives: Biography and Autobiography in the United States Past
description: The history of the United States seen through the lives of individuals, including Thomas Jefferson, Jane Addams, Malcolm  X, and Marilyn Monroe.

title: HIST 496 Internship in Public History
description: The ideas and practices of public history explored through a seminar and an internship at a museum, historical society, or archive.

title: HIST 492 Honors Thesis
description: Writing of the honors thesis; for students in the History Honors Program.

title: HIST 494 Seminar in New Historical Writing
description: Historical writing experiments combining historical specificity with more fluid approaches to time, characterization and objectivity associated with 20th century artists.

title: ISE 563 Financial Engineering
description: Concepts underlying the economic analysis of engineering projects; applications to call and put options; utility theory and mathematical optimizations models; and simulation.

title: ISE 561 Economic Analysis of Engineering Projects
description: Economic evaluations of engineering systems for both government and private industry; quantitative techniques for evaluating non-monetary consequences; formal treatment of risk and uncertainty.

title: ISE 562 Value and Decision Theory
description: Decision making under risk conditions; utility theory; sufficient statistics; conjugate prior distributions; terminal and pre-posterior analysis; Bayesian statistics versus classical statistics.

title: ISE 555 Invention and Technology Development
description: This project-oriented course elaborates on the process of engaging creative thought, tools and techniques for invention, and issues involved in bringing inventions to the production phase.

title: ISE 554 Innovation and the Engineering Enterprise
description: Examination of innovation in engineering enterprises including human behavior and human resources, organizational development, engineering management, business structures, financing the enterprise and intellectual property.

title: ISE 545 Technology Development and Implementation
description: Principles and practices of technology development and implementation, with application to products and systems in manufacturing and services.

title: ISE 544 Management of Engineering Teams
description: Design and management of engineering teams. Group decision-making, motivation, leadership, infrastructural requirements, performance measurement, team diversity, conflict, and integration.

title: ISE 539 Stochastic Elements of Simulation
description: Simulation techniques combined with probabilistic analysis for solving problems in inventory theory, queuing theory, financial engineering, decision analysis, and other fields having a stochastic element.

title: HIST 497 Senior Seminar in Early Modern Studies
description: Intensive engagement with current research, problems, and methodologies in Early Modern discourses and cultures. Required capstone seminar for interdepartmental minor in early modern studies. Open only to seniors; open only to early modern studies minors.

title: ISE 538 Markov Models for Performance Analysis
description: Random variables, stochastic processes, birth and death processes, continuous- and discrete-time Markov chains with finite and infinite number of states, renewal phenomena, and queuing systems.

title: ISE 533 Integrative Analytics
description: The three pillars of analytics (predictive, prescriptive, and validation) together under one framework. Use of statistics, learning enabled optimization. Based on publicly available data sets.

title: ISE 536 Linear Programming and Extensions
description: Linear programming models for resource allocation; simplex and revised simplex methods; duality; sensitivity; transportation problems; selected extensions to large scale, multiobjective, and special structured models.

title: ISE 530 Optimization Methods for Analytics
description: Linear Programming, Integer Programming, quadratic and nonlinear programming.

title: ISE 532 Network Flows
description: Tree, path, flow problems, formulation and solution techniques. Methods for minimal cost flows. Applications.

title: ISE 529 Engineering Data Analytics
description: Theory and methods of data analytics emphasizing engineering applications: multivariate statistics, supervised learning, classification, smoothing and kernel methods, support vector machines, discrimination analysis, unsupervised learning.

title: ISE 560 Analysis of Algorithms
description: Explores fundamental techniques such as recursion, Fourier transform ordering, dynamic programming for efficient algorithm construction. Examples include arithmetic, algebraic, graph, pattern matching, sorting, searching algorithms.

title: ISE 528 Advanced Statistical Aspects of Engineering Reliability
description: Advanced statistical methods applied to reliability engineering. Experimental design analysis and interpretation of multifactor reliability problems.

title: ISE 527 Quality Management for Engineers
description: Principles of quality management, quality philosophies and frameworks, quality leadership and strategic planning, process management, and performance measurements.

title: ISE 525 Design of Experiments
description: Planning data collection to investigate relationships between product/process design choices (materials, temperatures, etc.) and performance, empirical modeling to predict performance, identification of the best design choices.

title: ISE 556 Stochastic Systems and Reinforcement Learning
description: Stochastic system models, Dynamic programming, Linear quadratic control, Kalman filtering and estimation, System identification, approximate dynamic programming methods, adaptive control, reinforcement and online learning.

title: ISE 517 Modern Enterprise Systems
description: Managing the process design, interfaces and resources of service and manufacturing systems, based on the state of their processes.

title: ISE 520 Optimization Theory and Algorithms: Numerical Optimization
description: Numerical methods for multidimensional, non-linear optimization algorithms, simple and quadratic programming

title: ISE 515 Engineering Project Management
description: Applying industrial and systems engineering skills to problems drawn from industry, while working in teams of 3–4 students. Teach project management skills and provide direct experience in managing and executing a group project.

title: ISE 514 Advanced Production Planning and Scheduling
description: Advanced concepts in production planning and scheduling including resource allocation, lot sizing, flow shop and job shop scheduling, workforce scheduling and assembly line balancing.

title: ISE 511L Mechatronic Systems Engineering
description: Use of mechanical, electrical, and computer engineering, math, and computer science to design of high performance and sophisticated products and processes and systems involving mechatronic.

title: ISE 513 Inventory Systems
description: Deterministic and stochastic demand systems with static/dynamic models. Practice in inventory management, computerized procedures, materials requirements planning, just-intime production, Kanban systems.

title: ISE 510 Advanced Computational Design and Manufacturing
description: Study advanced concepts behind computational representations, algorithms, and mathematical foundations, and their applications in computeraided design and manufacturing. Develop hands-on computational skills in team projects.

title: ISE 509 Practicum in Health Care Systems
description: Performance improvement projects within hospitals are undertaken by small teams collaborating with hospital staff. Study of tools to improve and optimize operations.

title: ISE 505 Modeling for Health Policy and Medical Decision Making
description: Basic probability; advanced undergraduates are encouraged to take the class and should obtain instructor permission to attend

title: ISE 500 Statistics for Engineering Managers
description: Framing engineering management situations with statistical methods. Experiments, distributions, regression, ANOVA, hypothesis.

title: ISE 499 Special Topics
description: Course content to be selected each semester from recent developments in industrial and systems engineering and related fields.

title: ISE 490x Directed Research
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: ISE 495bx Senior Design Project
description: Group work on an industrial engineering design problem in an organization. Open only to industrial and systems engineering majors.

title: ISE 495ax Senior Design Project
description: Preparation and development of the senior project proposal. Open only to industrial and systems engineering majors.

title: ISE 470 Human/Computer Interface Design
description: Essentials of human factors and computer interface for the design, development, implementation, and evaluation of integrated media systems.

title: ISE 440 Work, Technology, and Organization
description: Impact of technology on work and organizational design; effects of automation; design of improvement programs; information infrastructures; teams; individual behavioral outcomes. Upper division standing.

title: ISE 460 Engineering Economy
description: Utilizing principles of economic analysis for choice of engineering alternatives and engineering systems. Pre-tax and after-tax economy studies. Upper division standing.

title: ISE 512 Software Management and Economics
description: Theories of management and their application to software projects. Economic analysis of software products and processes. Software cost and schedule estimation, planning and control.

title: ISE 426 Statistical Quality Control
description: Quantitative aspects of statistical quality control (process control, acceptance sampling by attribute and by variable, rectifying inspection), quality assurance and the management of QC/QA functions.

title: ISE 435 Discrete Systems Simulation
description: Model design to simulate discrete event systems with basic inputand output analysis using high order languages, applied to industrial systems analysis and design problems.

title: ISE 410 Planning and Scheduling
description: Production planning, forecasting, scheduling, and inventory; computer integrated decision systems in analysis and control of production systems.

title: ISE 390 Special Problems
description: Supervised, individual studies. No more than one registration permitted. Enrollment by petition only.

title: ISE 382 Database Systems: Concepts, Design and Implementation
description: Data models for industry applications. Modeling and designing robust databases. Implementing and querying databases with SQL. Innovations in database applications.

title: ISE 370L Human Factors in Work Design
description: Physiological systems and psychological characteristics; ergonomics; anthropometry; effects of the physical environment on humans; occupational safety and health; work methods.

title: ISE 375L Facilities Design
description: Design of facilities for operations and distribution. Product, process flow, material handling, and facility location techniques that lead to making good decisions for facilities layouts.

title: ISE 350 Principles of Systems Engineering
description: Systems as complex collaborative ensembles of interconnected components. Theory and practice of requirements, design, implementation, testing, deployment, operation, and disposal. Case studies from real projects.

title: ISE 344 Engineering Team Management
description: Examine team formation and team dynamics including organizational behavior, group dynamics, psychology, and business management, all in the context of engineering development; decision-making and negotiation.

title: ISE 335L Supply Chain Design
description: Design of Supply Chains. Product, distribution, transportation and site selection. Analysis and optimization of supply chain networks.

title: ISE 331 Introduction to Operations Research: Stochastic Models
description: Stochastic processes; Markov chains; queueing theory and queueing decision models; probabilistic inventory models.

title: ISE 330 Introduction to Operations Research: Deterministic Models
description: Introduction to linear programming; transportation and assignment problems; dynamic programming; integer programming; nonlinear programming.

title: ISE 327 Six Sigma and Lean Operations
description: Standardized methodology for problem solving, basic and advanced statistical tools for root cause identification and solution confirmation, key principles for quality management and organizational excellence.

title: ISE 315L Engineering Project Management
description: Techniques for planning, budgeting, scheduling, obtaining resources, monitoring and control of projects in a corporate environment. Use of software to evaluate performance and assess risks.

title: ISE 310L Facilities and Logistics
description: Facilities layout and design: material handling and transportation; site selection and sourcing; supply chain management.

title: ISE 225 Engineering Statistics I
description: Sampling distributions; parameter estimation, hypothesis testing; analysis of variance; regression; nonparametric statistics.

title: ISE 220 Probability Concepts in Engineering
description: Techniques for handling uncertainties in engineering design: discrete and continuous random variables; expectations, probability distributions and transformations of random variables; limit theorems; approximations and applications.

title: ISE 150 Solving Engineering Problems via Computer Programming
description: Engineering examples are used as a platform to introduce computer programming skills for problem solving; critical thinking skills.

title: ISE 232L Manufacturing Processes
description: Basic manufacturing processes including casting, machining, forming and welding; current trends in manufacturing processes including polymer, ceramic and composite material processing, and electronic device fabrication; introduction to numerical control and computer integrated manufacturing.

title: ISE 105 Introduction to Industrial and Systems Engineering
description: A combination of plant tours, laboratory experiences, and lecture are used to introduce the philosophy, subject matter, aims, goals, and techniques of industrial and systems engineering.

title: IRAN 350 Advanced Persian II
description: Duplicates Credit in former MDES 350.

title: IRAN 320 Advanced Persian I
description: Advanced verbal and written expression in Persian, including deeper understanding of Persian culture.

title: IRAN 220 Persian III
description: Intermediate Persian (Farsi). Building conversational skills, listening and reading comprehension, grammar and vocabulary necessary for intermediate level spoken and written expression.

title: IRAN 120 Persian I
description: Introduction to contemporary Persian (Farsi). Oral practice, listening and reading comprehension, grammar and vocabulary necessary for simple spoken and written expression.

title: IRAN 150 Persian II
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: IRAN 250 Persian IV
description: Continuing Intermediate Persian (Farsi). Building conversational skills, listening and reading comprehension, grammar and vocabulary necessary for intermediate level spoken and written expression.

title: IR 499 Special Topics
description: Selected topics in various special areas within international relations, which may vary from semester to semester or within semesters.

title: IR 494 Honors Thesis Seminar
description: Preparation and oral defense of senior honors thesis before supervising faculty and fellow honors students.

title: IR 490x Directed Research
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: IR 491x Field Study
description: Local, national, and international internships.

title: IR 483 War and Diplomacy: The U.S. in World Affairs
description: Perspective on recent American foreign policy; a case study of conflicting literature on the origins, development and legacy of the Cold War.

title: IR 470 Comparative Regionalism
description: Analysis of the factors that provide different forms of regional arrangements in different parts of the world (e.g, NAFTA, FU, ASEAN).

title: IR 466 Contemporary Issues in Latin American Politics
description: Focus on current politics in Latin America. Address a range of themes: electoral democracy, citizenship, political inclusion, human rights, corruption, economic inequality.

title: IR 468 European Integration
description: Research on the European Union's role in European international relations; internal EU developments since 1985 as an actor in the world economy.

title: IR 465 Contemporary Issues in United States-Latin America Relations
description: Examines major issues in the relationship between the United States and the countries of Latin America and the Caribbean, including trade and financial questions, security, immigration, the environment, narcotics, etc. Major bilateral relations (especially with Mexico, Brazil, and the Caribbean Basin countries) are emphasized, as are regional and multilateral relationships.

title: IR 464 US-Middle East Foreign Policy Issues
description: U.S. and Middle East perspectives on Middle Eastern affairs after the creation of the state of Israel.

title: IR 455 The Political Economy of Autocracy
description: Survey of autocracy, the world's most common form of government: its political economy, the role of elections, parties, repression, propaganda and civil resistance.

title: IR 454 The International Political Economy of Development
description: Provides a critical introduction to scholarship on international political economy (IPE), the interaction of states and markets in a global context.

title: IR 449 International Courts and the Globalization of Law
description: Research-based analysis of dramatic development of international courts, exploring causes for their development, autonomy and political relations with states, compliance, effects on international relations.

title: IR 446 The Role of Norms and International Security
description: The role of ideas, beliefs and norms in understanding state behavior and US foreign policy, from traditional security concepts to modern soft power.

title: IR 553 Political Economy of Global Telecommunication and Information
description: The political, economic, regulatory, and technological changes that are together creating a new world information economy. The politics of international telecommunications is emphasized.

title: IR 445 U.S. Defense and Foreign Policy: Nonproliferation and Weapons of Mass Destruction
description: Policies and programs aimed at stopping the spread of weapons of mass destruction. Presentations by executive/legislative officials involved in formulation and implementation of non-proliferation.

title: IR 443 Formulation of U.S. Foreign Policy
description: Critical discussion of alternative approaches explaining the formulation and implementation of U.S. foreign policy: domestic politics, organizational processes, group dynamics, individual personality and perception.

title: ITP 322 Using GIS Technology for Social Impact
description: Using geographic information systems to forward a social cause by compiling geographic data, creating and using maps, and analyzing the results; building a social impact technology product or business.

title: IR 444w Theories of Global Society
description: Why the world is organized into sovereign nation-states. The challenges to nation-states in the 21st century from globalization, democratization, revolution, technology, and new forms of cultural identity.

title: ITP 325 Ethical Hacking and Systems Defense
description: Hacking from a defense perspective. Hacker ethics and laws. Penetration testing. Vulnerability assessment. Securing workstations, servers, and networks.

title: ITP 320 Enterprise Information Systems
description: The role Information Systems play in an organization. Integration of Business Processes by using Enterprise Resource Planning Systems (ERP).

title: ITP 315x 3D Character Animation
description: Advanced exploration of the process of bringing 3D characters to life from concept to model, and through production to finished performance.

title: ITP 310 Design for User Experience
description: Fundamental concepts, techniques, practices, workflows, and tools associated with the practice of user experience and interaction design in web and mobile applications.

title: ITP 303 Full-Stack Web Development
description: Modern web development techniques and technologies used to create web applications from ground up. Topics include front-end, back-end, and web servers.

title: ITP 305 Advanced 3D Modeling, Animation, and Special Effects
description: Advanced modeling, surfacing, and animation techniques as well as dynamics, scripting, and other advanced 3D automation procedures.

title: ITP 301L Interactive Web Development
description: Design, programming techniques for creating interactive, dynamic Web pages. Web development technologies and techniques include scripting fundamentals, Javascript, dynamic HTML, Actionscript, and Flash.

title: ITP 302 Advanced Web Publishing
description: Advanced topics in Web Publishing including HTML5, CSS3, and jQuery. Concept and theory of responsive design. Miscellaneous Webmaster topics including analytics, podcasting and search engine optimization.

title: ITP 280 Video Game Production
description: History of video games; overview of game genres; phases of video game development (concept, preproduction, production, post-production); roles of artists, programmers, designers, and producers.

title: ITP 256 Blockchain
description: Explore blockchain technology, a secure and immutable way to record transactions. Learn the workings of cryptocurrencies and explore their impact on financial services, business and contracting.

title: ITP 230x Video Game Quality Assurance
description: Survey game software development through quality assurance and in-depth analysis of the development cycle with a focus on bug testing systems and methodologies.

title: ITP 228 Computer-Aided Modeling for 3D Product Design
description: Think, plan, and create in three-dimensional space using 3D printing technology and 3D modeling techniques for prototyping.

title: ITP 215L 3-D Modeling, Animation, and Special Effects
description: Developing a 3-D animation from modeling to rendering: Basics of surfacing, lighting, animation and modeling techniques. Advanced topics: compositing, particle systems, and character animation.

title: ITP 190 Tools for Digital Graphics
description: Digital tools for image creation, editing, composition, layout, web page development, professional page layout, and printing with color accuracy.

title: ITP 211 Power-Tools for Visual Communication
description: Fundamentals of visual communication; storyboarding, still and moving image creation and modification; special effects; use of standard software tools for effective visual communication.

title: ITP 125L From Hackers to CEOs: Introduction to Information Security
description: Introductory course in computer security. Fundamentals of information security management. Threats to information integrity. Ethical hacking concerns and practice. Policies and Procedures.

title: ITP 165 Introduction to C++ Programming
description: Fundamentals of C++ syntax and semantics, including function prototypes, overloading, memory management, abstract data types, object creation, pointers to class members, and I/O streams.

title: ITP 115 Programming in Python
description: Python's high level data structures and clear syntax make it an ideal first language with powerful applications to science, business, finance, math, and the web.

title: ITP 140 Mobile Application Technologies
description: Technologies, devices, operating systems, and tools of mobile applications, as well as the mobile industry. Students will use tools to create apps for different mobile devices.

title: ITP 168 Introduction to MATLAB
description: Fundamentals of MATLAB: a high-performance numeric computation and visualization environment. Overview of linear algebra and matrix manipulation; using 2-D and 3-D plotting routines; programming in MATLAB; basic numerical analysis.

title: ITP 109 Introduction to Java Programming
description: Introduction to object-oriented software design for business problems. Creation of console applications, windowed applications, and interactive Web applets.

title: ITP 101 Introduction to Business Information Technologies
description: Business technologies. Operating systems. Networks. Application software.

title: ITP 104L Web Publishing
description: Web publishing using HTML, CSS and other Web technologies. Concepts and theory of Web site creation, page layout and production. Introduction to advanced topics.

title: ITAL 592 Practicum in Teaching Italian
description: Introduction to the approaches and methods of teaching Italian as a second language.

title: ITAL 590 Directed Research
description: Research leading to the master's degree in cognate fields. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

title: ITAL 499 Special Topics
description: Special topics in Italian literature, culture, and society. Conducted in Italian.

title: ITAL 461 Italian Theatre
description: Italian dramatic literature from the earliest written documents to the present. Reading and close textual scrutiny of plays by major dramatists from the Renaissance to the present. Taught in Italian.

title: ITAL 490x Directed Research
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: ITAL 440 Futurism and Fascism in Italy
description: Literature, theatre, visual arts, and politics, from the Futurist Avant-Garde through the reign of Mussolini.

title: ITAL 403 Studies in Colonialism and Postcolonialism
description: Study and analysis of colonialism and postcolonialism in Italian contexts.

title: ITAL 401 Studies in Early Modernity
description: Study and analysis of representative works and major intellectual, cultural, and artistic trends from the early modern period (pre-1800). Taught in Italian.

title: ITAL 393 Seminar in Italian Thought
description: Introduction to important trends in recent Italian philosophy, political and social theory, and media studies. Emphasis to be determined by the department. Conducted in English.

title: ITAL 402 Studies in Modernity
description: Study and analysis of representative works and major intellectual, cultural, and artistic trends from the modern period (post-1800). Taught in Italian.

title: ITAL 392 Seminar in Literary and Cultural Studies
description: Selected topics in Italian literature and culture. Conducted in English.

title: ITAL 390 Special Problems
description: Supervised, individual studies. No more than one registration permitted.

title: ITAL 381 Storytelling in the Italian Tradition
description: Reading and close textual scrutiny of major short stories from Boccaccio's Decameron to the present. Conducted in English.

title: ITAL 380 Italian Women Writers
description: Selected poetry, prose, and drama by outstanding Italian women authors and their role in Italian society from the Middle Ages to 20th century. Taught in Italian.

title: ITAL 352 The Holocaust in Italian Fiction and Film
description: The transformation of the Italian Jewish community before, during and after World War II, through an examination of modern novels, essays and films. Taught in English.

title: ITAL 347 Italy Today: Youth, Family and Migration
description: Contemporary social, political and economic issues through readings of recent Italian literature onsite.  Conducted in English.

title: ITAL 350g Italian Renaissance Literature in Translation
description: Readings of major texts of Italian literature of the 15th and 16th centuries, including works by Petrarch, the Humanists, Lorenzo de Medici, Ariosto, Machiavelli, Castiglione, and Tasso.

title: ITAL 360 Italian Cinema
description: Survey of Italian cinema in its relation to social transformation, from the silent era to the present. Weekly screenings, lectures, and discussions. Conducted in English.

title: ITAL 345 Contemporary Italy
description: Italian literature and arts in Italy following World War II. Conducted in English.

title: ITAL 340g Italian and French Cinema and Society
description: Analysis of the global impact of cinema from the silent era to the 1990s; tracing the development of French and Italian cinematography and their effect on different cultures and periods; trends and genres such as commedia all'italiana, horror, spaghetti western, feminism and postcolonialism.

title: ITAL 235x Intermediate Conversational Italian
description: Designed for students interested in maintaining and developing Italian language competency. Builds and reinforces vocabulary, idioms, communication skills and knowledge of Italian cultural aspects through discussion of contemporary topics.

title: ITAL 320 Critical Writing in Italian
description: Advanced composition through critical reading of literary texts; comprehensive analysis of difficult grammatical structures and stylistics.

title: ITAL 224 Italian Composition and Conversation
description: Practice in composition and conversation; organized around a set of themes; develops close-reading techniques and discursive skills; reviews Italian grammar.

title: ITAL 220 Italian III
description: Continuation of Italian II. Review of structure of the language, drill in aural and reading comprehension, practice in oral expression.

title: ITAL 150 Italian II
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: ITAL 020x Course in Reading Italian
description: For graduate students who wish help in meeting the Italian reading requirement for the PhD degree. Synoptic presentation of Italian grammar. Emphasis on development of reading skills.

title: ITAL 120 Italian I
description: Introduction to current Italian. Oral practice, hearing and reading comprehension; grammar necessary for simple spoken and written expression.

title: ITAL 015x Italian 150 Language Practicum
description: English grammar as it relates to Italian in order to improve students' Italian language skills; explicit pronunciation and intonation practice.

title: ITAL 012x Italian 120 Language Practicum
description: English grammar as it relates to Italian in order to improve students' Italian language skills; explicit pronunciation and intonation practice.

description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: ISE 794d Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: ISE 790 Research
description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

title: ISE 794b Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: ISE 794a Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: ISE 690 Directed Research
description: Laboratory study of specific problems by candidates for the degree Engineer in Industrial and Systems Engineering.

title: ISE 651 Seminar in Industrial and Systems Engineering
description: Current research, guest speakers in the field; review papers; guidance in preparing research proposals and special projects. Open only to fifth-year seniors and master's students.

title: ISE 633 Large Scale Optimization and Machine Learning
description: Large scale optimization algorithms that arise in modern data science and machine learning applications. Stochastic Optimization, Accelerated Methods, Parallelization, Online Optimization, Randomized Linear Algebra

title: ISE 632 Network Flows and Combinatorial Optimization
description: Combinatorial optimization, particularly graph problems. Shortest paths, max flow, minimum cost flows, spanning trees, matroids, submodular functions. Bipartite and general matchings, polyhedral combinatorics, total unimodularity.

title: ISE 637 Equilibrium Programming
description: Built on the methodology of constrained optimization, a graduate level course on equilibrium programming cast in the framework of finite-dimensional variational inequality and complementarity problems.

title: ISE 631 Linear Programming
description: Doctoral course in optimization, the foundation for subsequent courses in mathematical programming. For first-year Ph.D. students and M.S. students who intend to pursue a Ph.D.

title: ISE 630 Foundations of Optimization
description: Convex sets, convex functions, structures of optimization problems, Lagrangian and conjugate duality. First and second order optimality conditions; applications in engineering and management.

title: ISE 620 Foundations of Stochastic Processes
description: An introductory PhD course on stochastic processes, covering such topics as conditional expectation, renewal processes, and discrete and continuous time Markov chains.

title: ISE 599 Special Topics
description: Course content will be selected each semester to reflect current trends and developments in the field of industrial and systems engineering.

title: ISE 610 Advance Design of Experiments and Quality Engineering
description: Advanced planning for data collection in order to investigate relationships between product/process design choices and performance; empirical modeling to predict performance; identification of the best design.

title: ISE 594z Master's Thesis
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: ISE 594b Master's Thesis
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: ISE 594a Master's Thesis
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: ISE 590 Directed Research
description: Research leading to the master's degree; maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

title: ISE 585 Strategic Management of Technology
description: Management skills and tools for technology intensive enterprises. Life cycle analysis of technology from planning through exploitation, obsolescence and renewal.

title: ISE 671 Randomized Algorithms
description: Standard techniques in the design and analysis of randomized algorithms and random structures. Topics include tail bounds, Markov Chains, VC-dimension, probabilistic method.

title: ISE 670 Advanced Analysis of Algorithms
description: Fundamental techniques for design and analysis of algorithms. Dynamic programming; network flows; theory of NP-completeness; linear programming; approximation, randomized, and online algorithms; basic cryptography.

title: ISE 582 Web Technology for Industrial Engineering
description: A fast-paced, project-based introduction to designing and implementing interactive Web applications. Emphasizes skills for building engineering and market research applications requiring information gathering, analysis, representation.

title: ISE 583 Enterprise Wide Information Systems
description: The role of enterprise resource planning systems (ERPs) in an organization and the task of implementing and managing the IS function.

title: ISE 580 Performance Modeling with Simulation
description: Introduction to modeling and analysis of stochastic systems, with an emphasis on discrete-event simulation of non-Markovian systems.

title: ISE 576 Industrial Ecology: Technology-Environment Interaction
description: Concepts and methods to analyze the environmental impacts of industrial systems, including lifecycle assessment, material flow analysis, design for environment and sustainable consumption.

title: ISE 573 Work Physiology
description: Survey of metabolic processes in the performance of physical work, study of individual and environmental factors affecting these processes.

title: ISE 570 Human Factors in Engineering
description: Psychological and physiological characteristics of humans; how they limit engineering design of machines and human-machine systems.

description: Practical guidelines for critically appraising scientific information applicable to the clinical practice of dentistry. Seminars will complement lectures with examples.

title: INTP 651 Experience in Dental Teaching
description: Practical teaching experience in dental laboratory and clinic settings under faculty supervision. Includes instruction in effective methods.

title: INTP 650 Dental Research Participation
description: Assist in research in basic science, biomedical, or clinical dental areas. Experience in research strategy, design and methods using practical scientific problem solving.

title: INTP 503a Evaluation of Scientific Information in Clinical Practice
description: Practical guidelines for critically appraising scientific information applicable to the clinical practice of dentistry. Seminars will complement lectures with examples.

title: INTP 502a Human Relations in Dental Practice
description: Introduction to behavioral concepts related to pain, fear, sedation; interviewing, treatment planning; care of geriatric and handicapped patients; patient education; includes principles of clinical application.

title: INTP 502b Human Relations in Dental Practice
description: Introduction to behavioral concepts related to pain, fear, sedation; interviewing, treatment planning; care of geriatric and handicapped patients; patient education; includes principles of clinical application.

title: INTP 501 Behavioral Strategies in Dentistry
description: Improvement of time and stress management and effectiveness in working with others; establishment of goals in dentistry; effective presentation of ideas. For Advanced Standing Program for International Dentists.

title: INTD 790 Research
description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Open only to doctoral students.

title: INTD 685 Bioinformatics in Genome Analysis
description: Basic programming concepts for computational genomic analysis.

title: INTD 622L Pre-clinical System Block for Health, Technology and Engineering
description: A three to- nine week block of lectures and laboratories focused on particular body system (e.g., cardiovascular, renal, etc.). Open only to Health, Technology and Engineering students.

title: INTD 621b Introduction to Clinical Medicine (ICM) for THE
description: A strongly patient centered course in which both PhD engineering and MD students experience how doctors handle communications, basic diagnostic thinking and engineering perspectives. Open only to Health, Technology and Engineering students.

title: INTD 621a Introduction to Clinical Medicine (ICM) for THE
description: A strongly patient centered course in which both PhD engineering and MD students experience how doctors handle communications, basic diagnostic thinking and engineering perspectives. Open only to Health, Technology and Engineering students.

title: INTD 620 Medical Students Elective Program
description: Opportunities for medical students as preceptors in research laboratories or in field medical service under guidance of sponsors approved by faculty committees.

title: INTD 600 Student Research Presentation
description: Students prepare and present their own research to an audience of faculty and peers.

title: INTD 596 Internship for Curricular Practical Training
description: Part-time or full-time, practical work experience in the student's field of study. The internship must be located at an off-campus facility. Students are individually supervised by faculty. May not be taken until the student has completed at least one semester of enrollment in the graduate program.

title: INTD 577 Writing in the Biomedical and Biological Sciences
description: Writing instruction for graduate students focusing on grant proposals and scientific papers. Includes both writing and providing critiques of classmates' work. Lectures and discussion. Open only to doctoral students in the school of Medicine.

title: INTD 574 Medical Biology Seminar
description: Registration Restriction: Open only to Systems Biology and Disease PhD students

title: INTD 575 Interdisciplinary Research Presentations
description: Broad Topics on Biomedical Research, Human Diseases and Career Development. Open only to doctoral students.

title: INTD 535 Continuing Introduction to Clinical Medicine for MD/PhD Students
description: Course for MD/PhD students in PhD years designed to allow maintenance and improvement of clinical skills prior to re-entry in clinical rotations in the Year III medical curriculum.

title: INTD 501 Recent Advances in Vision Science
description: Recent advances in the understanding of the ocular surface are reported and discussed; students will learn how to read papers critically, develop speaking skills to explain a research paper and attend a three-day workshop on NIH proposal development and scientific manuscript preparation.

title: INTD 500 Ethics and Accountability in Biomedical Research
description: The purpose of this course is to engage current (and potential) research trainees in discussions about the responsible conduct of science. The course is designed as an option for meeting current federal regulations which require that all predoctoral and postdoctoral fellows paid from federal contracts and grants have a component of ethical training.

title: INTB 690f Directed Dental Research
description: Dental clinical and/or basic science research under faculty guidance; proposal developed, research conducted, conclusion drawn, paper written. Units determined by extent of research.

title: INTB 690e Directed Dental Research
description: Dental clinical and/or basic science research under faculty guidance; proposal developed, research conducted, conclusion drawn, paper written. Units determined by extent of research.

title: INTB 690d Directed Dental Research
description: Dental clinical and/or basic science research under faculty guidance; proposal developed, research conducted, conclusion drawn, paper written. Units determined by extent of research.

title: INTD 537 The Structure of Scientific Revolutions in Molecular Biology
description: A course in how scientists make breakthrough discoveries and whether there are predictable ingredients for significant changes in perception of the living system.

title: IR 440 America's Pacific Century: Dialogues between the U.S. and Asia
description: A hands-on analysis of the contemporary U.S. foreign policy towards East Asia through lectures, interviews, and policy paper writing, including an exchange visit to Singapore.

title: IR 439 Political Economy of Russia and Eurasia
description: Interaction of politics and economics in the former Soviet Union and its component republics; the historical planned economy, the politics of reform and the political economy of former Soviet foreign relations.

title: INTB 690c Directed Dental Research
description: Dental clinical and/or basic science research under faculty guidance; proposal developed, research conducted, conclusion drawn, paper written. Units determined by extent of research.

title: IR 437 Comparative Genocide
description: An interdisciplinary treatment of the tragic phenomenon of genocide. Subject matter includes historical cases and analysis of contemporary global efforts toward prevention.

title: IR 438 Nationalism and Ethnic Conflict after Communism
description: Explores origins and nature of ethnic strife among post-socialist states (ethnicity and national revival, modern histories of East-Central Europe and Russia, problems and conflict resolution).

title: IR 430 The Politics of International Trade
description: Economic approaches and political processes are used to explain observed international trade policy choices. Topics covered include globalization, regionalism, labor standards, the environment and sanctions.

title: IR 431 Commercial and Financial Globalization-Trends, Challenges
description: Factors determining the feasibility, desirability and limits of economic globalization; the dynamics triggered by the Global Financial Crisis and the backlash against Globalization.

title: IR 426 Trade Politics in the Western Hemisphere
description: Focus on the dynamic process of trade integration that has occurred since the mid-1980s in the Western Hemisphere.

title: IR 425 The New Triangle: China, the U.S. and Latin America
description: China's rise in the international political economy raises policy research questions, including an analysis of how this trend relates to U.S and Latin American relations.

title: IR 428 China's Political Economy
description: Critical issues surrounding China's economic rise and the implications for international relations; the unique strengths and vulnerabilities of China's political-economic model; prospects for change.

title: IR 427 Seminar on Economics and Security
description: Introduction to important economic issue areas that are understood as security-related in the contemporary world: food, trade, debt, etc.

title: IR 424w Citizenship and Migration in International Politics
description: Changing notions of citizenship in the context of history, and of economic, political and sociological theories of international migration; diaspora and migration case studies.

title: IR 422 Ecological Security and Global Politics
description: Should environmental issues be treated as threats to security? Survey of recent literature explores global environmental politics using a security framework.

title: IR 412 Applied Data Science for International Relations 1
description: Introduction to statistical computing and data visualization in R. Focus on visualization of descriptive statistics; create publication-ready figures for actual faculty research projects.

title: IR 413 Applied Data Science for International Relations 2
description: Intermediate statistical computing and data visualization in R. Focus the on graphical presentation of complex statistical relationships. Students create publication-ready figures for actual faculty research projects.

title: IR 408 Global Democratization
description: Exploration of the global experience with democracy. Meaning of the term "democracy," explanations of the rise and fall of democracy, its current trends and future challenges.

title: IR 407 Chinese Foreign Policy
description: The domestic and international sources of Chinese foreign policy; political, military, and economic issues in China's relations with its neighbors.

title: IR 410 The History of Modern International Relations
description: Explores modern international relations history, focusing on the role of the U.S. in the global politics. Provides training in historical research methods.

title: IR 406 Ethics and World Politics
description: Exploration of the relationship between ethics and politics. Special focus on religion, violence and human rights in international relations

title: IR 402 Theories of War
description: Causes of war; means of prevention and consequences of war.

title: IR 404 International Relations Policy Task Force
description: Addresses unfinished question of public policy. Provides experience in interviewing and field research, oral presentation and collective discussion and deliberation. Open to juniors and seniors only.

title: IR 401 The United Nations and World Order
description: The contribution of the United Nations to world order, focusing on its history, principal organs, relationships with global actors, and prospects for reform.

title: IR 403 Transnational Diplomacy and Global Security
description: Explores emerging "diplomatic" relations between nation-states and transnational (non-state) entities, such as non-governmental organizations (NGOs), in the development of global peace and security policies.

title: IR 392 Supervised Undergraduate Research Experience
description: Collaborative research projects under faculty supervision. Regular skills training and professionalization workshops.

title: IR 391 Directed International Relations Field Study
description: Intensive internship experience in international relations professional areas with academic research component (may be repeated for credit different semesters).

title: IR 389 Islam in France
description: (Paris Semester only) Historical overview of interactions between Muslims and Europeans. Islam: origins, history and circumstances that led to its revival. France's immigration policy.

title: IR 387 Strategic Studies
description: Strategic theory and its application to national security and warfare from Western and non-Western perspectives. Topics include strategic culture, political decision-making, cyber operations, and non-state challenges.

title: IR 390 Special Problems
description: Supervised, individual studies. No more than one registration permitted. Enrollment by petition only.

title: IR 386 Terrorism and Counterterrorism
description: Examination of terrorism and responses to terrorism, including how societies understand and deal with terrorism; focus on ethical and normative issues.

title: IR 385 European Foreign Policy and Security Issues
description: In-depth analysis of foreign policy events and cases in Europe in the 20th century; focus on security issues.

title: IR 383 Conflict Mediation & Negotiation
description: Focuses on the international politics of resolving crises. Application of theories of conflict and negotiation in a UN Security Council Simulation.

title: IR 384 Asian Security Issues
description: Introduction to key security trends in the Asia-Pacific region, emphasizing strategic competition between U.S., Russia, and China; regional military capabilities; rise of neutrality politics.

title: IR 382w Order and Disorder in Global Affairs
description: Modern and post-modern perspectives on changes in the inter-state system, relations among cultures and civilizations, the conditions of ecologically sustainable human development.

title: IR 381 Introduction to International Security
description: Key concepts in international security studies; historical evolution of international warfare and diplomacy; contemporary international security issues.

title: IR 376 U.S.-Japan Encounters: War, Trade, and Culture
description: The significance of U.S.-Japan relations is addressed through historical and policy analysis of America, Japan, and the Asia-Pacific region.

title: IR 371 Global Civil Society: Non-State Actors in World Politics
description: Examination of diplomatic and moral relationships between sovereign states and transnational non-state actors, both benevolent (humanitarian groups and philanthropies) and malevolent (mercenaries, pirates and terrorists).

title: IR 369 Post-War European Relations
description: European interstate conflict and cooperation since 1945; history of Western European integration during the Cold War; the European Union in post-Cold War Europe.

title: IR 368 French Foreign Policy: 1945 to the Present
description: Introduction to historical, thematic perspectives of French foreign policy since 1945 including review of external and internal constraints influencing foreign policy. (Paris semester only).

title: IR 370 Global Governance and Health:  From Global to Local
description: Addressing global health challenges at multiple governance levels ranging from global to national to local.

title: IR 367 Africa in International Affairs
description: General overview of main historical, political, and economic issues as they affect Africa, focusing on nationalism, development, and superpower competition in Africa.

title: IR 366 Mexico and its Relations with the United States
description: Analysis of Mexico and U.S.-Mexico relations, both historically and in the present day, to understand better the challenges in this key bilateral relationship.

title: IR 365 Politics and Democracy in Latin America
description: Examines Latin America's experience with democracy emphasizing events since the 1980s. Analyzes the roles of interest groups, ideology, domestic politics, bureaucratic processes, perceptions and analogical reasoning.

title: IR 364 The Political Economy of Latin American Development
description: The main economic development themes and strategies in Latin America over the past century. The interplay between domestic and international variables, and the resulting dynamic changes.

title: IR 361 South and Southeast Asia in International Affairs
description: The historical, cultural, and political reasons for Asia's dramatic transformation into a powerful engine of world economic growth. The secondary consequences of economic growth for environmental protection, gender relations, ethnicity, and military tension.

title: IR 360 International Relations of the Pacific Rim
description: Political, economic and security relations among the countries in East Asia and the Pacific with the emphasis on the role of the United States, China and Japan.

title: IR 358 The Asia Pacific in World Affairs
description: The cultural, political, economic, and social aspects of the Asia Pacific's rise to prominence in world affairs. Reasons for the "successes" of many Asian economies and the environmental and social problems accompanying their rapid transformation. The difficulties of interaction in complex cultural situations illustrated by participation in a computer-assisted simulation.

title: IR 351 Insurgency and Counterinsurgency
description: Theories of insurgency and counterinsurgency emphasizing works of notable guerrilla writers and the Western experience of putting theory into practice.

title: IR 349 International Law and Politics
description: Exploration of international law and international politics, including sovereignty, war, international tribunals, the environment, and human rights.

title: IR 346 Communism and Post-Communism: Eastern Europe and the Balkans
description: Analysis of communism and post-communism in East-Central Europe, including economic transitions, nationalism, inter-and intra-state conflict, NATO and EU enlargement.

title: IR 345 Russian and Post-Soviet Foreign Policy
description: Overview of Tsarist and Soviet experience as background to detailed examination of the political, economic and ideological forces behind contemporary Russian foreign policy.

title: IR 344 Developing Countries in World Politics
description: Origin, concepts, realities, and ideals of the nonaligned movement, focusing on the United States' role in the developing world.

title: IR 343 U.S. Foreign Policy since World War II
description: Analysis of U.S. foreign policy since 1945 as a basis for understanding significant new trends. Explanation of contemporary issues in U.S. relations with other nations.

title: IR 342 The Politics and Strategy of Weapons of Mass Destruction
description: Causes and effects of use and spread of nuclear, biological and chemical weapons; responses to WMD, including deterrence, preventive war, and non-proliferation policies and negotiations.

title: IR 341 Foreign Policy Analysis
description: Basic concepts and analytical approaches in the study of decision-making at the international level. This is a case-based class, requiring participation of students in interactive discussions of decision forcing and retrospective foreign policy cases.

title: IR 340 The Political Economy of China
description: Sources, consequences, challenges to China's economic growth, including rural and urban economies, entrepreneurship, central and local governments, inequality, trade, investment, finance, demographics, and the environment.

title: IR 339 Public Health and International Relations
description: Examination of threats to global security, state sovereignty and population health posed by infectious diseases, natural disasters, war and civil conflict.

title: IR 337 The Impact of Remittances on Development in Mexico
description: Examines the nature of remittances and their effects. Can remittances promote development? Explores policy making focused on improving the quality of remittance expenditures in Mexico.

title: IR 333 China in International Affairs
description: Economic reform, the open door, and China's changing role in the international system. Relations with the United States, Japan, and other key powers in Asia. Tensions between the interests of American business and the human rights community over China policy.

title: IR 331 The Global Economy 2030
description: Examination of key ideas from economics, demography and technology. Guest lecturers illuminate possible conditions of the global economy in 2030.

title: IR 330 Politics of the World Economy
description: Exploration of questions and concepts in international economics and politics, especially as they relate to flows of trade, capital, people, and problems across borders.

title: IR 329 The Global Finance and Monetary Regime
description: The international financial and monetary regime, its evolution and the problems facing it today.

title: IR 328 The Evolving Global Economic Architecture-Capital Mobility
description: Exploration of the evolving global economic architecture of the past seventy years; overview of the possible future contours of economic and political globalization. Recommended preparation: Macro- and Micro-economics.

title: IR 326 U.S. Foreign Economic Policy
description: The U.S. economy and political-economic institutions in comparative perspective; economic diplomacy and policy; role of trade barriers, exchange rates, foreign aid, energy, foreign investment.

title: IR 327 International Negotiation
description: Practicum in negotiation skills. Diagnosis of situations and identification of strategies through case studies and personal exercises.

title: IR 324 Multinational Enterprises and World Politics
description: Political implications of interactions between different types of multinational enterprises and all levels of U.S. government, other industrial nations, and less-developed countries.

title: IR 325 North-South Relations in the Global Economy
description: Analysis of inequality in relations between developed and developing states; contending views on the causes and legacies of imperialism; development strategies and aid.

title: IR 323 Politics of Global Environment
description: Examines the politics of managing the global environment. The nature of ecosystems, common problems, population and resource utilization problems along with biodiversity and global governance are emphasized.

title: IR 319 Human Security and Humanitarian Intervention
description: Explore causes of human security threats, challenges to state sovereignty, and actions to address failed states, conflicts and protect people through humanitarian intervention.

title: IR 318 Violent Conflict
description: Origins and evolution of violent conflict among humans; modern efforts to end conflict; recent research in archaeology, anthropology, biology, economics, political science and psychology.

title: IR 320 Technology and International Relations
description:
Impact of technological advances to global security and development. Focus on surveillance and cyber conflict; nuclear weaponry, aviation and UAVs 
missiles and BMD; submarines and ASW.

title: IR 317 The Political Economy of Africa
description: Africa remains the world's poorest region. Why? Since when? Will it remain so? This course discusses tentative answers drawn from a number of disciplines.

title: IR 313 Religions and Political Violence
description: An introduction to debates about the intersection of religion and conflict in politics and international affairs; theoretical, classical, and contemporary issues.

title: IR 311 Research Design and Methods
description: Exploration of critical scholarship on research design, including case selection, hypothesis testing, and field research techniques.

title: IR 312 Introduction to Data Analysis
description: Introduction to statistical analysis with R, with applications to the study of International Relations: data manipulation, hypothesis testing, regression, causality, text analysis, visualization, and network analysis.

title: IR 309 Global Governance
description: Introduction to global governance structure and institutions. Exploration of the appropriate role for states, international organizations, civil society and individuals within the global governance structure.

title: IR 308w Economic Globalization
description: Globalization makes national borders and regulations increasingly obsolete. Analyzes the economic foundation of globalization, its consequences and efforts to manage it.

title: IR 307 Contemporary International Politics
description: Analysis of recent events, forces, and conditions in the international political system.

title: IR 315 Ethnicity and Nationalism in World Politics
description: Ethnic identity and nation formation in the global society of states; nation-states; conflict or political accommodation within multinational states; impact of dispersed nations on interstate relations.

title: IR 306 International Organizations
description: The emergence of international organizations as a permanent feature in world politics; role of the United Nations organization as well as regional international organizations.

title: IR 304 National Intelligence and the Shaping of Policy
description: The focus is intelligence to improve the making of policy, with attention to collection; overt and covert, operations; domestic intelligence; and oversight in democracies.

title: IR 305w Managing New Global Problems
description: Examines strategies for managing global issues in the post Cold War period. Explores ways that international institutions, national governments and non-state actors work separately and together to provide order and control over complex international issues areas. Issues that will receive attention could include financial and monetary relations, trade and foreign investment, preservation of the environment, the spread of weapons of mass destruction, population and migration, terrorism and ethnic strife.

title: IR 303 Leadership and Diplomacy
description: The role of leaders, diplomatic leadership and creativity in statecraft, providing a deep understanding of the theoretical and practical dimensions of diplomacy.

title: IR 302 International Relations of the Great Powers in the Late 19th and 20th Centuries
description: Introductory analysis of the interactions of the great powers during the period; initial focus on Europe, with expansion to include global relations.

title: IR 213 The Global Economy
description: Economic and political concepts necessary to the understanding of the modern global economy. Topics include international trade, foreign investment and migration.

title: IR 212 Historical Approaches to International Relations
description: Introduction to historical research methods, with an emphasis on historical texts and modes of discourse.

title: IR 211g International Relations: Approaches to Research
description: Introduction to theoretically oriented research approaches and designs; emphasis on the logic of argumentation.

title: IR 210gw International Relations: Introductory Analysis
description: Comprehensive introduction to contending theoretical and analytical approaches; development of critical, evaluative, cognitive, and analytical competencies regarding historical and contemporary issues.

title: IR 100gx The United States and World Affairs
description: The changing character of contemporary international political issues from the Cold War to the future and U.S. foreign policy options for the future; exploration of competing perspectives.

title: IR 101gxw International Relations
description: Basic concepts of world affairs for non-majors. Development of competency to understand and critically evaluate global relations and international events, stressing empirical approaches.

title: INTX 690f Directed Dental Research
description: Dental clinical and/or basic science research under faculty guidance; proposal developed, research conducted, conclusion drawn, paper written. Units determined by extent of research.

title: INTX 690e Directed Dental Research
description: Dental clinical and/or basic science research under faculty guidance; proposal developed, research conducted, conclusion drawn, paper written. Units determined by extent of research.

title: INTX 690d Directed Dental Research
description: Dental clinical and/or basic science research under faculty guidance; proposal developed, research conducted, conclusion drawn, paper written. Units determined by extent of research.

title: JS 180gp Judaism
description: Jewish beliefs, practices, and history from the biblical period to the present; Judaic contributions to Western civilization.

title: JS 211gw The Holocaust
description: Historical background and responses to the Holocaust, with special emphasis on ethical implications.

title: JS 100gp Jewish History
description: Major ideas, personalities, and movements in Jewish history from antiquity to the present in light of the interaction of the Jews with the general culture.

title: JOUR 599 Special Topics
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: JOUR 596 Follow the Money: Business and Economics
description: Reporting and writing on business, economics and public finance; students produce a series of professional projects for publication.

title: JOUR 598 Journalism Capstone Project
description: Production of a journalism capstone project with multimedia elements for a master's degree. Projects can be single stand-alone pieces, or series of pieces.

title: JOUR 594z Master's Thesis
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: JOUR 594b Master's Thesis
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: JOUR 594a Master's Thesis
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: JOUR 595 Critical Thinking: The Art and Science of Not Getting Fooled
description: Researching and writing about how not to get fooled as a journalist; includes research, writing and discussion. Open only to journalism and specialized journalism majors.

title: JOUR 592 Arts Journalism: Storytelling and Production
description: Reporting and writing on the arts; strategies for arts journalism in the digital era; survey of essays and reviews by great critics.

title: JOUR 593 Arts Criticism and Commentary
description: Writing workshops and independent fieldwork; development of critical skills to write socially valuable criticism and commentary about art, entertainment and culture.

title: JOUR 591 Arts Writing Practicum
description: Intensive writing workshop on the craft of arts criticism and persuasive writing of different arts genres.

title: JOUR 590 Directed Research
description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

title: JOUR 588 Cities, Climate and Risk
description: Reporting and writing on urbanization, climate change and environmental harm.

title: JOUR 589 Specialized Reporting: The Changing U.S. Population
description: Reporting and writing on immigration and other forms of demographic change; survey of immigration, the journalism it has generated and the impact of coverage.

title: JOUR 586 Specialized Reporting: Science
description: Reporting and writing on science; survey of scientific research fields and evaluation of evidence and claims.

title: JOUR 585 Specialized Reporting: Religion
description: Reporting and writing on religion; survey of world religion, religion and public life — including politics, gender and science.

title: JOUR 584 Specialized Reporting: Education, Youth and Learning
description: Reporting and writing on education; survey of historical and contemporary issues affecting children, families and public education.

title: JOUR 582 Specialized Journalism: Reporting Decisions
description: Reporting and analysis of decision making; case studies and analytical tools in dissecting decisions for readers, listeners and viewers.

title: JOUR 581 Specialized Journalism: Research Methods
description: Advanced skills in the use of expert sources, scholarly resources, computer-assisted and investigative reporting in specialized journalism; social and ethical issues in specialized reporting.

title: JOUR 579 Journalism Internship
description: Field experience in journalism, public relations, or related field.

title: JOUR 578 Reporting on Globalization
description: Understanding globalization, its origins, history and major characteristics. Developing skills in reporting, describing, analyzing, and responding to globalization.

title: JOUR 576 The Image of the Journalist in Popular Culture Seminar
description: Study and analysis of the conflicting images of the journalist in popular culture and its impact on the public's perception of the media and news gatherers.

title: JOUR 577 Monetization and the New Media
description: Understanding new media through an economic lens. Applying knowledge by creating, reporting and delivering a communications or business strategy model.

title: JOUR 575 Converged Media Center
description: Advanced multimedia news production; preparation and treatment of form and content; procedures, problems, ethics, and practice in operating a daily, 24-7 news outlet.

title: JOUR 574 Sports and Society
description: Develop and refine print and multimedia skills to work as a sports journalist. Gain perspective, context and background in how sports intersect with society.

title: JOUR 572 Reporting on Entertainment and Popular Culture
description: Reporting about entertainment, popular culture and their impact on American society; survey of past media coverage and current practices.

title: JOUR 570 Journalism Ethics Goes to the Movies Seminar
description: Understand ethical issues facing journalists as dramatized in the movies.  Develop an ethical structure to use as journalists and consumers of news in the complex world of social media and the Internet.

title: JOUR 571 21st Century Sports Storytelling
description: Seminar in how to report and write sports: news, previews, profiles, features, columns.

title: JOUR 561 Fundamentals of Data Journalism Reporting
description: Execute data-driven projects and add context to news stories with advanced quantitative analysis tools and techniques.

title: JOUR 560 Seminar in Mass Communication Law
description: Analysis of major elements of mass communication law, legal issues in contemporary mass communication, and the impact of legal trends on professional journalists.

title: JOUR 433 Writing About Science
description: Techniques of writing about science, including news, profiles, features and commentary.

title: JOUR 435 Writing Magazine Non-Fiction
description: A seminar in "how to" interview, research, write -- and place -- professional quality articles for a full range of magazines/newspapers including women's, sports, ethnic, local and national.

title: JOUR 432 Sports Commentary
description: Techniques of reporting and writing sports columns and commentary for print, video, radio and Web-based media.

title: JOUR 430 Writing the Film Review
description: Techniques of writing the film review; preparation and treatment of form and content; problems, responsibilities and ethics of film reviewing.

title: JOUR 431 Feature Writing
description: Techniques of writing newspaper feature stories, including the profile, the light feature, the news feature, the in-depth story; the art of narrative writing.

title: JOUR 422 Visual Journalism for Non-Majors
description: Emphasis on photographic storytelling in print, video and Web-based media; understanding of visual thinking and imagery techniques.

title: JOUR 425 Advanced Radio News Production
description: Production of public radio news: producing real-time newscasts for Annenberg Radio News. Newsgathering, assigning stories, anchoring, interviewing, working with reporters, editing and producing live programming.

title: JOUR 420 Advanced Photojournalism
description: Emphasis on advanced photojournalism techniques for complex photo storytelling; focus on style, content, design, expression and ethics.

title: JOUR 556 Online Journalism Seminar
description: Writing and reporting for the Internet and other technology platforms; computer-assisted reporting; multimedia storytelling.

title: JOUR 553 Coding and Programming for Storytelling
description: Sketch, design and code a website from scratch, using HTML, CSS and jQuery plug-ins to tell a rich multimedia story. Open only to journalism majors.

title: JOUR 555 Advanced Coding for Creative Storytelling
