description: Focuses on advanced coding techniques for the creation of dynamic, interactive, multimedia and data-driven news stories on the web.

title: JOUR 552 Television Reporting and Production
description: Writing, reporting and producing content for video and digital platforms; similarities and differences between media; application of audio-visual and digital equipment.

title: JOUR 546 News, Numbers and Introduction to Data Journalism
description: An overview of the basic quantitative analysis tools and techniques essential to give perspective to a journalistic story or to put it in context.

title: JOUR 547 Navigating the Media Marketplace
description: Explores the economics of the news industry and prepares students to navigate the journalism job market through practical exercises, practice interviews and cover letter-writing.

title: JOUR 414 Advanced Digital Media Storytelling
description: Production of a well-reported advanced multimedia package, with a blend of text, audio, video, photos, navigation and interactivity; final projects will be published by the Annenberg Media Center.

title: JOUR 545 International Internships in the Media
description: Intensive field experience at international news media and public relations organizations.

title: JOUR 542 Foreign Reporting
description: News stories analyzed, researched, and critiqued for validity and background; projects to include editorials, news stories, magazine articles or broadcast reports.

title: JOUR 533 Web Journalism and Editorial Site Management
description: Report, edit, and manage a major news Website while operating its content management system; understand best standards and practices in online site management.

title: JOUR 539 Introduction to Investigative Reporting
description: Focus on basic investigative reporting; understand its history, how to access records, identify sources, use computer assisted reporting, report in a fair and ethical manner.

title: JOUR 528 Summer Digital Journalism Immersion
description: A journalism immersion experience that orients and familiarizes students with the best practices and standards of cutting-edge multimedia, multi-platform fact gathering, reporting and storytelling. Open only to Journalism majors.

title: JOUR 531L Fall Digital Journalism Immersion
description: Students write, report, produce, code, promote (through social media), and publish/air cross-platform stories in a converged news environment. Open only to Journalism majors.

title: JOUR 526 Advanced Broadcast News Production
description: Production of television news programs; preparation and treatment of form and content; procedures, problems and practice in planning and producing broadcast news materials.

title: JOUR 525 Public Radio Documentary
description: Advanced production techniques for public radio-style reports: writing, sound, editing, narrative voice. Techniques applicable for broadcast features or Web audio documentaries.

title: JOUR 523 Public Radio Reporting
description: Reporting for public radio-style news: writing, newsgathering, editing, vocal delivery. Techniques applicable for broadcast or Web audio stories. Open only to journalism majors.

title: JOUR 524 Advanced Broadcast Reporting
description: Reporting and writing broadcast news; analysis and practical experience; role of the broadcast journalism reporter; similarities and differences between media; application of audio-visual equipment.

title: JOUR 522 Video Documentary Production
description: Production of video documentary including research and reporting techniques, writing, interviewing, field work, editing, legal issues, economics, aesthetics, balanced presentation, ethics, diversity and production problems.

title: JOUR 520 Advanced Broadcast Newswriting
description: Writing for broadcast, preparation and presentation. Responsibility and ethics of broadcast newswriting. Form and content of broadcast news presentation. Similarities and differences between media.

title: JOUR 521 Documentary Pre-Production
description: Pre-production of video documentary including selection of topic, diversity, ethical and legal problems, research and reporting techniques, interviewing, writing, balanced presentation, visual and audio literacy.

title: JOUR 519 Advanced Writing and Reporting for Magazine and the Web
description: Focus on reporting and writing for magazine and the web, learning fundamental production skills, and pitching stories in the freelance market

title: JOUR 517 Advanced Investigative Reporting
description: Advanced reportorial and analytical skills and techniques required for evaluating newsworthy events. Group research and publication of stories on important current topics.

title: LAW 567 Introduction to Litigation in U.S. Courts
description: Provides an overview of the United States legal system for those unfamiliar with common law courts, including the mechanics of the U.S. Court system in both criminal and civil courts, as well as more detailed analysis of torts and intellectual property disputes.

title: LAW 566 Academic and Professional Skills for U.S. Law Studies II
description: Registration Restriction: Open only to master students enrolled in Certificate in U.S. Legal Studies program at USC Gould School of Law.

title: LAW 565 U.S. Common Law Analysis and Skills
description: Registration Restriction: Open only to master students enrolled in Certificate in U.S. Legal Studies program at USC Gould School of Law.

title: LAW 564 Persuasive Advocacy
description: Registration Restriction: Open only to master students enrolled in Certificate in U.S. Legal Studies program at USC Gould School of Law.

title: LAW 563 Presentation Skills for International Lawyers
description: Registration Restriction: Open only to master students enrolled in Certificate in U.S. Legal Studies program at USC Gould School of Law.

title: LAW 562 Introduction to U.S. Legal Culture and Practice
description: Registration Restriction: Open only to master students enrolled in Certificate in U.S. Legal Studies program at USC Gould School of Law.

title: LAW 561a Fundamentals of Legal Writing Skills
description: Registration Restriction: Open only to master students enrolled in the Certificate in U.S. Legal Studies program at USC Gould School of Law

title: LAW 560 Academic and Professional Skills for U.S. Law Studies I
description: Registration Restriction: Open only to master students enrolled in Certificate in U.S. Legal Studies program at USC Gould School of Law.

title: JOUR 411 Broadcast and Digital Writing for Video and Audio for Non-Majors
description: Develop a broad-based knowledge of broadcast news writing and reporting; recognize, research and develop stories; write and format broadcast stories in all forms and learn to produce finished news packages.

title: LAW 561b Fundamentals of Legal Writing Skills
description: Registration Restriction: Open only to master students enrolled in the Certificate in U.S. Legal Studies program at USC Gould School of Law

title: JOUR 410 Radio Documentary
description: In-depth reporting for public radio news: writing, editing, advanced vocal delivery. Production of long-form radio features and short documentaries.

title: JOUR 409 Radio Storytelling and Podcasts
description: Techniques for audio journalism, including effective use of sound, art of the interview, writing for the ear and crafting stories to engage listeners.

title: JOUR 408 Advanced Media Law in the Digital Age
description: Advanced examination of the rights of journalists in the American legal system; understanding the First Amendment and seminal case law to provide a framework for the practice of journalism; recognizing ethical dilemmas confronting members of the media

title: JOUR 404 Produce and Host Sports Content in Studio A
description: Interview, present and design sports segments for television/video in Studio A.

title: JOUR 406 Social Media Storytelling for Latino Audiences
description: Create native journalistic content for current social media and emerging platforms with an emphasis on engaging content for Latino audiences and underrepresented communities.

title: JOUR 405 Non-Fiction Television
description: Presentation and selection in non-fiction television programs including documentaries, electronic magazines and news series; ethical problems, field research, reporting, interviewing, pre-production.

title: JOUR 401 Multiplatform Editing for Digital Audiences
description: Breaking news and real-time editing for digital audiences across platforms, including homepage, social media and mobile. Introduction to analytics for website and social media.

title: JOUR 402 Advanced Television Reporting
description: Role of the broadcast journalism reporter; similarities and differences between print and electronic media; application of audio-video equipment; analysis and practical experience.

title: JOUR 403 Television News Production
description: Production of live television and live-streamed news programs; preparation of form and content; procedures and practice in planning and producing broadcast and digital news materials.

title: JOUR 400 Interpretive Writing
description: Weekly assignments in the shorter forms of newspaper and magazine writing: essays, reviews, editorials, opinion-page articles, profiles; analyses of major 20th century journalists.

title: JOUR 390 Special Problems
description: Supervised, individual studies. No more than one registration permitted. Enrollment by petition only.

title: JOUR 381 Entertainment, Business and Media in Today's Society
description: An examination of the symbiotic relationship of the entertainment business and the media; press coverage of the entertainment industry; Hollywood's relationship with news media.

title: JOUR 373 Journalism Ethics Goes to the Movies
description: Ethical issues facing journalists in the complex world of legacy media, social media and the Internet as dramatized in the movies and in the newsroom.

title: JOUR 372 Engaging Diverse Communities
description: Explores how to engage diverse local communities through participatory journalism and communication strategies. Focuses on using digital tools to increase engagement with communities via field reporting and mobile platforms to produce stories across platforms.

title: JOUR 350 Introduction to Sports Media
description: Highlight norms, routines of content, including print, broadcast, video. Focus on opportunities, constraints posed by roles of reporters, fans, players, publicists, agents, leagues, teams.

title: JOUR 330 Photojournalism
description: Emphasis on fundamental skills necessary for photojournalism including camera techniques, story ideas and digital darkroom.

title: JOUR 322 Data Journalism
description: Overview of the basic data journalism techniques and tools for statistical analysis; understanding of numbers and basic statistics as they relate to journalism. Proficiency with gathering, analyzing and visualizing data.

title: JOUR 323 Creating your Digital Footprint and Brand
description: Build a personal website that features a culmination of your previous undergraduate journalism work; craft a professional digital profile using various social media platforms; understand the economics of the news business; prepare to enter the industry.

title: JOUR 321 Visual Journalism
description: Video for digital platforms, principles of photography, design for web and mobile platforms. Introduction to principles of digital news design, interactivity and presentation in interactive storytelling.

title: JOUR 513 Advanced Newswriting and Reporting
description: Reportorial and analytical skills and techniques required in searching out and evaluating newsworthy events. Research and publication of stories.

title: JOUR 510 Special Assignment Reporting
description: Beat reporting with a deep dive into research, source development, and writing/reporting skills. Focus on current trends, history, major actors and key issues.

title: JOUR 512 Advanced Interpretive Writing
description: Analysis and writing of editorials, essays, Op-Ed page articles, profiles, and other shorter forms of journalism, combined with study of historic practitioners of those forms.

title: JOUR 505 The Practice: Journalism's Evolution as a Profession
description: Analyzes the history, ethics and evolution of journalism; Students will be introduced to key innovations and innovators in journalism history as well as multimedia platforms.

title: JOUR 320 Introduction to Coding for Storytelling
description: Introduction to basic web technologies; conceive, design, code and produce an advanced multimedia story package.

title: JOUR 499 Special Topics
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: JOUR 498 Honors Seminar
description: Intensive study of a subject of contemporary relevance or of professional importance to journalists and public relations practitioners.

title: JOUR 497 Data Visualization and Interactive Tools
description: Present your data in tables, charts, graphs, maps, and complex multimedia pieces using readily available interactive tools.

title: JOUR 496 Interactive Media Design for Publishing
description: Design, test and distribute engaging news and publishing apps. Learn concepts of interactive design, color, type, UX, and more for digital mobile/tablet platforms.

title: JOUR 494 Python Coding for Data Journalism
description: Python coding language to gather, parse and analyze data for investigative news reporting.

title: JOUR 493 Comics and Graphic Storytelling
description: Focus on comics as a medium to tell a broad range of stories and speak to diverse kinds of audiences. Develop a core vocabulary for thinking about comics as a medium and analyze how artists have drawn on that vocabulary in a range of contexts.

title: JOUR 495 Journalism for Mobile and Emerging Platforms
description: Create video, audio and graphic news and information using mobile and emerging technology, such as phones, tablets and laptops, for non-broadcast platforms; understand ethical and legal issues related to journalists working on mobile and emerging platforms.

title: JOUR 490x Directed Research
description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

title: JOUR 492 Advanced Coding for Storytelling
description: Focuses on advanced coding techniques for the creation of dynamic, interactive, multimedia and data-driven news stories on the web.

title: JOUR 489 Hands-on Disruption: Experimenting with Emerging Technology
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: JOUR 483 Negotiating and Reporting Global Change
description: In-depth multimedia reporting on social, economic and political processes of global impact; combining intense fieldwork and specialized background knowledge.

title: JOUR 480 Sports and Media Technology
description: Examine and analyze the ever-changing technology sector of the sports business and sports media world.  Identify emerging technologies being developed in the sports industry and how they are being utilized to enhance the fan experience.

title: LAW 559 Human Resource Compliance
description: Provides an overview of human resource related law, and various legal issues involved in the employment relationship.

title: JOUR 481 The Athlete, Sports Media and Popular Culture
description: Analysis of the images of the athlete and sports media helps us understand how sports dramatically affects such social issues as race, class and gender.

title: LAW 551 Intellectual Property: Trademark
description: Provides an introduction to trademark law, the federal trademark registration process, and the application of trademark laws in litigation.

title: LAW 550 Business Law Digest
description: Write or edit articles for the Business Law Digest, a student-run publication that publishes advisory articles relevant to the intersection of business and law.

title: LAW 532 Constitutional Law: Rights
description: Examines constitutional rights particularly ones protected under the Equal Protection/Due Process Clauses and related questions of judicial role and theories of interpretation.

title: LAW 531 Ethical Issues for Public Interest, Government and Criminal Lawyers
description: Covers legal ethics issues with an emphasis on access to justice, nonprofit practice settings, and duties of prosecutors and defense attorneys. Fulfills Legal Profession requirement.

title: LAW 530 Fundamental Business Principles
description: Exposes students to everyday business and finance vocabulary, concepts and modes of analysis. Strongly recommended for students without significant prior business experience.

title: LAW 528 Constitutional Law
description: Covers the delineation of spheres of responsibility between three branches of the federal government, the federal government and the states and the government and individuals.

title: LAW 527 Intellectual Property: Copyright
description: Provides an introduction to copyright law, the application of copyright laws in litigation, and the management of copyrighted works.

title: LAW 522 Entertainment Law and Industry
description: Provides a detailed survey of entertainment law, entertainment-related transactions and litigation, and legal issues facing the entertainment industry.

title: LAW 520 Introduction to U.S. Legal System
description: The basic structure of government in the U.S., including the constitutionally mandated division of power in the federal government and the federal system of power sharing between state and federal systems. A comparative perspective on selected substantive and procedural matters, such as common law reasoning, jury trials, adversary process, and various aspects of civil procedure. Open to LLM students only.

title: LAW 521 Topics in American Law
description: This course provides LLM and MCL students with a survey of various topics in American law, including criminal law, evidence, family law, constitutional law, torts, wills and trusts, administrative law and property law. Open to LLM and MCL students only.

title: LAW 515 Legal Research, Writing and Advocacy I
description: Development of legal research, writing and advocacy skills. Emphasis on objective legal writing, including memoranda, and researching case law through primary and secondary sources.

title: LAW 511a Legal Writing
description: Two-semester course focusing on developing analytic and communication skills. Lawyers will analyze legal principles and incisively apply them to facts.

title: LAW 511b Legal Writing
description: Two-semester course focusing on developing analytic and communication skills. Lawyers will analyze legal principles and incisively apply them to facts.

title: LAW 516 Legal Research, Writing and Advocacy II
description: . Development of legal research, writing, and advocacy skills. Emphasis on persuasive legal writing, including appellate briefs, and researching statutory and administrative law. Participation in a moot court program.

title: LAW 512 Law, Language and Values
description: An introduction to legal interpretation and normative reasoning. Among the topics addressed are statutory and common law interpretation, the rule of law, externalities, and inequality.

title: LAW 510 Legal Research
description: Examination of the basic sources of law for federal and California jurisdictions, utilizing a vast array of sources from books to computer-assisted research and analyzing research methodology and techniques.

title: LAW 509 Torts I
description: Individual's obligation not to harm others; bases for compensating persons who are harmed, either by holding responsible whoever is at fault or by invoking other principles of liability, including the efficiency of resource allocation and the spreading of losses.

title: LAW 507 Property
description: The idea of property as understood through economic and philosophical concepts. Rights in land, water and other natural resources. Forms of shared ownership (e.g., landlord and tenant), and a survey of mechanisms for controlling land use.

title: LAW 505 Legal Profession
description: Functions of the lawyer in modern society; history and organization of the legal profession; the adversary system; equal access to justice; other problems of ethics and professional responsibility.

title: LAW 508 Constitutional Law: Structure
description: Considers the delineation of spheres of responsibility between the judiciary and legislature, the nation and the state, and the government and the individual.

title: LAW 504 Criminal Law
description: The crime problem and the legislative response to it through substantive criminal law; administration of criminal justice through police, prosecutorial, sentencing, and penological discretion.

title: JOUR 311 Multi-Platform Editing
description: Copyediting, headline writing, Search Engine Optimization and other production skills for preparation of content across platforms. Social responsibility and ethical framework also components of this course.

title: JOUR 310 Investigative Reporting
description: Reportorial and analytical skills and techniques required for portraying and evaluating contemporary newsworthy events; lectures, discussions.

title: JOUR 210x Basics of News Production for Non-Majors
description: Introduction to television, radio, and/or digital news production. Examination of issues in journalism.

title: JOUR 208 Media Law and Ethics
description: Introduction to the basics of the U.S. legal system and contemporary case law and ethics; impact of the Web on the practice of journalism; understanding essential legal frameworks and the rights and responsibilities of journalists.

title: JOUR 207 Reporting and Writing I
description: Provides students with foundational skills to report, write and produce journalism content across multiple platforms, including broadcast, digital and text.

title: JOUR 307 Reporting and Writing II
description: Report, write, produce and distribute in-depth stories produced off beats on multiple platforms for diverse audiences; enhance understanding of news judgment; develop and maintain sources; engage communities through field reporting and emerging digital tools.

title: JOUR 205 Journalism Practicum
description: Field experience in journalism, public relations, or related field.

title: JOUR 201 Culture of Journalism: Past, Present and Future
description: Understanding key moments, debates and ideas that have shaped journalism in the United States from the Revolutionary War period through today. Examination of the social, cultural, political and technological aspects of journalism and its impact on the profession and public service.

title: JOUR 190 Introduction to Journalism
description: Survey of all media and outlets including print, broadcasting, public relations and online journalism, plus analysis of what it means to be a professional journalist.

title: JOUR 200w The Power and Responsibility of the Press
description: Explores the role of journalism and social media in society - its influence on government, technology, business, national security, sports, science and entertainment.

title: ITP 491 Level Design and Development for Video Games
description: Theories and practices of defining, prototyping, testing, and refining a video game level, development of game level documents, and the tools for managing the development process.

title: ITP 489 In-Memory Database Systems for Real Time Analytics
description: Examines the design, architecture, and capabilities of in-memory databases and their application to real-time analytics.

title: ITP 496 The Startup Launchpad Lab
description: A real world, hands-on learning experience on what it's like to actually start a high-tech company. Students will work in teams to design, prototype and implement version 1.0 of a high tech web or mobile startup.

title: ITP 488 Managing Supply Chains with Advanced Planning & Optimization
description: Drivers and obstacles to the process of coordinating the flow of material/information along the logistics chain. Optimize the supply network, from raw materials to sales. Not available for major credit in engineering except toward undergraduate and graduate programs offered by the Epstein Department of Industrial and Systems Engineering.

title: ITP 487 Data Warehouses
description: Role of data warehouses in analytics. Modeling and building data warehouses. Extraction, transformation and loading data into cubes.

title: ITP 486 Securing and Auditing Enterprise Resource Planning Systems
description: Management and technical issues related to the security of ERP systems. Students will audit ERP systems and apply appropriate security controls.

title: ITP 484 Multiplayer Game Programming
description: Techniques for developing networked multiplayer games. Topics include Internet protocols, network topology, data streams, object sharing, client prediction, latency, and back-end databases.

title: ITP 485 Programming Game Engines
description: Techniques for building the core components of a game engine; 2-D/3-D graphics, collision detection, artificial intelligence algorithms, shading, programming input devices.

title: ITP 479 Cyber Law and Privacy
description: Cyber legal issues, search and seizure, 4th amendment and digital evidence, private searches, case law relating to search and seizure.

title: ITP 477 Software Based Engineering Design of Roadways
description: Orient students to the InRoads software and familiarize them with its capabilities to support engineering design of roadways.

title: JOUR 477 Web Analytics for News and Nonprofit Organizations
description: Introduction to using Web traffic and other audience behavior data to manage Websites and social media for news and nonprofit organizations.

title: JOUR 476 Reporting Urban Affairs
description: Examination of U.S. urban issues with an eye toward history for context; study of emerging 21st century solutions for urban communities.

title: JOUR 474 Interviewing and Profile Writing
description: Techniques of, and intensive application in researching and writing interviews and profiles for newspapers and magazines.

title: JOUR 475 Print and Digital Design for 21st Century Storytelling
description: Art, typography, and other graphic elements in publication design; traditional, contemporary, and advanced production methods, processes, and equipment; representative examples; practice in design.

title: JOUR 470 Community Journalism
description: Survey of how local journalism functions in a community. Students work as editors/mentors to high school students, writing for school newspaper and other media.

title: ITP 482 Engineering Database Applications
description: Planning and implementation of engineering information systems that interface with a large database. Emphasis is placed on web-based data entry and retrieval.

title: JOUR 469 Money, Markets and Media
description: Practical approach to understanding and writing about economic concepts through current events, case studies and historical examples.

title: JOUR 472 Strategies for Monetizing New Media
description: Learn strategies for how content creates value in a shifting media landscape. Work with a real client to create a sustainable media business model.

title: JOUR 468m The American Press and Issues of Sexual Diversity
description: Examines how news media reflect and affect perception of gay/lesbian issues; provides historical-contemporary context; arms students to bypass rhetoric and knowledgeably evaluate facts.

title: JOUR 466m People of Color and the News Media
description: Reporting and portrayal of people of color in the United States; impact of racial diversity on media, employment and access, and development of media for individuals and communities of color. Open to non-majors.

title: JOUR 462 Law of Mass Communication
description: Press law; government controls on the news media; legal responsibilities of the journalist.

title: JOUR 465m Latino News Media in the United States
description: History and growing importance of Latino print and broadcast news media in covering immigration, discrimination, culture, social differences and other aspects of U.S. Latino life.

title: JOUR 460 Social Responsibility of the News Media
description: News media as instruments of constructive social change; standards of ethics and aesthetics; interactions between news media and cultural settings; social responsibility of news media personnel.

title: JOUR 449 Reporting Los Angeles
description: Specialized reporting class focused on Los Angeles that requires intensive fieldwork in the neighborhoods, ethnic communities, and/or among local institutions.

title: JOUR 458 Media, Food and Culture
description: Analyzes the ways media tell the story of our food and examines the critical issues surrounding what we eat.

title: JOUR 459 Fact and Fiction: From Journalism to the Docudrama
description: Historical, legal and ethical limitations to the misrepresentation of fact. Includes print and broadcast journalism, books, theatre, cinema and new technology.

title: JOUR 448 Government and Public Affairs Reporting
description: Techniques for covering beats that are the foundation of daily newspaper reporting, including crime, education, immigration and local government.

title: JOUR 447 Arts Reporting
description: Techniques of reporting and writing about the arts, including television, film, theatre, music, graphic arts, architecture and design.

title: JOUR 446 Entertainment Reporting
description: Techniques of reporting and writing about the entertainment business, economics and finances. Analysis of the skills and background needed for reporters specializing in this area of the news.

title: JOUR 444 Reporting on Religion
description: Provides print, online and broadcast journalists with basic tools for reporting on the religion angle of news stories.

title: JOUR 441 Sports Reporting
description: News and feature coverage of sporting events, including social and economic factors influencing sports in America.

title: JOUR 443 Business Reporting
description: Techniques of reporting and writing about business, economics and finance.

title: JOUR 440 Environmental Journalism
description: Techniques of reporting and writing about the environment. Includes both theory and practice needed for reporters specializing in this area of journalism.

title: LAW 503 Contracts
description: The interpretation and enforcement of promises and agreements.

title: LAW 450 Law, Atrocity Crimes and Transitional Justice
description: Historical overview of the evolution of international legal norms prohibiting atrocity crimes found in the law of armed conflict, international human rights law and the 1948 Genocide Convention.

title: LAW 502 Procedure I
description: Consideration of the participants in litigation — private and public plaintiffs, defendants, and courts. Information exchange, process, outcomes, and costs of lawsuits.

title: LAW 404 Law and Psychology: Examining the Criminal Justice Process
description: Examination of the capacity of the criminal justice process to produce accurate verdicts. Application of psychological research on witnesses, detectives, suspects, judges and jurors.

title: LAW 403 Mental Health Law
description: Issues at the intersection of law and psychology, both civil — e.g., civil commitment — and criminal — e.g., the insanity defense. Emphasis on ethical issues.

title: LAW 350 Law and Entrepreneurship
description: Examines areas of the law that impact entrepreneurs, starting, operating and financing businesses. Topics include: selection of business entities; securities laws and issues that arise in fundraising; employment law; contracts; torts; intellectual property; global expansion; mergers and acquisitions; and IPOs.

title: LAW 402 Psychology and Law
description: Explores issues of responsibility and credibility. Intentional and unintentional behavior. Clinical biases. Topics include witness credibility, confessions, cults, hostages, battered persons, and repressed memories.

title: LAW 320p Law, Slavery, and Race
description: Studies how law, politics and culture interacted to shape the institution of slavery and the development of modern conceptions of race.

title: LAW 275p The Origin and Evolution of American Civil Rights Law
description: Traces the development of U.S. constitutional and statutory mechanisms designed to fulfill the promise of equality under the law.

title: LAW 300 Concepts in American Law
description: The main concepts and topics in American law, in the historical, economic and cultural contexts in which they have developed.

title: LAW 220 The Legal Profession
description: Introduces students to the basic aspects of the legal profession.

title: LAW 250 Children and Law
description: Examines topics such as children's suggestibility, decision-making, and risk and resiliency all as they apply to legal settings.

title: LAW 200w Law and Society
description: Sources and structure of law; history of Bill of Rights emphasizing effect on criminal justice system; limits of law in solving problems in American society.

title: LAW 101w Law and the U.S. Constitution in Global History
description: By examining key constitutional moments involving race, rights, and revolutions, students will explore how legal meaning changes over time.

title: LAT 499 Special Topics
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: LAT 490x Directed Research
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: LAT 390 Special Problems
description: Supervised, individual studies. No more than one registration permitted. Enrollment by petition only.

title: LAT 450 Readings in Latin Literature
description: Readings in various authors and genres of Latin literature.

title: LAT 385 Late and Medieval Latin
description: Selections from poets and prose writers from late antiquity to the 15th century.

title: LAT 365 Latin Literature of the Silver Age
description: Readings in Seneca, Martial, Pliny, and other representative writers.

title: ITP 470 Information Technology Practicum
description: Independent technology project related to specific topics under the direction of a faculty member.

title: ITP 475 Advanced Digital Forensics
description: Advanced forensic techniques. Live image analysis. Network level forensic investigation. Server forensic techniques. Deposition and trial.

title: ITP 468 Connected Devices Project
description: Capstone course for the Minor in Making and Connected Devices. Team-based interacting with real-world clients, designing a hardware system, developing firmware, and manufacturing a product.

title: ITP 466 Building the High Tech Startup
description: Teach students the basic technologies and processes involved in building web and mobile startups. Students will be introduced to the different aspects of building a web startup including online business models, Product management, Agile development processes, technology platforms and operations, customer development and online marketing.

title: ITP 457 Network Security
description: Network policy and mechanism, firewalls, malicious code; intrusion detection, prevention, response; cryptographic protocols for privacy; risks of misuse, cost of prevention, and societal issues.

title: ITP 454x Enterprise Resource Planning, Design, and Implementation
description: Process and requirements to implement an Enterprise Resource Planning System (ERP). Set up server, implement ERP system, then transfer and configure database for case company.

title: ITP 448 Cyber Litigation Support
description: Civil Litigation. Digital and Electronic Evidence. Electronic Discovery. eDiscovery. Electronically Stored Information.

title: ITP 450 Advanced 3D Texturing, Compositing, and Image Processing
description: Modern digital compositing, texturing, and image making techniques as they have evolved from legacy and analog media into state of the art digital formats.

title: ITP 446 Cyber Breach Investigations
description: Cyber breaches. Data theft. Enterprise data analysis. Network forensic analysis. Server forensics.

title: ITP 447 Mobile Device Security and Forensics
description: Mobile device security. Mobile device forensics. Android. Blackberry. Windows phone. Symbian.

title: ITP 445 Macintosh, OSX, and iOS Forensics
description: Digital forensics. Digital evidence. Apple. Mac. Macintosh. OSX. iOS. iPhone. iPad.

title: ITP 421x Advanced Programming for Enterprise Information Systems
description: Object Oriented Programming for Enterprise information systems. Working with classes, objects, database tables, SQL. Designing reports and Graphical user interfaces. Leveraging service oriented architecture.

title: ITP 422L Configuring Enterprise Resource Planning Systems
description: Business process integration is the core advantage of using ERP systems. Analyze, configure, and test business processes for a company from the ground up.

title: ITP 439 Compiler Development
description: Practical applications of techniques used to develop a programming language compiler.

title: ITP 415 3-D Design and Prototyping
description: Explore the range of 3-D printing and prototyping technologies, and their application in modern industrial, design, and creative fields.

title: ITP 411 Multimedia and Video Production
description: Visual communication and storytelling are essential skills, especially in the digital age. Overview of techniques and software to create, edit, and deliver compelling images and video.

title: LAT 322 Lucretius' De Rerum Natura
description: The didactic epic as a vehicle of Epicurean philosophy.

title: LAT 320 Vergil
description: Studies in the Aeneid or Eclogues and Georgics.

title: LAT 325 Roman Historians
description: or satisfactory completion of placement test.

title: JOUR 436 Magazine Production
description: Publishing and production technologies; economics of magazine publishing including cost analysis, marketing, advertising, and circulation.

title: LAT 316 Roman Comedy
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: LAT 317 The Roman Novel: Apuleius' "Golden Ass"
description: A reading in Latin of substantial parts of Apuleius' novel, "The Golden Ass," with study of its cultural context and the development of the ancient novel.

title: LAT 313 Ovid and Classical Mythology
description: Selections from the Metamorphoses and Fasti; collateral reading on classical mythology.

title: LAT 312 Roman Satire
description: Selected satires of Horace and Juvenal; history of the genre.

title: LAT 315 Cicero
description: Representative philosophical, oratorical, and rhetorical works; selected letters.

title: LAT 314 Catullus and Horace
description: Selected poems of Catullus and Odes of Horace.

title: LAT 120 Latin I
description: Essentials of Latin grammar and vocabulary.

title: LAT 020x Latin for Research
description: For students who wish to use Latin in their research, or who need help in meeting the reading requirement for the PhD Not available for degree credit.

title: LAT 222 Latin III
description: Reading Latin literature. Introduction to reading and translation of classical Latin prose and poetry. Extensive grammar review.

title: LAT 310 Latin Elegiac Poetry
description: Selected poems of Catullus, Tibullus, Propertius, and Ovid; meter, style, and themes.

title: LAT 150 Latin II
description: Essentials of Latin grammar and vocabulary, continued. Basic reading skills.

title: JS 680 Boundaries of Jewish Normative Behavior
description: Institutions claiming Jewish authenticity and their treatment of Jews perceived to be deviant.

title: JS 590 Directed Research
description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

title: JS 504 Modern Hebrew Literature
description: Reading of unvocalized texts primarily from modern Hebrew literature. A survey of the development of modern Hebrew literature, with an emphasis on short story and poetry. Knowledge of Hebrew required.

title: JS 501c Bible Texts
description: Critical readings in each of the biblical books of Ruth, Lamentations, Ecclesiastes, Esther, and Song of Songs, with a view toward gaining an appreciation of their literary and religious values. Knowledge of Hebrew required.

title: JS 501a Bible Texts
description: Advanced grammar and reading. An introduction to principles of form criticism as applied to selected narrative and legal portions of the Pentateuch.

title: JS 499 Special Topics
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: JS 467 Modern Jewish Thought
description: Foundations of modern Jewish thought from the Western European Enlightenment to the present.

title: JS 490x Directed Research
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: ITP 391b Video Game Project Management
description: Project management for the video game industry, focusing on internal development. Creating ROIs, P&Ls, managing internal creative personnel, and coordinating with internal and external stakeholders.

title: ITP 393 Video Game Design Documents
description: Creation of design documents, from treatment to Game Design Document (GDD). Structuring documents for ease of use by team members who will create the game.

title: ITP 388 Developing Connected Devices
description: Introduction to the design and development of production-ready connected devices, from PCB design to control algorithms; micro-controller logic; real world interfaces and connectivity.

title: JS 501b Bible Texts
description: A critical evaluation of the biblical books of Amos and Hosea with a view to gaining an appreciation of the prophets' literary skill, their religious motivations, and the originality of their thought.

title: ITP 391a Video Game Project Management
description: Project management basics for the video game industry, focusing on external development. Examine the role of the producer, managing development and coordinating with various stakeholders.

title: ITP 370 Information Security Management
description: Management techniques for security projects. Security team management. Laws and regulations for information security. Disaster recovery. Security Audits.

title: ITP 380 Video Game Programming
description: Underlying concepts and principles required for programming video games (topics include vectors, transformations, 3-D math, geometric primitives, matrices).

title: ITP 375 Digital Forensics
description: Forensic science techniques. Digital evidence preservation and presentation. Processes and methodologies for digital analysis.

title: ITP 368 Programming Graphical User Interfaces
description: Programming applications with dynamic graphical user interfaces. Topics include events, controls, resources, data bindings, styles, and user experience.

title: ITP 360 3D Compositing and Visual Effects
description: Advanced techniques for 3D animation and visual effects development including 3D pre-visualization, match moving, dynamics, multi-pass rendering, and digital compositing.

title: ITP 357 Enterprise Network Design
description: Network technologies. Strategies for managing thousands of systems. Routers and managed switches. Integrated operating systems (IOS). Windows and Linux networking. Subnets.

title: ITP 345 Advanced App Development for Phones and Tablets
description: Develop sophisticated phone and tablet applications for Android-based hardware platforms using advanced functionality including background threading, broadcast receivers, sensors, and low-level interaction events.

title: JS 428 Blacks and Jews: Conflicts and Alliances
description: Examination of the relationship between the American Jewish and African-American communities and what it teaches about race and coalition politics in American society.

title: ITP 348 Introduction to Physical Computing
description: Design of electronic devices that interact with the physical world; electronic interfaces; development of software algorithms; micro-controller implementation.

title: ITP 410 Social Media for Scientists and Engineers
description: An introduction to the various ways in which social media and science are intersecting in a compelling manner; new technologies and online communities are powerful tools that are changing the ways in which scientists are engaging one another (inreach) and general audiences (outreach).

title: JS 390 Special Problems
description: Supervised, individual studies. No more than one registration permitted. Enrollment by petition only.

title: JS 415 The American Jewish Experience in Film
description: A survey of American Jewish history through the medium of film, with particular emphasis on the experience of the post-war generation.

title: JS 389 Culture and Society in Israel: Inventing the Dream
description: Examination of the social forces that shaped and continue to shape culture and society in contemporary Israel.

title: JS 381 The Jew in American Society
description: The changing sociological profile of the American Jew and changing organization of the American Jewish community as they developed over the 19th and 20th centuries.

title: JS 383 Jews in American Popular Culture
description: Social and cultural history of American Jewish contributions to the arts, science, literature, economics and politics.

title: JS 375 Issues of American Jewish Literature
description: Issues-oriented study of the human experience in America as expressed in the fiction, poetry, drama, memoirs, and literary criticism of America's Jews, using a dual approach incorporating both literary history and specific issues.

title: JS 378 Jewish Magic in the Ancient World
description: A cross-cultural examination of different kinds of magical literature that describe miraculous practices in Jewish mainstream and marginal life in the ancient and classical periods.

title: JS 374 Messiah: The History of an Idea
description: Exploration of the history of the idea of a messiah in Judaism from antiquity to today.

title: JS 370gp Digs and Dispute: Religion and Archaeology in Israel
description: Investigates contemporary conflicts in the discovery of the ancient world. Students will ask essential questions about the power of discovering and showcasing specific narratives.

title: JS 362 Terror and Resistance in Literature and the Media
description: Investigation of the multiple ways that people experience and represent incidents of terror in literature, film, music, and social media.

title: JS 360m Identity, Community, and Service: Jews and Other Americans
description: Examination of relationships between identity, community and service by investigating ethno-religious organizations' attempts to serve members of their group and confront issues of injustice in society.

title: JS 361 Scripture and Polemic in Judaism, Christianity and Islam
description: Origins of Scriptures and their polemical environments in earliest Judaism, Christianity, and Islam. Scripture as polemic and legitimation, and cross-religious/cross-cultural interpretation and argument based on scriptural themes.

title: JS 342 Reading in Two Directions: Connecting Law and Literature in Jewish Tradition
description: Investigates understandings of law, legal interpretation and the integration of law and narrative in Jewish texts by exploring how to examine legal and literary texts.

title: JS 314gp Holy War And History: Jews, Christians, Muslims
description: Investigates the engagement in war by Judaism, Christianity and Islam by examining history and theology and looks at religious justifications and condemnations of war.

title: JS 330 Jewish Power, Powerlessness, and Politics in the Modern Era
description: Explores the relationship between the Jewish people and political powers. Topics include politics in exile, changing relationships to power, and relations with the modern nation-state.

title: JS 340 Modern Jewish History
description: A survey of the major trends and themes of modern Jewish history. Examination of Jewish culture, society and politics from the Spanish Expulsion to the Second World War.

title: JS 300 American Jewish History
description: Patterns of immigration, acculturation, religious forms, and ethnic expression in America from the colonial period to the present.

title: JS 258gp Food, Faith and Conflict
description: Investigates how food and food traditions create and cross religious and social conflicts between Jews, Christians and Muslims by exploring faith, practice, thought and ethics.

title: DES 202 Design II
description: Exploration of essential elements of traditional and digital design, including color and image-text integration, editing information, typography and sequencing.

title: EE 664 Advanced Topics in Communication Theory
description: Modern communication theory for heterogeneous networks. Novel methods for communication network analysis and design. New theoretical tools: e.g. interference alignment, polar codes, and sparse approximation.

title: DES 123xg The Design Challenge: Exploring the Design Process
description: An overview of the creative design process and introduction to techniques to solve visual problems.

title: EDUC 705 Survey Design and Analysis
description: Design, collection, and analysis of survey data; survey analysis techniques including classical test theory, item response theory, differential item functioning, scaling, linking.

title: ENGR 100d Engineering Honors Colloquium
description: Recent developments in a highly technological society with emphasis on selected topics. Enrollment limited to members of the Viterbi School of Engineering Honors Program.

title: ENGR 100c Engineering Honors Colloquium
description: Recent developments in a highly technological society with emphasis on selected topics. Enrollment limited to members of the Viterbi School of Engineering Honors Program.

title: EALC 340gp Japanese Civilization
description: Survey of the main characteristics and development of art, literature, philosophy, religion, political and social institutions through different periods. Conducted in English.

title: ECON 594z Master's Thesis
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: DANC 185a Hip Hop Dance
description: An introduction to elements of Hip Hop Dance, including technique, movement, musical rhythm, tempo, and phrasing, as well as the historical context required to develop the skills needed to practice and perform this popular dance form.

title: EDUC 205L Child Development and Learning in Schools
description: Introduction to processes of development and learning in school aged children, with an emphasis on school contexts.

title: DANC 184c Jazz Dance
description: Advanced study of Jazz Dance technique, focusing on Broadway, commercial, and concert Jazz Dance, with a continued emphasis on improvisation, center work, and performance techniques.

title: DHYG 602 Research Methods and Biostatistics
description: Understand research process with fundamentals of research protocol design and statistical methods commonly used in healthcare.

title: DHYG 600 Dental Hygiene Professional Issues
description: Explore issues related to professional development and advancement of the discipline of dental hygiene and addressing the growth of the knowledge base of the profession

title: DHYG 601 Development of Systematic Investigations
description: Focus of research study development that impacts the dental hygiene profession by exploring the ethical and legal principles that guide research and practice in healthcare.

title: CTAN 565L Motion Capture Performance
description: The art of directing, acting, and creating story for motion capture will be explored while learning the technology behind bringing virtual actors to life.

title: CTAN 508L Live Action Integration with Visual Effects
description: Survey of the digital techniques required to successfully marry live action shooting with CGI elements and green screen footage.

title: CTPR 479 Single Camera Television Dramatic Pilot
description: Collaborative writing, preproduction and shooting of a pilot act for an original episodic television drama, shot on stage sets built for the show.

title: CTIN 478 Level Design Workshop
description: Terms Offered: FaSp

title: CTPR 478 Practicum in Directing
description: Concepts of directing for motion pictures, emphasizing the working relationship of actors and directors. Scenes will be staged in class and filmed for class presentation.

title: CTPR 480 Advanced Production Workshop
description: Directors, producers, cinematographers, editors and sound designers collaborate to produce, shoot, edit and deliver fictional, documentary or experimental projects.

title: CTPR 476 Directing The Comedic Scene
description: Directing comedy: casting, rehearsing, directing actors, scene analysis, staging, shooting, and editing, leading to the filming of a two-person comic scene.

title: CTPR 594b Master's Thesis
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: CTWR 305 Advanced Screenwriting: The Relationship Screenplay
description: An inquiry into the complex nature of human relationships by writing an original feature length screenplay that examines the multidimensional world of characters and the ties that bind them together.

title: CTWR 420b Senior Thesis in Half-Hour Television Comedy
description: Rewrite, casting, and stage performance of the comedy development process. A rewrite of the final draft and completion of the series bible with multiple seasons.

title: CTPR 477 Special Problems in Directing
description: Detailed investigation and analysis of problems in directing. Individual projects.

title: CTWR 420a Senior Thesis in Half-Hour Television Comedy
description: Intense study in developing an original half-hour television comedy pilot including special attention to development of multiple seasons and character evolution.

title: CSCI 659 Introduction to Online Optimization
description: Foundation and advances of the theory of online learning/online convex optimization/sequential decision making.

title: CSCI 662 Advanced Natural Language Processing
description: Computational models of natural language. Formalisms for describing structures of human language, and algorithms for learning language structures from data.

title: CSCI 657 Advanced Distributed Systems
description: The foundations and modern applications of distributed systems. Topics include: logical time, fault tolerance, group communication, consensus, consistency, transactions, and peer-to-peer.

title: CSCI 653 High Performance Computing and Simulations
description: Advanced high-performance computer simulation techniques; multiscale deterministic and stochastic simulation algorithms on parallel and distributed computing platforms; immersive and interactive visualization of simulation data.

title: CSCI 656 Networked Systems in Cloud Computing
description: Systems and network design and protocols in cloud computing and data centers networks.

title: CSCI 646 Coordinated Mobile Robotics
description: State-of-the-art techniques for coordinating robot teams. Distributed approaches; task allocation; control and stability; network topology; coverage and monitoring; caging; bio-inspired approaches; persistence; probabilistic methods.

title: CSCI 648 Advanced Information Integration
description: Focus on foundations and techniques for information integration. Topics include Semantic Web, linked data, data integration, entity linkage, source modeling, and information extraction.

title: CSCI 651 Advanced Computer Networking
description: Computer communication protocols and systems, including classic and contemporary literature. The emphasis is on conceptual issues in the design and implementation of computer internetworks.

title: CSCI 631 Privacy in the World of Big Data
description: Privacy challenges that arise in the world driven by data. An overview of algorithmic and technical approaches to addressing them.

title: CSCI 644 Natural Language Dialogue Systems
description: Computational models of natural language dialogue; conversational interfaces to artificial systems; dialogue system architectures and applications; Reinforcement learning of dialogue policies.

title: CSCI 621 Digital Geometry Processing
description: Digital geometry processing (subfield of computer graphics), that covers the full pipeline from 3D scanning, processing, to 3D printing.

title: CSCI 620 Computer Animation and Simulation
description: Animation and Simulation techniques for computer games, virtual reality, and film visual effects. Research methods, SIGGRAPH papers. Deformable objects, fluids, sound, collision detection, haptics, rigid bodies, GPUs.

title: CSCI 599 Special Topics
description: Course content to be selected each semester from recent developments in computer science.

title: CSCI 598 Professional Writing and Communication for Computer Scientists
description: Instruction in discipline-specific workplace writing and communication skills for computer science graduate students.

title: CSCI 594z Master's Thesis
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: CSCI 596 Scientific Computing and Visualization
description: Hands-on training on the basics of parallel computing and scientific visualization in the context of computer simulations in science and engineering.

title: CSCI 610 Advanced Program Analysis and Verification
description: Advanced techniques for analyzing and verifying software systems; topics include program analysis, automated verification, and software testing.

title: CSCI 594b Master's Thesis
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: CSCI 594a Master's Thesis
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: CSCI 591 Computer Science Research Colloquium
description: Exploration and critical assessment of research activities in computer science. Course will serve as a forum for current research presentations from academia and industry

title: CSCI 590 Directed Research
description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

title: CSCI 589 Software Engineering for Embedded Systems
description: Software engineering methods and techniques for embedded, resource constrained, and mobile environments. Applications to real-time operating systems and wireless networking systems. Class project.

title: CSCI 585 Database Systems
description: Database system architecture; conceptual database models; semantic, object-oriented, logic-based, and relational databases; user and program interfaces; database system implementation; integrity, security, concurrency and recovery.

title: CSCI 586 Database Systems Interoperability
description: Federated and multi-database systems, database networking, conceptual and schematic diversity, information sharing and exchange, knowledge discovery, performance issues.

title: CSCI 587 Geospatial Information Management
description: Familiarity with conceptual data modeling tools such as Entity-Relationship (ER) data model, logical data models such as the relational and object-relational data model, SQL3 as a commercial query language, normal forms and logical data design. Familiarity with the physical design of a database using persistent data structures such as B+-tree and Hash indexes

title: CSCI 580 3-D Graphics and Rendering
description: Course outlines the process of creating images from 3D models. Includes transformations, shading, lighting, rastorization, texturing, and other topics.

title: CSCI 582 Geometric Modeling
description: Mathematical models and computer representations for threedimensional solids; underlying topics from set theory, geometry, and topology. Fundamental algorithms; applications to CAD/CAM and robotics.

title: CSCI 583 Machine Learning Theory
description: Developing the core concepts and techniques, inherent abilities, and limitations of learning algorithms in well-defined learning models.

title: CSCI 581 Logic and its Applications
description: Formal systems, first order logic, truth, completeness, compactness, Godel incompleteness, recursive functions, undecidability. Selected applications, e.g., theorem proving, artificial intelligence, program verification, databases, computational complexity.

title: CSCI 578 Software Architectures
description: Study of concepts, principles and scope of software system architectures, including architectural styles, languages, connectors, middleware, dynamism, analysis, testing and domain-specific approaches.

title: CSCI 577b Software Engineering
description: Software development, test, implementation, and maintenance methods. CASE tools and software environments. Software product engineering, configuration management, quality engineering, documentation. Application via projects.

title: CSCI 577a Software Engineering
description: Software life cycle processes; planning considerations for product definition, development, test, implementation, maintenance. Software requirements elicitation and architecture synthesis. Team project.

title: CSCI 576 Multimedia Systems Design
description: End-to-end multimedia systems -  content creation, compression, distribution using modern standards, DRM solutions,  Digital-Cinema pipeline, multimedia classification, virtual-augmented reality, natural-language multimedia queries, multimodal media analysis, stereoscopic-holographic  technologies.

title: CSCI 571 Web Technologies
description: Advanced study of programming languages with application to the Web. Languages for client-side and server-side processing. Examples taken from: HTML, Java, JavaScript, Perl, XML and others.

title: CSCI 572 Information Retrieval and Web Search Engines
description: Examines key aspects of information retrieval as they apply to search engines; web crawling, indexing, querying and quality of results are studied.

title: CSCI 569 Social Media Analytics
description: Introduction to quantitative analysis of social data. Topics include social network analysis, text analysis, machine learning and statistical methods and they are used to study influence, information diffusion, sentiment analysis and prediction of individual and social behavior online.

title: CSCI 574 Computer Vision
description: Description and recognition of objects, shape analysis, edge and region segmentation, texture, knowledge based systems, image understanding.

title: CSCI 568 Requirements Engineering
description: Techniques for successful requirements analysis and requirements engineering (RE) of software-intensive systems. Systematic process of developing requirements through cooperative problem analysis, representation, and validation.

title: CSCI 565 Compiler Design
description: Formal grammar; parsing methods and lexical analysis; code generation; local and global code optimization; and dynamic allocation.

title: CSCI 561 Foundations of Artificial Intelligence
description: Foundations of symbolic intelligent systems, search, logic, knowledge representation, planning, learning.

title: CSCI 556 Introduction to Cryptography
description: Modern secret codes. Public key cryptosystems of Rivest- Shamir-Adleman, Diffie-Hellman and others. The underlying number theory and computational complexity theory.

title: CSCI 555L Advanced Operating Systems
description: Advanced topics in operating system research: new OS structures, novel memory management, communication, file system, process management, reliability and security techniques.

title: CSCI 558L Internetworking and Distributed Systems Laboratory
description: Students complete laboratory exercises in operating system and network management, distributed systems, TCP/IP, SNMP, NFS, DNS, etc. Term project required.

title: CSCI 550 Advanced Data Stores
description: Selected topics on highly available, elastic data stores. Topics include non-relational data models, simple interfaces and query languages, weak consistency and benchmarking techniques.

title: CSCI 551 Computer Networking
description: Protocol design for computer communication networks, network routing, transport protocols, internetworking.

title: CSCI 549 Nanorobotics
description: Introduction to nanotechnology. Nanorobotic systems: sensing; actuation and propulsion; control; communication; power; programming and coordination of robot swarms. Nanomanipulation and nanoassembly with atomic force microscopes.

title: CSCI 548 Information Integration on the Web
description: Foundations and techniques in information integration as it applies to the Web, including view integration, wrapper learning, record linkage, and streaming dataflow execution.

title: CSCI 545 Robotics
description: Fundamental skills for modeling and controlling of dynamic systems for robotic applications and graphics animations; control theory; kinematics; dynamics; sensor processing; real-time operating systems; robot labs.

title: CSCI 544 Applied Natural Language Processing
description: Introduction to key components of human language technologies, including: information extraction, sentiment analysis, question answering, machine translation.

title: CSCI 542 Neural Computation with Artificial Neural Networks
description: Computation and adaptation in networks of interconnected distributed processing units; classical and statistical approaches to neural nets; stateof- the-art neural network research.

title: CSCI 540 Self-Organization
description: Massively distributed systems whose global behavior emerges from local interactions of components. Global to local compilation; robot swarms; formation of shapes/spatial patterns; self-assembly; programmable matter.

title: CSCI 538 Augmented, Virtual and Mixed Reality
description: Technical design and implementation of immersive environments; visual simulations, interactive 3D graphics and games.

title: CSCI 534 Affective Computing
description: Overview of the theory of human emotion, techniques for recognizing and synthesizing emotional behavior, and design application.

title: CSCI 535 Multimodal Probabilistic Learning of Human Communication
description: Principles and techniques to understand, build, and utilize multimodal machine learning algorithms through automatically understanding, recognizing, and analyzing phenomena of human communication.

title: CSCI 531 Applied Cryptography
description: Intensive overview of cryptography for practitioners, historical perspective on early systems, number theoretic foundations of modern day cryptosystems and basic cryptanalysis.

title: CSCI 530 Security Systems
description: Protecting computer networks and systems using cryptography, authentication, authorization, intrusion detection and response. Includes lab to provide practical experience working with such systems.

title: CSCI 529b Advanced Game Projects
description: Provides students in various areas of game specialization the practice of design, iterative stage 2 prototyping and development of a refined game.

title: CSCI 529a Advanced Game Projects
description: Team projects intended to address the multifaceted technical and creative challenges that are inherent to comprehensive game development.

title: CSCI 526 Advanced Mobile Devices and Game Consoles
description: Explore the complex engineering process required to design and build a real-time graphics engine to support physical realism on mobile devices.

title: CSCI 522 Game Engine Development
description: The principles of developing game engines targeted at modern PC and game console hardware.

title: CSCI 523L Networked Games
description: Design and implementation of networked games, from the origins of the supporting technologies in distributed systems, visual simulations, networked virtual environments, and shipped games.

title: CSCI 524 Networked Artificial Intelligence
description: Networked game communication architectures, protocol development, architecting networked game AI clients/services. Character following, knowledge representation and reasoning, dynamic play strategies, search, learning, and planning.

title: CSCI 511 Personal Software Process (PSP) and Project
description: Individual analysis, planning, development and maintenance of a software product or development artifact, using the principles and practices of PSP. Analysis of project's lessons learned.

title: CSCI 520 Computer Animation and Simulation
description: Fundamental techniques of computer animation and simulation, knowledge and/or experience in the design, scripting, production and post-production stages of computer animation.

title: CSCI 512 Testing and Analysis of Software Systems
description: Introduces students to the topic of automated testing and analysis of large-scale modern software systems.

title: CSCI 499 Special Topics
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture, Discussion

title: CSCI 491bL Final Game Project
description: Design, iterative stage 2 prototyping and development of a refined game.

title: CSCI 491aL Final Game Project
description: Design, iterative prototyping, and development of a 1st playable level.

title: CTWR 419b Senior Thesis in Dramatic Television
description: Revision of original pilot script, writing of mid-season episode, and completion of bible for original dramatic series developed in first semester.

title: CSCI 490x Directed Research
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: CTWR 418b Senior Thesis
description: Completion and revision of senior thesis project and introduction to motion picture industry procedures and practices through interaction with industry representatives.

title: CTWR 418a Senior Thesis
description: Creation of feature-length treatment and first draft senior thesis screenplay, including "pitching" experiences.

title: CTWR 419a Senior Thesis in Dramatic Television
description: Advanced workshop developing an original hour-long dramatic series including characters, world, and story lines for season one. Final assignment is completed hour-long pilot episode.

title: CTWR 417 Script Coverage and Story Analysis
description: Evaluation of completed scripts prior to their production. Coverage and analysis of scripts as potential properties from the perspective of a production company.

title: CTWR 416 Motion Picture Script Analysis
description: Critical analysis of story structure from classic films to contemporary works. Identification of key story concepts and elements of three-act structure.

title: CTWR 415b Advanced Writing
description: Creation of script with extensive work-shopping of scenes in class leading to a first draft and revision as a final assignment.

title: CTWR 413 Writing the Short Script I
description: Registration Restriction: Open only to Cinematic Arts Film and Television production majors.

title: CTWR 412 Introduction to Screenwriting
description: Introduction to the formal elements of writing the short film.

title: CTWR 414 The Screenplay
description: Students study story structure and develop several story outlines, write a short script for possible production, a feature film outline and first act.

title: CTWR 411 Television Script Analysis
description: In-depth analysis of the craft of writing prime-time episodic television. Examination of situation comedies and dramas through weekly screenings and lectures.

title: CTWR 415a Advanced Writing
description: Principles of the feature film; creating theme, character and structure that combine into a feature-length story treatment.

title: CTWR 410L Character Development and Storytelling for Games
description: An exploration of characters and story worlds as they relate to gaming with an emphasis on emotionally rich environments in interactive entertainment.

title: CTWR 404 Foundations of Comedy
description: Study of comedy theory and practical applications in film, television, and social media. Lectures and screenings of comedic forms tracing past, present and future.

title: CTWR 407 Creating the Comedic Character
description: Utilization of various techniques for character to emerge naturally in scene and stories. Creating multiple comedic characters to generate future stories.

title: CTWR 402 Writing and Social Change
description: An introductory course in writing for the screen with an emphasis on social issues.

title: CTWR 401 Writing the First Draft Feature Screenplay
description: Writing an outline and the first draft of a feature-length screenplay. Emphasis on character interrelationships, conflict, and three-act structure.

title: CTWR 324 Introduction to Half-Hour Television Writing
description: The fundamentals of writing for comedic episodic television. Writing scenes from popular comedy series and examination of half-hour television comedy story structure.

title: CTWR 315x Filmwriting
description: The basics of screenwriting: theme, story structure, characterization, format, dialogue, and scene description. A character profile, short treatment, and first 30 pages of the screenplay are written. Lectures, screenings, and in-class readings.

title: CTWR 321 Introduction to Hour-Long Television Writing
description: The fundamentals of writing for dramatic episodic television. Writing scenes from popular television shows and examination of television story structure.

title: CTWR 314 Writing To Be Performed
description: Understanding the elements of screen performance to enhance the writing of complex characters and human relationships.

title: CTWR 405 Storytelling for Virtual and Augmented Reality
description: Storytelling for the 360-degree visual arena. Focus on immersive worlds, challenges of virtual and augmented reality, and active audience engagement.

title: CTWR 250 Breaking the Story
description: Examination of the fundamental elements of a good story, and how to use those elements to develop new screenplay ideas.

title: CTWR 213 Content and Consciousness
description: Inquiry into the relationship between cognitive and affective knowledge as it relates to the art of screenwriting and the screenwriter.

title: CTWR 306 Advanced Screenwriting: Alternative Narrative
description: Develop and write an original feature-length screenplay utilizing a non-linear narrative story structure that examines the creative use of time, perspective, and point of view to enhance both character and story.

title: CTWR 212 Fundamental Topics of Writing for Film and TV
description: Introductory course focusing on varying topics of fundamentals for feature writing and television writing.

title: CTWR 215 Practicum in Writing Short Films
description: Developing stories less than feature length; writing screenplays from them; understanding what length each story demands; creating idiosyncratic forms and styles.

title: CTWR 211g The Television Writer: An Agent of Change
description: The television writer as an agent of change across current social issues including, but not limited to: race, gender, and class.

title: CTWR 206a Writing the Screenplay
description: Development of synopsis and treatment for a theatrical or documentary screenplay: theme, plot, character, mise-en-scene and utilization of cinematic elements.

title: CTWR 106b Screenwriting Fundamentals
description: Exercises in dramatic writing: theme, plot, character, dialogue and images. Integration of these elements into scenes and sequences.

title: CTWR 206b Writing the Screenplay
description: Writing a feature-length screenplay based on treatment developed in

title: CTWR 120 Genesis of the Screenplay
description: The evolution of the screenplay from its roots in myths, plays, and short stories. Writing original treatments for film and television inspired by literary masters.

title: CTWR 105 Nonverbal Thinking: Visual and Aural
description: An introduction to non-verbal elements of images and sounds which convey meaning, mood, and emotion.

title: CTWR 106a Screenwriting Fundamentals
description: Introduction to and overview of the elements of theme, plot, character, and dialogue in dramatic writing for film.

title: CTWR 100g Story: Character, Conflict, and Catharsis
description: Fundamentals course on the elements of scene writing, story structure, and character development.

title: CTSE 593b Master's Seminar
description: An examination and analysis of research and literature from the student's area of focus. Required of all master's candidates who do not enroll in the Master's Thesis (594abz).

title: CTPR 594z Master's Thesis
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: CTPR 599 Special Topics
description: Detailed investigation of new or emerging aspects of cinema; special subjects offered by visiting faculty; experimental subjects.

description: An examination and analysis of research and literature from the student's area of focus. Required of all master's candidates who do not enroll in the Master's Thesis (594abz).

title: CTIN 463 Anatomy of a Game

title: CTIN 462 Critical Theory and Analysis of Games
