title: CTIN 458 Business and Management of Games
description: Overview of current business models in games and interactive media, methods for pitching and getting products funded; copyright and intellectual property.

title: CTIN 459L Game Industry Workshop
description: Exploration of industry-related game play research questions. Student teams will develop concepts and materials to solve a research problem posed by an industry partner.

title: CTIN 456 Game Design for Business
description: Designed to provide the business professional with effective communication skills in working with the designers of games and game related venues.

title: CTPR 594a Master's Thesis
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: CTPR 587z Group Production Workshop
description: Advanced group project involving the creative use of visuals (live action or animated) and sound specifically designed for students who want to work in pairs.

title: CTIN 452L Themed Entertainment Design
description: The fundamentals of design, technology, operations and process for the creation of themed entertainment experiences and story-centric place-making.

title: CTPR 587c Group Production Workshop
description: Advanced group project involving the creative use of visuals (live action or animated) and sound specifically designed for students who want to work in pairs.

title: CTPR 587b Group Production Workshop
description: Advanced group project involving the creative use of visuals (live action or animated) and sound specifically designed for students who want to work in pairs.

title: CTPR 585z Advanced Producing Project
description: Supervised, individual study leading to the creation of a producer's package. The package will include script, schedule, budget, finance and marketing plan. Graded IP/Letter.

title: CTPR 585b Advanced Producing Project
description: Supervised, individual study leading to the creation of a producer's package. The package will include script, schedule, budget, finance and marketing plan. Graded IP/Letter.

title: CTPR 587a Group Production Workshop
description: Advanced group project involving the creative use of visuals (live action or animated) and sound specifically designed for students who want to work in pairs. Qualifying courses:

title: CTPR 585a Advanced Producing Project
description: Supervised, individual study leading to the creation of a producer's package. The package will include script, schedule, budget, finance and marketing plan. Graded IP/Letter.

title: CTPR 582a Advanced Production Seminar
description: Advanced individual film or video projects under the guidance of a faculty mentor, without benefit of university equipment or resources. Qualifying courses: CTPR 532 (for directors); CTPR 558 (for producers). Graded IP/Letter.

title: CTPR 581z Individual Production Workshop
description: Individual experimental projects involving the creative use of visuals (live action or animated) and sound. Graded IP/Letter.

title: CTPR 582z Advanced Production Seminar
description: Advanced individual film or video projects under the guidance of a faculty mentor, without benefit of university equipment or resources. Graded IP/Letter.

title: CTPR 582b Advanced Production Seminar
description: Advanced individual film or video projects under the guidance of a faculty mentor, without benefit of university equipment or resources. Graded IP/Letter.

title: CTPR 583 Graduate Television Production
description: Advanced television group production workshop for students who want to produce an advanced multi-camera project. Qualifying courses:

title: CTPR 581c Individual Production Workshop
description: Individual experimental projects involving the creative use of visuals (live action or animated) and sound. Graded IP/Letter.

title: CTPR 581b Individual Production Workshop
description: Individual experimental projects involving the creative use of visuals (live action or animated) and sound. Graded IP/Letter.

title: CTPR 573 Producing the Advanced Project
description: Basic skills of production planning as applied to students' advanced project scripts. Covers all steps from breakdown to delivery.

title: CTPR 581a Individual Production Workshop
description: Individual experimental projects involving the creative use of visuals (live action or animated) and sound. Qualifying courses:

title: CTPR 566 Developing and Selling Your Film and TV Projects
description: Developing, pitching, and selling your feature motion picture and TV projects.

title: CTPR 572 The World of Television: From Concept to Air and Everything in Between
description: Takes projects from conception to sale, including development, production, post-production, and marketing. Students will develop original projects.

title: CTPR 563 The Business of Representation
description: Various roles an agent, manager, attorney or publicist play in representing talent, producers and writers. Taught by professionals who are at the forefront of the entertainment industry.

title: CTIN 444 Audio Expression
description: Foundational aesthetic principles and creative technologies for game audio. Processing, mixing, and controlling sound for games for expressive effect.

title: CTPR 565 Making Media for Social Change
description: Each student will produce and direct a film incorporating a social issue of his/her choice into the narrative of the film.

title: CTIN 426 Video Games, Identity, and Diversity
description: Thinking about video games in relation to many personal and cultural factors, including race, disability, class, gender, sexuality, and body type.

title: CTIN 406L Sound Design for Games
description: Introduction to the techniques, terminology, and implementation of sounds in games, including establishing a sense of place and concepts of realistic sound.

title: CTIN 405L Design and Technology for Mobile Experiences

title: CTIN 404L Usability Testing for Games

title: CTIN 401L Interface Design for Games

title: CTIN 290 Digital Media Workshop

title: CTIN 332 Games for Animation
description: Contemporary examples and theories of the crossover between animation and video game practices.

title: CTIN 403L Advanced Visual Design for Games

title: CTIN 200L The New Games Industry
description: An overview of what it means to be a professional game developer in the modern and rapidly changing economic environment.

title: CTIN 190 Introduction to Interactive Entertainment

title: CTIN 110 Statistical Analysis for Games: Storytelling with Numbers
description: An introductory course on using statistical analysis for user research and assessment of interactive projects.

title: CTIN 191 Survey of Themed Entertainment
description: Introduction to the field of themed entertainment and education design, covering its history, and, especially, current practice.

title: CTCS 794z Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: CTIN 101 Fundamentals of Procedural Media
description: Introduction to the procedural nature of interactive media and games, though the coding language Processing. Students will develop proficiency in reading and creating computational media.

title: CTCS 794d Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: CTCS 794c Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: CTCS 794a Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: CTCS 791 Historical and Critical Research Methods
description: Methods and procedures for historical and critical research in the visual media. Required tutorial with Ph.D. student's dissertation committee chair, designed to assist initial work on dissertation.

title: CTCS 794b Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: CTCS 790 Research
description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

title: CTPR 562 Seminar in Motion Picture Business

title: CTPR 561 Publicity for Cinema and Television

title: CTPR 556 Advanced Editing

title: CTPR 558 Advanced Producing

title: CTPR 543 Editing the Advanced Project

title: CTPR 538 Intermediate Producing
description: Definition, examination and practical experience in the role of the line producer as it relates to preproduction, production and post production.

title: CTPR 536 Editing for Scriptwriters

title: CTPR 547L Production III, Documentary
description: Intensive workshop; students shoot and finish documentary projects up to about 25 minutes. Qualifying courses: for directors,

title: CTPR 540 Intermediate Sound

title: CTPR 534 Intermediate Production Design

title: CTPR 533 Directing Techniques

title: CTPR 537 Intermediate Cinematography

title: CTPR 535 Intermediate Editing
description: Editorial construction of film sequences to analyze the interrelationships of the various film elements, both visual and aural.

title: CTCS 673 Topics in Theory

title: CTCS 678 Seminar in Film Theory and Medium Specificity
description: Explores the way film has been theorized in relationship to traditional media that preceded it and electronic media that followed.

title: CTPR 532 Intermediate Directing

title: CTCS 688 Moving Image Histories: Methods and Approaches
description: Research seminar in methods and approaches to moving image history including film, television, and digital media. Focus on archival research and issues in writing history.

title: CTCS 677 Cultural Theory
description: Seminar in theoretical approaches to cultural studies; focus on interdisciplinary research of media and audiences, covering a range of methods and theoretical frameworks; concentration varies.

title: CTPR 531 Planning the Documentary Production
description: A preproduction workshop for the research and planning of a documentary project to be executed in

title: CTCS 679 Seminar in Genre and/or Narrative Theory

title: CTCS 599 Special Topics

title: CTCS 569 Seminar in Film and Television Authors

title: CTCS 587 Seminar in Television Theory

title: CTCS 567 Seminar in Film/Television and a Related Art

title: CTCS 521 Media Archiving: History and Practice

title: CTCS 564 Seminar in Film and Television Genres

title: CTCS 520 Film History Through the Archives and Special Collections

title: CTCS 518 Seminar: Avant-Garde Film/Video

title: CTCS 517 Introductory Concepts in Cultural Studies

title: CTCS 511 Seminar: Non-Fiction Film/Video

title: CTCS 510 Case Studies in National Media and/or Regional Media

title: CTCS 506 Critical Studies Colloquium/Professional Seminar

title: CTCS 505 Survey of Interactive Media
description: A survey course exploring the historical, cultural, business, creative and technological aspects of the new interactive media.

title: CTCS 504 Survey of Television History

title: CTPR 510 Concepts of Cinematic Production

title: CTPR 499 Special Topics
description: Detailed investigation of new or emerging aspects of cinema and/or television; special subjects offered by visiting faculty; experimental subjects.

title: CTPR 508 Production II

title: CTPR 496 The Film Industry: Career Challenges and Choices for Women

title: CTPR 497 Music Video Production

title: CTPR 487 Recording for Film Scores

title: CTPR 506 Visual Expression

title: CTCS 502 World Cinema After 1945

title: CTPR 486 Single Camera Television Dramatic Series

title: CTCS 500 Seminar in Film Theory

title: CTCS 501 World Cinema Before 1945

title: CTCS 503 Survey History of the United States Sound Film

title: CTCS 499 Special Topics
description: Detailed investigation of new or emerging aspects of cinema and/or television; special subjects offered by visiting faculty; experimental subjects.

title: CTCS 495 Honors Seminar

title: CTCS 469 Film and/or Television Style Analysis

title: CTCS 494 Advanced Cinema and Media Studies Seminar

title: CTCS 467 Television Symposium

title: CTCS 473 Film and Media Theory

title: CTCS 466 Theatrical Film Symposium

title: CTCS 409 Censorship in Cinema

title: CTCS 407 African American Cinema

title: CTCS 402 Practicum in Film/Television Criticism

title: CTCS 403 Studies in National and Regional Media
description: Detailed investigation of traditions, achievements, and trends of film and/or electronic media in a particular country or region.

title: CTCS 392 History of the American Film, 1925–1950

title: CTCS 394 History of the American Film, 1977–present

title: CTCS 400 Non-Fiction Film and Television
description: An international survey of documentary, informational, and independent experimental film, video and television.

title: CTCS 367 Global Media

title: CTCS 306 Cinema and Media Theory and Practice

title: CTCS 201 History of the International Cinema II

title: CTCS 192gm Race, Class, and Gender in American Film

title: CTCS 303 Japanese Anime

title: CTCS 200g History of the International Cinema I

title: CTCS 190g Introduction to Cinema

title: CTAN 599 Special Topics
description: Detailed investigation of new or emerging aspects of cinema; special subjects offered by visiting faculty; experimental subjects.

title: CTAN 594z Master's Thesis
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture, Lab

title: CTAN 594b Master's Thesis
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture, Lab

title: CTCS 191 Introduction to Television and Video
description: Exploration of the economic, technological, aesthetic, and ideological characteristics of the television medium; study of historical development of television and video including analysis of key works; introduction to TV/video theory and criticism.

title: CTAN 594a Master's Thesis
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture, Lab

title: CTAN 577b Fundamentals of Animation

title: CTPR 421 Practicum in Editing

title: CTPR 405 Filmic Expression

title: CTPR 386 Art and Industry of the Theatrical Film

title: CTPR 375 Functions of a Director

title: CTPR 340 Creating the Motion Picture Sound Track

title: CTPR 335 Motion Picture Editing

title: CTPR 301 Creating the Non-Fiction Film

title: CTPR 310 Intermediate Production
description: Principles of visual and aural communication; idea development and realization using image, movement, pace, the spoken word and other sounds; small crew projects.

title: CTPR 294 Directing in Documentary, Fiction and New Media

title: CTPR 288 Originating and Developing Ideas for Film

title: CTPR 280 Structure of the Moving Image

title: CTPR 285 Lateral Thinking for Filmmaking Practice

title: CTPR 290 Cinematic Communication

title: CTPR 242 Fundamentals of Cinematic Sound
description: Introduction to sound design, recording, editing, mixing and finishing. Lectures, demonstrations and exercises.

title: CTPR 240x Practicum in Production
description: Basic production techniques: introduction to the cinematic elements, production techniques, and equipment; film and/or videotape production.

title: CTIN 599 Special Topics
description: Detailed investigation of new or emerging aspects of interactive media; special subjects offered by visiting faculty; experimental subjects.

title: CTPR 241 Fundamentals of Cinema Technique
description: Introduction to cinema production techniques and equipment including producing, directing, camera, lighting, and editing.

description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: CTIN 542 Interactive Design and Production II

description: Planning, designing, and analyzing a research study for a digital media project. Production of a written report and presentation.

title: CTIN 501 Interactive Cinema

title: CTIN 492L Experimental Game Topics

title: CTIN 493L Advanced Game Project II

title: CTIN 490x Directed Research
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: CTIN 486 Alternative Control Workshop

title: CTIN 484L Intermediate Game Development

title: CTIN 479 Documentary and Activist Games

title: CTAN 563 Advanced Computer Animation

title: CTAN 564L Motion Capture Fundamentals

title: CTAN 550 Stop Motion Puppet and Set Design

title: CTAN 525 Gesture Movement for Animation

title: CTAN 505 The Business of Animation

title: CTAN 504L Creative Production in Virtual Reality

title: CTAN 502L Experiments in Immersive Design

title: CTAN 501 Experiments in 2-D Digital Animation

title: CTAN 499 Special Topics

title: CTAN 497L Generative Animation

description: Advanced dental hygiene techniques: treatment, referral and maintenance of the advanced periodontitis patient emphasizing treatment planning and patient management.

title: DHYG 413a Dental Hygiene Educational Concepts
description: Educational concepts for development of dental hygiene curriculum, including teaching and learning strategies, curriculum design, course development and evaluation methods.

title: DHYG 410c Clinic: Dental Hygiene

description: Seminar-discussion and analysis of current dental literature in selected topics related to dental hygiene practice.

title: DHYG 410b Clinic: Dental Hygiene
description: Application of advanced techniques with emphasis on increased proficiency in skills: principles of prevention; periodontal examination; root planing; soft tissue curettage; local anesthesia; inhalation sedation.

title: DHYG 410a Clinic: Dental Hygiene
description: Application of advanced techniques with emphasis on increased proficiency in skills: principles of prevention; periodontal examination; root planing; soft tissue curettage; local anesthesia; inhalation sedation.

description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: DANC 590 Directed Research
description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

title: DANC 499 Special Topics
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: DANC 495 Dance Internship

title: DANC 490x Directed Research

title: DANC 485 Advanced Performance Studies: Senior Project

title: DANC 333gw Origins of Jazz Dance

title: DANC 342gp International and Historical Perspectives on Dance
description: Exploration of dance as an art form in its artistic, political, and socio-cultural climate. Studies of the continuum of dance within its historical context.

title: DANC 312gw African American Dance

title: DANC 305 Dance and New Media

title: DANC 310 Dance Technique III

Applications of the elements of dance studies, art criticism, and viewing productions to explore topic such as architecture, photography, poetry, technology, cinematic arts, sports, medicine, and more.

title: DANC 212g Dance in Popular Culture

title: DANC 230 Improvisation and Composition III: Intermediate

title: DANC 210 Dance Technique II
description: Intermediate technique studies in a studio setting. Concentration on classical ballet, hip hop and its derivatives, partnering and contemporary techniques essential to the dancers' development.

title: DANC 201 Colloquium: History of Performance and Cultural Context

title: DANC 191 Gaga: Dancers

title: DANC 189a Tap Dance

title: DANC 188a International Style Ballroom Dance
description: Introduction to International Standard, International Latin, and American Style ballroom dances. Designed to introduce students to the fundamentals of ballroom dance, emphasizing partner connection, communication, and creativity, with the practical application of dance within a social setting.

title: DANC 187 Bollywood Dance
description: An introduction to basic and intermediate Bollywood Dance, including technique, movement, musical rhythm, phrases, and choreography. Inspired by the high energy music from Indian films, Bollywood is a fusion form that combines traditional Indian folk and classical dances with Hip Hop, Jazz, Latin, and Middle-eastern dance.

title: DANC 185b Hip Hop Dance
description: Continued study of Hip Hop Dance elements on an intermediate level, augmenting the historical context, technique, fluidity, and musicality required to execute the form with greater movement acuity.

title: EDUC 204L Sociological Foundations of Education
description: Introduction to the sociological foundations of education through focused study of schools, teacher-student relations, and classroom processes as they relate to social stratification.

title: DANC 186 Afro Cuban Dance
description: An introduction to Afro Cuban Dance techniques, basic drum rhythms, and musicality, with an understanding of cultural practices and vocalizations. Afro Cuban Dance examines the traditions related to specific ethnic groups in Latin Europe and West Africa, and the influences of Rumba and Salsa Dance on the form.

title: EDUC 200 Introduction to the Teaching Profession
description: Identification and discussion of current issues and trends in schools and the teaching profession. Introduction to the development of a professional portfolio.

title: EDUC 140m Mind, Belief and Behavior: Learning in a Diverse World
description: Examination of current research about learning and motivation in the context of human diversity.

title: EDPT 655 Advanced Research Methods in Education
description: Focuses on principles of research design in education including literature synthesis, formulation of research problem and questions, selection of methodology and integration of research proposal.

title: EDPT 652 Multiple Regression
description: Applied multiple regression analysis using Stata.

title: EDPT 654 Multivariate Statistical Techniques
description: Multivariate statistical procedures in the analysis of behavioral inquiries; particular emphasis on multivariate analysis of variance.

title: EDPT 576 Technology in Contemporary Education and Training
description: Development and scope of instructional technology and its role in modern educational and training systems; overview of instructional development; innovation and trends in the field.

title: EDPT 570 Language and Cultural Diversity in Learning
description: Analysis of current research and theory regarding the influences of language and culture on learning and cognition, with a special focus on academic achievement and instructional transactions.

title: EDPT 642 Measurement Theory
description: Mathematical concepts and psychometric theory underlying test construction and interpretation; emphasis on current research in the area.

title: EDPT 540 Introduction to Educational Measurement and Evaluation
description: Survey of theories, concepts, and procedures for assessing intellective and non-intellective characteristics and for evaluating individual and program performances.

title: EDPT 550 Statistical Inference
description: Application of statistical techniques in education; emphasis on underlying principles and concepts coupled with selected inferential techniques using desk-top computer software.

title: EDPT 502 Learning and Individual Differences
description: Theory and research in learning, development, and individual differences, and social psychology related to education or training contexts.

title: EDPA 612 Qualitative Methods in Educational Research
description: Overview of the assumptions, methods and techniques of qualitative educational research; discussion and application of analytical tools derived from anthropology, sociology, history, and related social sciences.

title: EDPA 308 Politics and American Education
description: Historical study of political, legislative, judicial decisions that have shaped American education; interaction of educators, courts, legislative bodies; emphasis on in-depth analysis of current issues.

title: EDPT 310 Parental Influences on Children's Educational Development
description: Basic principles and theories of child development and learning with emphasis on parent-child, parent-school, and child-school relationships.

title: EDHP 657 Management of Student Services in Higher Education
description: Delivery of student services and programs in higher education, organizational behavior, management systems, administrative procedures, and alternative leadership styles.

title: EDHP 687 Student Development in Higher Education
description: Theories of college student development and application of developmental models to program design, interventions, outreach, and research programs.

title: EDHP 679 Legal Issues in the Administration of Higher Education
description: Analysis of legal issues related to the administration of higher education; emphasis on relations with students, faculty, staff, alumni, and campus communities.

title: EDHP 594z Master's Thesis
description: Required for all master's candidates who do not enroll in the Master's Seminar (

title: EDHP 594b Master's Thesis
description: Required for all master's candidates who do not enroll in the Master's Seminar (

title: EDHP 593a Master's Seminar
description: An examination and analysis of research and literature in the student's area of focus. Required for all master's candidates who do not enroll in the Master's Thesis (

title: EDHP 587 Fieldwork in Higher, Adult, and Professional Education
description: Structured participation in supervised teaching or administrative activities. Assignments matched with student's goals, training, experience.

title: EDHP 594a Master's Thesis
description: Required for all master's candidates who do not enroll in the Master's Seminar (

title: EDHP 565 Intervention Strategies in College Student Development
description: Exploration of current campus issues such as violence, diversity and academic remediation, and their related intervention strategies (policy-based, programmatic, and counseling-based).

title: EDHP 593b Master's Seminar
description: An examination and analysis of research and literature in the student's area of focus. Required for all master's candidates who do not enroll in the Master's Thesis (

title: EDHP 580 The Community College
description: The community college movement; history; aims; curriculum; types of administrative organization; teaching procedures; relation to lower and higher institutions; profiles of faculty and students; evaluation.

title: EDHP 563 Student Affairs Work in College
description: Principles, services, and organizational patterns of student affairs programs and services for two-year, four-year and professional higher education institutions.

title: EDHP 552 The Politics of Difference
description: Explores strategies for restructuring institutions of higher education to improve student support and achievement among historically marginalized groups.

title: EDHP 551 Applied Educational Ethnography
description: Research for improving leadership in higher, adult, and professional education. Ethnographically motivated field designs, observations, focused and unstructured interviews and unobtrusive techniques.

title: EDHP 502 Administration of Higher, Adult, and Professional Education
description: Policies and theories for governance and management. Relations between historical and contemporary organizational processes in postsecondary education. Critique and applications of current research.

title: EDHP 503 Curriculum, Teaching, and Learning in Higher, Adult, and Professional Education
description: Curriculum, teaching, and learning strategies for general, vocational, and professional education; planning for lifelong learning; theories, policies, and practices for higher, adult, and professional education.

title: EDCO 575 School Counseling Field Experience
description: Supervised field experience in applying knowledge and skills within a K–12 school setting.

title: EDHP 500 Foundations of Higher, Adult, and Professional Education
description: Contemporary issues in higher, adult, and professional education in the United States; analytic perspectives from various disciplines (history, philosophy, sociology); implications for policy and practice.

title: EDCO 541 Theories in Counseling
description: Theory, research, and practice of psychological counseling.

title: EDCO 574 School Counseling Practicum
description: Supervised practice in school counseling.

title: EDCO 506 Development, Administration and Evaluation of Pupil Personnel Services
description: Develop skills in the evaluation and management of pupil personnel services programs in the public schools for comprehensive support of student learning and achievement.

title: EDCO 030x The Process of Paraprofessional Counseling for Young Adults
description: Explores the theoretical processes involved in paraprofessional counseling with specific application to issues faced by young adults.

title: EDCO 504 Behavior Management in the Classroom
description: Analysis of student behavior in school settings. Emphasis is on a problem-solving functional approach to behavioral changes.

title: EDCO 503 Ethical and Legal Issues in Counseling
description: Examination of current legal, ethical, and other professional issues in the practice of counseling and psychotherapy.

title: EDCO 505 Counseling and Collaborative Consultation in the School Setting
description: Theory and practice of collaborative consultations provided by school counselors and school psychologists to improve student achievement and the learning environment.

title: ECON 794z Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: EDCO 324m Asian American Psychology
description: Psychological issues of Asian Americans such as cultural identity, intergenerational conflict, stereotypes, interracial dating and marriage, educational achievement, and mental health.

title: ECON 794d Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: ECON 794c Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: ECON 794b Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: ECON 790 Research
description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

title: ECON 794a Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: ECON 696 Empirical Microeconomics Seminar
description: Presentations on current research in empirical microeconomics by outstanding scholars from leading economics departments and faculty at USC.

title: ECON 715 Advanced Topics in Econometrics
description: Time-series methods; aggregation; structural models and methods such as factor analysis and multiple indicator models; various special topics.

title: ECON 694 Seminar in Dynamic Economics
description: Topics in dynamic economics involving business fluctuations, economic growth and development, micro-economic adjustments and market mechanisms; related quantitative and qualitative methods; empirical research involving economic change.

title: ECON 693 Seminar in Applied Economics and Public Policy
description: Current research in applied microeconomics, macroeconomics and public policy presented by faculty, students and outside scholars.

title: ECON 695 Internship in Mathematical Finance
description: Internship for students in the Mathematical Finance master's program. Practical training in real market environments. Real-world first-hand experience in implementing trading strategies. Application of mathematical finance to real financial markets.

title: ECON 692 Seminar in Economic Development
description: Current research in international, regional, and urban development economics presented by faculty, students and outside scholars.

title: ECON 690 Seminar in Economic Theory
description: Current research in economic theory presented by faculty, students and outside scholars.

title: ECON 691 Seminar in Econometrics
description: Current research in econometrics presented by faculty, students and outside scholars.

title: ECON 687 Urban Economics
description: Economic models will be used to understand the main facts observed in cities in the developed and developing world. Special attention will be paid to empirical hypothesis testing and developing an urban economics research agenda. Students will be exposed to new data sets being collected using Smart Phones and other novel technologies that have greatly expanded our ability to test relevant hypotheses.

title: ECON 681 Economics of Regulated Industries
description: Theories and methods of government regulation; effects of regulation on various industries; behavior of regulatory agencies.

title: ECON 688 Empirical Industrial Organization
description: Econometric analysis of industrial organization issues including industry regulation and deregulation, collusions and pricing in differentiated oligopolistic markets, entry and exit, auction mechanisms, contractual relationships.

title: ECON 680 Industrial Organization
description: Decision making, economic behavior and organization in firms; types of competition and market structure; property rights, nonprofit decision making.

title: ECON 671 Economics of Labor and Human Capital
description: A human capital interpretation of labor demand and supply; wage determination, differentials, and discrimination; job turnover and occupational mobility; unions and collective bargaining.

title: ECON 673 Program Evaluation
description: This course first proposes various means of evaluating an economic program. It then applies the tools to specific problems.

title: ECON 663 Financial and Monetary Macroeconomics
description: Macroeconomic models of financing and nominal rigidities. Focuses on the ways through which the financial system or financing constraints can affect macroeconomic fluctuations.

title: ECON 659 Economics of Financial Markets I
description: Equilibrium model of finance economy; absence of arbitrage; complete and incomplete markets; asset pricing theory; representative agent pricing. Capital Asset Pricing Model, martingale property of security prices.

title: ECON 652 Economics of Financial Markets II
description: Financial market equilibrium and partial equilibrium asset pricing in discrete and continuous time; properties of equilibria with and without complete markets; theory of option prices; Black-Scholes pricing formula; term structure of interest rates; hedging strategies and managing market risk using options, futures and swaps; hedging exchange-rates risks.

title: ECON 653 Empirical International Economics
description: Empirical treatment of advanced topics in international finance including the determination of real and nominal exchange rates; stabilization policies in developing currencies and currency crisis models. Econometric methods in analyzing foreign exchange data and in forecasting.

title: ECON 650 International Trade Theory
description: General equilibrium theory applied to theory and practice of commercial policy, economic growth, and trade.

title: ECON 651 International Monetary Theory
description: Balance of payments concepts and measures; price theory and the foreign exchange market; international monetary systems; adjustment mechanisms; speculation and official intervention.

title: ECON 645 Economic Growth
description: Surveys theoretical and empirical developments in growth macroeconomics. To equip students to undertake frontier research and policy work to reduce global income inequality.

title: ECON 644 Economic Development Programming and Policy Planning
description: Model construction and application to policy and planning: open economy macroeconomics, trade and investment, institutions, technology, income inequality, environment, policy reforms, political economy.

title: ECON 641 Empirical Analysis of Economic Development
description: Theory and empirics of the sources of and barriers to economic development and the micro underpinnings of macroeconomic dynamics of growth, inequality, and productivity.

title: ECON 642 Poverty, Human Resources and Economic Development
description: Household production models and intra-household models of behavior and their empirical implementation, focus on poverty, human resource investments and their interaction with public policies.

title: ECON 634 Political Economy of Institutions
description: The functions of laws, rules, customs, conventions, and other restrictions on economic and social activity. Theories of institutional evolution.

title: ECON 639 Contemporary Economic Policy: Theory and Practice
description: History and analysis of the fundamental continuing policy issues: recession, inflation, public debt, regulation, international competition, energy resources and environmental issues, welfare and income distribution.

title: ECON 620bL Experimental Methods
description: Experimental methods relying on non-choice data. Design methods of experiments that record information in decision-making and physiological data of emotions.

title: ECON 620aL Experimental Methods
description: Experimental methods of and design of computer-based experiments. Use of standard software for data collection in individual decision-making experiments and games.

title: ECON 625 Economic Analysis of Social Networks
description: Mathematical tools for the study of social and economic networks.

title: ECON 616 Experimental Economics
description: Laboratory methods for testing economic theory; experimental comparison of alternative market and non-market institutions; identification of behavioral responses to alternative regulations.

title: ECON 613 Economic and Financial Time Series I
description: Simultaneous equation models, dynamic structural econometric models, vector autoregressions, causality, forecasting, univariate and multivariate nonstationary time series, tests for unit roots, cointegration, autoregressive conditional heteroscedasticity models, time series models with changes in regime.

title: ECON 615 Applied Econometrics
description: Use of quantitative models to describe and forecast economic activity; estimation and application of such models to selected policy problems.

title: ECON 614 Economic and Financial Time Series II
description: Stock returns, predictability and volatility, random walk and variance-bounds tests, estimation of capital asset, multifactor, and derivative pricing models, term structure of interest rates.

title: ECON 612 Econometric Theory
description: Inference and prediction, generalized and restricted least squares, specification analysis, multivariate and seemingly unrelated regressions, simultaneous equations techniques, dynamic models, instrumental variable estimation.

title: ECON 611 Probability and Statistics for Economists
description: Introduction to probability theory and statistical inference to prepare students for graduate courses in econometrics and economic theory; probability, random variables, distributions, estimation, testing, asymptotics.

title: ECON 610 Quantitative Analysis in Macroeconomics
description: Dynamic economics, applied general equilibrium models, computational and calibration tools, discrete-state dynamic programming, log-linearization of Euler equations.

title: ECON 608 Advanced Neuroeconomics
description: Advanced methodology of neuroeconomics including neural activity, memory, value and reward systems, emotions, and risk.

title: ECON 609 Econometric Methods
description: Review of statistical methods of estimation and inference, linear regression with multicollinearity and serial correlation; multivariate regression and simultaneous equations.

title: ECON 607 Topics in Dynamic Optimization
description: Theory and numerical methods for dynamic optimization and control; selected applications in economic analysis and econometrics.

title: ECON 606 Behavioral Theories of Decision-Making
description: Examination of behavioral theories used to describe and predict choices made in both an individual decision-making setting and strategic environments.

title: ECON 604 Game Theory
description: Strategies and equilibrium concepts; dynamic and repeated games; incomplete information and learning in games.

title: ECON 605 Macroeconomic Theory II
description: Macroeconomic theory based on the concepts of optimal growth and intertemporal equilibrium; overlapping generations models; recent developments in macroeconomic theory.

title: ECON 603 Microeconomic Theory II
description: General equilibrium theory; existence, uniqueness, and stability; welfare economics; social choice; dynamic models and uncertainty; special topics.

title: ECON 601 Microeconomic Theory I
description: Optimization of the consumer and the firm; duality and imputed value; perfect and imperfect competition in product and factor markets.

title: ECON 602 Macroeconomic Theory I
description: Aggregate demand, supply and government policy; theories of economic growth and business cycles; static and dynamic implications of government policies.

title: ECON 596 Internship for Curricular Practical Training
description: Part-time or full-time, practical work experience in the student's field of study. The internship must be located at an off-campus facility. Students are individually supervised by faculty. May not be taken until the student has completed at least one semester of enrollment in the graduate program with a cumulative 3.0 GPA.

title: ECON 600 Economics of Choice
description: Reviews the normative and positive theories of choice drawing upon recent theoretical and empirical work in cognitive and evolutionary psychology, artificial intelligence, linguistics and economics.

title: ECON 599 Special Topics
description: Selected topics in economics as developed by the instructor.

title: ECON 595 Research Seminar in Spatial Economics and Data Sciences
description: Original spatial analysis research; integrate economics, data creation, and spatial analytics.

title: EALC 580 Readings in East Asian Linguistics
description: Survey of some representative works in generative grammar since the mid '60s, including those that deal with similar phenomena in the contexts of more recent theoretical frameworks as well as non-generative grammatical works on Chinese, Japanese, and Korean.

title: EALC 588a Directed Readings
description: Assigned readings according to individual needs.

title: EALC 575 Literary and Artistic Movements in Modern China
description: Introduction to literary and artistic movements in 20th century China. Open to graduate students only.

title: EALC 570 Narratives of Desire in Modern Chinese Literature
description: The study of prominent fiction women writers from the first half of the 20th century in English and original translations. Open to graduate students only.

title: EALC 565 Bibliography and Research Methods in Chinese Studies
description: An introduction to reference works and research methods in all fields on sinology; works in Chinese, Japanese and Western languages.

title: EALC 562 Teaching of the East Asian Languages
description: Materials and methods in teaching East Asian languages; application of methods and techniques of foreign/second language teaching to East Asian language teaching.

title: EALC 558 History of the Chinese Language
description: Evolution of the Chinese language from the earliest time to the present: lectures and the reading of texts. Conducted in English.

title: EALC 560 Comparative Syntax of East Asian Languages
description: Descriptive-comparative study of the Chinese, Japanese and Korean languages with an emphasis on their structures, range of properties, similarities and dissimilarities.

title: EALC 555 Chinese Literary Criticism and Theory
description: Classical and modern literary theories and criticism; comparisons with literary theory and criticism in the West.

title: EALC 553 Seminar: Chinese Literature
description: Research in different genres of Chinese literature, traditional and modern.

title: EALC 551 Seminar: China
description: Individual research and seminar reports on selected phases of Chinese traditional civilization.

title: EALC 541 Seminar: Japan
description: Social, economic, political, and cultural problems in modern Japan. Bibliographic and reference materials.

title: EALC 535 Proseminar in Chinese Visual Culture
description: Chinese visual culture through the complex interface of art and thought. Examines architectural layout, pictorial representation, decorative motif as part of cultural production that intertwines with intellectual trends.

title: EALC 547 Structure of the Japanese Language
description: Descriptive analysis of phonetic, phonological, and grammatical structure of Japanese. Conducted in English.

title: EALC 534 Modernity and Cultural Representation in Korea
description: In-depth introduction to the cultural history, including emerging trends and new methodologies within modern Korean literary and cultural studies.

title: EALC 537 Structure of the Korean Language
description: Description and theoretical analysis of phonology, morphology and syntax of modern Korean; comprehensive view of the properties of the Korean structure.

title: EALC 543 Seminar: Japanese Literature
description: Readings in original texts in the works of selected major writers; lectures dealing with intellectual and cultural backgrounds of the periods and the authors.

title: EALC 545 Japanese Literary Criticism and Theory
description: Representative theories of literature; history of classical and modern literary criticism.

title: EALC 533 Proseminar in Japanese Cultural History
description: Intensive readings, chronologically arranged, in interpretive issues in the study of Japanese cultural history. Readings in English.

title: EALC 532 Proseminar in Korean Cultural History
description: Introduction to Korean cultural and social history through intensive reading of the English-language literature on Korean history and culture.

title: EALC 531 Proseminar in Chinese Cultural History
description: Intensive readings in English concerning interpretive issues in the study of Chinese cultural history.

title: EALC 530 Race, Ethnicity, and Multiculturalism in East Asia
description: Examination of scholarship and cultural production on issues and theories of race, ethnicity, and multiculturalism in East Asia (China, Japan, Korea, and Southeast Asia).

title: EALC 515 Classical Japanese Poetics
description: An analysis of major texts of the Japanese literary tradition from the 8th to the 16th century.

title: EALC 522 Classical Japanese Writers
description: Writings representative of important periods and genres of Japanese literary history up to the Meiji Restoration.

title: EALC 510 Contemporary Japanese Cinema
description: Japanese cinema since the 1980s focusing on the works by filmmakers.

title: EALC 520 Modern Japanese Writers
description: Selections illustrative of major literary trends and literary works since the Meiji Restoration.

title: EALC 512 Japanese Literature and Film
description: Relationship between Japanese literature and film, focusing on the transition from literary text to film text. Open to graduate students only.

title: EALC 509 Transnational Korean Cinema
description: Korean cinema since the early 20th century, focusing on transnational production, circulation, and consumption. Open to graduate students only.

title: EALC 507 East Asia in Cross-Cultural Theories
description: Introduction to major theoretical paradigms particularly relevant to the study of East Asian cultures. Seminal Western theoretical texts with studies on East Asia.

title: EALC 503 Chinese Poetry
description: Literary studies of the theory and practice of Chinese poetry from major poets.

title: EALC 506 Selections from Classical Chinese Literature
description: Writings of the important periods and genres of Chinese literary history.

title: EALC 505 Introduction to East Asian Languages and Cultures
description: An in-depth introduction to East Asian studies. Open to graduate students only.

title: EALC 504 Selections from Modern Chinese Literature
description: Literary currents and representative writings of the 20th century.

title: EALC 501 History of Chinese Literature
description: An in-depth survey of literary development concerning periods, thought, genres, and socio-cultural backgrounds in China. In English.

title: EALC 500 Advanced Classical Chinese I
description: Reading in classical Chinese and practice in classical vocabulary and syntax, with emphasis on translation into English and modern Chinese.

title: EALC 499 Special Topics
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: EALC 502 Advanced Classical Chinese II
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: EALC 494b Honors Thesis
description: Research and writing of original thesis under guidance of faculty member. Open only to EALC majors.

title: EALC 490x Directed Research
description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

title: EALC 489 The Mongol Era in China: Genghis Khan, Khubilai, Marco Polo
description: An exploration of the Mongol era in China through an examination of three great historical figures, including how depictions of them have changed over time.

title: EALC 494a Honors Thesis
description: Research and writing of original thesis under guidance of faculty member.

title: EALC 480 Marxism and Culture in East Asia
description: Intensive reading on current transnational issues in the study of East Asian or Asian cultures.

title: EALC 465 Topics in Korean Visual and Cultural Studies
description: Examination of dominant and emergent critical issues in the study of modern and contemporary Korean visual culture.

title: EALC 455 Japanese Fiction
description: Japanese fiction from early to modern times; literary, philosophical, and social aspects of tales and novels. Conducted in English.

title: EALC 452 Chinese Fiction
description: Development of Chinese fiction and readings from English translations of major Chinese novels such as the Dream of the Red Chamber, All Men are Brothers, and others. Conducted in English.

title: EALC 450 Contemporary Japanese Literature and Global Modernity
description: Examination of historical currents in contemporary Japanese literature and popular culture and the role translation plays in their global circulation and redefinition.

title: EALC 470 Introduction to East Asian Linguistics
description: Survey of the sound systems, writing systems, grammatical systems, historical development, and social environments of the Chinese, Japanese, and Korean languages.

title: EALC 438 The Tale of Genji and its Worlds
description: Explores the translation, history, and reception of The Tale of Genji, including its adaptation across multiple media and genres from premodern times to the present.

title: EALC 440 Current Topics in Japanese
description: Mastery of near native proficiency of the Japanese Language by handling variety topics of contemporary Japan such as literature, history, social and cultural issues.

title: EALC 428 Nature and the Ecological Imagination in Japanese Literature
description: Examination of cultural perceptions about nature and how they affect attitudes toward the environment: includes comparisons to Euro-American as well as other East Asian traditions.

title: EALC 427 Women's Lives in Premodern Japanese Literature
description: The social lives of women in ancient and medieval Japan as viewed through poetry, memoir, tale literature, legal documents, and personal correspondence.

title: EALC 429 Gender in Korean Film and Literature
description: Changing representations of gender in Korean films and literary works over the course of the 20th century.

title: EALC 426 Classical Japanese
description: Introduction to the fundamentals of classical grammar; readings from various classical works, both poetry and prose; translation practice.

title: EALC 422 Advanced Japanese III
description: Students develop advanced levels of Japanese linguistic knowledge and communication skills through speaking, listening, reading and writing activities using authentic Japanese texts and discourse.

title: EALC 419 Newspaper and Documentary Korean
description: Selected readings from newspapers, magazines, and other journalistic publications; analysis of styles and practice in writing articles.

title: EALC 424 Advanced Japanese IV
description: . Students continue to improve their Japanese language competence in the course of acquiring Japanese pragmatic skills and cultural knowledge.

title: EALC 418 Korean Writing in Mixed Script
description: Selected readings in Korean texts written in mixed script; a systematic study of Chinese characters and translation of text.

title: EALC 484 Studies in Chinese Art
description: In-depth exploration of specified topics within the area of Chinese art and architecture.

title: EALC 417 Advanced Korean IV
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: EALC 482 Japanese Photography
description: Surveys the evolution of Japanese photography from 1850 to 21st century and examines how photography has helped define Japan's national and cultural identity.

title: EALC 416 Advanced Chinese Oral Communication
description: Enhancement of advanced conversational skills through descriptions, summaries of texts, active participation in discussions, debates and oral presentations in class.

title: EALC 481 Studies in Japanese Art
description: In-depth exploration of specified topics within the area of Japanese art and architecture.

title: EALC 415 Advanced Korean III
description: Selected readings in Korean texts, pre- modern and modern, in various literary and non-fiction genres; focus on developing reading and translation skills.

title: EALC 413 Business Japanese
description: Practical advanced level Japanese business terms and their usage in a variety of business situations; cultural insights on Japanese customs that underlie business transactions.

title: EALC 412b Business Chinese
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: EALC 410 Chinese-English Translation
description: Structure, vocabulary, and techniques of written translation and oral interpretation; classroom and laboratory practice; English-Chinese and Chinese-English.

title: EALC 407 News and Web Chinese
description: Reading selections from newspaper articles and online reports to further develop proficiency in advanced Chinese and understanding of the society and culture.

title: EALC 406 Advanced Modern Chinese IV
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: EALC 412a Business Chinese
description: Practice in the basic vocabulary and idioms of foreign trade and other commercial transactions in Mandarin.

title: EALC 404 Advanced Modern Chinese III
description: Readings in modern Chinese literary, documentary, and epistolary styles; stylistic and syntactic analysis; composition; translation.

title: EALC 402 Classical Chinese II
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: EALC 390 Special Problems
description: Supervised, individual studies. No more than one registration permitted. Enrollment by petition only.

title: EALC 400 Classical Chinese I
description: Introduction to the classical styles, selections from classical style writings, contrastive analysis of modern and classical Chinese, translation and writing practice.

title: EALC 385 Myth, Folklore, and Fantasy in Japanese Literature and Film
description: Examines the uses of myth, folklore, and fantasy in Japanese culture across a range of genres and media from the premodern period to contemporary times.

title: EALC 386 Readings in Modern Korean Literature
description: Selected readings from modern Korean short stories, novels, plays and essays. Readings will be in English and Korean.

title: EALC 382 Art and Cultural Heritage in East Asia
description: Introduction to heritage studies with a focus on the developments and representative examples in China, Korea, and Japan.

title: EALC 380 Cultural Topics in East Asian Literature
description: Selected themes, genres, and periods in East Asian literature, e.g., Taoism and Buddhism, women, folktales.

title: EALC 366 Chinese Professional Internship: Communication and Culture
description: Combined classroom discussion and supervised internship at companies. Practical experience in applying communication and cultural knowledge in a professional, "real world" employment context.

title: EALC 360g Performing Japan: Bodies, Media, and Textuality
description: The classical foundations of Japanese performance, including noh, puppet theater, and kabuki; exploration of how these genres are implicated in modern and contemporary Japanese performance.

title: EALC 358g Transnational Chinese Literature and Culture
description: An introduction to Sinophone literatures and cultures (in English translation) from the Asia-Pacific region, including Taiwan, Hong Kong, Tibet, Southeast Asia, and North America.

title: EALC 365 Studies in Japanese Thought
description: Influence of native traditions and imported Chinese traditions on Japanese civilization; religious, ethical, aesthetic, and political aspects.

title: EALC 354g Modern Chinese Literature in Translation
description: Satisfies Old General Education in Category II: Global Cultures and Traditions

title: EALC 355 Studies in Chinese Thought
description: Chinese thought, particularly as formulated in the three great traditions: Confucianism, Taoism, Buddhism.

title: EALC 352g Chinese Literature and Culture
description: Readings of Chinese poetry, prose, novels and drama; influence of the West on Chinese literature and culture in modern times. Conducted in English.

title: EALC 388 Later Japanese Art
description: A survey of Japanese architecture, garden design, ceramics, and painting from 1333 to the present, stressing the role of art within cultural context.

title: EALC 387 Early Japanese Art
description: A survey of Japanese Buddhist and secular architecture, sculpture and painting from antiquity to 1333, stressing the relation of art to cultural context.

title: DANC 184a Jazz Dance
description: An introduction to Jazz Dance technique, focusing on African and Latin based diaspora dances with European influences, improvisation, and strength/stretching series.

title: EALC 384 Early Chinese Art
description: A survey of Chinese architecture, ceremonial bronzes, sculpture, ceramics and painting from antiquity through the T'ang Dynasty.

title: DANC 183d Ballet
description: Elementary to intermediate-level pointe technique for women and men, including strengthening exercises, barre and center work, and variations from classical and contemporary ballets.

title: DANC 184b Jazz Dance
description: Continued study of Jazz Dance technique at the intermediate level, focusing on African and Latin based diaspora dances with European influences, improvisation, center work, performance techniques, and strength/stretching series.

title: DANC 183b Ballet
description: Continued study of Classical Ballet technique with intermediate-level barre and center work, focusing on developing greater clarity, coordination, musicality, and knowledge of ballet history and terminology.

title: EALC 383 Later Chinese Art
description: A survey of Chinese painting from 900 to the present, emphasizing the role of painting within the context of Chinese intellectual history.

title: EALC 381g Visual Cultures of Asia
description: Exploration of one or more major traditions of visual culture in Asia through cross-cultural, interdisciplinary perspectives.

title: DANC 183c Ballet
description: Advanced study of Classical Ballet technique with emphasis on clarity, precision, musicality, movement quality, and artistic expression. Introduction of beats, tours, advanced adagio and allegro combinations, and pointe work.

title: DANC 183a Ballet
description: An introduction to Classical Ballet technique with beginning-level barre and center work, focusing on correct body alignment and musicality. Development of a basic knowledge of ballet history and terminology.

title: DANC 181b Contemporary Dance
description: Continued study in the fusion of modern, post-modern dance and classical ballet techniques encompassing the study of the democratic nature of dance and choreographic composition in the 20th and 21st centuries.

title: DANC 181c Contemporary Dance
description: An advanced exploration of modern, post-modern dance and classical ballet techniques encompassing the study of the democratic nature of dance, improvisation and choreographic composition in the 20th and 21st centuries.

title: DANC 175 Choreography for the Screen
description: Creative choreography of theatrical dance for the screen. Emphasis on rhythmic analysis, versatility, composition, notation techniques, and stylizing.

title: DANC 181a Contemporary Dance
description: An introduction to methods developed from modern and post-modern dance techniques, including the study of the rebellious, individualistic, and democratic nature of dance in the 20th and 21st centuries.

title: DANC 171 Commercial Dance: Professional Dance Preparation
description: Designed to explore the commercial dance industry in Los Angeles and provide specific tools in preparation for auditions, on-screen performances, and interactions with agents.

title: DANC 130 Improvisation and Composition I: Introduction
description: An introduction to improvisational and composition skills that start to prepare students for the creative processes of dancing, dancemaking and performance.

title: DANC 131 Improvisation and Composition II: Introduction
description: Continued investigation and introduction to improvisational and compositional skills in preparation for the creative processes of dancing, dance-making and performance.

title: DANC 170 Choreography and Performance
description: Compositional methods and approaches to developing choreographic ideas; integration of improvisational techniques as a means to generate movement ideas and expand movement vocabulary, edit choreographic material, and evaluate and execute choreography and performance.

title: DANC 110 Dance Technique I
description: Fundamental technique studies in a studio setting. Concentration on classical ballet, hip hop and its derivatives, partnering and contemporary techniques essential to the dancers' development. Placement audition required.

title: DANC 120L Repertory and Performance I
description: Study and guided practice of traditional and contemporary choreographic repertory. Emphasis in choreographic intention, stylistic approaches and performance technique.

title: DANC 107 World Perspective on Dance Performance
description: The practice and aesthetics of international dance styles through lecture and participant-driven interaction.

title: DANC 103 Conditioning for Dancers
description: Designed for the specific needs of the dancer in preparation for professional training, combining somatic work with the foundation of scientific principles.

title: DANC 105 Dance Science: Analysis of Dance Movement
description: A broad overview of the scientific principles of exercise physiology, functional anatomy, kinesiology, and bio-mechanics with applications to dance.

title: DANC 101 Colloquium: What is the Medium of Dance Today?
description: Topics related to dance techniques, repertory and varied art forms. Aimed at the interdisciplinary expansion of dance literacy and connections to allied art forms.

title: CXPT 794z Doctoral Dissertation
description: Independent research course for students enrolled in the CXPT PhD program who have passed their written and oral qualifying examination and advanced to PhD candidacy.

title: CXPT 794d Doctoral Dissertation
description: Independent research course for students enrolled in the CXPT PhD program who have passed their written and oral qualifying examination and advanced to PhD candidacy.

title: CXPT 794c Doctoral Dissertation
description: Independent research course for students enrolled in the CXPT PhD program who have passed their written and oral qualifying examination and advanced to PhD candidacy.

title: CXPT 794b Doctoral Dissertation
description: Independent research course for students enrolled in the CXPT PhD program who have passed their written and oral qualifying examination and advanced to PhD candidacy.

title: CXPT 794a Doctoral Dissertation
description: Independent research course for students enrolled in the CXPT PhD program who have passed their written and oral qualifying examination and advanced to PhD candidacy.

title: CXPT 610 Experimental and Clinical Drug Metabolism and Transport
description: Focus on the absorption, distribution, metabolism and elimination (ADME) of new chemical entities, with  particular focus on biotransformation process.

title: CXPT 790 Research
description: Research-based course for students enrolled in the CXPT PhD program who are preparing for their written and oral qualifying examination.

title: CXPT 596 Internship for Curricular Practical Training
description: Part-time or full-time, practical work experience in the student's field of study. The internship must be located at an off-campus facility. Students are individually supervised by faculty. May not be taken until the student has completed at least one semester of enrollment in the graduate program with a cumulative 3.0 GPA.

title: CXPT 609 Preclinical Experimental Drug Therapeutic Development
description: Evolution of a chemical entity as it is transformed into a drug candidate. Open only to students in clinical and experimental therapeutics and management of drug development.

title: CXPT 594z Master's Thesis
description: Grading Option: In Progress/Credit/No Credit

title: CXPT 594b Master's Thesis
description: Grading Option: In Progress/Credit/No Credit

title: CXPT 594a Master's Thesis
description: Completion of all required course work for MS degree

title: CXPT 590 Directed Research
description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

title: CTWR 599 Special Topics
description: Detailed investigation of new or emerging aspects of cinema; special subjects offered by visiting faculty; experimental subjects.

title: CTWR 572 Practicum in Directing Actors for Film
description: Seminar in directing actors for film; emphasis on demonstration and laboratory exercises, script analysis, and detailed study in character motivations.

title: CTWR 585 Advanced Genre Writing
description: Development and execution of writing in various genres of film, television, or new media scripts.

title: CTWR 559 The Business of Writing for Screen and Television
description: Examination and in-depth analysis of the studio system, the television development process, literary representation, new emerging markets, and the Writers Guild of America.

title: CTWR 560 Advanced Business Practices for Writers
description: Advanced seminar and analysis of the current state of the film and television markets as it relates to writers. Weekly industry guests and current trends.

title: CTWR 549 Advanced Rewriting Workshop in Hour-Long Drama
description: Advanced television writing, emphasizing the rewrite of a first draft pilot script and series bible for an hour-long television series.

title: CTWR 587 Advanced Television Staff Writing
description: An advanced workshop course in the development and writing of a television series as a writing staff including the production of episodes.

title: CTWR 574 Advanced Seminar in Directing Actors for Film
description: Emphasis on detailed script analysis and character motivation. Individual projects.

title: CTWR 557 Seminar in the Business of Writing and Producing Television
description: Examination of the role of the television writer in production through lectures, readings, and practical experiences on set.

title: CTWR 553 Advanced Rewriting Workshop
description: Advanced feature screenwriting, emphasizing the rewrite of a first draft script.

title: CTWR 550 Advanced Story Development
description: Advanced development of the story creation process by examining the core elements of a good story. Compiling a portfolio of story ideas.

title: CTWR 555 Pitching for Film and Television
description: Development and pitching of ideas for motion pictures, episodic and television pilots. Reducing ideas to basic components enhancing verbal presentation skills.

title: CTWR 543 The Character-Driven Screenplay
description: Advanced screenwriting wherein a first draft of a feature-length script will be developed and written with an emphasis on character as story engine.

title: CTWR 541 Dreams, the Brain, and Storytelling
description: Examination of the links between the brain, creativity, neuroscience and storytelling. Through lectures, screenings, and readings, students will log dreams for use in creative exercises.

title: CTWR 537 Advanced Half-Hour Comedy Series Pilot
description: Registration Restriction: Open only to master students in Theatre (Dramatic Writing) and Writing for Screen and Television.

title: CTWR 539 Advanced Hour-Long Drama Series Pilot
description: Registration Restriction: Open only to master students in Theatre (Dramatic Writing) and Writing for Screen and Television.

title: CTWR 534 Advanced Half-Hour Television Comedy
description: Advanced workshop in writing the first draft and revision of an episode of an existing comedic television series. The comedy writing room will be emphasized.

title: CTWR 533b Writing the Feature Script
description: Advanced screenwriting workshop. Rewriting the first draft into a second draft through advanced work-shopping of script. A third draft polish is the final assignment.

title: CTWR 528 Screenwriting Fundamentals
description: Introduction to the principles of screenwriting with special emphasis on story, characterization and dramatization.

title: CTWR 533a Writing the Feature Script
description: Advanced screenwriting workshop. Development of characters and story to complete a treatment and first draft of a feature length script.

title: CTWR 526 Advanced Storytelling for Interactive Media
description: Advanced writing workshop addressing issues specific to interactive storytelling regarding construction of narrative and character as seen in games and other forms of interactive media.

title: CTWR 529 Intermediate Screenwriting
description: Emphasizes structural elements crucial to the feature film. Techniques for creating an original and adapted theatrical-length script.

title: CTWR 521 Advanced Hour-Long Television Drama
description: Registration Restriction: Open only to master students in Theatre (Dramatic Writing) and in Writing for Screen and Television.

title: CTWR 522 Advanced Hour-Long Television Development
description: Investigation of development process for hour-long television, addressing issues of character, world, story, and concept. Vetting of multiple series ideas for viability.

title: CTWR 523 Introduction to the Screenplay
description: Introduction to formal elements of the screenplay through lectures and the workshopping of a complete first draft of a feature-length script.

title: CTWR 520 Advanced Scene Writing Workshop
description: Intensive workshop oriented specifically to writing and rewriting the most effective and telling dramatic scenes to heighten audience participation and greater story impact.

title: CTWR 519a Thesis in Television Drama
description: Part A — writing the pilot — is an intensive workshop in which master's students develop an original television 1-hour series including characters, world and storylines for season one. Final assignment is the finished pilot episode of the series.

title: CTWR 519b Thesis in Television Drama
description: Part A — Writing the series bible and mid-season episode — is part two of the television thesis course. Students develop their original series further by writing the bible for the series and the mid-season episode which is reflective of storylines, characters and settings developed in part A of the course. Open to Writing for Screen and Television master students only.

title: CTWR 518 Introduction to Interactive Writing
description: A series of exercises written and discussed for interactive experiences.

title: CTWR 516 Advanced Motion Picture Script Analysis
description: Critical analysis of the structure of films from the classics to current award winners. Students will learn how to identify key story concepts and break down three act structure in finished films and scripts.

title: CTWR 517a Thesis in Half-Hour Television Comedy
description: Developing an original half-hour comedy television series, including characters, world and storylines for season one. Completion of a first draft script, polish, and series bible.

title: CTWR 517b Thesis in Half-Hour Television Comedy
description: Developing an original half-hour comedy television series, including characters, world and storylines for season one. Completion of a first draft script, polish, and series bible. The re-write, casting, and performance stages of television comedy development. The completion of a final draft of the pilot script and series bible.

title: CTWR 514a Basic Dramatic Screenwriting
description: Dramaturgy for the fiction and nonfiction work. Techniques for creating the original or adapted theatrical script. Open to graduate screenwriting majors (CTWR) and dramatic writing (Theatre) majors only. Emphasizes narrative development, through short scripts, sequences, and story outlines.

title: CTWR 514b Basic Dramatic Screenwriting
description: Dramaturgy for the fiction and nonfiction work. Techniques for creating the original or adapted theatrical script. Open to graduate screenwriting majors (CTWR) and dramatic writing (Theatre) majors only. Development of an outline and feature length, original script.

title: CTWR 515d Practicum in Screenwriting
description: Supervised rewrite of feature screenplay.

title: CTWR 513 Writing the Short Script
description: Preparation of scripts for short films; dramatic, informational, experimental, and other forms.

title: CTWR 515c Practicum in Screenwriting
description: Grading Option: In-progress & Letter Grade

title: CTWR 515b Practicum in Screenwriting
description: Comprehensive rewriting of a second and third draft of a feature screenplay leading to a polished and professional piece.

title: CTWR 515a Practicum in Screenwriting
description: Creation of a feature screenplay from presentation through treatment, including some scene work.

title: CTWR 509 Understanding the Process of Film Making
description: An introduction for screenwriters to the process of creating a feature film, from script through release print, including pre-production, production and post-production.

title: CTWR 502 Graduate Writing Symposium
description: A survey of the creative and professional range of the working screenwriter.

title: CTWR 499 Special Topics
description: Detailed investigation of new or emerging aspects of cinema and/or television; special subjects offered by visiting faculty; experimental subjects.

title: CTWR 505 Creating the Short Film
description: Strengthening and deepening the ability to conceive and develop ideas that will lead to compelling, authentic, and personally meaningful films.

title: CTWR 497 Staff Writing the Single-Camera Half-Hour Series
description: Working on the writing staff for an original single-camera half-hour television series, with emphasis on the writers' room experience and challenges of single-camera half-hour television.

title: CTWR 477 Staff Writing the Sketch Comedy Show
description: Staff writing a sketch comedy show with emphasis on creating comedic characters, political humor, monologue writing, and joke construction. A live show will be produced.

title: CTWR 459b Entertainment Industry Seminar
description: Examination and analysis of various topics, issues and resources pertaining to creative, legal and business perspectives for writers in the entertainment industry.

title: CTWR 459a Entertainment Industry Seminar
description: Examination and analysis of various topics, issues and resources pertaining to creative, legal and business perspectives for writers in the entertainment industry.

title: CTWR 487 Staff Writing the Multi-Camera Television Series
description: Working on the writing staff of an original multi-camera television series, with emphasis on the writers' room experience and how to executive produce an episode.

title: CTWR 453 Advanced Feature Rewriting
description: An advanced workshop in which a feature length screenplay will be rewritten using a specific methodology that focuses on a macro to micro approach to revision.

title: CTWR 489 Straight to Series:  Writing and Producing the Episodic Drama
description: Staff writing and producing the original episodic drama, from development to post-production.

title: CTWR 468 Screenwriting in Collaboration
description: Writing an original screenplay or pilot collaboratively with a partner, with special attention paid to the writing team dynamic and the 'third' writer's voice.

title: CTWR 441 Writing Workshop in Creativity and Imagination
description: Students will explore a variety of problem solving techniques to strengthen their creative work and apply these techniques to individual writing projects.

title: CTWR 439 Writing the Original Dramatic Series Pilot
description: An advanced workshop in which students create an original dramatic series, including a first script and a summary of characters and storylines.

title: CTWR 437 Writing the Original Situation Comedy Pilot
description: Advanced workshop for writing an original half-hour comedy series, including a pilot script, summary of characters, and story lines for first season.

title: CTWR 449 Rewriting the Original Dramatic Series Pilot
description: An advanced workshop in which an original hour-long television pilot will be rewritten with emphasis on character, world creation and future story lines.

title: CTWR 435 Writing for Film and Television Genres
description: Preparation of proposals and scripts for different types of film or television programming: emphasis on conception, structure, characterization and format.

title: CTWR 432 Television Writers and Their Work
description: Detailed investigation of various television writers' styles, the worlds they have created, and the works they've influenced. Lectures include screenings and visiting television writers.

title: CTWR 431 Screenwriters and Their Work
description: Detailed investigation of a specific screenwriter's style and the works they've influenced. Lectures include screenings and visiting screenwriters.

title: CTWR 438 Linked Narrative Storytelling for the Web
description: Create, develop, and execute episodic video content for the web. Focus on content and characters that are viable in the internet landscape.

title: CTWR 434 Writing the Half-Hour Comedy Series
description: Writing an episode of an existing half-hour comedy series, with emphasis on the anatomy of a joke, comedic structure, and character.

title: CTWR 422 Creating the Dramatic Television Series
description: Examination and creation of the world, characters, and concept for an original hour-long dramatic series. Writing an outline for an original dramatic pilot.

title: CTWR 430 The Writer in American Cinema and Television
description: American and international writers in cinema; screenwriting; political and economic aspects of the writer in the motion picture industry. Lectures, guest speakers, screenings.

title: CTWR 433 Adaptations: Transferring Existing Work to the Screen
description: An examination of motion picture adaptations; problems attendant upon translating a novel, play, or other creative forms into screenplays.

title: ECON 594a Master's Thesis
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: ECON 594b Master's Thesis
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit
