title: CTWR 421 Writing the Hour-Long Dramatic Series
description: Writing an episode of an existing dramatic television series within the hour-long format with an emphasis on conception, pitching, characterization and structure.

title: ECON 590 Directed Research
description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

title: ECON 593x Practicum in Teaching the Liberal Arts
description: Practical principles for the long-term development of effective teaching within college disciplines. Intended for teaching assistants in Dornsife College.

title: ECON 580 Antitrust Economics and Competition Policy
description: Efficiency, market failure, government regulation, some basics for antitrust economics, competition policy analysis and collusion and agreements among competitors.

title: ECON 533 Capstone Research Seminar
description: Provides Masters students with a centerpiece of their graduate experience whereby they are able to experience first-hand turning the theory of their studies into practice under the guidance of an experienced faculty member.

title: ECON 537 Contracts, Organizations, and Institutions
description: Information, property rights, bargaining, transaction costs, incentives, free-riding and contracting in organizations; the nature of cooperation; bureaucracies.

title: ECON 541 Economic Development
description: Development, underdevelopment and the problems thereof; agriculture, industry, trade, population, human capital, capital formation; structural, technological, environmental and institutional changes; political economy of the state.

title: ECON 584 Economic Consulting and Applied Econometrics
description: Economic consulting and applied econometric methods applied to real world problems including issues of intellectual property, environmental damage, trademark infringement, brand value, and consumer demand.

title: ECON 538 Values and Social Analysis
description: Factors that make values an essential feature of human society; how values develop, change, and are abandoned; role of values in economic development.

title: ECON 570 Big Data Econometrics
description: Provides an introduction to the theory and practice of causal econometrics in modern settings of large-scale data.

title: ECON 527 Theory of Value: Classical Origins and Neoclassical Critique
description: Classical economic theory; its precursors, main contributors, extensions, and critics; focus upon the writings and ideas of Smith, Say, Malthus, Ricardo, Mill, and Marx.

title: ECON 523 Economic History and Development
description: Historical trends in developed and developing societies in various aspects of modernization such as human resources, capital, technology, resource allocation, income distribution, international relations.

title: ECON 515 Time Series Analysis
description: Understanding and implementing models commonly used in time series econometrics. Emphasis is placed on intuition and application. Assists students understanding how to use time series data to test hypotheses and serve as an introduction to the ideas and techniques of forecasting.

title: ECON 521 Open Economy Macroeconomics
description: The balance of payments, macroeconomic policy in an open economy, exchange rate determination, exchange rate systems, currency crises, international financial arrangements and monetary history.

title: ECON 513 Practice of Econometrics
description: Application of econometric tools using standard econometric software packages for microcomputers; empirical applications to selected economic problems of estimation and inference.

title: ECON 502 Mathematical Methods in Dynamic Economics
description: Movement of economic systems over time; differential and difference equations; introduction to the optimal control of economic processes; dynamic programming and optimal strategies; selected applications.

title: ECON 501 Macroeconomic Analysis and Policy
description: Theories of aggregate economic activity; design and use of macroeconometric models; stabilization and control of inflation, unemployment, and growth.

title: ECON 500 Microeconomic Analysis and Policy
description: Theories of the household and the firm; product and factor markets; perfect and imperfect competition; welfare criteria.

title: ECON 495 Honors Thesis
description: Individual research supervised by a faculty adviser. Successful completion required for departmental honors degree.

title: ECON 499 Special Topics
description: Selected topics in economic theory, history, or policy.

title: ECON 487 Resource and Environmental Economics
description: Management and extraction of renewable and non-renewable natural resources; environmental externalities and regulation of air, water, and land pollution; market incentives versus direct regulation.

title: ECON 490x Directed Research
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: ECON 504 Game Theory with Economic and Financial Applications
description: Students will cover large ground in applying game theory to economic and financial markets and interactions in a diverse set of examples like reputation, herding, bubbles and crashes, auctions, strategic information revelation and information accumulation in markets. We will witness the wide range of applications that is amenable to game theoretical analysis.

title: ECON 480 Economics of Industrial Organization
description: Pricing and resource allocation in imperfectly competitive markets; monopoly regulation, collusion, cartels, mergers and antitrust; patents and development incentives; industry case studies.

title: ECON 474 Economic Consulting and Applied Managerial Economics
description: Economic consulting and managerial economic methods applied in real world problems. Economic methods to analyze issues of intellectual property, environmental damage, trademark infringement, brand value, and consumer demand.

title: ECON 471 Economics of Labor Markets and Human Capital
description: A human capital interpretation of labor demand and supply; wage determination, differentials, and discrimination; job turnover and occupational mobility; unions and collective bargaining.

title: ECON 472 Economics of Medical Care
description: Health as an investment in human capital; analysis of the demand for and supply of health services and manpower; health insurance; cost-effectiveness analysis; market structures and the pricing of medical services.

title: ECON 452 International Finance
description: Consequences of trade deficits; theories of capital and currency markets, exchange rate regimes, and international monetary coordination.

title: ECON 457 Financial Markets
description: General equilibrium analysis of economies with financial markets; decision making under uncertainty; methods of risk reduction; portfolio theory and valuation of securities; efficiency of security markets.

title: ECON 450 International Trade
description: Determinants and economic consequences of international trade patterns; effects of trade restrictions and trading blocs; trade negotiations and arrangements.

title: ECON 434 Economic Analysis of Law
description: Common law and property; rationing of justice, resource allocation between prevention and enforcement; division of decision making between public and private sectors.

title: ECON 433 Empirical Economics Research
description: Analysis of economic variables; investigation of empirical economics to estimate or test for relationships using various forms of data.

title: ECON 420 Experimental Economics
description: Examination of economic theories and patterns of behavior useful in building new theories.

title: ECON 432 Economics of Happiness
description: What is happiness? How does it vary by socio-economic status and over the life cycle? This course will develop insight into the nature and determinants of subjective well-being.

title: ECON 415 Behavioral Economics
description: Examination of the traditional and behavioral theories of decision-making and the state of the art in the field.

title: ECON 405 Neuroeconomics
description: Introduction to the methodology used in experimental neuroeconomics and discussion of neural correlates of decision-making.

title: ECON 390 Special Problems
description: Supervised, individual studies. No more than one registration permitted. Enrollment by petition only.

title: ECON 404 Games and Economics
description: Analysis of strategic economic interactions. Topics include bargaining, insurance, patents, voting, environmental depletion, strategic trade, learning, reputation, strikes, corporate takeovers, and the provision of public goods.

title: ECON 401 Mathematical Methods in Economics
description: Introduction to quantitative methods for analyzing economic equilibria; comparative statics and dynamics. Utility theory, consumer behavior, and profit maximization. Model formulation in micro and macroeconomics.

title: ECON 369 Economics of European Integration
description: The challenges of policy coordination among independent political entities, starting from the aftermath of German unification (and the ramifications it had in a fixed exchange rate system) to the recent national debt crisis that followed the great recession.

title: ECON 395 Economic Policy Issues
description: Selected policy dilemmas, including welfare reform, urban renewal, government budget deficits, regulation and deregulation, environmental problems, immigration, and global development. Lectures by leading authorities and weekly discussion sessions.

title: ECON 419 Advanced Econometrics
description: Analysis of binary dependent variable models, panel data analysis, program evaluations, IV analysis, basics of time series and forecasting.

title: ECON 366 Urban Economics
description: Urban trends and problems, including changing urban form and function, urban public finance, housing, renewal, poverty, race, transportation, and the environment.

title: ECON 361 Understanding Financial Crises
description: Key facts and basic mechanisms concerning financial crises and related topics (bank runs, sovereign default decision, currency collapse).

title: ECON 360 Public Finance
description: Role of the government; income and corporate taxation; direct versus indirect taxation; optimal tax structure; public goods; public sector pricing; public debt and macroeconomic stability.

title: ECON 357 Money, Credit, and Banking
description: The money, bond, stock, and other financial markets; portfolio choice; determinants of asset prices and interest rates; inflation; interactions between financial markets and government policies.

title: ECON 350 The World Economy
description: International cooperation and conflict in the world economy. Global economic problems of growth and development, trade and finance, migration, economic stability, and the environment.

title: ECON 352x Macroeconomics for Business
description: Theoretical development and significance to business and markets of economic growth; inflation; unemployment; monetary and fiscal policy; business cycles; savings and investment; exchange rates.

title: ECON 348g Current Problems of the American Economy
description: A comprehensive investigation of problems stemming from changing composition of the work force, urban decline, new technologies, inequalities, ethnic relations, government deficits. Prospects for continued growth.

title: ECON 351x Microeconomics for Business
description: Development and business applications of: theory of the firm; theory of the consumer; intertemporal decisions; decisions under risk; market failures; industrial and enterprise structure. Not for major credit for: economics, economics/mathematics, social sciences (economics) majors.

title: ECON 346 Economics of Transition and Development: China
description: A focus on the Chinese economy, its reform and transition to a market economy, its relation with East Asian countries and integration into the world economy.

title: ECON 342 Economic Development of the Middle East
description: Contemporary economic problems of the Middle East: comparative and historical perspectives on issues of institutions, investment, oil, trade, migration, finance, inequality, labor and capital markets.

title: ECON 343 Economic Development of East Asia
description: Contemporary economic problems of East Asian countries: management, labor, technology, trade, investment. Determinants of their high growth rates in the late 20th century.

title: ECON 344 Economic Development of Sub-Saharan Africa
description: Contemporary economic problems of sub-Saharan African economies: policies and endowments. Focus on issues of poverty, agriculture, health, macroeconomy and political economy.

title: ECON 332 Contracts, Organizations and Institutions
description: Contract law and economic organization, determinants of firm boundaries, transaction cost economics, agency theory, incomplete contracting, business strategy, bureaucracy, institutional environment, politics and property rights.

title: ECON 322 Economic History and Modernization of the Middle East
description: Economic history of the Middle East from the rise of Islam to the modern era. Roles of law, religion. Processes of institutional transformation, stagnation, modernization.

title: ECON 340 Economics of Less Developed Countries
description: Causes of economic underdevelopment: historical, institutional, structural, ideological, technological, cultural. Patterns and theories of development. Role of government, international trade, and education in economic growth.

title: ECON 330 The Political Economy of Institutions
description: Social functions served by the rules, laws, regulations, and customs that constrain human activity. Processes whereby such institutions adapt, or fail to adapt, to changing circumstances.

title: ECON 318 Introduction to Econometrics
description: Application of statistical methods to economic data: estimating economic relationships using regression analysis, testing hypotheses involving economic behavior, forecasting economic variables.

title: ECON 317 Introduction to Statistics for Economists
description: Introduction to statistical methods appropriate for analyzing economic data: probability theory, random variables and probability distributions, sampling, estimation, statistical inference.

title: ECON 304 Mathematical Microeconomics
description: Explores the theoretical framework of how economic agents make choices and what the implications of these choices are; presentation and application of analytical tools.

title: ECON 305 Intermediate Macroeconomic Theory
description: The determinants of aggregate income, employment, and inflation; economic fluctuations; fiscal and monetary policy; financial markets; the national debt.

title: ECON 205g Principles of Macroeconomics
description: Unemployment, inflation and output determination and links. Effects of government taxation and spending on growth, investment, saving, consumption, and trade.

title: ECON 203g Principles of Microeconomics
description: Behavior of firms and consumers, functions of the price system, competition and monopoly, labor markets, poverty, government regulation, international trade, and the environment.

title: ECON 303 Intermediate Microeconomic Theory
description: Decision-making by business firms, consumer preferences and behavior, uncertainty, competition, monopoly, labor and resource markets, efficient resource allocation, externalities, and government policy.

title: ECON 238xg Political Economy and Social Issues
description: Contending politico-economic perspectives in modern Western thought: conservatism, liberalism, radicalism, and their relevance for contemporary policy issues including government and markets, class, race, gender, poverty and inequality.

title: EASC 596 Internship for Curricular Practical Training
description: Part-time or full-time, practical work experience in the student's field of study. The internship must be located at an off-campus facility. Students are individually supervised by faculty. May not be taken until the student has completed at least one semester of enrollment in the graduate program with a cumulative 3.0 GPA.

title: EASC 594b Master's Thesis
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: EASC 594z Master's Thesis
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: EASC 599 Special Topics
description: Special topics in East Asian Area Studies.

title: EASC 593x Understanding East Asia: An Introduction for Professional School Students
description: Historical, social, political and cultural survey of China, Japan and Korea with focus on topics of particular relevance for business practitioners and other professionals.

title: EASC 594a Master's Thesis
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: EASC 592 Proseminar on Issues and Trends in Contemporary East Asia
description: Introduction to graduate level study of policy issues and major trends in contemporary China, Japan, and Korea; contributions of various academic disciplines.

title: EASC 591 Interdisciplinary Seminar
description: An examination of a broad topic in the study of China, Korea, or Japan. Guest speakers, student reports, papers. Readings in English and the appropriate Asian language(s).

title: EASC 590 Directed Research
description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

title: EASC 499 Special Topics
description: Interdisciplinary examination of various areas of East Asian studies.

title: EASC 490x Directed Research
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: EASC 160gmp China and the World
description: Advanced-level introduction to China and its relations with the wider world in historic and contemporary perspective.

title: EASC 150gp East Asian Societies
description: Main patterns of change in modern China, Japan, and Korea; historical framework and the insights of geography, economics, political science, and other disciplines.

title: EALC 794d Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: EASC 360 Global East Asia
description: Maymester Study Abroad Program to China or Japan with a focus on globalization.

title: EALC 794b Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: EALC 794z Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: EALC 794a Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: EALC 794c Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: EALC 700 Professionalization Seminar for Advanced Graduate Students
description: Familiarizes advanced graduate students with topics relevant to academic work in East Asian humanities, including research planning, dissertation writing, publishing, and conference presentation.

title: EALC 650 Research Seminar in Chinese Documents

description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: EALC 610 Seminar: Buddhism and the Literary Arts in Japan

title: EALC 593 Teaching Practicum for East Asian Studies
description: Enhances the teaching experience of teaching assistants in East Asian studies through a collaborative study of relevant pedagogical principles, resources, and techniques.

title: EALC 599 Special Topics
description: Special topics in East Asian Languages and Cultures.

title: EALC 594z Master's Thesis
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: EALC 620 Seminar in East Asian Linguistics
description: Detailed theoretical discussions and empirical studies of the issues and development in East Asian linguistics.

title: EALC 594a Master's Thesis
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: EALC 590 Directed Research
description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

title: EALC 350gp Chinese Civilization
description: Characteristics and aspects of Chinese civilization; interpretation of philosophy, literature, religion, art, music. Conducted in English.

title: EALC 588b Directed Readings
description: Assigned readings according to individual needs.

title: EALC 346g Hallyu, the Korean Wave
description: Critical overview of the Korean Wave (Hallyu), the phenomenon defined as the growing, global circulation and consumption of Korean popular culture.

title: EALC 345 Korean Civilization
description: Survey of the main characteristics and development of Korean art, literature, philosophy, religion, political and social institutions through different periods. Conducted in English.

title: EALC 344gp Korean Culture from Ancient to Modern Times
description: Satisfies Global Perspective in Category H: Traditions and Historical Foundations

title: EALC 342gp Japanese Literature and Culture
description: Japanese literature from the earliest times to the present; development of prose, poetry and the novel; evolution of theatre; Japanese literature under Western influence. Conducted in English.

title: EALC 335m Korean American Literature
description: Survey of Korean American literature from the mid-20th century until the most recent years. Focus on issues and topics central to Korean American experience.

title: EALC 336 Chinese Language through Films and Television II
description: Further enhancement of functional, advanced-level Mandarin proficiency for vocabulary, grammar, listening, speaking, reading, writing, and cultural awareness through selected Chinese-language films and television programs.

title: EALC 334 Chinese Language Through Films and Television
description: Enhancement of functional, advanced-level Mandarin proficiency for vocabulary, grammar, listening, speaking, reading, writing, and cultural awareness through selected Chinese-language films and television programs.

title: EALC 333g Introduction to Korean Film
description: Survey of Korean film, the film industry, and critical issues from the colonial period to the present.

title: EALC 332 Modern Korean Literature in Translation
description: Introduction to Korean literature, with discussion of critical approaches to literary discourse, historical contexts of literary production, and aspects of contemporary popular culture.

title: EALC 322 Advanced Japanese II
description: . Improve and strengthen abilities to speak, listen, read and write, coping with more involved materials and situation.

title: EALC 320 Advanced Japanese I
description: Strengthen intermediate Japanese language proficiency. Oral/aural communication skills as well as reading and writing skills. Promote an understanding of the present-day Japanese culture.

title: EALC 318 Readings in Contemporary Korean
description: Selected readings in a variety of Korean styles. Materials are from essays, short stories and newspapers.

title: EALC 317 Advanced Korean II
description: , with emphasis on the use of Chinese characters, translation, and composition exercises.

title: EALC 304 Advanced Modern Chinese I
description: Reading selections from different styles of modern Chinese writings, analysis of stylistic techniques and syntactic structure, composition, and translation.

title: EALC 315 Advanced Korean I
description: Advanced reading in modern Korean materials; improvement of skills in conversation, composition, and translation.

title: EALC 221 Extensive Reading in Japanese II
description: Development of reading skills in Japanese for intermediate level students through short stories written for learners of Japanese and authentic materials written for native speakers.

title: EALC 306 Advanced Modern Chinese II
description: ; composition exercises in different styles of writing.

title: EALC 222 Japanese IV
description: . More sophisticated grammar and vocabulary for natural conversation. Enhancing fundamental reading and writing skills, expanding the knowledge of kanji.

title: EALC 217 Korean IV
description: Advanced level reading of modern Korean and exercises in written composition.

title: EALC 220 Japanese III
description: . Conversation practice, basic to intermediate grammar, and building proficiency of reading and writing Hiragana and Katakana with additional kanji.

title: EALC 207b Intermediate Chinese: Reading and Oral Communication
description: Improving Chinese reading techniques and oral presentation skills in an immersive environment. Offered only in Taiwan.

title: EALC 215 Korean III
description: Drill to increase proficiency in dialogue, reading, and writing; intermediate level readings.

title: EALC 204 Chinese III
description: Conversational practice: reading of stories and essays; writing of short essays.

title: EALC 207a Intermediate Chinese: Reading and Oral Communication
description: Improving Chinese reading techniques and oral presentation skills in an immersive environment. Offered only in Taiwan.

title: EALC 206 Chinese IV
description: , with emphasis on reading and writing, frequent interaction with native speakers.

title: EALC 202 Language, Art, and Culture: Calligraphy II
description: Furthers students' knowledge in the Chinese writing system and develops students' skills in a more advanced calligraphy style.

title: EALC 150gw Global Chinese Cinema and Cultural Studies
description: Examination of the transnational production and circulation of Chinese-language cinema. Analysis of the larger sociocultural significance of films by engaging their historical context.

title: EALC 145g Introduction to Chinese Culture, Art and Literature
description: Introduction to the civilization, art and literature of pre-modern China through the lens of the cultural products of identity.

title: EALC 130gp Introduction to East Asian Ethical Thought
description: Introduction to the history of Chinese, Japanese, and Korean ethical thought; perspectives on human nature, historical writing, religious options, and aesthetic implications. Conducted in English.

title: EALC 125g Introduction to Contemporary East Asian Cinema and Culture
description: An introduction to and overview of the contemporary cinemas of East Asia: China (Hong Kong, the People's Republic, and Taiwan), Japan, and Korea.

title: EALC 121 Extensive Reading in Japanese I
description: Development of reading skill in Japanese for elementary level students through short stories written for learners of Japanese and authentic materials written for native Japanese speakers.

title: EALC 119 Essential Communications in Korean II
description: Continuation of EALC 118. Aims to develop basic communication skills required for survival in Korea. Students will practice simple conversations and understand some cultural practices through Korean drama clips.

title: EALC 122 Japanese II
description: . Basic Japanese conversation practice, basic grammar and building proficiency of reading and writing Hiragana and Katakana and basic kanji.

title: EALC 120 Japanese I
description: Basic Japanese conversation practice, basic grammar and building proficiency of reading and writing Hiragana and Katakana (Japanese alphabetical systems).

title: EALC 115 Korean I
description: Aural comprehension and oral practice; the writing system; grammar drill, sentence patterns.

title: EALC 117 Korean II
description: . Progressive drill in dialogue, reading, and writing.

title: EALC 118 Essential Communications in Korean I
description: A basic foundation of Korean, focusing on conversation skills. Students communicate on a variety of familiar topics and handle basic transactions.

title: EALC 110gp East Asian Humanities: The Great Tradition
description: Introduction to the major humanities traditions of China, Japan, and Korea through an examination of representative works drawn from literature, aesthetics, philosophy, religion, and historical writing.

title: EALC 108 Reading and Writing Chinese
description: The basics of reading and writing modern Chinese; intensive reading and writing of paragraphs, essays, and stories; extensive reading of beginner-level authentic materials.

title: EALC 104 Chinese I
description: The sound system of modern Chinese; aural comprehension, oral expression, basic patterns, and writing system.

title: EALC 106 Chinese II
description: Dialogue practice and conversation; reading of simple stories and essays; comparison of Chinese and English grammar; writing of paragraphs.

title: EALC 103b Fundamental Chinese I
description: Basic listening, speaking, reading and writing abilities in Mandarin Chinese.

title: EALC 101x Conversational Chinese and Intercultural Communication
description: Basic Mandarin conversational skills for effective communication in familiar, everyday Chinese contexts and better understanding of intercultural communication through content-based language acquisition. Not available for credit to East Asian Area Studies and East Asian Languages and Cultures majors and minors.

title: EALC 103a Fundamental Chinese I
description: Basic listening, speaking, reading and writing abilities in Mandarin Chinese.

title: EALC 102 Language, Art and Culture: Calligraphy
description: This course introduces students to the origin of the basic Chinese scripts and the basic principles and styles of calligraphy.

title: DSR 794z Doctoral Dissertation
description: Registration Restriction: Open only to doctoral students.

title: DSR 794d Doctoral Dissertation
description: Registration Restriction: Open only to doctoral students.

title: DSO 528 Data Warehousing, Business Intelligence, and Data Mining
description: Introduction to data-warehousing, multidimensional database, on-line analytical processing, and survey of business intelligence applications that extract useful information from data warehouses. Business applications emphasized.

title: DSO 516 Probability and Data Modeling
description: Principles of probability methodology. Application for providing structure to uncertainty. Develop, implement, and use probability models.

title: DSO 506 Sourcing and Supplier Management
description: Factors to consider when making sourcing decisions (costs, prices, ethics, globalization); impact of sourcing on other activities such as product design or inventory management. Open only to graduate business students.

title: DSO 520 Logistics Management
description: Gives students a managerial knowledge of basic logistics concepts and principles. Some topics include management of logistics cost integration, transportation, distribution, and customer service. Open only to graduate business students.

title: DSO 505 Sustainable Supply Chains
description: Sustainability concepts and frameworks, design for environment, closed-loop supply chains, sustainability in sourcing, green facilities, renewable energy, facility location and transportation decisions, strategic sustainability implementation. Web registration open only to graduate business and accounting students.

title: DSO 510 Business Analytics
description: Foundational knowledge for business analytics, including strategies, methods, and tools integrated with hands-on skills for defining business analytics for data-driven decision making and innovation.

title: DSO 499 Special Topics
description: Selected topics reflecting current trends and recent developments in data sciences, information systems, operations management, and statistics. May be repeated only if topic is different.

title: DSO 483 Operations Consulting
description: Study of concepts and techniques for improving operations, formulation and implementation of operations strategy, and development of frameworks for process design, selection and performance evaluation.

title: DSO 462 Managing a Small Business on the Internet
description: Foundational knowledge for managing a small business on the internet including strategies, tools, and resources integrated with hands-on skills for developing a small business website.

title: DSO 522 Applied Time Series Analysis for Forecasting
description: Survey of forecasting and time series methods. Models for stationary and nonstationary time series; ARIMA model identification, estimation, and forecast development. Seasonal and dynamic models. Web registration open only to graduate business and accounting students.

title: DSO 482 Supply Chain Management
description: Issues in supply chain management. Supply chain performance and dynamics. Tools for planning, control and coordination. Supply chain design and strategy.

title: DSR 794c Doctoral Dissertation
description: Registration Restriction: Open only to doctoral students.

title: DSO 455 Project Management
description: Topics related to project management in a variety of industries such as real estate projects, new product launch, plant location, etc.

title: DSO 443 The Business of Digital Entertainment
description: Understanding the entertainment and media industries, the effects of the internet, mobile and new information-communication technologies on the business models and management of these industries.

title: DSR 794b Doctoral Dissertation
description: Registration Restriction: Open only to doctoral students.

title: DSR 794a Doctoral Dissertation
description: Registration Restriction: Open only to doctoral students.

title: DSR 790 Research
description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Open only to doctoral students.

title: DSR 542 Principles of Developmental and Stem Cell Biology
description: Introduction to developmental and stem cell biology. Lectures and lab component prepare students for a career in developmental and stem cell biology and regenerative medicine.

title: DSR 580 Clinical Perspective of Regenerative Medicine
description: Offers interaction with clinicians in patient-care setting to understand the need and role of regenerative medicine in bedside management.

title: DSO 677 Dynamic Programming and Markov Decision Processes
description: Introduction to Decision Analysis; MDP model formulation and examples; Finite horizon models; Infinite-horizon models: Discounted MDPs; Average reward criteria; Continuous-time models. Open only to doctoral students.

title: DSO 674 Queueing and Stochastic Networks
description: Jackson Networks; Kelly networks; the M/G/1 model and the Pollaczek–Khintchine formula; the G/G/1 queue; the GI/GI/1+GI queue and its diffusion approximation. Open only to doctoral students.

title: DSO 699 Special Topics
description: Exploration of emerging topics, literature and research techniques in contemporary data sciences, operations management, supply chain management, and/or decision support systems.

title: DSO 673 Mathematical Programming
description: Integer programming; duality theory; shortest path and max flow problems; network flow; matching problems; convex sets and functions; lagrange duality; unconstrained minimization methods; optimization problems. Open only to doctoral students.

title: DSO 670 Current Research in Operations Management
description: Critique of the current research-based literature in operations management to include scheduling, forecasting, MRP, technology planning, inventory management, and facilities location and layout.

title: DSO 621 Research Forum
description: Seminar. Review and discuss current research in Data Sciences and Operations. Presentations by faculty, visiting researchers, and advanced students. Open only to Marshall PhD students. Open only to Marshall PhD students.

title: DSO 607 High Dimensional Statistics and Big Data Problems
description: Overview of cutting-edge developments of methodologies, theory, and algorithms in high-dimensional statistical learning and big data problems; their applications to business and many other disciplines.

title: DSO 671 Inventory Models and Supply Chain Management
description: Single product, single location inventory models; multi-echelon inventory models; assembly systems; inventory and pricing; value of information; incentives and coordination in supply chains. Open only to doctoral students.

title: DSO 599 Special Topics
description: Selected topics reflecting current trends and recent developments in data sciences, operations management, supply chain management and/or decision support systems.

title: DSO 606 Bayesian Data Analysis
description: Principles of Bayesian inference, subjective probability, posterior inference via Markov chain Monte Carlo, applications to latent variable models. Hierarchical models and shrinkage estimation. Model averaging.

title: DSO 596 Research Practicum in Data Sciences or Operations
description: Hands-on practical experience working with a Marshall faculty member in the Data Sciences and Operations Department on an ongoing research project. Open only to graduate students.

title: DSO 598 Special Topics
description: Selected topics reflecting current trends and recent developments in data sciences, operations management, supply chain management and/or decision support systems. Online registration open only to graduate business students.

title: DSO 595 Internship in Data Sciences or Operations
description: Supervised on-the- job business experience in the student's area of interest (Curricular Practical Training).

title: DSO 597 Consulting Project in Data Sciences or Operations
description: Individual or team project solving real business problems for an existing business entity, domestic and/or international. Proposal, field research, analyses and oral and written presentations. Open only to graduate business students.

title: DSO 593 Independent Research in Data Sciences or Operations
description: Independent research beyond normal course offerings. Proposal, research and written report/paper required. Open only to graduate students.

title: DSO 435 Enterprise Data Architecture
description: Management of enterprise data architecture including data structures, conceptual data modeling, logical data modeling, structured query language (SQL), and physical optimization of high performance data architecture.

title: DSO 433 Business Process Design
description: Analyzing and improving business processes with digital technologies; use cases; business case design.

title: DSO 428 Essentials and Digital Frontiers of Big Data
description: An overview of key concepts of big data and related digital technologies and their applications to different business problems. Hands-on experience at introductory level.

title: DSO 431 Foundations of Digital Business Innovation
description: Foundational frameworks for understanding the planning and execution of digitally-enabled strategic initiatives.

title: DSO 427 Designing Spreadsheet-Based Business Models
description: Application of decision analysis, simulation, and optimization techniques to managerial problems. Learn how to create and present useful spreadsheet models to analyze practical business problems.

title: DSO 402 Business Information Systems – Database Applications
description: Applied understanding of how work group databases are used to analyze business information. Create real world software applications used in accounting, finance, marketing and operations.

title: DSO 401 Business Information Systems – Spreadsheet Applications
description: Applied understanding of how spreadsheets are used to analyze business information. Create real world software applications for use in accounting, finance, marketing and operations.

title: DSO 424 Business Forecasting
description: A variety of forecasting techniques used by a variety of businesses. Emphasis on learning to apply these techniques to real data.

title: DSM 590 Directed Research
description: Research leading to graduate degree. Maximum units which may be applied to degree determined by department.

title: DSM 599 Special Topics
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: DSM 560 Digital Media Policy, Law, Practices, and Regulation
description: Explores laws, policies, and regulations affecting online sites, mobile apps, games, and social platforms, including intellectual property, contracts, libel/defamation, and financial aspects of digital content.

title: DSM 520 Managing Technologies for Digital Media
description: Strategies and decision-making for development and management of online sites, mobile apps, and social platforms, including search optimization, monetization, product development, and user experience testing.

title: DSM 510 Introduction to Digital Social Media
description: Explores the sector of digital social media and online communities, with a focus on user experience, social impact, strategic content creation, and models for success.

title: DSM 550 Analytics and Research Methodology
description: Teaches the use and interpretation of digital analytics as well as the use of research design, methodology, and basic statistics for digital sites and apps.

title: DSM 596 Final Project Capstone
description: Students produce a working site, app, or embedded social platform project with digital/multimedia elements. Development includes pitching, conceptualization, and launching of the final project.

title: DPHR 701 Advanced Pharmacology
description: Pharmacologic principles and practice of drug use to control anxiety, pain, and infection. Treatment of drug and medical emergencies as they relate to dental specialty practice.

title: DPHR 410 Principles of Pharmacology
description: Basic principles of drug action; application of drugs in the prevention and treatment of disease; harmful effects of drugs on biological systems.

title: DPHR 601 Clinical Drug Therapy in Dentistry
description: Clinical pharmacology of drug therapy important to dental practice using case history disease signs and symptoms and attendant drug therapy.

title: DPHR 501 Pharmacology
description: General principles of drug action: prescription writing; toxicology; pharmacology of drugs affecting cardiovascular, autonomic, endocrine, and central nervous systems; drug control of pain, anxiety, infection.

title: DPBL 534b Dental Problem Based Learning — Human Clinical Dentistry IV
description: Problem based learning approach to the delivery of dental health care. Didactic, preclinical and clinical principles of endodontics, geriatrics, oral diagnosis, oral pathology, oral radiology, oral surgery, orthodontics, pediatric dentistry, periodontics, prosthodontics and restorative dentistry will be presented with a direct relationship to a well-characterized human clinical case.

title: DPBL 534a Dental Problem Based Learning — Human Clinical Dentistry IV
description: Problem based learning approach to the delivery of dental health care. Didactic, preclinical and clinical principles of endodontics, geriatrics, oral diagnosis, oral pathology, oral radiology, oral surgery, orthodontics, pediatric dentistry, periodontics, prosthodontics and restorative dentistry will be presented with a direct relationship to a well-characterized human clinical case.

title: DSO 592 Field Research in Data Sciences or Operations
description: Individual or team projects studying the practices of an industry, company, government agency, country, geographic region, etc. Proposal, data collection, analyses, and written report. Open only to graduate students.

title: DPBL 533b Dental Problem Based Learning — Human Behavior IV
description: Problem based learning presentation of normal and abnormal behavior including communication, ethics, multiculturalism, patient management, phobias associated with treatment of patients with and without special needs. All material discussed with direct relationship to a well-characterized human clinical case.

title: DSO 590 Directed Research
description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Open only to master's students.

title: DPBL 533a Dental Problem Based Learning — Human Behavior IV
description: Problem based learning presentation of normal and abnormal behavior including communication, ethics, multiculturalism, patient management, phobias associated with treatment of patients with and without special needs. All material discussed with direct relationship to a well-characterized human clinical case.

title: DSO 586 Global Healthcare Operations Management
description: Application of operations management tools and techniques to improve the performance of healthcare delivery systems. May include international travel.

title: DSO 583 Operations Consulting
description: Development of conceptual and analytic skills for improving operations. Analysis of business strategy, formulating and implementing operations strategy, process analysis and design, and project management.

title: DSO 573 Data Analytics Driven Dynamic Strategy and Execution
description: Advanced applications of data analytics in dynamic strategy formulation and execution; analytics and business methods for data connected enterprises to continuously enhance their competitive advantage.

title: DSO 582 Service Management: Economics and Operations
description: Examination of the service industry from a managerial and entrepreneurial perspective; emphasis on the tactical decisions needed to design and deliver successful and profitable services.

title: DSO 562 Fraud Analytics
description: Fraud detection model systems; identify normal vs. outlying behavior; malicious adversaries; complex datasets; supervised and unsupervised fraud statistical models; measures of model efficacy.

title: DSO 581 Supply Chain Management
description: Issues in supply chain management. Supply chain performance and dynamics. Tools for planning, control and coordination. Supply chain design and strategy. Open only to business majors.

title: DSO 580 Project Management
description: Applications of systems theory and concepts, matrix organizational structures, PERT/CPM project modeling, and management information systems to the management of complex and critical projects. Open only to business majors.

title: DSO 557b Global Supply Chain Management in International Settings
description: The influence of value-added services and regulatory issues on suppliers and supply chains. Readings, team research and presentation, site visits (LA), and final written report. Open only to Global Supply Chain Management majors.

title: DSO 570 The Analytics Edge: Data, Models, and Effective Decisions
description: Decision making under uncertainty using real data applying the most advanced optimization, statistical and probability methods.

title: DSO 556 Business Models for Digital Platforms
description: Managing Business models in digital platform ecosystems; designing new products and services for digital platforms; establishing digital platform leadership; assessing emerging niches in digital spaces.

title: DSO 557a Global Supply Chain Management in International Settings
description: Study of global logistics infrastructures – water, rail, road, and air – through readings, team research and presentation, international site visits, and final written report. Open only to Global Supply Chain Management majors.

title: DSO 552 SQL Databases for Business Analysts
description: Registration Restriction: Online registration open only to graduate accounting and business students

title: DSO 553 NoSQL Databases in Big Data
description: Registration Restriction: Online registration open only to graduate accounting and business majors

title: DSO 551 Digital Transformation in the Global Enterprise
description: Leveraging large enterprise system applications for strategic value; managing organizational transformation of global enterprises through digital business platforms; coping with disruptive technologies. Open only to business majors.

title: DSO 549 Application of Lean Six Sigma
description: Application of Six Sigma practices and techniques to improve operations in organizations. Open only to graduate business students.

title: DSO 543 Global Business Issues in the Networked Digital Industry
description: Assessing business impact of emerging technologies on companies, business models and strategies in the "converging" digital communications, media and entertainment industries: incorporates company field projects. Open only to graduate business students.

title: DSO 547 Designing Spreadsheet-Based Business Models
description: Application of decision analysis, simulation and optimization techniques to managerial problems. Learn how to create and present useful spreadsheet models to analyze practical business models.

title: DSO 545 Statistical Computing and Data Visualization
description: Data cleaning and reshaping; good vs. bad graphics; univariate, bivariate, trivariate, hypervariate, and time series graphics; interactive graphics; web-related computing. Extensive computer applications using R.

title: DSO 536 Monte Carlo Simulation and Decision Models
description: Application of Monte Carlo simulation to determine a range of outcomes for all possible courses of action. Application of Excel simulation.

title: DSO 534 Discrete-Event Simulation for Process Management
description: Application of discrete-event simulation models to events that occur randomly over time. Representation using process flow diagrams. Use of simulation methodology to improve process performance.

title: DSO 530 Applied Modern Statistical Learning Methods
description: Overview of highly computational modern statistical learning methods; applications of logistic regression, neural networks, LASSO, trees, boosting and GAM, etc., to finance and marketing data.

title: DSO 531 Digital Foundations for Business Innovation
description: Developing a strategic perspective on emerging digital innovations shaping consumer-oriented businesses. Topics include artificial intelligence, autonomous vehicles, augmented/virtual reality, post-screen usability and cybersecurity.
