title: DMAT 521b Dental Materials
description: Properties, biomechanical function, manipulation, and clinical application of dental materials. Correlates restorative, biological, and materials sciences.

title: DMAT 701 Advanced Biomaterials
description: Fundamental principles of materials science and clinical dentistry relative to proper selection and manipulation of dental materials.

title: DMAT 521a Dental Materials
description: Properties, biomechanical function, manipulation, and clinical application of dental materials. Correlates restorative, biological, and materials sciences.

title: DMAT 505 Dental Materials Update
description: Biocompatibility of dental materials, restorative materials and techniques update, critical analysis of published literature. Includes specific laboratory testing research methodology and design of clinical trials.

title: DMAT 316L Dental Materials and Clinical Procedures
description: Biomechanical principles, properties, and manipulation of dental materials; armamentarium for various dental procedures.

title: DIAG 621 CAD/CAM in Dentistry
description: Modern principles of dental Computer Assisted Design/Computer Assisted Manufacturing and will fabricate such restorations in the laboratory.

title: DIAG 523 Oral Maxillofacial Imaging
description: Clinical application of intraoral and extraoral radiographic techniques; emphasis upon radiation physics, biology, safety, film and digital imaging and image interpretation.

title: DIAG 615 Digital and Oral Maxillofacial Imaging
description: Introduction to computer based imaging in dentistry. Student will learn to use video cameras, scanners, intraoral sensors and advanced imaging technology.

title: DIAG 522 Radiographic Techniques
description: Clinical applications of radiographic chairside and darkroom techniques; quality control and evaluation of the radiograph.

title: DIAG 521 Principles of Oral Radiology
description: Introduction to ionizing radiation and its use in the health professions; radiation biology, physics and hygiene; descriptive terms used in radiography, with illustrations; documentation.

title: DIAG 415 Radiographic Techniques
description: Clinical application of radiographic chairside and dark room techniques and quality control.

title: DHYG 615 Geriatric Healthcare Program Planning
description: Independent learning environment of interactive experiences to understand the complexities of oral health care management of older people and geriatric care facilities.

title: DHYG 613 Laboratory and Clinical Course Development
description: Curriculum design for teaching psycho-motor skills in a simulation laboratory and providing feedback and strategies for achieving competence in student-patient clinical setting.

title: DHYG 612 Dental Hygiene Curriculum and Program Design
description: Prepare dental hygienists with basic guidelines and skills for development of dental hygiene program and curriculum. Focus on designing academic courses, course materials and overall evaluation methods.

title: DHYG 609 Capstone Project Fieldwork
description: Guided learning of the research process by the design and fieldwork implementation of an approved Capstone project with proper data management.

title: DHYG 611 Research Writing
description: Enhancement of critical research thinking by fulfilling anticipated conceptual components of the journal article; perfection of writing skills by correcting inter- and intra-sentence distractions.

title: DHYG 614 Dental Hygiene Student Teaching Practicum
description: Application of theory and skills developed through student teaching in the classroom, laboratory and clinical settings.

title: DHYG 608 Current Trends in Oral Healthcare
description: Current trends in oral healthcare is explored by evaluating the evolving discoveries of wellness, pathology and risk factors affecting oral health.

title: DHYG 610 Capstone Project
description: Independent study through guided learning to complete a capstone project including preparation of a publishable manuscript that will be defended in an oral presentation.

title: DHYG 605 Professional Leadership in Program Development
description: Introduce concepts of business planning for the healthcare professional. Grant writing; application of leadership theory; professional leadership development in education, healthcare, research and business settings.

title: DHYG 607 Knowledge Assessment
description: An intensive course developing and evaluating dental hygiene skills and scholarly activities for application in advanced professional careers.

title: DHYG 606 Multidisciplinary Population Health Management Strategies
description: Explore population health management of multidisciplinary team care for complex patient populations and strategies for group dynamics for collaborative practice

title: DHYG 603 Learning Theories and Technology
description: Theories of learning with emphasis will be placed on teaching strategies to a variety of audiences and use of technology in the learning process.

title: ENGR 100b Engineering Honors Colloquium
description: Recent developments in a highly technological society with emphasis on selected topics. Enrollment limited to members of the Viterbi School of Engineering Honors Program.

title: DHYG 604 Health Advocacy Program Planning and Evaluation
description: Explore issues related to oral health promotion and disease prevention and health services research by investigating oral health reports and surveys influencing the DH profession.

title: ENGR 100a Engineering Honors Colloquium
description: Recent developments in a highly technological society with emphasis on selected topics. Enrollment limited to members of the Viterbi School of Engineering Honors Program.

title: ENGL 794z Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: ENGL 794c Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: ENGL 794d Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: ENGL 790 Research
description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

title: ENGL 794a Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: ENGL 794b Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: ENGL 700x Theories and Practices of Professional Development I
description: A structured environment in which to craft a research project, write a dissertation prospectus, and define areas of professional expertise.

title: ENGL 701x Theories and Practices of Professional Development II
description: This two-credit course helps ABD students craft their professional identities and placement materials as they make the transition from graduate school to their academic position.

title: ENGL 697 Graduate Fiction Writing Workshop
description: Intensive practicum in advanced level fiction writing, intended to develop high level creative compositional ability. Open only to Creative Writing PhD degree candidates.

title: ENGL 696 Graduate Poetry Writing Workshop
description: Intensive practicum in advanced level poetry writing, intended to develop high level creative compositional ability. Open only to Creative Writing PhD degree candidates.

title: ENGL 698 Graduate Poetry Form and Theory
description: Registration Restriction: Open only to doctoral students

title: ENGL 695 Graduate Fiction Form and Theory
description: Registration Restriction: Open only to doctoral students

title: ENGL 650 Multicultural Literary Studies
description: Theories of race and ethnicity, cultural imperialism, discourse of power and class, literatures of the Americas, and other topics.

title: ENGL 660 Studies in Genre
description: History, transformation, and theory of genre; studies in epic, lyric, drama, comedy, tragedy, the novel, biography, essay, and other forms.

title: ENGL 640 Individual Writers
description: Studies in major and minor, canonic and non-canonic writers.

title: ENGL 610 Theory and Criticism
description: Studies in meaning and meaning-making, form, comparative theory, theories of history and culture, theory in the classroom, and other topics.

title: ENGL 620 Literature and Interdisciplinary Studies
description: Issues and theory of studying literature in relation to history, science, politics, psychology, religion, sociology, media, the visual arts, and other disciplines.

title: ENGL 612 History of the Book and Material Bibliography
description: Book history and the use of primary source material in literary research.

title: ENGL 609b Internship in Editing and Publishing: Eloquence and Ethics
description: Practical experience in the publishing world for acquiring skills and knowledge beyond the classroom.

title: ENGL 607 Digital Publishing and Literary Writing for New Media
description: Discussion of literary texts combined with hands-on digital practice in composition, design, and fabrication for electronic publication, including formal, technical, and philosophical issues.

title: ENGL 608 Publishing on Both Sides of the Transom
description: Editorial and publishing workshop with an intensive hands-on student project following the progress of a single piece of writing from manuscript to print.

title: ENGL 605 The History of Rhetoric
description: Studies in European and American rhetoric and their contexts.

title: ENGL 602 Writers in the World: Text and Context
description: Editing and publishing within the tradition of literary and cultural influences upon a wide range of authors, readers, and genres.

title: ENGL 604 The Nonfiction Experience: A Literary-Editorial Focus
description: Topics on literary and popular forms: profile portrait; science writing; food writing; place and travel; memoir; and personal essay; with venues for publication.

title: ENGL 609a Internship in Editing and Publishing: Eloquence and Ethics
description: Practical experience in the publishing world for acquiring skills and knowledge beyond the classroom.

title: ENGL 603 The Editorial Experience: The Craft of Publication
description: An intensive workshop in applied English, coordinating literary analysis with editing and publication, including relationships with authors; academic and trade presses; journals; editing, and design.

title: ENGL 601 Introduction to Literary Editing and Publishing
description: Comprehensive introduction to the MA degree and its range of study, focusing on elements of the craft of editing and the literary marketplace.

title: ENGL 600 Publication in Humanities Journals
description: Development of academic strategies for preparing articles for publication in scholarly journals. Aspects of publication will include abstracts, introductions, argumentation, style and footnotes.

title: ENGL 596 Internship for Curricular Practical Training
description: Part-time or full-time practical work experience in the student's field of study. The internship must be located at an off-campus facility. Students are individually supervised by faculty. May not be taken until the student has completed at least on semester of enrollment in the graduate program.

title: ENGL 599 Special Topics
description: Thematic, theoretical, or experimental studies in British and American literatures and cultures.

title: ENGL 595 Literary Studies Across Cultures
description: Studies in Empire and Commonwealth literatures, post-colonialism, American hemispheric connections, African-American literary discourse, Asian American writers, dialects and the folk, and other topics.

title: ENGL 593 Practicum in Teaching English and Narrative Studies
description: Practical principles for development of effective teaching within the disciplines of English, Creative Writing, and Narrative Studies. Intended for teaching assistants in English.

title: ENGL 592 Contemporary British and American Literatures and Cultures
description: Studies in contemporary women and ethnic writers, "extra-literary" forms (journalism, autobiography), the theatre of the absurd, post-modern fabulations, and other modes and issues since World War II.

title: ENGL 591 20th Century American Literatures and Cultures
description: Studies in rural and urban fictions, modernism, the shift from imagism and symbolism to confessional poetry, recovered writers, hemispheric traditions, literature and kindred arts, and other topics.

title: ENGL 590 Directed Research
description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

title: ENGL 580 19th Century American Literatures and Cultures
description: Studies in canonic and non-canonic literature in the American Renaissance, cultural nationalism, the consequences of race, immigration, expansion, urbanization, science, and the marketplace, and other topics.

title: ENGL 570 18th Century American Literatures and Cultures
description: Studies in the rhetoric, literature, and language of the pre-revolutionary and revolutionary periods, narrative and polemical writing, the American Enlightenment, and other topics.

title: ENGL 560 Early American Literatures and Cultures
description: Studies in the literature of discovery, exploration and conquest, the Puritan migration, literary genres in Colonial America, history and myth of American origins, and other topics.

title: ENGL 550 20th Century British Literatures and Cultures
description: Studies in literary modernism, critical scrutiny and moral seriousness, poetry and politics, the Irish revival, and other topics.

title: ENGL 530 Restoration and 18th Century British Literatures and Cultures
description: Studies in prose, poetry, drama, and culture of the period 1660–1800.

title: ENGL 540 19th Century British Literatures and Cultures
description: Studies in the Romantics and Victorians, gender and genre, the new woman and the novel, authorship and the marketplace, science, imperialism, the crisis of narrative, and other topics.

title: ENGL 535 Literatures and Cultures of the Romantic Period
description: Studies in British literature and culture, from the 1790s to 1830s, including gender and genre, authorship and authenticity, "romance" and revolution, forms of belief and doubt, and other topics.

title: ENGL 520 Renaissance English Literatures and Cultures
description: Studies in poetry and patronage, the popular tradition in literature and drama, the social and sexual dynamics of comedy, historical and cultural uses of genres, among other topics.

title: ENGL 510 Medieval English Literatures and Cultures
description: Investigations of chivalry and romance, allegory, drama, popular literature in the Middle Ages, the reception of medieval literature, and other topics.

title: ENGL 536 Literatures and Cultures of the Victorian Period
description: Studies in British literature and society, 1837–1901, including gender and genre, industrialism, science and technology, empire and race, new forms of media and narrative, and other topics.

title: ENGL 507 Rhetoric and Language
description: Examination of critical and linguistic theories; may include the changing structures of English discourse, cognitive poetics, and discourse analysis.

title: ENGL 508 History, Theories and Practice of Cultural Studies
description: Looking at specific case histories, this course introduces students to the basic methods, theories and activities in cultural studies.

title: ENGL 503 Theories of History, Ideology and Politics
description: The principal ways in which history, ideology, and politics have informed the study of literary and cultural discourse.

title: ENGL 502 Contemporary Literary and Cultural Theory
description: The assumptions and practices of major post-modern theorists and theoretical schools.

title: ENGL 501 History of Literary and Cultural Theory
description: The assumptions and practices of major theorists and theoretical schools from Plato to literary modernism.

title: ENGL 499 Special Topics
description: Studies in the works of one or more authors, or in the development of a theme or genre.

title: ENGL 495 Senior Honors Seminar
description: Advanced seminar involving extensive reading, research, and discussions. Selected subjects; offered in Fall only and restricted to Honors students.

title: ENGL 492 Narrative Studies Capstone Seminar
description: Individual research, reading, writing and project development as a senior capstone experience in the study of narrative.

title: ENGL 496 Senior Honors Thesis
description: Seminar in workshop form to accompany completion of Senior Honors Thesis. Bi-weekly meetings to complete thesis according to contract.

title: ENGL 491 Senior Seminar in Literary Studies
description: Selected problems in literary history and criticism.

title: ENGL 490x Directed Research
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: ENGL 465 The English Novel to 1800
description: Theory and practice of fiction in works of writers such as Defoe, Richardson, Fielding, Sterne, Burney, and Smollett.

title: ENGL 466 The 19th Century English Novel
description: Theory and practice of fiction in works of major writers such as Austen, Dickens, Thackeray, George Eliot, Meredith, and Hardy.

title: ENGL 462 British and American Drama 1800–1950
description: Representative plays of England, Ireland, and the United States, especially those written after 1890.

title: ENGL 461 English Drama to 1800
description: Representative plays, especially those of the Elizabethan, Jacobean, and Restoration periods.

title: ENGL 446 African-American Poetry and Drama
description: Survey of black poetry and plays in America from the Emancipation to the present, with special emphasis on the new poets and dramatists of the current "Black revolution."

title: ENGL 445m The Literatures of America: Cross-Cultural Perspectives
description: Introduction to African- American, Chicano, Asian American, and Native-American literatures — and to the literary diversity of American cultures.

title: ENGL 447m African-American Narrative
description: Development of the novel in African-American literature beginning with the anti-slavery fiction of William W. Brown and his pre-Emancipation contemporaries and concluding with the emerging novelists of the late sixties.

title: ENGL 442 American Literature, 1920 to the Present
description: American poetry, fiction, and drama since World War I with special attention to Eliot, Frost, Hemingway, Fitzgerald, O'Neill, Stevens, Faulkner, and Nabokov.

title: ENGL 444m Native American Literature
description: Survey of Native American literature, including oral traditions and print genres, such as short story, poetry, novel, and autobiography, from 1700 to the present.

title: ENGL 430 Shakespeare
description: Major history plays, comedies, and tragedies.

title: ENGL 441 American Literature, 1865 to 1920
description: American poetry and prose with special attention to Twain, James, Dickinson, Henry Adams, Crane, and Dreiser.

title: ENGL 440 American Literature to 1865
description: American poetry and prose to the Civil War with special attention to Irving, Cooper, Poe, Hawthorne, Emerson, Thoreau, Melville, and Whitman.

title: ENGL 425 English Literature of the Victorian Age (1832–1890)
description: Selected studies in the prose and poetry of such figures as Tennyson, Dickens, the Brontes, the Brownings, Hopkins, Arnold, Ruskin, and Newman.

title: ENGL 426 Modern English Literature (1890–1945)
description: Studies in English literary modernism, including the prose of Conrad, Joyce, and Woolf and the poetry of Pound, Eliot, Yeats, and Auden.

title: ENGL 423 English Literature of the 18th Century (1660–1780)
description: Selected studies in poetry, prose, and fiction of such writers as Defoe, Dryden, Fielding, Richardson, Pope, Swift, and Johnson.

title: ENGL 424 English Literature of the Romantic Age (1780–1832)
description: Selected studies in major writers, including Blake, Austen, Wordsworth, Coleridge, Byron, Mary Shelley, P.B. Shelley, and Keats.

title: ENGL 422 English Literature of the 17th Century
description: Selected studies of prose and poetry in the age of Bacon, Donne, Jonson, Herbert, Browne, Marvell, and Milton.

title: ENGL 420 English Literature of the Middle Ages (1100–1500)
description: Selected studies in major figures, genres, and themes of Middle English literature to Malory, with special emphasis on Chaucer.

title: ENGL 449m Asian American Literature
description: Survey of Asian American literature from the earliest time to the present; development of prose, poetry and novel.

title: ENGL 404 The Writer in the Community
description: Apprenticeship with experienced writer-teachers, providing students with a pedagogical framework and practical experience for teaching creative writing in schools and community settings.

title: ENGL 408 Advanced Poetry Writing
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: ENGL 421 English Literature of the 16th Century
description: Selected studies in the non-dramatic literature of Renaissance England, with emphasis on Sidney, Spenser, and Shakespeare.

title: ENGL 406 Poetry Writing
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: ENGL 405 Fiction Writing
description: A practical course in composition of prose fiction.

title: ENGL 448m Chicano and Latino Literature
description: Development of poetry, essay, short story and novel of the Chicano and Latino peoples of the United States, with particular emphasis on the differentiating characteristics between the multiple cultures that constitute the Latino populations.

title: ENGL 395 Junior Honors Seminar
description: Selected subjects; offered in spring only and restricted to honors students.

title: ENGL 407 Advanced Fiction Writing
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: ENGL 402 Narrative Composition
description: Intermediate practical workshop concentrating on the creation of narrative in fiction and literary nonfiction.

title: ENGL 390 Special Problems
description: Supervised, individual studies. No more than one registration permitted. Enrollment by petition only.

title: ENGL 392 Visual and Popular Culture
description: Course in the theory and practices of "popular culture," highlighting modern and contemporary culture, film, video and popular music, as well as narrative forms.

title: ENGL 380 Modern Literary Criticism: Theory and Practice
description: Analysis of philosophies and methods of modern schools of criticism; writing critical essays.

title: ENGL 381 Narrative Forms in Literature and Film
description: Critical approaches to narrative form in literature and film; readings and films from several genres and periods, emphasis on gender, ethnic, and cultural studies.

title: EE 447Lx Mixed Signal Electronic Circuits
description: Application of solid-state electronic devices to the design of linear and mixed-signal systems. Laboratory experiments and projects involving the design of electronic hardware. Capstone design experience.

title: EE 444 Power Systems Technology
description: Comprehensive assessment of the technical, environmental, and regulatory challenges that affect the future delivery and utilization of electric power. Case-study analysis.

title: EE 443 Introduction to Power Systems
description: Components of power systems; analysis techniques in electrical power generation transmission and utilization; and environmental and economic considerations in system operations and planning.

title: EE 434Lx Digital Signal Processing Design Laboratory
description: Experiments and design project in digital signal processing (e.g., real-time DSP, acoustics, video) including: systems specification, preliminary analysis, trade-off studies, implementation, presentation. Capstone design experience.

title: EE 390 Special Problems
description: Supervised, individual studies. No more than one registration permitted. Enrollment by petition only.

title: EE 370 Electromagnetics for Engineering Systems
description: Electromagnetic plane-wave propagation and interactions with simple media, transmission/reception of wireless signals in complex environments. Optimization design methods for system applications.

title: EE 422x Electromagnetic Systems Design
description: Applied electromagnetics for large- and small-scale electromechanical systems. Comprehensive design project. Capstone design experience.

title: EE 364 Introduction to Probability and Statistics for Electrical Engineering and Computer Science
description: Introduction to concepts of randomness and uncertainty: probability, random variables, statistics. Applications to digital communications, signal processing, automatic control, computer engineering and computer science.

title: EE 445 Introduction to Robotics
description: Designing, building and programming mobile robots; sensors, effectors, basic control theory, control architectures, some advanced topics, illustrations of state-of-theart. Teamwork; final project tested in a robot contest.

title: EE 352L Computer Organization and Architecture
description: Computer organization and architecture. Concepts include: computer evolution and performance, system busses, cache memory, internal and external memory, input/output, operating system support, computer arithmetic.

title: EE 423Lx Loudspeaker and Sound-System Design
description: Project-based design of loudspeaker transducers, filters, and enclosures. Measurement of transfer functions, acoustical performance, distortion, Thiele-Small parameters, and power handling. Listening evaluations. Capstone design experience.

title: EE 355x Software Design for Electrical Engineers
description: Object-oriented programming techniques, basic data structures, and elementary complexity analysis for the modeling, simulation, and solution of engineering problems.

title: EE 354L Introduction to Digital Circuits
description: Digital system design and implementation; synchronous design of datapath and control; schematic/Verilog-based design, simulation, and implementation in Field Programmable Gate Arrays; timing analysis; semester-end project.

title: EE 337L Engineering Nano-Systems
description: Methods to control and exploit the phenomena of nanoscience, and the integration of nano-technology into systems. Development of fundamental concepts through a series of experimental modules.

title: EE 348L Electronic Circuits
description: Basic analog and digital circuit design using Bipolar Junction Transistors, Field Effect Transistors and integrated circuits.

title: EE 330 Electromagnetics I
description: Basic static and dynamic electromagnetic field theory and applications; electrostatics, magnetostatics, Maxwell's equations, energy flow, plane waves incident on planar boundaries, transmission lines.

title: EE 338 Physical Electronics
description: Semiconductor device characteristics and applications. Physical models of electronic conduction in solids, p-n junctions, bipolar and field effect transistors and other solid-state devices.

title: EDUC 572b Teaching in an International and Intercultural Context
description: Examines social context of education from an international and intercultural perspective, linkages between societal values, culture, and schooling, and implications for the role of teachers.

title: EDUC 572a Teaching in an International and Intercultural Context
description: Examines social context of education from an international and intercultural perspective, linkages between societal values, culture, and schooling, and implications for the role of teachers.

title: EE 326Lx Essentials of Electrical Engineering
description: Network analysis and theorems; transient analysis; transformers; semiconductor physics and circuits; power amplifiers, modulation and demodulation, and pulse, digital, and switching circuits. Introduction to instrumentation.

title: EDUC 570 Research Methods and Data Analysis
description: Various research designs and their appropriateness for addressing different research questions. Threats to validity and other challenges in research. Basic statistical methods and their use.

title: EDUC 568b Guided Practice
description: Supervised practicum in observation and teaching. Focus on planning, implementing, and assessing instruction for whole classes and individual students. Open only to MAT students.

title: EDUC 568a Guided Practice
description: Supervised practicum in observation and teaching. Focus on planning, implementing, and assessing instruction for whole classes and individual students. Open only to MAT students.

title: EDUC 569a Capstone Portfolio in Learning and Instruction
description: The culminating experience in the Master of Arts in Teaching Program for students in the non-credential track. Open only to MAT students.

title: EE 415 Introduction to MEMS
description: Introduction to micro-electro-opto-mechanical systems; scaling effects on material properties, fluid flows, dynamical behavior; fabrication methods; design considerations for MEMS sensors and actuators.

title: EDUC 569b Capstone Portfolio in Learning and Instruction
description: The culminating experience in the Master of Arts in Teaching Program for students in the non-credential track. Open only to MAT students.

title: EDUC 567 English and Language Arts in Elementary Social Studies
description: Integrating English and language arts development with learning in elementary social studies classrooms. Factors affecting the teaching and learning of social studies and language arts. Open only to MAT students.

title: EDUC 566 Teaching Mathematics and Science
description: Instructional approaches for integrating mathematics and science with other content areas in elementary and secondary classrooms. Open only to MAT students.

title: EE 301L Linear Systems
description: Representation and analysis of linear time-invariant systems primarily for the continuous time case. Convolution, Fourier series and transform, Laplace transform, controls and communications applications.

title: EE 222 Fundamentals of Audio Engineering
description: Introduction to basic audio engineering principles and techniques, with emphasis on practical sound-system analysis and design. Sound measurements, microphones, amplifiers, loudspeakers, and system integration.

title: EE 322 Introduction to Digital Audio
description: Fundamentals of sound, acoustics and digital audio signal processing.

title: EE 202L Linear Circuits
description: Lumped circuit elements; network equations; zero-input and zerostate responses; sinusoidal steady-state analysis; impedance; resonance; network functions; power concepts; transformers; Laplace transforms.

title: EE 209 Foundations of Digital System Design
description: Logic-function synthesis, state machines, combinational and sequential data-path components. Physical principles used to analyze and design digital integrated circuits.

title: EDUC 565b Social Foundations of TESOL
description: Teaching linguistically and culturally responsively to English language learners. Topics include sociolinguistic theories, sociocultural contexts of language development, and multifaceted assessment of learner competencies.

title: EE 277L Introduction to Digital Integrated Circuits
description: Physical principles and circuit theory used to analyze and design digital integrated circuits. Introduction to digital abstractions that bridge the gap between basic circuit theory and VLSI.

title: EE 250L Distributed Systems for the Internet of Things
description: Introduction to hardware, operating systems, signal processing and control, network protocols, mobile applications, databases, cloud computing, machine learning, and security for the Internet of Things.

title: EE 150L Engineering Computational Methods
description: Algorithms and computational methods for efficient solution of engineering problems. Introduction to engineering software tools.

title: EE 155L Introduction to Computer Programming for Electrical Engineers
description: Introduction to solving engineering problems using computational methods. Survey of various programming languages and their strengths and weaknesses. Program structure, input/output, conditionals, loops, functions, arrays.

title: EE 141L Applied Linear Algebra for Engineering
description: Introduction to linear algebra with engineering applications.  Weekly laboratory exercises using MATLAB.

title: EDUE 596 Internship for Curricular Practical Training
description: Part-time or full-time, practical work experience in the student's field of study. The internship must be located at an off-campus facility. Students are individually supervised by faculty. May not be taken until the student has completed at least one semester of enrollment in the graduate program with a cumulative 3.0 GPA.

title: EE 101 Introduction to Digital Logic
description: Boolean algebra; number systems; Boolean function synthesis; binary arithmetic; codes; combinational logic devices; sequential circuits; state machine design and implementation.

title: EDUC 565a Social Foundations of TESOL
description: Sociocultural contexts of English language learning, and awareness of language variation as a vehicle for developing and articulating one's personal praxis in TESOL.

title: EDUC 564 Teacher Leadership
description: Strategies of leadership that lead from influencing learning in the classroom to influencing learning across an entire school. Becoming an instructional leader.

title: EE 109L Introduction to Embedded Systems
description: Information representations, embedded programming, digital and serial I/O, analog-to-digital conversion, and interrupt mechanisms. Elementary analog, logic, and state-machine design.

title: EE 105 Introduction to Electrical Engineering
description: Electrical engineering overview: communications, computers, circuits, components, signals, electromagnetics, microelectronics; data encoding and compression, USPS and UPC product codes, DVDs, semiconductor devices, and integrated circuits.

title: EDUC 563 Teaching from a Comparative and International Perspective
description: Examines the social context of schooling from a comparative and international perspective, connections between cultural beliefs and societal values; issues of social stratification and marginalization.

title: EDUC 561 TESOL Instruction and Methods of Teaching A
description: Overview of approaches and methods in TESOL, topics include curriculum and lesson planning, lesson sequencing and delivery and methods for teaching reading, writing, speaking and listening.

title: EDUC 559 Discourse Analysis and Technology in STEM Classrooms
description: Using multiple assessment strategies and technology to assess mathematical and scientific thinking and performance.

title: EDUC 560 Primary Language Instruction in a Bilingual Setting
description: Bilingual programs, their goals, personnel, teaching methods, and materials.

title: EDUC 562 Teaching English to Speakers of Other Languages Pedagogy II
description: Introduction to microcomponents of effective teaching, including curriculum and lesson planning, lesson sequencing and delivery, and creating a classroom environment conducive to English language learning.

title: EDUC 558 Culture Learning in Schools: Latino
description: History, values, beliefs, and the demography of Spanish-speaking people; implications for the American classroom. Conducted in English. No previous knowledge of Latino culture is needed.

title: EDUC 557 Civics Education
description: Uses of pedagogical practices for increasing student engagement in the study of history and civics. Becoming critical thinkers, problem solvers, and effective citizens.

title: EDUC 556 Integrating English Language Arts and Social Studies
description: Strategies and methods for integrating English language arts in social studies classrooms. Reinforces the concept of social studies as a conduit to further student learning. Open only to MAT Multiple Subject and Multiple Subject (online) students.

title: EDUC 555 STEM Education in Secondary Classrooms
description: Developing innovative practices in designing inquiry-based lesson plans to faciliate integrating the STEM disciplines as a foundation for teaching.

title: EDUC 554 Visual and Performing Arts in Elementary Subjects
description: Instructional approaches for integrating visual and performance arts content across the elementary curriculum. Open only to MAT students.

title: EDUC 553 Psychopharmacology and the Effects of Substance Abuse
description: Focus on the effects of psychotropic medication, alcohol, and other substances on behavior. The professional and ethical issues for marriage and family therapists.

title: EDUC 552 Literacies in the Content Area
description: Literacy and language within content areas. Developing reading, writing, speaking and listening skills for real audiences. Academic language.

title: EDUC 551 Teaching Physical Education
description: Instructional approaches for integrating physical education content across the elementary curriculum. Open only to MAT students.

title: EDUC 549 Supervising Instruction for Optimal Learning
description: Application of adult learning theory to evaluate instruction. Appropriate professional development to improve student achievement.

title: EDUC 550 Multimedia Literacy
description: Applying new technology in the classroom. Exploration of the use of multimedia tools to increase literacy. Examination of multiple forms of technology to facilitate learning. Open only to MAT and Gifted Education Certificate students.

title: EDUC 548 Data-Driven Leadership for Schools
description: Analyzing, interpreting, and using data to increase effectiveness of instruction and programs, improve student learning, and reduce or eliminate the achievement gap.

title: EDUC 547 Career Development: Theory and Process
description: Theories and process of career development; principles of career and leisure planning and counseling applicable throughout life.

title: EDUC 546 Psychopathology for Marriage and Family Therapy
description: Theories of psychological impairment emphasizing diagnosis of child and family dysfunction. Practice in utilizing DSM-IV classification of case studies.

title: EDUC 544 Measurement Procedures for Counselors
description: Educational and psychological instruments; psychometric concepts and the rationale for the use of psychological instruments in the counseling relationship.

title: EDUC 545 Teaching Secondary Mathematics
description: Instructional procedures, techniques, strategies, and resources for teaching mathematics in secondary classrooms. Open only to MAT students.

title: EDUC 541b Teaching Social Studies in Secondary Classrooms
description: Strategies, methods, and materials for teaching social studies to all learners in secondary classrooms. Open only to MAT Single Subject and Single Subject (online) students.

description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: EDUC 794c Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: EDUC 794a Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: EDUC 792 Critique of Research in Education
description: A survey and critical analysis of selected research and literature. Open to students admitted to the EdD only.

title: EDUC 791 Proposal for Doctoral Dissertation
description: Preparation of initial dissertation proposal.

title: EDUC 764z Consulting Project
description: Credit on acceptance of consulting project. Open only to doctoral students.

title: EDUC 790 Research
description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

description: Credit on acceptance of consulting project. Open only to doctoral students.

description: Credit on acceptance of consulting project. Open only to doctoral students.

title: EDUC 764a Consulting Project
description: Credit on acceptance of consulting project. Open only to doctoral students.

title: EDUC 764b Consulting Project
description: Credit on acceptance of consulting project. Open only to doctoral students.

title: EDUC 732 Building Capacity for Organizational Change
description: Focuses on learning issues related to building organizational capacity for change through leadership and development of personnel within an organization.

title: EDUC 731 Economics of Organizational Change and Learning Environments
description: Leadership, problem solving, communication, research, reflection, and professional dispositions will concurrently expand. Candidates will acquire the knowledge and skills to identify and implement economic change.

title: EDUC 730 Using Communication to Facilitate Organizational Change
description: Addresses communication strategies that leaders use to facilitate positive change in their organization. Reinforces written, non-verbal, and verbal communication skills through leadership situations.

title: EDUC 733 Analyzing Data and Identifying Solutions
description: Designed to help students interpret study data and construct evidence-based solutions for real-time organizational problems of practice.

title: EDUC 729 Assessing Policy Impact in Educational Settings
description: Theory and practice of educational policy evaluation. Limits of rationality and the political forces that shape policy. Preparation of an evaluation design.

title: EDUC 539 Teaching Secondary Science
description: Instructional procedures, techniques, strategies, and resources for teaching science in secondary classrooms. Open only to MAT students.

title: EDUC 541a Teaching Social Studies in Secondary Classrooms
description: Strategies, methods, and materials for teaching social studies to all learners in secondary classrooms. Open only to MAT Single Subject and Single Subject (online) students.

title: EDUC 536 Inquiry Methods II
description: Logic and methods of qualitative data analysis in the examination of educational issues and the framing of solutions for them. Open only to EdD students.

title: EDUC 538 Entrepreneurial School Leadership
description: Entrepreneurial opportunities in education. Developing the skills and knowledge for entrepreneurial leadership to improve educational outcomes.

title: EDUC 537 Leading with the Community and Culture in Context
description: Creating a positive culture of learning to promote student success. Strategies to engage diverse communities.

title: EDUC 535 Teaching Secondary English and Language Arts
description: Instructional procedures, techniques, strategies, and resources for teaching English in secondary classrooms. Open only to MAT students.

title: EDUC 533 School Leadership: Theory and Practice
description: Theories and principles of leadership and the application of principles to solve authentic problems in elementary and secondary schools.

title: EDUC 532 Inquiry Methods I
description: Logic and methods of quantitative data analysis in the examination of educational issues and the framing of solutions for them. Open only to EdD students.

title: EDUC 530 Differentiated Curriculum and Pedagogy for Gifted Students
description: Recognizing the talent and potential of gifted and high ability students. How gifted education can be generalized to affect the education of all students. Open only to MAT students.

title: EDUC 531 Student Disability Issues in Higher Education
description: History of the disability movement; current research on the success of students with disabilities in higher education; legal and management issues.

title: EDUC 529 Political and Academic Issues Affecting Gifted Students
description: Examination of the political and academic issues affecting gifted and high-ability students. Psychosocial reasons contributing to achievement and underachievement. Institutional and personal factors inhibiting potential. Open only to MAT students.

title: EDUC 527 Assessment in the Language Classroom
description: Introduces students to relevant research in language assessment, reviews concepts of reliability and validity and examines assessment practices in the classroom.

title: EDUC 528 Course Proposal Project
description: Using a framework of course development, students present a course proposal, linking the theoretical, methodological and practical principles gained from all course work in the program.

title: EDUC 525 Challenges in Urban Education: Learning
description: Theory and research in learning, motivation, and instruction for diverse educational settings. Open only to EdD students.

title: EDUC 524 Challenges in Urban Education: Leadership
description: Theories, principles, and concepts of leadership in urban K–12 schools and institutions of higher education. Open only to EdD students.

title: EDUC 522 Challenges in Urban Education: Accountability
description: Issues related to accountability theory and practice in urban education settings. Open only to EdD students.

title: EDUC 523 Challenges in Urban Education: Diversity
description: Diversity issues in urban educational settings. Open only to EdD students.

title: EDUC 521 Assessment and Instruction for Diverse Language Learners
description: Assessment practices and strategies in English language instruction with special attention to learner differences (social, cultural, physical, intellectual) that influence academic performance. Open only to MAT TESOL and TESOL (online) students.

title: EDUC 519 Human Differences
description: Equity and diversity in learning environments. Issues in teaching special populations. Beliefs about how people learn. Inclusive environment for special populations in the general classroom. Open only to MAT and MAT (online) students.

title: EDUC 520 Counseling for College and Career Readiness I
description: Theoretical foundations of individual and systemic characteristics that impact college and career choices. Consideration of economic, political, social, and policy issues.

title: EDUC 518 Application of Theories of Learning to Classroom Practice
description: Registration Restriction: Open only to Multiple Subject Teaching, Multiple Subject Teaching (online), Single Subject (Music Education). Single Subject Teaching, and Single Subject Teaching (online).

title: EDUC 728 Global Trends: Emerging Ideas, Emerging Markets
description: Examination of a range of emerging markets in education. Global efforts of institutions of higher education to access new markets through collaborations and offshore endeavors. Open only to doctoral students.

title: EDUC 516 Framing the Social Context of High Needs Schools
description: Introduction to the Master of Arts in Teaching Program. Relationship between the actions of the teacher and student learning in the classroom and school context. Open only to MAT and MAT (online) students.

title: EDUC 726 Making Choices: Deciding Among Policy Alternatives
description: Models of decision making including cost-benefit analysis, risk-benefit analysis, and decision analysis. Ethical considerations and the political environment. Open only to doctoral students.

title: EDUC 725 Analyzing Organizational Change and Its Effectiveness
description: Designed to help leaders apply research about learning and motivation to the strengthening of organizational performance in organizations around the world.

title: EDUC 727 Implementing Policy in Educational Systems
description: Effective policy-making. Human and financial resources to support implementation. Targeting resources to support implementation to attain policy goals.

title: EDUC 515 Theories of Marriage and Family Therapy
description: Major psychotherapeutic orientations relating to family systems, marital relationships, and communications theory applied to the family unit.

title: EDUC 724 Creating Policy Alternatives for Educational Settings
description: Effective policy-making and constructing alternatives. Open only to doctoral students.

title: EDUC 720 Leadership for Principals
description: The role of the principal as an instructional leader with a focus on improving student achievement. Open only to doctoral students.

title: EDUC 721 Leadership for Superintendents
description: The role of the superintendent in establishing a focus on student achievement and holding school sites accountable. How superintendents support student learning through leadership. Open only to doctoral students.

title: EDUC 723 Evaluating and Assessing Educational System Outcomes
description: Evaluating impact. Examination of key assessment theories; planning and implementation of learning and program effectiveness.

title: EDUC 718 Maximizing Human Resources in Education
description: Strategically understanding the management of human capital to ensure high student performance. How to attract and retain top quality teachers. Open only to doctoral students.

title: EDUC 717 Schooling as an Economic Enterprise
description: Applying economic theory to the study of education. Application of market theory to education, partnerships, allocation of resources, and the examination of educational enterprises. Open only to doctoral students.

title: EDUC 719 The Policies and Politics of Education Governance
description: Major issues facing educators in the 21st century. Emphasis on how educational policy can focus on incentives for schools to improve student learning. Open only to doctoral students.

title: EDUC 715 Current Research in Learning
description: Current research in the application of learning theories, and the applicability of this research across a variety of contexts. Open only to doctoral students.

title: EDUC 716 Instructional Leadership
description: Examines the role of instructional leaders in improving student performance; current issues in curriculum design and implementation; and effective instructional leadership approaches for school improvement. Open only to doctoral students.

title: EDUC 713 Issues in Lifespan Development
description: An examination of issues related to the development of diverse students and the development of environments that promote motivated behavior. Open only to doctoral students.

title: EDUC 714 Measurement and Evaluation for Decision-Making
description: Collecting, analyzing, and using quantitative data to solve problems of practice and in evaluating educational institutions, programs, and policies. Open only to doctoral students.

title: EDUC 712 Issues in Human Motivation
description: Analysis of motivational principles; diagnosis and solutions to motivation gaps in learning environments; and motivation and efficacy theories and principles. Open only to doctoral students.

title: EDUC 709 Finance in Higher Education
description: Local, national, and global economic and policy environments and their effect on institutional policies and practices.

title: EDUC 711 Social Factors Influencing Learning and Motivation
description: Social psychological principles and research techniques applied to educational problems; school environment, group behavior, teacher effectiveness, teacher-student interaction, behavioral change. Open only to doctoral students.

title: EDUC 710 Assessment, Organizational Learning and Performance
description: The role of assessment in higher education. An analysis of the purpose and value of particular assessment approaches and instruments, in particular those addressing classroom learning and institutional effectiveness.

title: EDUC 707 Administration in Higher Education
description: Administrative issues in higher education. Academic leadership related to undergraduate and graduate education. Quality standards and assessment. How administrators create efficiency, effectiveness, performance, and change.

title: EDUC 708 Advanced Student Development Theory
description: Examination of traditional and emergent student development theories.

title: EDUC 514 School Counseling Seminar
description: Current issues and problems in school counseling; emphasis is on K–12 learning and achievement.

title: EDUC 513b Teaching English Language Arts in Secondary Classrooms
description: Strategies, methods, and materials for teaching English to all learners in secondary classrooms. Open only to MAT Single Subject and Single Subject (online) students.

title: EDUC 706 Proseminar in Higher Education
description: Critical issues in urban higher education from historical and philosophical perspectives.

title: EDUC 513a Teaching English Language Arts in Secondary Classrooms
description: Strategies, methods, and materials for teaching English to all learners in secondary classrooms. Open only to MAT Single Subject and Single Subject (online) students.

title: EDUC 512 Reading and Writing Methods for Secondary Teaching
description: Analysis of reading/writing processes; methods for teaching literacy in grades 9–12; issues in biliteracy and instruction.

title: EDUC 511 Introduction to Counseling
description: The role of the school counselor. An overview of key elements in increasing access to and equity for primary and secondary education for all students.

title: EDUC 509b Teaching Mathematics in Secondary Classrooms
description: Strategies, methods, and materials for teaching mathematics to all learners in secondary classrooms. Open only to MAT Single Subject and Single Subject (online) students.

title: EDUC 510 Theories of Language Learning and Teaching
description: Application of learning theories to the design of second language instruction and student assessment to promote motivation, investment, self-regulation and engagement among language learners.

title: EDUC 509a Teaching Mathematics in Secondary Classrooms
description: Strategies, methods, and materials for teaching mathematics to all learners in secondary classrooms. Open only to MAT Single Subject and Single Subject (online) students.

title: EDUC 505 Integrating Literacy in Secondary Content Instruction
description: Facilitation, mediation and intervention in the development of literacy and language integrated within the content areas. Connection between language and literacy to developing content knowledge. Open only to MAT Single Subject, Single Subject (online), TESOL and TESOL (online) students.

title: EDUC 508 Creating Communities of Interest
description: Framing the graduate experience for master's students. Establishing a professional foundation and philosophy as educators.

title: EDUC 506 New Media Literacies in High Needs Schools
description: Instructional procedures and resources for encouraging secondary students' interests in communications, cultural studies, media production, and literacy education. Open only to MAT Single Subject, Single Subject (online), TESOL and TESOL (online) students.

title: EDUC 503 Learning and Motivation
description: Design and advancement of learning and motivation outcomes in various environments through a systematic examination and application of current research.

title: EDUC 502b Teaching Science in Secondary Classrooms
description: Strategies, methods, and materials for teaching science to all learners in secondary classrooms. Open only to MAT Single Subject and Single Subject (online) students.

title: EDUC 504 Foundations of Literacy Development and Instruction
description: Application of a balanced, integrated, interactive perspective to teaching reading in an elementary classroom. Foundational skills needed in the developmental phase of learning to read. Open only to MAT Multiple Subject and Multiple Subject (online) students.

title: EDUC 507 Professional Identity, Law and Ethics for Counselors
description: History of the field of counseling and professional identity development for counselors are addressed. Examination of current legal, ethical, and other professional issues in counseling.

title: EDUC 502a Teaching Science in Secondary Classrooms
description: Strategies, methods, and materials for teaching science to all learners in secondary classrooms. Open only to MAT Single Subject and Single Subject (online) students.

title: EDUC 501 Instruction for Teaching English as a New Language
description: Teaching linguistically and culturally responsively to linguistic minority students. Topics include learning theories, sociocultural contexts of language development, and assessment of language and non-language competencies. Open only to MAT and MAT (online) students.

title: EDUC 490x Directed Research
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: EDUC 500 The Counseling Process
description: Theoretical foundations, models, values, and assumptions underlying psychological counseling; cross-cultural perspectives, ethical and legal considerations.

title: EDUC 499 Special Topics
description: Seminar in selected topics in education. Specific topics to be determined at the time seminar is offered.

title: EDUC 429 Early Childhood and Contemporary Society
description: Consequences of "corporate world" on developing expectations of young children as consumers and scholars, an emphasis on films, television, and toys that effect intellectual growth.

title: EDUC 430 Early Childhood: Action Research Focus
description: Selecting an instructional or developmental problem of young children to investigate through an action research design.

title: EDUC 703 Examining Literacy Theories and Practice
description: Literacy theories as practiced in urban, teacher education and professional development settings using an inquiry approach to examine best practice. Open only to doctoral students.

title: EDUC 704 Evaluation and Assessment in Teacher Education
description: Evaluation and assessment in the context of public schools, teacher preparation and professional growth in urban settings. Policy implications of data-based decision making and program implementation.

title: EDUC 701 Pedagogy in Teacher Education
description: A critical examination of pedagogical practices in teacher education. The design of pedagogical approaches and programs for diverse and underserved students in urban schools.

title: EDUC 702 Curriculum, Teacher Preparation, and Student Learning
description: The process and role of curriculum in a variety of urban settings, teacher preparation, and professional growth. The philosophical and psychological foundations of curriculum development. Open only to doctoral students.

title: EDUC 698 Enhancing Student Retention
description: Examines how student characteristics are associated with persistence and graduation, how rates vary with institutional type, and the institutional role in student success.

title: EDUC 700 Research and Practice in the Preparation of Teachers
description: Research on the preparation of teachers for diverse populations. Measures of teacher quality and student achievement. Existing practices in teacher education from multiple perspectives.

title: EDUC 696 Financial Aid in Enrollment Management

title: EDUC 697 Research, Planning, and Accountability

title: EDUC 694 Legal Issues in Enrollment Management

title: EDUC 693 Institutional Positioning in Student Recruitment

title: EDUC 692 Role of Diversity in Admissions

title: EDUC 695 Organizations and Leadership in Education
description: Emphasizes models of educational organizations and how they are influenced by the contexts and problems they experience, with emphasis on leadership, change management, and governance.

title: EDUC 690 Framing and Enrollment Management

title: EDUC 689 Fiscal Support and Expenditure in Higher Education
description: Analyses of private and public financial support and expenditure patterns; includes recent trends in state and federal legislation related to higher education.

title: EDUC 691 Admission Policy and Practice
description: Examines admission policy within the contexts of history, social class, professional practice, and the interplay of institutions and society.

title: EDUC 688 Institutions, Organizations, and Equity in Education
description: Examine how sociologists and organizational theorists conceptualize institutions, stasis, and change. Learn to apply these perspectives to pressing issues of educational equity.

title: EDUC 687 Capstone Seminar
