title: AHIS 499 Special Topics
description: Comprehensive exploration of particular aspects of the history of art.

title: AHIS 498 The Gods and Goddesses of the Renaissance
description: Renaissance visual and material culture and the visual representation of Ancient mythology, recovery and reception of ancient art, and collecting practices.

title: AHIS 496 Paintings in the Prado Museum
description: (Madrid Center only) From Romanticism through Goya in relation to European and Mediterranean antecedents using paintings in the Prado Museum. Field trips in conjunction with classwork.

title: AHIS 495b Undergraduate Honors Thesis
description: Research and writing of original thesis under guidance of faculty member. Departmental approval.

title: AHIS 495a Undergraduate Honors Thesis
description: Research and writing of original thesis under guidance of faculty member. Departmental approval.

title: AHIS 494 Undergraduate Proseminar in Art History
description: Historiography and methodology: introduction to techniques of research and writing. Required of all art history majors, preferably in the junior year.

title: AHIS 492 Museum Educator Training
description: Experiential research conducted at the Getty Center museum; supervised development of docent skills.

title: AHIS 488 Topics in Art Conservation
description: Introduction to heritage conservation, an interdisciplinary field devoted to preserving material objects and structures that are deemed to hold cultural significance.

title: AHIS 486 Introduction to Museums: Past, Present, and Future
description: Comprehensive exploration of the role of art museums in society. Inquiry into the present and future potential of museums as a complex force in society.

title: AHIS 477 Studies in Visual and Material Culture
description: In-depth exploration of selected topics in visual and material culture.

title: AHIS 470 Studies in Contemporary Art
description: In-depth exploration of specified topics within the area of contemporary art and architecture.

title: AHIS 475m Blackness in American Visual Culture
description: A historical overview of how people of African - descent have been represented visually in American culture.

title: AHIS 469 Critical Approaches to Photography
description: Selected problems in the history, theory and criticism of photography; recent scholarship considered in relationship to specific photographers and photographic images.

title: AHIS 468 Studies in Modern Art
description: In-depth exploration of a specified topic in art of the late 19th and/or early 20th centuries.

title: AHIS 467 19th Century French Art
description: Exploration of the main movements in 19th century French art, using the city of Paris and its museums. Field trips in conjunction with classwork.

title: AHIS 466 Studies in the Decorative Arts and Design
description: Exploration of a specified topic in the history of the decorative arts and design in Europe and America.

title: AME 578 Modern Alternative Energy Conversion Devices
description: Alternative energy/power conversion including fuel cells, photovoltaic, batteries, and biologically inspired energy processes; biomass conversion and utilization; Environmental implications of alternative energy processes.

title: AME 577 Survey of Energy and Power for a Sustainable Future
description: Power production includes conventional fossil fuels, synthetic fuels, hydroelectric, solar, wind, geothermal, biomass and nuclear. The environmental consequences of various energy sources are discussed.

title: AME 573 Aerosol Physics and Chemistry
description: Examination of the fundamentals of aerosol formation and evolution, aerosol effects on health and climate, and the principles of aerosol measurement.

title: AME 575 Advanced Engineering Analysis
description: Solution of engineering problems by methods of calculus variations, integral equations, asymptotic expansions.

title: AME 572L Experimental Engineering Projects
description: Experimental methods appropriate to engineering research, emphasizing interdisciplinary investigations. Individual projects.

title: AME 576 Advanced Engineering Analytical Methods
description: Solution of engineering problems by methods of linear and nonlinear partial differential equations of first and second order; perturbations.

title: AME 550 Seminar in Aerospace and Mechanical Engineering
description: Recent developments and research in aerospace and mechanical engineering and related fields. Oral and written reports.

title: AME 552 Nonlinear Control Systems
description: Phase plane, describing functions, applications to mechanical and aerospace systems. Lyapunov direct and indirect methods, applications; Popov circle criteria applications.

title: AME 544 Computer Control of Mechanical Systems
description: Computer control as applied to machine tools, mechanical manipulators, and other mechanical machinery; discrete time controller design; microprocessor implementation of motion and force control servos.

title: AME 545 Modeling and Control of Distributed Dynamic Systems
description: Modeling and analysis of complex flexible mechanical systems; distributed transfer function synthesis; frequency-domain control methods; smart structure design; applications in vibration and noise control.

title: AME 543 Foundations for Manufacturing Automation
description: Fundamentals of contemporary manufacturing automation; underlying building blocks of the automation system; mechanics-based models for designing automation system; and physical and decision-making aspects of automation.

title: AME 539 Multi-body Dynamics
description: Kinematics and kinetics of rigid body motion, quaternions; elastic vibrations of continua; geometric and material nonlinearities; Galerkin methods; meshless finite elements; complex dynamical systems; computational methods.

title: AME 541 Linear Control Systems II
description: State space representation, linearization, solution of state equations; controllability and observability; state feedback, state observers; optimal control; output feedback.

title: AME 537 Microfluidics
description: Introduction to fluid dynamics in the microscale. Scaling parameters, dynamic, thermodynamic, electroosmotic and electrochemical forces. Flow in microdevices, external flow measurement and control, microvalves and micropumps. Limited to students with graduate standing.

title: AME 535a Introduction to Computational Fluid Mechanics
description: Convergence, consistency, stability: finite difference, finite element, and spectral methods; direct and iterative procedures for steady problems; linear diffusion and advection problems; non-linear advection problems.

title: AME 533 Multi-Phase Flows
description: Physics of the interaction between phases, empirical and analytical methods of solution to relevant technological problems.

title: AME 535b Introduction to Computational Fluid Mechanics
description: Generalized curvilinear coordinates; grid generation; numerical techniques for transonic and supersonic inviscid flows; boundary layer flows; reduced Navier-Stokes equations; compressible and incompressible viscous flows.

title: AME 530b Dynamics of Incompressible Fluids
description: A unified discussion of low-speed fluid mechanics including exact solutions; approximation techniques for low and high Reynolds numbers; inviscid flows; surface waves; dynamic stability; turbulence.

title: AME 532a Flight Vehicle Stability and Control
description: Response of flight to linear, nonlinear, and randomly defined disturbances. Generation and measurement of error signals in navigational systems. Stability and control techniques.

title: AME 532b Flight Vehicle Stability and Control
description: Response of flight to linear, nonlinear, and randomly defined disturbances. Generation and measurement of error signals in navigational systems. Stability and control techniques.

title: AME 534 Nuclear Thermal-Hydraulics
description: Thermal-fluid phenomena for nuclear power stations. Heat generation by nuclear reactions, conduction in fuel rods, and transport of generated heat by convection, boiling, and condensation.

title: AME 530a Dynamics of Incompressible Fluids
description: A unified discussion of low-speed fluid mechanics including exact solutions; approximation techniques for low and high Reynolds numbers; inviscid flows; surface waves; dynamic stability; turbulence.

title: AME 529 Aircraft Structures Analysis
description: The direct stiffness (finite element) method for analysis of semimonocoque structures; energy methods; elasticity, plates and shells, vibration, and stability; system identification.

title: AME 527 Elements of Vehicle and Energy Systems Design
description: Design synthesis of aero/hydro/mechanical systems; techniques of design; conceptual thinking; problem definition, configurational development, analytic engineering approximation, oral briefings and group problem solving.

title: AME 525 Engineering Analysis
description: Typical engineering problems discussed on a physical basis. Vector analysis; functions of complex variables, infinite series, residues.

title: AME 526 Engineering Analytical Methods
description: Typical engineering problems discussed on a physical basis. Fourier series; Fourier integrals; Laplace transform; partial differential equations; Bessel function.

title: AME 524 Advanced Engineering Dynamics
description: Principle of virtual work, constraints, Lagrange's equations, Gibbs-Appell equations, Gauss's Principle, Theory of Rotations, dynamics of rigid bodies, Hamiltonian mechanics, Hamilton-Jacobi equation.

title: AME 522 Nonlinear Dynamical Systems, Vibrations, and Chaos
description: Lagrange equations; nonlinear maps and differential equations; fixed points; periodic motion; qualitative/quantitative and local/global analysis; higher order systems; stability; bifurcations; chaos; fractals.

title: AME 521 Engineering Vibrations II
description: Multi-degree of freedom systems; modal analysis. Rayleigh's quotient. Continuous systems; modal analysis. Beams, rods, membranes. Colocations, Galerkin, Rayleigh Ritz methods; finite elements.

title: AME 523 Random Vibrations
description: Random processes, ergodic theory. Ito calculus. Linear systems under stationary and nonstationary excitations. Fokker-Planck equations. Failure analysis and first passage problems.

title: AME 511 Compressible Gas Dynamics
description: Thermodynamics, kinetic theory, compressible flow equations, shock and expansion waves, similarity, shock-expansion techniques and linearized flow applied to bodies, characteristics, theory of boundary layers.

title: AME 515 Advanced Problems in Heat Conduction
description: Review of analytical methods in heat conduction; moving boundaries melting and freezing; sources and sinks, anisotropic and composite media; numerical methods for steady and unsteady problems.

title: AME 517 Radiation Heat Transfer
description: Radiation properties; black body radiation; shape factors of radiation network analogy and solar radiation.

title: AME 516 Convection Processes
description: Analysis of isothermal and nonisothermal boundary layers. Exact and approximate solutions of laminar and turbulent flows. Variable-property and high-speed effects; dimensional analysis.

title: AME 514 Applications of Combustion and Reacting Flows
description: Advanced topics and modern developments in combustion and reacting flows including ignition and extinction, pollutant formation, microscale and microgravity combustion, turbulent combustion and hypersonic propulsion.

title: AME 509 Applied Elasticity
description: Condensed treatment dealing with engineering applications of the principles of elasticity, using the theories of elasticity, elastic stability, and plates and shells.

title: AME 505 Engineering Information Modeling
description: Symbolic and object-oriented modeling, product and process modeling for design and manufacturing, information models for computer integrated and collaborative engineering, information modeling for life-cycle engineering.

title: AME 503 Advanced Mechanical Design
description: Specific problems and methods of analysis in mechanical systems design.

title: AME 499 Special Topics
description: Course content to be selected each semester from recent developments in mechanical engineering and related fields.

title: AME 490x Directed Research
description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

title: AME 491 Undergraduate Design Projects II
description: Analysis, design, fabrication, and evaluation of devices intended for entry in local and national design competitions. Intended for students with prior project experience. Upper division standing.

title: AME 486 Mechanics of Composite Materials for Modern Structures
description: Current and potential applications of composite materials including manufacturing methods; determining mechanical properties; failure analysis; and design, inspection, and repair considerations.

title: AME 502 Modern Topics in Aerospace Design
description: Current topics in Aerospace Engineering are addressed by a number of industry panelists. Students, under panelists' supervision and guidance, complete independent research reports and briefings.

title: AME 481 Aircraft Design
description: Aircraft design and analysis, design requirements and specifications; integration of structure, propulsion, control system, and aerodynamic configuration; performance analysis and prediction.

title: AME 485 Aerospace Structures I
description: Design, qualification, and workmanship verification of aerospace structures. Analysis for assessing buckling and crippling, welds, and analysis of connections and thin-walled structures.

title: AME 460 Aerodynamic Theory
description: Basic relations describing the inviscid flow field about bodies and wings moving at subsonic and supersonic speeds.

title: AME 457 Engineering Fluid Dynamics
description: Laminar and turbulent boundary layer flow with and without heat transfer; boundary layer separation, stability, transition and control; introduction to compressible fluid flow.

title: AME 453 Engineering Dynamics
description: Principles of dynamics applied to mechanical and aerospace problems. Introduction to gyroscopic motion and rigid body dynamics.

title: AME 459 Flight Mechanics
description: Applications of basic aerodynamics to aircraft and missile performance, power and thrust, stability and control, compressibility effects.

title: AME 451 Linear Control Systems I
description: Transform methods, block diagrams; transfer functions; stability; root-locus and frequency domain analysis and design; state space and multiloop systems.

title: AME 441bL Senior Projects Laboratory
description: Individual engineering projects designed and constructed to model and test a physical principle or system.

title: AME 441aL Senior Projects Laboratory
description: Individual engineering projects designed and constructed to model and test a physical principle or system.

title: AME 436 Energy and Propulsion
description: Performance and analysis of reciprocating, jet, rocket engines, and hybrid systems. Characteristics of inlets, compressors, combustors, turbines, nozzles and engine systems. Energy and environmental problems.

title: AME 430 Thermal Systems Design
description: Design methodology for thermal systems; boilers, condensers, air conditioning, power generation, air pollution control, combustion and alternative fuels.

title: AME 415 Turbine Design and Analysis
description: Physics of turbine operation; design and analysis for the development of turbine hardware for propulsion and power generation.

title: AME 412 Molecular Theory of Gases
description: Molecular structure; intermolecular potentials; molecular processes in gases; molecular interpretation of concepts of classical thermodynamics; radiative transport phenomena in gases.

title: AME 409 Senior Design Project
description: Modeling, analysis, integration, layout and performance analysis of a mechanical system to meet specified design requirements.

title: AME 405 Functional Approach to Computational Methods
description: Introduction to computational methods in engineering: learning to develop and implement numerical algorithms for solving a range of mathematics, physics, and engineering problems. Suitable for undergraduate students in aerospace, bio, civil and mechanical engineering.

title: AME 410 Engineering Design Theory and Methodology
description: Product planning and task clarification, voice of customers, quality function deployment, conceptual and embodiment design, axiomatic theory of design, product quality and manufacturability, design decision-making.

title: AME 404 Computational Solutions to Engineering Problems
description: Mathematical aspects of the solutions to typical advanced mechanical engineering problems. Modeling, simulation, computational aspects, computer solutions, and computational tools.

title: AME 390 Special Problems
description: Supervised, individual studies. No more than one registration permitted. Enrollment by petition only.

title: AME 403 Stress Analysis
description: Theories of failure, shear center, unsymmetrical bending, curved beams, torsion of non-circular sections; cylinders, rotating discs, thermal stresses, inelastic strains, energy methods.

title: AME 420 Engineering Vibrations I
description: Theory of free and forced vibrations with and without damping; systems of single and multiple degrees of freedom; iteration; methods; vibration isolation; instrumentation.

title: AME 341bL Mechoptronics Laboratory I and II
description: A coordinated laboratory and lecture sequence on aeromechanical instrumentation and device control stressing the symbiotic integration of mechanical, optical and electronic components.

title: AME 408 Computer-Aided Design of Mechanical Systems
description: Design of mechanical systems using advanced graphics techniques; computer-aided drafting, design optimization, elements of computer graphics, solids modeling; introduction to computer-aided manufacturing.

title: AME 331 Heat Transfer
description: General principles underlying heat transfer by conduction, convection, and radiation; steady and transient conditions; heat exchangers.

title: AME 312 Engineering Thermodynamics II
description: Application of thermodynamic principles to fluid flow, power cycles, and refrigeration.

title: AME 341aL Mechoptronics Laboratory I and II
description: A coordinated laboratory and lecture sequence on aeromechanical instrumentation and device control stressing the symbiotic integration of mechanical, optical and electronic components.

title: COMM 653 Research, Practice and Social Change
description: Examination of theoretical models and best practices of academic research and advocacy relationships; students conduct a community-based research project using a model of community-based participatory research.

title: COMM 652 Field Research in Communication
description: Examines quantitative and qualitative field methods in communication research; survey development and scaling, content analysis, ethnographic study; quasiexperimental design; time series analysis.

title: COMM 651 Experimental and Quasi-Experimental Designs
description: Advantages and drawbacks to experimental designs and quasi experimental designs for social research and theory building. Emphasis on how to design and report experiments.

title: AME 309 Dynamics of Fluids
description: Fluid statics; conservation of mass, momentum, and energy in integral and differential form; applications. Laminar and turbulent pipe flow; compressible flow; potential flow over bodies.

title: AME 310 Engineering Thermodynamics I
description: Fundamental laws of thermodynamics applied to actual and perfect gases and vapors; energy concepts, processes, and applications.

title: COMM 648 Online Communities and Networks
description: Examination of academic research on the social, cultural, political, and economic effects of online communities; policy implications of this research; mobile technology's role in community building.

title: COMM 650 Survey Construction and Validation
description: Principles of survey construction and validation; format selection, sampling, question wording, adaptation for international audiences, response option formats, order, and avoiding acquiescence bias and breakoffs.

title: COMM 645 Communication Networks
description: Conceptual and analytic issues in network perspectives; emphasis on communication patterns, processes, content, influences and impacts.

title: COMM 641 Organizations and Communication Technologies
description: Communication technology impacts on organizations; organizational influence on technology development and deployment; methods for organizational communication technology studies; critiques and implications for theory and research.

title: COMM 647x Network Society
description: Advanced research seminar examining the interaction between communication technology, society, economy, politics and culture from interdisciplinary and cross-cultural perspectives.

title: COMM 640 Communication and Organizational Change
description: Analysis of communication and information networks in organizations and their relationships with communication technologies, organizational behavior, and management.

title: COMM 638 Global, International and Intercultural Communication in Organizations
description: Communication processes in global organizational transformation; influences of information technology, intercultural variables, and globalization on decision-making, operations and practices of international and transnational organizations.

title: COMM 637 Current Readings in Organizational Communication
description: Recent developments in organizational communication theory and research; emerging issues and methodologies; future directions.

title: COMM 636 Interpretive and Cultural Approaches in Organizational Communication
description: Interpretive, critical and cultural research in organizational communication; emphasis on narrative approaches to ethnographic studies, critical essays, and quantitative intercultural research in organizational communication.

title: COMM 635 Economics of Information
description: Applications of macro and microeconomic principles: economic role of the information sector; production, distribution, and pricing of information products; information in the functioning of markets.

title: COMM 630 Communication Technology and Social Change
description: Impact of technological advances on human communication practices and theories; trends, forecasts, implications.

title: COMM 629 Global Culture
description: Examines the relationship of culture to globalization, ranging from nationalism and colonialism to global cultural products, multinational cultural production, diasporic cultures, global media, and cosmopolitanism.

title: COMM 620 Studies in Communication Theory
description: Current problems in communication theory and research: advanced, specialized interest areas of individual faculty on the frontiers of knowledge.

title: COMM 618 Mass Media Effects
description: Theoretical and research questions about mass communication effects; criticism and interpretation of current research and theory, and formulation of new theory.

title: COMM 616 Health Communication for Prevention
description: Examination of health communication efforts for the prevention of diseases or other adverse physical or mental health outcomes by the promotion of behavior change.

title: COMM 614 Computational Approaches in Health Communication
description: Statistical and computational approaches to health communication data; better understanding, using simulations, of how theory might better guide empirical research.

title: COMM 615 Health Communication
description: Evaluation of research about communication in patient care, health campaigns for diverse publics, tools for disease management, and outreach to producers in mass media.

title: COMM 613 Grant Writing in Communication
description: Finding the right grant; how to develop theory, optimize funding, write critical components of grants, form collaborations with experts; how review panels work.

title: COMM 612 Designing Health Communication Interventions
description: Effectively changing health outcomes for target population using games, mobile and online interventions; formative and summative evaluation; virtual environments for fMRI studies.

title: COMM 611 Communication Technology and Healthcare
description: Impact on healthcare and patient empowerment of new communication technologies including social media and mobile communications, online interventions, syndromic surveillance, user-generated reviews, electronic health records.

title: COMM 610 Studies in Rhetorical Theory
description: Problems in rhetorical theory and criticism; advanced, specialized interest areas of individual faculty on the frontiers of knowledge.

title: COMM 605 Advanced Macro Theories of Communication
description: Advanced macro theories of communication and culture creation/change; emphasis on structural-functionalism, neo-Marxism, critical theory, symbolic interactionism, phenomenology, post-structuralism, deconstruction.

title: COMM 599 Special Topics
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: COMM 602 Seminar in Persuasion
description: Classical and contemporary theories of persuasion, attitude formation and change; impact of cognition, affect and emotions; cultural and group influences; message strategies and framing.

title: COMM 598 Practicum in Global Communication Research
description: Development and assessment of research into global communication; selection of appropriate research methodologies; production of scholarly research; and completion of an internship/practicum.

title: COMM 594z Master's Thesis
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: COMM 594b Master's Thesis
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: COMM 594a Master's Thesis
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: COMM 590 Directed Research
description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the school.

title: COMM 585x Organizational Communication
description: Theory and research; field experience in analyzing and solving communication problems in organizations.

title: COMM 580 Media and Politics
description: Mass media in American political life, including political reporting, election campaigns, non-electoral politics, and the media as a political issue.

title: COMM 582 Information and Communication Technology for Development
description: Roles of media institutions and communications behavior in national development, including political, economic, and social spheres; Western and non-Western conceptions of development processes.

title: COMM 579 Entrepreneurship in the New Media
description: Examination of how the digital revolution is creating news media entrepreneurs, and changing the way news is disseminated by journalists and heard by consumers.

title: COMM 578 New Media Literacies
description: Examines intersection of education and participatory culture, literacy and media change, the participation gap, informal learning and knowledge communities, emerging social skills and cultural competencies.

title: COMM 577 Fandom, Participatory Culture and Web 2.0
description: Emerging models of audience engagement and participation in a networked culture with a strong focus on grassroots communities and their relationships with cult media content.

title: COMM 576 Civic Media and Participatory Politics
description: Examines tools and practices enabling activists to exert voice and influence public policies; ways citizens are working to meet the information needs of their communities.

title: COMM 575 Advocacy and Social Change in Entertainment and the Media
description: Examines how diverse groups (i.e., governmental agencies, advertisers, health organizations, advocacy groups, actors, social scientists) attempt to influence audiences through entertainment and traditional media channels.

title: COMM 573 Networked Publics: Theories and Encounters
description: Examines models of a democratic public sphere, with special focus on design and use of networked information infrastructures supporting free speech.

title: COMM 574 Science and Technology Studies for Communication and Media
description: Introduction to the field of Science and Technology Studies; examines sociotechnical models of knowledge, power and society as related to communication and media.

title: COMM 572 Theories of Computer-Mediated Communication
description: Selected topics in the study of new technologies for human communication: adoption of CMC technologies; social networking; self-presentation and impression formation in CMC; online friendships.

title: COMM 570 Economics of the Communication Industries
description: The economic forces that determine the structure and outputs of communication and media industries, including newspapers, broadcasting, cable, and telecommunications.

title: COMM 567 The Political Economy of Privacy and Cybersecurity
description: Considers the challenges of maintaining and protecting privacy while improving cybersecurity in the United States and globally.

title: COMM 566 Using Theory to Craft Policies to Affect Change
description: Review path-breaking ideas from Nobel-winning economists; examine specific cases, trying to understand the process by which markets and institutions transform ideas into results.

title: COMM 563 Black Popular Culture: Theory and Central Debates
description: Examines black popular cultures as indexes for historical struggles over race, gender, nationalism, identity, subjectivity, aesthetics, institutional resources, political/cultural autonomy, and ideology.

title: COMM 564 Communication, Culture and Capitalism
description: A survey of scholarship about the relationship between money and culture, with emphasis on poststructural accounts of neoliberalism.

title: COMM 561 Leading and Communicating Change in Global Organizations
description: Communication perspectives on the process and outcomes of globalization; role of large media organizations in the global flow of information; and leadership and multiculturalism.

title: COMM 560 Global Media and Communication in China and Asia
description: The characteristics of global communication in global capitalism and the political economic processes within which policies, interests, and implications of global communication are embedded.

title: COMM 554 Regression and Multivariate Communication Research
description: Advanced analysis of variance, regression models, path analysis, MANOVA, and discriminant analysis.

title: COMM 559 Globalization, Communication and Society
description: Comparative analysis of social, cultural and political impacts of communication technology and media; emphasis given to communication's influence in the social dimensions of globalization.

title: COMM 556 Advanced Methods in Communication Research
description: Structural Equation Modeling, LISREL, log linear and other advanced statistical methods used in contemporary communication research.

title: COMM 550 Quantitative Research Methods in Communication
description: Epistemological assumptions, design, and beginning methods of quantitative analysis in communication research.

title: COMM 552 Qualitative Research Methods in Communication
description: Developing expertise in qualitative methods, including participant-observation, ethnography, discourse analysis and historiography in communication research.

title: COMM 525x Humanistic and Social Scientific Approaches to Human Communication I
description: Overview of the humanistic and social scientific approaches to the study of communication; emphasis on rhetorical/critical and macro social scientific perspectives.

title: COMM 546 The Political Economy of Innovation
description: How does innovation occur and spread? How has innovation changed over time?

title: COMM 524x Small Group Process
description: Contemporary theoretical models; problems in determination and measurement of variables in small group communication environments; assessment of recent research.

title: COMM 526x Humanistic and Social Scientific Approaches to Human Communication II
description: Overview of the humanistic and social scientific approaches to the study of communication; emphasis on macro and micro social scientific, symbolic and structural perspectives.

title: COMM 522x Kenneth Burke's Dramatistic Theory
description: Studies the contributions of Kenneth Burke, among the most significant figures in the development of contemporary rhetorical theory and criticism.

title: COMM 521x Argumentation
description: Foundation of critical deliberation; the nature of informal reasoning; logical and ethical problems; analysis and appraisal of naturalistic argument.

title: COMM 520 The Rhetoric of the Presidential Campaign Trail
description: Students follow the ongoing presidential campaign and consider topics such as gender, race, new media, polling, religion, and advertising on election outcomes.

title: COMM 519x Cultural Studies in Communication
description: Theoretical foundations, history, and development of cultural studies in communication; implications of issues of nationalism, colonialism, technologies, popular culture, and politics of bodies for communication.

title: COMM 518x American Public Address
description: History and criticism of major American speakers and speeches with reference to the social, political, and intellectual background of their times.

title: COMM 517x Rhetorical Theory and Culture
description: Issues of culture in recent rhetorical theory; in-depth examination of representative idealist, pragmatist, structuralist, critical, and post-modern accounts of the symbolic construction of cultural forms.

title: COMM 515x Postmodern Rhetorical Theory
description: Implications of postmodernity for rhetorical theory and criticism; issues of textuality, agency, and subjectivity in communication; study of selected postmodern figures.

title: COMM 513x Neoclassical Rhetorical Theory
description: Theories of rhetoric from the fifth century A.D. through the 18th century; emphasis on dictamin, praedicandi, poetriae, Alquin, Ramus, Port-Royalists, Bacon, Campbell, Blair, and Whately.

title: COMM 512x Rhetorical Criticism
description: Theories and methods of assessing popular persuasive art forms such as contemporary drama, music, poetry, and journalism as well as traditional forms of public address.

title: COMM 514x Social Movements as Rhetorical Form
description: Study of the rhetoric of social change; methodologies for analysis and appraisal; investigation of specific collective protest and reform movements.

title: COMM 511x Contemporary Rhetorical Theory
description: Theories of rhetoric from the 18th century to the present; emphasis on Perelman, Burke, Habermas, Grassi, and Booth.

title: COMM 509x Classical Rhetorical Theory
description: Theories of rhetoric from the fifth century B.C. through the fifth century A.D.; emphasis on the Sophists, Plato, Aristotle, Cicero, Quintilian, and St. Augustine.

title: COMM 508x Power, Politics and Conflict in Communication
description: Human communicative behavior involving the creation and resolution of conflict in interpersonal, small group, and formal organizational settings.

title: COMM 504x Interpersonal Communication
description: Theories of communication behavior in relatively unstructured, face-to-face situations; examination of decoder-encoder, message, channel, and situational variables.

title: COMM 502 Theoretical Approaches to Multidisciplinary Design Projects
description: Focuses on theories and research in communication and social sciences to bridge disciplines to produce a proposal, business plan, publication, or a research project.

title: COMM 499 Special Topics
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: COMM 497x Honors Thesis
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: COMM 498 Ethical Issues in Entertainment and Communication
description: Examines social and political controversies over conflicting ethical standards for communication in a variety of media: mass-media, communication technology, and entertainment.

title: COMM 494x Research Practicum
description: Students gain research experience in the design, implementation, analysis, and reporting of communication research. Students serve as research assistants to faculty members.

title: COMM 490x Directed Research
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: COMM 495 Honors Seminar
description: Advanced study of issues in communication; recent developments in communication and rhetorical theories. Recommended for seniors.

title: COMM 487 Communication and Global Organizations
description: The role of communication in global organizations; information, networks, and communication technologies for global organizing; computer-based collaborative work and virtual organizations.

title: COMM 488 Communication Research in Organizations
description: Seminar in application of communication research tools; diagnosis and analysis of communication problems; current topics in organizational communication scholarship; students complete original research projects.

title: COMM 486 Human and Technological Systems in Organizations
description: How communication and information technologies are linked to organizational control, design, cultures; technology and competitive advantage; ethics and policy issues; technology-mediated work.

title: COMM 480 Nonverbal Communication
description: Theory and research; examination of the influence of environmental factors, physical behavior, and vocal cues on human communication.

title: COMM 473 Advanced Issues in Communication and Technology
description: Advanced level readings into human-computer interfaces; social interaction with artifacts; concept of presence, and emerging social and psychological issues of new communication and computer technologies.

title: COMM 470 Information and Communication Technologies Strategic Analysis
description: Frameworks for strategically analyzing information and communication technologies; issues of regulation, control and social impacts of evolving ICTs; original research project of ICT strategy.

title: COMM 475 Environmental Communication
description: Communication about environmental controversies in the public sphere: history of environmentalism; forms of citizen participation; media coverage; advocacy campaigns and movements; scientific and industrial discourses.

title: COMM 460 Collaboration and Group Decision Making
description: Advanced seminar examining the theoretical, empirical and practical aspects of human and technological communication in group processes; experiential and/or field experiences in group observation.

title: COMM 458m Race and Ethnicity in Entertainment and the Arts
description: Examines how race and ethnicity as social categories are shaped by communication media; focuses on how race and ethnicity sustain entertainment and media industries.

title: COMM 457 Youth and Media
description: Exploration of youth media and culture, including television, movies, video games, toys, magazines, music, social media. Examines representations of youth and youth as audience.

title: AMST 447 Caribbean Literature
description: An introduction to Caribbean studies, using literature and film, with a focus on specific islands examined in their transnational and global contexts.

title: AMST 446 Cultural Circuits in the Americas
description: How does culture move within and across the Americas? What are the relationships between new global media conglomerates, "national cultural industries," and local cultural practices?

title: AMST 395m African American Humor and Culture
description: Examination of one of several traditions of African American humor for insights into shifting notions of race, culture, language and identity in and beyond Black America.

title: AMST 385 African American Culture and Society
description: Examines social and cultural issues affecting the past and present lives of African Americans in the United States.

title: AMST 389m Carceral Geographies
description: Focusing on California, interdisciplinary research teams will study why there are so many new U.S. prisons. What is their relationship to shopping malls, gated communities, globalization?

title: AMST 382 America and the World: Japan Case Study
description: Transnational, global perspective on American culture to examine the relationship between Los Angeles and various cities in Japan. Trip to Japan.

title: AMST 365 Leadership in the Community — Internship
description: Eight to 10 hours per week in a community-based internship plus two hour lecture. Theoretical and practical issues associated with community leadership.

title: AMST 350 Junior Seminar in American Studies and Ethnicity: Theories and Methods
description: Advanced study in interdisciplinary theories and methods for analyzing race and ethnicity in the United States, including a comparative study of topics such as inequality, gender, and class.

title: AMST 348m Race and Environmentalism
description: Relationships between environmentalism, environmental problems and racial-ethnic minorities. Rise of environmental justice movement. Assessment of social science methods used to investigate these relationships.

title: AMST 345 Law and American Indian Studies
description:
Examines indigenous sovereignties and the historical and
contemporary legal histories and cases which inform them.

title: AMST 342m Law and Identities
description: Examines the complex and contested interaction between the law and racial, gender, religious, ethnic, and sexual identities using historical and contemporary cases.

title: AMST 340m Latina/o LA
description: Examination of spatial and social patterns of the Latino population in Los - Angeles. Emphasis on economic, demographic and cultural processes.

title: AMST 330m Black Music and the Political Imagination
description: Explores the changing political meanings of "Black music" throughout the 20th century, from freedom to a threat to civil order, from racial integration to Black liberation.

title: AMST 332m Post-Civil Rights Black America
description: Analyzes the political, economic, and cultural experiences of the post-1965 period through an interrogation of contemporary conditions, movements, and responses to power in Black America.

title: AMST 305 Art and Performance in the Americas
description:
Critically examine the histories, formations, and possibilities of art and
performance from the 1970s forward.

title: AMST 274gmw Exploring Ethnicity through Film
description: Satisfies Global Perspective in Category G: Citizenship in a Diverse World

title: AMST 252gmw Black Social Movements in the U.S.
description: This course examines black social movements for freedom, justice, equality, and self-determination. Beginning with Reconstruction, movements include labor, civil rights, radical feminism, socialism, reparations, Black Nationalism, prisoners' rights, and Hip Hop.

title: AMST 242gm Social Responses to Disaster
description: Exploration of social complexities associated with U.S. disasters; influences of (political) action on mitigation, response, recovery; how activities and investment vary along racial and economic lines.

title: AMST 301gp America, the Frontier, and the New West
description: Introduction to the interdisciplinary study of American political, cultural, and social life with a particular emphasis on the Western United States as a region.

title: AMST 230g Introduction to African American Studies
description: Examines the socio-historical and political imperatives of multi-disciplinary scholarship foundational to the study of African Americans.

title: AMST 220gmw The Making of Asian America
description: Historical, social, and cultural analysis of (East, South, and Southeast) Asians in the United States. Themes examined: immigration, race and gender relations, ethnic culture, community and identity.

title: AMST 205g Introduction to American Popular Culture
description: Examines the relation between U.S. national culture, race, and popular culture.

title: AMST 204g Introduction to Native Studies
description: Overview of Native American studies, including Indigenous intellectualism and resistance through language revitalization, film-making, and the recognition of one another.

title: AMST 206gm The Politics and Culture of the 1960s
description: Examines political and cultural change in the United States during the decade of the 1960s.

title: AMST 202m Interethnic Diversity in the West
description: Introduction to community, culture, and ethnicity within the Western United States with emphasis on African American, Asian American, and Chicano/Latino cultures and social patterns.

title: AMST 201g LGBTQ America
description: Examines how U.S. sexual identity and experience are represented in the 20th and 21st century and introduces the interdisciplinary field of LGBTQ Studies.

title: AMST 200gm Introduction to American Studies and Ethnicity
description: Introduction to American studies and ethnic studies. Provides an overview of major theories, concepts, and issues.

title: AMST 150gw The American War in Viet Nam
description: Examination of the ways that different nations and cultures have remembered the Vietnam War or the American War as it is called in Vietnam.

title: AMST 140gw Borderlands in a Global Context
description: Interdisciplinary survey of theory and borderland site cases, national sentiment, linguistic and cultural conflicts, exploration of local, regional, and national identities in cultural contact zones.

title: AMST 135gmw Peoples and Cultures of the Americas
description: An introduction to cultures and people in the Americas; the social, historical, economic and cultural formations that together make up the Latino/a American imaginary.

title: AMST 101gmw Race and Class in Los Angeles
description: Analysis of race and the economic, political, gender, and social dimensions of contemporary Los Angeles including topics such as residential segregation, economic inequality, and city politics.

title: AMST 111g Sex in America
description: Explores how the proliferation of sexual cultures, identities, politics shape everyday lives in the U.S. and beyond.

title: AMED 750c Physical Evaluation and Anesthesia
description: In-depth examination of physical evaluation, emergency medicine, basic life support, inhalation sedation, intravenous sedation, local anesthesia, and patient monitoring; includes clinical experience.

title: AMED 750b Physical Evaluation and Anesthesia
description: In-depth examination of physical evaluation, emergency medicine, basic life support, inhalation sedation, intravenous sedation, local anesthesia, and patient monitoring; includes clinical experience.

title: AMED 610 Physical Diagnosis/Cardiology
description: Participation in the Cardiac Clinic at LAC+USC Medical Center; experience in cardiac auscultation, abnormal breath sounds, use of cardiac drugs, and prosthetic valve management.

title: AMED 750a Physical Evaluation and Anesthesia
description: In-depth examination of physical evaluation, emergency medicine, basic life support, inhalation sedation, intravenous sedation, local anesthesia, and patient monitoring; includes clinical experience.

title: AMED 524 Pain and Anxiety Control
description: Theory and techniques for pain control, anxiety includes: local anesthetics; drugs, adjunctive premedication, techniques in oral, rectal, intramuscular, inhalation sedation, prevention, management of complications.

title: AMED 523 Pharmacosedation II
description: Introduction to intravenous sedation; evaluation of patient, selection of technique and procedure; prevention of complications, recognition and management of complications; introduction to general anesthesia.

title: AMED 502 Emergency Medicine
description: Recognition and management of life-threatening emergencies, including unconsciousness, altered consciousness, respiratory distress, convulsions, drug-related emergencies, and chest pain.

title: AMED 421 Seminar: Teaching Local Anesthesia
description: Techniques of teaching local anesthesia to dental hygiene students.

description: Laboratory study of specific problems by candidates for the degree Engineer in Mechanical Engineering.

title: AME 652 Turbulent Shear Flows

description: Application of the basic concepts of rotating, stratified fluid motion to problems in meteorology, oceanography, geophysics and astrophysics.

title: AME 621 Stability of Fluids
description: Linear and nonlinear stability analysis applied to free shear layers, boundary layers and jets; Rayleigh-Benard convective instabilities and centrifugal instability of rotating flows.

description: Linear and nonlinear wave motion in fluids: group velocity, dispersion, wave action, wave patterns, evolution equations, solitons and solitary waves, resonance phenomena.

description: A hands-on laboratory-based survey of post-production technologies, including editing both new and older footage. Students should be finishing their own documentaries.

title: ANTH 590 Directed Research
description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

title: ANTH 575 Seminar in Ethnographic Film
description: A survey of ethnographic film using both the dimensions of natural history descriptions and process, contrasted with naturalism and structuralism as tools of controlled comparison and analysis.

title: ANTH 562 The Practice of Ethnography
description: Major approaches to ethnographic fieldwork are explored in classic cases.

title: ANTH 509 Key Topics in Linguistic Anthropology
description: Introduction to key topics in linguistic anthropology with special focus on interrelations between language, identity, culture, gender, and power in the U.S. and beyond.

title: ANTH 510 Urban Anthropology
description: Intensive ethnographic analysis of specialized urban niches, microsettings, ethnicity, community studies.

title: ANTH 503 Regional Ethnography
description: An intensive analysis of the anthropology of a major culture area.

title: ANTH 506 Primate Behavior and Sociobiology
description: Advanced course on the behavior, ecology and socio - biology of living primates. Takes a Darwinian approach to behaviors such as parenting, mating, diet and feeding, competition, and demography.

title: ANTH 501 History and Foundations of Anthropology
description: An historical survey of the development of theory and methods in social anthropology.

title: ANTH 499 Special Topics
description: Current literature: social change, comparative institutions, urbanization, ideology.

title: ANTH 502 Contemporary Theory in Anthropology
description: , focusing on current models, methods, and issues in social anthropology.
