description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: ANTH 476 Ethnographic Film Theory from an Historical Perspective
description: Technologies and uses of, theoretical frameworks for, and the presentation styles of ethnographic materials are examined from an historical perspective.

title: ANTH 491 Directed Research for Honors
description: Individually guided research and readings culminating in the production of an honors thesis.

title: ANTH 475 Ethnographic Film Analysis
description: Analysis of film as a tool for investigating primitive and modern cultures and societies.

title: ANTH 481L GIS for Investigating the Past
description: Training of archaeology students in the use of GIS through the understanding of basic principles and theoretical restrictions of geospatial sciences.

title: ANTH 474 Posthuman Anthropology
description: Examines how posthumanism is reshaping our understanding of humankind, including the ways in which "vernacular posthumanisms" are increasingly enacted in our everyday lives.

title: ANTH 470 Multidisciplinary Seminar in Visual Anthropology
description: Application of broad cast journalism, cinema, and anthropology to ethnographic film making.

title: ANTH 472 Visual Techniques in Anthropology: Stills
description: Visual techniques for data collection and analysis in anthropological research. Visual anthropology research using 35 mm. photography skills, fieldwork procedures, data analysis, and presentation formats.

title: ANTH 460 Economic Anthropology
description: Comparative study of human systems of production, distribution, and consumption; anthropological approaches to study of economic behavior; economic systems of primitive, peasant, and developing societies.

title: ANTH 440 History of Anthropological Theory
description: Ideas about man, culture, and society which have formed the field of anthropology as a research discipline; present trends and problems.

title: ANTH 445 African American Anthropology
description: An examination of anthropological research on race and African American culture, from the 18th century to the present.

title: ANTH 435x Ethnic Diversity in China/Inner Asia
description: Tibetans, Mongols, Muslims and other minorities on the China and Inner Asian frontier will be surveyed through ethno histories, lectures, films and guest lectures.

title: ANTH 450 Field Research in Maya Archaeology
description: Hands on research experience at a Maya ruin, including archaeological survey and excavation in the jungle.

title: ANTH 415 Global Studies Senior Seminar
description: Preliminary analysis for research data for overseas research to compare results, discuss writing strategies and gain comparative perspective to prepare a senior thesis.

title: ANTH 425 Peoples and Cultures of Latin America
description: Cultures of the indigenous peoples of South America; results of Spanish conquest and colonization; present folk societies and their cultures.

title: ANTH 409 Indigenous Languages in the Contemporary World
description: Examination of indigenous languages in Northern Ireland, with a focus on the sociopolitical dimension of revitalization movement.

title: ANTH 407 Peasant Society
description: Comparative study of the social, economic, political, and religious characteristics of peasant societies as they have existed and continue to exist in Asia, Africa, and Latin America.

title: ANTH 410a Ethnographic Field Methods and Practicum
description: Survey of anthropological methods for acquiring and analyzing data. Ethnographic research methods and modes of analysis; development of a field research project.

title: ANTH 410b Ethnographic Field Methods and Practicum
description: Survey of anthropological methods for acquiring and analyzing data. Implementation of the field project.

title: ANTH 400 Maya Resilience: Constructing Past and Present Identities
description: Examination of how the Maya, past and present, have forged their cultural identity. Issues are explored through visits to sites and communities.

title: ANTH 390 Special Problems
description: Supervised, individual studies. No more than one registration permitted. Enrollment by petition only.

title: ANTH 393 Directed Internship
description: Real-world work experience in an internship position, while also learning to apply anthropological theory and research methods to complete a related research project. Enrollment requires permission from department.

title: ANTH 377g Archaeological Interpretation of Complex Societies
description: Archaeologists translate raw data sets into broader understanding through interpretation. Students engage specific examples and develop their own perspectives on past societies. (Block semester)

title: ANTH 375 Human-Centered Research Practicum
description: Practical training in qualitative research methods for design consulting and real-world problem solving in development, government, and corporate contexts. Socially-engaged ethnography; anthropology as cultural critique.

title: ANTH 373 Magic, Witchcraft and Healing
description: Analysis of the practices of witches and witch doctors, priests, diviners and traditional healers in Western and non-Western societies, relating their practices to religion and medicine.

title: ANTH 376 Scientific Analysis in Archaeology
description: Examination of the range of scientific techniques and technologies used for the analysis and interpretation of material culture recovered during archaeological excavations.

title: ANTH 372 Interpretation of Myth and Narrative
description: Oral narratives from non-Western cultures; communications about deeply-held beliefs, psychological tensions, social problems, and the structure of the mind.

title: ANTH 365 Life History in Anthropological Perspective
description: Examination of one's life within its sociocultural context; study of family history, autobiography, diary, journal, and film; research and writing of a life history.

title: ANTH 360 Symbolic Anthropology
description: The role of symbols in the evolution of culture; symbolic aspects of myth, ritual, and social life.

title: ANTH 371gm Cross-Cultural Research on Urban Gangs
description: Youth gang dynamics and their effects on institutions. Comparative analysis of Asian, African, and Mexican American gangs.

title: ANTH 355 Urban Anthropology
description: Exploration of empirical and analytical approaches employed by anthropologists in studying urban phenomena cross-culturally; urban origins, structure, and social processes.

title: ANTH 357g Cultures of Genocide
description: The comparative analysis of genocide in different cultures and historical moments in order to understand the processes through which genocide has been perpetuated, as well as different cultural responses to it.

title: ANTH 344 Living History: An Anthropological Inquiry into the Past as Ritual, Experience and Practice
description: Focuses on the use of practice, craft, ritual, and phenomenology in the production of historic narratives and knowledges. Using anthropology, social history, and practical archaeology, explores the complex relationship between vernacular traditions and formal or official histories.

title: ANTH 338g Cultures of Food: The Anthropology of What We Eat and Why
description: An introduction to the field of food studies, as a historical and cross-disciplinary study of the place of food in culture and society.

title: ANTH 345 Politics, Social Organization, and Law
description: Political and legal systems of primitive societies, social control, and structure.

title: ANTH 337 Anthropology of Warfare
description: Examination of the origins of warfare, its evolution and the changes it brought to human civilization.

title: ANTH 335 Comparative Muslim Societies
description: Examines issues of nationality, religion, and culture among Muslim peoples in the Middle East, Africa, East Asia, and the Soviet Union from an anthropological perspective.

title: ANTH 333gm Forms of Folklore
description: Introduction to folklore as a discipline, including folklore research methods and theory. Core course for the minor in Folklore and Popular Culture.

title: ANTH 329 Archaeology and Global Cultural Heritage
description: Exploration of the role archaeology plays in the creation of modern national, ethnic, racial and other types of identities worldwide.

title: ANTH 328m Culture Change and the Mexican People
description: Culture change theories and methods (archaeology, community studies, participant- observation) used to examine the varied experiences of peoples in Mexico and the U.S. Southwest.

title: ANTH 327 Anthropology of the Middle East and Islam
description: Explores written and visual ethnography for study of Middle East community, sociopolitical forms and religious life. Examines scriptural and living Islam and dynamics of contemporary Islamic revival.

title: ANTH 332g Anthropology and Narrative Medicine
description: Exploration of illness, disability, and healing narratives, how narratives are culturally shaped, and their significance for western biomedical practices.

title: ANTH 323 Southeast Asian Cultures Today:  Globalization and Multiple Modernities
description: The cultural and social diversity of Southeast Asia today, focusing on globalization, modernity, and change.

title: ANTH 326 Ethnography of European Culture
description: Europe as a geographic area in terms of its linguistic, ethnic, racial, and cultural diversity; particular focus on peasant society and the Little Tradition.

title: ANTH 325 Global Studies Research Methods
description: Methods for field research in international settings include ethnography, archival work, surveying and documentation; preparation for overseas research and senior thesis.

title: ANTH 322 Anthropology of Bali
description: An introduction to the methodology of social anthropology, focusing on the culture of the Indonesian island of Bali.

title: ANTH 324 Regional Ethnology: China
description: Anthropological perspective of the ordinary citizens of the Peoples' Republic of China: peasants, workers, bureaucrats, students, and women.

title: ANTH 315g North American Indians
description: North American Indian societies, their major cultural themes, ethnological significance, and comparability with Western European cultural forms; lectures, visuals, and indigene demonstrations.

title: ANTH 317 Imaging Indians: From Warriors to Windtalkers
description: An historical and anthropological overview of 500 years of the presentation of differing and, often, contradictory perceptions of Native American life and character in popular and academic media.

title: ANTH 314g The Nature of Maya Civilization
description: A seminar forum on Maya culture from the earliest form to present; problems of origins, classic florescence, systems collapse, conquests, persistence, and transformation today.

title: ANTH 310 Archaeology of the Americas
description: Pre-Columbian culture from early hunters to the Spanish conquest in major geographical areas of Mexico, Central America, Peru, or the United States.

title: ANTH 311 Old World Archaeology
description: Neolithic revolution and origins of civilization in major culture centers such as Mesopotamia, Egypt, India, or China.

title: ANTH 307 Trojan Archaeology: Excavating USC
description: Archaeological excavation on USC's campus features training in research design, digging, survey, mapping, archive use, artifact analysis, public communication, and confronting political and ethical challenges.

title: ANTH 304 Prehistoric Archaeology
description: Examination of the rise of human social complexity from the first Homo Sapiens through the development of agriculture, chiefdoms, states and empires.

title: ANTH 301g The Global Performance of Healing
description: Survey of the performance of healing in cross-cultural perspective. The course culminates in field research to Spiritist centers outside the United States.

title: ANTH 273g Shamans, Spirits and Ancestors: Non-Western Religious Traditions
description: An intensive study of local systems of belief and knowledge in selected societies in the Pacific, Asia, Africa, the Caribbean and Latin America with emphasis on ideas of the spirit world.

title: ANTH 302 Humans and Ancient Environments
description: Examine ways that humans have caused and adapted to environmental change in the past.

title: ANTH 263g Exploring Culture through Film
description: Concepts of social anthropology using filmic representations of societies throughout the world in contrast to written ethnography.

title: ANTH 250g Race and Sexual Politics in Southeast Asia
description: Southeast Asia is studied as a meeting place of different races and cultural traditions, with emphasis on the precolonial heritage of sexual equality and postcolonial reinterpretations of men's and women's worlds.

title: ANTH 240gm Representing 9/11 and Hurricane Katrina
description: Critical examination of visual, textual, and performative representations of culture and identity anchored by discussion of the terrorist attacks of 9/11 and Hurricane Katrina .

title: ANTH 201g Principles of Human Organization
description: Major culture types, nomadic hunters and herders, peasant and tribal societies, sophisticated kingdoms; social, political, economic, and religious institutions.

title: ANTH 205g Introduction to Global Studies and Overseas Research
description: Cultural differences and social processes examined in global and regional networks. Issues are studied ethnographically, using materials from several disciplines.

title: ANTH 235g The Changing Pacific: History, Culture, Politics
description: Current social and political developments in the South Pacific analyzed from the perspective of the historical relationship between indigenous cultures and the West.

title: ANTH 140g Mesoamerican Cosmovision and Culture
description: An exploration of the nature and contributions of pre-Columbian high civilizations (Maya, Aztecs, etc.) and their descendants as they resist and assimilate to the modern world.

title: ANTH 125g Social Issues in Human Sexuality and Reproduction
description: Examination of the "natural" (biological) and "unnatural" (social and cultural) dimensions of human sexuality and reproduction.

title: ANTH 101g Body, Mind and Healing: Introduction to Medical Anthropology
description: The body, illness and healing from a cultural perspective, including comparative studies of folk healing systems, curing rituals and Western biomedical practices.The body etc.

title: ANST 694d Doctoral Capstone Project
description: Mentored research on an individualized topic of interest leading to the professional doctorate. The project will culminate in a formal written research paper or presentation.

title: ANST 694a Doctoral Capstone Project
description: Mentored research on an individualized topic of interest leading to the professional doctorate.  The project will culminate in a formal written research paper or presentation.

title: ANST 694b Doctoral Capstone Project
description: Mentored research on an individualized topic of interest leading to the professional doctorate.  The project will culminate in a formal written research paper or presentation.

title: ANST 694c Doctoral Capstone Project
description: Mentored research on an individualized topic of interest leading to the professional doctorate. The project will culminate in a formal written research paper or presentation.

title: ANST 691 Doctoral Capstone Proposal
description: Preparation of capstone project proposal. Examination/analysis of research and literature to prepare and facilitate the student's area of focus culminating in the written capstone proposal and presentation.

title: ANST 621b Clinical Synthesis II
description: A two semester curriculum promoting synthesis and mastery of topics integral to nurse anesthesia planning, management, and delivery. A continuation of ANST 620.

title: ANST 620b Clinical Synthesis I
description: A two semester curriculum promoting synthesis and mastery of topics integral to the art and science of nurse anesthesia planning, management, and delivery.

title: ANST 621a Clinical Synthesis II
description: A two semester curriculum promoting synthesis and mastery of topics integral to nurse anesthesia planning, management, and delivery. A continuation of ANST 620.

title: ANST 620a Clinical Synthesis I
description: A two semester curriculum promoting synthesis and mastery of topics integral to the art and science of nurse anesthesia planning, management, and delivery.

title: ANST 619 Advanced Clinical Residency in Nurse Anesthesia IV
description: Terms Offered: FaSpSm

title: ANST 618 Advanced Clinical Residency in Nurse Anesthesia III
description: Terms Offered: FaSpSm

title: ANST 616 Advanced Clinical Residency in Nurse Anesthesia I
description: Terms Offered: FaSpSm

title: ANST 617 Advanced Clinical Residency in Nurse Anesthesia II
description: Terms Offered: FaSpSm

title: ANST 613 Clinician-Technology Interface
description: Exploring informatics, the integration of computer science, cognitive science, and informational science to manage and communicate data, information, knowledge and wisdom in healthcare delivery.

title: ANST 614 Clinical Residency in Nurse Anesthesia I
description: Correlation of techniques of anesthesia administration with application of scientific and pharmacologic theory in the clinical setting with observation and supervised clinical residency.

title: ANST 615 Clinical Residency in Nurse Anesthesia II
description: Correlation of techniques of anesthesia administration with application of scientific and pharmacologic theory in the clinical setting with observation and supervised clinical residency.

title: ANST 611 Leadership and Collaborative Practice
description: Emphasis on the professional components of nurse anesthesia practice including scope of practice, organizational leadership, accountability, ethics and collaborative practice.

title: ANST 605 Clinical Prevention and Population Health
description: Focuses on positive/protective social and behavioral factors influencing well-being of individuals and populations. Public health promotion strategies, clinical prevention and lifestyle choices will be reviewed.

title: ANST 607 Advanced Health Assessment
description: Advanced health assessment of all human systems utilizing advanced assessment techniques, concepts and approaches.

title: ANST 604 Healthcare Policy for Advocacy in Health Care
description: Examining the health care system focusing on policy development, health care costs, quality and patient safety, access to care, disparities, and future trends.

title: ANST 603 Anatomy and Advanced Health Assessment
description: Lectures and laboratory simulation in anatomy emphasizing structure and function of major organs to include brain, cardiovascular, lungs, liver, kidneys and musculoskeletal systems. Acceptance into the USC Program of Nurse Anesthesia.

title: ANST 591 Special Projects
description: Supervised learning in functional and/or clinical area of focus reflecting current trends and development in the field of nurse anesthesia.

title: ANST 602 Analytical Methods for Evidence-Based Practice
description: Evaluation of the appropriateness of statistical methods applied to answer research questions and impact of statistical choice on applying evidence-based medicine to nurse anesthesia practice.

title: ANST 601 Professional Integration to the Clinical Environment
description: Correlation of techniques of anesthesia administration with application of scientific and pharmacologic theory in the clinical environment with observation and supervised clinical instruction.

title: ANST 600 Gateway Tools
description: Emphasize strategies that build critical skills for the transition from clinician to doctoral level scholarship and clinical practice. Discussions used to develop  self awareness,  self regulation, internal motivation, empathy, social skills and role transition. Acceptance into the USC Program of Nurse Anesthesia.

title: ANST 590 Directed Research
description: Research leading to the master's degree in nurse anesthesia. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

title: ANST 514 Specialty Fellowship
description: Optional internship to develop advanced skills and critical assessment of anesthesia specialty or clinical research.

title: ANST 511 Advanced Clinical Residency in Nurse Anesthesia II
description: Correlation of techniques of anesthesia administration with application of scientific and pharmacologic theory expanded to neuroanesthesia, cardiac anesthesia, trauma anesthesia, critical care and pain management.

title: ANST 512 Research Integration: Capstone Experience
description: A capstone course that requires students to demonstrate ability to integrate theory, research, and practice through a mentored research experience with direct relevance to graduate specialization.

title: ANST 510 Leadership and Professional Aspects of Nurse Anesthesia
description: Emphasis on the professional components of nurse anesthesia practice, including socialization, regulation, culture, ethics, law, employment, advocacy, and contemporary practice issues.

title: ANST 508 Research: Investigative Inquiry
description: Utilization of research, which includes the evaluation of research, problem identification within the practice setting, awareness of practice outcomes and the clinical application of research.

title: ANST 507 Clinical Residency in Nurse Anesthesia II
description: Correlation of techniques of anesthesia administration with application of scientific and pharmacologic theory in the clinical setting with observation and supervised clinical residency.

title: ANST 505 Clinical Residency in Nurse Anesthesia I
description: Correlation of techniques of anesthesia administration with application of scientific and pharmacologic theory in the clinical setting with observation and supervised clinical residency.

title: ANST 506 Advanced Principles of Nurse Anesthesia Practice
description: Advanced theory of anesthesia management for general and specialized procedures, diagnostic procedures, pediatrics and obstetrics.

title: ANST 509 Advanced Clinical Residency in Nurse Anesthesia I
description: Correlation of techniques of anesthesia administration with application of scientific and pharmacologic theory expanded to geriatric, obstetrical, and pediatric anesthesia; anesthetic management to include medically compromised patients.

title: ANST 504 Advanced Pathophysiology Related to Anesthesia Practice
description: In-depth study of cardiovascular, respiratory, renal, liver, endocrine and neurophysiology and pathophysiology with application of these principles to anesthetic case management using problem-based learning.

title: ANST 502 Principles of Nurse Anesthesia Practice
description: Basic theory of anesthesia administration, preanesthetic assessment, physical examination, monitoring. Case management including airway and blood/fluid management, anesthesia machine, and postoperative pain. Lecture/case study format.

title: ANST 501 Advanced Pharmacology of Anesthesia Practice I
description: Pharmacokinetic and pharmacodynamic principles, uptake and distribution of inhalational anesthetics, and pharmacology of respiratory and cardiovascular drugs. Application of pharmacologic principles to anesthetic management.

title: ANST 503 Advanced Pharmacology of Anesthesia Practice II
description: Pharmacokinetic/pharmacodynamic principles of drugs covering different organs systems (cardiovascular, CNS, hematology, endocrine), herbal therapies, chemotherapeutics, antimicrobials. Application of pharmacology to anesthetic management using problem-based learning.

title: ANST 500 Human Anatomy
description: Lectures and laboratory simulation in anatomy emphasizing structure and function of major organs to include brain, cardiovascular, lungs, liver, kidneys and musculoskeletal system.

title: ANAT 722 Advanced Head and Neck Anatomy Laboratory
description: Dissection of the head and neck with emphasis on the osteology and morphology of the face.

title: ANAT 701 Advanced Head and Neck Anatomy
description: Detailed study of structure and function of the orofacial region including recent research and advances in dentistry.

title: ANAT 522 Systemic Human Anatomy
description: Structure and function of the human body; organ systems and morphology of the abdomen and pelvis; axilla and arm; osteology of the skull.

title: ANAT 523 Head and Neck Dissection
description: Laboratory experience in dissection of the structures of the human head and neck with emphasis on the osteology and morphology of the face.

title: ANAT 521 Head and Neck Anatomy
description: Detailed morphology of the head and neck emphasizing considerations applicable to dentistry; morphology of the thorax; osteology of the skull.

title: ANAT 501 Functional Neuroanatomy-Neurophysiology
description: Structure and function of the human nervous system. Includes participation in neurology clinics at LAC+USC Medical Center.

title: ANAT 321 Head and Neck Anatomy
description: Anatomy of the head and neck with lecture and laboratory demonstration for dental hygienists.

title: AMST 794d Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: AMST 794c Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: AMST 794z Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: AMST 794b Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: AMST 794a Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: AMST 701 Contemporary Theories of American Studies and Ethnicity
description: Seminar in representative theoretical works in the fields of American Studies and Ethnic Studies published in the past fifteen years.

title: AMST 790 Research
description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the program.

title: AMST 700 Theories and Practices of Professional Development
description: Offers students a structured environment in which to write their dissertation proposals and focuses on professional development. Completion of qualifying exam.

title: AMST 680 Interdisciplinary Research Seminar in Cultural Studies
description: Explores theoretical approaches to cultural studies as an interdisciplinary field and guides students through the design and completion of a journal-quality research paper.

title: AMST 662 Research Seminar in Comparative Ethnic Studies
description: Examination of the historical evolution and current status of comparative and relational ethnic studies. Original research project required.

title: AMST 670 Interdisciplinary Research Seminar on Los Angeles
description: Introduces students to issues of - urban-based research concerning Los Angeles and guides students through the design and completion of a journal-quality research paper.

title: AMST 660 Interdisciplinary Research Seminar in Race and Ethnicity
description: Explores issues of conducting interdisciplinary research in race and ethnicity and guides students through the design and completion of a journal-quality research paper.

title: AMST 630 Interdisciplinary Research Seminar: African American Studies
description: Methodological and theoretical approaches to conducting research in African American Studies; design and completion of a publishable research paper.

title: AMST 610 Interdisciplinary Research Seminar in Chicano/Latino Studies
description: Exploration of issues involved in conducting research in the interdisciplinary field of Chicano/Latino Studies and guides students through the design and completion of a journal- quality research paper.

title: AMST 593 Practicum in Teaching the Liberal Arts: American Studies
description: Practical principles for the long term development of effective teaching within college disciplines, intended for teaching assistants in American Studies and Ethnicity.

title: AMST 599 Special Topics
description: Seminar in selected topics in American studies and ethnicity.

title: AMST 590 Directed Research
description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the program.

title: AMST 585 Topics in Cultural Theory
description: Introduction to key texts on poststructuralism and its theorizing of the body, power, and historical trauma.

title: AMST 586 Utopia and Dystopia
description: How did Marx conceptualize modernity? What is capital? Historical materialism? Dialectical materialism? What roles do race, class, gender, sexuality, territory and the state perform?

title: AMST 580 Readings in Cultural Studies
description: Seminar in theoretical approaches to cultural studies, with an emphasis on the analysis of race, gender, sexuality, and class in the U.S.

title: AMST 572 Quantitative Methods for a Diverse Society
description: Diversity and empirical social research; conceptualization, design and measurement; conducting, analyzing and evaluating surveys and experiments; focus on obstacles in the empirical study of diversity.

title: AMST 570 Readings on Los Angeles and Urban Culture
description: Exploration of some of the leading scholarship from a variety of disciplines writing about Los Angeles and the Southern California area. Particular emphasis is placed on the intersections of historical, contemporary and cultural issues that inform recent scholarship on Los Angeles.

title: AMST 560 Readings on Race and Ethnicity
description: Exploration of research on race and ethnicity in the United States as it pertains to political, social, economic, cultural and historical issues.

title: AMST 552 Archives and Subcultures
description: Introduction to the practice of archival research with an emphasis on the literary and historical methods of documenting subcultural groups, particularly racial and sexual minorities.

title: AMST 543 Critical Studies in Whiteness
description: Examines meaning of "whiteness" from historical and other disciplinary perspectives; focus is on how whiteness operates within specific racial regimes to perpetuate inequality.

title: AMST 530 Readings in African American Studies
description: Seminar exploring crucial theoretical, methodological and historical issues in the development of African American Studies.

title: AMST 520 Readings in Asian American Studies
description: Graduate seminar covering critical themes in the interdisciplinary field of Asian American Studies, including perspectives from anthropology, literature, sociology, history, political science, religious studies, cultural studies, women/gender studies and psychology.

title: AMST 519 Indigenous, Decolonial and Transhemispheric American Studies
description: Evaluate pressing social science and humanities concerns hemispherically in relation to first peoples, decolonialization, land, cultural memory, and politics within comparative ethnic studies.

title: AMST 510 Readings in Chicano/Latino Studies
description: Perspectives from the major debates that have driven the development of the field of Chicano/Latino/a studies across the disciplines.

title: AMST 500 Introduction to American Studies and Ethnicity
description: An exploration of themes, theoretical influences, and methodological approaches current in American Studies and Ethnic Studies.

title: AMST 499 Special Topics
description: Special topics in the earth sciences. Field trip required when appropriate to the topic. Departmental approval required.

title: AMST 493 Senior Honors Thesis in American Studies and Ethnicity
description: Writing the honors thesis; for students in one of the four American Studies and Ethnicity majors and Honors Program.

title: AMST 492 Research Methods in American Studies and Ethnicity
description: Develop the research proposal and methods for completing a senior honors thesis; for students in one of the four American Studies and Ethnicity honors programs.

title: AMST 498 Senior Seminar in American Studies and Ethnicity
description: Capstone course for majors, highlighting interdisciplinary study of race and ethnicity in a comparative context.

title: AMST 490x Directed Research
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: AMST 466m The Psychology of African Americans
description: Provides an introduction to the study of health, mental health, and social behavior among African Americans.

title: AMST 452m Race, Gender and Sexuality
description: Examination of sexual discourses in the United States in the context of slavery, empire, sex work, labor markets, schools and prisons.

title: ARCH 420 Visual Communication and Graphic Expression
description: An exploratory study of fundamental and innovative visual communication principles and graphic expression techniques to facilitate the design enquiry process for architects.

title: ARCH 419 Architectural Sustainability Tools and Methods
description: Lectures, comparative studies and exercises on international architectural sustainability rating and certification systems.

title: ARCH 417 Computer Programming in Architecture
description: Principles underlying computer programming, emphasizing algorithms, procedures, and program structures applicable to architecture.

title: ARCH 418 Designing with Natural Forces
description: Investigation of natural force effects and their relationships to architecture; laboratory work includes drawing, photography, model building and tests on models.

title: ARCH 414 Perspectives in History and Theory in Architecture
description: Perspectives in Architecture and Urbanism is an advanced course that allows students to delve deeply into one aspect of world history, theory and/or contemporary issues to develop more focused and critical understanding of that discourse.

title: ARCH 411 Architectural Technology
description: Architectural design considered as a technological problem; influence of technology on design; buildings as integrated sets of subsystems.

title: ARCH 409L Design Foundation
description: Introduction to basic architectural design principles for problem solving scenarios; foundational architectural design course for systematic thinking.

title: ARCH 410 Computer Transformations
description: To explore the potential of computer-integrated design software; to develop techniques for critical analysis of architectural precedents; to expand the ability to visualize options; to expand perception; and to learn the basics of computer-integrated design.

title: ARCH 407 Advanced Computer Applications
description: Investigation of computer graphic applications, emphasizing the role of computers in helping designers create and communicate using color (rendering), form (modeling), and time (animation) and the implications of future technological advancements.

title: ARCH 404 Topics in Modern Architecture in Southern California
description: Investigation of modern architecture in southern California within its cultural and historic contexts.

title: ARCH 406 Global Studies: Topics in Architecture, Urbanism, History and Art
description: Offered for particular geographic areas of study. Required prerequisite for all full semester undergraduate global programs. Also intended for general interest in focused study on particular geographic area.

title: ARCH 405bL Building Science III
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture, Lab Required

title: ARCH 403 Principles of Spatial Design II
description: Emphasis on developing advanced urban spatial design solutions set within contemporary urban conditions, with a particular emphasis on ecology, public space, neighborhoods and districts.

title: ARCH 405aL Building Science III
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture, Lab Required

title: ARCH 402bL Architectural Design IV
description: Selected areas of specialization; three projects chosen with advisement from a variety of studio offerings that concentrate on different areas of vital concern.

title: ARCH 402aL Architectural Design IV
description: Selected areas of specialization; three projects chosen with advisement from a variety of studio offerings that concentrate on different areas of vital concern.

title: ARCH 390 Special Problems
description: Supervised, individual studies. No more than one registration permitted. Enrollment by petition only.

title: ARCH 370 Architectural Studies — Expanding the Field
description: Survey of opportunities, specializations, and professions related to architecture provides a resource for professional growth for architecture majors, and introduction to the field for non-majors.

title: ARCH 326 The Modern Movement in Architecture
description: Major theories of modern architecture are presented by studying the work of masters such as: Gropius, Mies van der Rohe, Corbusier, and Kahn.

title: ARCH 316 Place and Culture
description: (Study abroad programs only) Study of the relationships between places and culture through readings, lectures, discussion and weekly field trips.

title: ARCH 341 History of Italian Architecture 1400–1990
description: Introduction to the important buildings, architects and architectural movements in Italy from the Renaissance to the present.

title: CSCI 485 File and Database Management
description: File input/output techniques, basic methods for file organization, file managers, principles of databases, conceptual data models, and query languages.

title: CSCI 476 Cryptography: Secure Communication and Computation
description: Introduction to modern Cryptography; mathematical/algorithmic studies of methods for protecting information in computer and communication systems: Public-Key Cryptosystems, zero-knowledge proofs, data privacy.

title: CSCI 459 Computer Systems and Applications Modeling Fundamentals
description: Techniques and tools needed to construct/evaluate models of computer systems and applications. Analytical and simulation methods, capacity planning, performance/reliability evaluation, and decision-making.

title: CSCI 467 Introduction  to  Machine  Learning
description: Methods for building intelligent and adaptive systems from statistical analyses; theoretical understanding of such methods and the computational implications.

title: CSCI 430 Introduction to Computer and Network Security
description: A broad overview of security threats and defenses, security systems and functionalities, as well as current security practices. Includes homeworks and in-class exercises to provide practical experience working with such systems.

title: CSCI 426 Game Prototyping
description: Developing games or technology based on current and relevant special topics.

title: ARCH 315 Design for the Luminous and Sonic Environment
description: Ideas, problems, and computations related to the design of buildings in response to the luminous and sonic environment.

title: CSCI 423 Native Console Multiplayer Game Development
description: Implementation of AAA style multiplayer game running on consoles and DX11. Console development in native C++, console SDKs, engine components, gameplay, networking, data prediction/replication.

title: ARCH 314 History of Architecture: Contemporary Issues
description: Examination of the buildings, issues and images, the polemics and personalities that are animating current architectural discourse and practice.

title: ARCH 306m Shelter
description: Investigation of issues, processes, and roles of individuals, groups and communities in relation to present and future shelter needs and aspirations.

title: ARCH 307 Digital Tools for Architecture
description: Exploration of digital tools with an emphasis on building information modeling (BIM), parametric modeling, and interoperability including special topics in Architecture/Engineering/Construction (AEC) and sustainable design.

title: ARCH 313 Design of Building Structures
description: Problems and processes of design of building structures; structural investigation for design; codes and standards; design of elements and systems of wood, steel, masonry, and concrete for gravity and lateral loads.

title: ARCH 305bL Building Science II
description: The design of a building as a complex of interacting systems; relations of subsystems; influences of production and marketing on design.

title: ARCH 305aL Building Science II
description: The design of a building as a complex of interacting systems; relations of subsystems; influences of production and marketing on design.

title: ARCH 304x Intensive Survey: Prehistory to the Present
description: An intensive historical overview of architecture from prehistory to the present, emphasizing interrelationships of various global cultures and how social considerations were translated into form.

title: ARCH 303 Principles of Spatial Design I
description: Introduction to design principles and processes; sequence of exercises emphasizing development of basic skills, ideas, and techniques used in the creation of simplified urban space design projects.

title: ARCH 302bL Architectural Design III
description: Special integrative year including design issues relating to housing.

title: ARCH 302aL Architectural Design III
description: Special integrative year including design issues relating to housing.

title: ARCH 220 The Architect's Sketchbook
description: The architect's sketchbook as a portable laboratory for perceiving and documenting space introduces the study of the built environment. On-site sessions develop drawing, observation, and visualization skills.

title: ARCH 215 Design for the Thermal and Atmospheric Environment
description: Ideas, problems, and computations related to the design of buildings in response to the thermal and atmospheric environment; passive solar systems, mechanical control systems.

title: ARCH 214bg World History of Architecture
description: A world-wide perspective of architectural history as a product of social, cultural, religious, and political dimensions, 1500 CE to present.

title: ARCH 214ag World History of Architecture
description: A world-wide perspective of architectural history as a product of social, cultural, religious, and political dimensions, 4500 BCE to 1500 CE.

title: ARCH 213b Building Structures and Seismic Design
description: Investigation and design of structure systems: their resistance to seismic and wind forces and integration with architectural design for synergy of form and structure.

title: ARCH 213a Building Structures and Seismic Design
description: Investigation and design of elements and systems for building structures; applied mechanics, strength of materials, structural investigation as a design tool.

title: ARCH 211 Materials and Methods of Building Construction
description: Basic considerations and design implications of the problem of determination of the materials and construction details and processes for buildings.

title: ARCH 207 Computer Applications in Architecture
description: Introduction for the non-programmer to the uses of the computer in architecture, including the application of existing programs and their implications for design. Overview and use of software types.

title: ARCH 205bL Building Science I
description: The process and communication of building design: physical building shell, systems for structure, enclosure, and space ordering.

title: ARCH 205aL Building Science I
description: The process and communication of building design: physical building shell, systems for structure, enclosure, and space ordering.

title: ARCH 203 Visualizing and Experiencing the Built Environment
description: Methods for direct observation and recording of the directly experienced built environment through drawing, diagramming, photographing, and writing. Course includes exercises and field experience.

title: CSCI 410x Translation of Programming Languages
description: Concepts of assemblers, compilers, interpreters and their design; macro assemblers, Polish notation and translation techniques; operator precedence parsing, push down automata, code generation.

title: CSCI 404 Capstone: Creating Your High-Tech Startup
description: Capstone class in which students create their own technology startup, leveraging comprehensive CS knowledge and best industry practices.

title: CSCI 420 Computer Graphics
description: Computer graphics, OpenGL, 2D and 3D transformations, Bézier splines, computer animation, rendering including ray tracing, shading and lighting, artistic rendering, virtual reality, visualization.

title: CSCI 390 Special Problems
description: Supervised, individual studies. No more than one registration permitted. Enrollment by petition only.

title: CSCI 401 Capstone: Design and Construction of Large Software Systems
description: Group project with an outside stakeholder to develop real-world software solutions to large-scale problems. Topics include software engineering, professional preparation, and recent computer science research.

title: CSCI 402 Operating Systems
description: Concurrency, deadlock control, synchronization, process and thread scheduling, memory management, file systems, security and access control, communication and networking, distributed file systems, data management.

title: CSCI 356 Introduction to Computer Systems
description: Computer organization; entity abstraction and representation; program execution; code optimization; memory usage; exception handling; processing control; computer performance; hands-on work done in C and assembly.

title: CSCI 353 Introduction to Internetworking
description: Global Internet: design principles, layering, protocol design/analysis. Networked applications, Internet structure/architecture, Protocols for transport/congestion control, network layer/routing, link layer/MAC. Network security.

title: CSCI 360 Introduction to Artificial Intelligence
description: Concepts and algorithms underlying the understanding and construction of intelligent systems. Agents, problem solving, search, representation, reasoning, planning, machine learning.

title: CSCI 310 Software Engineering
description: Introduction to the software engineering process and software lifecycle. Covers project management, requirements, architecture, design, implementation, testing, and maintenance phase activities in team based projects.

title: CSCI 281 Pipelines for Games and Interactives
description: Explores the aesthetic development/technical implementation necessary to achieve unique, compelling, intuitive visual design in games. Students will develop group visual game design portfolios.

title: CSCI 350 Introduction to Operating Systems
description: Basic issues in concurrency, deadlock control, synchronization scheduling, memory management, protection and access control, inter-process communication, and structured design. Laboratory experiences with Unix-like operating system. Duplicates credit in CSCI 402.

title: CSCI 270 Introduction to Algorithms and Theory of Computing
description: Algorithm analysis. Greedy algorithms, divide and conquer, dynamic programming, graph algorithms. NP-completeness and basic recursion theory and undecidability. Sorting lower bounds. Number-theory based cryptography.

title: CSCI 201L Principles of Software Development
description: Object-oriented paradigm for programmingin- the-large in Java; writing sophisticated concurrent applications with animation and graphic user interfaces; using professional tools on team project.

title: CSCI 109 Introduction to Computer Science
description: An introduction to, and overview of, Computer Science; both as a discipline and a body of knowledge.

title: CSCI 170 Discrete Methods in Computer Science
description: Sets, functions, series. Big-O notation and algorithm analysis. Propositional and first-order logic. Counting and discrete probability. Graphs and basic graph algorithms. Basic number theory.

title: CSCI 104L Data Structures and Object Oriented Design
description: Introduces the student to standard data structures (linear structures such as linked lists, (balanced) trees, priority queues, and hashtables), using the C++ programming language.

title: CSCI 103L Introduction to Programming
description: Basic datatypes, assignments, control statements (if, switch, for, while), input/output (printf, scanf, cin, cout), functions, arrays, structures, recursion, dynamic memory, file handling. Programming in C/C++.

title: ARCH 202aL Architectural Design II
description: Continuing development of principles and processes; sequence of projects selected to broaden awareness of design issues at various scales in the urban context.

title: ARCH 106x Workshop in Architecture
description: Introduction to the ways architecture is created and understood, for minors and non-majors. Hands-on discussion and laboratory session with some drawing and model building.

title: ARCH 202bL Architectural Design II
description: Continuing development of principles and processes; sequence of projects selected to broaden awareness of design issues at various scales in the urban context.

title: ARCH 114 Architecture: Culture and Community
description: Introduction to the ways architecture represents aspirations of culture, satisfies practical and spiritual needs, shapes the social and urban environment, and helps preserve the planet.

title: ARCH 105L Fundamentals of Design Communication
description: Visual communication techniques applicable to the design of the built environment; drawing, photography, modeling.

title: ARCH 102bL Architectural Design I
description: Introduction to principles and processes; sequence of exercises emphasizing development of basic skills, ideas, and techniques used in the design of simplified architectural projects.

title: ARCH 102a Architectural Design I
description: Introduction to principles and processes; sequence of exercises emphasizing development of basic skills, ideas, and techniques used in the design of simplified architectural projects.

title: ARCG 490x Directed Research
description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

title: CSCI 102L Fundamentals of Computation
description: Fundamental concepts of algorithmic thinking as a primer to programming. Introduction to C++.

title: CSCI 101L Fundamentals of Computer Programming
description: Introduction to the design of solutions to computer solvable problems. Algorithm design, solution implementation using a high-level programming language, program correctness and verification.

title: CSCI 100xg Explorations in Computing
description: A behind-the-scenes overview of the computational/algorithmic principles that form the basis of today's digital society. Exploration areas include social media, web search, videogames and location-based services.

title: CRIT 599 Special Topics
description: Selected topics in various specialty areas of public art.

title: CRIT 594z Master's Thesis
description: Duplicates Credit in former PAS 594abz.

title: CRIT 594b Master's Thesis
description: Duplicates Credit in former PAS 594abz.

title: CRIT 590 Directed Research
description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

title: CRIT 591 Field Internship Experience
description: Supervised internship in an art institution or an art agency, or with an independent curator or artist, on projects and research specific to public space.

title: CRIT 594a Master's Thesis
description: Duplicates Credit in former PAS 594abz.

title: CRIT 557 Curatorial Practicum: Group Project Summation
description: Third in a sequence of three courses on history/theory of curatorial methods, with practical experience necessary to mounting exhibitions and devising interfaces with the public.

title: CRIT 555 Methods of Curating: Introduction to Curatorial Practicum
description: First in a sequence of three courses on history/theory of curatorial methods, with practical experience necessary to mounting exhibitions and devising interfaces with the public.

title: CRIT 556 Curatorial Practicum: Individual/Group Projects
description: Second in a sequence of three courses on history/theory of curatorial methods, with practical experience necessary to mounting exhibitions and devising interfaces with the public.

title: CRIT 512 Art and Curatorial Visits
description: Site visits relating to art and curatorial practices, from art museums and artists' studios to public art offices and performance venues, and meet professionals.

title: CRIT 499 Special Topics
description: Comprehensive exploration of particular aspects of public art.

title: CRIT 510 History and Theory of Art and Exhibitions
description: Gives broad and deep overview of history of "art" as a conceptual and practical category, emphasizing development of exhibitionary sites and engagement with public sphere.

title: CRIT 450 Visual Culture in Southern California: Images in and of the City
description: Exploration of the relationships among art, design, visual culture, urban spaces and institutions, through urban, social, and visual theory.

title: CRIT 445 Art in the Public Realm
description: Focuses on contemporary artistic and design practices in relation to questions of the public sphere and audience, addressing topics from public art to social practice.

title: ARCG 308 Techniques and Issues in 3D Imaging and Modeling
description: In-depth exploration of applications, techniques and standards involved in stereoscopic imaging and photogrammetric modeling.

title: ARCG 306L Maritime Archaeology Survey and Technology
description: Introduction to the use of remote sensing technologies for underwater archaeology, mapping and research on submerged cultural heritage remains whether ancient sites or sunken ships.

title: CRIT 440 Exhibition and Museum Histories
description: History and theory of curating, exhibitions, and museums, critically examining the historical structures and current politics informing contemporary practices and institutions.

title: ARAB 352 Advanced Arabic II
description: Duplicates Credit in former MDES 352.

title: ARAB 334 Media Arabic
description: Introduction and development of language skills encountered in print and broadcast media Arabic.

title: ARAB 322 Advanced Arabic I
description: Advanced expression in written and spoken Arabic, including reading of original texts, understanding different registers, and exposure to modern Arabic cultures.

title: ARAB 300 Introduction to Translation
description: Introduces students to the fundamentals of Arabic-English translation and offers analytical, linguistic and cross-cultural factors affecting interpreting and translation.

title: ARAB 252 Arabic IV
description: Continuation of Arabic III. Continued development of speaking, listening, reading, and writing skills in Modern Standard Arabic.

title: ARAB 222 Arabic III
description: Intermediate Modern Standard Arabic. Continued development of speaking, listening, reading, and writing skills.

title: ARAB 333 Colloquial Arabic: Regional Dialects
description: Introduction to a regional Arabic dialect, focusing primarily on verbal skills.

title: ARAB 122 Arabic I
description: Introduction to Modern Standard Arabic: Development of speaking, listening, reading, and writing skills in contemporary cultural contexts.

title: ANTH 794z Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: ARAB 152 Arabic II
description: Duplicates Credit in former MDES 152.

title: CRIT 430 Undergrounds and Avant-Gardes in Film and Visual Culture
description: Study of theories of critique or resistance in art and cultural studies, particularly in relation to developments in contemporary art, design, and/or popular culture.

title: CRIT 435 Artists' Magazines as Alternative Spaces
description: Histories of art and/or design from alternative points of view, exposing the limits of conventional histories of art and design.

title: CRIT 425 Identity and Visual Representation
description: A critical study of the relationship between identity or coalitional politics and specific practices, meanings, and sitings of contemporary art and design.

title: CRIT 420 The Artist in History and Popular Culture
description: Addresses relationships among contemporary art, design, and popular culture, with a focus on specific visual media and their histories.

title: CRIT 371 Art in the Public Realm: Contemporary Issues
description: Critical frameworks and theoretical perspectives of contemporary public art issues explored through case studies and discussions with artists, architects, and designers engaging the public realm.

title: CRIT 410 Deconstruction in Design
description: Addresses overlapping issues in contemporary design and art relating to activism, audience, and technologies of making and dissemination.

title: CRIT 160g Critical Theory in Art, Design and Visual Culture
description: An issues-based introduction to critical theory in the twentieth and twenty-first centuries, especially as it relates to philosophy, art, design, and visual culture.

title: CRIT 415 Event, Action, and Situation: Performance Art since 1960
description: The role of the body, performance, action, and the question of the "event" in contemporary art and design.

title: CRIT 350gw Global Art, Design and Visual Culture since 1960
description: A critical history of art, design, visual culture, and visual theory since 1960, addressing through a postcolonial/decolonial lens the concepts and practices of "global" art.

title: CRIT 150gp Histories of Art, Design and Visual Culture
description: A loosely chronological, thematic survey of art, visual culture, design, and critical theory from the early modern period through modernism (1500 – 1950).

title: CORE 499 Special Topics
description: Intensive interdisciplinary exploration of a selected theme, problem process, or period.

title: CORE 601 Teaching Analytical Writing Through Readings in the Humanities
description: Theories and practices in the university-level teaching of close-reading and analytical writing, using texts central to Western tradition. Graduate student professionalism through topical workshops and discussions.

title: CORE 450 Los Angeles: A Polymathic Inquiry
description: A guided polymathic inquiry into Los Angeles as fact and imaginative creation, featuring in-depth student research and projects.

title: ANTH 794b Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: ANTH 794c Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: ANTH 794a Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: ANTH 794d Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: ANTH 790 Research
description: Research leading to the doctorate. Minimum 8 units, maximum number of units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

title: ANTH 650 Seminar in Ethnography and Interpretation
description: A seminar where issues in contemporary ethnography and interpretation are discussed, grouped around a theme of current concern, such as power and resistance, colonialism, Marxist approaches, feminism, etc.

title: ANTH 606 Seminar on Nationalism and Ethnicity
description: Cross-cultural analysis of nationalism and ethnicity from an ethnographic perspective.

title: ANTH 605 Race: Performance, Politics, Cultural Production
description: Focuses on the performance and social construction of race and its intersection with gender, sexuality, class, place, nation and empire.

title: ANTH 604 Bodies and Practices
description: The cultural construction of body image, embodied practice, race, sexuality and healing.

title: ANTH 603 Experiments in Ethnographic Writing
description: The problems of representation involved in rendering experience into narrative are examined in a number of contemporary "experiments."

title: ANTH 601 Feminist Issues in Anthropology
description: Feminist concerns in both Western and Non-Western societies are examined in relation to globalization; the practice of ethnography and issues of power.

title: ANTH 594z Master's Thesis
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: ANTH 599 Special Topics
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: ANTH 594b Master's Thesis
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: CORE 401x Ethics and Leadership
description: Debates concerning moral and cultural ethics in a globalizing world; paradigms of leadership, ethical conduct, moral courage, and humanitarianism.

title: CORE 400 Capstone
description: Guided study of select works of classical literature in relation to contemporary issues and concerns. Capstone for minor in Classical Perspectives.

title: CORE 301 Modes of Inquiry
description: Modern tools of cultural and discursive analysis which seek to demystify "the natural," as it appears in the formation of cultures, their institutions, and individuals.

title: CORE 112 Writing Seminar II: Thematic Option Honors Program
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: CORE 195 Summer Seminar
description: An honors course for high school students in summer; each section focuses on a topic in the arts or humanities, social or natural sciences.

title: CORE 111 Writing Seminar I: Thematic Option Honors Program
description: Instruction Mode: Lecture

title: CORE 200 Liberal Arts Reading Salon
description: Critical readings of a series of texts in the liberal arts designed to promote discussion of important themes, theoretical approaches, research directions, and interdisciplinary connections.

title: ANTH 594a Master's Thesis
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: CORE 104gw Change and the Future: Thematic Option Honors Program
description: Analysis of historical change; social and political theory and revolutionary thought; introduction to competing images of future states of affairs; the continuing process of change.

title: CORE 103g The Process of Change in Science: Thematic Option Honors Program
description: Critical problems in the development of scientific thought, studied as vehicles for understanding the content and structure of the sciences. Specific subject matter in selected scientific disciplines will be presented.

title: CORE 102gp Culture and Values: Thematic Option Honors Program
description: Systematic reasoning about values and ways of living; close reading of major texts within the Western tradition; Biblical and classical through contemporary sources.

title: COMM 794z Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: CORE 101g Symbols and Conceptual Systems: Thematic Option Honors Program
description: Study of the structures through which we shape our experience in religion, philosophy, literature, music, and the visual arts, and of competing theories of interpretation.

title: COMM 794d Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: COMM 794c Doctoral Dissertation
description: Grading Option: In-progress to Credit/No Credit

title: COMM 662 Video Games Research
description: History and content, motivation and selection, reception and reaction processes, and effects of video games; students conduct original research into video game usage and effects.

title: COMM 660 Entertainment and Games
description: Contemporary meaning of "entertainment," historical and cultural developments of entertainment; entertainment as psychological process of responding to/interacting with various media.

title: COMM 656 Theorizing Race, Culture, Cross-Cultural Exchange
description: Intersection of communication and culture; focus on race, ethnicity, interracial and intraracial relations in shaping political, social dynamics of U.S. in late 20th and early 21st centuries.

title: COMM 655 Studies in Sound, Music and Communication
description: An introduction to listening as a methodology of critical practice. Key topics in the study and interpretation of sound and music as forms of communication.
